Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 18:22:18 -0700 (PDT)
From: "C.B.Godwin" <cbgodwin@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944 motor mount replacement?

On 30 Jun 1995 SCHULZ_BILL@Tandem.COM wrote:

> I have the need to replace the motor mounts on my '87 944 and I have purchased
> 2 new ones (turbo style).  I had been given a great "blow by blow" document by
> Karl Haug with instructions on how to accomplish this job but I've managed to
> misplace it.  I have the Haynes manual (ONE picture!) and consider myself a
> "fair" home mechanic.
> 
> QUESTION: Does this fall into the catagory of "don't try this at home"?  Are
> there any "gottchas" I should be aware of?  Can this be done using the usual
> ramps to raise the car?
> 
> Any opinions, encouragements, and/or discouragements welcomed.
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Bill
> 
> '87 944 (YELLOW, 35K, daily driver)
> schulz_bill@tandem.com
> 
 
Hi Bill, I have an 85.5 944 and replaced the engine mounts myself. All I 
used in the way of tools was car ramps and a floor jack, I also had a 
engine hoist but you could get away with just the trolley jack if you do 
not have access to one. The Hanes manual talks about removing stabalizer 
bars and suspension stuff, I looked at it from a different angle. I 
removed and installed both mounts from the top. I did remove the arms 
that connect to the engine and mounts. The job only took an evening to 
do. Good luck.  

Charles Godwin	cbgodwin@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca

ago - approx 16K miles since - 6K miles last 5 years.  Interior in super

original seats.  Carpet is near perfect, and original.  Lousy stereo system,
but I always preferred the sound of the engine, and never used it.  It is air
conditioned, and it works!  Blood orange paint is 80 point quality, and is
mostly original.  RS front and rear bumpers, with good originals (rear only)
in storage.  ATS factory wheels (cookie cutters), in very nice condition.
 All mechanicals and electricals function normally, and the motor is VERY
strong.  The following items new within the last 2 years (about 2000 miles):
 all calipers (new, not rebuilt) and pads, factory muffler, air box w/pop
valve, A-008R's.  Body is exceptional and straight.  I've owned this guy for
5 years, and really hate to part with it, but will not have enough garage
space for everything.  Have pictures, if really interested.  Best offer
around $9,000, and I'll put it in storage rather than give it away.  Pat
Garvey (606)331-8810, or e-mail.

Date: Sat, 01 Jul 1995 00:13:54 EDT
From: AWJK94A@prodigy.com ( DREW SPENCER)
Subject: Re: Wandering C2.....ain't fixed  but go



Hi Steve,

As someone else already mentioned, corner balancing wouldn't hurt.  The
C2's are pretty easy to corner balance because of the threaded perches
on the coil-overs (at least with the M030).  You should not need short
springs just to get the car's ride height adjusted to properly.

It would be interesting to find out what kind of camber and caster
specs the mechanics were using to set it up.

Also, you mention a "front-end" alignment only?  If the rear alignment
wasn't checked as well and the mechanic is trying to sell you
lowering springs, you may want to consider another mechanic.

Drew
Drew Spencer (aka awjk94a@prodigy.com)
'93 RS America
'82 911 SC

Date: Sat, 01 Jul 1995 00:13:43 EDT
From: AWJK94A@prodigy.com ( DREW SPENCER)
Subject: Re: '92 RS America??



The RS America that was used in the press tour was guards red with
sunroof and radio, but w/o A/C (as far as I can discern from the photo
in the Jan '93 issue of Your-a-pee'n Car).  This is also the same car
that appeared on cover of the December '92 Panorama.

If this is the press tour car, it might have some additional collector
value, but it also was probably thrashed pretty well by the press corps.
If this is the car, Be sure to check out the condition of the clutch
and transmission first.  R&T and C&D probably beat the hell out of it
doing 5K clutch drops trying to see who could get the fastest 0-60
times...;-).  Or maybe that was Autoweek...Pete?


Good luck,
Drew
Drew Spencer (aka awjk94a@prodigy.com)
'93 RS America
'82 911 SC

can take of the bucking. I am thinking of pulling the fuel
injection,computer,bloody afc and whatever else I can get my hands on and
putting on a couple of carbs. This would seem the more economical solution.
So far I have a new coil,cylinder sensor, points,plugs,distributer and air
box. This didn't help and most of the folks that have put in their two cents
around here have given up. When it reaches that critical running temperature
it craps out and there's nudda can be done about it soooo I'm wonderin' how
much it would cost to try and set myself up with a couple of solex carbs and
ditchin' the electronics. It would seem this would be the best solution if I
want to ever hit the road this year.

Porschephiles #1522                         Sat Jul 1 21:31:58 CDT 1995
Date: Sat, 1 Jul 1995 02:01:50 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1517 Thu Jun 29 18:58:52 CDT 1995

Jeff Kyle (jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com) wrote: 

>Deathtrap? Hey, that's my baby you're talking about! :)

    Kitty Menendez probably said the same thing about each of her
    sons...

>Perhaps I should rephrase. The spring is connected to the motor and to
>another arm that comes out of the same shaft that the throttle is 
>attached to, but they're not connected. With the car running, I've 
>moved this other arm, and it doesn't seem to affect anything... Any 
>idea what it's supposed to do?

    Oh.  Sorry, Jeff... I misunderstood and thought that one end of the
    spring was simply disconnected.

    From what I remember of my 914's engine in its pre-6 days, the
    throttle valve shaft has a stack of about a dozen parts on it.
    One piece is the arm to which your throttle cable is attached.
    It's firmly fixed to the shaft; it has a square hole that fits on
    the square shaft.

    Next to it is this other arm you're talking about, to which the
    throttle-return spring is connected.  THIS arm has a round hole, so
    it's basically free to rotate on the square throttle-valve shaft
    (or, more accurately, on a round bushing).  In order for it to
    apply spring-return force to the throttle, it has a little hook
    that fits into a notch in the first arm.

    Sounds as though the last guy who messed with your throttle put the
    pieces together incorrectly, so that the hook on the return-spring
    arm isn't captured by the notch in the throttle-cable arm.  Because
    the return-spring arm is free to rotate, it can't exert any force
    on the throttle-cable arm.

    This is BAD; it means that the only return force you're getting is
    from the secondary spring that's also mounted (coaxially) on the
    shaft, but which has probably rusted and broken by now, or is
    missing, or was ALSO installed incorrectly.

    Take your throttle-valve shaft assembly apart (there's just one nut
    on the end that basically holds it all together), replace the
    secondary spring if it's broken (its ends hook onto two OTHER hooks
    on the two arms), and re-align the two arms so that the
    return-spring arm's hook fits into the notch on the throttle-cable
    arm.

    Let me know how this goes... Like I said, it's been a while since I
    looked at a 4-cylinder 914 motor, so some of the details are a
    little fuzzy.

    -Andy

    P.S.  Hope you don't mind my copying this to the list...

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

My thanks for the patience and *Generosity* of those of you who sent your
checks, and have been waiting for me to get off my duff and get them in
the bank.  (Does "get off my duff" bit this sound familiar...?"

Since the last report, we've added $450 in new deposits, and we now have 
$8,347 in the Bank (we're getting 5% interest, so we actually have a few more 
pennies than that).  Oh Yeah, 156 of us care enough to pony up the old "hard
earned."

It gives me great pleasure to join you all in offering our special thanks
to Steve Poole and Pat Moyle, our newest Patrons!  Thanks, guys, for and from 
all of us!

Did I mention that it's easy for anyone to take advantage of our easy
upgrade policy, to join the exhaulted rank of Patron, merely by sending
another check to bring your total up to $100 (or *more*, if the spirit
moves...)

Date: Sat, 1 Jul 1995 10:01:48 -0400
From: "H.Shrikumar" <shri@eternity.cs.umass.edu>
Subject: Larry Dunlap's  924-VW-Audi Compatibility List.


Hi,

Here is Larry Dunlap's compilation of the 924-VW-Audi parts
compatibility list.

Please mail all suggestions and updates to him (Larry Dunlap) at:
          bgz9143@dcro2.dcro.dla.mil

Larry .. thanx so much for finding the time to forward me a copy of the
list. Also my sincere best wishes to your mother.


- -- Shrikumar

'82 924 and a HP 100lx

shri@cs.umass.edu    ------+ Qua!-lx - cc:Mail<->Unix g/w for HP100lx/200lx
shri@shakti.ncst.ernet.in  | ftp://eddie.mit.edu/pub/hp95lx/NEW/qualx13.zip
X.400: G=Shrikumar S=Hariharasubrahmanian P=itu A=arcom C=CH --------------+



>From: bgz9143@dcro2.dcro.dla.mil (Larry Dunlap)
Subject: The List!
To: shri@cs.umass.edu
Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 09:58:45 -0400 (EDT)


Sorry for the delay, was busy at work, had a couple of road-trips, then
my brother came home from Europe for a couple of weeks so we had some
major goofing off to do.  Anyway, here is the list.

It is broken down into 2 sections:  Specifics and Generals.  

Specfics lists items and their inter- changeability with a specific
car/year.  Generals lists items that I have found references to, but
have not yet checked out exact appilications.  The generals sections is
also by groups of items/cars.  So anything within one of the "groups"
is/should be interchangeable with the "group" of cars in the same
block, not just the cars listed on that line!

Also take all of this with a grain of salt, I tried to be as accurate
as possible, but beware...      Hope it helps!

                                               -Larry

******************************************************************************

                       VW/AUDI/PORSCHE  Cross References

Specifics:

Front Struts              VW SuperBeetle
Front Wishbones           VW Golf
Semi-Trailing Arms        VW SuperBeetle
Steering Components       VW Golf
Front Disk Brakes         Audi 100
Rear Drum Brakes          VW SuperBeetle
Oil Filter                Audi 5000
Radiator                  Audi 5000 turbo (?)
Timing Belt Tensioner     Audi 4 cylinders
Thermostat "O" ring       Audi 100, 4000, fox
Timing Belt               Audi 5000 1984-on
Water Pump Gaskets        Audi/VW with "B" pumps (?)
Fuel Distributor 77-79    Audi 100 LS   75-77
Warm-up Regulator         Audi Fox  75-78
Auxiliary Air Valve       Audi 100 LS 75-77, Audi 5000  81-on
Fuel Injector 80-82       Audi 4000, Audi 5000 thru 83
Clutch Disk               Audi 4000  80-83
Presssure Plate           Audi 100 LS 75-77, Audi 4000
Release Bearing           Audi 100 LS
Clutch Cable              Audi 100  71-74
Alternator                Audi 4000S  80-82, Audi 5000 78-82, 100LS  75-77
Ignition Coil 77-80       Audi 100LS  75-77, Audi 5000 77-80
Ignition Coil 81-82       Audi 4000, Audi 5000 80-84
CD Ignition Unit 76-80    Audi 5000 78-80
CD Ignition Unit 81-82    Audi 4000, Audi 5000 Quattro 80-84
Starter                   Audi 5000 78-79, Audi 5000 turbo, Quattro 81-82
Head Gaskets              Audi 100

******************************************************************************
Generals:

For the "generals" section, I have found references to these
parts, but haven't found specific information on car/year....

The engine used in the 76-82 924 was the same engine used in
the Audi 100, VW Van, and AMC Gremlin!!  So, Most engine
parts from those will interchange.

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Timing Belt Sprocket          VW Van
Timing Belt Tensioner         Audi 4000/5000/100
Timing Belt                   AMC Gremlin
- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Clutch Disk               
Pressure Plate                Audi 4000/Fox
Throw-out Bearing             VW Quantum/Dasher
Clutch Cable
- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Parking Brake                 VW Quantum/Dasher
Rear DISK Brakes              Audi 4000S/Quattro
- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Front Brakes and Suspension   Audi 4000
Master Cylinder               VW Quantum/Dasher
                              VW Rabbit/Jetta/Scirrocco
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Heater Core/Heater Valve
CIS Injection Components      VW Rabbit/Jetta/Scirrocco
Fuel Pump/Accumulator
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Oxygen Sensor                 VW 81 & later
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Half Shafts                   VW Quantum/Dasher
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Wiper Switch
Wiper Relay                   VW Rabbit/Jetta/Scirrocco
Wiper Motor
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------








------------------------------

Date: Sat, 1 Jul 1995 10:16:32 -0400
From: "H.Shrikumar" <shri@eternity.cs.umass.edu>
Subject: Digest: 924 Odometer fix.


Hi everybody,

Here is a collection of mail I received on HOWTO fix a broken odometer
on a 924.  Apparently very often the odometer is not really "broken"
but just has a slip-disc.

+------------
 Moral: 
 On a 924, NEVER DEPRESS TRIP-RESET UNLESS YOU ARE COMPLETELY AT REST.
+------------

I have two mails : 
First a HOWTO written by Larry Dunlap (Mail suggestions and updates to
him at  bgz9143@dcro2.dcro.dla.mil)
Followed by another mail that is apparently by Gary Cook.

My sincere thanx to Larry and Greg for forwarding these to me.


- -- Shrikumar

'82 924 and HP 100lx

shri@cs.umass.edu    ------+ Qua!-lx - cc:Mail<->Unix g/w for HP100lx/200lx
shri@shakti.ncst.ernet.in  | ftp://eddie.mit.edu/pub/hp95lx/NEW/qualx13.zip
X.400: G=Shrikumar S=Hariharasubrahmanian P=itu A=arcom C=CH --------------+



- ---------------------------------
>From: bgz9143@dcro2.dcro.dla.mil (Larry Dunlap)
Subject: odometer fix!
Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 11:25:23 -0400 (EDT)


Hey Guys,

Sorry for the delay.  I've been out of the office and had some family problems,
(Mom's got cancer), and had some family in visiting so, I haven't gotten
much done lately.  Anyway the fix for the odometer is pretty easy to do,
I must have fixed about a half-dozen already.  So here goes:

1.  Remove steering wheel

2.  Remove plastic gaurds and turn signal/wiper arms.  Should come out as
    a unit.

3.  Uuscrew the holding screws for the instrument cluster, but don't remove
    it yet.

4.  Open hood, locate speedometer cable coming from left front wheel and,
    push all the slack through the firewall.  Rather easy, most probably
    will get your hands dirty.

5.  Now pull out instrument cluster.  It won't come out completely, but it
    will give you enough room to get a pair of channel locks on the speedometer
    cable "nut"  It is a silver knurled circular assembly.  Just grab with
    channel locks and turn, it'll come off pretty easy.

6.  Remove wiring from back of speedometer cable.  I wouldn't worry about
    labeling everything, stuff only goes in one place.

7.  Press the speedometer cable forward, out of the instrument cluster.

   >From bgz9143@dcro2.dcro.dla.mil Tue Jun 13 13:05:18 1995
   >Subject: odometer fix! Correction.
   >
   >7.  Press the speedometer forward, out of the instrument cluster.
   >    Not the cable!!


8.  With a small flat blade screwdriver, start prying up the black metal
    bezel on the back lip of the front of the unit.  Keep prying until you
    get more than 50% of the circumfrence done.  The plexiglass bezel will
    then just lift off.

9.  Unscrew the few screws on the back of the unit, this will allow you
    to remove the assembly from the housing.  

10. Holding the assembly, so that the speedometer face is pointing away from
    you, on the left side, you will see a small gear that sits on top of a worm     gear.  That gear has slid either inside or outside of the worm gear.  
    gear has slid either inside or outside of the worm gear. 
    Push/Pull  the gear until it sits squarely on top of the worm gear.             That's all there is to it.  

11. Put the assembly back in the housing, put the screws back in and set the
    plexiglass bezel back on.  Put the black band on over the lip. turn the
    assembly over and start pressing the lip back down that you pryed up.
    If you take your time and are careful not to scratch the front of the 
    black ring, it will be invisible from the front when your done.

12. Put the rest of it back together.  Before putting the instrument cluster
    back in, if you have any blown dash lights, now is the time to replace
    them!  Don't forget to pull the speedometer cable slack back into the
    engine compartment.


All told, it should take you less than an hour to do.  And the big tip is,
NEVER, EVER push the trip odometer button while the car is moving.  And I
mean moving!  Don't touch that damn thing unless the car is at an absolute
stand still!  Even if your barely moving, it's enough to cause that gear to
"pop" off again.  This is experience talking now!  If you have any other
questions drop me a line!


                                                        -Larry

ldunlap@dcro.dla.mil
1984 944
1979 924
Cleveland, Ohio
(216) 522-6859 work
(216) 937-5122 home


- ---------------------------------
>From GASKILL@rerw.wpafb.af.mil Tue Jun 13 10:07:38 1995
Subject: Congratulations


I noticed in your last post to the pfiles your purchase.  Congratulations 
and best wishes.  I also noticed you mentioned the "obligatory" cracked dash 
(me too, don't use Armor All), split seat cover (me too, passenger seat) and 
you mentioned your speedometer wasn't working.  Mine too, but I just got it 
fixed a week or so ago.  I have some postings on the subject.  I'll attach 
the one which was the most help and comfort.  I needed to know what I was 
looking at for a repair bill.  It turned out to be the cable from the wheel 
to the EGR counter box.    $78 parts and labor.  See note below.  I also 
know of a place to repair speedometers here in Dayton OH if it turns out to 
be a bad speedo.

Greg



It is a mechanical failure.  Either a broken cable or broken
speedometer.  How to determine the failure?  Remove the speedometer and
see if the cable turns when you drive the car.  Also, you should be
able to spin the input of the speedometer to see if the needle jumps.

The cable is driven off the left fron wheel.  The cable is in two
sections, at least on most 924's, because there is a box that
drives the counter for the 02 service indicator.  If yours is
an old 924 without the 02 light, the cable may run directly from
the front wheel.  If yours does have a 2 piece cable, there should
be a black box attached inside the engine compartment on the left
front wheel well.

In any case, you can check it by removing the speedometer.  The three
instruments just push out from the rear.  The easiest method I've found
is to reach up from under the dash and push out the tach first.  The
speedometer is hard to access from the rear since it is directly above
the steering column.  You can then use the tach opening to disconnect
the speedometer cable push out the speedometer.

You should be able to locate a used speedometer very cheap.  Partsheaven
in Hayward California (510-782-0358) probably has one and can ship ups.
If you want to do the cable, they can probably assist with a used one.
You can buy repair kits that consist of just the center rotating section
too.

>From an ex-924 Turbo owner..  An glad.  :^)

Gary W. Cook                    Director of Technical Services
Minicomputer Exchange, Inc.     610 North Pastoria Avenue
Sunnyvale, CA  94086            Email: gary@mce.com
Tel: 408-733-4400               Fax: 408-733-8009

Date: Sat, 1 Jul 1995 16:15:56 +0000 (GMT)
From: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
Subject: Re: exhaustnuts

Use either stainless steel hex nuts with stainless shakeproof washers, or 
stainless steel all-metal locknuts (sometimes called Kaynor nuts after a
major manufacturer).  Use some 'Silver Goop' as a thread lub (available 
from Swagelok fitting distributors), or other similar silver-based compound.

Actually you can also get get these aerospace-style locknuts with either a 
molydisulfide or silver coating, so that the thread lub is not needed.
- -- 
Wayne Flowers                 Voice:  505-678-8303
Senior Scientist              Fax:    505-678-6049
Science & Technology Corp.    E-mail: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
White Sands, New Mexico       URL:    http://aprf.arl.mil/

Date: Sat, 1 Jul 1995 16:54:36 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : 911 Ride Height Adjust. Que

Mike Dayton (MLBDayton@aol.com) asked :

>I adjusted the rear ride height of my 911 as a result of
>putting some Koni shocks on a few weeks ago.  The Konis
>actually lifted the rear of my car about 14mm (hence the
>need for adjustment).  Anyway, the whole task was pretty
>easy (thanks to a comment Mike Piera(?) made).  I 
>needed to rotate the torsion bar relative to the spring
>plate, but since I have the Sway-a-way adjustable spring
>plates, I only took the "outer" part off and left the main
>part of it bolted to the banana arm.  My quandary is that
>due to the way the thing came apart, I rotated the inner
>end of the torsion bar on one side and the outer end on
>the other.  If I'm not mistaken this results in a difference
>side to side of about 0 degrees 50 minutes.  I was able
>to easily level the car using the spring plate adjustment
>screws, and it seems that ride height is a function of
>"torque" on the torsion bar, so even though I have this
>slight initial difference in geometry, everything should
>be OK, right?

Basically, if your car was corner balanced before you adjusted
the rear height, and it was level (left and right rears at the
same height) then as long as it is level now you are fine.
It does not matter which spline you are on, the "torque"
on the torsion bar and resulting ride height is what matters.
You probably have more sway-away adjustment screw sticking up 
on one side than the other to make them even.

But I find it strange that you were able to lower the rear about
14mm by moving a whole spline on the bar. I think that a whole
spline (rather than a partial spline done by turning the inner end
spline one way and the outer end spline the other way) will change the
ride height about 2" or so. When I first got my car I did calculations
that would make Byron proud ;) to see if I could lower it one spline.
I tried it and blistered the paint off my fender at Lime Rock because
it was too low.

There seems to be some black magic involved in the rear torsion bars
(so calculations with our modern science will not work). I still have 
problems balancing them after all these years. I tried to raise 
my Right Rear a bit for weight balance recently. I did the MINIMUM
adjustment : rotated the inner and outer ends in opposite directions
(no sway away spring plates this year - illegal in SCCA Solo-II stock).
It seemed to raise the RR too much, now that corner is too heavy. It
seems that the range of adjustment is not small enough to really
corner balance a car within 5-10 pounds. Maybe my mojo was missing? Anyone
know the minimum adjustment?

Regards, Mike Piera '72S & '73E 911 Targas, '73 914/2.0 AnalogMike@aol.com

Date: Sat, 1 Jul 1995 17:27:34 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re:Wandering C-2

Bill says, "... did you check that the tires are pointing in the right
direction?  
I had some work done on my wheels and suspension last fall and, when I got it
back from the shop, the car was all over the road.  It was kind of fun, but
not
quite what I was looking for.  Turns out the right rear tire was installed
backwards so the tread was pointing the wrong way."

Not as improbable as it may sound, Bill.  I've gotten mine back from a
supposedly reputable shop with the rear wheels mounted on the front (wrong
width, wrong offset for the front)!  Although I have a shop now that knows
what they're doing, I still watch my tire rotations to see that the tire ends
up on the proper wheel and the wheel ends up on the proper corner.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S (with directional RE71s)

Date: Sat, 1 Jul 1995 17:46:51 -0400
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: 68 911S

Among other things, you wrote - 

>The mechanical fuel injection was rebuilt about 5,000 miles ago.<

Since the first S w/mech injection was 1969, my guess is the car you're
looking at is an early 1969, hence, long wheel base, 911S. If you can post
the SN's of both the car and the engine, I'll look them up for you. It was
probably sold in late 68 and titled as a 68 car.

Also, while the 68 911S was only delivered to the European market, some have
found their way to the US, but they had Weber 40 IDS carbs, not mech FI.

Good luck,

Phil Van Buskirk, PMLetter@aol.com

Date: Sat, 1 Jul 1995 18:14:59 -0700
From: "Volney Spalding" <vol@espresso.corp.sgi.com>
Subject: Computer and Car fans rejoice!

FYI...  Don't miss this month's edition of Automobile Magazine wherein
Robert Cumberford waxes eloquently about the wonders of CAD wrt designing
Cars.  He happens to be really jazzed about a specific SGI machine,
but that's not the point ;^)  The point is that a few months back he
wrote about how evil computers are and how they are threatening to take
all the creativity and romance out of designing cars... He even suggested
we are all sentenced to a life of dull, efficiently designed cars with
the only key metric involved being cycle time--leaving no room for art.

When we read that article our first thought was:  "This man has never seen
anything analyzed, designed or tested in 3D or he wouldn't think that way".
Of course we happen to be biased around here.

To make a long story short, suddenly Cumberford thinks computers are
amazing and can't wait to design something with one :-)  Watch Automobile
for his progress and realtime impressions...

Vol

vol@sgi.com
415.390.2879

Date: Sun, 02 Jul 1995 08:55:55 -0500 (cdt)
From: zwerner@RoseVC.Rose-Hulman.Edu
Subject: 73 1/2 ride height & shocks?

OK, I finally got my 18 yr old KBY pressurized gas shocks replaced ( they
were really in good shape, only had about 3000 mi on them when I put the
car up!!)  with new Koni hydraulics.

 After sitting for this long, I found that the ride height measured 26in
at rear fender lip, and 27.5 in at FRONT!!!  I felt that the gas had
caused the chassis to rise.  After  beating my car around the back roads
for about 500 mi., nothing changed!!  The Konis resulted in about a 1/2 in
drop. I,ve only drived it for about 50mi, but I don't think it will change
much!!

What do I have to do to drop it back to normal ride height?? The front
doesn't seem to difficult, but the rear is sort of hard to understand in
the shop manual. I should't have to do anything with the torsion bars???
I'm just trying to get back to factory height... Nothing has been done to
the chassis before, and it came with Konis. I thought that over time the
torsion bars and bushings will wear and the ride height will become
lower?? I checked the sway-bars and they're not binding. Any info on
desired alignment specs for my chassis specialists?

     Any suggestions???
                                                  thanks

                               Paul Zwerner

Subject: The constant drip, drip,drip

I am looking for helpful hints on replacing the rubber section of fuel line
that runs from the fuel rail to the metal line that runs all the way back to
the fuel pump. The rubber line under the hood is crimped to  the metal line,
the metal line runs through the wheel well then turns underbody back under
the torsion bar and to the fuel pump. It appears as though the rear
suspension needs to be partialy dissasembled to remove the line!  There must
be a better way, i am not sure if there is enough room between the wheel
well and the head to try to cut and thread the metal line.

Any insights would be greatly appreciated.

Date: Sun, 2 Jul 1995 13:09:17 -0400
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Re: 912 History

Bob:

Your reflection of 912/911 price differential being less than 25 percent is
correct.

The prices for 1969 Porsches of interest (MSRP/Dealer Cost) in the summer of
1969 were as follows:

912   Coupe-4 Speed ($5235/$4382)
911T Coupe-4 Speed ($6060/$5077)

You could really "kick this up" by adding the 5-speed to either
($69.55/$57.95). How about a 911S coupe for ($7970/$6636) !!!

The 912 was still "big bucks" in price comparison to a new Corvette T-Top
Coupe ($4926/$3884).

Perry

Date: Sun, 2 Jul 1995 13:40:21 -0500
From: Johnny.Miller@i-link.net (Johnny Miller)
Subject: Shaky Wheel Thanks

Just wanted to thank all who replied to my shaky steering wheel.

I started by swapping the tires on the left side of the car.  Not much
change. Possibly even worse.  I switched them back.  Next I switched the
tires on the right side.  Ooo!  That's it!  I lived for over a year with
this problem and it only took 5 minutes to fix. Arrrgh!

Thanks for the ideas!

                Johnny Miller

    Total                     $493          $480


Overall a small saving by changing companies.

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 2 Jul 1995 15:48:13 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: The constant drip, drip,drip

At 12:30 PM 7/2/95 -0400, Lyle Tolhurst wrote:
>I am looking for helpful hints on replacing the rubber section of fuel line
>that runs from the fuel rail to the metal line that runs all the way back to
>the fuel pump. The rubber line under the hood is crimped to  the metal line,
>the metal line runs through the wheel well then turns underbody back under
>the torsion bar and to the fuel pump. It appears as though the rear
>suspension needs to be partialy dissasembled to remove the line!  There must
>be a better way, i am not sure if there is enough room between the wheel
>well and the head to try to cut and thread the metal line.

Lyle,

>From the who's who, I learn that you have a MY86 951.  This car had a service
campaign to replace, gratis, the fuel delivery line you describe.  You should
learn from your dealer whether or not this has been done to your car.

In any event, you need to replace the hose *NOW*, before you have a parts
car and/or one less member in your immediate family (you).  If you absolutely
have to drive the car to whoever will replace the hose, do the following.  Put
a small hose clamp on the fuel hose so that it abuts the crimped end at the
rail.  This will tighten the rubber hose against the inside metal sleeve
of the fitting.

It would be safer for you to have the car towed, and I'd recommend that.

Both the supply and return hoses run from the rail to the rigid lines at
the right front wheel well.  At the point they enter the well, you can see
that each has a fitting which can be opened to replace just the hose.  You
really need to use a flare nut wrench here, because there is not enough
"height" to the fitting to loosen or tighten it with, say, a flat wrench
without trashing the fittings.

Kevin

Date: Sun, 2 Jul 1995 21:02:10 -0400
From: ltolh@gate.net (Lyle Tolhurst)
Subject: Re: The constant drip, drip,drip

Kevin, thank you for your quick responce. 
I have taken measures to stop the leek,  a short piece of metal tube and a
few hose clamps. I see it as only a temporary fix as I am sure the rest of
the line is in the same condition. Yes the car has had the updated fuel
rail/line as per service campaign.
I don't recall the set-up of the lines prior to the campaign (it hase been
five years),
but currently there are fittings for both the supply and the return lines on
the engine side.  On the wheel well side the return is secured by a clamp to
the steel line.  The supply line (the bad one) goes into a very factory
looking crimp on the steel line.
I am starting to wonder if the line was changed as part of the service
campaign or just the fuel rail, I will check with my local West Palm Beach
P-car dealer.

Date: Sat, 01 Jul 1995 11:50 -0600 (MDT)
From: Hunter Heath <HEATH@ENDO.MED.UTAH.EDU>
Subject: ABS dash covers

My '83 944 has a brown ABS dash cover that was on it when I got the car two
years ago.  From the catalog pix it appears to be from Automotion.  It
doesn't look bad; as a Porsche ignoramus when I got the car, it took me a few
weeks to figure out that it was an add-on.  However, it really doesn't match
the OEM plastic at all.  It certainly protects the dash, but I dislike two
things: it squeaks where it rubs on other plastic, and it is too shiny.
Other than that, I think it beats the heck out of a cracked, faded dash....
For the price, I mean.  I need to work up the courage to remove the cover and
see what I've got underneath; maybe I'm lucky and it was put on when the car
was new to "protect" the  pristine original....  And pigs fly, eh?

A few questions to the list:

1. Curb hits have yielded a minor crack in the front dam, and bending of the
corner braces.  I think I can remove and straighten the braces, but wonder if
anyone has hints on repairing the crack.  It is only about 0.5 cm deep, in
the structure I would call the center brace of the dam.

2. At least one other lister and I are *still* waiting to hear of *anyone's*
experience with sheepskin seat covers.  Advice on suppliers of quality
covers, in particular.  Mine are shot.

3. Despite replacing motor mounts with newest type, my engine still shakes
itself-- makes me think of a slightly wet dog, or a pee shiver-- as it
decelerates through about 1000-1100 rpm.  I've cadged rides in several other
944s, and found that some seem to have that shake, and others didn't.  What
do the 944 experts say?  Is this the price one pays for a large displacement
4-lunger?  Now, here's one for the engineers: why does the engine shake when
coming *down* through 1100 rpm but not when going *up* through the same rpm
range?

4. When the car is cold, slamming a door yields a strange "boiiinnng" sound
from underneath.  Warm, no sound.  Up on the lift today, beat on everything,
no boing.  Of course, it was hot from running to the shop by then.  Ideas?

TIA,

Hunter
1983 944 Platinum
Recent winner of worst novice autocross performance
 in US history

Date: Sun, 2 Jul 1995 22:56:56 -0700
From: Harry Pellow <maestro@well.com>
Subject: 912 Overheating

Subj:	Re: Overheating 912
>From:	MAESTRO132@aol.com
To:	porschephiles@tta.com
 
>From your description, you have a VERY BAD MISMATCH! You apparently have a
European Fan Shroud (with open air outlet hole for the Euro heaters), but
you
have the  American  style "Flapper Boxes"! The air bleed off the fan shroud
is really needed to cool the 5' of exhaust pipe inside each  Euro heater
box.
The Euro heater is always "on", with  a deflector valve on the body under
ther car either sending hot air to you inside or to the  atmosphere outside,
depending on what position your heater control is in. 
    In your case, having the flapper boxes,  what  you should do is BLOCK
OFF
the air bleed hole on the right hand side of the fan shroud. Cut a piece of
sheet metal to fit, and use the existing bolt holes/weld nuts to attach. If
you really need something to block this off, let me know at (408) 727-1864,
as I have a few of them around the  Shop. A Better Solution (at least a more
visually appealing solution) would be either to replace the  Euro fan shroud
with an American one, or convert the engine  to the Euro heater boxes. If
your  engine number is 830,000 to 836,xxx it was Originally a Euro model.
Unfortunately, to convert to Euro you need some expensive parts- like the
heater boxes, muffler, muffler supports, etc. I have them in stock in case
you want to  go that way. If you want more info, give me a call at (408)
727-1864.
KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro

Porschephiles #1525                         Mon Jul 3 14:05:22 CDT 1995

(we were living in a rental house and they wouldn't even talk to us, 
regardless of the fact that it has a garage) They don't insure you if 
your house doesn't have a closed and locking garage attached to the house 
where someone is at "all times" (This prompted us to ask, "Well, what the 
hell do you expect us to do? Hire a security guard?") and amongst other 
things (by the time we got the answer to this one, we knew Leland wasn't 
for us) they won't insure young drivers... That clearly leaves the 
majority of Porsche drivers open for them to take, but we were not in 
their category.
 -Derek

Date: Mon, 03 Jul 95 11:51:00 PDT
From: "Thiger Jonas, Netsupport" <jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se>
Subject: Vacation in Germany...

Just came back from a nice 2-week trip to Germany, lots of P- and other cars 
and beer! I'd like to share some things from the trip with my fellow P-car 
friends:

Naturally we visited Nurburgring, we had an old Toyota though, so no 
driving... Interesting was what we heared from a German friend who often goes 
there, and is very experienced in Ring-driving:
He'd seen the Boxter on test drives around the Ring and quote: "...never seen 
any car handling as good as the Boxter" According to this guy the car will be 
something out of this world... So, hold your horses and keep the money in the 
bank until 986 arrives!

Next, we went to Weissach and tried to get in (no such luck, of course...). 
In any case we spotted some Boxters, the new 911 panorama, and a 996.

Rest of the trip we stayed in Nurnberg, went to the DTM races there, and had 
a lot of fun around town!

Eagle-eyed porschephiles saw that I sold my beloved 944 (still the only 
limone gelb I ever seen), on my way down to Germany. Of course I paniced 
(no Porsche -no life?) so on the way home I bought my dream car:
a '72 911S Targa, almost original, kein umbau!
Some rust on the front fenders and left rear, 90.000 miles, mech sound, 
chrome and interior (leather) OK. Probably matching numbers, will check 
today. Sadly not the original color but that'll be fixed this or next winter. 
Got it for about USD 6000. If somebody knows if that's the correct price, he/
she could please e-mail me!

Jonas Thiger (jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se)
Sweden
Proud new owner of a 911S 2,4...

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 08:33:23 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Zone 1 48 Hours Report (long)

Well, we just returned last night from a very successful PCA
Driver Education at Watkins Glen, the Zone 1 48 Hours of
Watkins Glen.

The name of the event comes about from the Saturday/Sunday 
sessions. Instructors are allowed to run on Friday for 
workshops and checkouts. We had a total of 240 drivers from 10 
states participate, some from as far away as Texas. 

The long course that we use had a couple of changes from last
year, the first being a large curb at the entrance to the inner
loop (chicane) on the back straight, put there to ensure that
the cars do slow down and not cut across there. The second is
a widening of the track out of Turn 14 (the left hander after
the off camber) so that the turn is now just a lift and go in
4th gear for everybody (VERRY FAST).

In a couple of places, they have also added some concrete
patches along the line, so that there is a bit more traction
and less breaking up of the surface.

The weather was just about perfect, from an overcast and
coolish Friday (where the thunderstorms held off until 3
minutes until 5 p.m.) and a warm and muggy (but dry) Saturday,
and a cool and clear, low humidity Sunday.  Altogether, we lost
about 20 minutes of track time to weather and about 15 minutes
of track time due to cleanup of a couple of minor incidents.

One of the incidents was a 911 at the toe of the boot. His tail
started to wash out as he was accelerating up the hill. He
jerked the wheel to catch it, noticed that the jerk had not
accomplished the desired result, so he jerked it again. In his
words, "The car just jumped into the guardrail."

He and his passenger were not injured, and the damage was
limited to a couple of powder blue stripes running down the
driver side of the car, a bent front strut, a bent front
control arm, and a couple of scratched wheels, (as well as a
damaged driver ego).

The other incident was at the aforementioned Turn 14, where a
993 from Michigan realized that he was carrying too much speed
there, lifted in the middle of the turn, lost it and backed
around into the armco on the inside of the turn. Again, no
injuries and the car will be easily repaired...

But that was the only negative part of the event.

A couple of new 993 Turbos showed up, one delivered only 2
weeks ago, the other with trick muffler and HUGE Fikse wheels
and tires, all painted black to match the car. Incredibly fast.

Lots of race cars, including 356s and 914s and GTU and GT2 cars.
Bill Hawe brought his Ruf Turbo to join a couple of other of
Mr. Ruf's cars... Once again, incredibly fast...

The best part of an event like this was seeing Porsche friends 
from all over the Northeast at a great spot like the Glen. I 
must mention the Porschephiles that were there: Lou Krieg, Bill 
Hawe, Mark Forrester, David Rothenberg and Christine Ryan, 
Larry and Geri Reynolds, Thak and Thwen Chaleomtirana (who 
incidentally threw a great party in Ithaca for the Central New 
York Region - we had a great time!) and my lovely wife and 
myself...

Mark your calendar for attending this event next year, we'll
have it the week after the IMSA/Busch events at the Glen...

I'll let you know the dates as soon as they are resolved...
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services to "Her Majesty"
Orders: 800-all-p944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 87 944S (SOLD!), 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 09:05:40 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 73 1/2 ride height & shocks?

>After sitting for this long, I found that the ride height measured 26in
>at rear fender lip, and 27.5 in at FRONT!!!  I felt that the gas had
>caused the chassis to rise.  After  beating my car around the back roads
>for about 500 mi., nothing changed!!  The Konis resulted in about a 1/2 in
>drop. I,ve only drived it for about 50mi, but I don't think it will change
>much!!

Paul,

Believe it or not, the 26/27.5 inch fender lip measurements you note
indicate that the car is pretty close to the factory recommended ride
heights.  I am also in the process of adjusting the height of my '76 as
we speak.  Using the factory method of measuring ride height - meas-
uring the difference between the center line of the torsion bar and the
center line of the wheel hub - I got a 26 inch fender lip measurement
in the rear for a 12mm difference in torsion bar/hub (12mm +/- 5mm
is the factory recommendation for "Euro" cars - US cars were alot 
higher).  I just went out in the garage and measured my fronts - 27 inches.
I had measured my front hub/torsion bar difference a while back and it
was 108mm - right on the factory spec.  So, to make a long story long,
you're not real far off right now.

>What do I have to do to drop it back to normal ride height?? The front
>doesn't seem to difficult, but the rear is sort of hard to understand in
>the shop manual. I should't have to do anything with the torsion bars???
>I'm just trying to get back to factory height... Nothing has been done to
>the chassis before, and it came with Konis. I thought that over time the
>torsion bars and bushings will wear and the ride height will become
>lower?? I checked the sway-bars and they're not binding. Any info on
>desired alignment specs for my chassis specialists?

The front is straightforward, the rear is a character builder.  Especially
on a car the age of yours.  You will have to move the spring plates relative
to the torsion bars in the rear to change your ride height.  After 22 years
of blissful union, your torsion bars and spring plates may have developed
an attraction for each other and may not want to come apart.

If you would like more info on what is involved with this, let me know.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 08:23:12 -0700 (PDT)

Subject: 944 starting prob


hi p'philes,
	I've recently run into a problem with my 83 944.  When i turn the 
key to start the car, absolutely nothing happens--no motor trying to turn 
over, etc...the only sound i've noticed is a slight whirring from the 
back of the car (maybe from the fuel pump?).  Anyhow, i'll turn the key 
on and off 1-2 times and the car will start fine (no stumbling to start 
or anything) and will run fine.  The difficulty starting isn't very 
predictable either--sometimes when cold, sometimes when hot, sometimes it 
takes just 2 turns of the key, sometimes 5 or more.  I don't think it's 
the fuel pump or the relay since I would think that would also effect the 
car even while it is running, not just the starting.  I checked the 
electrical connections to the battery and they are fine.  I haven't 
checked the connections to the sarter yet, but will do so soon.  I don't 
think it is the battery because if the battery were low, I would think 
that the engine would try to turn over, but wouldn't be able to--no sound 
is made in my situation.  I'm thinking right now that it might be the 
starter :-( .  any advice on a diagnosis, ways and things to check? 

tia,

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 08:24:35 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: R1 Tire Wear/Inflation

You wrote: 
>
>Since there seems to be a wide range of opinion whithin my region as 
to the
>correct starting point for inflation on R1's I'd like to know what 
some of
>you use.
>
>I am running 255.40.17's in front and 275.40.17's in the rear.  The 
front
>camber is set at -2.4 and the rear is at -1.5.  The tire temps seem to 
be OK
>running 33 lb. in front and 31 lb in the rear.
>
>If I go lower, current thinking by some, I get rapid tire wear in the 
center.
>
>Any comments would be welcome.
>
>Alan968
>95 968 M030
>
Invest is a bottle of white shoe polish. At your next and subsequent 
events put four marks on each quarter of the outside of your tires at 
the edge of the tread. If the marks are still there on the outter part 
of the roll edge of the tread then too much air pressure for the course 
and time on course. Once the marks wear off then you got it right for 
your car and set up.

Mike

- -- 
- --
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 12:03:27 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: 924S buying

On Mon, 3 Jul 1995, Robert Rhodes wrote:

> 	2)  There are no records for this car.  Am I asking for trouble 
> in buying a "bargain" porsche without some history?
None? Zilch? If so, the owner may be covering up something majorly bad 
wrong with the car

> 	As a final note on the condition of this car the tires are, I 
> believe, P-6s all around, but are obviously of 3 different vintages as 
> though the owner only bought one at a time when one wore out.  Also the 
> car vibrates badly over 60 mph.
Not knowing precise things about 924S's, I cannot say this for sure, but 
I believe that the tires are the problem. If they are incorrectly 
balanced, or never were (likely incorrectly balanced as the description you 
give makes the wheels seem like they've been worn out) the car would 
begin to vibrate badly at highway speeds and above. Many people notice 
this after changing tires if they don't go ahead and get their tires 
balanced. Ask the owner if/when the tires were last balanced, and if they 
were, was it spin or bubble? (Spin is better) If this appears to be your 
problem, you are probably looking at $50-$100 depending on how much the 
garage you take it to charges per tire to balance, and an hour or so in 
waiting.
 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 09:13:09 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: carb conversion


You might want to look at the 914 FAQ about this conversion before you start;
the 912E motor is basically a 914-2.0 motor with the 914-1.8 injection
system.

For a 914, converting to carbs is number 2 or 3 on the list of the 10
*worst* things you can do to the car.

Gary.

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 09:20:23 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: R1 Tire Wear/Inflation


>Invest is a bottle of white shoe polish. At your next and subsequent
>events put four marks on each quarter of the outside of your tires at
>the edge of the tread. If the marks are still there on the outter part
>of the roll edge of the tread then too much air pressure for the course
>and time on course. Once the marks wear off then you got it right for
>your car and set up.

Mike,

This does not work with BFG R1's. The outer sidewall is so stiff I have
not found a low enough pressure for there to be any roll over on the edge.

The best thing to do is get a pyrometer out and to compare lap times until
the temps are right and the laps are as fast as possible. Sound easy...I
wish!

My experience suggests that 30 psi is way to high...but my experience is
with a 911 on 225/50R15 fronts and 245/45/R16 rears....

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 12:23:48 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: R1 968 Tire Wear/Inflation

Alan,
I assume you are using these tires for track usage. If you are you are
running them WAY too high. Try starting about 24lbs front and rear cold and
be sure and bleed them down once they are hot. I run about 25 on the front
and 23 in the back on my 89 944 turbo. These are hot pressures BTW. You are
also running too much camber considering the stiffness of the tire. Try about
1.75 in the front and 1.25 in the rear. A little toe out in the front and a
little toe in in the rear and you have a reasonable setup.
If you are using them on the street run them at about 35-36lbs all the way
around. You are going to wear them out on the street fairly quickly,
especially in the insides, with those camber settings.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
12:18 pm

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 12:27:57 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 924S buying

>	I am looking at a 1987 924S and have a few questions.
>
>	1)  Does this car have the self adjusting timing belt thingy?

Yes, but read the FAQ. The builtin adjuster only sets it once, and then
you lock it in place. It does not adjust over a period of time for wear, etc.

>
>	2)  There are no records for this car.  Am I asking for trouble 
>in buying a "bargain" porsche without some history?

Take it to a competent watercooled Porsche mechanic for an analysis.
If you belong to PCA, or know a PCA member in your area, ask for
a recommendation from one who owns a watercooled car.

>
>	3)  The previous owner seems to have spent more on the stereo 
>than on the car.  Is there anything I can look for in terms of 
>identifying neglect?

Yes, see number 2.

>
>	4)  What size tire is "supposed" to be on this car?  what other 
>sizes will fit?  This car currently has the phone dial type rims, but 
>they are pretty shabby, anything to correct this?

Stock size was 195/60-15 on 6Jx15 wheels, 7Jx15 wheels optional
in the rear.


>
>	5)  Any other advice would be appreciated.

Buy it if you can afford to maintain it. Otherwise, pass.
>
>	As a final note on the condition of this car the tires are, I 
>believe, P-6s all around, but are obviously of 3 different vintages as 
>though the owner only bought one at a time when one wore out.  Also the 
>car vibrates badly over 60 mph.

New tires are cheap to buy.  If this is any indication of what the 
previous owner was willing to do to maintain the car, I would pass on it.


Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services 
Orders: 800-ALL-P944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 09:33:21 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: Re: 914 Trim

On Sun, 2 Jul 1995 AllPorsche@aol.com wrote:

> I pulled the vinyl covering off the rollbar and sides of my '74 914 as I plan
> to paint everything "uni-color". However, I guess I will still need the rear
> sloping trim piece, as well as the top sides. Can these be painted
> (aluminium) or is there another way to deal with the exposed spotwelded seems

Bart, a lot of people feel that the sail vinyl is an important part of a 
914's appearance.  I disagree - my '74 had the sail vinyl removed at last 
rework and it looks much better.  I did replace the aluminum trim pieces, 
though.  Also, I put the top vinyl back on after the paint started 
getting scratches caused by trapped debris.

To see it, what it looks like, check out my 914 Fan web page (see the 
.sig below)

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 14:05:11 -0600 (CST)
From: "thak chaloemtiarana" <tc17@cornell.edu>
Subject: smoking 914

My 2 litre engine was partially rebuilt last week--new Mahle pistons and
cylinders, new valves and guides--and it still smokes, especially after
down-shifting.  I was attempting to avoid being black flagged at the Glen,
but apparently I am jinxed with the smoking the mosquitoes syndrome.

Sympathetic friends suggested that the smoking will go away after the seals
seat themselves, unsympathetic enemies suggested that I had broken oil
rings, my mechanic suggested that I try a different oil.  I am sure that my
son will say "stop complaining, let's trade cars."  My daughter would want
me to give her the car, smoking and all, out right.  I have yet to ask my
wife who will see our VISA bill SOON.

Any one with any reassuring thoughts?  I hate to pull the engine again.
After the rebuild, I drove it around (frenzily for two days after work) for
200 miles before tracking it. It is possible that I did not break the engine
in long enough and managed to screw something up.  Aside from the smoking,
the car ran strong.
Thak Chaloemtiarana                              EMail:TC17@cornell.edu

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 11:51:49 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: 1989 Speedster Info.

Not half its original price (as recommended by the factory), but the
price that speculators were willing to pay.  Actually, a new '89
Speedster stickered for somewhere around $70K, if I remember
correctly.

That was when collector cars had got out of hand, especially Ferraris
and Lamborghinis.  Then the bottom fell out of the entire market.  I'm
wary of buying any car as an investment just because too many gross
things can happen to it.  But if you are, I would think an '89
Speedster at $60K wouldn't be a bad choice.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 15:01:54 -0400
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: What's it all about, Bartie...?

Patrons and members can just hit the ol' D key here...

> hi bart,
> what on earth are you going to do with $8,347?
> sorry, i was away on vacation when the phund was being set up so i missed the 
> initial info.

Hi Mitch,

Thanks for asking!

Porschephiles has steadily grown to a membership of *OVER* 1800 members,
generating traffic of more than 68,000 messages per *day*, which is more
traffic than MCI handles!

This volume of traffic is eating a significant chunk of Stan's T-1
service.  In addition, it now requires that a machine be dedicated to
handle this traffic.  This machine is old, nearing the end of its service
life, and should be replaced.

Not to put too fine a point of this, this eats into the Listmeister's
livelihood, and, amigos, that ain't right.  We owe Stan an inestimable
debt of gratitude for freely providing this service at no cost for the
past 5.5 years.  The very least we can do to show our gratitude is to
take as much of the capital burden upon ourselves as possible.

We have established a Not-for-profit bank account with my bank in
Crofton, Maryland, to accumulate the funds, and are asking that each
member who is concerned for the survival of Porschephiles, to contribute
what they can.  I have suggest appropriate donations would be $15 for
Students, $50 for Employed people, and $100 for those who wish to be
considered Patrons.

*Nobody* has to contribute anything.  We are trying to acquire the funds
to build the infastructure to ensure the survival of Porschephiles
independent of any member.

I don't have firm figures for the costs we are facing, and that doesn't
bother me a bit. I do know that Stan has made the service available to
the group, using the capital resources that he depends upon to earn his
daily bread, and is begining to feel the strain.

So where do the suggested contribution numbers come from?  Can you say
"Rectal Data?"  It is my sense that a Student should be able to afford
$15.  If a poor starving Stoont can cough up $15, it isn't far out of
line for a Working person, who can afford both a love of Porsches and
access to the 'net, to be able to pony up $50.  If you want to do more,
then $100 seemed like a nice, tidy round number.

I don't think it's anal-retentive to recognize those who dig deeper.  I
have assured all that no one's name or contribution level will be
published *unless* they instruct me to do so.  NOBODY *HAS* TO CONTRIBUTE
ANYTHING!

I also know (I've been investigating the costs of becoming a Service
provider on the 'net, and) it's not cheap.  Last week's InfoWorld has a
comparison of two package servers, one from BBN, and the other a Sun
Netra.  We're looking at $7-10K just for the box and software.  I don't
believe that Mailing list Software was in those figures, but I do know
that they do *not* include T-1 service.  As we determine what the blivid
(5 lbs in a 3 lb bag) of stuff totals out to be, you will be advised.

So what If you don't send anything?  You're *still* a Porschephile, with
all the privilidges and rights pertaining thereto.  As long as the
service survives...

If you want to ensure the survival of this organization, and I sure as
hell do, then send what you can.  Many folks have asked what would be
appropriate to send, and I've tried to offer guidelines.

So What do you get out of this?  How about a nice shiny *Number*,
reflecting the order in which I receive your check?  Whatever
organization we form to shelter the funding under, this number will be
your membership number.  You get to be a *charter* member of whatever it
becomes.  Impress your Friends!  Be *attractive* to Members of your
favorite Gender!  Be known as a *True* Porschephile...

And, how about *Satisfaction* that you've been part of one of the *great*
happenings on the 'net?

Finally, the "membership" issue.  By 3/18/95, we must apply to the IRS
for Non-Profit Organization status. (tick...tick...tick) I'm the guy in
the barrel here.  We need to decide what kind of an organiztion we will
be.  Here, again, you can be a PORSCHEPHILE and not join any more
organizations.  Many of us would like to be the Electronic Frontier
Region of PCA, but this is not universal. Most of the Non-US folks are
not interested in affiliating with PCA, and that's no problem either.

Everyone *Can* send a donation; *NOBODY* has to!  Everybody can Join
(whatever orgainzation we decide); again, *NOBODY* has to...there is
enough interest in the EFR business that we *can* go that route if
required to keep my butt out of the [deleted] grasp of the IRS.

Finally, for you good souls who want to contribute:  The bank folks would
rather that you send the checks to me, made out to

for deposit to "Porschephiles" Acct #3933150532

My address is:

Custodian "Porschephiles" 
c/o Bart Chambers (aka Yer Kindly ol' Unka Bart)
1270 Lavall Drive
Davidsonville, MD  21035 

(410) 721-2989

If you wish to call me, please do so prior 8:30 PM EST.

***Please send me an Email with your address, ck number and amt.*** This
will be private unless you wish to send it to 'philes yourself:

Here is the name, address and Phone number of the bank officer so anyone
who whishes, may verify that this is on the up-and-up.

Cathy Laster, 
re:  Porschephiles 
acct.# 3933150532 
NationsBank, Crofton Office 2227 
Defense Highway Crofton, MD  21114 

(410) 793-0770

We are grateful any and all donations.


Cheers

(yer Kindly ol' Unka) Bart

Frau Dora, 
(fond memory of a couple of little feline varmints in my heart)

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 95 15:10:59 EDT
From: David Watters <watters@cranel.com>
Subject: Many 951 Questions


I have a bunch of questions and would love responses to any of them, THANKS!

Car: '88 951 Black/Black 70K miles


1)  My rear wiper motor has died.  I need to replace it and I would like to
    replace the whole wiper on the rear and the two fronts as they have many
    rock chips and look worn.

    I noticed that the wipers on the 968 seem different, so;

    a. Will a 968 rear wiper motor work on a 951?
       i. is it just the same part or different (newer, better)?

    b. Will the 968 wipers fit on a 951?
       i. are they just the same or different?

2)  My A/C is no-opp.  The dealership says that the aluminum tubing that goes
    through the firewall has been crimped by bad work previously done and that
    the refrigerant escapes there.  He says that they tried to rig it, but it
    needs replaced.  He estimated that part to be ~$300 but noted that it would
    require ~$800 in labor to do the job as much of the top of the engine would
    need to be removed to get back in there.

     a.  How does that sound to people that know what part he is talking about?
         i.  Is it possible to be fixed without replacing the part?
        ii.  Is the labor estimate out of hand?
       iii.  Can a non-dealership do the work cheaper but just as well.
        iv.  Can I do the work myself (moderate abilities)?

     b.  What else should be done at the same time if much of the engine needs
         to be opened up?
         i.  Head gasket? _minor_ oil near front
        ii.  Valve guides? (burns .5qt./4-5K miles)
       iii.  Any belts?

3)  The rear speaker housing has form factors for both a 4x6" speaker and
    a round speaker.

     a. Is it 4" circular or 5"?

5)  Is it possible to get that damn heat shield to quit rattling?  :-)

6)  My clutch pedal has a few inches of play before there is any sort of
    pressure.  I also have the gear meshing problems going into second that
    someone was talking about earlier.  It is really tight in the winter, and
    I have to do the second or two pause before pulling it into second.  In
    addition, pushing the pedal much much farther into the carpet, :-), seems
    to help.  It seems to me that a lot of the problem is that I am not getting
    enough pedal.

     a.  Is the clutch pedal hydrolic?
         i.  Does it need bled or added to?
        ii.  Does the fluid ever need changed?
       iii.  Any other ideas if it is not the pedal needing ajusted?
        iv.  Can I ajust this?

7)  Thinking about chipping the car.

    a.  Should I?
        i.  If I have the head gasket replaced with the newer, better gasket
            should I go ahead since I removed the major problem with chiping
            a 951 (failed head gasget)?
       ii.  What other problems are there?

8)  I need to replace the rear seat belt assebly covers.

    a.  Should I replace the whole belts?
    b.  Are there 3rd party belts that are better, cheaper?
    c.  Should I just remove them from those fake seats? :-)

9)  The car is running rich.  The car has always run rich.  The car will
    forever run rich.  :-)  I have had them look at this a bunch of times
    and they have "spec'ed" the car over and over, but I still run rich
    (especially in the winter).  I am tired of fighting to keep from fouling
    the plugs in the first few moments of starting it during the winter.

    a.  Is there a bigger problem?
    b.  Is there a solution?
    c.  Will chipping the car help? 8->

10) I need a 993 C4 (995?)

    a.  Can somebody buy me one?
    b.  Did I earn any points for not asking for a 996?

11) I am not sure if my car has LSD or not.  I was given an option code list
    with some holes, but I do have the code that was listed as being a LSD.
    This puzzels me as I didn't think I had one.  I drove a '92 968 which 
    acted very different from my car and I though all 968's had LSD.  With
    my car, it is very easy for me to get into a power-on oversteer.  With the
    968 I couldn't and I believed the inner wheel slipped a bit but then it
    felt like something happened and it grabbed.  This discription makes it
    sound like I have LSD and the 968 didn't.

    a. Do I have an LSD?
    b. What is the 100% sure option code for an LSD?
    c. How does an LSD differ from what I (ignorantly, I'm sure) refered to
       as posi-traction during my youth?

12) Why didn't the 968 sell well?  It was a damn fine car, though was
    underpowered for the price range it was in compare to it's competitors.

    a. Is this why?
    b. Does someone want to trade my 951 for one?
    c. Should I have bought a '92 968 with _4K_ miles in '94 for $30K?

13) Now and then I get into it and up in revs.  I was actually told once that
    this is good for the car to burn off stuff.

    a. Should I do this?
    b. Is it completely save to use the full range of revs?

14) I almost never drop my clutch from high revs, in fact I probably under
    rev it when taking off.

    a. How high should the revs be before beginning to release the clutch?
    c. How bad is power-on oversteer for the clutch/gearbox/etc?  (note: I
       do not peel out, but sometimes I get hard onto it when leaving a turn
       and let it slide a bit.  Man, my old baldies were a blast! :-) )

15) My alloys look like crap. (16" phone dials)

    a. How well does refinishing look?
    b. Can they be chromed?
    c. Should I get new +1 or +2" tire/wheel sets instead if I want to
       start doing some track stuff?

Well, enough for now.

Thanks to those that read this far!!! :-)


David Watters
'88 951 Black

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 15:57:52 -0500
From: mac3d@superlink.net (Ed Dougherty)
Subject: 944/951 A/C

A few days ago it finally got hot enough to roll up the windows and turn on
the A/C. Nothing happened...
I stopped in to a local auto A/C shop to have them check it out. The tech
told me that the system "held vacuum OK, but we tried recharging it 3 times
and it wouldn't accept any Freon". He suggested I take it to the Porsche
shop because it must be something "peculiar to Porsches".
Anybody heard of this before? I've checked the 944 FAQ, and the A/C
problems section is not done yet. The fact that there *is* an A/C section
makes me think there may be some common problems. I've made it a point to
run the system about 20 minutes a month during the winter, as Porsche
recommends.
Any tips, clues or hints would be greatly appreciated.
 -ed

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 03 Jul 95 13:25:00 PST
From: Peter Barlow <PBarlow@sierrasys.com>
Subject: Re: '68 911S



Here's another vote for the likelihood of this car being a '69, potentially
sold in (and titled as a) '68.  The 68 911S didn't meet the States first big 

emissions year, so wasn't imported.  The 911L replaced it, and was an
S with the E-engine - all the trim of the S, but the 130 hp engine.  The 68
'S' in Europe was indeed a Weber car, and short wheelbase of course.
The '68 car serial numbers start with 118.  And yes, there are a few that
have made there way into the States and Canada.

All that said, the '69 S is a nice find.  A lot of people, once settled on 
the
slightly flared fenders and the fuel injection, lean towards the last of the
series ('73).  But the '69 has all the important improvements (4 vented
discs, dual circuit master cylinder, updated front suspension, actually
obtainable interior parts) with the smaller displacement,  peakier (more
entertaining?) engine.

Peter Barlow
'68 911S

------------------------------

Date: 03 Jul 95 16:32:55 EDT
From: "Jay S. Karolyi" <102062.710@compuserve.com>
Subject: 924 Horror Story! Ahhh!

Hello Phello Porschephiliacs,
	I witnessed a true assault on the good Doctor's name.  Thankfully
this trajedy didn't involve my 924, but it was painful just the same.  I
was travelling on I-75 into Atlanta in my '77 924 coming back to 
Charlotte from a weekend visiting my brother in Chattanooga, TN.  In my
rear view mirror I spotted a familiar silhouette, that of a 924.  I was
getting prepared to wave at the fellow 924 when I made out the electric
purple color on the car.  I also noted it was riding a bit lower than my
stock 924.  What drove up beside me was nausiating.  Not only was the 
924 painted electric purple with fishing boat sparkle paint, but it had
been lowered and shod with tiny chrome wheels with ultra low profile
tires.  It had a sizeable chunk of sheetmetal gouged out of the front
fender and door from an accident.  It had a HUGE whale tail glued (at 
least I assume it was glued, no way could the hatch survive hole 
drilling) to the hatch.  Also, white coolant smelling smoke puffed from
its LOUD exhaust.  Head gasket time!  Over the loud exhaust could be 
heard a soft boom-boom from a stereo.  
	I gave the 924 a half hearted wave but I don't know if he waved
back, the windows were tinted too dark.  I thought this kind of 
"customization" only happened to BMWs and Mercedes!  I've never see the 
"drug dealer" package applied to a Porsche!  Could this be the start of
a trend?  Has anyone else seen this gaudy 924 around the Atlanta area?
Are there any other P-cars you guys have seen this done to?  
	Anyway, at least I had an excellent time carving TN country roads
in The Bastard with my brother and his 914 2.0.  The Bastard is much
faster in the straights but he catches up in the corners.  He doesn't 
like to get behind me though, he claims my car smells!  I still need to
rebuild the six (ugh!) carbs...  Let me know if anyone has seen any other
atrocious Porsches.  Thanks!
				Jay Karolyi
'75 Fly Yellow Corvair/914 "The Bastard"
'77 Mist Green 924
'85 Forest Green VW GTI (traded with sister for the '80 Toy 'rolla while
	I replace the engine for her)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 13:54:38 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 mystery part, cam timing

When removing my engine, a aluminum bush/spacer fell out.
it is cylindrical (actually an annulus) 3.7 cm long, 1.8 cm 
outer diam, 0.8 cm inner diam.

Can anyone tell me what it is/where it goes?

Thanks,

 -Mitch Craig - hcrms@chevron.com

p.s. Got the cams' end play and timing set Saturday.
Here's how I timed the cams:
(parts of this are in the factory workshop manual):

1. Remove all spark plugs, install rockers on #1 and #4 intake valves
   and adjust valves with cams turned so that the rocker foot is on the back
   side of the cam (away from the lobe). #1 and #4 intake valves are
   on opposite sides of the motor, on the top, rearmost end of the motor
   (The end of the engine with the crank pulley).

2. Turn the crank so that the Z1 mark on the pulley points straight up,
   in the 12:00 position, in line with the joint between the case halves.
   This is TDC.

3. Turn the cams so the the dots on their ends points straight up,
   in the 12:00 position.

4. Install timing chains, gears, dowel pins, washers, and nuts on the
   ends of the cams. Tighten the nuts (no need to get carried away,
   just tight enough to flatten the spring washers).
  
5. Pick a cam, install dial indicator on cam housing overhanging the
   intake valve (either #1 or #4, depending on which side you're doing).
   You will need a specialDate: Mon, 3 Jul 95 15:35:48 EDT
From: David Watters <watters@cranel.com>
Subject: Re: Many 951 Questions


I want to add to one question...

> 1)  My rear wiper motor has died.  I need to replace it and I would like to
>     replace the whole wiper on the rear and the two fronts as they have many
>     rock chips and look worn.
> 
>     I noticed that the wipers on the 968 seem different, so;
> 
>     a. Will a 968 rear wiper motor work on a 951?
>        i. is it just the same part or different (newer, better)?
> 
>     b. Will the 968 wipers fit on a 951?
>        i. are they just the same or different?

The 968 rear wiper does have a different part number.  It is also _$150_
_cheaper_ than the motor for the '88 944.  I would love to know that I can
use the 968 motor. :-)

David Watters
'88 951 Black

'S' in Europe was indeed a Weber car, and short wheelbase of course.
The '68 car serial numbers start with 118.  And yes, there are a few that
have made there way into the States and Canada.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 13:54:38 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 mystery part, cam timing

When removing my engine, a aluminum bush/spacer fell out.
it is cylindrical (actually an annulus) 3.7 cm long, 1.8 cm 
outer diam, 0.8 cm inner diam.

Can anyone tell me what it is/where it goes?

Thanks,

 -Mitch Craig - hcrms@chevron.com

p.s. Got the cams' end play and timing set Saturday.
Here's how I timed the cams:
(parts of this are in the factory workshop manual):

1. Remove all spark plugs, install rockers on #1 and #4 intake valves
   and adjust valves with cams turned so that the rocker foot is on the back
   side of the cam (away from the lobe). #1 and #4 intake valves are
   on opposite sides of the motor, on the top, rearmost end of the motor
   (The end of the engine with the crank pulley).

2. Turn the crank so that the Z1 mark on the pulley points straight up,
   in the 12:00 position, in line with the joint between the case halves.
   This is TDC.

3. Turn the cams so the the dots on their ends points straight up,
   in the 12:00 position.

4. Install timing chains, gears, dowel pins, washers, and nuts on the
   ends of the cams. Tighten the nuts (no need to get carried away,
   just tight enough to flatten the spring washers).
  
5. Pick a cam, install dial indicator on cam housing overhanging the
   intake valve (either #1 or #4, depending on which side you're doing).
   You will need a special bracket to mount the dial indicator. The probe
   of the dial indicator needs to be positioned such that it has a straight 
   shot at the valve spring retaining collar. It should contact the flat 
   surface on the top of the collar and be preloaded sufficiently (i.e.
   0.200 in) and zeroed such that when the valve opens, it will be able to
   register the required valve lift.

6. Rotate the crank 360 degrees. When you start getting close (within 45-30
   degrees), start watching the dial indicator. When the Z1 mark is aligned 
   at the the case split, check to see how far the valve has opened.  It is
   a little tricky reading the dial indicator because the needle moves
   backwards (counterclockwise) as the valve opens.  In the case of a 2.2 L
   911 T, I wanted about 0.096 in of lift.  This is different according to
   whether you have a T, E, or S.  The T has the least lift, the S has the
   most.

7. If you are not within tolerance, remove the cam nut and dowel pin,
   being careful to not disturb the position of the cam. Using the cam
   holding socket, watch the dial indicator and rotate the cam (which 
   will now rotate independently of the timing gear) very slightly as 
   needed until the correct lift is indicated on the dial indicator.
   Insert the dowel pin to lock the timing gear to the cam. Put the
   cam washer and nut back on, tighten, and double check.
  
8. Repeat for other cam.

- ---------- end ------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 16:52:52 -0400
From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: Re: A/C

Tony,

I suggest you read the owners manual that came with the car. Because of the
nature of your question, I assume a limited knowledge of the subject, without
intending to be emotional. I used to be there too. A/C needs equipment these
days and is not a simple "fill it up" act. 
If you really have a mechanical interest, than the factory workshop manuals
are a must and reference.
Than join PCA and really learn to drive your car. In the mean time,
Porschephiles will have assisted you to the extend that $100 to bacame a
Patron is peanuts compared to you P-car investment.

Welcome !

Bart D (AllPorsche@aol.com)

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 95 14:00:23 PDT
From: Henrik Eriksson <henrik@chronologic.com>
Subject: Replacing oil-thermostat

I posted a while ago about my HOT running C2,

The problem is that the oil never passes the oil-thermostat,
(located just in front of the right rear fender)
so the oil never gets to the oil-cooler....
I'm going to try to replace the thermostat and the two rubber hoses
that connects to it.

A fellow p-phile heard this:
     Apparently the oil thermostat is changed from the inside the car. 
     Behind the passenger seat are two panels, one on the side and the 
     other on the floor, which need to be removed.  The mechanics called it 
     a pain in the a...  He cautioned to also change the hoses, as they do 
     tend to leak - something about German rubber.  

Anyone could verify this? and please add a little more details?
Seems like it should be changed from the outside, also
I'm not yet sure where one of the rubber hoses go...

Thanks,
Henrik
henrik@chronologic.com

ps.
Both the hose started to leak and the thermostat failed, :-(
maybe this is due to switching to synthetic oil one week before?
Again it might just be a coincidence. :-)

involved which I don't plan to get involved with.

it were. The manual does not tell you how to check the transmission fluid 
level?? I've been involved with cvars, as a hobby, since the early '70s.

not pollute the environment.

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 19:20:19 -0400
From: Phyl346@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 starting prob

Just had the same thing on my '83 944.  It's obviously the starter solenoid
which luckily is VERY easy to replace.  Shop around,  many people will say
you can't get just the solenoid but I got mine from a general
alternator/starter rebuild firm for $34.  It's working great!!!!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 21:20:38 -0400
From: RonS993@aol.com
Subject: Boing!

Hunter,
I once owned an early 944 that did the same sort of thing - made a strange
metallic sort of noise when the door was shut, except mine did it only when
hot.  It turned out to be a piece of heat shielding (I'm not sure which one
exactly - this is what the dealer mechanic told me) in the vicinity of the
catalytic converter.  The dealer just loosened and retightened the shielding,
and no more boing.

Ron
