Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 00:29:51 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: aftermarket FI

At 04:18 PM 7/3/95 -0400, CAcuff@aol.com wrote:
>I am about to start a 914 project that may include the addition of an
>aftermarket FI system to my 2.0 engine.
>
>Does anyone have any experience with the TMW throttle bodies or an injection
>control system such as the Haltech F7.

Cory,

The TWM (not TMW) throttle bodies are OK but not great.  We put a set on
a customer car a while back.  Well, we put the second set on.  The first
set got sent back to TWM because of binding of the butterflies to the
bodies, a problem which TWM described as being "not uncommon."  They were
very good about it, and their package is *very* cost-effective when
compared with, say, a nice guillotine set-up.

We've also done a handful of cars with the F7 system.  It works fine.
The monitoring/programming software leaves a lot to be desired in terms of,
well in terms of a lot of things.  But it is more than adequate to getting
the job done, assuming a) you have a dyno (engine or chassis), and b) you
have a high-speed, wide-range exhaust gas monitor.  Both of which are major
investments.

Kevin

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 18:40:49 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 73 911:  Wheel & Tire Combinations

>I would like to run  6x16/7x16 Fuchs, however I have never seen that 
>combination on an early 911 before.

I have seen this combo on a '77 911.  Correct me if I'm wrong (that goes
without saying on this list), but I believe the flares were the same from
'69 to '77.

The thing is, some cars will tolerate more tire/wheel than others.  The
car I saw had 16x7s with 205/55s in the rear and they DIDN'T RUB.  The
fender lips weren't even rolled.  I have also seen 225/50s on 15x7s on the
rear.  I have to imagine that would take some effort to make them the 
225s fit.

Your best bet is a 7x15 wheel with 205/60s.  It is not a sure thing, but this
should fit in the rear.  The fronts are a little more wide open.  I would
decide what will fit in the rear and size the fronts accordingly (don't put
195/50s on 6x15s in the rear and then put 205/55s on 7x16s up front -
T*d already tried that):>). 

Good luck and HTH,

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911



------------------------------

Date: 30 Jun 1995 09:30:41 -0400
From: "Kreg Ulery" <kdu@aloft.att.com>
Subject: Re: 911 1990 C4 Resolved stu

        Reply to:   RE>911 1990 C4 Resolved studdering

>RedNineCo suggested it could be the belt between the two distributors
>and that was exactly what it was.  This was causing only one plug per 
>cylinder to fire.  BTW, there were not any dash lights to indicate there 
>was actually a problem.
......

>warranty (5yrs,50k miles) still applies.  And low and behold - it was 
>covered.  Jim Ellis said it would be a $600 repair otherwise.  Probably 
>could have been done cheaper if you just replaced the belt - but they 
>replaced the whole distributor.

At the factory, they actually match belts to the distrubutors. I've
been told that they have several belt sizes (all withing just a few
fractions of a mm of each other), and they individually size each
distributor to its belt.  The broken belts can really be a problem
at track events, because it's possible for the non-rotating distributor
to fire a single plug 6 times per cycle while the engine's already
running plenty hot.  If it goes unnoticed, people have ended up
with one toasted cylinder....

 -Kreg Ulery
'84 Carerra

Date: Mon, 03 Jul 95 13:25:00 PST
From: Peter Barlow <PBarlow@sierrasys.com>
Subject: Re: '68 911S



Here's another vote for the likelihood of this car being a '69, potentially
sold in (and titled as a) '68.  The 68 911S didn't meet the States first big 

emissions year, so wasn't imported.  The 911L replaced it, and was an
S with the E-engine - all the trim of the S, but the 130 hp engine.  The 68
'S' in Europe was indeed a Weber car, and short wheelbase of course.
The '68 car serial numbers start with 118.  And yes, there are a few that
have made there way into the States and Canada.

All that said, the '69 S is a nice find.  A lot of people, once settled on 
the
slightly flared fenders and the fuel injection, lean towards the last of the
series ('73).  But the '69 has all the important improvements (4 vented
discs, dual circuit master cylinder, updated front suspension, actually
obtainable interior parts) with the smaller displacement,  peakier (more
entertaining?) engine.

Peter Barlow
'68 911S

Date: 03 Jul 95 16:32:55 EDT
From: "Jay S. Karolyi" <102062.710@compuserve.com>
Subject: 924 Horror Story! Ahhh!

Hello Phello Porschephiliacs,
	I witnessed a true assault on the good Doctor's name.  Thankfully
this trajedy didn't involve my 924, but it was painful just the same.  I
was travelling on I-75 into Atlanta in my '77 924 coming back to 
Charlotte from a weekend visiting my brother in Chattanooga, TN.  In my
rear view mirror I spotted a familiar silhouette, that of a 924.  I was
getting prepared to wave at the fellow 924 when I made out the electric
purple color on the car.  I also noted it was riding a bit lower than my
stock 924.  What drove up beside me was nausiating.  Not only was the 
924 painted electric purple with fishing boat sparkle paint, but it had
been lowered and shod with tiny chrome wheels with ultra low profile
tires.  It had a sizeable chunk of sheetmetal gouged out of the front
fender and door from an accident.  It had a HUGE whale tail glued (at 
least I assume it was glued, no way could the hatch survive hole 
drilling) to the hatch.  Also, white coolant smelling smoke puffed from
its LOUD exhaust.  Head gasket time!  Over the loud exhaust could be 
heard a soft boom-boom from a stereo.  
	I gave the 924 a half hearted wave but I don't know if he waved
back, the windows were tinted too dark.  I thought this kind of 
"customization" only happened to BMWs and Mercedes!  I've never see the 
"drug dealer" package applied to a Porsche!  Could this be the start of
a trend?  Has anyone else seen this gaudy 924 around the Atlanta area?
Are there any other P-cars you guys have seen this done to?  
	Anyway, at least I had an excellent time carving TN country roads
in The Bastard with my brother and his 914 2.0.  The Bastard is much
faster in the straights but he catches up in the corners.  He doesn't 
like to get behind me though, he claims my car smells!  I still need to
rebuild the six (ugh!) carbs...  Let me know if anyone has seen any other
atrocious Porsches.  Thanks!
				Jay Karolyi
'75 Fly Yellow Corvair/914 "The Bastard"
'77 Mist Green 924
'85 Forest Green VW GTI (traded with sister for the '80 Toy 'rolla while
	I replace the engine for her)

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 13:54:38 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 mystery part, cam timing

When removing my engine, a aluminum bush/spacer fell out.
it is cylindrical (actually an annulus) 3.7 cm long, 1.8 cm 
outer diam, 0.8 cm inner diam.

Can anyone tell me what it is/where it goes?

Thanks,

 -Mitch Craig - hcrms@chevron.com

p.s. Got the cams' end play and timing set Saturday.
Here's how I timed the cams:
(parts of this are in the factory workshop manual):

1. Remove all spark plugs, install rockers on #1 and #4 intake valves
   and adjust valves with cams turned so that the rocker foot is on the back
   side of the cam (away from the lobe). #1 and #4 intake valves are
   on opposite sides of the motor, on the top, rearmost end of the motor
   (The end of the engine with the crank pulley).

2. Turn the crank so that the Z1 mark on the pulley points straight up,
   in the 12:00 position, in line with the joint between the case halves.
   This is TDC.

3. Turn the cams so the the dots on their ends points straight up,
   in the 12:00 position.

4. Install timing chains, gears, dowel pins, washers, and nuts on the
   ends of the cams. Tighten the nuts (no need to get carried away,
   just tight enough to flatten the spring washers).
  
5. Pick a cam, install dial indicator on cam housing overhanging the
   intake valve (either #1 or #4, depending on which side you're doing).
   You will need a special bracket to mount the dial indicator. The probe
   of the dial indicator needs to be positioned such that it has a straight 
   shot at the valve spring retaining collar. It should contact the flat 
   surface on the top of the collar and be preloaded sufficiently (i.e.
   0.200 in) and zeroed such that when the valve opens, it will be able to
   register the required valve lift.

6. Rotate the crank 360 degrees. When you start getting close (within 45-30
   degrees), start watching the dial indicator. When the Z1 mark is aligned 
   at the the case split, check to see how far the valve has opened.  It is
   a little tricky reading the dial indicator because the needle moves
   backwards (counterclockwise) as the valve opens.  In the case of a 2.2 L
   911 T, I wanted about 0.096 in of lift.  This is different according to
   whether you have a T, E, or S.  The T has the least lift, the S has the
   most.

7. If you are not within tolerance, remove the cam nut and dowel pin,
   being careful to not disturb the position of the cam. Using the cam
   holding socket, watch the dial indicator and rotate the cam (which 
   will now rotate independently of the timing gear) very slightly as 
   needed until the correct lift is indicated on the dial indicator.
   Insert the dowel pin to lock the timing gear to the cam. Put the
   cam washer and nut back on, tighten, and double check.
  
8. Repeat for other cam.

- ---------- end ------------

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 16:52:52 -0400

Subject: Re: A/C

Tony,

I suggest you read the owners manual that came with the car. Because of the
nature of your question, I assume a limited knowledge of the subject, without
intending to be emotional. I used to be there too. A/C needs equipment these
days and is not a simple "fill it up" act. 
If you really have a mechanical interest, than the factory workshop manuals
are a must and reference.
Than join PCA and really learn to drive your car. In the mean time,
Porschephiles will have assisted you to the extend that $100 to bacame a
Patron is peanuts compared to you P-car investment.

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 95 14:00:23 PDT
From: Henrik Eriksson <henrik@chronologic.com>
Subject: Replacing oil-thermostat

I posted a while ago about my HOT running C2,

The problem is that the oil never passes the oil-thermostat,
(located just in front of the right rear fender)
so the oil never gets to the oil-cooler....
I'm going to try to replace the thermostat and the two rubber hoses
that connects to it.

A fellow p-phile heard this:
     Apparently the oil thermostat is changed from the inside the car. 
     Behind the passenger seat are two panels, one on the side and the 
     other on the floor, which need to be removed.  The mechanics called it 
     a pain in the a...  He cautioned to also change the hoses, as they do 
     tend to leak - something about German rubber.  

Anyone could verify this? and please add a little more details?
Seems like it should be changed from the outside, also
I'm not yet sure where one of the rubber hoses go...

Thanks,
Henrik
henrik@chronologic.com

ps.
Both the hose started to leak and the thermostat failed, :-(
maybe this is due to switching to synthetic oil one week before?
Again it might just be a coincidence. :-)

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 95 15:35:49 -0700
From: donr@tdnet.com (Don Rutherford)
Subject: Air conditioning unit

There is another option with the degree of pain directly related to how 
close you stay to the coast <g> on the way down.

By all reports, and personal experience, Performance Aire/Scotts Independent 
Porsche, 1885 S Santa Cruz St, Anaheim, CA 92805, 714-634-2027 are the best 
there is for 911 A/C. You might want to plan a day at Disneyland and include 
them on the trip. Only partly joking because they really are only minutes 
from Disneyland/Angel Stadium/The Pond etc.

>I just recently purchased my 911s a couple of months ago.  It came with a
non-functioning air conditioning unit.  It's getting quite hot now since the
summer is finally here and I was just wondering how much it would cost to
fix this thing.  If I did fix it, would it last and would it be worth it?  I
was thinking of driving down to LA from Vancouver (2500 miles) next month
and I would think that I'd be boiling in my black car with black leather
seats if I didn't have air con bracket to mount the dial indicator. The probe
   of the dial indicator needs to be positioned such that it has a straight 
   shot at the valve spring retaining collar. It should contact the flat 
   surface on the top of the collar and be preloaded sufficiently (i.e.
   0.200 in) and zeroed such that when the valve opens, it will be able to
   register the required valve lift.

6. Rotate the crank 360 degrees. When you start getting close (within 45-30
   degrees), start watching the dial indicator. When the Z1 mark is aligned 
   at the the case split, check to see how far the valve has opened.  It is
   a little tricky reading the dial indicator because the needle moves
   backwards (counterclockwise) as the valve opens.  In the case of a 2.2 L
   911 T, I wanted about 0.096 in of lift.  This is different according to
   whether you have a T, E, or S.  The T has the least lift, the S has the
   most.

7. If you are not within tolerance, remove the cam nut and dowel pin,
   being careful to not disturb the position of the cam. Using the cam
   holding socket, watch the dial indicator and rotate the cam (which 
   will now rotate independently of the timing gear) very slightly as 
   needed until the correct lift is indicated on the dial indicator.
   Insert the dowel pin to lock the timing gear to the cam. Put the
   cam washer and nut back on, tighten, and double check.
  
8. Repeat for other cam.

- ---------- end ------------

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 16:52:52 -0400
From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: Re: A/C

Tony,

I suggest you read the owners manual that came with the car. Because of the
nature of your question, I assume a limited knowledge of the subject, without
intending to be emotional. I used to be there too. A/C needs equipment these
days and is not a simple "fill it up" act. 
If you really have a mechanical interest, than the factory workshop manuals
are a must and reference.
Than join PCA and really learn to drive your car. In the mean time,
Porschephiles will have assisted you to the extend that $100 to bacame a
Patron is peanuts compared to you P-car investment.

Welcome !

Bart D (AllPorsche@aol.com)
'87 Carrera Cabriolet
'87 Carrera Cabriolet Factory Turbo look
'86 930 -under negotiation-
'74 914 racecar
'74 914/4 growing up to a 914/6
'73 914 2.0
'93 Grand Cherokee Ltd.

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 95 14:00:23 PDT
From: Henrik Eriksson <henrik@chronologic.com>
Subject: Replacing oil-thermostat

I posted a while ago about my HOT running C2,

The problem is that the oil never passes the oil-thermostat,
(located just in front of the right rear fender)
so the oil never gets to the oil-cooler....
I'm going to try to replace the thermostat and the two rubber hoses
that connects to it.

A fellow p-phile heard this:
     Apparently the oil thermostat is changed from the inside the car. 
     Behind the passenger seat are two panels, one on the side and the 
     other on the floor, which need to be removed.  The mechanics called it 
     a pain in the a...  He cautioned to also change the hoses, as they do 
     tend to leak - something about German rubber.  

Anyone could verify this? and please add a little more details?
Seems like it should be changed from the outside, also
I'm not yet sure where one of the rubber hoses go...

Thanks,
Henrik
henrik@chronologic.com

ps.
Both the hose started to leak and the thermostat failed, :-(
maybe this is due to switching to synthetic oil one week before?
Again it might just be a coincidence. :-)

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 19:20:19 -0400
From: Phyl346@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 starting prob

Just had the same thing on my '83 944.  It's obviously the starter solenoid
which luckily is VERY easy to replace.  Shop around,  many people will say
you can't get just the solenoid but I got mine from a general
alternator/starter rebuild firm for $34.  It's working great!!!!


Phil Carr
Austin, TX
'83 944
'65 M.G. Midget
'70 BMW R60/5

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 21:20:38 -0400
From: RonS993@aol.com
Subject: Boing!

Hunter,
I once owned an early 944 that did the same sort of thing - made a strange
metallic sort of noise when the door was shut, except mine did it only when
hot.  It turned out to be a piece of heat shielding (I'm not sure which one
exactly - this is what the dealer mechanic told me) in the vicinity of the
catalytic converter.  The dealer just loosened and retightened the shielding,
and no more boing.

Ron

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 18:38:32 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 cam sprockets

I wrote: 

> Got the cams' end play and timing set Saturday.

As was pointed out,

>> The end play on the 911 cams is not adjustable, what were you adjusting?
 
Sorry, I was adjusting the axial position of the cam sprockets 
(selecting the correct number of spacers), making sure that the
cam sprockets were properly aligned with the intermediate shaft
sprockets.

 -Mitch

From: Maestro103@aol.com

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 00:29:51 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: aftermarket FI

At 04:18 PM 7/3/95 -0400, CAcuff@aol.com wrote:
>I am about to start a 914 project that may include the addition of an
>aftermarket FI system to my 2.0 engine.
>
>Does anyone have any experience with the TMW throttle bodies or an injection
>control system such as the Haltech F7.

Cory,

The TWM (not TMW) throttle bodies are OK but not great.  We put a set on
a customer car a while back.  Well, we put the second set on.  The first
set got sent back to TWM because of binding of the butterflies to the
bodies, a problem which TWM described as being "not uncommon."  They were
very good about it, and their package is *very* cost-effective when
compared with, say, a nice guillotine set-up.

We've also done a handful of cars with the F7 system.  It works fine.
The monitoring/programming software leaves a lot to be desired in terms of,
well in terms of a lot of things.  But it is more than adequate to getting
the job done, assuming a) you have a dyno (engine or chassis), and b) you
have a high-speed, wide-range exhaust gas monitor.  Both of which are major
investments.

Kevin

and it wouldn't accept any Freon". He suggested I take it to the Porsche
shop because it must be something "peculiar to Porsches".

problems section is not done yet. The fact that there *is* an A/C section
makes me think there may be some common problems. I've made it a point to
run the system about 20 minutes a month during the winter, as Porsche
recommends.
Any tips, clues or hints would be greatly appreciated.

Date: Mon, 03 Jul 95 13:25:00 PST
From: Peter Barlow <PBarlow@sierrasys.com>
Subject: Re: '68 911S



Here's another vote for the likelihood of this car being a '69, potentially
sold in (and titled as a) '68.  The 68 911S didn't meet the States first big 

emissions year, so wasn't imported.  The 911L replaced it, and was an
S with the E-engine - all the trim of the S, but the 130 hp engine.  The 68
'S' in Europe was indeed a Weber car, and short wheelbase of course.
The '68 car serial numbers start with 118.  And yes, there are a few that
have made there way into the States and Canada.

All that said, the '69 S is a nice find.  A lot of people, once settled on 
the
slightly flared fenders and the fuel injection, lean towards the last of the
series ('73).  But the '69 has all the important improvements (4 vented
discs, dual circuit master cylinder, updated front suspension, actually
obtainable interior parts) with the smaller displacement,  peakier (more
entertaining?) engine.

Peter Barlow
'68 911S

------------------------------

Date: 03 Jul 95 16:32:55 EDT
From: "Jay S. Karolyi" <102062.710@compuserve.com>
Subject: 924 Horror Story! Ahhh!

Hello Phello Porschephiliacs,
	I witnessed a true assault on the good Doctor's name.  Thankfully
this trajedy didn't involve my 924, but it was painful just the same.  I
was travelling on I-75 into Atlanta in my '77 924 coming back to 
Charlotte from a weekend visiting my brother in Chattanooga, TN.  In my
rear view mirror I spotted a familiar silhouette, that of a 924.  I was
getting prepared to wave at the fellow 924 when I made out the electric
purple color on the car.  I also noted it was riding a bit lower than my
stock 924.  What drove up beside me was nausiating.  Not only was the 
924 painted electric purple with fishing boat sparkle paint, but it had
been lowered and shod with tiny chrome wheels with ultra low profile
tires.  It had a sizeable chunk of sheetmetal gouged out of the front
fender and door from an accident.  It had a HUGE whale tail glued (at 
least I assume it was glued, no way could the hatch survive hole 
drilling) to the hatch.  Also, white coolant smelling smoke puffed from
its LOUD exhaust.  Head gasket time!  Over the loud exhaust could be 
heard a soft boom-boom from a stereo.  
	I gave the 924 a half hearted wave but I don't know if he waved
back, the windows were tinted too dark.  I thought this kind of 
"customization" only happened to BMWs and Mercedes!  I've never see the 
"drug dealer" package applied to a Porsche!  Could this be the start of
a trend?  Has anyone else seen this gaudy 924 around the Atlanta area?
Are there any other P-cars you guys have seen this done to?  
	Anyway, at least I had an excellent time carving TN country roads
in The Bastard with my brother and his 914 2.0.  The Bastard is much
faster in the straights but he catches up in the corners.  He doesn't 
like to get behind me though, he claims my car smells!  I still need to
rebuild the six (ugh!) carbs...  Let me know if anyone has seen any other
atrocious Porsches.  Thanks!
				Jay Karolyi
'75 Fly Yellow Corvair/914 "The Bastard"
'77 Mist Green 924
'85 Forest Green VW GTI (traded with sister for the '80 Toy 'rolla while
	I replace the engine for her)

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 13:54:38 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 mystery part, cam timing

When removing my engine, a aluminum bush/spacer fell out.
it is cylindrical (actually an annulus) 3.7 cm long, 1.8 cm 
outer diam, 0.8 cm inner diam.

Can anyone tell me what it is/where it goes?

Thanks,

 -Mitch Craig - hcrms@chevron.com

p.s. Got the cams' end play and timing set Saturday.
Here's how I timed the cams:
(parts of this are in the factory workshop manual):

1. Remove all spark plugs, install rockers on #1 and #4 intake valves
   and adjust valves with cams turned so that the rocker foot is on the back
   side of the cam (away from the lobe). #1 and #4 intake valves are
   on opposite sides of the motor, on the top, rearmost end of the motor
   (The end of the engine with the crank pulley).

2. Turn the crank so that the Z1 mark on the pulley points straight up,
   in the 12:00 position, in line with the joint between the case halves.
   This is TDC.

3. Turn the cams so the the dots on their ends points straight up,
   in the 12:00 position.

4. Install timing chains, gears, dowel pins, washers, and nuts on the
   ends of the cams. Tighten the nuts (no need to get carried away,
   just tight enough to flatten the spring washers).
  
5. Pick a cam, install dial indicator on cam housing overhanging the
   intake valve (either #1 or #4, depending on which side you're doing).
   You will need a specialditioning.

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 19:20:19 -0400
From: Phyl346@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 starting prob

Just had the same thing on my '83 944.  It's obviously the starter solenoid
which luckily is VERY easy to replace.  Shop around,  many people will say
you can't get just the solenoid but I got mine from a general
alternator/starter rebuild firm for $34.  It's working great!!!!


Phil Carr
Austin, TX
'83 944
'65 M.G. Midget
'70 BMW R60/5

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 21:20:38 -0400
From: RonS993@aol.com
Subject: Boing!

Hunter,
I once owned an early 944 that did the same sort of thing - made a strange
metallic sort of noise when the door was shut, except mine did it only when
hot.  It turned out to be a piece of heat shielding (I'm not sure which one
exactly - this is what the dealer mechanic told me) in the vicinity of the
catalytic converter.  The dealer just loosened and retightened the shielding,
and no more boing.

Ron


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 18:38:32 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 cam sprockets

I wrote: 

> Got the cams' end play and timing set Saturday.

As was pointed out,

>> The end play on the 911 cams is not adjustable, what were you adjusting?
 
Sorry, I was adjusting the axial position of the cam sprockets 
(selecting the correct number of spacers), making sure that the
cam sprockets were properly aligned with the intermediate shaft
sprockets.

 -Mitch

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 00:29:51 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: aftermarket FI

At 04:18 PM 7/3/95 -0400, CAcuff@aol.com wrote:
>I am about to start a 914 project that may include the addition of an
>aftermarket FI system to my 2.0 engine.
>
>Does anyone have any experience with the TMW throttle bodies or an injection
>control system such as the Haltech F7.

Cory,

The TWM (not TMW) throttle bodies are OK but not great.  We put a set on
a customer car a while back.  Well, we put the second set on.  The first
set got sent back to TWM because of binding of the butterflies to the
bodies, a problem which TWM described as being "not uncommon."  They were
very good about it, and their package is *very* cost-effective when
compared with, say, a nice guillotine set-up.

We've also done a handful of cars with the F7 system.  It works fine.
The monitoring/programming software leaves a lot to be desired in terms of,
well in terms of a lot of things.  But it is more than adequate to getting
the job done, assuming a) you have a dyno (engine or chassis), and b) you
have a high-speed, wide-range exhaust gas monitor.  Both of which are major
investments.

Kevin

>combination on an early 911 before.

I have seen this combo on a '77 911.  Correct me if I'm wrong (that goes
without saying on this list), but I believe the flares were the same from
'69 to '77.

The thing is, some cars will tolerate more tire/wheel than others.  The
car I saw had 16x7s with 205/55s in the rear and they DIDN'T RUB.  The
fender lips weren't even rolled.  I have also seen 225/50s on 15x7s on the
rear.  I have to imagine that would take some effort to make them the 
225s fit.

Your best bet is a 7x15 wheel with 205/60s.  It is not a sure thing, but this
should fit in the rear.  The fronts are a little more wide open.  I would
decide what will fit in the rear and size the fronts accordingly (don't put
195/50s on 6x15s in the rear and then put 205/55s on 7x16s up front -
T*d already tried that):>). 

Good luck and HTH,

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911



------------------------------

Date: 30 Jun 1995 09:30:41 -0400
From: "Kreg Ulery" <kdu@aloft.att.com>
Subject: Re: 911 1990 C4 Resolved stu

        Reply to:   RE>911 1990 C4 Resolved studdering

>RedNineCo suggested it could be the belt between the two distributors
>and that was exactly what it was.  This was causing only one plug per 
>cylinder to fire.  BTW, there were not any dash lights to indicate there 
>was actually a problem.
......

>warranty (5yrs,50k miles) still applies.  And low and behold - it was 
>covered.  Jim Ellis said it would be a $600 repair otherwise.  Probably 
>could have been done cheaper if you just replaced the belt - but they 
>replaced the whole distributor.

At the factory, they actually match belts to the distrubutors. I've
been told that they have several belt sizes (all withing just a few
fractions of a mm of each other), and they individually size each
distributor to its belt.  The broken belts can really be a problem
at track events, because it's possible for the non-rotating distributor
to fire a single plug 6 times per cycle while the engine's already
running plenty hot.  If it goes unnoticed, people have ended up
with one toasted cylinder....

 -Kreg Ulery
'84 Carerra

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 18:40:49 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 73 911:  Wheel & Tire Combinations

>I would like to run  6x16/7x16 Fuchs, however I have never seen that 
>combination on an early 911 before.

I have seen this combo on a '77 911.  Correct me if I'm wrong (that goes
without saying on this list), but I believe the flares were the same from
'69 to '77.

The thing is, some cars will tolerate more tire/wheel than others.  The
car I saw had 16x7s with 205/55s in the rear and they DIDN'T RUB.  The
fender lips weren't even rolled.  I have also seen 225/50s on 15x7s on the
rear.  I have to imagine that would take some effort to make them the 
225s fit.

Your best bet is a 7x15 wheel with 205/60s.  It is not a sure thing, but this
should fit in the rear.  The fronts are a little more wide open.  I would
decide what will fit in the rear and size the fronts accordingly (don't put
195/50s on 6x15s in the rear and then put 205/55s on 7x16s up front -
T*d already tried that):>). 

Good luck and HTH,

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: 30 Jun 1995 09:30:41 -0400
From: "Kreg Ulery" <kdu@aloft.att.com>
Subject: Re: 911 1990 C4 Resolved stu

        Reply to:   RE>911 1990 C4 Resolved studdering

>RedNineCo suggested it could be the belt between the two distributors
>and that was exactly what it was.  This was causing only one plug per 
>cylinder to fire.  BTW, there were not any dash lights to indicate there 
>was actually a problem.
......

>warranty (5yrs,50k miles) still applies.  And low and behold - it was 
>covered.  Jim Ellis said it would be a $600 repair otherwise.  Probably 
>could have been done cheaper if you just replaced the belt - but they 
>replaced the whole distributor.

At the factory, they actually match belts to the distrubutors. I've
been told that they have several belt sizes (all withing just a few
fractions of a mm of each other), and they individually size each
distributor to its belt.  The broken belts can really be a problem
at track events, because it's possible for the non-rotating distributor
to fire a single plug 6 times per cycle while the engine's already
running plenty hot.  If it goes unnoticed, people have ended up
with one toasted cylinder....

 -Kreg Ulery
'84 Carerra

the A/C. Nothing happened...

told me that the system "held vacuum OK, but we tried recharging it 3 times
and it wouldn't accept any Freon". He suggested I take it to the Porsche
shop because it must be something "peculiar to Porsches".
Anybody heard of this before? I've checked the 944 FAQ, and the A/C
problems section is not done yet. The fact that there *is* an A/C section
makes me think there may be some common problems. I've made it a point to
run the system about 20 minutes a month during the winter, as Porsche
recommends.
Any tips, clues or hints would be greatly appreciated.

Date: Mon, 03 Jul 95 13:25:00 PST
From: Peter Barlow <PBarlow@sierrasys.com>
Subject: Re: '68 911S



Here's another vote for the likelihood of this car being a '69, potentially
sold in (and titled as a) '68.  The 68 911S didn't meet the States first big 

emissions year, so wasn't imported.  The 911L replaced it, and was an
S with the E-engine - all the trim of the S, but the 130 hp engine.  The 68
'S' in Europe was indeed a Weber car, and short wheelbase of course.
The '68 car serial numbers start with 118.  And yes, there are a few that
have made there way into the States and Canada.

All that said, the '69 S is a nice find.  A lot of people, once settled on 
the
slightly flared fenders and the fuel injection, lean towards the last of the
series ('73).  But the '69 has all the important improvements (4 vented
discs, dual circuit master cylinder, updated front suspension, actually
obtainable interior parts) with the smaller displacement,  peakier (more
entertaining?) engine.

Peter Barlow
'68 911S

------------------------------

Date: 03 Jul 95 16:32:55 EDT
From: "Jay S. Karolyi" <102062.710@compuserve.com>
Subject: 924 Horror Story! Ahhh!

Hello Phello Porschephiliacs,
	I witnessed a true assault on the good Doctor's name.  Thankfully
this trajedy didn't involve my 924, but it was painful just the same.  I
was travelling on I-75 into Atlanta in my '77 924 coming back to 
Charlotte from a weekend visiting my brother in Chattanooga, TN.  In my
rear view mirror I spotted a familiar silhouette, that of a 924.  I was
getting prepared to wave at the fellow 924 when I made out the electric
purple color on the car.  I also noted it was riding a bit lower than my
stock 924.  What drove up beside me was nausiating.  Not only was the 
924 painted electric purple with fishing boat sparkle paint, but it had
been lowered and shod with tiny chrome wheels with ultra low profile
tires.  It had a sizeable chunk of sheetmetal gouged out of the front
fender and door from an accident.  It had a HUGE whale tail glued (at 
least I assume it was glued, no way could the hatch survive hole 
drilling) to the hatch.  Also, white coolant smelling smoke puffed from
its LOUD exhaust.  Head gasket time!  Over the loud exhaust could be 
heard a soft boom-boom from a stereo.  
	I gave the 924 a half hearted wave but I don't know if he waved
back, the windows were tinted too dark.  I thought this kind of 
"customization" only happened to BMWs and Mercedes!  I've never see the 
"drug dealer" package applied to a Porsche!  Could this be the start of
a trend?  Has anyone else seen this gaudy 924 around the Atlanta area?
Are there any other P-cars you guys have seen this done to?  
	Anyway, at least I had an excellent time carving TN country roads
in The Bastard with my brother and his 914 2.0.  The Bastard is much
faster in the straights but he catches up in the corners.  He doesn't 
like to get behind me though, he claims my car smells!  I still need to
rebuild the six (ugh!) carbs...  Let me know if anyone has seen any other
atrocious Porsches.  Thanks!
				Jay Karolyi
'75 Fly Yellow Corvair/914 "The Bastard"
'77 Mist Green 924
'85 Forest Green VW GTI (traded with sister for the '80 Toy 'rolla while
	I replace the engine for her)

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 13:54:38 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 mystery part, cam timing

When removing my engine, a aluminum bush/spacer fell out.
it is cylindrical (actually an annulus) 3.7 cm long, 1.8 cm 
outer diam, 0.8 cm inner diam.

Can anyone tell me what it is/where it goes?

Thanks,

 -Mitch Craig - hcrms@chevron.com

p.s. Got the cams' end play and timing set Saturday.
Here's how I timed the cams:
(parts of this are in the factory workshop manual):

1. Remove all spark plugs, install rockers on #1 and #4 intake valves
   and adjust valves with cams turned so that the rocker foot is on the back
   side of the cam (away from the lobe). #1 and #4 intake valves are
   on opposite sides of the motor, on the top, rearmost end of the motor
   (The end of the engine with the crank pulley).

2. Turn the crank so that the Z1 mark on the pulley points straight up,
   in the 12:00 position, in line with the joint between the case halves.
   This is TDC.

3. Turn the cams so the the dots on their ends points straight up,
   in the 12:00 position.

4. Install timing chains, gears, dowel pins, washers, and nuts on the
   ends of the cams. Tighten the nuts (no need to get carried away,
   just tight enough to flatten the spring washers).
  
5. Pick a cam, install dial indicator on cam housing overhanging the
   intake valve (either #1 or #4, depending on which side you're doing).
   You will need a special bracket to mount the dial indicator. The probe
   of the dial indicator needs to be positioned such that it has a straight 
   shot at the valve spring retaining collar. It should contact the flat 
   surface on the top of the collar and be preloaded sufficiently (i.e.
   0.200 in) and zeroed such that when the valve opens, it will be able to
   register the required valve lift.

6. Rotate the crank 360 degrees. When you start getting close (within 45-30
   degrees), start watching the dial indicator. When the Z1 mark is aligned 
   at the the case split, check to see how far the valve has opened.  It is
   a little tricky reading the dial indicator because the needle moves
   backwards (counterclockwise) as the valve opens.  In the case of a 2.2 L
   911 T, I wanted about 0.096 in of lift.  This is different according to
   whether you have a T, E, or S.  The T has the least lift, the S has the
   most.

7. If you are not within tolerance, remove the cam nut and dowel pin,
   being careful to not disturb the position of the cam. Using the cam
   holding socket, watch the dial indicator and rotate the cam (which 
   will now rotate independently of the timing gear) very slightly as 
   needed until the correct lift is indicated on the dial indicator.
   Insert the dowel pin to lock the timing gear to the cam. Put the
   cam washer and nut back on, tighten, and double check.
  
8. Repeat for other cam.

- ---------- end ------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 16:52:52 -0400
From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: Re: A/C

Tony,

I suggest you read the owners manual that came with the car. Because of the
nature of your question, I assume a limited knowledge of the subject, without
intending to be emotional. I used to be there too. A/C needs equipment these
days and is not a simple "fill it up" act. 
If you really have a mechanical interest, than the factory workshop manuals
are a must and reference.
Than join PCA and really learn to drive your car. In the mean time,
Porschephiles will have assisted you to the extend that $100 to bacame a
Patron is peanuts compared to you P-car investment.

Welcome !

Bart D (AllPorsche@aol.com)
'87 Carrera Cabriolet
'87 Carrera Cabriolet Factory Turbo look

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 95 14:00:23 PDT
From: Henrik Eriksson <henrik@chronologic.com>
Subject: Replacing oil-thermostat

I posted a while ago about my HOT running C2,

The problem is that the oil never passes the oil-thermostat,
(located just in front of the right rear fender)
so the oil never gets to the oil-cooler....
I'm going to try to replace the thermostat and the two rubber hoses
that connects to it.

A fellow p-phile heard this:
     Apparently the oil thermostat is changed from the inside the car. 
     Behind the passenger seat are two panels, one on the side and the 
     other on the floor, which need to be removed.  The mechanics called it 
     a pain in the a...  He cautioned to also change the hoses, as they do 
     tend to leak - something about German rubber.  

Anyone could verify this? and please add a little more details?
Seems like it should be changed from the outside, also
I'm not yet sure where one of the rubber hoses go...

Thanks,
Henrik
henrik@chronologic.com

ps.
Both the hose started to leak and the thermostat failed, :-(
maybe this is due to switching to synthetic oil one week before?
Again it might just be a coincidence. :-)

Am new to Porsche; however I do like a hands on approach. I am a member 
of PCA, Northern NJ chapter. I assumed there must be a valve to add the 
freon and if I knew where it was I could tackle that before seeking 
service. I know there are compressors and what have you that are also 
involved which I don't plan to get involved with.

I checked the owners manual and it did not say where to fill her up, as 
it were. The manual does not tell you how to check the transmission fluid 
level?? I've been involved with cvars, as a hobby, since the early '70s.

So far I've replaced the sunroof cables, belts and done oil cxhanges.

Thanks for the Welcome.

Tom

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 95 15:35:49 -0700
From: donr@tdnet.com (Don Rutherford)
Subject: Air conditioning unit

There is another option with the degree of pain directly related to how 
close you stay to the coast <g> on the way down.

By all reports, and personal experience, Performance Aire/Scotts Independent 
Porsche, 1885 S Santa Cruz St, Anaheim, CA 92805, 714-634-2027 are the best 
there is for 911 A/C. You might want to plan a day at Disneyland and include 
them on the trip. Only partly joking because they really are only minutes 
from Disneyland/Angel Stadium/The Pond etc.

>I just recently purchased my 911s a couple of months ago.  It came with a
non-functioning air conditioning unit.  It's getting quite hot now since the
summer is finally here and I was just wondering how much it would cost to
fix this thing.  If I did fix it, would it last and would it be worth it?  I
was thinking of driving down to LA from Vancouver (2500 miles) next month
and I would think that I'd be boiling in my black car with black leather
seats if I didn't have air con bracket to mount the dial indicator. The probe
   of the dial indicator needs to be positioned such that it has a straight 
   shot at the valve spring retaining collar. It should contact the flat 
   surface on the top of the collar and be preloaded sufficiently (i.e.
   0.200 in) and zeroed such that when the valve opens, it will be able to
   register the required valve lift.

6. Rotate the crank 360 degrees. When you start getting close (within 45-30
   degrees), start watching the dial indicator. When the Z1 mark is aligned 
   at the the case split, check to see how far the valve has opened.  It is
   a little tricky reading the dial indicator because the needle moves
   backwards (counterclockwise) as the valve opens.  In the case of a 2.2 L
   911 T, I wanted about 0.096 in of lift.  This is different according to
   whether you have a T, E, or S.  The T has the least lift, the S has the
   most.

7. If you are not within tolerance, remove the cam nut and dowel pin,
   being careful to not disturb the position of the cam. Using the cam
   holding socket, watch the dial indicator and rotate the cam (which 
   will now rotate independently of the timing gear) very slightly as 
   needed until the correct lift is indicated on the dial indicator.
   Insert the dowel pin to lock the timing gear to the cam. Put the
   cam washer and nut back on, tighten, and double check.
  
8. Repeat for other cam.

- ---------- end ------------

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 16:52:52 -0400
From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: Re: A/C

Tony,

I suggest you read the owners manual that came with the car. Because of the
nature of your question, I assume a limited knowledge of the subject, without
intending to be emotional. I used to be there too. A/C needs equipment these
days and is not a simple "fill it up" act. 
If you really have a mechanical interest, than the factory workshop manuals
are a must and reference.
Than join PCA and really learn to drive your car. In the mean time,
Porschephiles will have assisted you to the extend that $100 to bacame a
Patron is peanuts compared to you P-car investment.

Welcome !

Bart D (AllPorsche@aol.com)

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 95 14:00:23 PDT
From: Henrik Eriksson <henrik@chronologic.com>
Subject: Replacing oil-thermostat

I posted a while ago about my HOT running C2,

The problem is that the oil never passes the oil-thermostat,
(located just in front of the right rear fender)
so the oil never gets to the oil-cooler....
I'm going to try to replace the thermostat and the two rubber hoses
that connects to it.

A fellow p-phile heard this:
     Apparently the oil thermostat is changed from the inside the car. 
     Behind the passenger seat are two panels, one on the side and the 
     other on the floor, which need to be removed.  The mechanics called it 
     a pain in the a...  He cautioned to also change the hoses, as they do 
     tend to leak - something about German rubber.  

Anyone could verify this? and please add a little more details?
Seems like it should be changed from the outside, also
I'm not yet sure where one of the rubber hoses go...

Thanks,
Henrik
henrik@chronologic.com

ps.
Both the hose started to leak and the thermostat failed, :-(
maybe this is due to switching to synthetic oil one week before?
Again it might just be a coincidence. :-)

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 19:20:19 -0400
From: Phyl346@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 starting prob

Just had the same thing on my '83 944.  It's obviously the starter solenoid
which luckily is VERY easy to replace.  Shop around,  many people will say
you can't get just the solenoid but I got mine from a general
alternator/starter rebuild firm for $34.  It's working great!!!!


Phil Carr
Austin, TX

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 21:20:38 -0400
From: RonS993@aol.com
Subject: Boing!

Hunter,
I once owned an early 944 that did the same sort of thing - made a strange
metallic sort of noise when the door was shut, except mine did it only when
hot.  It turned out to be a piece of heat shielding (I'm not sure which one
exactly - this is what the dealer mechanic told me) in the vicinity of the
catalytic converter.  The dealer just loosened and retightened the shielding,
and no more boing.

Ron

sprockets.

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 00:29:51 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: aftermarket FI

At 04:18 PM 7/3/95 -0400, CAcuff@aol.com wrote:
>I am about to start a 914 project that may include the addition of an
>aftermarket FI system to my 2.0 engine.
>
>Does anyone have any experience with the TMW throttle bodies or an injection
>control system such as the Haltech F7.

Cory,

The TWM (not TMW) throttle bodies are OK but not great.  We put a set on
a customer car a while back.  Well, we put the second set on.  The first
set got sent back to TWM because of binding of the butterflies to the
bodies, a problem which TWM described as being "not uncommon."  They were
very good about it, and their package is *very* cost-effective when
compared with, say, a nice guillotine set-up.

We've also done a handful of cars with the F7 system.  It works fine.
The monitoring/programming software leaves a lot to be desired in terms of,
well in terms of a lot of things.  But it is more than adequate to getting
the job done, assuming a) you have a dyno (engine or chassis), and b) you
have a high-speed, wide-range exhaust gas monitor.  Both of which are major
investments.

Kevin

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 18:40:49 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 73 911:  Wheel & Tire Combinations

>I would like to run  6x16/7x16 Fuchs, however I have never seen that 
>combination on an early 911 before.

I have seen this combo on a '77 911.  Correct me if I'm wrong (that goes
without saying on this list), but I believe the flares were the same from
'69 to '77.

The thing is, some cars will tolerate more tire/wheel than others.  The
car I saw had 16x7s with 205/55s in the rear and they DIDN'T RUB.  The
fender lips weren't even rolled.  I have also seen 225/50s on 15x7s on the
rear.  I have to imagine that would take some effort to make them the 
225s fit.

Your best bet is a 7x15 wheel with 205/60s.  It is not a sure thing, but this
should fit in the rear.  The fronts are a little more wide open.  I would
decide what will fit in the rear and size the fronts accordingly (don't put
195/50s on 6x15s in the rear and then put 205/55s on 7x16s up front -
T*d already tried that):>). 

Good luck and HTH,

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911



------------------------------

Date: 30 Jun 1995 09:30:41 -0400
From: "Kreg Ulery" <kdu@aloft.att.com>
Subject: Re: 911 1990 C4 Resolved stu

        Reply to:   RE>911 1990 C4 Resolved studdering

>RedNineCo suggested it could be the belt between the two distributors
>and that was exactly what it was.  This was causing only one plug per 
>cylinder to fire.  BTW, there were not any dash lights to indicate there 
>was actually a problem.
......

>warranty (5yrs,50k miles) still applies.  And low and behold - it was 
>covered.  Jim Ellis said it would be a $600 repair otherwise.  Probably 
>could have been done cheaper if you just replaced the belt - but they 
>replaced the whole distributor.

At the factory, they actually match belts to the distrubutors. I've
been told that they have several belt sizes (all withing just a few
fractions of a mm of each other), and they individually size each
distributor to its belt.  The broken belts can really be a problem
at track events, because it's possible for the non-rotating distributor
to fire a single plug 6 times per cycle while the engine's already
running plenty hot.  If it goes unnoticed, people have ended up
with one toasted cylinder....

 -Kreg Ulery
'84 Carerra

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 19:20:19 -0400
From: Phyl346@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 starting prob

Just had the same thing on my '83 944.  It's obviously the starter solenoid
which luckily is VERY easy to replace.  Shop around,  many people will say
you can't get just the solenoid but I got mine from a general
alternator/starter rebuild firm for $34.  It's working great!!!!


Phil Carr
Austin, TX
'83 944
'65 M.G. Midget
'70 BMW R60/5

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 21:20:38 -0400
From: RonS993@aol.com
Subject: Boing!

Hunter,
I once owned an early 944 that did the same sort of thing - made a strange
metallic sort of noise when the door was shut, except mine did it only when
hot.  It turned out to be a piece of heat shielding (I'm not sure which one
exactly - this is what the dealer mechanic told me) in the vicinity of the
catalytic converter.  The dealer just loosened and retightened the shielding,
and no more boing.

Ron

Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 18:38:32 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 cam sprockets

I wrote: 

> Got the cams' end play and timing set Saturday.

As was pointed out,

>> The end play on the 911 cams is not adjustable, what were you adjusting?
 
Sorry, I was adjusting the axial position of the cam sprockets 
(selecting the correct number of spacers), making sure that the
cam sprockets were properly aligned with the intermediate shaft
sprockets.

don't think it has anything to do with the engine.

later and there seemed to be no slippage, but the car had cooled off.  Could

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 00:29:51 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: aftermarket FI

At 04:18 PM 7/3/95 -0400, CAcuff@aol.com wrote:
>I am about to start a 914 project that may include the addition of an
>aftermarket FI system to my 2.0 engine.
>
>Does anyone have any experience with the TMW throttle bodies or an injection
>control system such as the Haltech F7.

Cory,

The TWM (not TMW) throttle bodies are OK but not great.  We put a set on
a customer car a while back.  Well, we put the second set on.  The first
set got sent back to TWM because of binding of the butterflies to the
bodies, a problem which TWM described as being "not uncommon."  They were
very good about it, and their package is *very* cost-effective when
compared with, say, a nice guillotine set-up.

We've also done a handful of cars with the F7 system.  It works fine.
The monitoring/programming software leaves a lot to be desired in terms of,
well in terms of a lot of things.  But it is more than adequate to getting
the job done, assuming a) you have a dyno (engine or chassis), and b) you
have a high-speed, wide-range exhaust gas monitor.  Both of which are major
investments.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 18:40:49 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 73 911:  Wheel & Tire Combinations

>I would like to run  6x16/7x16 Fuchs, however I have never seen that 
>combination on an early 911 before.

I have seen this combo on a '77 911.  Correct me if I'm wrong (that goes
without saying on this list), but I believe the flares were the same from
'69 to '77.

The thing is, some cars will tolerate more tire/wheel than others.  The
car I saw had 16x7s with 205/55s in the rear and they DIDN'T RUB.  The
fender lips weren't even rolled.  I have also seen 225/50s on 15x7s on the
rear.  I have to imagine that would take some effort to make them the 
225s fit.

Your best bet is a 7x15 wheel with 205/60s.  It is not a sure thing, but this
should fit in the rear.  The fronts are a little more wide open.  I would
decide what will fit in the rear and size the fronts accordingly (don't put
195/50s on 6x15s in the rear and then put 205/55s on 7x16s up front -
T*d already tried that):>). 

Good luck and HTH,

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911



------------------------------

Date: 30 Jun 1995 09:30:41 -0400
From: "Kreg Ulery" <kdu@aloft.att.com>
Subject: Re: 911 1990 C4 Resolved stu

        Reply to:   RE>911 1990 C4 Resolved studdering

>RedNineCo suggested it could be the belt between the two distributors
>and that was exactly what it was.  This was causing only one plug per 
>cylinder to fire.  BTW, there were not any dash lights to indicate there 
>was actually a problem.
......

>warranty (5yrs,50k miles) still applies.  And low and behold - it was 
>covered.  Jim Ellis said it would be a $600 repair otherwise.  Probably 
>could have been done cheaper if you just replaced the belt - but they 
>replaced the whole distributor.

At the factory, they actually match belts to the distrubutors. I've
been told that they have several belt sizes (all withing just a few
fractions of a mm of each other), and they individually size each
distributor to its belt.  The broken belts can really be a problem
at track events, because it's possible for the non-rotating distributor
to fire a single plug 6 times per cycle while the engine's already
running plenty hot.  If it goes unnoticed, people have ended up
with one toasted cylinder....

 -Kreg Ulery
'84 Carerra

Porschephiles #1527                         Tue Jul 4 02:00:10 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 3 Jul 95 9:05:43 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Theft recoveries and hopeful bargains


>While perusing one of those autotrader magazines I came across several full
>page ads from places that sell damaged vehicles.  My question is this, I
>already know that water damaged vehicles are ok if you like electrical
>problems, but what about theft recovery?  It seems to me that these would be
>even better bargains.  What are the negatives about these vehicles?  What is
>typically missing from them?  I can guess that maybe a radio and/or some
>trim pieces, but is there usually any substantial missing items (i.e.
>Engine, transmission, chassis, etc.)?

>Adam

   A theft recovery could be the best or the worst....if you get one that
 is really stripped of engine, tranny, interior, you'd better have another
 wrecked car to get parts from;  otherwise you'll be nickle and dimed
 into oblivion. Most salvage yards could make money parting out whole,
 complete cars (since the sum is greater than the whole if you could sell
 everything) and not a part is cheap.

   Usually thieves are very rude, and don't bother to use wrenches to get
 things loose; a lot of theft recoveries have been hacked and replacement
 of electrical harnesses, fuel lines, etc with a hacksaw or cutting torch
 or sledge becomes very inconvenient to us hobbyists...Even a complete,
 recovered car usually comes back in dented enough to require full repaint.

    Bottom line; there are few bargains anywhere in the car world. Once in
 a while you'll find an owner who will give away his car (I just missed
 buying a 2 year old not-running 930 for $3800 once...) but in the salvage
 world you'll find savvy people who eek out a living dealing with damaged
 cars, and they leave few steals for the rest of us. Porsches (or any other
 really exciting car) generally sell for way more than they are worth even
 to the professionals, you are more likely to see a ridiculously high price
 than a low price when a damaged Porsche sells at auction (even the Pros
 get foggy in the head when a sexy car rolls by).

    Behind just about every bargain is usually a lot of hard work on top
 of a low initial price...

            -Lee A.

Porschephiles #1528                         Wed Jul 5 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 01:33:36 -0500
From: Ezra Goldman <ez@chi.shl.com>
Subject: re: Carrera radar detector

dmklein@pipeline.com asks:
> Does anyone have any unique thoughts for discreet mounting
> of a Valentine radar unit in a C2.

I'm gnawing on the same problem. I really liked my old K40 built-in
unit, but I want the updated features and performance of the 
Valentine in my '91 C4. The two places I'm considering are:

1) hiding the unit in the third brake light holder,
hopefully without losing the high brake light. I got 
the idea from a prior p'filer post who had mounted his
unit on the rear glass of a 914. This seems to be the stealthiest 
location. Since then I've had more experience with the Valentine
and it's relatively soft volume even on maximum setting.
I'm concerned that in a rear mount I would not hear the alerts 
with windows open or radio on.

2) mounting the unit sort of up under the rear-view mirror so that
the unit is mostly behind the mirror. In this case I would
still use the remote display, but I'm not sure where to
put that yet. This location provides good front and rear 
clear lines for the radar recievers. This is where I'm using
it now, with the suction mount.
In this position, I would fabricate something roughly like the mount
for the rear brake; i.e. solid, sloped to match the windshield,
and reasonably opaque so I can leave the thing there all the time
and not invite theft. 

I don't know if the the radio antenna in the windshield directly
in front of the Valentine degrades performance -- does anyone on the
list have some data on this?


Ezra Goldman
ez@interdyn.com
'91 C4 (red, but not cause I wanted to attract any attention)

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 08:49:46 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Bad Day (long)

Hey,

My son and I were on the way home last night and decided
to stop by the video store (about 2.5 miles from our house).
We needed to hurry because a tremendous thunderstorm was
bearing down on us.  I got out of the 911 and as I walked around
to his side, I heard a loud hissing sound.  16 penny nail in the 
right rear tire.  Rather than use the air compressor with the
car, we ran across the street to a Shell station and filled
the spare with their little complimentary air/water thingy.
By this point, the winds were gusting to probably 50mph.  We
made it back to the car and had just enough time to figure
out that the jack receiver on the car was too rusty to get the
jack in before the rain hit.  We took shelter in a supermarket
in the same little shopping center as the video store to wait
out the storm.  The power went out.  I figured this was one of 
those "scattered afternoon and evening thundershowers" and that
the sun would be back out before too long even though it would
be getting dark soon.  It never stopped raining.

Thinking that all I needed to do was clean some of the rust out
of the jack receiver, we waited for the rain to let up some.  As
it was getting dark, I decided to let my son sit in the car (out of
the rain) as I finished the job.  Got the jack in in about 2 or 3 
minutes.  It started raining harder.  Grabbed the lug wrench to 
lossen the lug nuts.  IT WAS THE WRONG SIZE!!!  It didn't fit!  I 
have the tool kit that comes with the car?!?  It didn't fit!!  I took
the jack back out and we go in search of a lug wrench.  With the
storm/power outage/darkness etc., no one seemed to want to
help.  My wife later told me that she thought my problem was
that I was asking people for a "lug wrench".  She said nobody
knows what a lug wrench is, I should have been asking for "tire 
iron".  Yeah, right.

I couldn't reach anyone on the phone (evidently some phone lines
were down) and the intensity of the rain was increasing.  I finally
broke down and bought a can of "Fix-a-Flat".  I figured the tire is
shot anyway, what the hell.  I put the stuff in per the directions 
while mother nature rubbed it in by raining even harder.  The can
didn't seem to make a dent in re-filling the tire so I immediately
drove across the street and filled the tire with air thinking that
this would at least get me the 2.5 miles home.  Wrong.  I made it 
about a mile away when it became obvious that "bad things" were
happening back there.  It was pouring, it was dark, I couldn't put
the spare on anyway, so I drove the rest of the way home on what
was left of the tire.

Luckily, when I got home, I found that the tire was still intact and
that the wheel appeared to be OK.

Shame on me for not checking that the lug wrench in the tool kit
fit the car.  I'm trying to talk my wife into spanking me.  :>)

On the bright side, I get to buy some new tires sooner than I had 
planned.  That is about as bright as it gets, though.

Sorry for the length.

Have a good fourth,

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911 - listing badly at the moment

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 10:44:49 -0400
From: ALAN968@aol.com
Subject: A-arms 968

It appears that the sport suspension, M030, on the 968's does not include the
951.341.---.--- series parts.  I was inspecting the condition of the arms
when I noticed that the part numbers were the 944.341.---.--- series. 

I was told that the M030 was the same suspension as used on the 88 Turbo S
and the 89 Turbos.

It seems odd that Porsche would put the big sway bars, adjustable Konis, 928
brakes, vented rotors etc. on the car and then scrimp on the A-arms.

Does anyone have any knowledge of the 951 arms being applied to the 968 with
M030 suspension?

Thanks,

Alan968
95 968 M030 (sortof)

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 12:52:27 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 911 1990 C4 Resolved stu

>>RedNineCo suggested it could be the belt between the two distributors
>>and that was exactly what it was.  This was causing only one plug per 
>>cylinder to fire.  BTW, there were not any dash lights to indicate there 
>>was actually a problem.

In fact what happens is that the second distributor keeps firing on
whatever cylinder it has landed.  One mechanic friend said he's seen
this hole a *cylinder*, rather than the more common holing of a
piston.

Kevin

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 15:56:21 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Drive belts 

>George,
>
>I'm trying to remove the drive belts on my '88 944 and I'm having a
>problem. I can't seem to get enough slack in the belts to remove them.
>The belt tensioners don't give enough play and I don't see where any of
>the components can be loosened to get the needed slack. Neither my shop
>manuals nor my Haynes manual says exactly how this is supposed to be
>accomplished. Any advice you could give would be greatly appreciated.
>
>Thanks in Advance,
>
>Doug Kush
>
>

Hi, Doug,

What both the factory and the Haynes manual do not say about the 
87 and new timing belt tensioner is that to remove the tension you do the 
following:

1) Remove the balance shaft belt the old fashioned way...

2) Loosen the two locknuts on the timing belt adjuster.

3) Use the balance shaft sprocket tool to release the tension on the timing
belt, by preloading the tensioner spring.

4) With the tensioner preloaded, tighten the locknuts to hold it in place.

5) Remove the belt by sliding it (with some difficulty) off the camshaft 
sprocket...

6) To remove the belt completely, you have to remove the tensioner but loosening
the three mounting nuts. See the factory service manual for the exact 
location of the
nuts.

Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services 
Orders: 800-ALL-P944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 13:29:05 -0700 (PDT)
From: dough@netcom.com (Douglas Holtsinger)
Subject: rust on new porsche oil filter


The recent thread on aftermarket Porsche oil filters encouraged 
me to immediately swap out the aftermarket filter in my '84 944
for a factory part.  I went to the local Porsche dealership to 
get a filter, figuring that I'd endure their price gouging just 
this once. 

When I went to inspect the filter, it had a thin layer of rust
covering the entire mating surface.  I managed to scrape off a 
bit of the rust with my fingernail.  I didn't see any rust inside
the filter. The cardboard box didn't have any signs of water damage.

I showed this to the parts guy, and he said "it probably won't 
hurt it." He went back inside the parts storeroom and came back 
a few minutes later and told me that the filters "were all like 
that."  I handed the filter back to him and he seemed rather
nonchalant about the whole thing.  BTW, this occurred at Lipshy 
Motor Cars in Austin, TX.

Who do you suppose is responsible for allowing these filters to 
become rusted?  Is it the dealership's fault, the manufacturer, 
or someone in between?  The parts storeroom had AC, although they 
could have turned it off when they closed up shop.  It does get 
very humid during these Texas summers.

Doug Holtsinger


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 17:45:26 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: A-arms 968

Alan,

You said:

>Does anyone have any knowledge of the 951 arms being applied to the 968
>with M030 suspension?

 Not to worry. What you saw was the casting number.  The basic part is the
same, only the rubber bushings are different.  At one time, no more, you
could buy just the bushings as a racing part. They used them before the Turbo
S came out in the Turbo Cup series cars to convert standard a arms.

Jon Lowe
'87 Escort Series 944T

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 01:47:02 +0100 (METDST)
From: Morten Christian Holmgreen <joker@diku.dk>
Subject: REPOST: Braking at track-events?

Hi,

I tried mailing this some weeks ago, but received only one answer,
so I'm trying again, since I'd really like to know :-)

I have a couple of questions for you track-gurus and instructors, since
I've been told different things by different people (and read differently
in Vic Elfords book), and I'd like to know what's the best and why...:

(1) When for instance braking at the end of a long straight - why should
    you downshift through the gears (4-3-2)?

    Isn't it better to just (a) declutch (b) put gently it in second during 
    your brake (or whatever needed at the turn) (c) brake hard (d) heel-and-
    toe some revs to the engine and engage the clutch when you're about 
    finished braking.

    If (1) the brake balance is adjusted perfect such that the front locks
    just a fraction before the rear and (2) your brakes can handle the
    heat - wouldn't the downshifting through the gears (and engage the
    clutch) actually upset the balance in the car?

(2) When braking hard (again :-) ) - should you press down the brake-pedal
    40% first and then do for max preassure or should you just go for max
    pressure immediately and as fast as you can. (Vic Elford says do the 
    40% first to move weight to the front - and then go for max. preasure).


I'd like to know what's the best way of braking - especially after a long
brake. I'm having a tough time getting used to braking as late as I should
so I'd like to know the optimal way before experimenting with later braking.

Thanks,

Christian

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 20:17:57 -0400
From: "Daniel G. Pouzzner" <douzzer@prez.mit.edu>
Subject: Re: REPOST: Braking at track-events?

The reason for sequencing downshifts and engaging the clutch in the
process to affect a deceleration is that, basically, the brakes on
your wheels have their limits. By using the engine as a brake, the
disks have more time to cool. Remember, your engine has an extensive
cooling system, either via air or water, and is much more able to
dissipate the energy of a 3000 pound object moving at 70MPH than those
four metal disks are.

Why do you need to sequence through the shifts? Just for completeness
I thought I'd add that if you skip gears in downshifting, in general
you've either 1) worked the brakes harder than necessary, or 2)
possibly over-rev'd the engine, and probably worked the synchro-mesh
disks harder than necessary. Both options are destructive to your
car, and don't improve your performance.

If your engine, gearbox, and brakes were "ideal" (like an "ideal
gas"), then your best time would come from braking as hard as physics
allows ( (coefficient of rolling friction * 1G ) + aero. downforce) at
the end of a straight section (and accelerating similarly at the start
of the straight section), but there's more than one turn in a typical
race and you'll need the engine and brakes later on, and real hardware
is far from ideal. This is ignoring the obvious economic issues :-).

I'm not sure about the brake-pumping question. Instinct tells me that
that technique just lets you reacquaint yourself with the feel of the
brakes at every turn, and is not necessary from a mechanical
perspective, but I could certainly be missing something. For example,
brake fade is a dynamic phenomenon the driver _must_ be aware of, and
this pumping technique allows him/her to find out how the brakes are
doin'.

 -douzzer

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 20:55:22 -0400
From: RUBBERDOC@aol.com
Subject: Tire and wheel combo's, early 911s 

If you are at the "normal ride height" the 16x6 and 16x7s should
work with 205/55r16.  I bought a 69E with this combination on 
it.  I think the car had been raised to accommodate the fitment
(It looked like it was on stilts) 205/60r15s on 6x15s work well for the
street.  Going to 7x15s may cause rubbing particularly if the car has been
lowered. 
Tom

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 19:24:26 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: 944/951 A/C

Ed - you worte:
> told me that the system "held vacuum OK, but we tried recharging it 3 times
> and it wouldn't accept any Freon". He suggested I take it to the Porsche
> shop because it must be something "peculiar to Porsches".

That doesn't tell me enough, but it sounds like the compressor wasn't 
running if it wouldn't take any freon.  What readings was the mechanic 
getting on his refrigeration gauges?  The system will take a lot more 
then the required amount and that will just allow more "liquid" freon to 
reach the compressor which is bad if over-charged.  Most systems have a 
low pressure switch on the suction side of the compressor that when it 
gets below 10 pounds pressure shuts system off to protect compressor.  
You will have to jump the contacts to get the compressor to run, fill 
with freon and then remove jumper after you are down or after the system 
has enough pressure to no trip compressor off.  Just holding a vacuum 
tells me that the system is leak free now.  the reason I say now is 
because with all the vibrations and such, automobile a/c systems have a 
terrible reputation for loosing freon.

Hope this helps.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

dealers but if you prefer a dealer this one has been there forever I think

Hope this helps

Date: Tue, 4 Jul 1995 14:48:59 -0700
From: hod@cns.bc.ca (Hod Pharis)
Subject: Buckin' Bronc 912 solved!

Well do I ever have egg on my face (but I'm not alone heh heh). The problem
I was having stemmed from a bad rotor. I am guessing that there was a
hairline crack or something along that line that expanded when hot and
caused the juice to ground out. Hence the violent bucking as it simply
didn't fire whenever this happened. I am definitly breathing a sigh of relief.
She runs like a dream now and about the only thing left thats pressing is
the clutch which I will change next week.
>From all the feedback I have received regarding the vinyl restoration I
think the best method is to send it away and have it redone. But thats
something that can wait until it goes to bed for the winter.
BTW, thanks to all who gave me the good advice.

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 07:25:20 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: WANTED: 944 Info/Opinion

>  1984 944 "Weissach Edition"  
>
>Does anyone know what the details of this special edition were?  From 
>what I can tell, the changes were limited to cosmetics: gold (vs. black) 
>wheels, wider than standard at rear, 911 seats inside.  Anyone have more 
>info?
>
>Also, the car's sunroof has MAJOR paint damage -- probably a function of 
>being fiberglass instead of steel, plus some heavy-duty stone chips up 
>front, but has a full main-dealer service history.  Should I overlook the 
>cosmetics in favor of this well-looked-after powertrain?  BTW, the guy's 
>asking $5000 

Well, $5000 sounds about right, but take it to a good Porsche mechanic for a 
checkout first.  Figure about $500 to have the sunroof damage repaired and 
repainted. Figure another $300 to $500 for the stone chips upfront...

There is no option code in the factory fiche for "Weissach Edition"...What you 
describe is a collection of normal factory optional equipment...probably put
together by a dealer who then called it a Weissach (since at the time, there 
were special edition 911s called just that...)
Good Luck!

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 07:30:54 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: REPOST: Braking at track-events?

As the risk of sounding pedantic, if you were to participate in 
a PCA track event with your car, you would see for yourself 
the reasons for following Mr Elford's recommendations.

As an alternative, I would suggest the Skip Barber school, in
whcih they teach you how to beat ABS in a braking situation,
using just those techniques, then they have you practice it 
until it becomes part of your unconscious memory.
Good Luck!

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 09:34:39 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Original owner and InformationPages

I know how you all like hearing about the Porsche content, so I'll keep 
the web content REAL slim... Check out 
http://tta.com/Porschephiles/InformationPages/356.html

Over time, in order to keep TechTips from overflowing, these pages will 
sprout out of there. Also, check out /Porschephiles/vendor.html and tell 
me what you think. There. Done. On to Porsche content.

I had attempted to contact the original owners of my dad's Porsche 
earlier this year, but their housesitter informed me that they were on 
vacation... So like normal, I put that in the to-do pile and never 
contacted them again, until yesterday. Well, the original owner (who must 
be around 75 or so, since his daughter told me she was 50) had a stroke 
and was not up and about, but still alive. He was, to put it mildly, more 
than shocked to hear about the Porsche after 20 years of not seeing it. 
He had put 1/3 of the miles on that car in the first year and a half. He 
then sold it... (This much we knew from service records)

The car, we found out, has a story about it... We figured as much, but we 
weren't sure. He used it as his daily driver, and did not pull out the 
fuel injection (the second owner did, we aren't sure who that was) The 
911 T had been used on his daughter's honeymoon (quite possibly where 
5000 or so of the miles came from).  We found that the windshield is in 
fact the original (it has the original PCA sticker from his free year of 
membership in the corner)

We are now going to try to keep in touch, and swap photos of the car, now 
and then. We were pleased to say the least, at finding out the car is the 
original color. Whoever re-painted it got EVERY nook and cranny very well 
(yes, the rubber must be well preserved under all that paint *g*) and we 
weren't sure. Not that the paint job is perfect, there is one bubble 
right by the gas fill.

Either way, I talked to his daughter for 20 minutes or so, and we got 
quite a bit of information about the car... They were also shocked to 
hear that the car made it's way to New Jersey (in all it's years with us, 
it went outside of Indiana ONE time, the previous (third) owner never 
took it out of Indiana, and we don't know quite who the hell the second 
one was, there are no real records from then)

Everybody look for that maroon book with clear cover... Call up the 
original owner if they're listed (they should be) and see what you find 
out... Remember, the traditional Porsche owner is in their 40's to 50's, 
so many of them are getting old now, this may be the last chance they 
ever have to see their Porsche. Besides, most of the time, Porsches stay 
in one area, people relocate and sell their Porsche... You might even get 
together with the original owner (hey, who knows, maybe they've got a 993 
they'd let you drive if you let them drive their old Porsche)... Contact 
'em, whaddya got to lose?
 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: 5 Jul 1995 10:15:43 U
From: "Chrisman Andrew" <Chrisman.Andrew@mail.ndhm.gtegsc.com>
Subject: RE: A/C Problem

response to Ed:


>Date: Mon, 3 Jul 1995 15:57:52 -0500
>From: mac3d@superlink.net (Ed Dougherty)
>Subject: 944/951 A/C

>A few days ago it finally got hot enough to roll up the windows and >turn on
>the A/C. Nothing happened...
>I stopped in to a local auto A/C shop to have them check it out. The >tech
>told me that the system "held vacuum OK, but we tried recharging it 3 >times
>and it wouldn't accept any Freon". He suggested I take it to the Porsche
>shop because it must be something "peculiar to Porsches".
>Anybody heard of this before? I've checked the 944 FAQ, and the A/C
>problems section is not done yet. The fact that there *is* an A/C >section
>makes me think there may be some common problems. I've made it a >point to
>run the system about 20 minutes a month during the winter, as Porsche
>recommends.
>Any tips, clues or hints would be greatly appreciated.
>-ed

Ed;

I had the same problem with my 968 and the dealer fixed it by replacing the
switch for the de-icer as he called it.  I'm not sure if the de-icer is the
same as the receiver/dryer or what but it keeps the compressor from running. 
Can't help on what it should cost to fix since mine was done under warranty. 
Very good idea to run system to lube the seals since they seem to fail very
early.

Andrew

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 95 10:32:23 EDT
From: oscar_ortega@pts.mot.com (Oscar Ortega)
Subject: Reference: Porschephiles #1522 Sat Jul 1 21:31:57 CDT 1995


 I recently bought a 1983 Porsche 928. The dash is cracked on top of the 
gauges and near the defrost vents. I have been smothering the dash with 
Armor All to try and prevent further cracking. I was reading the above

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 95 09:25:06 PDT

Subject: Re: ABS Dash Covers


Someone asked about ABS dash covers...

I used one on a 240Z (made by CoverCraft, I think), and
it was excellent.  When properly installed you have to 
look carefully to notice it.  In fact, if you were not
familiar with the car, you probably would never know.

It may not work as well for a 911, but my 240Z experience
is at least one point on the curve.
