------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 12:14:05 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: REPOST: Braking at track-events?

Morten Christian Holmgreen got only one reply and asks again:

>(1) When for instance braking at the end of a long straight - why should
>    you downshift through the gears (4-3-2)?

For me, the key-phrase of your question is "at the end of a long straight."
Coming down sequentially through the gears (while simultaneously braking by
heal-and-toe) to reach your "exit-gear" before turn-in may be the best way
to slow your car, using a combination of brakes (80%) and deceleration in
each gear (20%). You should rely on your brakes and not the gear-box to
stop your car, but deceleration in gear while braking helps the slowing
process. You might want to begin this way.

As you gain proficiency in using your brakes and maintaining control of
your car under abrupt deceleration, you may feel comfortable going deeper
into the turn with heavier braking making it unecessary to use some, or
all, intermediate gears before selecting your exit gear by heal and toe,
double-clutching, still braking. If so, you might want to try heavy braking
while in your straight-away gear and then skip-shifting (going, for
example, from 4th to 2nd) while continuing your braking for the turn making
sure that when you release the clutch in second gear (still before turn-in
and at the end of your braking period) you've slowed sufficiently to match
the engine-rpm to the mph of your exit gear. If not, you may seriously
over-rev the engine, and in the excitement, fail to make the turn. Ergo,
broken engine and maybe broken car.

I don't believe there is any standard answer here -- it may depend on the
terminal speed you reach on the straight approaching the turn, your
equipment, the type of turn to negotiate after braking, and most
importantly, the amount of seat-time you bring. A relatively inexperienced
driver should not try the "best" answers you will receive to your questions
until he/she develops the necessary skills to move up to that particular
level of competitive driving. Learning how to drive (or anything else, for
that matter) is like climbing to a series of plateaus. You realize a degree
of improvement, then no progress for a while, then more improvement.

It's like the newstand operator's reply to a first-time New York City
visitor who wanted to know how get to a concert hall (Carnegie Hall).
"Practice man, practice."

>    Isn't it better to just (a) declutch (b) put gently it in second during
>    your brake (or whatever needed at the turn) (c) brake hard (d) heel-and-
>    toe some revs to the engine and engage the clutch when you're about
>    finished braking.

See above -- you should downshift and release the clutch while braking, not
"when you're about finished braking."

>    If (1) the brake balance is adjusted perfect such that the front locks
>    just a fraction before the rear and (2) your brakes can handle the
>    heat - wouldn't the downshifting through the gears (and engage the
>    clutch) actually upset the balance in the car?

You've already "upset the balance in the car" during heavy braking -- the
front-end is planted and the rear is light. Downshifting through the gears
won't add to that imbalance.

>(2) When braking hard (again :-) ) - should you press down the brake-pedal
>    40% first and then do for max preassure or should you just go for max
>    pressure immediately and as fast as you can. (Vic Elford says do the
>    40% first to move weight to the front - and then go for max. preasure).

If Vic Elford says so, it must be true. The logic makes sense -- that is,
moderate (40%) braking helps to plant the front tires so they are ready for
100% pedal pressure and the brakes are less likely to lock-up.

But, in my experience on the track (10 years SCCA racing), I never had time
to think about differentiating between 40% and 100% pedal pressure. I
wanted to get inside the guy ahead of me which required 120% pedal
pressure, a small prayer, and then lots of brake pedal modulation to unlock
the brakes. Maybe you've read too far in Elford's book. Master the "basics"
chapters first, then you'll have a fairly informed opinion about the 40%
factor.

>I'd like to know what's the best way of braking - especially after a long
>brake. I'm having a tough time getting used to braking as late as I should
>so I'd like to know the optimal way before experimenting with later braking.

You're certainly asking one of the "right" questions. Learning how to stop
is fundamental to going fast at an autocross, track event, or in racing. In
racing, more passes are made under braking than acceleration. One thing
though, don't ask for more performance than your equipment can deliver.
Heat is the enemy of brakes, so you'll need ways to get air to the front
rotors. And for heavy braking, you'll need tire adhesion, so wheel-weight
the corners of your car to prevent lockup of a light corner at the front of
the car. And finally, if you're on street tires, don't expect a trick brake
setup on your car to do much more than flat-spot your tires and give a
fright to corner workers.

Date: Wed, 05 Jul 1995 16:13:52 -0500
From: Joe Browne <brownej@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  competition

Oops - I mean challenge. Don't forget the Porsche -
I found this on the autox server and thought that fellow p-filers might be
amused.  My comments follow the quote.

"Corvette/Camaro Challenge is this Saturday at Stockton. Its going to be
fun.... Its going to be walk in the park; like stealing candy from a baby; a
piece of cake.... Hmmm - maybe I'll bring the Corvette so it won't look as
bad... Not - I'm bringing the
Camaro going for the gold......

This past weekend I was hanging with a lot of PCA people and they are
already getting their excuse list together. They really have some neat
ones, some that I hadn't even thought of. Thats OK just as long as they
bring money because the losers (Porsche Drivers) are buying the beer
and it better not be that crap in green bottles..."

My comments;
1. It is not wise to predict sporting events before they happen, lest you
resemble the north end of a southbound burro in the end ( pun pardon, if
you please).
2.  Depending on who is designing the course and making the rules, it is
possible to make almost any car beat any other car.  Earnhardt & Hurley
Haywood at Daytona vs. the same duo at Watkins Glen, etc.
3.  No matter who wins, the porsche drivers will be driving Porsches and
the the others will be driving, well, others.  You guys (and ladies)
probably know what I mean.

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 15:53:26 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: early vs. late 911s


>Yes, I have pointed out to this list that Bruce Anderson is not God. But
>never did I show such blatant disrespect for someone without cause. Sure,
>Bruce does not like the '74 to '77 911's. With good reason. It is damn
>hard to find one that has been "properly rebuilt". So why not just stay
>away from them when you can get a better car, the 911SC, for just a bit
>more money?

One of the local European Speciality (whatever that is?) shops sales
European cars as well as servicing them.  I noticed last week that
they advertised having 6 Porsches for sale.  This in addition to 
two others for sale in the paper by private owners.  This is a lot
of Porsches to have for sale in Cedar Rapids, IA (pop. 150k) at one
time, so I had to go down and have a look at their stock.  They had
a nice '86 944 for $9500.  This seemed a little high, but not out of 
line for a used car dealer.  They had 3 911s and a '77 930.  They 
wanted $21k for the 930 and knew absolutely nothing about it.  I found
out that I know significantly more about 930s than they do, and I haven't
so much as been inside of one!  The real killer was the 911s.  They
were all mid-70s (75-77) with (supposedly) original engines and no 
records.  The place wanted $12.5k+ for all of them!  I'm scared to 
think of the poor sucker who buys one of these...  When I mentioned 
that the 2.7L engines had some problems, the salesman told me I didn't
know what I was talking about.  I think he figured out that I wasn't really
looking to buy.

Ross Stites
'87 951 (waiting for a new brain in MN)

Date: Wed, 05 Jul 95 13:01:00 ADT
From: "Southard, Keith" <KSOUTHAR@atu.com>
Subject: RE: competition


Yea, know what you mean.  I chair the Alaska Region's Challenge Series
(7 events, point accumulation to determine the overall winners). We
have one driver (me) in the top five. Most are at the bottom of the list.

In our region, there is a distinct difference, besides the cars, between
a PCA member and a member of the Corvette Club or SCCA. Our
members tend to want to sit around drinking that stinkin' green bottle
beer while they admire their car and extoll its virtues. The Corvette
drivers just want a parade, while the SCCA youngsters bring their
Camaros out and kick everyone's butt.

They (SCCA) are VERY serious about autocrossing and their
members are very competitive. Our members are more like a
social club. One of our members went so far as to suggest that
we shouldn't give prizes or trophies to anyone except PCA members!
 ----------

Porschephiles #1530                         Thu Jul 6 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 17:11:43 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: RE:RE:Re: 944 ball joint: observed!

>Doug wrote about the control arms for the 951 and questioned the availability
>of something better.
>
>Performance Alignment, Cincinnati 513.489.8500, indicated they could get the
>arms modified through FabCar with new beefier parts.  This would abviously be
>cheaper thatn going the new FabCar control arm avenue.  Obviously you'd want
>to make shure your current arms aren in good shape.
>
>I'm running the same tire and wheel setup as you.  So far no problems.  But I
>plan to modify my arms this fall ater the last event.
>
>Alan968
>95 968 M030

I just talked to the owner at Fabcar. He claims this place has no
affiliation with them AT ALL.
FabCar ONLY makes 4130 chrome-moly heat treated arms with larger diameter
ball joints and some killer stainless steel alloy pin for $800- each. Can
you say expensive replacement parts? They just got a failed arm (at the
sway bar mount) off a 95 968 that did $15,000 in damage. Can you say cheap
insurance?
The only IMSA approved arm is FabCar. Hint, hint.

He also said the pin failures might have been from loose/improperly torqued
hub clamps. There was evidence of wear on the pin at the bottom of the
clamp assembly. When was the last time you retorqued yours?

The PMNA arms are apparently the same arm in a different alloy.

Anybody interested in a "bulk buy discount"?

Looks like my for parts for sale list will include control arms, in
addition to adjustible konis and sport sway bars...

Uy.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 17:28:01 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Braking at track-events?

>The reason for sequencing downshifts and engaging the clutch in the
>process to affect a deceleration is that, basically, the brakes on
>your wheels have their limits. By using the engine as a brake, the
>disks have more time to cool. Remember, your engine has an extensive
>cooling system, either via air or water, and is much more able to
>dissipate the energy of a 3000 pound object moving at 70MPH than those
>four metal disks are.

I have to disagree with this.  The primary reason for downshifting is
to put the car in the proper gear to prepare to get back on the throttle
following turn-in.  I would *never* intentionally try to use the engine
as a means of slowing the car at the end of a straight.  My brakes (which
are basically stock, BTW) don't seem to have *any* trouble slowing the
car down repeatedly from high speeds on the track.  Yes, they have their
limits, but 9 times out of 10, when using proper braking techniques
you will not exceed these limits and the brakes will not fade, etc. 

Another way to look at this is:  Which would you rather wear out quicker -
the brakes or the engine/drivetrain?  Use the brakes to stop the car, that's
what they're for.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 16:37:22 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>

  I just added Freon to my '87 951 two weeks ago.  It works just like
  every other car I've ever added Freon to.  Did they lift the car?

  pan to get to one of the connections.  Btw, you can no longer
  buy Freon without a license or "connections".

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 16:48:33 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: The Weekend from Hell (part III)

Last week the dealer got the new air flow sensor for my car in and
installed.  The service manager called to let me know that it didn't 
have any affect on the problem.  The mechanic told him that this 
meant a bad DME control unit (ugghh!).  They checked out the price
on a used one, and I had them order it for under half what a
"rebuilt" one costs.  The good thing is they aren't charging me
for any of the time or the parts for installing the new air flow
sensor and the DME control unit is 1/2 an hours work to install.
I figure it's probably 4 bolts and a connector:)  I can't decide
whether I hope this fixes the problem or maybe it won't and they'll
find something cheaper to fix it:)

The other good news is that we found a place to live in Roseville,
a suburb of Minneapolis.  I also have had several recommendations 
for a good 944 mechanic in the area.  The nice thing is everyone
has mentioned the same guy so far.  Of course, I'm hoping that
I can fix anything that goes wrong on the car from now on myself,
but it's nice to have good backup.  This list has been very helpful
in giving me some additional peace of mind when moving to a new
city that I have no other contacts in.

Thanks for the listen,

Ross Stites
'87 951 (needs a brain - afterwords maybe it can click its heels together
and come home:)

Date: 5 Jul 95 09:41:00 -0700
From: MIFSUD_BRIAN@Tandem.COM
Subject: 914 Displacement Increase Inquiries

Hello All,
  I have a '76 2.0 with low miles on rebuild but am not too happy with perform-
ance.  I'm green-minded (and CA resident), so the Smog Pump and CAT must stay,
but I know more power can be had through cubic centimeters.  I've read the
Bosch F.I. Books and they all point to one thing, change the pumping capacity
of the motor.  The question is, how much range does my Bosch-D have built into
it?  I'd like to bump displacement up between 10-20%. I understand that the
Pressure Sensor (which does most of the "driving" in the D-System) is calibrat-
able for different flow/pressure ranges.  Has anyone out there successfully
bumped up the displacement, maintained correct stoicheometry (smog legal), all
with the stock system?
  If the stock system needs mods. what are they?

  Other than under the front bumper, where are some good locations for large
capacity oil coolers?  The Type I's I've rebuilt all relied on oil getting to
the heads through the pushrods...this seems very lame..is the Type IV the same?
My Moto Guzzi (air cooled pushrod 90 degree twin) lubs. the rockers/valves
through pressure fed external lines...has anyone done this to the Type IV for
increase in flow/head cooling with oil?
  Most of these mods. are probably needed only on the track, but I'm a big fan
of over-engineered cooling/lubrication systems.  Besides, I hate it when I'm
stuck in summer traffic and the temp guage keeps on climbing.
thanks in advance  brian mifsud

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 17:28:01 -0400

- ----------------------------Original message----------------------------
*Snip*
>your wheels have their limits. By using the engine as a brake, the
*Snip*

I have to disagree with this.  The primary reason for downshifting is
to put the car in the proper gear to prepare to get back on the throttle
following turn-in.  I would *never* intentionally try to use the engine
as a means of slowing the car at the end of a straight.  My brakes (which
*Snip*
_______________________________My Message__________________________________

This seems to go along with what my PCA drivers school teacher told us (he
is the local champion in his class in both autocross and the Club Race). He
said something like the engine wasn't designed to go backwards, and in effect,
we are asking the engine to go backwards when we downshift.  He said that it
is alright every once in a while, but to use the brakes whenever you can
instead(siteing the same reason as above- it is cheaper to replace brakes!)
and ultimately to learn to heel-toe.  Seems logical to me, Sean  '80 928

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 95 18:35:30 EDT
From: "Bill Kan" <bkan@banmail.ml.com>
Subject: 951 control arm - the resolution with PCNA

Hi all,

Thanks to all who answered my questions regarding replacment control arms.  My 
car *had* ;-)  a loose ball joint on the driver side control arm of my 88 951, 
which has less than 36K miles.  

I ended up getting a replacement from the dealer.  PCNA offered to cough up 
1/2 of the cost of the part with me paying the rest.  Although it wasn't any 
great concession on their part, the 2-year warrantee on parts and labor they 
was included  nudged me to go with the dealer.  I had the district service rep 
come out to check the car and *complained* that the ball joint should not have 
come loose on a car that only had 36K miles and is running totally stock.

I also had the camber set a little more negative as suggested by our own Jim 
Pasha.  It's great to have the 951 back!!  Everything feels tighter now and 
the road response seems "improved"  -- it seems like I am getting less "noise" 
in the steering wheel and getting "cleaner" road feel when I expect it.  Is 
this due mostly to the allignment setting or to the new control arm??

The response that I got from you all suggested  that a rebuilt control arm was 
a reasonable way to go (outside of going with an upgrade, e.g. FABCAR)  
Everyone seems to be pretty satisfied.  Both Zim's and European Dynamics (hope 
I have the name correct), which  offer rebuilds, claim that they have not had 
problems with their products and will warrantee their rebuilds for about 2 
years (if I remember correctly).  The rebuilds run around $250 and both shops 
claim that their product is an improvement over the OEM part.  

BTW, I wanted to go with the Euroselect part control arm, which is listed at 
$250, but had no luck in locating any dealer that had access to one.   One 
dealer said that even if the part has a part number and has been priced it 
does not mean that the part will be available any time soon.  Hope this is not 
really true about Euroselect....

Cheers,

Bill Kan
88 951
internet:  bkan@banmail.ml.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 18:36:24 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: Re: Re: Braking at track-events?


Regarding engine braking,

Mike Dayton Said:

>I have to disagree with this.  The primary reason for downshifting is
>to put the car in the proper gear to prepare to get back on the throttle
>following turn-in.  I would *never* intentionally try to use the engine
>as a means of slowing the car at the end of a straight.  My brakes
>(which are basically stock, BTW) don't seem to have *any* trouble 
>slowing the car down repeatedly from high speeds on the track.

Boy do I agree with Mike. Engine braking at it's worst can overrev 
an engine and at it's best is just a lazy way to slow down a car. Think
about it - if you're at redline, or even in the powerband and you down-
shift a gear, you pick up 1,000 RPM right? 

If the brake pedal can't slow the car equally fast, then either the 
brakes are bad or the person should be spending the time in the gym
rather than on the track. I just can't imagine the car dynamics of engine
braking into a turn then transitioning to full throttle at the apex.

This goes for around-town driving as well. If you know you're going to
have to stop (like for a light) don't doodle down through the gears
unless you like buying synchros every couple of years. Just brake
to a stop.


Reid Zeigler

(I usually get 100K fast miles + out of clutches and transmissions)

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 16:36:36 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Braking at track-events?

>This seems to go along with what my PCA drivers school teacher told us (he
>is the local champion in his class in both autocross and the Club Race). He
>said something like the engine wasn't designed to go backwards, and in effect,
>we are asking the engine to go backwards when we downshift.  He said that it
>is alright every once in a while, but to use the brakes whenever you can
>instead(siteing the same reason as above- it is cheaper to replace brakes!)
>and ultimately to learn to heel-toe.  Seems logical to me, Sean  '80 928

Sean,

You mailer is doing the wrong thing, at least with this last message. The
"From:" field should haver your address, not Mike's. Here is what I am
talking about:

=================
Resent-Date:  Wed, 05 Jul 95 18:11:34 EDT
Resent-From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SS8299A@american.edu>
Resent-Organization: The American University
Resent-To: Porschephiles@tta.com
>From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 17:28:01 -0400
=================

Anyway, engines do not go backwards when you downshift. When you downshift
you get higher rpms and additional "compression braking". Brakes were made
for braking, engines were made to propel. One of the points of "heel and
toeing" is to get the engine speed up so the wheel speed in the new gear
matches the current wheel speed. That way the engine has no effect on
braking or the overall balance of the car before you enter the turn.

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 20:07:20 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Any PCA Club Racers Here?

Getting your Club Racing Licence:
Basically they now need to know your level of experience. An SCCA or IMSA
licence will do nicely. In lieu of that you need a recommendation from the
chief instructor of your region. I believe you need a minimum of 6 track
events and the recommendation. 
Trust me when I tell you that 6 track events will make you into a moving
chicane at a track event. Please analyze your degree of experience very
carefully before you enter a Club Race. Although it's not SCCA it can get
pretty rough out there.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
8:07 pm

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 21:03:14 -0600
From: dkelly@iquest.com (David Kelly)
Subject: Re: Reference: Porschephiles #1522 Sat Jul 1 21:31:57 CDT 1995

oscar_ortega@pts.mot.com (Oscar Ortega) said:
> I am also in need of front shocks and tires, any recommendations for brand
> names. I was thinking of putting on Eagle GS/D?, as far as shocks I am
> not sure.

Would suggest you replace all 4 shocks at once rather than upset the
balance of the car. Face it, if the fronts are bad, so are the backs.

Over the years I've reached the conclusion that for anything other than a
lightly sprung Detroit Land Ark the best solution for new shocks is factory
OEM. Next best thing is aftermarket adjustables. IMHO.  :-)

Last time I looked the going price for OEM Boges (probably what your car
has) was a quite reasonable $60 or $70 each. They're low tech, non-gas,
non-adjustable, etc, etc. They are also HUGE.

83 928S
(6) cats

David Kelly N4HHE,   n4hhe@amsat.org,    dkelly@iquest.com

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 22:13:10 -0400
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Any PCA Club Racers Here?

Tad,

If your car is prepped to PCA Club Race guidlines, your next step is to
contact Ruth Harte in the PCA National office (703-922-9300) and ask for a
"Club Race icensing packet".  This contains the Club Racing license
application which spells out the requirements.  Fill it out COMPLETELY and
mail it back to her with $30.00, a passport photo, and a copy of your
physical form (filled out of course).  The form will be forwarded to Anita
Moyle, Club Race licensing coordinator, who will determine your license
status. The experience requirements for a "rookie license" are at least 8
days of PCA Drivers Ed AND an endorsement from your regions Chief Driving
Instructor.  If your region does not have one, some recognized authority in
your area who is familiar with your experience and driving ability will
suffice.  Steve Kent from Maverick Region would be a good alternative.  If
you have any questions when filling out the application, call Anita Moyle at
303-794-7256 (after 9 AM MST) or E-mail her at kilner@aol.com.  She will be
happy to help.
Get this done soon as Brainerd is not that far off.  This will be a good
first event for you, as that event is low key.  (Not as many preditors there
as at some events in the East :-).)

Regards,

Pat Moyle (pm9146@aol.com)
PCA Club Racing National Steward

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 23:35:55 -0400
From: Ronskian@aol.com
Subject: Re: Braking at track-events?

I'm a newbie to this list, and absolutely  *love* it.  Discussions like this
are wonderful!

I've gotta put my $.02 in.  I'm no expert by any means, but REALLY get into
the subject of performance driving.  I don't have any trophies, nor am I
anywhere near the fastest in the club.  But I tend to agree with this. The
brakes on a Porsche should be more than adequate, if used and maitained
properly, to slow down the car during a typical autocross or time trials run.
 Cool brakes are key, but from what I read and hear using the engine for
compression braking is usually considered an obsolete idea.  Brake technology
nowadays is such that it should be unneccessary in most applications other
than endurance racing, where maximizing brake longevity is key.

Great thread....and thanks for the bandwidth...

Ron Boltik
1987 944

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 21:00:53 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: 914 engine break-in

Dave
Put in 30 wt oil and crank it, coil wire disconnected, until you have 
oil pressure, Then start it up and let idle for a few minutes ck for 
leaks noise etc. Then drive like you would a new car for the first few 
miles. When I had the 911 done I put on 1,000 then drained the oil, 
adj. the valves. changed filter etc. From that point on you are home 
free change oil, filter every 3,000.

mike

You wrote: 
>
>        Well, it looks as if Zero Hour is approaching.  So, I'd like 
to
>know what kind of special instructions I should follow to start and 
break
>in my 2.0L 914 motor after a complete re-build.
>        No, please don't ask me "when will it be done?"--believe me, 
you'll
>all *know*...   8)
>        I'm tempted to just fire it up and drive it for about 50 
miles...
>It'll take major surgery to get the grin off my face by then!
>
>--DD

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 23:10:57 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 356 restoration in European Car

> While thumbing through magazines I stumbled across "Project
> 1951 356 Restoration part *9*" by Brett Johnson.  Are the previous 8 parts wort
> h buying the back issues to get?

Not really. Basicly they say

1) I'm not really restoring it, I'm building a Vintage Race Car

2) I'm not really doing any of the work, but here's who I took it to for
   *this* and here's who I took it to for *that*.

On the whole, about average for a European Car article. And way, *WAY*
below what I have come to expect from Brett...

The very best use of your money on this one is to join The Registry,
and get the $20 "technical book" that's basicly a compilation of 20 years
of technical and hands-on how-to articles.

And see Trond Olson's pages here at tta.com on his rustoration efforts!

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 14:11:40 +0500
From: javier@ascc01.ascc.att.com (Javier Rodriguez - ATT ASCC)

Porschephiles #1531                         Thu Jul 6 12:05:12 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 05 Jul 1995 23:15:09 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: Re: 1987 944 Side mirrors.

>How do you remove the side mirrors of the 944?  The dealer said to look 
>on the underside of the mirror and I'll find a hole where I insert a 
>screwdriver.  Now the questions:  What type of screwdriver, what am I 
>looking for and I just have to tighten the break-away mirrors since at 
>high speeds, the mirror  tends to turn in at about 10-20 degrees throwing 
>off their use.

A small flat screwdriver (1/8 ") will do. The mirror glass is held on by tabs
on a plastic circular ring which releases the mirror if you rotate it 
counterclockwise with the screwdriver (thru the hole). Poke the screwdriver
in the hole and try to feel for a notch on the ring. When you find it, try to
push the ring CCW by moving the screwdriver tip sideways. When released
the glass can be pulled forward with your fingertips. 
 
If it's the mirror assembly that is rotating loosely on the mirror 'arm'
you're in for
a fun time.  When my mirror 'popped' off it's base, I had to remove the interior
door panels to unscrew the mirror base from the door (at the same time
cutting the control wires). Since the base is tensioned against the mirror 
assembly by a super-firm spring, I had to devise a way to screw the two back
together while compressing the spring. After trying everything, I discovered
that
I could insert a long screw into the hollow mirror arm shaft , and using some
washers and a screw, pull the two pieces together by tightening the screw.
Just make sure that the screw isn't so long that you can't remove it after
you've got the two parts together.
 
Ken '86 944




   


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 09:43:21 +0200
From: fk90@bfkvax.fm.bs.dlr.de (Wulf Moennich, DLR - Institut fuer Flugmechanik, Braunschweig, Germany)
Subject: Re: Wanted: Float Level Gauge

Don't buy a float level gauge. I bought mine from Baum
Tools; it doesn't really fit and it leaks.

All you need to check the float level is a calibrated
light (e.g. wooden) stick. Make a mark on the stick
37 mm from one of the ends. Take off your air cleaners.
Put stick through the brass tube in the middle of the
carb cover. At the correct float level the mark on the
stick is right at the top edge of the brass tube. This
method is *much* easier and faster (and of course less
expensive) than using a float level gauge.

Wulf Moennich  (wulf.moennich@dlr.de)
'69 912

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 10:28:55 -0400
From: pigozzi@pilot.msu.edu (Bruce Wm. Pigozzi)
Subject: Tracking Tiptronic

A recent article in Autoweek about what they've called "automanual"
transmissions along with an advertised on-the-steering wheel shifting button
(or switch) for Porsches tiptronic cars (maybe just 911s) has me thinking
about the merits and liabilities of a Tiptronic for serious tracking.  Does
it work?  Does it work well?  How does it hold up?  Is there any track
experience amongst the P_philes with the Tiptronic on the track?  In theory
it should be as fast or faster.  But, it also seems reasonable that it would
be more prone to failures.  As my '84 944 is about as far from this  theory
as one can get - - is there any knowledge to be shared out there?
Bruce Wm. Pigozzi
Associate Professor of Geography
Michigan State University
Email:pigozzi@pilot.msu.edu

dad's Buick I use Fram stuff, but without going to the Buick garage in 
this area, I have a hard time finding anything for it (air filters I have 
not seen since we moved here a year ago) so when I see the Fram filters, 
I stock up.

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 95 16:58:06 CET
From: "Robert Dru Martin" <rmartin@sgit.iaea.or.at>
Subject: Re:Fram filters

Consumer reports ran a filter test a few years ago, and Fram was far and 
away the best one they tested.  So for use on the ol' family hauler, the 
Fram filter is a great choice.  Unusual applications with special needs (a 
911, say) weren't addressed in the testing, so it's best to use OEM.  Can 
anyone dig out that test and give particulars?  Unfortunately, mine are in 
storage (along with most of my technical library  :-(   )

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 11:03:52 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Tracking Tiptronic

On Thu, 6 Jul 1995, Bruce Wm. Pigozzi wrote:

> A recent article in Autoweek about what they've called "automanual"
> transmissions along with an advertised on-the-steering wheel shifting button
> (or switch) for Porsches tiptronic cars (maybe just 911s) has me thinking
> about the merits and liabilities of a Tiptronic for serious tracking.  Does
> it work?  Does it work well?  How does it hold up?  Is there any track
> experience amongst the P_philes with the Tiptronic on the track?  In theory
Well, there is more racing with automatics now than there was 30 years 
ago, mainly because the automatics are getting better at knowing when you 
want them to shift. Either way, with that said, I've heard that the 
Tiptronics of last year had a problem with shifting how they saw fit if 
you were pushing the car too hard (simply to keep you from blowing the 
motor) while this is a wonderful (sometimes) feature for some drivers, 
this won't do you much good on the track, especially if you're not into 
chipping the car like that (I'm not sure if there are any performance 
chips out there for Tiptronic yet anyway) and have moved the redline up 
say 1000 or 1500 RPM.
Just my few thoughts... On a side note though, there is now talk in 
Porsche engineering of a 'fast' manual transmission. The way it work is 
an H pattern shift, but for a 6 or 7 speed transmission. It puts the gear 
you will want within one shift forward or back. For instance, if you are 
in 3rd, the shift pattern would look like this:
2 1
3-+
4 R <--- The reverse stays put, and first stays put, for stoplights and such.
As you shift to 4th, you push in the clutch, pull the shifter back 
towards you and let go, changing the shift pattern to:
3 1
4-+
5 R
and so on... they are working on this as a solution to the problem that 
the conventional shift design was design for 3 gears and a reverse, or at 
best, 4 forward and an offshoot reverse. With 6 speeds, you're up into a 
triple H when you add in reverse.
Keep in mind though, that the variable speed transmission is getting 
closer and closer to working too... this would be 1000x better, as there 
would only be '1' 'gear'
 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 06 Jul 95 10:52:23 EST
From: "paul foster" <paul_foster@imailhub.tdc.com>
Subject: Re: Steel A-Arms

     This message is a reposting. My apologies about the uuencode fiasco. 
     Our email administrator thought the existing configuration needed more 
     "features".
     
     Doug Dykaar writes:
     
     >Are the steel arms a LOT heavier than the Aluminum ones?
     
     No. They are relatively lightweight, and you can easily swap the 
     balljoint and bushings. They are from the VW Rabbit, so go to a VW 
     parts department and save big bucks.
     
     However, I have had some TERRIBLE experiences with them. The SCCA Solo 
     II stock class allows you to exchange the front swaybar. The only 
     adjustable one I know of is the Weltmeister bar from Automotion. It 
     mounts in the normal position on the aluminum a-arms, but you must 
     drill a hole through the middle of the steel a-arms to mount it.
     
     Accident #1: I was autocrossing at Sacramento about 2 1/2 hrs from 
     home. I was going around a 20-25 mph right corner when the a-arm 
     snapped in half, right through the drilled mounting hole. Carroll 
     Smith would say "stress riser". I would say SH*T.
     
     At the time I blamed my lack of mechanical aptitude. Since I was so 
     far from home, I had the car towed to Dwight Mitchell's shop 
     (Autosport Technology). $1200 and one week later, I had 2 new steel 
     a-arms, a four-wheel alignment, and a crumpled left fender.
     
     Accident #2: About one year later, I was autocrossing at Pleasanton 
     about 1/2 hour from home. I was going around a left-hand corner about 
     30-40 mph when the a-arm once again breaks, right through the drilled 
     mounting hole.
     
     Ken Mitchell (ex-GGR PCA member), bless his heart, helped me put my 
     car on his trailer and towed me home.
     
     Now, I had matching crumpled fenders.
     
     If you want to go to another vendor, I understand somebody (Racefab?) 
     makes competition a-arms. This month's Pano has an interesting warning 
     from the factory concerning aluminum a-arms. Porsche is recommending 
     the Club Sport arms for heavy competitive uses. They have a 951 part 
     number instead of a 944 number.
     
     In the Northeast, there are a lot of stories about balljoint failures 
     at speed on cars that have been lowered too much. The July 1 Driver Ed 
     at Watkins Glen won't allow lowered 944s with aluminum arms to run.
     


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 06 Jul 95 07:35:00 PST
From: "RADSICKT" <radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil>
Subject: Dave's 914 engine: Break-in procedure

 Dave,
 
 I know that list-meister *STAN* has put out a really good description of this 
 (and may have done so again for you -- I'm on the digest version)  But here's 
 is a test of my memory:
 
 1) Like Mike W said, remove coil wire and turn engine over until oil pressure 
 light goes out (make sure oil filter is FILLED before you start this) Do not 
 use synthetic yet, use 30Wt
 
 2) Reinstall coil wire, make sure all hoses and stuff are hooked up right, and 
 start the car.  Immediately bring revs up to 2000-3000 and hold there for an 
 honest-to-god 20 minutes.  Use a watch!  I have done this on a few Type 1 
 engines and trust me it seems like a LONG time!  This helps to break in the cam 
 and lifters, plus get the oil heated up and circulating everywhere.
 
 3) Drain the oil.  Replace filter.  New oil (not synthetic yet).  Start car and 
 take it for your first drive.  Never go beyond 3/4 throttle and never stay 
 cruising at a constant speed/RPM.  Sort of let the engine rev up and then rev 
 down.  Vary your rates of acceleration and deceleration.  This seats the rings 
 properly for various engine demands.  Make this trip about 40-60 minutes.  Do 
 not test out the RPM capacity at this time.
 
 4) Drain the oil.  Replace filter. New oil (nope- still no synthetic!) Let 
 engine cool overnight.  Have a beer and sleep.  Wake up. Brush your teeth.  Set 
 the valves properly.  Now your car is sort of drivable as a car.  Just try to 
 vary engine RPM and don't rev too high.
 
 5) At 300 miles, new oil (Maybe synthetic?) and filter, reset valves.
 
 6) When oil consumption drops (rings have seated) swap over to synthetic and 
 change oil and filters every 3000-5000 and set valves every 6000.
 
 Some of that varies I am sure from the STAN HANKS approved method, so use his 
 if in doubt.
 
 -Tim

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 11:43:42 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Re: Tracking Tiptronic

Hello All,

Bruce writes:
> ...
>experience amongst the P_philes with the Tiptronic on the track?  In
>theory it should be as fast or faster.  But, it also seems reasonable that
>it would ...

I think the biggest disadvantage a Tiptronic car has is that the Tiptronic
tranny is only a four speed. With only four gears to choose from, as opposed
to six speeds in the manual car, the Tiptronic car is not going to be in the
good part of the powerband as often. Since shifting is really a minor part of
track driving once heel and toe is mastered, the faster (and easier) shifting
of the Tip does not make up for the loss of gears. 

One other disadvantage is the Tip trans is heavier.

My $.02,
Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 11:07:15 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: Air Conditioners at speed

>Does anyone have an opinion on running the AC while reving the engine to red
>line?  Can the AC handle red line with no problems.  I can feel a decrease in
>performance but is it bad for either the engine or the AC.  My wife insists on
>being cool while I would just as soon take the AC out of the car.  

This should cause no hardships on your engine.  It takes the same amount
of work for the engine to red line whether all the power is going to
the rear wheels or some is taken by the AC compressor.  This will
obviously lead to a decrease in power to the wheels and hence will
decrease overall performance.  An intersting point is that in newer
cars at speed, running the AC will probably not hurt perfromance as
much as the aerodynamic hit for having the windows down will.  Of course,
at speed will probably be a triple digit figure, but it should be an
interesting experiment to try... <G>

Ross Stites
'87 951

Date: Thu,  6 Jul 1995 12:27:34 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Tracking Tiptronic

> you will want within one shift forward or back. For instance, if you are 
> in 3rd, the shift pattern would look like this:
> 2 1
> 3-+
> 4 R <--- The reverse stays put, and first stays put, for stoplights and such.
> As you shift to 4th, you push in the clutch, pull the shifter back 
> towards you and let go, changing the shift pattern to:
> 3 1
> 4-+
> 5 R
> and so on... they are working on this as a solution to the problem that 
> the conventional shift design was design for 3 gears and a reverse, or at 

	Sounds to me like a modification of the old "straight line" 3-speed
shifter...  think it could be done with a modification of the "spring
gate" used on old 911/914's?  I'm thinking have the gate move with the
shifter when you engage a gear... and you'd have to have two different
spring gates, not just one big one... oh well, I should probably get
back to work...

later,


Nate

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 95 09:30:46 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Steering Column Wobble



The steering shaft in the '72 911T that I am restoring wobbles in 
the steering column.  The problem appears to be lack of support 
for the shaft at the steering wheel end.  The parts manual shows 
a Mounting, 914.347.711.00, which looks like it ought to fit 
snugly around the steering shaft to hold it in place.  When I look 
at mine, the Mounting is there, but it sure isn't snug, and I can't 
easily pry it out to inspect it. The only thing I can think of is that 
part of the Mounting, the part that snugged up against the 
steering shaft, has disintegrated and fallen down the column 
where I can't see it.

Several catalog houses offer a plastic bushing that purports to 
fix the wobble, and indeed the part pictured looks like it will do 
the trick.  However, it is specified for '74 -  '89 911's, not '72's.

Has anyone had this problem with an early 911?  Do I need a 
new 
914.347.711.00?  I suppose I have to remove the entire column to 
fix it.

Thanks for your help.

 -Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 95 09:37:53 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Installing gears on crankshaft


I just had my crank polished, and now I have to replace the 
distributor and intermediate shaft drive gears.  I've done the 
former before, but not the latter.  Haynes says to heat it to 350 
degrees F in an oil bath before driving it on.  Sounds pretty 
hot and possibly messy, and how am I supposed to know 
how hot the oil is?  I think my wife would smell it if I used 
the kitchen over, and I don't want to risk the consequences.

Anybody done one of these before?  Any advice? 

Many thanks.

 -Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

'72 911T with crankshaft sans drive gears

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 18:01:08 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Braking


heavy braking and/or engine braking.

brake pad sets cost around $100 clutches around $800 - you take your pick

my view is brake first, then change gear.

there is no way you can brake, clutch and match the revs on the throttle 
all at the same time.

The safest way is to aim to complete your braking 15 yard before the 
corner, wap it into the correct gear then hit the loud pedal. 

Pete

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 95 10:10:28 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Brakes and Braking.


The current thread about braking should include a little history about
technique.

In the old days, before the Birdcage Maserati, everyone jammed gears
up and down to accerate and deaccelerate because the damn brakes would 
fade after a few miles or laps if the car was driven in a *spirited*
manner. 

Hero drivers would brag about their "heel and toe" technique for mashing
what was left of the brakes and simultaneously the throttle to match 
engine rpms with whatever gear he selected. Most of the time, the hero
driver got it right, when he didn't, the engine or some other component
would barf itself onto the track to show the world the goof.

The Italians figured that it could ba faster to just mash the brakes 
hard, select the correct gear for exiting the corner and be on with it.
This valuable piece of driving style came from no less than one Juan
Manuel Fangio. The secret to his trouncing of Mike Hawthorne at the
Nurburgring was that Senor Fangio dive-bombed the corners and didn't 
bother with selecting the intermediate gears. He figured the brakes 
would and did last. 

Porsches of the era had great brakes and could be driven in this manner, providing you respected the gearbox.

When the Birdcage Maserati appeared, lap times feel as every track it
 appeared at. It was not a particularly fast car, yet it had better 
handling and brakes than it's contempraries. Phil Hill and Roger Penske
recognized this and turned the American racing world upside down with 
this car. Penske: "all you do is set up your line in, mash the brakes 
hard, select the correct gear and stand on the gas. Anyone tailing you 
in another car will lose four or five lengths to you. I wish it had
more power, though."

Porsche had used most of this philosphy for some time, yet the smaller 
displacement engines needed to be worked hard to keep up with the
bigger cars. You learned that minimal braking and concentrating on the 
line and maximum velocity through the corners kept you right on a larger 
Ferrari's tail. You either drove well or finished last. 

When you are learning, concentrate on the line first, exiting the corner 
smoothly next, then the throttle application point and correct gear and 
finally your brake points. I usually have most of the first stuff 
memorized for a given track. I then start working in the brake points 
closer to the apex. Times drop rapidly once you find the deepest point
to suit your style. I very rarely use the engine for braking as it
upsets the balance ofthe car if you aren't careful and don't have the 
rpm matched. 

If you see old movies and watch people spinning as they enter a corner, 
then they have probably locked the rear brakes or selected the wrong 
gear/broken the rear tires loose thereby losing control. 

Jim Pasha

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 13:36:04 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Brakes and Braking.

>
>When you are learning, concentrate on the line first, exiting the corner 
>smoothly next, then the throttle application point and correct gear and 
>finally your brake points. I usually have most of the first stuff 
>memorized for a given track. I then start working in the brake points 
>closer to the apex. Times drop rapidly once you find the deepest point
>to suit your style. 

Excellent commentary on the way it should be...

>I very rarely use the engine for braking as it
>upsets the balance ofthe car if you aren't careful and don't have the 
>rpm matched. 

My student at the Glen and I had this very same discussion as I
realized that he was dumping the clutch just before turning in at the
ninety.  I had thought that he was hitting the brakes again, fairly hard,
before turning in.  When he rode with me for the next run, I was able
to show him how to match the revs with heel and toe for smooooooooth 
transition into the corner...

Incidentally, he said, "I do that all the time on the street, but never at
the track..."

He's a good learner, but we'll see how he does at the next event...
Good Luck!

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 11:16:43 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: Steering Column Wobble

> The steering shaft in the '72 911T that I am restoring wobbles in

> snugly around the steering shaft to hold it in place.  When I look

> easily pry it out to inspect it. The only thing I can think of is that 
> part of the Mounting, the part that snugged up against the 
> steering shaft, has disintegrated and fallen down the column 
> where I can't see it.
>

> fix the wobble, and indeed the part pictured looks like it will do 
> the trick.  However, it is specified for '74 -  '89 911's, not '72's.
>

> 914.347.711.00?  I suppose I have to remove the entire column to 
> fix it.

> 
> -Bob Spindel
> spindel@apl.washington.edu
> 
> 

A 914.xxxx part number.  Something I *might* actually know something
about.....    :)

The little plastic bushings pop right back out.  What you need is something
that looks sort of like the crush-bushing that holds the gear shift
knob on.  The factory part looks like a steel version of the center
layer of a piece of corrugated cardboard (did that make any sense?).

Wrap it around the shaft, snug it into the bearing, then reef it in.

Gary

Date: Thu,  6 Jul 95 14:30:14 PDT
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: bras

Paul, you wrote:

>   I am looking for some net advice on car bras.  My 928S4 is getting

>   1). Will sand/dirt get trapped under the bra, causing paint abrasion?

Yes.  Also, mildew can develop if moisture is allowed to build up under
the bra, which I'm *told* may damage the paint.  Also, if the bra is left
on for long periods of time, the sun will fade the paint, except under the
bra.  Maybe this isn't too noticeable for a black car?  But, it's best
to use a bra only for long trips, remove the bra frequently, and clean
any grit from behind the bra.

>   2). Are they lined with cotton or some soft material to protect the paint?

Cotton on mine.

>   3). Are the 2-piece models better/worse than the 1-piece?

I believe the fit would be better with a 2 piece.

>   4). How well do they behave at high speeds?  I often travel at 100-130 mph,
>        and flapping/whistling would be annoying.

At 90mph mine was quiet.

>   5). Any recommended high-quality manufacturers or styles?

I went with Colgan Custom.  It's widely available from finer auto detailing
shops; also available from Performance Products.  About $110-150.
Note- the mirror bras are ordered separately.

I like the Colgan bra.  It has cutouts for everything and fits well.  It uses
a few plastic hooks on elastic bands as well as bendable, felt covered, metal 
tabs to secure.  The metal tabs bend over the lip on the fender.  It works, 
but you really have to pull to get a snug fit.  I haven't driven/used the bra 
much, so I'm not sure how well this hold up to frequent installation/removal 
of the bra.

>   6). A co-worker mentioned a lexan (?) shroud is available. Any comments?

I don't know.  What about noise?

Matt Carpenter
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 15:56:57 -0400 (EDT)
From: Matt Clement <mclement@access.digex.net>
Subject: Re: Too much brake dust.



On Thu, 6 Jul 1995, 'Beans' D. Tong wrote:

> After I wash my car and drive it for a while, I notice that there is a 
> black soot on the rear end of the car.  Is that a sign that I need to 
> change my brakes?  Or would it be something else?  A visual inspection 
> tells me that they're still good.

This black brake dust is normal, though a nuisance.  You may want to 
invest in a set of brake covers, I believe they go under the brand-name 
"Clean Wheels." and are about $20 per set.  Other than that, 
frequent wheel cleaning is about all that I can suggest.

- -- Matt
   1987 Porsche 944S (just bought it!)

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 16:08:08 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Brakes and Braking

Jim Pasha writes a nice treatise on the evolution of driving technique.

>When the Birdcage Maserati appeared, lap times feel as every track it
>appeared at. It was not a particularly fast car, yet it had better 
>handling and brakes than it's contempraries.

Ah, the Birdcage, with its fragile spaghetti-tube frame and (relatively)
massive brakes.  A regular drill after each race was replacing broken frame
tubes, so I suspect any more power would have warped this car into a
corkscrew!  But, it made for some nicely competitive racing, particularly in
Sterling Moss' capable hands....

Bob Joyce

Date:         Thu, 06 Jul 95 14:46:40 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: 1987 944 Side mirrors.

I just recently disassembled my mirror completely to fix it. It had
come off its mounting base. You should not have to do anything from
inside the car.  If you swing the mirror out, you should see a hex
screw. Undoing this will allow the entire mirror assembly to come
off the door...however, you still have the electrical wires attached.
I'll try to recite what I did from memory.

1) Using mirror switch, adjust mirror as far UP as possible. This will
   allow you to see the locking ring holding the mirror to it's mount.
   You will see a soft rubber locking ring with small nubs on it. One
   of these nubs, locks in place to keep the ring from rotating due to
   vibration.  Rotate the ring counter-clockwise. Mirror can be removed
   except I believe there are some wires to be disconnected. These wires
   didn't appear to be motor related. I think the mirrors may be heated.
   Anyway, detach these wires...2 I think.  Mirror is now in your hand
   and can be set down somewhere.

2) Now you have to remove the mirror motor mount...3 screws I think.

3) Unplug the wires at the white plastic connector.  Okay, now you should
   have an empty mirror housing with wires and a connector.

4) CAREFULLY remove the wires from the connector and write down where each
   wire came from!!!!  I think there are 5 all together.

5) Swing the mirror base out to expose the screw that holds it to the door
   and undo it. You can now remove the entire mirror mount from the door
   leaving just the wires coming out of the hole in the door.

6) Go inside, get a cold beer. You'll need it

7) Using a star point (dont know what else to call it, its not an allen head
   but looks close) tip on a screwdriver, remove the 2 or 3 screws. Dont
   remember how many but they should be the only screws left to undo.
   This will allow the vertical part of the mount to seperate from the
   part that held the actual mirror.  The vertical part is where that damned
   screw with a spring around it is held. I used an hex head socket that fit
   in the bottom of that damned screw, attached to a screwdriver type driver.
   Drink some beer.  Put the vertical mirror mount on the floor screw side
   up, and using that hex head socket, push down with all your strength plus
   10% and with your free hand rotate the vertical mount until the threads
   catch.  It took me 3 times and a 6-pack before I could get mine in.
   Lots of cussing helps too. Anyhow onces it catches, tighten it.

8) Installation is the reverse of above.

9) Drink rest of case of beer.

This was not a fun procedure. But once you're done, you'll feel like Superman.
I hope this makes sense. I did this from memory plus I'm in a hurry to get my
car in the shop for its new clutch......more beer. *burp*

Darren Evans-Young
'87 944S Indischrot
darren@ua1vm.ua.edu

------------------------------

already "big-barreled & webbered" '68 912 engine with a bosch dist. on it. 
What I'm after is mega-reliability on the street, more than anything else. 
I'm not looking to build a killer engine-I just want it to run like a Timex...

occasional PCA/POC etc. track work? or would I hafta go back to the original
system order to get past tech inspection? 
Does anyone have any ideas?

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 16:48:05 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Option Codes

Option codes updated July 6, 1995

Option codes are located on a sticker under the carpet in the spare wheel
compartment.

CO2

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 17:44:22 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Option Codes

>Option codes updated July 6, 1995
>
>Option codes are located on a sticker under the carpet in the spare wheel
>compartment.
>
>CO2

        This one is Catalytic Converter, or Catalyst Emissions Control,
or some verbiage that indicates a cat.  That's been through the list
a few times, and I remember being amused that it's also the chem symbol
for carbon dioxide, one of the less-harmful emissions...

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 17:46:34 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Braking

>there is no way you can brake, clutch and match the revs on the throttle
>all at the same time.

        Yes you can--that's what "heel and toe" is for!  Left foot for the
clutch, right foot for the brakes, and roll your right foor over (or swing
your heel over) to blip the throttle.

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 17:51:39 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Fuel Pump

>My question is:  Can I
>connect the fuel pump to the main power cable under the dash on the left
>driver's side wall through a relay activated by the ignition switch through
>the fuse panel or must I use the original power source through the electronic
>control unit and the relay on the relay board?

        It's easier, but it is not correct.  The fuel pump / fuel pump relay
is controlled by more than just "switched power".  For instance, when you
turn the key to the "on" position, the pump runs for about 1-2 seconds to
pressurize the fuel system.  I think there are other examples, but the bot-
tom line is that you should go through the hassle and run the lines.
        BTW, it's not that bad to get stuff into the passenger compartment
from the engine compartment.  You just gotta pull the wire "boot" away from
the firewall so you can poke a coat-hanger in there.  With the wires you are
trying to run through attatched, of course.  Then pull up the carpet over
the center tunnel, pull up that black "inspection plate", and fish for the
wires.  I had no probs.
        I haven't tried running wires through the front bulkhead...  Yet.

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 06 Jul 1995 19:05:42 EDT
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: RE: Racing a Tiptronic.

I drove a Tip equipped 911 at an autocross a year or so ago. Here is what I
remember.

1- The damn thing upshifts automatically from 1st to 2nd just prior to
redline. You can NOT stop it from happening. It does not do this in any
other gear. Why Porsche engineers decided that it's okay to bump the rev
limiter in a manual but not in the Tip is beyond me.

2- You can not make it downshift in any gear until it determines that
something less than redline will be achieved. (300-400 RPM) While this
seems like a good idea, it means that the shift will likely NOT occur at
the time you request it.

3-It receives its power through a torque converter. Can you say Power Loss?
Okay then say Heat. All right then say Heavy.

4- Although the torque converter compensates somewhat, it's only a four
speed. Not five. Not six.

Barney Bettilyon
cmxk95a@prodigy.com
'70 914-6 4DTrack
'89 911 Cab 4DCommute

Date: 06 Jul 1995 23:56:16 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.COM (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: 73 911T mirrors, tint, bushings, Fuchs wanted


1) The previous owner removed the stock driver's side rear view mirror on
this 73.5 T and mounted tiny "Carrera Cup" teardrop-style mirrors (secured to
the  corner window frame by drilled holes!).  I'd like to put the original
mirror on.
  a) Is there a nice solution to filling the holes or do I have to replace
the frames?
  b) I have the original mirror.  Anyone have a good idea for a matching
passenger side?  A body shop recommended older BMW mirrors that look very
close to the factory's right side mirror.  Anyone ever heard of this?  What
year & model BMW?
  c) Anyone want to buy these teardrop mirrors?

2) The car has very dark after-market window tint; it's good for the interior
but terrible for spotting authorities.  I've heard removing it from the rear
window will probably damage the defrost wiring.  True?  Alternatives short of
replacing the window?

3) I need two 7x15 Fuchs.  Must be good condition and straight.  Any leads?

BTW, I finally solved the plastic bushing squeak/groan problems: new "street
hardness" Weltmeister bushings on sway bars, drop links, A-bars, and torsion
bars with fashioned grease fittings.  Fun job.  But at last the 911 now
sounds as tight as it drives (new ball joints and Recaros helped a bit too).

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 17:58:26 -0800 (PDT)
From: John Wright <jpw@reebok.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Elect mirrors repost

>Subject: Dual electric mirrors
>To: porschephiles@tta.com
>Date: Mon, 28 Nov 94 12:48:32 PST

In the November 94, PCA Panorama magazine, there is a brief discussion
of C2 mirror installation on page 30.

The text has "The assembly of the mirror base and headpiece is
difficult, sometimes requiring two people to compress a rather
large tension spring and lock bolt"

There may be an easier way.

If the C2 assembly is similar to the later "square" style electic mirrors, 
the lock bolt is a hollow bolt to allow the wiring to reach the mirror motors.

I installed a dual electric mirror kit on my 72T and learned some things
about them.  The dealer supplied kit came with zero documentation and 
required some extra parts.

It became a learning experience. 

If you're curious, read on.

In assembling the mirror base + headpiece I used a 2.5" X 1/4 - 20 bolt + nut
+ washer (a 8mm X 65mm bolt should also work) to draw the tension 
spring + lock bolt into the mirror headpiece threads.

1/4-20 is approximately a 1.25 metric thread pitch.

The 2.5" long bolt head rests inside the hollow lock bolt's head, and the 
mirror + base is assembled with the 1/4-20 nut + washer inside the mirror
housing.

Then the 2.5" bolt is tightened with a socket wrench on the bolt head
and an open end wrench on the nut in the mirror housing to compress the 
mirror spring and draw the hollow bolt into engagement. 

When the lock bolt's threads engage, the tension on the 1/4-20 will
drop because one turn of the 1/4-20 bolt advances the bolt 1.25mm
while the threads on the mirror lock bolt are 1.5mm.  So each turn of
the lock bolt after engagement puts 0.25mm of slack in the thru bolt/nut assy.

After the lock bolt is engaged for a 5 or 6 threads, the 1/4-20 bolt
can be removed and a 12mm star drive (the same as on the 911 flywheel bolts)
is used to do the final tightening.

Another item to keep in mind is the electrical differences between
early/late electric mirrors.

As far as I can determine, the early electric mirrors had one motor to 
position the mirror in both horizontal/vertical axis.  A magnetic clutch
determined which axis was changed.   So the early mirrors saw +/-12 volts 
to the mirror motor and either +12 or 0V to the magnetic clutch depending 
on the axis selected.

Later mirrors (1987+) used separate horizontal/vertical motors.
The motors require independent +/-12 volts for each motor, and will not
work with the earlier mirror wiring. 

To make later mirrors work with earlier wiring, the magnetic clutch
drive lines can activate a 12V SPDT (single pole-double throw relay) added
inside each door.  The SPDT relay will switch +/-12volts to the appropriate
mirror motor under control of the magnetic clutch on/off signal line.
One motor drive wire is common to the other motor's drive wire in this
arrangement.

John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 21:40:10 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: Braking

Peter Diffey said:

>there is no way you can brake, clutch and match the revs on the throttle 
>all at the same time.

Gosh, I guess I've been doing it all wrong for 20 years of track driving.
 Thought that was EXACTLY what I do every time I heel and toe/double clutch
on downshifts. Glad someone finally set me straight ;).

If you leave downshifting until you get off of the brakes, you have just had
to brake earlier.  If you jam it into gear without matching revs, when you
let out the clutch the car WILL jerk. I've ridden with too damn many students
who don't match revs, getting my head jerked back and forth. NOT the smooth
way around a course.  I don't use the engine for its braking; that would
imply that I'm not threshold braking and I do. Any engine braking I get is
purely incidental to getting smooth downshifts and smooth transition into
corners.  It is also a LOT easier on the transmission synchros and drive
train in general to match revs. And if you don't heel and toe, how the hell
do you trail brake into a corner where you also have to downshift?  You can't
left foot brake and downshift at the same time the last time I looked, unless
you LEFT foot heel and toe!

Jon Lowe
SCCA Nati'l License holder '74-'79
PCA and BMW CCA instructor '80 to present

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 18:50:16 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)

>Has anyone had any experience, good or bad, with any of these 
>"high-end" ignition systems?, (such as Jacobs, MSD, Crane, Hy-Fire, et 
>al).  I was looking at the Jacobs setup in particular.  The 
>application would be an already "big-barreled & webbered" '68 912 
>engine with a bosch dist. on it. 
>What I'm after is mega-reliability on the street, more than anything 
>else.  I'm not looking to build a killer engine-I just want it to run 
>like a Timex...

Thom:

I'm actually writing the software for a new high-end ignition 
controller manufactured by one of the companies yuo mentioned, so I 
guess I have a little experience...

Here's the straight scoop:  75% of what you hear about these things is 
total hype, 15% only applies to those cars that come with really crappy 
OEM systems, and 5% is useful only to racers looking for any minute 
improvements they can find.  That leaves you with about 5% of the 
claimed advantages that can actually be believed.

The biggest advantage -- and the only one that's basically
undisputed -- of most aftermarket "high-performance" ignitions (to 
those of us with really good factory ignitions, anyway) is that the 
combination of multiple-spark and higher voltage makes for easier 
starting.  That's it.

I could go on and on about the software metrics, the testing, the 
attention to detail, the to-a-fault error-avoidance and -recovery built 
into my software and the hardware on which it runs, but the bottom line 
is that, if you just want "mega-reliability on the street", you're 
probably best served by sticking with your factory Bosch CD ignition.

Hope this doesn't piss off my client... I DID manage to avoid 
mentioning his name, didn't I?

 -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 20:02:33 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Holes in 914 engine tin

I don't know how big these holes are, but I belatedly discovered an
item that you can get in a good hardware store.  It's an electrical
plug--a disc that will cover up to a 2-inch hole or so, with a screw
and bracket fastener.  You can paint it black.  I used one to cover a
hole for the smog pump on my car.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 23:12:53 +0000
From: "Jeff Kyle" <jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com>
Subject: Sticky 914 throttle solved.

(Whoops, this was supposed to go out last night, but I'm using a new 
newsreader and entered the wrong address. Oooops. :)

I had quite a night with the 914 tonight - new Mann air filter, new 
tires (Bridgestone Potenza 195/60/15s. Very nice, much better than 
the 195/50/15s I had - MUCH better ride, quieter, easier to turn, and 
they just plain look better! :), ...AND fixing the sticky throttle.

The problem was, as I guessed, in the shaft that the throttle cable 
attaches to. There was another arm that had a spring on it, but it 
was not hooked in with the throttle cable. Turns out it's supposed to 
be, plus it wasn't in the right position at all, and being that it's 
the "other half" of the main spring that's wound around the shaft - 
so not only was the secondary spring not doing its job, the main 
spring wasn't under enough tension! I'm amazed the throttle sticking 
wasn't much worse. Anyways, it wasn't TOO bad to fix, though I 
shoulda taken the engine lid off - it's a royal pain working through 
that little opening. :)

(I did have to dig out the factory service manuals that were lying 
around the dealership for an exploded view of it... Ah, 'twould be 
nice to own, but just a tad expensive. :)

| Jeff Kyle                                |
| jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com        |
| http://www.servtech.com/public/jeffk914/ |
| "Katarina" 1975 Porsche 914              |

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 22:17:27 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Cross reference list

> I recently had a daughter buy an old 77- 924 (poor man's Porsche) with low
> milelage. Seemed like a good thing to do at the time, but.... I've had
> several things go bad and Porsche parts are expensive. My service manual says
> that certain VW and Audi parts can be interchanged and the only effect is
> price. Anyone have such a list. Should I bail on this car or drive on ?

Well, as one of the resident anti-water guys, I'd bet you can guess my
response there....  That however is *YOUR* decision; mine is just to not 
own anything with water in it (unless it's been raining...). 

However, that's not the point. There is a certain amount of interchange
between VW, Audi, and Porsche but there is not that much savings available.
All of those mid-series waterpumpers have expensive fuel injection and
engine electronics, and vastly overpriced trim and interior pieces. As a
result, you'd do better shopping the Porsche aftermarket hard than trying
the VW dealer. In fact, there are VWs that are even more expensive to
maintain than the 924! For sources, there is the Euroselect line of parts 
from Porsche, there are tons of folks in the aftermarket who make their 
living by looking up who made the parts originally and buying direct, etc. 
Take the time to shop carefully, you'll be surprised how much you can save.

*ANY* Porsche is still a Porsche and as such is probably worth having.
Good luck figuring out how to continue to afford to do so.

Stan

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 22:21:12 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Widen the 914 throttle bore?

> Anyone ever add a wider-bored throttle to their D or L-jet to try to 
> improve upon performance?  

Yes.

> It would seem that it might improve things to 
> me.  

Only if you do all the other crap that you have to do to make it work...
And there's more tha meets the eye.

> Also, I know that later 914's have air injection, is this really a 
> good thing?  

It is if you have a late 914.... It is *REQUIRED* to pass emissions. As to
whether it's good for early 914s or not, you *CAN* use an air pump to 
let you run a lot richer than you might otherwise, but believe me, that
is a pretty extreme engineering job... Did that on my 911SC, among other
things....

Stan

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 22:24:46 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: High-end ignition systems

> >Has anyone had any experience, good or bad, with any of these 
> >"high-end" ignition systems?, (such as Jacobs, MSD, Crane, Hy-Fire, et 
> >al). 
> 
> The biggest advantage -- and the only one that's basically
> undisputed -- of most aftermarket "high-performance" ignitions (to 
> those of us with really good factory ignitions, anyway) is that the 
> combination of multiple-spark and higher voltage makes for easier 
> starting.  That's it.

While *EVERYTHING* said in this strip-the-hype-away note is true, there
is *ONE* other thing -- if you use a multi-spark system, you can run
very cold plugs without fouling on the street which means you don't necessarily
have to change plugs between tooling around town and taking it to the track.

If this is important to you, you've got worse problems than fouled
plugs...

> Hope this doesn't piss off my client... I DID manage to avoid 
> mentioning his name, didn't I?

Yeah, but some of us know anyway... Now what's it worth not to forward
this I wonder.... 8{)

Stan

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 22:33:02 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Holes in 914 engine tin

>         Anyone have suggestions on covering up some of the holes
> temp sensor sits behind.  My new sensor didn't come with a "boot",
> nor did the old sensor have one.

Two options:

1) if there's still something under the hole (like a temp sensor)
   the get the right boot. Probably from Stoddard. Possible from AA.
   Even less likely from a recycler.

2) if there is nothing behind the hole, go to an aircraft supply place
   and try to get some 3 mil aluminimum tape. Then clean the area
   around the hole well, tape it up and paint. Never know it was 
   there....

stan

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 22:47:30 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: ring and pinion on 915 tranny

> I was wondering if any of you could tell me how to switch the ring and
> pinion on a 915 transmission (911 rear engined) to be able to be used on a
> 914( mid-engined) Do you need a kit? Does anyone know where to get a kit
> if there is one? What does the renegade hybrid conversion for converting a
> 914 to a v8 contain? Does anyone have any tips on how to make a mount for
> a chevy 350 to mount mid engined in a 914.

If you want to do something wierd, your best bet it to find someone
that's done it before and do what they did. If you want to put a Chevy
350 in a 914, there are only a couple of places in the country doing that
so go ask them.

There is no "kit" for flopping the ring and pinion on a 915. It's *TRIVIALLY*
easy to do. What's hard is re-setting the ring lash once you're done. This
is a job for a professional shop that has the tools and the experience. And
while you're in there, it's foolhardy not to replace the bearings and
synchros and seals. So plan on spending close to $2k to get it done right.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 22:52:04 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Displacement Increase Inquiries

> I'm green-minded (and CA resident), so the Smog Pump and CAT must stay,
> but I know more power can be had through cubic centimeters.  I've read the
> Bosch F.I. Books and they all point to one thing, change the pumping capacity
> of the motor.  The question is, how much range does my Bosch-D have built into
> it?  I'd like to bump displacement up between 10-20%. 

That is certainly within the range of the D-jet system. And there are other
ahhh "tricks" you can use to also compensate.

> I understand that the
> Pressure Sensor (which does most of the "driving" in the D-System) is calibrat-
> able for different flow/pressure ranges.  Has anyone out there successfully
> bumped up the displacement, maintained correct stoicheometry (smog legal), all
> with the stock system?

But of course...

>   If the stock system needs mods. what are they?

You may need larger injectors, you almost certainly need to modify the Manifold
Pressure Sensor to be "adjustable". There are some other subtle things too.

>   Other than under the front bumper, where are some good locations for large
> capacity oil coolers?  

I usually sacrifice the floor of the front trunk, and mount a fan blowing
down on top of the cooler. Pull the 2" rubber plug thingies behind front
bumper and you have more than adequate air flow...

> The Type I's I've rebuilt all relied on oil getting to
> the heads through the pushrods...this seems very lame..is the Type IV the same?

Yup. And it works very well.

>   Most of these mods. are probably needed only on the track, but I'm a big fan
> of over-engineered cooling/lubrication systems.  

High capacity oil pump is a MUST. Also add a Canton/Meca canister oil
filter and an Accusump. At that point, you pretty well have the water
front covered on lubrication.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 23:01:43 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 engine break-in

>         Well, it looks as if Zero Hour is approaching.  So, I'd like to
> know what kind of special instructions I should follow to start and break
> in my 2.0L 914 motor after a complete re-build.

See the archives, I know I've answered this before...

>         I'm tempted to just fire it up and drive it for about 50 miles...
> It'll take major surgery to get the grin off my face by then!

That's *NOT* a bad idea. However, it's better to run the engine in at
about 2-3000 RPM for at least half an hour, let it set overnight, do
the oil change/valve adjust thing, *THEN* run it hard for about 100-200 
miles through a variety of engine speeds, repeat the oil change thing.
Etc.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 23:12:25 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Widen the 914 throttle bore?

> 	So Stan, tell me before I burst here, what happened?  Was there 
> no major effect until you made other modifications I assume?  

That's the basics, yup yup yup...

> I'm just 
> looking for cheap horsepower here, and I've been taught that air flow is 
> one of the major limitations to engine performance.  It would seem that 
> anything that increases air flow should improve performance, and was 
> wondering if there was a reasonably simply way to do this to the 914 
> short of turbocharging it.

That bit of wisdom comes from the days when people put smallish two-barrel
carbs on 400 CID engines. The 914 2.0 has *VERY* good air flow. What it
doesn't have is high-rev capability. You gotta do many, many things before
you get to the point that the 2.0 can't breath well enough at the max
RPM you can run it at...

It's a *PORSCHE* -- there's no such thing as cheap horsepower!!!
Sheesh, don't you people ever learn anything??? 8{)/2

> > Only if you do all the other crap that you have to do to make it work...
> > And there's more tha meets the eye.
> > 
> Like???

Then it would meet the eye! 8{) Sorry, I may divulge that on a case basis
but that's something I sell to customers...

Stan
