Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 00:48:07 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Too Much Brake Dust

Danny Tong says, "After I wash my car and drive it for a while, I notice that
there is a black soot on the rear end of the car.  Is that a sign that I need
to 
change my brakes?  Or would it be something else?  A visual inspection 
tells me that they're still good."

More likely it's a sign that you're burning oil through the exhaust.  Or,
possibly, leaking exhaust gas somewhere in front of the tailpipe.

The only place you're likely to notice brake dust is on the wheels..and then
mostly on the front ones.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 21:49:54 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: High-end ignition systems

Earlier, I wrote: 

>The biggest advantage [of aftermarket high-performance ignition 
>controllers] .... is that the combination of multiple-spark and higher 
>voltage makes for easier starting.  That's it.

Then I went back to debugging the rev-limit code in the 
ignition-controller software I'm writing, and realized that there 
actually are other advantages, although they have little to do with the 
"high-performance" claims:

    1.  Most microcontroller-based aftermarket ignitions include a
        rev-limiter, usually programmable to +/- 10 RPM.

    2.  Many even have TWO rev-limits... Very useful for those twitchy,
        steely-eyed types who are into bracket-racing.

    3.  Most "street" systems have some sort of anti-theft protection
        built in.

    4.  Some can be equipped with a knock sensor to retard timing on a
        cylinder-by-cylinder basis.

    5.  Most have extensive internal diagnostics to keep them from
        melting down if there IS a problem.

    6.  Some have programmable timing curves.

    7.  Some can even have their timing curves controlled by external
        inputs, e.g., they know when the nitrous has been turned on,
        and adjust the timing accordingly.

Each of these features can be implemented through additional hardware 
bolted to your existing factory ignition, of course, but there's a lot 
to be said for being able to buy one box that gives you everything.

 -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Thu, 06 Jul 95 23:06:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Re: ring and pinion on 915 tranny


>> I was wondering if any of you could tell me how to switch the ring and
>> pinion on a 915 transmission (911 rear engined) to be able to be used on 
a
>> 914( mid-engined)

[snip]

>There is no "kit" for flopping the ring and pinion on a 915. It's 
*TRIVIALLY*
>easy to do. What's hard is re-setting the ring lash once you're done. This
>is a job for a professional shop that has the tools and the experience. And
>while you're in there, it's foolhardy not to replace the bearings and
>synchros and seals. So plan on spending close to $2k to get it done right.
>
>Stan

>From what my tranny mechanic told me, (who did this exact thing for me),
you have to grind a little bit of the inside of the case to make room for 
the
flipped ring gear.  You'll also have to cut a small notch in the forward 
shift
fork thingy since it'll hit the ring gear otherwise.  Then you'll have to do
something about a new speedo switch (for later 915 trannys).  I bought a
custom Vellios switch for $75 and had my tranny guy install it while doing
the flip ring gear/rebuild tranny job.  Works great.

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 00:13:53 -0200
From: dhagood@henge.com (Dave Hagood)
Subject: Front End Maintenance Questions

Pfellow Pfiles:

        I am in the process of rebuilding the front end of my '84 Carrera.
As I rather expected,
this has turned into one of those "while I'm in there" exercises.  To date,
I have decided to:

1)      magnaflux the struts (bad curb!)
2)      rebuild the calipers
3)      replace the brake pads
4)      have the rotors turned
5)      replace the rubber brake lines
6)      replace the alloy brake line I twisted off
7)      replace the strut inserts
8)      reinstall the brake pad sensors the PO left off
9)      repack the front wheel bearings

        The question is, should I replace the ball joints?  The car has 95K
miles.  I haven't
noticed anything out of the ordinary, but they are 11 years old and, "while
I'm in there"...
Is there anything I'm forgetting?

        Finally, what brand of grease is best for re-packing the bearings?

Dave ('84 Carrera Targa, up on blocks)

Porschephiles #1534                         Fri Jul 7 11:59:49 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 00:23:08 -0800
From: nms@slip.net (Nick Silva)
Subject: Re: bras

> I went with Colgan Custom.  It's widely available from finer auto detailing
> shops; also available from Performance Products.  About $110-150.
> Note- the mirror bras are ordered separately.
>
> I like the Colgan bra.  It has cutouts for everything and fits well.  It uses
> a few plastic hooks on elastic bands as well as bendable, felt covered, metal
> tabs to secure.  The metal tabs bend over the lip on the fender.  It works,
> but you really have to pull to get a snug fit.  I haven't driven/used the bra
> much, so I'm not sure how well this hold up to frequent installation/removal
> of the bra.

I had a Colgan on my 928S for 7 years. I only used it for long trips
(3hrs+) and for bug-ridden areas. It fit beautifully, and stood up to a lot
of wear and tear. Two major problems, though: as it aged thru usage, the
Velcro surrounding the headlight cover flaps wore down, so that at speeds
above 100mph the flaps would come loose and fly backwards, beating
themselves against the hood. This never did any damage, but it was really
annoying, esp.at 100+! The second was almost identical to the first: the
elastic holders that hold back the rolled-up headlight flaps also stretched
so that they became useless, and allowed the flap again to fly backwards at
normal highway speeds. They might have changed the design by now, but
realistically, just buy a new bra after the 5 years it took to get to this
state.

Nick Silva
95 C4 (silver) on order, July build, I can't wait anymore!!!

________________________________________________________________________________
                         I'm growing Betsy in a bag.

                                nms@slip.net
________________________________________________________________________________

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 00:49:44 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 2.4 motor again

Michael Willis (mswillis@ix.netcom.com) wrote:

>In Calif. you need to use the smog stuff for the year of the engine.

    Mike:

    Since most people doing engine swaps put newer engines in old cars,
    this is true, but the regulations state that the smog requirements
    to be satisfied can be those of either the car OR the engine --
    whichever is newer.

>If your smog guy doesn't ck serial numbers then you should be ok as 
>the flat sixes all look alike to most smog guys.

    Too bad for those of us with 914-6 conversions that the sixes don't
    look much like the fours...

    In fact, the only way I know to do a California smog-legal 914-6
    conversion with Weber carbs is to start with a 1973 or older 914
    and drop in an engine that (at least externally) was from a
    1969-1973 mechanically-injected 911.  The converted car will only
    have to meet 1973 smog requirements (charcoal canister, crankcase
    breather, etc... Minor things), and PMO has a CARB Exemption Order
    covering the replacement of 69-73 mechanical injection with Webers.

 -Andy

1973 914-6 with 1973 mechanical-to-Webers engine.
That's my story, and I'm sticking to it.

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 07 Jul 95 10:09:00 PDT
From: "Thiger Jonas, Netsupport" <jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se>
Subject: 911 chain tensioners

I'm about to pick up my "new" 911S '72, tonight to be exact, and have some 
1000 kms or 1600 miles to drive back home.

anyway) ready at home, but the question is:

Date:         Fri, 7 Jul 95  08:50:38 EDT
From: TOM BLUE <tblue@STATE.VT.US>
Subject:      FIRST TIME QUESTION

I've been following Porschephille for about a month or so and have found some
comments very informative.  Some members (George Beuselink,  Larry Dunlop and
Jay Karoly to name a few have) have been personnaly helpful in addressing some
work I have had to attempt on my 78 924 (wish there were more of us out there).
So a big thank to them for their help, and now I'd like to attempt to reach a
"broader" universe.

I recently had to have my exhaust system put back together after it encountered
another one of Vermont's road "ripples" (in the winter they are called frost
heaves) on US 15.  At first I thought it was the cataylic converter that was go
ne, but it seems it really was the resonator in an aftermarket product.  The
muffler and converter are fine so in the interest of time (I had already waited
for 4 weeks for an ordered converter to be delivered) my local garage cut out
the remanants and welded in a piece of straight exhaust pipe.  Great! that got
the car through inspection AND significantly strengthened/stabilized the
exhaust system!

Now to the problem, the system now vibrates a great deal until about 4000 rpm
(or 75 mph) which is only possible on the few interstates we have in Vermont.
My question is did the resonator perform a "smoothing out" function using the
appropriate laws of physics regarding sound waves?  If so, I will have to repla
ce it because the sound level in the car is VERY uncomfortable at 35 or 40 (and
I don't just want to turn up the radio!).  Or is that in the repair process the
exhaust pipe was shortened too much?  What do you think?

Also, does anyone know of a good source for a used (but functioning) Speedomete
r/Odometer.  I have attempted the proposed fix from Larry, Jay and George to no
avail.  So I guess it is the replacement option for me now?

Thanks, and I look forward to more Porshcephiles.

Tom Blue
Waterbury, Vt
78 924

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 08:39:50 -0500
From: bpolys@solar.sky.net (Bob Polys)
Subject: Re: FIRST TIME QUESTION

Tom,

Just a thought. I am definitely not an expert and definitely not Porsche
expert, but:
>
>Now to the problem, the system now vibrates a great deal until about 4000 rpm
>(or 75 mph) which is only possible on the few interstates we have in Vermont.
>My question is did the resonator perform a "smoothing out" function using the
>appropriate laws of physics regarding sound waves?

As a mechanical engineer I know a bit about resonating systems.  Any system
of mechanical components subject to an input vibration frequency vibrates.
What most designers are *supposed* to do is either provide sufficient
damping to reduce vibration or tune the system to such a high resonating
frequency, that nothing on the vehicle can (technical term) excite it.
Vibrating mechanical systems have mass, springiness, and damping.  Changing
any one of the three will have an effect on the resonating frequency or
behavior of the system.

A story: A friend of mine flies Learjets.  When his company acquired a
particular new one, the front landing gear vibrated ferociously on landing.
Lear was contacted and sent an engineer to attach a vibration sensing
package with telemetry to the front gear.  The idea was to measure the
vibration and do appropriate tuning.  With the sensor attached the vibration
ceased.  The added mass of the sensor moved or tuned the mechanical system
to a frequency different than whatever inputs it received from the brakes,
tarmac, etc.  The fix was the addition of a small lead (Pb) weight to the gear.

Not a high tech solution huh?

As a said, I am not an expert, but you could

A) Add additional damping (Mushy high dampening mounts)

B) Stiffen the system supports or the exhaust tubing

C) Play with adding small amounts of weight

D) Any of the above

However, if your talking about resonance due solely due to your detuning of
the sound waves inherent to the exhaust system:  Nevermind (Small attempt at
humor.)  No really, sound resonance is a function of baffling (dampening),
tuned columns of air (springiness), and air viscosity/density (mass.)

IMHO

Bob


>Thanks, and I look forward to more Porshcephiles.

Me too.

Building a Beck Spyder.  Need info on building performance Type IV/914 engines.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 09:52:12 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Displacement Increase Inquiries

> Does anyone have the ISBN numbers for the above referenced book and/or for
> other books on the 914 engine including performance rebuilding?

All of the Colin Cambell books on the various engineering aspects of
building performance engines. Required reading before you even start.

The Bosch Automotive Handbook to make sure you have the right formulas.

"Rebuild Your Aircooled VW Engine" from HP Books. Best source of info
for a first time low-grade 914 engine rebuild.

There are no specific books on 914 performance although I know of two
being written. You can get some good base info that you then have to
integrate appropriately from "How to Hotrod the VW Beetle" (so old
that dual port heads are a novel idea) and "The 356 Performance Handbook".
But, like I said, you gotta understand enough to know what to do with the
info.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 08:07:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: Wayne Joerding - Economics <joerd@wsunix.wsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Hidden radar detectors


Bart asked about the size of the antenna on my radar detector:

The antenna is approximately 3 x 1.5 x 2 inchs, however, it has a flange 
at the rear that makes it more like 2 x 2.5 on one end.  I doubt that it 
would fit into the mirror or the third light.  The system also comes with 
a remote laser sensor that is much smaller, about .5 x 3/4 x 1.5 inches 
that might fit into the mirror or the third brake light.  I havn't 
decided on a solution to the laser sensor yet.

Also, I mounted the display with magnets just below the ash tray.  My 
plan is to depress the ash tray if stopped, thus obscurring the display 
and only appearing to be a Porsche trasher of unredeemably bad taste by 
having mounted a largish LCD clock on my dash.  I checked with BeL and 
they claimed that the magnets glued to the display panel will not 
interfere with its operation.

I'm rather pleased with the setup so far, but I wish I was cool enought 
to have connected the LCD clock read out to a temp or pressure sensor on 
the enging and thus get digital readouts.  As for the BeL 615STi, I 
suppose it is pretty good.  It's the first radar detector I've had and is 
irritatingly sensitive to other radar detectors, but I can't say whether 
its worse or better than other radar detectors.

Good luck,

Wayne

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 08:59:40 -0700
From: rsaldana@qualcomm.com (Rolando Saldana)
Subject: 1986 944 Front Shocks and Suspension


After the last auto-x I've noticed the following:

1. There is fluid in right front  suspension area of my 86 944.
2. The car has developed a slight steering wheel vibration at around 65 MPH.
3.  Front tires exhibit a non-uniform, "cup" shaped wear pattern accross
the thread surface.

My assumption is that the front shock is shot and causing the leak as well
as contributing to the steering vibration.  Tire pressure and tire balance,
or lack thereof, are also contributing to the steering vibration and the
ugly tire wear pattern.

I plan to do the following:

1. Procure and install new set of shocks on the four corners.
2. Balance the tires (I may even get new tires).
3. Have an alignment done.

I do have some questions regarding the front shock replacement. Per the
option set for my car, it does not have the "474" Koni shocks/struts. Thus,
it should be equipped with the standard Sachs struts. According to the
local Porsche dealer, the Sachs units do not have a replaceable cartridge
and the whole strut assembly must be replaced. I most certainly do not want
to display a lack of trust on the dealer, but is this a fact? If this is
so, then I might as well buy an option 474 kit. If the Sachs unit does have
a replaceable cartridge, would a Boge cartridge work?

The 474 kit comes with 250 lbs front springs. However, if the front springs
are replaced, would I have to replace the rear torsion bars to match? I
hear they are a bear to replace!

Thanks,

detector?  I have ads here from Road & Track for a couple or three different
ones.  One is an Escort Solo 4 which is a cordless one.  The cordless idea
appeals to me.  It's $200.  There's also another Escort in here called the

don't know how often I want to look at the display and try to decipher some
little tiny picture.  That one is $170.  Then there's one from a company
called "Valentine One" that is supposedly the best of the best (according to
the ad) that costs $400.  It's got arrows on it to show where the signal is
coming from and the case is metal (I like that...radar dectectors always
seem so cheaply made).  Anyway, does anyone have any opinions on these or
others?  I'd just like to buy the absolute best one and get it over with.

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 95 09:52:04 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 924 wont start and 914 Drag


For fred Hess:

The 76-77 924 had an accumlator in line with the fuel filter but 
between the fuel pump and the fuel distributor at  the front of the car.
The purpose of the accumulator is to hold the system pressure after the 
engine has been turned off.

You may be having a problem with the AUX air bypass valve or the cold
start regulator at the back of the manifold (it has a fuel line going 
in and out of it). To check, find a pressure gauge for the Bosch system,
install it at the fuel distributor. Run the engine, check the delivery 
pressure, turn off the engine. Watch to see if the pressure bleeds off 
to under 25 pounds within 5 minutes. If it does, change the accumulator.
If it doesn't, then check the AUX air valve and cold start regulator.


For you 914 people.

Somewhere, this is from memory, probably Panorama, there were figures
printed about the Cd for the 914. It was expressed thusly:

	Cd = .34 for a 914 with all windows up and the targa roof on.
	Cd = .39 for a 914 with all windows down and the targa roof on
	Cd = .45 for a 914 with all windows down and the targa roof off
	Cd = .43 for a 914 with all windows up and targa roof off

This included driver's side rearview mirror and North American ride 
height (nose high). It could be a little better with the car set level.

I've owned a few 914/6s, they are quite stable at high speeds (140+)
if the car is set level (not nose low or nose high, both modes increase
drag and make the car unstable, nose high disturbs the air flow to the 
engine). The enlarged 914/6 GT engine cover opening is a desireable 
modification, even for the street. I kept two covers, one for concours
and one for real driving.

Jim Pasha

>I recently had a daughter buy an old 77- 924 (poor man's Porsche) with low
>milelage. Seemed like a good thing to do at the time, but.... I've had
>several things go bad and Porsche parts are expensive. My service manual says
>that certain VW and Audi parts can be interchanged and the only effect is
>price. Anyone have such a list. Should I bail on this car or drive on ?

>  "AARRRGGHHHH!"

Hey .. thats a sound I recently made :-) 

I had to replace a cracked exhaust manifold before my 924 I got could
do inspection. My mechanic told me $400, which brought forth said
primal invective. But then I found Imparts had a Bosal after-market
part for $198 new (which I ordered), and PAR-Porsche had several used
ones for $135. Reasonable price for 5 feet of metal. A <sigh!>  then
replaced the earlier utterance.

I still need to find a replacement mirror for the driver side, but
everything I have seen so far looks like $90-100 ... its just a piece
of glass! Still hunting.

BTW, I recently posted, per his request, Larry Dunlap's compilation of
924-VW-Audi interchangable list on this here list. If you missed it, or
are unable to dig it in the archives, drop me a line, and I would be
glad to email out a copy to you.

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 11:00:46 -0700
From: gcook@netcom.com (Gary W. Cook)
Subject: 924 / 931 Parts For Sale - San Franciso Bay Area.





Garage cleaning time.  Doesn't make sense to leave these parts in the
garage _AND_ the Bimmer outside.  Best offers.  Remaining parts from a 81 
924 ($931$) Turbo.  These are the parts saved from the crusher.  I 
guess you could call it a 924(3) now.


	924 Turbo Hood 

	924 Turbo Rear hatch & spoiler - Ok condition.

	Taillights

	Front and Rear Adjustable "Orange" Koni's - (about 15K miles on them)

	Front Springs - Two non-stock sets.  200 Lb and 220 Lb versions.

	Misc 924 Turbo Electonics - (no DITC unit) including the $75 931
	specific fuel pump relay with the that always goes bad.  Misc
	other relays.

	Front seats.  Recovered and used about 15K miles.  Look ok.  Tan 
	vinyl.  Side supports are a little weak on the drivers seat.

	Space Saver Spare (165x15) + jack 

	Turbo Exhaust Manifold.  2" hairline crack, engine side, not
	near the ports.  Maybe it
	can be fixed.  Better than one cracked all the way.  

	Intake manifold with one cracked flange.  Cold start valve, 
	freq valve, etc. still there.  Injectors gone.

	Some of the 931 F.I. system, including some new pressure hoses
	to the various valves on the intake manifold.

	150 MPH Speedometer.

	Stock instruments - Tach, Fuel guage, clock.

	Power Mirrors

	Power Window motors

	931 Headlamp motor

	Wiper Motor

	Alternator

	Coil

	High Pressure (external) fuel pump

	Stock rear sway bar + mount kit for cars that didn't have
	one from the factory.

	Stock front sway bar.

selling off my very trusty 1987 Toy Tercel 4wd wagon.  It was rear-ended

back end and a slightly sprung drivers seat.  I was fortunate though, the 
offending party's insurance company totaled it and paid me approx. 
$800.00 more than I had in it, which I pocketed.  It still runs fine, 
although the rear drivers side door doesn't open and close very well and 
neither does the rear hatch.  The problem is my wife won't drive the car 
anymore because  of the accident (gun shy) and the appearance of the car 
with the accident damage.  I basically have driven the car about 30000 
miles (3 yrs) for free and selling it should get me an additional $1500 - 
$2000.

I am considering two choices right now.  1.  85-87 VW Cabriolet   2.  
85-88 Saab 900 Sedan.  (choices listed in order of preference)

I really don't want to spend more that $5500 total.  The car must have 
the capacity to carry 4 adults in relative comfort.

Any comments or suggestions appreciated.

I realize this isn't Porsche related, but I have seen similar threads 
before.  Besides, who else to offer advice and transportation than a 
Porsche person.

Thanks

Keith

Date: Fri, 07 Jul 95 17:26:02 EST
From: "Thwen Chaloemtiarana" <chaloemt@vrinet.com>
Subject: Long, Re: Wisdom on 2nd car

Keith,

I come from a P-car/SAAB family.  'Course we used to be a VW family, but all 
that's left of the campers, busses, bugs, and rabbits is the GTI my sister runs 
(into the ground).

My '85 900 3-door was bought in '90 with 79k miles on it.  Since then, it has 
moved my wife and me from Ithaca, NY, to Dallas, to Ann Arbor, to DC, and back 
to Ann Arbor.  Coupled with all the camping trips and holiday trips home etc., 
I have just reached 165k.  No troubles whatsoever.  And I mean it.  Regular 
services and that's it.  New rotors and pads a year ago, steel rims are no 
longer round so needs new ones, one exhaust system replacement, new belts, one 
wheel bearing, but nary a major failure.  Getting to where it could use new 
shocks.

If you really mean 4 adults and luggage, forget the V-dub.  We regularly stuff 
2 golden retrievers, 3-4 people, and light baggage in the car for pretty long 
trips (6 hrs) and everyone's happy, including the guy who pays the bills.

>From what I can tell from my close involvement with 5 or 6 900s (turbos 
included), and a couple 9000s, if you get a good one, you'll know it and it'll 
run forever.  If you get a bad one, you'll also know it PDQ; get rid of it and 
try again.  BTW, 900s don't "loosen up" like VWs seem to.  Compared to a '90 
Jetta my pal got when I got my 900, my car is tight as hell, no squeaks.  
Clutch on that Jetta feels like a toggle switch and everything's coming apart 
like Detroit metal after 50k.

My $2.00 (inflation is a killer!)

Thwen.

covered with car advertisements -- mostly Porsche.  Now at age 34,
when I return to my parents house and stay in my room, those
advertisements are still there!  It is really cool to read an
advertisement for the 1974 Carrera or the first 1976 911 Turbo and to
see all those 911s and 914s splayed out in their garish '70s colors.

Sign me up -- I'll buy one.

to spend ~ $250 (the going rate) for a tattered old book.  I'd love it
if someone reprinted it and re-released a few thousand copies.

and a few chapters about Donohue's life after the book was written

the rights to this book?

  Nick -
  My father is on pins and needles waiting for his '95 911 C4 Cab (also
  Polaris silver)  to arrive.
  Here are some milestone dates for your reference.

  Car production started mid-May
  VIN # assigned early June
  Brought to dock June 13
  Shipped June 28
  Arrive North Carolina July 12
  Get to the dealer/prep/etc (in Chicago) 7-10 days thereafter.

  The big variable is catching the boat across.  You could wait one day,
  you could wait more.  I think they have two boat-trips per month.

  Hmmm... I think it might just be about time to visit the parents.  I
  haven't seen them in such a while   ;-)

  Pat
  pbuddenb@inside.intel.com
  '84 911 Carrera coupe

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 18:55:01 -0400
From: Russ930@aol.com
Subject: Naricist rings

an upgrade. (the engine was apart for another reson)  Last weekend at the
Glenn one of the head gaskets blew.  In the past I have never had this type
problem and don't want to start now.  My question to the list is does anyone
know or have first hand experience with Naricist rings?  Would this be a
permanent solution?

Thanks  Russell

Date: Fri, 07 Jul 95 19:32:50 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: 911 window tint removal

          When I bought my 1979 Targa, it had the drug dealer look.
          Extra dark window tint and black metallic paint with extra
          metallic.  I couldn't do much about the paint, but I decided
          to remove the tint.

          The easy part is getting the film off. Just start in a
          corner where there is an edge and peel it off.  It should
          come off the rear window too, without damage to the
          defroster.  The hard part is now to remove all the adhesive
          that got left on your windows.

          I used acetone, lots of paper towels, and a razor blade.
          First wet a paper towel with the acetone and scrub the
          adhesive.  It should smudge, but not easily come off.
          However, it's now softer and less sticky, and can be scraped
          off with the razor blade.  Repeat.  You can only do small
          areas at a time.  The paper towel will get covered with glue
          too, so you have to change that often.  Be careful not to
          use so much solvent that it runs down the window, as it will
          eat rubber, vinyl, and who knows what it will do to leather.

          You can't use the razor blade on the defroster.  Just use
          more paper towels, scrub harder, and carefully remove small
          areas of adhesive.  It will eventually all come off.

          Acetone is relatively harmless, but it is flammable.  Use
          plenty of ventilation, and be careful with the discarded
          paper towels.  You might want to wear a respirator with
          organic cartridges when doing the rear window.  Even with my
          roof off, I found I was getting light-headed from the fumes,
          and I had to stop and get some fresh air.  Plan on taking 3
          to 4 hours to strip all windows.

          Now if I could get some of that metallic out of my paint...

          Mark_Salvetti@abbsmtp.abb.com

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 19:37:18 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: 3.2 oil cooler for 914/6 conversion

Bart,

You said:

>What is "oil cooler conversion for fitting a 3.2 to a 914/6" ?
I don't know what you are quoting from, but all 914/6's had an engine mounted
oil cooler with a right angle bend in the intake pipe on the bottom with a
screw on hose fitting.  This was to clear the rear suspension and mounts. Any
engine that big (in fact any 6 over about 2.2 driven even on the street) will
require more oil cooling than the engine mounted cooler can provide. Most
mount the cooler in the front like the 914/6 GT's.  You also need to add
grill area to the engine lid to get more air to the engine.


Jon Lowe

------------------------------

Date: Fri,  7 Jul 95 17:10:08 TZ
From: Eric Brown (NetNT) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: WANTED: 944 Info/Opinion

} From: Matt Clement  <mclement@access.digex.net>
}
} I went to see a 944 this weekend, and it'll be my first Porsche (used to
} drive a VW Corrado)...  I was just wondering if someone could give me a
} recommendation plus a little more information on this particular model...
}
}   1984 944 "Weissach Edition"
}
} Does anyone know what the details of this special edition were?  From
} what I can tell, the changes were limited to cosmetics: gold (vs. black)
} wheels, wider than standard at rear, 911 seats inside.  Anyone have more
} info?

All 944's have 911 seats. If it has the "wide wing" sports seat, then that is
a plus. Also if the wheels are Fuchs (rounded spokes instead of the very
angular "cookie cutter" ATS wheels), then that is a really valuable addition.
A set of good-condition Fuchs wheels can run a kilobuck by themselves.

} Also, the car's sunroof has MAJOR paint damage -- probably a function of
} being fiberglass instead of steel, plus some heavy-duty stone chips up
} front, but has a full main-dealer service history.  Should I overlook the
} cosmetics in favor of this well-looked-after powertrain?  BTW, the guy's
} asking $5000 for the car.

Hmmm, the sunroof on my '84 is aluminum. I thought it was steel, but the
magnetic base of my antenna didn't stick...

Stone chips are pretty normal for these cars and are nowhere as
expensive to fix as mechanical neglect. If the car has been well
cared for (get an independent P-car mechanic to go over it
for you), then it is well worth $5K.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 18:34:33 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re:       how to prepare for painting

I understand the problem, but would maybe caution you against the idea of 
using a coat of paint as a filler. Issue which comes to my mind is adhesion 
both to the surface under the paint you were thinking of adding and the paint 
which your paint shop will cover it with. If the paint you brush on is not 
sticking well, then you might end up with a bubble underneath your great new 
coat of paint.

Given that you don't want to get out a sanding board and some reasonably 
coarse sand paper (say p200) and just hand sand it close to the metal and then 
let the paint shop make it beautiful (my far and away number one suggestion) I 
would do the following.

1. Wash car with soap and water, and a good scrub with something reasonably 
gentle

2. Use a good degreaser (I use Sikkens M600, but that's only 'cause I am using 
Sikkens paint) and give it a really good wipe over with some clean rags. Maybe 
even use a soft toothbrush on each pit to get at all the edges. (Don't forget 
to buy the wife a new one if you use hers, as when you go through the process 
of rubbing tongues and exchanging spit later it tastes funny otherwise...)

3. Do step 2 again

4. Do step 3 again

5. If you have chips down to the metal, you need to use phosphoric acid type 
stuff (Rustoleum or similar) to ensure the rust is gone, then you need to 
prime with suitable primer. Remember galvanized metal needs to have a 
compatible primer, plus you need to be compatible with your paint...

6. Assuming no chips to metal, I would use a urethane compatible filler 
(really a heavy primer) such as Sikken's Kombi and spatula over each chip 
(probably leave the wife's stuff alone at this point...)

7. Let the paint shop do the rest....


Happy to give more info if you need it.....


Dennis

'75 911 S with Kremer 3.2  and new paint....

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 18:45:16 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: Front End Maintenance Questions

Sounds like fun, only comment that I'd make is why rebuild the calipers and 
turn the rotors? If there is some reason then it makes sense, but I wonder if 
I'd tend to leave well enough alone if there is no reason to get into it...

Dennis Kalma

'75 911 S with Kremer 3.2

Date: Fri, 07 Jul 1995 16:36:20 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: 944 Waterpump questions

About 1000 km ago, I replaced all the timing & balance belts and rollers 
on my '86 944 (using the P9201). The car is now at 85,000 km (53K mi)
and I've noticed recently a faint squeaking coming from the waterpump
area which I only hear when the car is warm. There is no fluid leaking
at the waterpump pulley. I checked the tension of the AC/Alternator belt
in case it was making the noise. A momentary squeak can also be 
induced by letting off the gas quickly and listening as the engine rev's
back up to idle. 

Is squeaking ok so long as the pump doesn't leak? Could the new 
tighter timing belt (4.0 on P9201) have stressed the old pump bearings? 

After reading the 944 FAQ, Factory manuals, Jim Pasha's articles, and
George's DIY waterpump instructions I still have some questions:
 
1. Buy new or rebuilt?

2. Where is the best to buy from (in terms of price)

3. What is the likelihood of breaking off a waterpump bolt at removal.

4. The crankshaft pulley bolt is torqued to 154 ftlbs. Is it at all possible
   to remove it by first blocking the wheels, setting the handbrake, and
  putting the car into gear to lock the crank? Will this be too stressful 
  on the driveshaft , gearbox, clutch etc?

5. If 4. is not possible, where is the best price on a 944 flywheel lock?
   (Perf Parts has one for $46!) The balance sprocket holder I will try
   to weld unless anyone knows where to buy for less than $40!
 
6. I understand the crankshaft pulley needs a puller to be removed.
   Is there enough room to use the puller without taking out the rad?

7. What is the typical lifetime for an 85.5+ 944 waterpump.  85K km
   seems premature.

Ken

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 22:19:16 -0400

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 1995 23:00:44 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Hot 77 won't restart

> I have posted this problem before. 1977 cpe after sitting for an hour won't
>restart. I put a new fuel pump in the vehicle last week. If you try to start
>the car 1/2 an hr after a hot run, it fires up fine. I assumed that there
was
>a bad check valve, and that was what was causing the problem. Is there
>another check valve in line after the fuel pump? I changed the Permatune CD
>and replaced it with a Bosch unit we had sitting around. Those are the only
>changes made (so far). Help please!

Fred,

Check the fuel accumulator also.  This thing has a diaphragm in it to
maintain fuel pressure to help with hot starts.  When the diaphragm
ruptures, the fuel pressure leaks down and presto! - hot starting
problems.

On the accumulators that have a fitting on the bottom, you may be able
to remove this fitting and see if any fuel leaks out.  If it does, I think 
it is safe to say the diaphragm is shot.  These are cheap and easy to 
replace also.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

standard for the '75-'77 Carreras.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 08 Jul 1995 00:54:13 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Paintless Dent Removal

I've seen this technique demonstrated.  It works by using pointed
steel rods angled 90 degrees near the tip.  Some tips are plastic
covered, some are not.  The bodyman must have access to the
backside of the dent.  (we're assuming "inzees", not "outzees")
The rod is placed behind the ding and manipulated to move the
sheetmetal back out, approximating the original surface.  

This method works best on shallow smooth dents that haven't
work hardened the metal.  It also helps if the paint has some
orange peel in it, like your average Detroit factory job.  Smooth
and shiny cars like ours take *alot* more skill to get right.

Done correctly, it's worth the money if you're between paint
jobs.  Being of the old school, I'm firmly grounded in the 
"beat and grind" method.  Real bodymen use DA's and paintguns.


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

 

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1537                         Sun Jul 9 00:57:39 CDT 1995
Date: Sat, 8 Jul 1995 07:37:10 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Adjusting Handling

Here's a blatant copy of a wallet card that I was given by a major
tire company. These adjustments do work!

I have also placed a copy in  the ftp directory of 
tta.com/pub/porschephiles/Images/UPLOAD.
(Stan, would you please move it to Tech Tips?)

- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Guide to High Performance Handling

Aim for the theoretical Neutral Steer - matched front and rear traction.
Understeering is a plowing or pushing effect when cornering. Oversteer
is the rear sliding outward on turns.


ADJUSTMENTS                  TO DECREASE UNDERSTEER        TO DECREASE OVERSTEER
                             TO INCREASE OVERSTEER         TO INCREASE 
UNDERSTEER

Front Tire Pressure          Lower                          Higher
Rear Tire Pressure           Higher                         Lower
Front Tire Section           Larger                         Smaller
Rear Tire Section            Smaller                        Larger
Front Wheel Camber           More Negative                  More Positive
Rear Wheel Camber            More Positive                  More Negative
Front Wheel Toe              Toward Toe-Out                 Toward Toe-In
Rear Wheel Toe               Toward Toe-In                  Toward Toe-Out
Front Wheel Caster           More Positive                  More Negative
Front Springs                Soften                         Stiffen
Rear Springs                 Stiffen                        Soften
Front Anti-Sway Bar          Soften (Thinner)               Stiffen (Thicker)
Rear Anti-Sway Bar           Stiffen (Thicker)              Soften (Thinner)
Weight Distribution          More Rearward                  More Forward


Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services 
Orders: 800-ALL-P944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 85 Audi 5000S Sedan,  80 GMC Pickup (drivers)
86 944 Turbo, 89 944S2, 87 924S, 84 944 (parts cars)

Date: Sat, 8 Jul 95 07:00 EST
From: Jay Ellis <0007142347@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: BMWCCA vs PCA events

Someone recently wrote:

>don't know what your ride is, but the bmw club runs schools at virtually
>every major track in the country, and they don't require you to drive a
>bmw, the way pca requires a porsche. The prices are lower, as they aren't
>in it for the money, and they get subsidized by the national club. 

For members in the D.C. area, the BMW driver schools at Summit Point, WV are
over double the cost of the PCA events.  The PCA events can save you about
$120 per 2 day event.  The BMW run groups are a little slower as well. 

Jay Ellis
'87 951 (dismantled, Head in the shop)

Date: Fri, 7 Jul 95 16:29:55 CDT
From: Bert=Garcia%DSS%DSS=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: 944 Turbo S sold.  Good bye for now!

Hello folks,

I hate to say it but the day has finally come.  My bank just gave me a call 
and let me know that the buyer of my 944 Turbo S had just sent the money and 
the title was on its way back to him.  The car is now officially sold. :-(  I 
had been getting a feeling of foreboding emptiness while the transaction was 
underway but I never realized how hard it would hit until I got word that that 
the car was no longer mine.  I'm sure some of you know it, it's an increadably 
mixed feeling of relief and sadness; kinda like breaking up with a long time 
girlfriend.  I'm glad the car is sold because I can now get the family wagon 
we need but I'm very sad that it had to go.  Oh well, like I mentioned before, 
I've got another little Porschephile coming who will more than fill any void 
the car left by many orders of magnitude!  :-)  

I would like to take this opportunity to let y'all know what a great group of 
people you are and that the collective wisdom displayed here is an invaluable 
resource to keeping the cost of ownership of our favorite marque within reach 
of the common man.  I thoroughly enjoyed reading the excellent commentary you 
all offered and especially liked the many different stories many of you told.  
I will highly highly highly recommend this list to anyone who owns a Porsche 
and has an Internet connection.  

So it is with some sadness but no regret that I must say good bye for now.  
I'm going to unsubcribe from the list for a while so as to make brain space to 
concentrate on other things.  I know that I will be back, though.  This 944 
Turbo S was my last. (I've had three others)  When I return it will probably 
be in a 911 but that won't be for some time.  I want to wish y'all good luck 
and keep at least two tires on the ground at all times.

Best personal regards,


Bert

family wagon at home, and that it passes a tech inspection.

Date: Sat, 8 Jul 1995 10:41:32 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : '72 911S 911 chain tensione

>I'm about to pick up my "new" 911S '72, tonight to be exact, and have some 
>1000 kms or 1600 miles to drive back home.
>The car has reached 152 000 kms/94 400 miles and still has got the original 
>chain tensioners. 

Holy cow! I find this very hard to believe, as these shouldn't last more than
ten years. If the engine is in good shape and you don't want to rebuild it,
I would not drive it more than a few miles with ancient tensioners.

But it made it this far, so it would probably be OK at low speeds.
I would not want to take this chance - if you slip the chain it
will cost about twice what you paid for the entire car to get the engine
rebuilt!!! (or it will become a parts cart - a damn shame of a fate for a
real S!).

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 8 Jul 1995 10:52:04 -0400
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: Re;option codes

Most of the late model option codes the so call "m" codes are included in the
fact books issued to salesmen at dealerships each year, if you can get access
to a '93 or newer one it will have all the option codes whereas the earlier
ones are model specific and by year in general. For your information most
code numbers never change from year to year.  The C codes are usually
emission or govt certification codes.  If you need other codes please drop me
a line.

                           Steve slr944.aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 8 Jul 1995 11:04:55 -0400
From: jfoster@omni.voicenet.com (Jim Foster)
Subject: 944S2 down on power - Problem Resolved!

Remember this?  We've been working on it for over a month.  This was
a real tough problem to troubleshoot because the car ran pretty good
on the street.

We took the car to dealer A the week after the Glen.  This was with
three days left on the one-year warranty.  We asked them to do a 15K
service and fix the problem.  They charged us $56 for diagnosis time
and couldn't find anything really wrong with the car.  They gave us
two cans of fuel-injector cleaner and sent us on our way.

I ran several cans of cleaner through the system and changed the
fuel filter yet again at the tech session before Summitt Point.
But to no avail...the car was even worse at SP last week.  It was
a struggle to get above 95MPH on the front straight.  :(  On the 
bright side, this was a good way to learn to keep my foot planted
from Wagon's Bend through the Chute (turn 4)... I actually caught
a lot of faster cars that way.  :)

So we took the car to Dealer B (Holbert's) this week and explained 
the problem.  Everyone was betting on a clogged cat and maybe a 
bad O2 sensor or DME.  It turned out to be a broken muffler!  An 
internal baffle had collasped.  As the car got hotter, the baffle
became a worse and worse restriction.  That explains why it didn't
drive too poorly on the street.  I think changing the fuel filter
at the Glen improved things because the car got a chance to cool 
while I was changing the filter...  The mechanic found the 
problem by banging on the exhaut system with a rubber mallet after
a back-pressure test confirmed a great deal of pressure in the 
system.

Can you believe that a new muffler for an S2 is $700USD!  And there
is no such thing as an aftermarket replacement.  Oh, the muffler
isn't covered under the one-year or the emissions warranty.  :(
However, my wife can be pretty pursuasive over the telephone.  Ask
any Riesentoter member... She complained that a muffler with 15K 
miles on it shouldn't just break.  That (and maybe the promise of 
some home-baked cookies :-) got the dealer to agree to replace the 
muffler at no cost for the part if we agreed to pay for the labor 
(1.5hours).  We very quickly agreed to the deal and now the car is 
as good as new!



>To: porschephiles
>From: jfoster@omni.voicenet.com (Jim Foster)
>Subject: 944S2 down on power
>
>I ran into a problem with my 944S2 (1991, 15K miles) at Watkins Glen this
>weekend.  The car ran great for a day and a half but then several laps
>into a mid-day run session I started to lose power at high RPMs.  I was
>getting concerned that I wouldn't even be able to make it back into the
>pits.  The car wasn't missing, but wouldn't pull high RPMs.  It seemed 
>like it just wasn't getting enough fuel so we decided to replace the fuel 
>filter.
>
>The other symptom is that at low RPMs it's "bucking" as if I'm jabbing
>at the throttle or not releasing the clutch smoothly.  You can even feel
>this at 2,500 RPM in 5th gear.  It smooths out at higher RPM (so we just
>drove faster on the way home... :-))
>
>Replacing the filter made the car run _much_ better, but it was still very
>slow to rev.  For example, I usually pull about 6K in 4th gear at the 
>top of the esses.  Yesterday I was lucky to be hitting 5,800 RPM by the
>_end_ of the back straight.  I guess I'm down about 20MPH in top speed.
>I _could_ hit the rev limiter in 3rd gear, but it took much longer to 
>get there.  All four spark plugs look okay.  Disconnecting the O2 sensor 
>didn't help either.  The fuel pressure regulator has vacuum at idle, as 
>does the other regulator at the front of the rail.    All the ignition 
>connections are clean and tight.
>
>Any ideas?  Could I have bought bad gas the night before?  We bought
>gas about an hour after a very bad thunderstorm.  The car did run great
>for two run groups the following morning though.  
>
- --

Date: Sat, 8 Jul 1995 12:14:54 -0400
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 R serial #'s

Oleg,

John Starkey's book, "911, R to RSR", indicates 4 prototype R's were built on
chassis# 307670, 307761, 305876, 306681 (BTW, you can see from these numbers
that they were built from 1967 cars). Also, a series of "production" R's were
built, #'s 11899001 thru 11899019 (that's 19 cars, and looking at the serial
number format, you can tell that ALL of these cars were built on 1968
chassis, even though the cars were built in the fall of 1967!).

I hope you have found a real 911R!

Good luck,

Phil Van Buskirk,  PMLetter@aol.com

Date: Sat, 8 Jul 1995 14:22:15 -0400
From: RedNineCo@aol.com
Subject: Re: how to prepare for painting

Hi,
 unfortunetly there is only one right way,although there is half ass ways
around most every thing.I wish I could tell you what you want to hear but
,the best things in life are not simple.A magic wand would be the best
solution ,but until they are for sale, the correct way is to sand out the
 road chips.one of the possible problems you could run into with dabbing the
chips is when it's time to do the complete paint job the solvents in the
paint cold penetrate the chip ereas and create solvent popping or chemical
reactions,pinhole effect or what is known as fish eyes from contaminents
trapped in the chips,waxes,oils,etc., and put you back where you are now only
to find you have a much bigger problem and twice the work.As to stripping the
car,it may only require spot stripping or D.A. sanding in the specific ereas
needed.As to the worry of removing the galvinized metal finish or the zinc
primers. Metal treatment washes and acid etching primers can meet and excceed
the factory's job if you buy the quality products.
BASF makes some great products for this application and is the maker of what
you get when you order factory paint from the factory.
silkkens ,and glasurit are some of the best I have found.
What you may encounter is a bodyshop not familiar with these products and not
willing to use them since they don't know how to .,or at least won't admit
to.
I currently own my own shop doing porsche body conversions and paintwork on
german only paint systems for the last 15 years if you would some tech advise
E-mail me back and I'll give you my tel#

Date: Sat, 8 Jul 1995 15:54:29 -0400
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: Re:autocross classifications

Regarding your inquiry on autocrossing your 74 911;

1.  SCCA classifies all non turbo 911's together, so right off the bat you
are running against some very stiff competition.

2.   Shock inserts are free in solo II

3.   torsion bars are generally not free, remember this is considered a
spring in other cars and is expressly forbidden.

4.  wheels and bars are ok but only if you can show that it was a factory
option

5.  exhaust is free behind the header but most local events are muffled due
to town ordinances, there are exceptions.

6.  for more specific infor e-mail mike piera at analogmike@aol.com


7.  As far as PCA is concerned, the PCR's( Porsche competition rules) are
printed each year for the Parade autocross, there is no rule that says any of
the 120 odd PCA regions have to use them but many do.  For instance, here in
the Northeast we use a modified version which narrows down 40 some odd
classes to 12, and we do not have a separate ladies class.  Best bet is to
find out if your local porsche club uses the pcr classes and rules, if so,
then get a copy and read them carefully, many items which you think would be
free to change are not and vice-versa, plus tire circumferance is a big
issue.


                           Good luck autocrossing

                              Steve  slr944.aol,com

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 8 Jul 1995 21:37:06 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: 912E running gear etc.

On Sat, 8 Jul 1995, Hod Pharis wrote:

> I have been looking through my porsche books (all two of them) and can't
> seem to find info on the running gear transmission etc. The '60's model 912
> had the 911 body a running gears but I am wondering if the 912E has the
> same. If it is basically 911 parts other than the engine what would be
> involved in putting a larger engine in and what would the ltr/hp limit be
> without overloading the transmission etc.
Hm... I'm inclined to ask Why? Why bother? This isn't a 914, where you 
get the different car (mid-engine, different looks) than the 911, but the 
same engine... If you put a 911 engine in your 912, are you making a 911? 
It would be cheaper to just buy a 911 for the price of getting a decent 
engine and 912 to put it in.

Oh, and it isn't litres of displacement that do a transmission in... It's 
torque and horsepower... After all, you could put a 4.3 liter V8 with it 
and depending on engine design, still not get as much torque and hp out 
of it as a 2.0 litre VW engine
 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 8 Jul 1995 22:50:30 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : '74 carrera Autocross class

Peter Kauffman kaufpw@ix.netcom.com asked :

>  In SCCA, the car is in A Stock.  What modifications 
> are acceptable? 

I have written a series of articles that answer all these questions.
I'm still finishing them up and will post the remaining ones
soon, then upload them all to the archives.

> Can you upgrade the Boge shocks using Bilstein Gas inserts?

Yes, any shock using stock mounting points.

> Can you lower the car?

Yes, any factory provided adjustment may be adjusted through
its normal range.

> Change the torsion bars to 27mm?

Nope. Springs must be stock in SCCA.

> Go to 7" and 8" wide rims?

OK, as they were stock in late '74 and '75 on CARRERAS
ONLY!

> Install sway bars front and rear?

Front bar is free, rear must be completely stock.

> Go to a non standard exhaust system?  Use a stinger exhaust?

Any exhaust past the manifold (heat exchangers) is legal.
But you must use heay exchangers.

> How does Porsche Club rules apply?

Lots more legal mods, you can choose things which give you
a number of points and still stay in stock class. The best mods
to stay in PCR Stock that are illegal in SCCA stock are : 

Bigger torsion bars, hard bushings, 1" bigger wheels (but you
already have big enough wheels), adjustable rear spring plates.

Also asked :

>I have Yokos 008IIS mounted on 7" and 8" rims.
> What pressures would you recommend for autocrossing?  Someone 
> suggested 26 in the front and 29 in the rear to start.

That's too low for Yokos. Try mid 30's :  34/36 or so. I used 38/42 on
the original Yoko A008R tires.

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S Targa SCCA A-Stock

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 08 Jul 1995 23:38:59 -0400 (EDT)
From: "James L. Fry" <JFRY@UOFT02.UTOLEDO.EDU>
Subject: High RPMS and AC

I can tell you my experience with the effects of overreving on a Porsche

AC system.  I once downshifted from 5th to 4th at about 90 mph and 
accelerated in my '82 931 up to the redline (a Bimmer was tailgating
at the time!).  The result was an instant loss of AC.  It turns out that
I blew the electromagnetic clutch from the front of the AC compressor.
The flying parts took out the compressor assembly itself. The total
cost to re-establish AC in my 931 was more than $1K!  The moral of 
the story, from my point of view, is that you may be able to run the
P-car engine up to the redline, but the AC may not be up to  following.
Life choices!

really hard to find these days.

BTW, did you get a bottlecap stuck under your caps lock key?

Regards from California, where some of us are still somewhat sober and awake.

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 21:27:34 EST
From: Lynn Kane 904-833-3660 <KANEL@mail.firn.edu>
Subject: Transmissions & Shifting

I have been reading with interest the various angles on different 
transmissions and shift patterns/mechanisms.
The current state-of-the-art setup right now is on the Formula 1 racing 
cars I believe. The way I understand it the driver upshifts and downshifts 
by pushing the appropriate button on the steering wheel. The electronics on 
the car actually does the shifting. I don't know if it's shift on demand, 
it shifts when you select a gear, or if it's done by a computer selecting 
the proper shift point.
The Indy cars on the other hand retain the manual transmission but utilize 
sequential shifting, just like a motorcycle. The is no "H" pattern 
everything is in-line so you have to hit the gears in order going up or 
down.

Just my $.02.
Mike Kane
84 944(in pieces)
kanel@mail.firn.edu

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 95 17:47:21 PDT
From: dupree@alldata.com (Jim Dupree)
Subject: Re: where is brake pedal light switch on 81 911?


911's from 1976 (I think) on have two pressure switches on the master cylinder that operate the brake lights and the brake warning light.

Jim Dupree
"71" 914/4

Date: Wed, 05 Jul 95 10:47:32 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: Re: where is brake pedal light switch on 81 911?


Its on the master cylinder.  You'll need to open the trund and look below 
the area where the brake fluid reservoir is.  BTW there are two of these 
switches.  Hope this helps.

Derek Au

P.S.  These switches operate on brake fluid pressure!  You can't adjust them, 
only replacing is an option.
______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________

I'm having trouble finding the switch which causes the brake lights 
to come on as the brake pedal is depressed.  The Clymer manual
shows an adjustment procedure with photo showing switch location behind 
the pedal on the floor.  Mine doesn't match.
I need to adjust mine so that the lights come on before the pedal 
gets to the floor ;-)  Where is this switch located?
81 911SC

Thanks,

Garland Phillips

Date: Wed, 5 Jul 1995 15:14:33 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Porschephiles FAQ for July '95


+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
+             PORSCHEPHILES - FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS              +
+                   (last revised June 11, 1995)                      +
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This is the FAQ for the Porschephiles list.  It is posted regularly,
once a month at or near the start of the month.  There are undoubtedly
additions, changes, etc., needed.  Your input is solicited in improving
the FAQ.  Send any comments to the address at the end of the FAQ.

Changes this month include some additional information about PCA and
some corrections to miscellaneous factual information.

=======================================================================

Questions answered in this FAQ:
  What is Porschephiles?
  How does Porschephiles work?
  Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?
  What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?
  Are there any suggestions on how I should submit to the list?
  How do I submit administrative requests?
  Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?
  What else is available in the tta.com archives?
  Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
  What about other Porsche-related WWW links?
  What about other automotive WWW links?
  What about splitting the list?
  What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?
  What is the Porschephiles Fund?
  Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?
  I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?
  How can I find out more about the car I own?
  What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?
  What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
  What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?
  What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?
  What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?
  What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?
  What references are available for information about Porsches?
  Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?
  Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
  Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?
  Who maintains this FAQ?

=======================================================================

What is Porschephiles?

     Porschephiles is an Internet mailing list centering on the Porsche
automobile in all of its incarnations.

=======================================================================

How does Porschephiles work?

     This list is being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming 
mail to the whole list at once.  The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  To send a message to the 
whole list, mail to

                porschephiles@tta.com

     To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other 
administrative issues, send mail to

                porschephiles-request@tta.com

     If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you
feel moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request"
address.  The list is also available as a digest, where you get a
compilation of the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all
of the individual messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow
mail links or who are just too busy to stay current. If you want to
convert to (or from) the digest, send mail to the "porschephiles-
request" address above.

=======================================================================

Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?

     The moderator is:
          Stanley P. Hanks
          Principal, 
          Technology Tranfer Associates
          P.O. Box 2087
          Bellaire TX 77402-2087

          e-mail: stan@tta.com, 
          voice:  1-713-661-2084 

     His Porsches currently include:  
          '64 356 SC (daily driver)

=======================================================================

What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?

     There are a lot of members on the list.  It's small enough to be 
effective, and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and
sets of experience.  You ought to be able to ask any question you like,
although it's probably a good idea to look it up yourself if you can and
save the net bandwidth.  Keep the diversity of the list in mind before 
you decide to not ask a question, or if you get flamed for asking an 
"obvious" question.  Diversity -- it's a *feature*...

=======================================================================

Are there any suggestions on how I should submit to the list?

     Beyond using normal good sense and discretion, you can submit
whatever you like that is relevant to Porsches.  You might want to use
descriptive "Subject" lines, including the model number when it is
relevant (e.g., "944 S2 Fuel leak query").  Your submissions would be 
easier for others to read if you make sure that your mailer wraps 
lines of text at 80 characters or less.

=======================================================================

How do I submit administrative requests?

     Send them, and ONLY them, to the "porschephiles-request" address 
(porschephiles-request@tta.com), or to Stan directly.  

=======================================================================

Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?

     Archives are available at ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/archives.
Archives in six subdirectories (90, 91, 92, 93, 94, 95) each of which 
has the archives for that year, in UNIX compress format.  There are no
older archives available.  While it might seem like a good idea when
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before,
there are OVER 13 MEG of archives.  DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE
TIME.  And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or Stan
may have to take access away.  Also, DO NOT ask Stan to mail you
archives.  To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY
mode in FTP.  On receipt you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program,
or equivalent, to restore to textual format.  Mac and Windows versions
of "uncompress" are available via FTP from /pub/porschephiles/programs.

=======================================================================

What else is available in the tta.com archives?

     FAQs: The FAQs directory contains the following FAQs:

          NAME                    LAST UPDATED
          911.faq                 Apr 19, 1995 
          914.faq                 May  9, 1994 
          924.faq                 link to 944.faq
          944.faq                 ???
          968.faq                 link to 944.faq
          carrera.faq             ???
          general.faq             (monthly) 

Feel free to contribute one on YOUR favorite Porsche or to suggest
revisions to those that exist).  These are available at
ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/FAQs.  (Note: Each FAQ was developed by
a different volunteer or volunteers, and none of us who worked on a
specific FAQ knows much about the FAQs developed by others.)

     Images: All sorts of Porsche images for your viewing pleasure,
mostly in .gif format.  There's also a directory called "UPLOAD" where
you can deposit your own images for inclusion in the collection.  If
you add any images, please include a file called "from.<username>",
where <username> is your login ID, that describes the files if
possible.

     PCA racing info: The PCA Club Racing Newsletter is now on-line,
thanks to the tireless efforts of the editor.  This is available by FTP 
in the directory tta.com:/pub/porschephiles/PCA/ClubRacing.  The 
newsletters are available both in PostScript and in Windows Write 
format.  If this is useful to you, send your thanks to the editor, Tom,
at "tt911@ibm.net".
 
     MiscInfo: Various other interesting bits of information potentially
useful to Porschephiles.
 
     Survey: The questionaire and results (when compiled) of the 
membership survey.

     Logo contest: Several Porschephiles logos have been submitted;
check them out and choose one you like, or develop your own candidate.
Someday maybe we'll decide on a winner, and then we can have T-shirts,
coffee mugs, stationery, etc., made up.

     And as usual, Monthly-Update, RULES, and Whos-Who, which get 
updated on a monthly basis.

=======================================================================
 
Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
 
     Yes, WWW access is through http://tta.com/porschephiles.  The 
FTP restriction above applies to major downloading of stuff from the
archives, not WWW access.  Suggestions for improving the WWW pages
would be welcomed, as well as experienced help in doing so.

=======================================================================

What about other Porsche-related WWW links?

     There are several WWW home pages related to Porsches.  Stan has 
created an unofficial PCA home page, and has offered to make room for 
additional PCA region home pages.  Contact him if you're interested.  
The PCA home page, listed first below, contains references to all of
the known PCA region home pages.  Here are some other interesting
links:

     http://tta.com/PCA/home.html -- Porsche Club of America Home Page

     http://192.253.114.31/Stuttgart/Porsche/Porsche_contents.html -- 
     Porsche Museum (courtesy of an American High School in Stuttgart)

     http://www.indirect.com/www/timjones/porsche/ -- described by Tim
     Jones <timjones@indirect.com> as a "914-centric web page."

     http://akebono.stanford.edu/yahoo/Entertainment/Automobiles/
     Porsche -- the Yahoo Porsche page

In case you missed it and haven't met Stan, you can find a picture of 
him at http://tta.com/~stan/home.html; check it out.

     If you know of any other links that should be mentioned here, 
please submit them.  

=======================================================================

What about other automotive WWW links?

     There are many references to other home pages in the links noted
above.  Here is a list of a few that might be of interest to the
readership; suggestions for more are welcomed: 

     http://ram.chem.tulane.edu:8080/f-body/trivia/gasoline.html --
     "FAQ: Automotive Gasoline"

     http://www.eng.hawaii.edu/Contribs/carina/ra.home.page.html -- 
     "The Racer Archive"

     http://ganglion.anes.med.umich.edu/NSX/other.html -- "Other
     Automotive Resources"

     http://www.dealernet.com/index.html -- "Dealernet"

     http://www.valvoline.com/ -- Valvoline's Indy 500 Home Page

     http://www.nashville.net/speedtrap/ -- The Speed Trap Registry

     http://espnet.sportszone.com/car/ -- ESPNET SportsZone Auto Racing

     http://www.motorsport.com/Series/Index.html -- Motorsports
     News International Index

     http://reality.sgi.com/employees/rck/PhOR/ -- Physics of Racing
     Series

=======================================================================

What about splitting the list? 

     Various proposals surface now and then about splitting the list 
into components based on car model, activity types, or other divisions.  
Stan's reply to these suggestions is as follows:  

     "I just want all you Faithful Readers to understand: there are only 
two votes that count. Mine, and anyone who's willing to pay me to change 
my mind or operation or whatever.
 
     "Posted rates around here are $75/hr for automotive engineering 
projects, $125/hr for information technology consulting, and $2k/day for 
expert witness engagements.  Just so you know where the bidding starts...

     "In other words, the list *WILL* **NOT** be split."

=======================================================================

What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?

     The Who's Who is a listing of those who receive Porschephiles and 
who have responded to the offer to be listed.  It lists the owners, 
their state/country of residence, their car's year and model, and
their net address.  The list is updated when people send Stan the
information, and when he has time to update the list.  He sends it out
on a monthly basis to the list.  Only Porsches are listed, so don't
send your Alfa Zagato or your Buick GN in to be included.  Send
submissions or changes to "porschephiles-request@tta.com."

=======================================================================

What is the Porschephiles Fund?

     From Bart Chambers, the custodian of the fund: "Here, gentle 
reader and Porschephile, is *The Problem*!  Porschephiles has over 1200
members and generates so much traffic and creates such a demand for
computer and bandwidth resources, that its future is in jeopardy if it
remains dependent upon the *ability* and willingness of any individual
to *donate* them.  In order to ensure the continued survival of
'Philes, we, like PBS, are asking members to donate to a non-profit
fund to be used to acquire the required resources, to be *owned* by
Porschephiles.  This will reduce the load on our beloved Listmeister to
merely backbreaking.  We are asking everyone for a *VOLUNTARY* Donation
for the survival of Porschephiles.  Send your check, made out to
`Porschephiles Acct# 3933150532' to Porschephiles Custodian, c/o Bart
Chambers, 1270 Lavall Drive, Davidsonville, MD 21035.  We suggest $50
for members, $15 for Students and $100 for Patrons.  Thanks."

=======================================================================

     Several different clubs are available, depending on your interests
and location:

          Porsche Club Great Britain
          Ayton House
          West End, Northleach
          Gloucestershire GL54 3HG
