The Porsche club in Great Britain, obviously.

          Porsche Owners Club
          P.O. Box 9000-277
          Seal Beach, CA  90740
          1-310-784-5653

Based in Southern California, the focus of POC is time trialing and 
racing.

          356 Registry Inc.
          27244 Ryan Rd.
          Warren, MI, 48092
          Telephone: 1-810-558-3692

For 356 enthusiasts around the world.  $25 per year and cheap at twice
the price (The 356 Registry Magazine with Vic Skirmants' racing column 
is worth that, as are the classifieds).  5000 happy members can't be 
wrong!

          914 Owner's Association
          100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
          Palm Springs CA 92262
          Telephone: 1-619-325-6583

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries.  Dennis Deeds published the 
club newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly.  Membership is $22 a 
year.

          Early 911S Registry
          PO Box 363
          West Point, PA 19486
          Telephone: 1-215-652-701 (day), 1-215-287-5083 (evening)

Contact Vern Lyle.  Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter.  
Dedicated to all early 911S models.

     A more complete list of Porsche US regional and other special 
interest groups, from the January 1994 Porsche Panorama, is on tta.com,
in /pub/MiscInfo/sigs.

=======================================================================

I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?

     The following comes from Judy Hendrickson, Chairman, PCA National
Membership Committee (DH993@aol.com):

     "PCA membership is unique among car clubs in that the criteria to
become an Active Member includes ownership of a Porsche.  This is
apparent when you see a membership application and there is a blank to
fill in the VIN.  I know for a fact that "speculation in VINs" for
acquiring membership in PCA is not new.  We have a 35-year member who 
admits his original membership was based on a 10% share in a car! 
Innovation I have witnessed includes "loaning" a VIN number to a 
friend who wants to join so he can do his first Porsche shopping.  
Using a VIN from a car acquired by a PCA member who joined with 
another, earlier car's VIN, and I'm sure some people have just made 
up a number!  Also, once you have joined PCA and are in between 
Porsches, you can remain an Associate Member, as long as you continue 
paying the $36 dues each year.  Application for Associate Membership 
can also be made by "...any person, employed by a Porsche-oriented 
business, interested in the Club and its objectives, having paid Club 
dues and fees as required."  Associate Members cannot, however, vote 
in National PCA Elections or hold National Office.  Requests for 
Associate Membership must be done through a local Region's Membership
chairperson, to verify their relationship to a business.  If you need
to be put in contact with your local Region's Membership Chairperson,
send me a note including your ZIP code.
     "The $36 annual dues (Active or Associate) not only includes your
monthly subscription to *Panorama*, but an annual payment of $12 per
member to your local Region.  Other subsidy payments to the Regions 
may also be voted by the National organization."

     Some of the features of membership (also from Judy Hendrickson):

     *Largest single marque car club in the world! (over 34.000 
      members)
     *Award winning monthly magazine - Porsche Panorama.
     *Local Regions with local newsletters and events.
     *Vast technical publications - Up-Fixin- Vols 1-8 (reprints of 
      all technical articles ever appearing in PANO, vols organized 
      by year of original publication).
     *Tech Committee (of renowned credentials) available to answer 
      your questions.  Specialists for all models plus exteriors/
      interiors and historic race cars.
     *Valuation committee to help you establish the value of your 
      car.
     *Access to specialized insurance for Porsches that are second 
      autos/pleasure only/limited mileage =$saved (Leland-West 
      Insurance - must be a PCA member)
     *Annual National Convention (Porsche Parade) gathers in 
      different location each year; over 600 Porsches and 1500 folks 
      gather for a week of nothing but Porscheing. 
     *Dues are $36 per year. MC/VISA accepted. Must provide VIN# for 
      application to be processed.

     Additional PCA membership information (courtesy of Stan):

     The Club affiliates you with a local region based on where your
ZIP code falls on their territory map.  You *CAN* request to join a
specific region, and you can specify an affilate region or dual
membership in another region.  The local regions put on many different
events, some social, some educational, some driving or compeition
oriented.  The annual gathering of the whole membership, the Porsche
Parade, features competition for the national championships in many
events, seminars, a GREAT goodie store, and one of the most fun weeks
you'll experience.

     Once you have a VIN number, you can:

     1) Send a letter to the national office saying that you want to 
join, with your name, address, car info and a check for $36.

     2) Call them.  If you have your Visa/MC number and your VIN 
number handy, you can do it over the phone (see below for #).  
Otherwise, they'll send you an application which you can mail in with 
your check.  This is the FASTEST way, and if you need to be a member 
*RIGHT NOW* to go to an event that is members only, this is your best 
bet.  Don't count on using this method the week of or before Parade...

     3) find someone active in your local region.  *MANY* of the regions
are represented on the Porschephiles list, so that's a good place to
start.  Once you have found someone, get them to put you in touch with
the local region membership chair, they can give you the form, and off 
you go.

     For further information or to join contact one of the following:

     Judy Hendrickson
     National Membership Chair
     email: DH993@aol.com
     146 Coburn Ave.
     Nashua NH 03063
     (603) 881-7576
     or
     Nann Weissenberger
     National Membership Committee
     5 Nicholson St.
     Marblehead MA 01945
     (617) 631-4157
     email: NannW@aol.com
     or
     Myra Sutton
     National Membership Committee
     201 Mistletoe Dr.
     Richardson TX 75081 
     (214) 690-6205
     email: jsutton@Esy.COM
     or
     Wendy Gulick
     National Membership Committee
     4329 Hunts Point Rd.
     Bellevue WA 98004
     (206) 455-4329
     email: leedsg@halycon.com
     or
     Caryl Hatch
     National Membership Committee
     2739 Tanglewood Dr. SW
     Roanoke VA 24018
     (703) 989-0949 Note: Area Code Changes to (540) EFF: 15 July 1995
     or 
     PCA Executive Office
     P.O. Box 30100
     Alexandria VA 22310
     (703) 922-9300

=======================================================================

How can I find out more about the car I own?

     If you own a North American Porsche, Porsche Cars North America 
will, for a fee of $20, research the original bill of sale for your car
and give you a Certificate of Authenticity stating the facts and 
figures for the car as it was delivered to the dealer.  If you're 
interested, contact: 
          Howard Adams
          PCNA
          P.O. Box 30911
          Reno Nevada 89520-3911
Include a copy of your title or registration as proof of ownership.
It takes 2-3 weeks depending on backlog.  A similar service is
available in Great Britain from Porsche Cars Great Britain, for about
30 pounds Sterling.

     It's also possible to get dealers to run a search for warranty and
other repairs for your car.  Some authorized dealers will search PCNA 
files for warranty and other maintenance records on specific cars.  
This data base apparently only goes back to sometime in the mid-1980s.  
It's not known how widespread this practice is among dealers; some will 
search only for warranty work done, while others also provide 
information about routine maintenance and repairs.  Ask your dealer.

=======================================================================

What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?

     The following list was extracted from _Illustrated_Porsche_Buyers_
Guide_, _Porsche_Specials_, _Cars_Are_My_Life_, _We_At_Porsche_, and
the article "Project Porsche, The Early Years" in the June '83 issue of
_Thoroughbred_&_Classic_Car_.  It includes only more or less complete 
automobiles designed by Ferdinand Porsche or by the Porsche factory.  
Components (engines, transmissions, etc.) have not been included.  
The list is incomplete, in part because there has apparently been 
imperfect record keeping at the factory.  In addition, the nature of the
list has changed over the years from an in-house listing of project 
numbers to a market-driven listing.  Additions and corrections are 
welcomed:

      "1" - Lohner-Porsche electric car, 1900; Ferdinand's first design,
            but not part of the "official" model sequence.
       7  - Wanderer passenger car, 1.7-liter, 6-cylinder engine, 1930; 
            the first official model, chosen to convey impression of 
            prior experience.
       8  - Wanderer 8-cylinder saloon design, 3.5-liter engine, 1931.
       9  - Second Wanderer 8-cylinder prototype, supercharged, 1931.
      12  - Zundapp small car, 5-cylinder radial rear-engined, 3 built.
      22  - Auto Union P-Wagen Grand Prix car, 4.3-liter, V16 engine, 
            1932-1937.
      24  - Zundapp three-wheel vehicle.
      27  - Mathis-Ford Saloon.
      32  - NSU prototype (Volkswagen forerunner).
      52  - Auto Union sports car based on P-Wagen GP car, 1934.
      60  - Original Volkswagen prototype, renamed KdF (Kraft durch 
            Freude, or strength through joy, by Adolf Hitler), basis 
            for the postwar Volkswagen, 1934-1941; the 60K10, a variation 
            of the 60, was a sports coupe built for the later cancelled 
            Berlin-Rome race, 1939. 
      61  - Another Volkswagen prototype, a narrower version of the 60.
      62  - Volkswagen-Kubelwagen (bucket car) cross-country prototype.
      64  - KdF-based sports car, 3 built, 1937-1938.
      65  - Volkswagen for driving schools.
      66  - Volkswagen for export, right-hand drive.
      67  - Volkswagen for invalids with steering column gear change.
      68  - Volkswagen Post office delivery van, model A, 1939.
      80  - Mercedes-Benz land speed record car, 44.7-liter V12
            Daimler-Benz engine, 1938-1939.
      81  - Volkswagen Medium Van, 1939.
      82  - KdF-based military Kubelwagen, 1939-1940.
      86  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen with 4wd, 6 built.
      87  - 4-wheel-drive version of Kubelwagen, 1939-1941.
      88  - Volkswagen delivery van on Kubelwagen chassis, model B, 1939.
      90 -  V12 rear-engined racing car for Daimler-Benz, 1937.
      94 -  V12 rear-engined racing car for Daimler-Benz, 1937.
      97  - Daimler-Benz heavy lorry.
      98  - Volkswagen amphibious car.
     100  - Panzer Leopard tank, 2 prototypes, 1939.
     110  - Volkspflug Small Tractor.
     111  - Small Tractor (2-cylinder engine).
     112  - Further development of 111 above.
     113  - Further development of 111 above.
     114  - F-wagen, 1.5-liter sports car prototype, 1.5-liter V10
            twin-ohc water cooled mid-engined coupe, 1938-9.
     115 -  1.1-liter supercharged Volkswagen mid-engined coupe, 1938.
     116 -  1.5-liter Volkswagen mid-engined coupe.
     128  - KdF-based amphibian Schwimmwagen, 1940-1941.
     130  - Tiger Tank (Jagpanzer) "Ferdinand".
     138  - Volkswagen Amphibious Car (version 2).
     155  - Half Track version of Kubelwagen.
     164  - Six-wheel lorry.
     166  - Volkswagen amphibious car (production version).
     182  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen (production version).
     187  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen 4wd (production version).
     205  - 180-ton Maus tank, 1942; two built, never saw action.
     245  - 18-ton multipurpose tank, 1942.
     293  - Caterpillar tractor.
     312  - Tractor with petrol engine.
     323  - 11-hp diesel tractor, 1946.
     328  - Tractor, 28 hp. engine.
     340  - Wheelbarrow.
     355  - Volkswagen delivery van.
     356  - The original Porsche sports car, the first to wear the
            Porsche name, 1948-1965; various engine and drivetrain 
            components and numerous styling variations existed.
     360  - Cisitalia 4-wheel-drive Grand Prix car, 1947-1948.
     370  - Cisitalia 1.5-liter sports/touring car, 1947.
     425  - 20 bhp diesel tractor.
     514  - LeMans car, also called 356SL, 1951.
     524  - Improved 356 prototype with mechanical injection, 1951;
            not economically feasible to take to production.
     530  - Experimental 4-passenger Porsche, 1951-1952.
     534  - Volkswagen Small sports car.
     540  - Porsche America Roadster (Speedster).
     541  - Special sports version of 356.
     542  - Studebaker Saloon 1952-1954.
     550  - Mid-engine, 2-seat sports/racing car, 1954 (the car that 
            James Dean died in); the 550A was a redesigned 550 with a
            tubular space frame, 1956.
     597  - Jagdwagen (Hunter) 4-wheel-drive vehicle, 1954-1955.
     621  - Porsche single-cylinder tractor (allgaier).
     622  - 2-cylinder tractor.
     623  - 3-cylinder tractor.
     624  - 4-cylinder tractor.
     633  - Studebaker saloon prototype.
     645  - Sports/racing car, "Mickey Mouse," 1956.
     675  - Small Volkswagen 1955-1959.
     691  - Porsche 550 RS (1956)
     695  - Porsche predevelopment (T7) for 911.
     702  - One man Helicopter.
     718  - Bergspyder sports/racing car (RSK), 1957; the 718/2 was a 
            1.5-liter single-seat racing car (F-2), 1959.
     726  - Volkswagen Saloon 1958.
     728  - Small Volkswagen 1957-1961.
     737  - Porsche outboard motor.
     753  - Porsche 1.5-liter 8-cylinder Formula 1.
     764  - Volkswagen 6-cylinder saloon.
     787  - Grand Prix car, 1961.
     804  - Grand Prix car, 1962.
     806  - Leopard Tank.
     814  - Leopard Tank.
     901  - Prototype 6-cylinder sports car, basis for 911, 1963; 
            changed to 911 for production because of conflict with 
            Peugeot numbering scheme.  6 prototypes built.
     904  - Mid-engine competition GT coupe, with various engines in 
            1963-1964, 100+ built, some for street use. 
     906  - Competition sports coupe (space frame), 1966-1967.
     907  - Sports/racing coupe, various iterations, 1967-1968.
     908  - 3-liter, 8-cylinder competition car, various bodies,
            1968-1970.
     909  - 2-liter hill climb spyder, 1968.
     910  - Sports racing coupe, different configurations, 1966-1968.
     911  - Porsche's flagship.  Built from 1964 (excluding the '63
            901 prototype) in numerous variations through the 993.  
            Rear-engined, air-cooled, boxer six-cylinder engine.
            Many engine variations have existed through its long life, 
            from the original 2-liter car to the 3.8-liter RS.
     912  - The 911 with the four-cylinder engine from the 356 inserted
            in place of the flat six-cylinder.  Built from 1966 through
            1969; 912E in '76 was a revival with engine from the 914.
     914  - The mid-engined car co-developed with Volkswagen between
            1970 and 1976; a popular autocross/slalom car.  The 914/6
            was a Porsche-built variant with a two-liter 911 engine
            inserted in place of the four-cylinder engine and other
            refinements.
     916  - Projected 2.4-liter version of 914/6, 1971.  Was apparently
            used in competition by the factory.  Also, a few examples 
            of an 8-cylinder (908-based) version supposedly exist.
     917  - 12-cylinder competition car, famous for Le Mans and CanAm
            victories; various iterations, 1969-1973.
     924  - The first of the water-cooled front-engine cars, built from
            1976 to 1988.  Originally with a four-cylinder, Audi-derived
            engine; updated in mid-86 as the 924S with the 944 drivetrain;
            has the best aerodynamic shape of any street Porsche.
     928  - The high-end car produced from 1978 to present, V8 in the
            front, water-cooled, has grown from an original 4.5-liter
            to 5.4 today.
     930  - Turbocharged 911, homologation and street version of the
            racing 934.
     931  - Turbocharged 924, sold in 1980-1982.
     934  - Group 4 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1975-1976.
     935  - Group 5 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1976.
     936  - Group 6 turbocharged spyder, 1976.
     937  - 924 Carrera GT.
     939  - 924 Carrera GT Le Mans.
     944  - Front-engined, water-cooled inline four-cylinder car, with
            nearly perfect 50/50 weight bias.  Sixteen-valve and
            turbocharged versions were produced.  Produced from 1982
            through 1991. 2.5-liter displacement, except for a 2.7-liter
            eight-valve 944 model in 1989 and the 3-liter 944S2.
     951  - The turbo version of the 944.  Built from 1985 to 1991.
     956  - GT racing car, loosely based on 911; 1982-1983.
     959  - Supercar 911 derivative; 2.85-liter, four-valve, twin cam,
            dual turbochargers, all-wheel drive; not street-legal in US.
     961  - Racing version of the 959.
     962  - GT racing car based loosely on 911; used in endurance racing 
            and IMSA GTP; 1984.
     964  - The 911 Carrera 2 and Carrera 4, introduced in 1989.
     968  - Rebirth of the 944 series in 1992 with revised styling.  A 
            noteworthy feature is variable valve timing.
     986  - The Boxster, due in Sept. '96, the newest hope for Porsche's 
            future.
     993  - The latest iteration of the 911, introduced in 1994.

    1764  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1834  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1866  - Volkswagen successor.
    1906  - Leopard tank.
    1966  - Volkswagen small car prototype.
    2539  - "Save" ambulance.
    2567  - "Orbit" fire fighting system.
    2708  - Cart.

=======================================================================

What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
 
     General answer:  Buy the latest one you can afford of the model you
like.  Within models, there are certain years that are generally thought
of as more reliable or otherwise desirable, and others that have proved
troublesome over the years.  If you have questions about a particular
model, ask the list.  (We are looking for contributors to write about 
specific models.  Contributions, which may be too lengthy to include 
here, will be stored at tta.com and available via FTP.  Dave Darling has
gotten the ball rolling with a summary for the 914.  Feel free to 
contribute regarding your favorite model.)

=======================================================================

What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?

     There are several kinds of events organized and run by Porsche
clubs and organizations:

     Autocrosses.  These normally occur in a large parking lot or other 
relatively flat, open area.  The lot is filled with traffic cones that 
define a course.  Only 2 or 3 cars are on the course at the same time, 
and never at the same location on the course.  You race against the 
clock, and your times are compared to others in your class.  Classes 
are organized so that you compete against similarly-configured cars of 
about equal capability, ranging from box-stock to extensively modified.
Autocrossing is probably the safest and cheapest way to go fast in your 
Porsche (or any other car for that matter).  In some parts of the 
country, autocrosses are called slaloms.

     Time Trials.  These are also timed events, but they usually take
place on an actual race course.  They are often held in conjunction
with Track Events.  The time trial, like the autocross, is not against
other cars at the same time but against a clock.

     Driver's Education.  These events are held at a race track (but not
during a formal race meeting).  Multiple cars are on the track at the 
same time.  Instructors ride with the students, who are taught to drive 
at speed safely.  The US PCA has a basic set of rules and various PCA 
regions have their own rules which don't differ much from each other.  
Usually, the only modification to the car is a fire extinguisher that is
mounted metal to metal.  Students and instructors must wear an approved 
helmet.  

     PCA Club Racing.  This is racing in the traditional sense, in that
there's a full complement of cars, a definite start and finish, and
head-to-head racing.  The concept is similar to the various vintage
racing events that are becoming so popular; the idea is to preserve your
car and those of others while racing against each other.  If you don't 
race responsibly, you are not allowed to race.  There's a policy
governing this that is referred to as the 13/13 rule.  Under this rule,
if a driver is judged to be at fault in an incident that results in
damage to his car or another (no matter how small), he's out of that
particular event  and on probation for the next 13 months.  If in that
probation period that driver is again determined to be at fault in
another incident with damage, he's out of club racing for the next 13
months.  Equipment requirements include the fire extinguisher, a cut
off switch, an approved roll bar, and a five point seat belt harness.
There are several of these around the country.  You should have 
experience with autocross and driver's education events under your 
belt before you jump into this kind of racing.  Contact your local
club racing officials to get copies of rules, needed equipment, etc.

=======================================================================

What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?

     BTDT = Been there, done that
      BTW = By the way
      EFI = Electronic fuel injection
      FAQ = Frequently asked questions (but you knew that)
      FTP = File transfer program
     FWIW = For what it's worth
     IMHO = In my humble opinion
      IMO = In my opinion
      IOW = In other words
      LWB = Long wheelbase
      MFI = Mechanical fuel injection
      PAG = Porsche AG, the mother company back in Stuttgart; "AG"
            stands for "Aktiengesselschaft," which means that the 
            company has publicly traded stock
     PANO = Not an acronym; this stands for Porsche Panorama, the PCA 
            national monthly magazine
      PCA = Porsche Club of America, the major US/Canada Porsche
            enthusiasts organization
     PCGB = Porsche Club Great Britain OR Porsche Cars, Great Britain
     PCNA = Porsche Cars North America (Reno, NV), the US importer
     PMJI = Pardon me for jumping in
      POC = Porsche Owner's Club, the *other* US Porsche owner's group;
            in the past they have been more competition-oriented than 
            PCA, which has many interest groups participating
     ROFL = Rolling on the floor laughing
  ROFL,PP = Rolling on the floor laughing, peeing in my pants (!)
     RTFM = Read the f**king manual (for some, "read the Ford manual")
      SWB = Short wheelbase
      TIA = Thanks in advance
     TTFN = Tata for now
     TTYL = Talk to you later
      WWW = World Wide Web
     YMMV = Your mileage may vary
      <g> = Grin
     <bg> = Big grin
    <vbg> = Very big grin
      :-) = Smiley face (turn your head 90 degrees to the left to 
            "read" it); various iterations exist using different ASCII 
            characters
    
=======================================================================

What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?


     Excellence -
       Independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Many of the same
       authors you see in Panorama, less jingoistic in their praise
       for everything PCNA brings to market.

       US rates: $20 one year, $35 two years, $49 three years
       foreign (incl. Canada): US$27 one, $49 two, $69 three years

       Excellence
       Circulation Dept.
       P.O. Box 1529
       Ross, CA  94957
       Telephone: 1-415-382-0580


     Christophorus -
       Porsche AG's official magazine.  Very good source of some
       technical information about their cars and technology.
       Beautiful magazine.

       US rates: US$28 surface mail, US$40 air mail

       Porsche AG
       Editors, Christophorus
       Porschestrasse 42
       D-70435 Stuttgart
       Germany
       FAX: D-711/827-6245


     European Car -
       Formerly "VW & Porsche", now devotes some bandwidth to other
       European cars, esp. BMW.  Lots of technical how-to's, but
       biased by "placed" articles from advertisers - beware!

       US rates: $18.80 one year, $28.20 two years
       Canada: $26.80 one year, $44.20 two years, includes GST
       foreign: $28.80 one year, $48.20 two years

       Argus Publishers Corp.
       P.O. Box 454
       Mt. Morris, IL  61054-0454
       Telephone: 1-800-877-5602


     911 and Porsche World -
       British independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Coverage
       of UK club racing, tech Q&A, owner's reports, and so forth.

       US, Canada, Mexico:

         Canada, Mexico: US$43 one year, US$83 two years

What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?

     Be aware when buying a part in the aftermarket that it may or may
not be the same part you would get from Porsche.  This holds true even
when the part carries the "correct" Porsche part number, and when it
carries Porsche's parts trademark.  The following suppliers, listed
alphabetically, have been praised by various Porschephiles:


     Andial
     3203-3207 S. Shannon St.
     Santa Ana, CA  92704
     Telephone: 1-714-957-3900
     FAX:       1-714-957-9332

     Porsche's official agent for competition parts and products in 
     the US.  Catalog $6.00.


     Automobile Atlanta
     505A South Marietta Highway
     Marietta, GA 30060
     Telephone: 1-404-427-2844
 
     The most comprehensive catalog of 914 parts.  Higher-than-average
     prices.  Catalog $5.00.  (Also a 924 catalog?)

 
     Automotion
     193 Commercial St.
     Sunnyvale, CA 94086
     Telephone: 1-800-777-8881
                1-408-736-9020
     FAX:       1-408-736-9013

     Wide selection of maintenance and replacement parts and products;
     sister company to Weltmeister, whose suspension kits they carry.
     Free catalog.


     Autothority Performance Engineering
     3769-B Pickett Road
     Fairfax, VA  22031
     Telephone: 1-703-323-0919
     FAX:       1-703-323-7325

     Performance chips for Porsches ECU's; also other performance 
     products.


     Baum Tools Unlimited, Inc. 
     4000 S. Tamiami Trail
     Sarasota FL 34231
     Telephone: 1-813-927-1414 Office
     Telephone: 1-800-848-6657 Orders (US & Canada)

     1523 38th Avenue
     San Francisco CA 94122-3011
     Telephone: 1-415-566-9229
     FAX:       1-415-566-0694
     Mobile:    1-415-298-7831

     Manufacturers, importers and distributors of Porsche special tools.
     They specialize in all tools for Porsches from 356 to 968, and also
     carry an extensive line of German automotive hand tools (Hazet, 
     Stahlwille, Usag, Matra and Peisler).  Catalogs available ($10, 
     which is refunded with the first order).  $35 minimum order 
     required from their main warehouse but smaller orders accepted 
     at their West Coast warehouse.  They also have an extensive 
     technical library covering all German makes and models.

What references are available for information about Porsches?

     There are many books and manuals available, and the right one for 
you depends a lot on your interests and your particular car.  Porsche
publishes a Workshop Manual for all late model cars, as well as
various Technical Specification booklets.  Your local dealership's
parts manager can show you a catalog of technical literature
available from PCNA.

     The Porsche Club of America periodically assembles all of the 
technical articles which have appeared in Panorama into a new volume of 
their Upfixin der Porsche series.  These are available from PCA's 
executive office.

     What follows is a list of some of the more popular and often-cited
books.  This list is not exhaustive, but provides a starting point.  If 
you want information about other books, ask the list.  (Note: there's 
not much information about water-cooled cars; those with favorites 
should submit them to the name at the end of this FAQ.)

     Aichele, Tobias
     Porsche 911, Forever Young
     (translated by Pete Albrecht)
       ISBN 0-92975811-0
     Beeman Jorgensen, Inc.

     Anderson, Bruce
     Porsche 911 Performance Handbook
       ISBN 0-87938-269-4
     Motorbooks International

     Automobile Quarterly, Volume 9, Number 2 (Porsche is featured 
     marque, with 58 pages devoted to the man, the car, and racing)
       Library of Congress Card Catalog No. 62-4005
     Automobile Quarterly, Inc.
 
     Automobile Year, Number 41

     Barrett, Frank (ed.)
     Porsche Panorama, The First 25 Years
       ISBN ?
     Porsche Club of America, Inc.

     Batchelor, Dean
     Illustrated Porsche Buyer's Guide
       ISBN 0-87938-239-2
     Motorbooks International

     Boschen, Lothar & Barth, Jurgen
     The Porsche Book, A Definitive Illustrated History
       ISBN 0-668-06003-4
     Arco Publishing, Inc.

     Conradt, Dirk-Michael
     Porsche 356, Driving in its Purest Form
     (translated by Pete Albrecht)
       ISBN 0-929758-09-9
     Beeman Jorgensen, Inc. 

     Elfrink, Henry
     Porsche Technical Manual
       ISBN ?
     Henry Elfrink Automotive

     Fujimoto, Akira (ed.)
     Famous Automobile Museums: Volume 3, Porsche Museum
       ISBN ?
     Car Styling Publishing Co.

     Johnson, Brett
     The 356 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-08-0
     The 911 and 912 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-00-5
     The 914 and 914/6 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-01-3
     Beeman Jorgensen Inc.

     Ludvigsen, Karl
     Porsche, Excellence Was Expected
       ISBN 0-525-10117-9
     E.P. Dutton & Co.

     Maltby, Gordon
     Porsche 356 & RS Spyders
       ISBN 0879385510
     Motorbooks International
 
     Merritt, Richard E. Merritt & Miller, Susann C.
     Porsche, Brochures and Sales Literature, 1948-1965
       ISBN 0-914822-15-2
     John W. Barnes, Jr., Publishing, Inc.

     Morgan, Peter
     The Porsche 924/944 Book
       ISBN 0-85429-764-2
     Haynes Publishing Group

     Porsche, Dr. Ing. h.c. Ferry, & Bentley, John
     We At Porsche
       ISBN 0-385-05309-6
     Doubleday & Co.

     Probst, Charles O.
     Bosch Fuel Injection & Engine Management
       ISBN 0-8376-0300-5
     Robert Bentley, Inc.

     Pellow, Harry 
     The ABC's (and 912's) of Porsche Engines
       ISBN 0-941210-04-9
     HCP Research (408) 727-1864
     (The "Maestro" has several other books available as well)

     Puhn, Fred
     How To Make Your Car Handle
       ISBN 0-912656-46-8
     HP Books

     Rasmussen, ?
     Porsche 356 & 550
       ISBN 1879301032
     Top Ten Publications
 
     Sloniger, Jerry
     Porsche, the 4-Cyclinder, 4-Cam Sports & Racing Cars
       ISBN 0-914792-03-2
     Dean Batchelor Publications

     Spencer, Duane
     Porsche 356 Performance Handbook  
       ISBN 0-87938-417-4

     356 Porsche Technical and Restoration Guide
       ISBN 0-929758-10-2
     Beeman Jorgensen, Inc. 

     There are also Haynes manuals available for most models.  While 
the Haynes manuals tend to be very weak on specifics having to do with
different model years and variations, they are good at teaching how-to
procedures for different maintenance and repair tasks.

     The following sources for books and publications were provided by 
Bob Joyce (Bob356@aol.com):

     Toad Hall Motorbooks
     1235 Pierce Street
     Lakewood, CO 80214, USA
     Telephone 1-303-237-0911, FAX 1-303-237-6080
 
     Block's Books, the Fanatic's Choice
     c/o MetPath
     4444 Giddings Road
     Auburn Hills, MI 48326, USA
     Telephone 1-810-678-3017
 
     Classic Motorbooks
     729 Prospect Avenue
     Osceola, WI 54020, USA
     Telephone 1-800-826-6600 (24 hours)
 
     TPR, Inc.
     7510 Allisonville Road
     Indianapolis, IN 46250, USA
     Telephone 1-317-841-7677, 1-800-553-5319, FAX 317-849-2001
 
     Motor Books
     33 & 36 St. Martin's Court
     London WC2, ENGLAND, UK 

=======================================================================

Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?

     This is Stan's response:  "Duralube, Slick-50, and *EVERYTHING ELSE 
THAT ISN'T JUST PLAIN OIL* is, to be blunt, snake oil.  Or as Bruce 
Anderson commented about something else, "a cash flow device."  Slick-50
is *evil* if you have an engine with an aluminium case.  Guess what we 
all have, eh?  There is a bit of info on it via anonymous FTP in tta.com
in /pub/porschephiles/MiscInfo.  Additionally, many of these additives 
use teflon.  DuPont (the inventors of Teflon) have stated categorically 
that teflon is useless in such applications."
 
=======================================================================

Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
 
     Yes. There are many luminaries in the Porsche world on this list.
If something is relevant to them, they'll typically respond to you
privately.  Their participation is greatly valued, so respect their
privacy and don't try to draw them out in the open.  If they want to
say something to the list as a whole, they'll do so.

=======================================================================

Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?

     The FAQ is stored on tta.com in the /pub/porschephiles/FAQs 
directory, filename general-FAQ.  The version stored there will be 
the same one sent out monthly.  (There's also a FAQ that's specific to
the 914; other specific FAQs are welcomed, if anyone wants to contribute
to the archives.)

=======================================================================

Who maintains this FAQ?

     The FAQ is maintained by Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil).  I have
a 1972 911T as my daily driver.  Anyone who wants to contribute should 
do so.  Contributions, revisions, and suggestions for new items are 
always welcomed.  I peruse the list for potential additions, but I don't
promise to find everything you might want in the FAQ.  Don't be shy 
about sending suggestions directly to me, or to the maintainers of the
model-specific FAQs in the tta.com archives.  Also, don't expect me to 
know anything about those model-specific FAQs -- this one is my only
vice.

=======================================================================

Porschephiles #1540                         Mon Jul 10 02:00:08 CDT 1995
Date: Sun, 09 Jul 95 01:58:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: RE: 914 project on the go


Bart's pondering his 914 project:

>Thinking ahead (definitely prematurely), I have the following questions:

You can't do enough of this....this is a large project.

>2. Sound proofing material.
>Do people routinely replace the floor pan paneling ? If so with what ?
>How about the patches of black cloth that cover the edges and central 
tunnel
>?
>Does the fire wall rubber panel need to be replaced ? (Still in good shape,
>shouldn't be a problem

Are you planning on entering your car in a concours event?
If not, don't worry about it.  Just make sure all rusty areas
are removed and fixed properly.  If it ain't broke....

>3. 914/4-to-914/6
>I plan to relocate the battery box and oil tank. What's a good alternate
>battery location. Needs  ?
>If the oil tank is relocated to the front, is an original 914/6 tank still
>needed or are there other alternatives ?

What are your plans for the car?  Street?  Autox?  Race?
914's are known for boiling the battery and having the acid
eat out the car.  My solution?  Check the area frequently.
I'm using my car for 99% street use and I have *NO* plans
for moving the battery since I like my trunk space.  Same
goes for the oil tank.  The factory unit is cool....it mounts
inside the driver's rear fender behind the door jamb.  It
couldn't possibly be less intrusive on the storage capacity
of the car.

If you want to race the car you may want to install the battery
and aftermarket oil tank in the front trunk on the passenger
side to help balance the left/right sides of the car (to help
compensate for the driver) and to lower the center of gravity.
Of course this effectively kills the storage capacity of the
front trunk....you decide based on your priorities.

Good luck!

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>
'75 914-6  3.0 SC

Date: Sun, 9 Jul 95 05:46:43 -0500
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William Marten)
Subject: 914 Parts

I have found someone with 2 914 'parts or restore' cars for sale locally.

bit.  If there's something you want or need from either a '73 1.7 or a '74

this week, and I will check for any and all parts requested then.

On the phone he mentioned that the 1.8 has stainless steel heat exchangers
that look 'brand new'.  And yes Nate, I saw your post and I'll look into it.
A few of the things that *won't* be on the auction block: the center
console, the side view mirror {unless there is more than one}, the headlight
switch {from the '74} and the chrome bumpers.

I'm not looking to make money on this, so insulting offers are invited, BUT
you pay shipping.  And if enough of the '73 remains, I might try
refurbishing it -- I don't think I'm capable of 'restoring' a vehicle.  :)

Let me know -- sooner the better.

Bill Marten
wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu
Madison, WI, USA


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 9 Jul 95 05:50:24 -0500
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William Marten)
Subject: Jumping 914 Tachs

A couple of members mentioned that their tach jumped and was this 'normal'.
Does the tach jump when you step on the brake?  If so, according to Dr. 914,
the brake light fuse isn't making good contact.  I've had this happen a lot.
If that isn't it, I'd start checking ground connections.

Just a thought,

Bill Marten
wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu
Madison, WI, USA

Date: Sun, 9 Jul 1995 14:12:24 -0400
From: craig@newforce.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: Re: 924S buying

At 11:40 AM 7/3/95 -0400, Robert Rhodes wrote:
>	I am looking at a 1987 924S and have a few questions.

Cool. I have one.

>
>	1)  Does this car have the self adjusting timing belt thingy?

Mine doesn't, but its a very early '87. YMMV.

>	2)  There are no records for this car.  Am I asking for trouble 
>in buying a "bargain" porsche without some history?

Um, scary. I would get it checked by a competent Porsche mechanic. I
would also get it checked for previous body work/accident damage by a
good body shop...

>	3)  The previous owner seems to have spent more on the stereo 
>than on the car.  Is there anything I can look for in terms of 
>identifying neglect?

see above.

>	4)  What size tire is "supposed" to be on this car?  what other 
>sizes will fit?  This car currently has the phone dial type rims, but 
>they are pretty shabby, anything to correct this?

195/65 VR 15 on 6x15 phone dial rims were standard. (In Canada), 205/60
VR 16's on 6x16 rims were optional (slotted 928 style). 7x15 rims were
fitted to the rear of the "Special Edition" car in '88. 205x60-15 tires
will fit with no clearance or speedo problems.

>	5)  Any other advice would be appreciated.

Depending on your needs for the car, an 85.5 and up 944 might be a better
vehicle for you. The 944 handles a bit better, thanks to a wider track
and wider rims/tires, and has the updated interior, with a more powerful
A/C unit. You should be able to pick up a 924S for a lot less money than
the same year 944, though. Current value of these cars is pretty low <sigh>.

>	As a final note on the condition of this car the tires are, I 
>believe, P-6s all around, but are obviously of 3 different vintages as 
>though the owner only bought one at a time when one wore out.  Also the 
>car vibrates badly over 60 mph.

The vibration may be due to improper wheel balancing, or lack of alignment,
or (eek) improperly-repaired body damage. I'd really advise getting the 
car checked out thoroughly.

Good luck!
Craig.

Date: Sun, 9 Jul 1995 17:56:12 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Your Car at PCA Events

>> The only requirement is that you car be sporting in nature, so leave the
>> family wagon at home, and that it passes a tech inspection.

>Have seen awesome performances turned in by Volvo 240 wagons at some of
>these "sporting car" events. Advise that such generalizations may be
>somewhat overstated...

The weight distribution on a typical station wagon is better (more nearly
50/50) than that on a typical sedan, so, properly set up, will generally
handle better.  I mentioned once doing some laps at the Oesterreichring with
the Alfasuds...that was in a rental Peugeot wagon, and I came away amazed at
how well it handled (and how easily it caught some of the Alfasuds).  Don't
scoff at that young mother and her day-care hauler...she may beat your socks
off!

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 00:23:45 -0400
From: HHeath3@aol.com
Subject: 1983 944 vs. 1995 Mustang 5LV8

Having read several car mag articles on current Ford Mustang 5.0L V8 coupes,
I found myself near a local Ford house w/ a few minutes to kill.  Schmoozed
w/ salesman a while (*he* drives a 944T!) and cadged a ride in a pretty blue
Mustang.  Well, it's sure a better car than the old '65-'69 versions I grew
up with, but... well, I hate to say it, it's still a tub.  The live rear axle
lets the rear wheels skitter and hop over the least irregularities in turns,
and the car seems sluggish in acceleration, considering what it's supposed to
be.  The front-heaviness and turgidity of its maneuverability were striking.
 The clutch was heavy, the usual for Ford, I recall.  I did like the shifter
and the highway tracking was okay.
I got back into my aged 944 and went back over the same roads at similar
speeds, and fell in love with my modest little used car all over again.  Why
can't an American car maker create machines with the balance and
sophistication of these little Deutschmobiles?

Thoughts?  Would the new Camaro/Firebird be any more sophisticated?  C & D et
al. praise them highly.

Hunter

------------------------------

> 914 1.7 liter?  Or is there a gasket?

No gasket on either of mine or in the manuals.  Klymer does recommend VW 
D1a sealing compund, though, when reinstalling.

ovious, like fan belt, timing, just did the valves about 3 months or
so ago.

It runs between 210 and 250 on the guage, even at night, when its 
cool outside.  I am used to seeing it right at 180.  I'm guessing
it might be the oil thermostat - does that sound reasonable, and is there
any way I can verify it?

The car still has good power, even when its hot.  Does't 'dog out' at
all.

Date: Sun, 9 Jul 1995 23:06:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: re: Porsche - Corvette/Camaros "GET" slaughtered

Ex-Porsche owner Ken Mitchell wrote:

> Oops - I mean challenge. Don't forget the Porsche -
> Corvette/Camaro Challenge is this Saturday at Stockton. Its going
> to be fun.... Its going to be walk in the park; like stealing
> candy from a baby; a piece of cake.... Hmmm - maybe I'll bring
> the Corvette so it won't look as bad... Not - I'm bringing the
> Camaro going for the gold......
> 
> This past weekend I was hanging with a lot of PCA people and they
> are already getting their excuse list together. They really have
> some neat ones, some that I hadn't even thought of. Thats OK just
> as long as they bring money because the losers (Porsche Drivers)
> are buying the beer and it better not be that crap in green
> bottles...
> 
> Hey Lommatzsch - Are you going to post this to Porschephiles???

Yes, I will post this to Porschephiles with "our" winning results.

Well Ken, where's the beer for the winning Porsches!  Porsche didn't
dominate every class at the local Porsche - Corvette Challenge, but did
take enough class wins to have bragging rights until the next challenge. 
That may last about five years, since the last one was around 1989-90. 
When it can down to the end, Porsche had a clean sweep of the top five
"challenge" positions in the open class and the top four in the ladies
class.  Challenge winners were Tom Dugan in a bone stock 914 beating
Dwight Mitchell because of his breakout time on his previous challenge run
and Tricia Braun (alias Tricia Hills) in another somewhat stock 914.  All
Corvettes / Camaros went out in the first round of the ladies and open
class challenges.  Top Time of Day and Top Time Corvette did belong to Ken
Yeo with a 40.8xx.  Meanwhile the Top Time of Day Porsche went to Mike
Lommatzsch in a 914 at 42.6xx. 

More details will be avialable when I see a final tally of results.

The course was designed by Bud Behrens from the Porsche club but everyone
loved the course.  Start and finish were a little tight for the Corvettes
/ Camaros but with a 360 turn in the middle that the 914 took in third
gear at 4000 rpm it was fast and open every where else.  Many kudos to Bud
for a competitive course for all of the competitors. The morning started
quickly except fot the cars that had to run immediately after Henry "Hank"
Watts had oiled down the course with a wheel that wore a hole thorugh an
oil cooler hose first thing in the morning.  After about a forty-five 
minute cleaned up we were back running again.  Meanwhile the heat had 
been turned up and with the early morning showers, the humidity must have 
been near 100%.  Many people were seen wearing towels and drinking plenty 
of the non-alcoholic drinks for the rest of the day.  Everyone got two 
sets of two runs.  A run consisted of two laps; a warm up and a hot lap.

Many thanks to Jeff Glorioso from the Corvette club and Pat Ikeda from 
the Porsche club for setting this event up.  Also instrumental in 
the class structures, course design and site arrangement were Dwight 
Mitchell and Bud Behrens as mentioned earlier.

Everyone had a fantastic time and looks forward to a repeat challenge 
next year.  Though we would prefer that the beer be available at the end 
of the event by the Corvette's to make up for this years win by Porsche.

So Ken, what do you have to say now?  And about those excuses you had 
talked about all the Porsche owners needing to use?  Guess you'll have to 
save them for the next challenge should Porsche lose......NOT!

mike lommatzsch

pca-lpr/svr/ggr
scca-sfr/rr

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 12:06:08 +0100
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Tyre brand recommendations for 911 Carrera 3.2

	My 3.2 Carrera is currently shod with Comp T/As, 205/55 ZR16 on the 
front and 225/50 ZR16 on the rear.

	I need to replace one of the fronts (down to legal limit!) and one of 
the rears (small but deep hole near sidewall), and the other rear is no longer 
pristine, so I'm thinking of biting the bullet and buying a set of 4 new tyres, 
especially as Comp T/As are getting quite hard to find in the UK.

	I use the car mostly for commuting with the odd blast down country lanes 
at weekends, but no track or Auto-X at all. We get lots of rain in England and 
the odd snowfall in winter and my car sees them all. I'm more concerned with 
good mileage than with stickiness at the limit (so don't want A008Ps!). Noise 
doesn't bother me at all. Price is an issue, though all these tyres seem to be 
in the same ballpark. So what tyres should I go for?

	My local Porsche main dealer is pushing PIRELLI P700Zs very hard, saying 
that they are much the same as GOODYEAR EAGLE 5-rib or DUNLOP D40/2, but that 
these two tyres wear in the centre more quickly than the PIRELLIs. A tyre dealer 
(who runs a 928) is trying to sell me BRIDGESTONE EXPEDIAs or BRIDGESTONE RE71s 
... he says that the RE71s give better mileage but not quite as much grip as the 
EXPEDIAs.

	I have also come across TOYO (who claim to come as standard equipment on 
Porsches), AVON TURBOSPEED (not approved by Porsche and said to be noisy) and 
FULDA (though no fronts are available for my car just now).

	All suggestions and advice appreciated.

Confused of Ipswich.
Philip Katz

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 06:26:00 ADT
From: "Southard, Keith" <KSOUTHAR@atu.com>
Subject: Reply : Your Car at PCA Events


> The only requirement is that you car be sporting in nature, so leave the
> family wagon at home, and that it passes a tech inspection.

Alaska Region PCA welcomes all competitors regardless of "sportiness"
providing that they pass Tech. The 3rd place driver in our our 1995 
challenge
series drives a pick-up, he is blinding fast!! Have a nice lady who comes 
out
occasionally in her Lincoln Towncar, doesn't place well but finishes in the
top two-thirds. Have another guy who drives a highly modified 914 with a
2.7 911 motor, always finishes last.  Forget the "CAR", the driver makes all
the difference. A good driver in a Towncar or even a pick-up will beat the 
bad
driver in the best car on the street!

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 07:35:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: Walter Stander <wstander@cts.com>
Subject: Re: 1983 944 vs. 1995 Mustang 5LV8

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995 HHeath3@aol.com wrote:

> Having read several car mag articles on current Ford Mustang 5.0L V8 coupes,
> I found myself near a local Ford house w/ a few minutes to kill.  Schmoozed
> w/ salesman a while (*he* drives a 944T!) and cadged a ride in a pretty blue
> Mustang.  Well, it's sure a better car than the old '65-'69 versions I grew
> up with, but... well, I hate to say it, it's still a tub.  The live rear axle
> lets the rear wheels skitter and hop over the least irregularities in turns,
> and the car seems sluggish in acceleration, considering what it's supposed to
> be.  The front-heaviness and turgidity of its maneuverability were striking.
>  The clutch was heavy, the usual for Ford, I recall.  I did like the shifter
> and the highway tracking was okay.
> I got back into my aged 944 and went back over the same roads at similar
> speeds, and fell in love with my modest little used car all over again.  Why
> can't an American car maker create machines with the balance and
> sophistication of these little Deutschmobiles?
> 
> Thoughts?  Would the new Camaro/Firebird be any more sophisticated?  C & D et
> al. praise them highly.
> 
> Hunter
> 
Interesting.....
I too looked at a new Mustang and also the new Trans Am; I'm impressed!
I typically commute 100 miles per day- half freeway, half mountainous, 
tortuous roads. I am 5'6" and have been a confirmed Porsche addict all my 
life: no more. It is simply financial for me: The most expensive Porsche 
to me is a used one, and new ones are obscenely priced for what one 
gets(i.e.:$47,000.00 gets me either a 300HP Corvette, 2 
Camaros/TransAms/Mustangs, or a 968/986). And lets not forget the gas 
guzzler tax and luxury tax. Oh, luxury? I've owned a new 944, a used 
944S, and a 911SC "Weissach Coupe". The leather in those cars is so hard 
and uncomfortable it could better be used as tire retread plies. Oh yes, 
and we must not forget the sheer joy of taking out 2nd and 3rd mortgages 
to repair these vehicles; the 911 series was (IMHO), the worst. I 
actually sold mine while it sat in the local Porsche dealer's bay.

Auf Wiedersain Herr Ferry..............


Walt

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 10:40:41 -0400
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: Re: Wisdom on 2nd car

Hi Kieth,
> 
> I am considering two choices right now.  1.  85-87 VW Cabriolet   2.  
> 85-88 Saab 900 Sedan.  (choices listed in order of preference)
> 
> I really don't want to spend more that $5500 total.  The car must have 
> the capacity to carry 4 adults in relative comfort.

We traded the Frau's 87 VW Wolfsburg Edition Cabriolet on the Carrera Cabriolet
two years ago (only had 25K miles on the VW).  If you like Convertibles,
this is absolutely one of the best, and the frau probably wishes she still
had it, because it is so roomy and comfortable, and *much* easier to get in
and out of (for a couple of geezers like us).  The fully lined and insulated top
makes the interior more like a coupe than a ragtop.  The back seat is *Very* 
comfortable and roomy for two full-sized adults.  Luggage space, however is
seriously compromised if you are thinking of 4 adults on a long trip.  That's 
the only flaw (OK, it could use more hp, but then, so could the Carrera...)

Bottom line: My advice is go for a cab, and don't even consider the Saab (which 
does have more room, but is not a rag-top).  Nothing, I mean *nothing* beats a 
rag-top, and the VW meets your criteria beautifully!


Cheers

(yer Kindly ol' Unka) Bart

Frau Dora, 
(fond memory of a couple of little feline varmints in my heart)
'86 Indischrot Carrera Cabriolet, 
'87 Alpenweis Syncro.
Custodian, Porschephiles Phund

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 10:50:29 EST
From: "paul foster" <paul_foster@imailhub.tdc.com>
Subject: Re: Autocross classifications

     peter kauffman writes:
     
     >I have a 1974 Porsche 911 Targa Carerra.  I am interested in how the 
     >classification system works for Porsche Club Solo II autocrosses or 
     >SCCA autocrosses.  In SCCA, the car is in A Stock.  What 
     >modifications are acceptable? 
      
     >Can you upgrade the Borge shocks using Bilstein Gas inserts?
     
     >Can you lower the car?
     
     >Change the torsion bars to 27mm?
     
     >Go to 7" and 8" wide rims?
     
     >Install sway bars front and rear?
     
     >Go to a non standard exhaust system?  Use a stinger exhaust?
     
     >How does Porsche Club rules apply?
     
     The 911 is a good A Stock or ASP car. For the stock class you are not 
     allowed to change much. Any shock or strut (gas shocks will make your 
     car 1/4" higher than it used to be!), any front swaybar (check out 
     Weltmeister from Automotion), no lowering, no torsion-bar changes, no 
     non-OEM wheels (if 7s and 8s were offered by the factory for your 
     year, they are OK - but you may be better off using the same size 
     wheels to easily rotate your tires). Any exhaust system is OK as long 
     as it still has the heating stuff...
     
     Make friends with Mike Piera (sp?). He is an SCCA A Stock National 
     Champ. Dwight Mitchell was very competitive in a '73 911 in ASP. I 
     don't think he ever won ASP nationally, but he did win SP1 (Pro Solo) 
     a number of times.
     
     PCA classifications are entirely up to your local region.
     
     If you are in the least bit serious, get sticky tires ASAP and get a 
     ride from someone who knows how to autocross.
     
     Good Luck!
     
     Paul Foster
     '84 944

Mike,

I'd like to return to some questions about the car you have (had?) 4sale.

I've just contacted the Customs and there are new rules which let cars older
than 3 years being imported. I have not gotten all the details, but I
believe I will have to pay 18% of the *very high* import tax we have for new
cars. They will calculate the cars price from '73 and I will have to pay
after some strange rules,....checking at the moment.

Questions (some may have been asked before,...I don't remember);

1) How much rust, and where is it located? What panels are needed?

2) What is needed mechanichally?

3) How is brakes and suspension parts?

4) Does the interior suck?

5) Did you already sell it?

cheers,
Trond V.

*** Attached File #1: AUTOX.DOC ***
I nabbed the article about autocross from the Chronicle/Examiner WWW site
(http://sfgate.com).  Without permission, I offer it to you:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ROAD WARRIORS / THE WEEKEND RACERS WHO HAUL THEIR PORSCHES, BMWS AND CORVETTES
OUT TO MAKESHIFT RACETRACKS AREN'T HOPING FOR PRIZES OR MEDALS -- JUST A CHANCE
                          TO INDULGE THEIR FANTASIES
                                       

 Peter Sinton, Chronicle Senior Writer  


Choosing between Sunday in the park and Sunday in a parking lot is a
no-brainer for most people. But to a committed cadre of sports car
nuts, nothing beats renting the asphalt around Candlestick Park or
Oakland Coliseum on a nongame weekend and turning it into a mini race
course.

  On Father's Day, 88 members of Porsche Club of America drove or
trailered their four-wheel treasures to the 'Stick from as far away
as Reno and paid $20 each to navigate a twisting course marked by
scores of orange cones. Although the would-be Mario and Maria
Andrettis spent most of their time watching, waiting and discussing
tire pressures and torsion bars, most believed that eight laps and a
total of five or six minutes of adrenaline-rush track time was worth
it.

 Ken Masuda, a Campbell landscape contractor, got bitten by the
racing bug six months ago when he saw a list of car clubs, including
the 1,100-member Golden Gate Chapter of the Porsche Club.

 ``I always loved to drive,'' said Masuda, who now leaves his wife
at home to take care of the 9-year-
old and twin 7-year-olds so he can play with his other baby, a 5-year-
old Porsche model 911 C4. ``Now I get to drive at 90 percent to 100
percent potential.''

 Masuda, 40, was so anxious to enter his first autocross in Salinas last
January that he cut short a weekend ski trip to Lake Tahoe to drive back
Saturday night.

 Parking-lot autocrosses are relatively cheap. In addition to the entry fee,
equivalent to an amusement-park admission, you only need a helmet. But the
event takes a toll on the auto, mainly tires that don't last long when
you're skidding sideways or slamming on the brakes before a tight turn.

 Drivers compete against the clock, trying to better their own lap times.
Winning isn't everything, but most drivers watch the competition carefully.
There are dozens of classes of cars, categorized by year and model and
whether they have special tires or more serious modifications.  Amateur
racing extends beyond a Candlestick 500 -- that's yards, not miles -- to
time trial events at bona fide race courses. Porsche Club, BMW Club, Sports
Car Club of America (SCCA) and other groups increasingly are renting Laguna
Seca Raceway in Monterey County and Sears Point Raceway in Sonoma County for
their members.

 The leap to the race track is a serious one, because speeds are far greater
and the consequences of spinning out are far graver than knocking over a
rubber cone and taking a one-second deduction on your lap time.

``This is a loony sport,'' said a grinning Larry Jackson, a gas crew foreman
for PG&E who last year ran 35 Porsche Club and SCCA events. ``It's like an
addiction; I'm here at Candlestick for my weekly fix.''

 It doesn't have to cost a lot. Jackson, 40, plunked down $3,200 for a
turquoise 1973 Porsche 914 three years ago. Then came the set of soft
compound racing tires and a new suspension system for about $500 each, a
smaller steering wheel for $150, an anti-sway bar he found for $30 at a swap
meet and a $350 roll bar.

 ``None of this makes sense,'' admits Jackson. He added, ``Costs for the
first event can be a killer.''

 In addition to the $165 basic fee for a weekend of racing (about two hours
of actual track time), Masuda figures he spent about $1,500 to get ready for
his first time trial. Porsche and most other clubs require five-point safety
harnesses, installed fire extinguishers, fireproof gloves and shoes. Once
drivers get hooked, they can easily spend double or triple that on a second
set of wheel rims and sticky compound racing tires as well as roll bars.

So far Masuda has been content paying more attention to improving his
driving skills than beefing up his car.

 ``Learning to drive what you have is important,'' said Lloyd DeMartini, who
bought his first Porsche 25 years ago. ``More people blame their cars more
than themselves.'' The 48-year-old aerospace engineer and his wife Patti
have three Porsches, including a six-cylinder 1973 Porsche 914 that is as
customized as the Batmobile.  DeMartini does everything but motor
modifications himself and figures if he had paid someone else for all the
work he's done, the bills would top $80,000 instead of $30,000.

 David Kimes, 52, president of the Porsche Club's Golden Gate Region,
figures he has invested about $20,000 in his own 1971 914, which he calls
Herbie. Two sets of Goodyear racing slicks run about $1,800 a year, brake
pads add some more, and ``then there's little stuff that breaks,'' said
Kimes, a project manager for IBM in San Jose.

 Herbie rewarded Kimes with the best lap time on Father's Day -- 34.928
seconds -- about 10 seconds faster than the slowest time. But it came at a
cost. Monday morning Herbie was in the shop to diagnose a serious
clutch/transmission problem.

 Turning a parking lot into a race track can chew up the asphalt a bit, too,
but no more so than weekdays when Candlestick and other public facilities
turn their lots over to fire and police departments, the Highway Patrol and
Muni drivers. Public agencies increasingly are using parking lots to learn
or brush up on their parallel parking, high-speed driving and obstacle
avoidance techniques.

 These groups don't pay a dime to rent the lots while car clubs and dealers
pay $1,000 or more per day for the open space. ``It's starting to be a big
thing for all the stadiums,'' said Candlestick Park Chief Engineer Michael
Gay. In addition to Porsche and Sports Car Club of America events, carmakers
such as Acura, BMW and Chrysler are taking over Candlestick this year to
show dealers and potential buyers what the new models can really do.

 On June 9 through 11, Corvette rolled into the Oakland Coliseum with its
``American Dream & Drive Tour,'' part of a 20-city annual road show of
General Motors' sportiest car.

 ``More groups want to rent the space,'' said Bill DiCarlo, assistant
general manager of the Coliseum. One Saturday, Corvette rented half the
parking lot and a radio station rented the other half for a promotion. The
revenue is nice, but it hardly compares to what the stadium will make
renting all 10,000 parking spaces for $7 each when the Raiders return to
Oakland.

 If it's hard finding an open day at the biggest public parking lots, it's
even tougher finding a vacant race track. Weekends at Sears Point and Laguna
Seca are all booked up, not just for professional races but also for amateur
events.

 The Sports Car Club of America has reserved the Monterey track for five
events this year. But the 5,000-member local chapter of the national
organization has so much demand that two years ago it built its own track,
Thunderhill Park in Willows north of Sacramento.

 Tracks don't come cheap. Laguna Seca rents for a minimum of $2,800 a day
plus a 20 percent administrative fee. Then there are incidentals: an
ambulance on standby for $114.42 an hour, eight to 12 course workers (if you
don't provide your own) for $50 each, a sound tester (another $50) to make
sure the racket remains below 92 decibels. Finally, you'll need at least $5
million in liability insurance.

 Porsche Club is one of the most active sports car organizations, with 11
chapters and close to 3,000 members in Northern California.  But it is
hardly alone in searching out vacant parking lots or race tracks and holding
rallies, overnight fun runs and Friday night socials.

Tom Georgalos, a produce salesman for Fresh Express in Salinas, remembers
clinging to the fence at Laguna Seca as a kid and wishing he could be on the
track. Now his Green Flag Driving Association occasionally takes over the
track and he can throw his 1965 Ford Shelby GT 350 through the famous
corkscrew turn himself.

 The Pacific Region of the Ferrari Club of America also runs on local
tracks. But its most popular event is the annual September hill climb to
Virginia City from Carson City, when the 375-member organization pays the
state of Nevada to close down a five-mile stretch of Highway 341.

 The BMW club, with more than 3,000 members in Northern California, holds
autocrosses at an airport in Sonoma County and also stakes out race tracks.
But the events are geared more to instruction than competitive time trialing.

 ``Our program is focused on the learning curve,'' said Jim Grinstead, a
PG&E transmission planner who manages BMW's driving events in his spare
time. ``We provide an alternative to learning the limits of your car some
morning on a rain-soaked Nimitz Freeway.''

  __________________________________________________________________________


BAY AREA CAR CLUBS

CAR CLUBS:
- -- Alpha Romeo Association, (408) 578-8903. About 800 members. Hosts
tours and other driving events.
- -- BMW Club, (510) 889-6363. About 3,000 members in Golden Gate
chapter. Sponsors drivers' education, autocross and track driving
events.
- -- Ferrari Club of America, (415) 598-0611. 375 members in Pacific
region. Holds track events and annual hill climb.
- -- Green Flag Driving Association, (408) 988-7986. More than 500 on
mailing list. Organizes noncompetitive, non-timed track events.
- -- National Auto Sport Association, (510) 232-6272. 4,800 members.
Holds autocrosses at Candlestick Park and Oakland Coliseum as well as
high performance driving schools and semi-professional events at
Laguna Seca, Sears Point, Thunderhill and Altamont race tracks.
- -- Porsche Club of America, (408) 779-5988. 1,100 members in Golden
Gate region. Holds drivers education programs, autocrosses, time
trials, fun runs and socials.
- -- Shelby American Auto Club, (408) 374-1298. About 400 members in
Northern California chapter. Hosts events for owners of high
performance Fords.
- -- Sports Car Club of America, (510) 373-7222. 5,000 members in the
Bay Area, the largest of the national amateur racing organization's
110 regions. Sponsors education and licensing programs as well as
autocross and time trial events.
- -- Western States Corvette Council, (510) 462-2185. More than a dozen
clubs in Northern California. Events range from drag racing and
overnight fun runs to socials.
RACE TRACKS:
- -- Altamont Raceway Park, (510) 373-7223. The recently reopened
Alameda County half-mile oval is used primarily for stock car racing
but can be rented for tuning and testing.
- -- Laguna Seca Raceway, (408) 648-5111. Monterey County track hosts
professional and amateur events, as well as Russell Racing School.
- -- Sears Point Raceway, (707) 938-8448. Sonoma County race track holds
both professional and amateur events, including drag racing, as well
as Skip Barber Driving School.
- -- Thunderhill Park, (916) 934-5588. Built by the Sports Car Club of
America two years ago, this new track in Willows (north of
Sacramento) is used by both amateurs and professionals.
*** EOF ***

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 11:33:55 EDT
From: berry@cgi.com (Franklyn Berry)

>>From: "Daniel G. Pouzzner" <douzzer@prez.mit.edu>
>Subject: electrical instability

>both my portable CD and portable DAT...
>seem to just get fried....
>so, what should i do about this? build a box with another voltage
>regulator and a big filter capacitor?

Sorry for the late reply. The TWO:1995 edition of Audio Amateur magazine
includes a design for a high-accuracy low impedance regulator for a 
radio shack 3400 (6V), one popular CD model. I expect waht you're seeing 
is an overvoltage at the supply, which forces the internal regs to dissipate
mucho heat.

Just throwing a canned regulator and filter at the problem is likely
to be susceptable to noise (high impedance).

You can order back issues from Audio Amateur Pubs, (603)924-9464.
- --frankb

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 10:28:22 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 Displacement Increase Inquiries

> You can get some good base info that you then have to
>integrate appropriately from "How to Hotrod the VW Beetle" (so old
>that dual port heads are a novel idea) . . .

        It came out in 1970, the year that the 914 was introduced.
About all he has to say about the Type IV is that "It's already got
a lot of these modifications built in, and we don't know enough
about it yet to make many successful modifications."  He also talks
about putting Porsche power in a Bug--and means only 356.  And talks
about a $1000 rebuild for that motor.  >chuckle!<  He also mentions
putting a Corvair engine in a bug, but no mention of the 911 engine.
Odd, seeing as the 911 engine is *much* better engineered than the
Corvair one.

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 08:57:09 PDT
From: bezzant@corp.cirrus.com (Dan Bezzant)
Subject: 911 Window Tint Removal

Citrus cleaner works real well to loosen up all that
adhesive from window tint.

I used 3M brand stuff in the spray can, but you can use
DeSolvIt(most hardware stores, some grocery stores) just
as well.

Spray the window, then stick some newspaper to the wetted
window, and spray the newspaper again, let soak for a while
to loosen up all the adhesive.

Same precautions: the aerosol stuff is flammable, and even
though the stuff is made from orange peels, it is dangerous
to inhale concentrated over a period of time.  Use a ton
of ventilation.

Dan Bezzant
'68 912

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 10:50:00 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Holes in 914 engine tin

>Let's see...   "Old sensor was like this, new sensor is just like it,
>so I need to change it."  That's basically it?

        More like, "P.O. did things cheap; Dealer didn't have the boot
when I bought the sensor, but told me, "It should be there."

>Mayby the hole is *supposed* to be there?

        Nope.  Correct air-flow to the heads is *VITAL*!  That's why
the spark plugs (right next to the sensor) have "boots" or covers on
them.  Air getting outside the sheet-metal is bad for engine life.

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"

Date: Sun, 9 Jul 1995 23:06:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: re: Porsche - Corvette/Camaros "GET" slaughtered

This message was sent to me by Mike Lommatzsch, Team Porsche, and
I am forwarding it to the world because he did an excellant job
in writing it and I'm too damn lazy to write something right now
because I want to rest up for the SCCA National Tour in Seattle.

However, I would like to add my 2 1/100ths of a dollar to this
posting. Yes, the top remaining cars in the overall challenge
were Porsches and Team Chevrolet was eliminated in the first
round.

Fact (Not an excuse) - Team Chevrolet wanted to live up its kool
& laid-back image in slamming down the cold ones immediately so
we decided to just go out immediately and let the Porsches play.
(It was too damn hot and we were thirsty) I went fast in the
first round in the overall challenge but, on my timed lap
someone, no doubt someone from Team Porsche, put 3 cones on the
line I was taking. Subsequently, they were killed and of course,
I was charged with the kills. (Those damn kones keep getting in
my way - SHIT!) Teresa Lommatzsch, Team Chevrolet (My Co-Driver)
was a winner in her class and made the challenge but, was
eliminated immediately in the first round. I'm not sure if she
was thirsty to.

All kidd'n aside, the event was a lot of fun for both teams. Bud
even bought the beer ("BUD") (I wonder why Bud drinks "BUD") for
everyone and joined Team Chevrolet for dinner. 

I think Mary Anne Behrens, the wife of the PCA National Safety 
God, wants to get a Corvette now. I think she likes the roar of
the V8. 

Who WON??? We don't know yet. A Team Porsche driver won the
overall challenge. There were some Team Chevrolet class wins and
there were some Team Porsche class wins. I asked Bud, which team
won? He said he couldn't tell at the moment and that he would
have to set down and add things up. Definitely, it was not a
onesided event. It looks like a toss-up, its that close.

No it wasn't a walk in the park, or like taking candy from a
baby, a piece of cake for either team but, we had lots of fun and
that is the important factor. I want to do it again.

Ken "Those damn kones are magnetized to my car" Mitchell
nokones@ix.netcom.com

Team Chevrolet - 1990 Camaro 1LE
PCA - SVR & SCCA - SFR      Date:  07/09/1995  11:06 pm  (Sunday)

> to be fun.... Its going to be walk in the park; like stealing

> Camaro going for the gold......

> This past weekend I was hanging with a lot of PCA people and they
> are already getting their excuse list together. They really have
> some neat ones, some that I hadn't even thought of. Thats OK just
> as long as they bring money because the losers (Porsche Drivers)
> are buying the beer and it better not be that crap in green
> bottles...

> Hey Lommatzsch - Are you going to post this to Porschephiles???

Yes, I will post this to Porschephiles with "our" winning results.

Well Ken, where's the beer for the winning Porsches!  Porsche didn't
dominate every class at the local Porsche - Corvette Challenge, but did
take enough class wins to have bragging rights until the next challenge. 
That may last about five years, since the last one was around 1989-90. 
When it can down to the end, Porsche had a clean sweep of the top five
"challenge" positions in the open class and the top four in the ladies
class.  Challenge winners were Tom Dugan in a bone stock 914 beating
Dwight Mitchell because of his breakout time on his previous challenge run
and Tricia Braun (alias Tricia Hills) in another somewhat stock 914.  All
Corvettes / Camaros went out in the first round of the ladies and open
class challenges.  Top Time of Day and Top Time Corvette did belong to Ken
Yeo with a 40.8xx.  Meanwhile the Top Time of Day Porsche went to Mike
Lommatzsch in a 914 at 42.6xx. 

More details will be avialable when I see a final tally of results.

The course was designed by Bud Behrens from the Porsche club but everyone
loved the course.  Start and finish were a little tight for the Corvettes
/ Camaros but with a 360 turn in the middle that the 914 took in third
gear at 4000 rpm it was fast and open every where else.  Many kudos to Bud
for a competitive course for all of the competitors. The morning started
quickly except fot the cars that had to run immediately after Henry "Hank"
Watts had oiled down the course with a wheel that wore a hole thorugh an
oil cooler hose first thing in the morning.  After about a forty-five 
minute cleaned up we were back running again.  Meanwhile the heat had 
been turned up and with the early morning showers, the humidity must have 
been near 100%.  Many people were seen wearing towels and drinking plenty 
of the non-alcoholic drinks for the rest of the day.  Everyone got two 
sets of two runs.  A run consisted of two laps; a warm up and a hot lap.

Many thanks to Jeff Glorioso from the Corvette club and Pat Ikeda from 
the Porsche club for setting this event up.  Also instrumental in 
the class structures, course design and site arrangement were Dwight 
Mitchell and Bud Behrens as mentioned earlier.

Everyone had a fantastic time and looks forward to a repeat challenge 
next year.  Though we would prefer that the beer be available at the end 
of the event by the Corvette's to make up for this years win by Porsche.

So Ken, what do you have to say now?  And about those excuses you had 
talked about all the Porsche owners needing to use?  Guess you'll have to 
save them for the next challenge should Porsche lose......NOT!

mike lommatzsch

pca-lpr/svr/ggr
scca-sfr/rr

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 12:46:47 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Re: Tyre recommendations (long)

Hi Philip,

Although I do not have a 911, I have had a number of high performance cars,
and a few different types of tires (or should I say tyres?). I have had
Goodyear Eagle GT and GT+4, Goodrich Comp T/A VR, Dunlop SP4000, and
Bridgestone RE 71. One of my friends currently had Dunlop D40 M2.

Of all the tires, I like the Bridgestone RE 71 the best. 

I HATED the Goodyear Eagle GT. They (Goodyear) had good dry weather
performance, but very poor feedback at the limit. They would stick, stick,
stick, and then just let go in one big slide with little warning. They were
also TERRIBLE in the rain. They lasted about 30,000 miles

My wife had Eagle GT + 4. These were much better in rain an snow than the
Eagle, but not nearly as good in the dry. They did provide better feedback.
Due to my type of driving (more pure sports than just driving) I have ruled
these out, but you want to consider them. The GT + 4 also lasted a long time,
close to 50,000 miles. They were reasonable affordable, too.

The Bridgestone RE 71 were as good as Goodyead GT in the dry (maybe a little
better), and gave plenty or warning before they would start to slide. THe car
would stick, stick, stick, squeal a little, squeal some more, squeal LOUD,
and then start to slide.The slides were predictable, and controllable. The
Bridgestone were also much better in the rain. The RE 71 lasted about 40,000
miles.

I also liked the Goodrich Comp T/A. They were a lot cheaper than the
Bridgestone, and probably better in the rain. They were not as good in the
dry. They gave plenty of feedback, and slides were easy to control, with
plenty of warning. They appeared to wear well, although I can't give exact
numbers because one car that I had them on was stolen, and the other car I
had them on was sold before the tires were worn out.

My current car has Dunlop SP4000. So far, they have impressed me with how
well they work in the dry. I have a few track day's on them, and on the track
they were better than I expected. Not as good as the RE 71, but at least as
good, and maybe a little better than the Comp T/A. I have heard that they are
good in the rain, but I have very little experience so far. I also can't help
with mileage.

Finally, one of my friends has the D40 M2, and I like them. They seem similar
to the SP4000. I think the SP4000 might be a little better, but it is hard to
say because it's not my car and I don't have that much time behind the wheel.

I hoped this helpd. It is just hy $.02

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White (with SP4000's)

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 10:14:37 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: exhaust studs from hell

A machinist friend told me of a recent bout he had with some 911 heads.
Not only were the exhaust studs broken off, but they also had broken-off 
EZ-outs in them.

He sent the heads to someone else for EDM (Electrical Discharge Machining),
which is a very precise (but slow) way of melting the old studs out.

 -Mitch


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 12:05:50 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Bobbing *TACH* in 914

> Was there a thread recently on fixing a VDO odo that bobs when you shift?
>The
> arm swings 3-4 inches then settles on the _true_(I hope) rpm reading.

        This is the tachometer, not the odometer.
        The tach in a 914/4 works off the FI trigger points in the base of the
distributor.  I remember someone saying, if the tach does this, to check those
points out.  They may be dirty or dying.  Also check the connections and wires,
if possible.
        Does anyone have harder/better info on this?

- --DD

darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 10:18:08 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 mystery part, solved

The mystery aluminum bushing ended up being a spacer for the MFI pump
base plate. Thank you John, Reid Ziegler, and Bob Spindel.

 -Mitch Craig
