Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 13:27:22 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: argh....

    Just got back from a fun weekend with the ever-present 914 project
(now nearing completion, thankfully!).  I was finishing up the brake job
that I had started the last time I was home, installed the new hard line
for the left front wheel ($35 from Stoddard!  for 1.5' of line!),
finally got my rear caliper off (no, there weren't any locking tabs,
just "wavy" washers, they were just really rusted on), drilled out the
broken bleeder screws (actually, I got an ez-out that worked pretty
well, I only had to drill one) and.... argh!  the new screws the parts
guy sold me were the wrong size.  Just so you know, the standard VW
screws are 6mmx1.0 and the ones I needed are 7mmx1.0.  Doh.
    Two little screws away from driving my car again, I am....

Nate

'71 914/1.7

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 13:18:53 EST
From: "paul foster" <paul_foster@imailhub.tdc.com>
Subject: Re: Steel  A-arms

     This message is a double reposting. My apologies about the uuencode 
     fiasco. Our email administrator thought the existing configuration 
     needed more "features". I tried once again, but I didn't see it 
     reflected. If this is a repeat, my apologies.
     
     Doug Dykaar writes:
     
     >Are the steel arms a LOT heavier than the Aluminum ones?
     
     No. They are relatively lightweight, and you can easily swap the 
     balljoint and bushings. They are from the VW Rabbit, so go to a VW 
     parts department and save big bucks.
     
     However, I have had some TERRIBLE experiences with them. The SCCA Solo 
     II stock class allows you to exchange the front swaybar. The only 
     adjustable one I know of is the Weltmeister bar from Automotion. It 
     mounts in the normal position on the aluminum a-arms, but you must 
     drill a hole through the middle of the steel a-arms to mount it.
     
     Accident #1: I was autocrossing at Sacramento about 2 1/2 hrs from 
     home. I was going around a 20-25 mph right corner when the a-arm 
     snapped in half, right through the drilled mounting hole. Carroll 
     Smith would say "stress riser". I would say SH*T.
     
     At the time I blamed my lack of mechanical aptitude. Since I was so 
     far from home, I had the car towed to Dwight Mitchell's shop 
     (Autosport Technology). $1200 and one week later, I had 2 new steel 
     a-arms, a four-wheel alignment, and a crumpled left fender.
     
     Accident #2: About one year later, I was autocrossing at Pleasanton 
     about 1/2 hour from home. I was going around a left-hand corner about 
     30-40 mph when the a-arm once again breaks, right through the drilled 
     mounting hole.
     
     Ken Mitchell (ex-GGR PCA member), bless his heart, helped me put my 
     car on his trailer and towed me home.
     
     Now, I had matching crumpled fenders.
     
     If you want to go to another vendor, I understand somebody (Fabtech?) 
     makes competition a-arms. This month's Pano has an interesting warning 
     from the factory concerning aluminum a-arms. Porsche is recommending 
     the Club Sport arms for heavy competitive uses. They have a 951 part 
     number instead of a 944 number.
     
     In the Northeast, there are a lot of stories about balljoint failures 
     at speed on cars that have been lowered too much. The July 1 Driver Ed 
     at Watkins Glen won't allow lowered 944s with aluminum arms to run.
     


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 11:58:44 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Fords and Porsches



Well, comparing Mustangs and 944/968s now? I have been for the last year,
with a 94 Mustang Cobra coupe and my various 924 Turbos, 944s,etc. 

Handling wise, the Porsche is better, though not by much. The tactil
driving response is much better in the Porsche. The Mustang does have a 
live axle, but remains fully controllable through all but the most 
uneven surfaces, the Porsche handling also suffers on theses surfaces, 
but does not have the heaving effect a live axle has because of the 
lower mass.

On a track comparison, which many magazines are using these days, my
Mustang was a full 5 seconds slower a lap than my 944. There is a good 
reason for this. The 944 had almost 16 years of behind the wheel 
experience in it's favor AND some very good chassis preparation, Koni 
sport shocks and very stick A008RTU tires. The Mustang was barely into
being 5 weeks old and I had very little time in it prior to going out on the track.

Despite the lack of prep, I found that the Mustang Cobra was very well
balanced, easy to drive hard and quite comperable in feel to an
unprepped 944 that I drove at the same event to tie my impressions
together. The Mustang was faster than that stock example. The Cobra 
model also had the best Non-Porsche, non-Corvette brakes I have ever 
used. They match the Club Sport brakes in size and response. The Mustang 
GT is not as well suspended, nor does it have the larger brakes, two
critical deficiences.

Power-wise, the Mustang is fine.  Gearing could be better, though it is 
perfect for highway driving. It is hard to pass on the value offered,
mine was about $24K. True, fit and finish could have been more 
meticulous in a couple of areas, but for commuting, the Mustang Cobra 
is a fine choice. Most of the brain-dead commuters are far more 
courteous to the Mustang than they are to the Porsche.

For serious driving, I prefer the Porsche. A much finer automobile
for the enthusiast.

Jim Pasha

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 12:14:02 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Bobbing *TACH* in 914

Dave Darling writes:

>        The tach in a 914/4 works off the FI trigger points in the base of the
>distributor.  I remember someone saying, if the tach does this, to check those
>points out.  They may be dirty or dying.  Also check the connections and wires,
>if possible.
>        Does anyone have harder/better info on this?

I believe Dave is mistaken. The tachometer works off the (ignition) points.
 It's the same on all 4-cylinder 914s, including the 1.8, which has
L-Jetronic and hence does not have seperate FI trigger points.

As to _why_ the tach is bobbing, there isn't much to the tacho's wiring. If
the points and condensor are good, and the wires to the tach are good, you
may actually have a bad tacho - it happens.

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |
|        standard disclaimers apply         | 
|___________________________________________|

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 15:23:40 EST

International driver's license is a piece of cake. . .Just go to AAA (assuming 
you're a member) with a variety of little slips of paper and they'll take your 
picture and fill out the card while you wait.  It'll cost $15 or so.

You're on your own with the passport, though.

same thing (i.e. not working) even when the engine
is warm-started, though if I rev-up around 3000-4000
rpm. it comes alive. 

Is this common? Is there any easy-to-check points
to get rid of this?

Thanks a lot.

>after a cold start. It requires some warm-up or me
>to tap on the dashboard. I'd imagine there is a 
>connection problem somewhere. It sometimes does the
>same thing (i.e. not working) even when the engine

>rpm. it comes alive.

>to get rid of this?

Mostl likely cause is a bit of oil causing the tach to be
sticky until you tap it.  You can either replace it for 
about $100 or live with it... (P.S. when you get ready to
sell the car, keep it warmed up...)
Good Luck!

> Remote, they are very high grade steel

> 4. The crankshaft pulley bolt is torqued to 154 ftlbs. Is it at all possible
>    to remove it by first blocking the wheels, setting the handbrake, and
>   putting the car into gear to lock the crank? Will this be too stressful 
>   on the driveshaft , gearbox, clutch etc?

torsional energy -DANGEROUS

through the (removed) starter hole.

anyway in my erperience.  tap on the pully or maby carefully pry x2
on the back side.

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 13:54:12 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Gears on Crankshafts


Don't you love it when someone asks for advice, folks 
generously take their time to give it, and then it's ignored.  
Guilty.

Advice about putting the gears back on the crankshaft included 
using an arbor press, heating on a hotplate, heating in an oven, 
and heating in a frying pan, all of which are simple and work.  
But when I picked up the crankshaft from the machine shop 
where it had been micropolished, I asked the machinist how he 
does it.  You would have to see this place to understand why 
you would do whatever this fellow says. He's an old-timer, 
been building racing engines - lots  of Porsche's - for many 
years.  He does all the machine work for the best places in 
Seattle.   Doesn't advertise.  All word of mouth.  His shop is an 
extension of his house.  You'd never know it was there.  It's in 
the middle of a quiet, residential neighborhood. And it's 
equipped with everything, and I mean everything.  To an 
amateur mechanic/machinist like me, it's paradise.

Anyway, he said he just heats 'em with a Bernz-O-Matic
torch till you can smell a little oil smell in the air, and
then slips 'em right on.  So that's what I did.  Took about
a minute and a half.  No fry pan.  No hot plate.  No oven. No 
oil.
No upset wife due to borrowed kitchen utensils.
Can't get any simpler!

- --
Thanks again to all those who tried to get me into
trouble with the kitchen meister...

 -Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu
'72 911E Targa
'72 911T Coupr

> definitely need to have a lot of netters interested and willing to
> help out.

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 16:59:07 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 FI wiring

        Oops.  I think I may have done some mis-labeling when I took
the FI wiring harness apart.  This is for a 74 2.0L, BTW--made 10/73.
        I have three single wires that I think may have gotten con-
fused.  Two come out of the wire bundle that eventually goes to the
coil.  One is green with a red tracer, the other is white.  The final
wire is also white, and come out of the wire bundle that eventually
leads to the FI trigger points in the base of the distributor.  All
three wires have/had female spade-type connectors on the end.
        I had the GN/RD wire marked "oil press", but now I think it
possible I mis-labeled it.  The second white wire was marked "thermo
time", which is what controls the aux air valve.  It may also be mis-
labeled.  The first white wire is not marked.
        Can someone help me straighten out my spaghetti?  TIA!

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 18:13:54 +0000
From: "Jeff Kyle" <jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com>
Subject: Re: Bobbing *TACH* in 914

> I believe Dave is mistaken. The tachometer works off the (ignition) points.
>  It's the same on all 4-cylinder 914s, including the 1.8, which has
> L-Jetronic and hence does not have seperate FI trigger points.

For what it's worth, my '75 with the 1.8 and L-Jetronic has the 
standard 914 bouncy tach, and the other '75 w/1.8 that I've had close 
exposure to (though it was a long time ago) had a bouncy tach, as 
well...

I've had the points changed twice since I've had the car, with no 
change in the bobbing at all. I've just always assumed that "that's 
the way it is..."
| Jeff Kyle                                |
| jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com        |
| http://www.servtech.com/public/jeffk914/ |
| "Katarina" 1975 Porsche 914              |

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 17:08:27 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Bobbing tach in 914 (corr)

>I believe Dave is mistaken. The tachometer works off the (ignition) points.
> It's the same on all 4-cylinder 914s, including the 1.8, which has
>L-Jetronic and hence does not have seperate FI trigger points.

        BING!  That was it!  It's the *regular* points!  And the bobbing
tach *can* be caused by a failing condensor.  That was the memory I was
trying to dig up!
        Thanks, Andrew!

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 15:21:20 -0700 (PDT)
From: JAH@slc.slac.stanford.edu
Subject: Re: Autocross classifications

    > >I have a 1974 Porsche 911 Targa Carerra.  I am interested in how the 
    > >classification system works for Porsche Club Solo II autocrosses or 
    > >SCCA autocrosses.  In SCCA, the car is in A Stock.  What 
    > >modifications are acceptable? 
      
    > >Can you upgrade the Borge shocks using Bilstein Gas inserts?
     
Yes, any shock/strut may be used provided it follows the rules. Without 
getting long-winded about it. You can use any shock so long as the 
original mounting points and system are unaltered.

    > >Can you lower the car?

Contrary to some beliefs, there are -some- situations that allow you 
to lower a car in Stock class. The torsion bar suspension does seem to
allow for this.

13.8
...Both front and rear suspension may be adjusted through their designed
range of adjustment by use of factory adjustment arrangements or by 
taking advantage of inherent manufacturing tolerances...

The front suspension of all 914s and older 911s qualify here. So if 
you feel like it'll help, you can lower the front as far as you want...

    > >Change the torsion bars to 27mm?                                

Nope, not in stock class, as a torsion bar is considered a "spring" 
and spring rates must stay stock.
     
    > >Go to 7" and 8" wide rims?

Nope, not unless the width, diameter, and offset could be had as an 
option that model year. Otherwise, what was stock for the car then, 
is what you can use.

    > >Install sway bars front and rear?

Front sway bars are unrestricted, rear sway bars may not be altered, 
and you may not add one that wasn't available as an option that model
year.
     
    > >Go to a non standard exhaust system?  Use a stinger exhaust?

Exhaust is open from the cat back. If there is no catalitic converter,
technically speaking, you could do anything.

    > >How does Porsche Club rules apply?

I'm not too familiar with PCA rules. I'll let somone else get that one.

 -Josh

Joshua Hadler				'74 914 2.0L CSP
Accelerator Operations
Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu

Everything expresed here is the opinion of the idiot that wrote it, 
namely ME. So don't go suing the DOE, they don't care...


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 15:26:30 -0700
From: cherie@corp.cirrus.com (Cherie Woodward)
Subject: Pesky varmints/How could I?

This comes as a warning to all of us P-philes. I'd parked the Orange
Monster a little too long at my SO's. I was aware he has a bit of a rat
problem, but _really_ no idea!!! There's a restaurant behing his house with
a sign "RAT HEAVEN! We keep our dumpster wide open to all little furries.
Bring the whole family and have more!" This has created the problem and our
dog (150+ to date), ratter tho she is, doesn't allow no 'katz' in the yard.

On to the reason of this post...

A weekend ago I was preparing the Orange Monster for a leisurely drive to
the beach. I opened the bonnet and found the cutest thing, an oil rag
curled into a most comfortable position and cushily lined with grass. The
spoor around indicated that a small mouse/rat had been having a little too
much fun (the disco lights should have been the first tip off) at my baby's
expense.

I thought that, after throwing the evidence away, I'd crashed the party and
rid myself of the pest. HA! <-- Rat laugh

I started driving the beast to work again and noticed this odor invading
the cab. I figured the few calling cards I'd found had spoiled the pristine
carpet and I now needed to shampoo and deodorize. No problem. I was so
happy that I'd caught this thing early. HA HAA <-- Hearty rat laugh

I proceed to buy special deodorizing shampoos (nothing too good for my
honey) and start the tear down. I take the carpet out, spread it out on a
nice clean surface and start scrbbing away. It occurred to me that I might
find another comfy nest in the spare. But there was no more evidence, so
I'm off scott free, right? HA HA HAAA <-- Scoundrelly rat laugh

I finished the carpet cleaning and put it up to dry. I then went on to
washing and deodorizing the boot just in case that teeny tiny bit of rat
piss soaked through to the metal. At this time I thought it might be a good
idea to check the heater cockpit. I don't have a gas heater and keep a few
emergency items stored there. I always thought of this place as a
'sanctuary'. A secure, hidden place to keep those small items that are
seldom used, but necessay when needed. HA HA HA HAAAA <-- Twist of the
whiskers rat laugh

A sickening feeling sunk into my bowels when I flipped the lock and popped
the hatch. Nudged right up against the hatch door was a mound of grass. An
overwhelming rat piss/shit odor, no smell soured the air. On went the
rubber gloves and mask. I grabbed the wet/dry vac, but soon realized that I
just had to roll up my sleeves and remove the bulk of the debris by hand.

When I grabbed the first handful it felt very heavy. I caught a glimpse of
something gray diving into a large porthole under the steering column. Did
I really see something? Was I disturbing a rat condo? Seems so. The little
rascal had filled the entire box with grass and shit. I never knew how deep
that box is. After a whole grocery bag full of this refuse, I knew that
this was not a condo, but the whole project! It must've taken weeks for
this monument to be built. Where was I and what was my role in coming to
the aide of my sleigh?

I began with thourough vaccumming, then doused with vinegar (great for
metal!), followed with an organic cleaner. Even with a week of airing, the
stench hasn't gone completely away. I'm going to give it another treatment.

The entry to the boot itself was a plastic plug that had been gnawed
through. Cute, huh? Saved it for posterity. The entry to the heater hatch
was the large porthole under the steering column. I plugged this hole with
a formed heavy duty screen (formed around a pool ball that was roughly the
same size as the hole) and some steel wool. Because of the heater duct
going directly into the cab, I figured the hole is to push presurized air
through the area and on into the cab. It probably isn't a good idea to plug
this hole so the screen allows airflow, but restricts rodent flow.

It makes sense to check this hatch if you've left your car sitting anywhere
for any length of time. Especially if you've caught a whiff of something
distinctly animalistic.

This is how I spent last weekend - oh and my company golf tourney!



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 15:29:22 PDT
From: "William M. York" <york@parc.xerox.com>
Subject: Re: 1983 944 vs. 1995 Mustang 5LV8 

   From:  HHeath3@aol.com
   Date:  Mon, 10 Jul 1995 00:23:45 -0400
   Having read several car mag articles on current Ford Mustang 5.0L V8 coupes,
   I found myself near a local Ford house w/ a few minutes to kill.
[. . .]
   I got back into my aged 944 and went back over the same roads at similar
   speeds, and fell in love with my modest little used car all over again.  Why
   can't an American car maker create machines with the balance and
   sophistication of these little Deutschmobiles?

As a former Mustang GT and SVO Mustang owner (and current 911 owner),
I agree with most of your comparison comments, especially the live
axle problems.  However, to be fair, I should point out that I bought
my '82 Mustang GT brand new for $7,200.  How much did your '83 944
cost?  Ford had a pretty different set of goals and constraints for
the Mustang that Porsche had for the 944.

And I still miss the SVO's shifter...

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 19:16:51 EDT
From: "Wayne G. Namerow" <itsmagic@VNET.IBM.COM>
Subject: "the Fatherland"

"Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>  writes:

> I would need an international driver's license
>anyway... true/false?  How does one go about getting an international
>driver's license, anyway?  Come to think of it, I don't even have a
>passport...

Nate,
     A international drivers license is not necessary. Your license is valid
due to reciprocal agreement. However, you definitely need a passport. These
can be obtained in 24 hours if needed (In a pinch, at extra cost)
     Regarding trains + freebies, your in luck. the Porsche Factory tour
and museum are both free and easily accessible by train. After arrival in
Stuttgart, take the local S-bahn subway which stops about a block from the
factory complex. I suggest you contact PCNA now to make a reservation for
a tour. It is usually possible for U.S. folks to tag onto a existing tour
without a reservation, however this is frowned upon and not guaranteed.
The museum is open to the public without reservation.
     Enjoy.
                                                 -Wayne

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 16:50:59 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: Porsche sightings (commercials)

Here's one from way back:

Circa '82-83 -

ADA is pushing softer bristled toothbrushes along with Oral B.  Scene -

hand rubbing hard bristled toothbrush on painted metal surface.  Surface
turns out to be green 911/912 front fender.  After some time, brushing
stops to reveal clean, bare metal where Porsche paint USED to be!  

Moral - don't let anyone near your baby overnight with a hard bristled 
toothbrush! 

Kick - thud ... oh you mean it was to show toothbrush wear on teeth?  Buy
those softer bristled tooth brushes!

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 20:12:41 -0400 (EDT)
From: gt7451b@prism.gatech.edu (Bryan R. Mattern)
Subject: 914 -> Early 911 Brakes

Hello All,
	While looking through some catalogs, I became confused.  I was
thinking about bolting on the 911 front suspension to gain the benifits of
better braking/handling.  From what I understand, the '65 to early '75 911
front calipers are fitted w/the same pad as the 914.  I understand Porsche
went to vented rotors in '70 for most models, but they retained the same size
pad until 1975(with exception the the "S" alloy calipers, which had a larger
pad.  My question is this, what is the added benifit of going to a 65-75 model
911 front suspension?  Besides possibly better handling from the larger
torsion bars, I can't think of any.  In terms of braking, there should be
less fade under constant, heavy braking with the vented rotors, not better
braking.  If the only way to get better braking is to install a 75 to
present front end, this is not a very economical swap, as there are just
not as many "spare" suspensions lying around. Also, what is the story with the
BMW 320 Calipers (what year, what needs to be done...)?  If they have a
larger pad area than the early 911/914, wouldn't this be the best route to
improved braking?

Thanks for any contributions,
Bryan
'74 914 2.0ltr


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 18:19:06 -0500
From: stamper@interaccess.com (scott sanda)
Subject: Re: 1983 944 vs. 1995 Mustang 5LV8

Well, to add my $.02:

I have raced against both a 95 mustang (SCCA Showroom stack A with 6 cyln
engine) and a Ford special vehicle team 95 V8. The SVT V8 was considerably
faster, and even beat me in the corners( it should, with a well race
developed suspension!) The SSA V6 was 4 or 5 seconds slower, but in its
defence it had the stock suspension, so even though it boasted about 190 hp,
the handleing wouldn't let it really run. I am making a broad assumption
that on a short track, I could also outrun a regular mustang V8, but I would
get beated at a long track like Road America. Of course a lot of this would
depend on the nut behind the wheel....

Scott D Sanda


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 17:42:26 PDT
From: William Kirkwood <kiwi@mbari.org>
Subject: Heat related start problems

To anyone who has solved this before -

I'm having a problem with starter / ignition system which
has some odd behavior. First, I read the note on the hot '77
restart problem and I think mine is different. The car is a 
'78 911SC and it will not turn over (not even click) when the 
car is hot. It has always started when it's cold and also seems
(by experimentation) to start right after being turned off
when hot. In the time it takes to fill the gas tank it 
will refuse to turn over (same as a DEAD battery). Defining hot
is still in the experimental stage, but using the factory gauge
anything mid-range and above will repeat this phenomenon.

This first happened on vacation, so I pulled into a dealer and
had it 'fixed'. The new starter imitates the old one perfectly.

I also checked with two other people who have SC's but different 
years. Both have experienced the same problem with no solution, 
their problem seems to be more intermittent than the one I'm having.
A suggestion has been made that it might be the heat from the engine
roasting the starter solenoid which either swells and won't move or
some contact set seperates. I've also been told the ground strap
might be the cause, but I would think I'd see a charging light
problem if that were the case.

I'd really like to hear from someone who has had this happen before
I go digging into the car, or give up and visit a dealer again. If
you have a clue, I know of three people who will listen. 

Thanks ahead of time for any help! 
   
Bill Kirkwood
kiwi@mbari.org
'78 911SC Targa                                   

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 19:01:15 -0600
From: dhagood@henge.com (Dave Hagood)
Subject: Re: 1983 944 vs. 1995 Mustang 5LV8

Hunter sez:

> speeds, and fell in love with my modest little used car all over again.  Why
> can't an American car maker create machines with the balance and
> sophistication of these little Deutschmobiles?

> Thoughts?  Would the new Camaro/Firebird be any more sophisticated?  C & D et
> al. praise them highly.

        These cars are aren't meant to be sophisticated, they're meant to
be fast.  Further,
at around $23K, they offer *huge* value for the money, assuming of course
you want
a very fast car to stand on for a couple of years.  A friend of mine has
one, and I can't
keep up in my 911.  Sure, my car maybe is as fast as his, but me in my car
is not as
fast as Vinnie is his car.

        You want sophistication?  Buy a Porsche, at around 3 times the
price.  Sure, the
Porsche will be worth far more in 5 years.  But at basic bang for buck,
these cars are
at the top of their pyramid.  It's called market focus, and GM finally
seems to be doing
something right.

>Bill Kirkwood
>kiwi@mbari.org
>'78 911SC Targa                                   
>
>

I just went through this, new starter and all. What finally fixed it was a 
small relay and wiring harness I got from Zim's. I still don't know exactly 
what the problem was but I think that the wire from the ignition switch to 
the starter developes resistance with age. The relay kit took me 5 minutes 
to install and the problem was cured immediately. (Zim's phone number is 
800-356-2964)


___________________________________________________________
Tim Heikell
1969 911S

Date: 11 Jul 1995 02:29:21 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.COM (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: 911 Heel and Toe

> Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 14:38:52 -0600
> From: gwilensky@gryphonsw.com (Gabriel Wilensky)
> Subject: Heel and toe
>
> I have a problem with trying to heel and toe in my '77 911S. I can't reach
> the accelerator pedal while braking, so I added a 3/4" wood block to the
> accelerator pedal and now I can reach it with the edge of the foot, but
> then I realized the pedal has about 1" of play! It goes in for a bit and
> only then the engine revs up. To go that far and still brake I would have
> to be a contorsionist! Is that normal? Can anything (in the accelerator
> play) be adjusted? How important is it to cover the wood block with some
> sort of rubber pad? I couldn't find anything that would fit.
>
> Thanks
> Gabriel

Gabriel,
I just made this fix to my 73.  The height of both the clutch and brake
pedals can be adjusted.  And I took care of the accelerator pedal by screwing
on top a new (second) pedal.  The brake and gas are now easily reachable for
heel-and-toeing, and the clutch is at a height near the footrest plate so I
can just swivel by the heel.  What an amazing difference!  (I wish I could
claim credit but a Porsche body shop pointed the way...)

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara, CA)
95 993 coupe, guards red
73.5 911T 2.7 coupe, ferrari red
85 535i, grey

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 17:08:43 -0700
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re[2]: Bobbing *TACH* in 914

     To all "Tacho-philes
     
     Among other reasons for the tachometer "bobbing" is because the 
     magnetic damper is "kaput".  I don't know how to describe it exactly, 
     but VDO uses a magnet to dampen the needle action.  I think it 
     probably some cheap platic magnet.  In any event, the fix is to send 
     out the tach to a repair facility and get it fixed and recalibrated.
     
     Dan
     


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Re: Bobbing *TACH* in 914
Author:  "Jeff Kyle" <jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com> at SMTP
Date:    7/10/95 6:13 PM


> I believe Dave is mistaken. The tachometer works off the (ignition) points. 
>  It's the same on all 4-cylinder 914s, including the 1.8, which has
> L-Jetronic and hence does not have seperate FI trigger points.
     
For what it's worth, my '75 with the 1.8 and L-Jetronic has the 
standard 914 bouncy tach, and the other '75 w/1.8 that I've had close 
exposure to (though it was a long time ago) had a bouncy tach, as 
well...
     
I've had the points changed twice since I've had the car, with no 
change in the bobbing at all. I've just always assumed that "that's 
the way it is..."
| Jeff Kyle                                | 
| jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com        | 
| http://www.servtech.com/public/jeffk914/ | 
| "Katarina" 1975 Porsche 914              |

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 17:34:45 -0800 (PST)
From: BMESSINGER@ewu.edu
Subject: asking for advice on building a competition 914.


Fellow P-philers,
I am humbly asking for advice about how to go about building a 914 for auto-x
and other club-type competitions.  You are probably saying "that depends on
which 'other' competitions you are talking about." Well, I am not sure. You
see, I have only been to one amateur event in my life.  It was a Memorial Day
auto-x put on by a local sports car club. I saw a small three-line plug in 
the local paper and was shocked; I didn't even know there was a local club!

Four years ago at age 20 I bought my first Porsche, a '72 914 1.7. I told
myself that I would start at the bottom of the Porsche ladder and work my
way up over the years until I attained my dream Porsche (which changes with
each new model year!) Well, a big chunk of my heart now belongs to the 914
no matter what any of the snob-segment of our fellow P-nuts ever say.

Ramblings aside, I want to build a 914 for competition. Here are the
parameters:

           1. It must be street-legal, and at least marginaly street-drivable
           2. harsh ride is acceptable
           3. body mods are acceptable (to lighten and/or accomodate tires)
           4. anything else goes (well, anything but a chevy engine!)

Questions I have:

           1. If I do the project a little at a time, what things should I
              do first (shocks,sway-bars,springs/t-bars,chassis stiffening,
              engine, etc.)?
           2. Everybody is saying the 901 trany is weak. Is it hard to swap
              in a modified 915? Is the linkage hard to rig?(I saw one for
              915's in 914's in "Exellence" for over $1K. OUCH!!!
           3. How much power can you wring out of a type-IV ?
           4. What mods specific to 914's are allowed in the different
              competition categories? What category should I shoot for?
           5. Are there any publications you recomend that would be helpful?
           

I am requesting this advice since I know that many of you have experience
preparing cars for competition. I am sure that there are more wrong ways
than right ways to do it, and I am hoping you will help me sort out the 
things that will help me win from the stuff that I don't need. Then me and 
my new 914 will go to driving school to learn how to propperly late-apex and
such!

                                thanks guys!
                               Ben Messinger
                               bmessinger@ewu.edu

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 20:00:35 -0700 (PDT)
From: Walter Stander <wstander@cts.com>
Subject: Re: Pesky varmints/How could I?

On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Cherie Woodward wrote:

> This comes as a warning to all of us P-philes. I'd parked the Orange
> Monster a little too long at my SO's. I was aware he has a bit of a rat
> problem, but _really_ no idea!!! There's a restaurant behing his house with
> a sign "RAT HEAVEN! We keep our dumpster wide open to all little furries.
> Bring the whole family and have more!" This has created the problem and our
> dog (150+ to date), ratter tho she is, doesn't allow no 'katz' in the yard.
> 
> On to the reason of this post...
> 
> A weekend ago I was preparing the Orange Monster for a leisurely drive to
> the beach. I opened the bonnet and found the cutest thing, an oil rag
> curled into a most comfortable position and cushily lined with grass. The
> spoor around indicated that a small mouse/rat had been having a little too
> much fun (the disco lights should have been the first tip off) at my baby's
> expense.
> 
> I thought that, after throwing the evidence away, I'd crashed the party and
> rid myself of the pest. HA! <-- Rat laugh
> 
> I started driving the beast to work again and noticed this odor invading
> the cab. I figured the few calling cards I'd found had spoiled the pristine
> carpet and I now needed to shampoo and deodorize. No problem. I was so
> happy that I'd caught this thing early. HA HAA <-- Hearty rat laugh
> 
> I proceed to buy special deodorizing shampoos (nothing too good for my
> honey) and start the tear down. I take the carpet out, spread it out on a
> nice clean surface and start scrbbing away. It occurred to me that I might
> find another comfy nest in the spare. But there was no more evidence, so
> I'm off scott free, right? HA HA HAAA <-- Scoundrelly rat laugh
> 
> I finished the carpet cleaning and put it up to dry. I then went on to
> washing and deodorizing the boot just in case that teeny tiny bit of rat
> piss soaked through to the metal. At this time I thought it might be a good
> idea to check the heater cockpit. I don't have a gas heater and keep a few
> emergency items stored there. I always thought of this place as a
> 'sanctuary'. A secure, hidden place to keep those small items that are
> seldom used, but necessay when needed. HA HA HA HAAAA <-- Twist of the
> whiskers rat laugh
> 
> A sickening feeling sunk into my bowels when I flipped the lock and popped
> the hatch. Nudged right up against the hatch door was a mound of grass. An
> overwhelming rat piss/shit odor, no smell soured the air. On went the
> rubber gloves and mask. I grabbed the wet/dry vac, but soon realized that I
> just had to roll up my sleeves and remove the bulk of the debris by hand.
> 
> When I grabbed the first handful it felt very heavy. I caught a glimpse of
> something gray diving into a large porthole under the steering column. Did
> I really see something? Was I disturbing a rat condo? Seems so. The little
> rascal had filled the entire box with grass and shit. I never knew how deep
> that box is. After a whole grocery bag full of this refuse, I knew that
> this was not a condo, but the whole project! It must've taken weeks for
> this monument to be built. Where was I and what was my role in coming to
> the aide of my sleigh?
> 
> I began with thourough vaccumming, then doused with vinegar (great for
> metal!), followed with an organic cleaner. Even with a week of airing, the
> stench hasn't gone completely away. I'm going to give it another treatment.
> 
> The entry to the boot itself was a plastic plug that had been gnawed
> through. Cute, huh? Saved it for posterity. The entry to the heater hatch
> was the large porthole under the steering column. I plugged this hole with
> a formed heavy duty screen (formed around a pool ball that was roughly the
> same size as the hole) and some steel wool. Because of the heater duct
> going directly into the cab, I figured the hole is to push presurized air
> through the area and on into the cab. It probably isn't a good idea to plug
> this hole so the screen allows airflow, but restricts rodent flow.
> 
> It makes sense to check this hatch if you've left your car sitting anywhere
> for any length of time. Especially if you've caught a whiff of something
> distinctly animalistic.
> 
> This is how I spent last weekend - oh and my company golf tourney!
> 
> 
> 
Several years ago, we drove to Phoenix from San Diego for a time trial 
event at Firebird. After offloading, I went over to tech/safety and the 
crew removed a roadrunner from my engine compartment!! (only feathers 
left, no smells)

Walt

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 23:10:46 -0400 (EDT)
From: Matt Clement <mclement@access.digex.net>
Subject: Re: 1983 944 vs. 1995 Mustang 5LV8



On Mon, 10 Jul 1995, Walter Stander wrote:

> Camaros/TransAms/Mustangs, or a 968/986). And lets not forget the gas 
> guzzler tax and luxury tax. Oh, luxury? I've owned a new 944, a used 
> 944S, and a 911SC "Weissach Coupe". The leather in those cars is so hard 
> and uncomfortable it could better be used as tire retread plies. Oh yes, 
> and we must not forget the sheer joy of taking out 2nd and 3rd mortgages 
> to repair these vehicles; the 911 series was (IMHO), the worst. I 
> actually sold mine while it sat in the local Porsche dealer's bay.

I would disagree with you on many counts here.  I find the interiors of 
Porsche's the epitome of understated elegance, and if the leather 
interior of yours was hard, either you got a bad batch or the leather 
wasn't looked after very carefully by the previous owner.  Mine has 
received Hide Food regularly since new and is as soft as a baby's bottom. 

As far as the luxury tax and gas guzzler tax, the simplest solution is to 
buy a car that is a few months old -- traded back in by someone who 
decided a Porsche wasn't for them (either that, or their wife divorced 
them over the car, leaving them financially ruined) -- you avoid both 
taxes, reduce the price by 20%, and still get a very new car.

Finally, I have found that Porsches, *** WHEN PROPERLY MAINTAINED ***, 
will run almost forever without major failure.  If you call routine oil 
changes and 15,000 mile service intervals unreliable, I beg to differ.

- -- Matt
A very satisfied owner of an '87 944S



------------------------------


Porschephiles #1544                         Tue Jul 11 02:00:16 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 15:47:35 TZ
From: Harvey Yancey <harveyy@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Factory tour / Europe travle info ?

Hi G.E.,

In order to arrange a factory tour you need to call PCNA at 1-800-443-0340
or (702) 348-3109.  They will send a telex the factory and confirm your
date and time via letter.

The tour is really great.  I took it in Dec. 1991, WELL worth the effort.
Watch out for the forklift drivers ... they will run you down.

Since you are doing to go through southern Germany, you will definately
want to go to Munich and Garmische (sp?).  There is a small peninsula on
Lake Constance called Lindau.  Very cool place.  Settled by the Romans
in 13 B.C. if my memory serves me correctly.

Hope this helps,

Harvey - harveyy@microsoft.com
73 911T/S

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 95 10:22:38 PST
From: "RADSICKT" <radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil>
Subject: 914 Owners Association Reunion:  Post-game report

 Greetings P-Philes,
 
 I made the two hour trek down to Palm Springs (on the motorcycle, wearing black 
 leathers in 110 degree heat) for the 914 OA reunion.  All in all there were 
 around, oh... I'd say 20-25 cars entered in the car show part and I also 
 spotted a few back out at the hotel.  The show started around 0800 and went 
 until around 1030 (I got there at 0930). I have to admit I was a bit 
 disappointed as to the number of cars but most were in pretty good condition 
 and there were quite a few 914/6's.  Only a select few of the cars were 
 anywhere near being stock, practically all had funky upholstery, different 
 wheels (both road and steering), stuff painted that should not be, blah. blah, 
 blah.  The best looking cars were (1) P-Phile's own Mike Willis' brown car, 
 complete with restored fuchs that made me quite jealous (mine look like they 
 have been through an acid bath!) and (2) Roy Juan's (PCA-Grand Prix or Orange 
 Coast) modified 73 (neat paint job, 6-cyl, fiberglass flares, etc.)  Anyway, on 
 seeing all the cool cars, my first instinct was to hop right back on the bike 
 and ride home so I could start working on mine. And actually, that's about what 
 I did because there wasn't really much to do after that.  Just a tour of the 
 stars homes (big yawn -- I decided to pass...) and the dinner and then a tech 
 session I guess on Sunday.  I paid my money to Dennis as I was leaving -- a 
 little steep for just a car show, but hopefully next time there will be more 
 events, driving competitions, organized trips/cruises downtown, stuff like 
 that.  (I hope Dennis is listening....)
 
 Extra special thanks to Mike Willis for "showing the new guy around" and for 
 driving me to lunch in his very nice car.  It is nice to know at least one 
 person when you go somewhere like that and Mike made me feel like part of the 
 group.  Definitely a nice guy.
 
 Summary:  Good way to spend a free day; wish there was more car-oriented stuff 
 to do; Mike is cool. That's my report!
 
 -Tim



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 00:07:32 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: re : bouncing 914 tach

Hi,

I have been waiting for someone else to point this out but
nobody did so here it is :

I had the same problem 15 years ago on my first Porsche,
a '73 914/1.7 . I pulled out the tach (easy) and noticed a small
screw on the back. This screw adjusted the damping tension,
and by turning it a bit I was able to get it too tight, then
tried again and the bounce was almost gone.

I don't remember exactly where or what it looked like, but
you should be able to figure it out if I could when I was 19.

Regards, Mike Piera '72S & '73E 911 Targas, '73 914/2.0

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 00:27:26 -0400
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: International driver's license

Hi Nathan and everyone else,

You don't need to get an international driver's license to legally drive in
Europe.  People holding American licenses have a year to get a new license. 

I wish I had gotten my license when I first lived in Germany in 1991-92. I
went back 2 years later and tried to get one and was told that I would have
to follow the arduous and expensive (about $1500-$2000) German driving school
program. Apparently, so many Eastern Europeans had moved to Germany, bought
120mph cars (in place of their 60mph top speed Trabants, Skodas and Ladas)and
wrecked them that the German authorities had to stop giving out German
licenses to anybody who had a foriegn one.

Too bad. Here in Miami, it would be great to pull out a German license when
pulled over and say "Gibt es ein Problem Herr Polizist?" I would then get a
police escort to wherever I wanted to go- wouldn't want to offend another
German tourist.

Bye,
Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 01:32:51 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: 914 FI wiring

In response to text from Dave Darling:

>        I had the GN/RD wire marked "oil press", but now I think it
>possible I mis-labeled it.  The second white wire was marked "thermo
>time", which is what controls the aux air valve.  It may also be mis-
>labeled.  The first white wire is not marked.
>        Can someone help me straighten out my spaghetti?  TIA!

Having just performed such an operation this evening(will finish tomorrow),
I can give you what I recall(I had to trace my hardness to the brain
connector to determine what went where...)

The GN/RD wire is does indeed connection to the oil pressure idiot light
sender.  The wire that connections to the aux. air valve is *not* white
and not part of the fuel injection brain harness.  My wire to the aux. air
valve went directly to the relay box and not the FI brain.

Now, the white wires(as there are several):

3 white, male connectors, two wires each, out from harness in between the
connectors for injectors #3 & #4 - those ground to the 3 pronged terminal
on the case(you did put is back didn't you?).  In this area will also be
the two-holed, female connector for the intake air temperature sensor.

One of the white wires goes to cylinder head temperature sender - it is
immediately after the #3 & #4 injector connectors.

In the center of the harness there will be a group consisting of a 3-hole, 
female connector, 2-hole female connector, and a single wire female spade 
end. The 3-hole connector is for the distributor trigger points(obviously). 
The 2-hole is for the cold start value on the front of the intake air 
distributor.  The final lone wire in that area connects to the thermo-time 
switch on the engine block below said air distributor.  

You can verify the thermo-time switch wire before connecting it, as it will 
be connected(wired)  the hardness to one of the poles of the cold start value 
connector.  The switch provides a ground to the cold start valve when the 
engine is cold - I don't know for how long.

Hey Dave, we should be starting our cars up about the same time!

p.s. Anyone have a deceleration valve(3 vaccuum connections - pneumatic) 
for a 1.7L engine laying around?  Can I just bypass it in the meantime
by looping the vaccuum lines?  I can't see why not as they were removed 
from later engines.
- -- 
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 - Jerry R. Brady         - Open Networks Engineering -          jrb@one.com -
 - 1976 Sunflower Yellow 914/2.0(ok,ok, it's a 1.7 with 96mm NPR)            -
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 02:23:31 -0400
From: NineinNail@aol.com
Subject: '87 924S A/C Performance Ques.

Gentleman!

My '87 924S with the old style interior (similiar to older '83-'85/1 944's)
seems to have marginal A/C performance.

The compressor seems to click off before it is cool enough in the interior.
 I recently had a new compressor installed along with the system recharged
and leak tested, so I think enough freon is in the system.

One other note, the heat is "stuck" on due to a bad water control valve
cable, could this be causing the poor performance? (i.e warm air mixing w/
ice cold creating luke cold air?)  I have not had a chance to manually close
the water valve and see it's effect.  Or is it the interior thermostat? Any
thoughts?

Are other 924S-944/1 owners satisfied with the A/C system performance or are
these earlier systems just kinda weak (I'm aiming for GM style A/C
performance!)

Thanks in advance

Paul Tacke
'87 924S
NineinNail@aol.com

Hi all -

The final results are now processed.  Porsche has taken home the honors as
predicted this morning after the Porsche - Corvette/Camaro Challenge this
weekend. 

With contenders in 17 classes, Porsche took home 12 (can you say twelve 
Ken) to Corvette/Camaro's 5 (*only five, what happened Mr. Mitchell?).  
If you go deeper, both sides scored 6 second places and 4 third places.  
Meanwhile Porsches numbers took home another 5 fourths and 2 fifths to 
Corvette/Camaro's 1 and 3 respectively.

If you calculate points based on complete results with first getting 20, 
second getting 16, third getting 13, fourth getting 11 (5th=9, 6th=7, 
7th=5, 8th=3, 9th=2 10th=1) it is Porsche 497 points to Corvette/Camaro's 
293 points.  Trying to help the Corvette/Camaro people out, I tried just 
doing points based on first and second places only.  Still Porsche stays 
way ahead with 336 points to corvette/Camaro's 196 points.  Anyway I cut 
it it comes up with PORSCHE DOMINANCE (sorry Ken, maybe next year..NOT).

Porsche did have a few more cars than the Corvette/Camaro contingent (36
to 20).  Maybe next year we can drag a few more Corvette/Camaro's out to
the event.  Rumor has it that Crown Chevrolet in Dublin is going to
sponsor the site and trophies next year so that should help draw a bigger
Chevy crowd.  Then again, maybe PCNA is interested in getting into the 
action or one of the other local dealerships to match Crown and draw more 
Porsches.  Who knows?  I will be looking forward to it though either way.

ESPL	Teresa Lommatzsch '90 Camaro 1LE	SCCA-SFR 46.104
	Susan Shead	'74 Porsche 914 2.0	PCA-RR	 48.265

EXHIB 	Raymond Robison	'78 Porsche 911SC	PCA-DR	 51.000

After all runs were taken, we had a challenge for all the first place
winners that had stuck around.  A few had already left, but with ten men
and five women, we paired everyone off randomly and each person in the
pair had another run.  Similar to a run-off, the idea was to continue to
run an equal time to your dial-in (your 1st place time).  The person in
each pair with the best difference (quicker time) advanced to the next
round (i.e. if your competitor turned a time faster than his dial-in by .1
and you had a slower time, you were out, but if your time was faster than
your dial-in by .2 then you advanced). This is different than a drag strip
becuase there if you break-out (beat your dial-in time) your out.  But in
this case, if you did better your dial-in time, we multiplied your
difference by 2 and subtracted it from your previous dial-in; thus a new
dial-in much quicker than you had ever run.  This was known ahead of time
so sand bagging was out.  Ladies quickly got down to the final two with
Tricia Braun beating Mary Ann Behrens and Nikki Duncan beating Teresa
Lommatzsch.  Then Tricia did away with Mary Ann for the Ladies Challenge
win.  In the mens class, Richard Antoine, Bob Ikeda, Jay Dugan, Dwight
Mitchell and Mike Lommatzsch won their first rounds.  Out in the first
round were Ken Mitchell, David Blanchard, Mike Joliffe, Ken Yeo and Larry
Sharp.  Then with an odd number of drivers, each took another run and the
top two competited for the challenge.  Dwight Mitchell broke out big with
a half second improvement which didn't help him in the next round.  The
other four driver were within .2 second of each other with Jay Dugan
ending up on top.  Jay then faced Dwight for the Open Challenge final and
even tough Dwight still got within .1 of his new dial-in time Jay took the
win in his 914 1.7 stock car. 

Other awards:
TTOD / TTOD (Corvette)  Ken Yeo    	 40.845 
TTODL			Patti Yeo	 41.952   
TTOD (Porsche)		Mike Lommatzsch  42.697

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 02:36:03 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Jacobs Wires unt uh

Sean

I recommend you stick with the stock wires on you 912.  If they're
in good condition they'll take about as much juice as you care to
pump through them.  I have an Allison electronic ignition conversion
on my 050 with stock wires and have no problem with shorts or
radio interference even at the higher voltage.

If you still insist on aftermarket "super wire" be sure it will accomodate
the original Beru plug boots.  You need to maintain the air seal in the
sheet metal at the plug penetration to keep that cooling air where it
belongs (i.e. cooling the engine, not heating up the engine compartment).
This was a common problem with under-informed VW owners and
I've seen lots of scorched engines because of it.

Additionally, the original boots extend past the sheet metal far enough
so you can actually get a hold on em to remove them.  Trying to remove
a VW type boot that's got a good grip on the plug is cause for some
interesting contortions and lots of fancy language!  (I'll bet you can
figure out how I know this.)

The last time I checked, Stoddards was selling *complete* wire sets
for less than the price of the boots alone.  Go figure.  Whenever I feel
the urge to replace wires, I just cut some new wire, crimp on new
distributor terminal ends, and screw my old boots in the other end.
The boots themselves seldom fail unless they've been seriously
overheated (another reason, if you need one, for the boot seals).
Saves me $$$ and I can customize the length to dress them out more
elegantly.

Is there any particular reason you want to go to different wire?
(cross firing? RFI?)  If you come up with something better, be
sure to let us know.  I'm always willing to experiment (with someone
else's car).


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 95 08:12:00 CDT
From: gregg@cyrix.com (Greg Grohoski)
Subject: '88 51 central locking failure

The central locking system on my '88 951
has stopped working. The red light on the
locking switch below the radio stays lit
and the electric locks don't operate.

The fuse is good.  I don't have access to

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 10:00:43 -0400
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Re: 1983 944 vs. 1995 Mustang (long)

Hunter Heath wrote that he happened to be "hanging" around a Ford dealership
and got a ride/drive that allowed some comparisons with his 944.

>From being in the automobile business in past years (including Utah), I'd
like to put a different "twist" on this drive/ride.  (I sure Hunter wouldn't
do any of this).  I'll term it "Freeloaders and Drugstore Cowboys".

An automobile dealership is in business to make money.  It's generally a
battle to fight overhead and reduce costs in all departments along with
trying to increase or maintain sales.  When someone who has no interest in a
car (other than curosity to see if what R/T, C&D, Autoweek, etc said is
"right") who convinces a friend/acquaintance/salesman to go for a drive to
"see what it'll do", it increases the cost of doing business for everyone.
 Yes, a big part of the business is "qualifying" customers.  But when a
"Drugstore Cowboy/Dale Earnhart/Mario Andretti Imitator" takes a friend out
for a joyride, that car is still for sale to some "less than lucky???" buyer.
 When a salesman comes in and says "You know the Blue GT (or Cobra, or 968,
or C-36, or Z-28) we got in last week?  It's got the right front alloy wheel
and apron bent!  How did that happen?

Who pays?  Not the factory...the dealer to start with, a "good" salesman with
wife and kids who loses a sale on a particular car,  and ultimately (if the
damage is not "apparent" immediately) some unlucky customer.  The cost of
business goes up and you all pay when you buy your next (whatever).  Would
you want your new Silver C4to have been run that way?  The reaction to this
can get ridiculous (locking the doors in the showroom or requiring a "test
drive deposit" before you can even drive one).

Rarely happens you say!!  I still remember the call when I was in New Mexico
"...your F150 broke down on me"  (6 hours after the "test drive" round the
block).  The wrecker found it on the highway from El Paso (had been to
Juarez) with a 6000 load of cider blocks in the back and a broken axle!

Again, I'm not inferring Hunter or anyone else on this list would "abuse" a
vehicle during a non-interested test drive, nor do I believe you should buy a
car (or any product) without trying it out.  Flame away to your hearts
content!

Perry

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 10:34:02 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Pesky varmints/How could I?

    Reminds me of something that happened to me a couple of years
ago.... My dad has this old Chevy pickup truck that we kinda fixed up
and made it go faster....  It had a lot of rust, though, and it took us
about a year to get it all back together and driveable again.  The very
first time we took it out for a spin, we were happily whizzing (OK,
actually kind of a dull roar) down the road, when a little mouse pokes
his head above the hood (there's about a 1" gap between the hood and the
windshield...  kinda like older cars with hidden wipers.  But it doesn't
have hidden wipers.  Don't ask me why.)  Aforementioned mouse
immediately is slammed up against the winshield by 60 MPH breeze, holds
onto windshield wiper, shakes furry little head in puzzlement, and is
immediately whisked off to oblivion.  Repeat about three or four times.
    I'd like to think the little buggers actually survived their short
careers as the world's first flying mice, 'cause they were actually
kinda cute.  Just don't try to live in my p-car....

later,

Nate

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 09:51:07 -0500
From: Brian Scudder <bscudder@spdmail.spd.dsccc.com>
Subject: Battery tray cleaning

What's the best way to clean the battery tray from acid and rust and to
prevent the rust from returning?

I bought a can of h2so4 battery cleaner and tried it on the hold down
clamp last night. It sprays on as a yellow foam and turns pink when it
neutralizes any acid. Then you wash it off with water and repeat until
the spray does not turn pink.

I was planning on using this to clean the tray, use a wire brush to
knock any loose debris off, then use some kind of rust inhibitor paint.

TIA
Brian Scudder
'83 928S
'70 old bue truck
'93 Redi (the Cat)

Date:     Tue, 11 Jul 95 11:11:47 EDT
From: "Hugh A. Huntzinger" (CCAC) <huntzing@PICA.ARMY.MIL>
Subject:  Re: 1983 944 vs. 1995 Mustang

A minor counterpoint for Perry:

Surveys of customers have shown that most buyers test-drive ONLY the model
they end up buying.  I've done this myself.

I've been forcing myself to go into dealerships and test-drive various
makes and models (see my note on the "Wisdom on 2nd car" thread).  I've
found that an actual drive has been VERY revealing and truely the only
way to really comparison shop for a car.

For example, one model that I've had several friend recommend to me
(including my wife), it looked promising but I found I absolutely HATED
it on the road compared to others I've tried.  I've also found that the
brand I _thought_ I was going to buy is no longer even in the running.  


What seems to be working is that I'll drive "promsing" cars to determine
if its worth investigating further as a serious "short list" contender.
The final short list gets a 2nd test drive that will be more focused on
observed differences between models and so forth...preferably all the
competitors on the same day, same road.

BUT...

I know these test drives cost the dealership money and I don't like to
test drive ANY car unless I'm "really serious" about buying, but I'm not
going to comprimise the road tests I do because I feel guilty about it.
Afterall, that's what we DID do in the past (and bought a Ford ;-).

While I think you'll agree that I'm not joyriding in this circumstance,
what I've found that I don't like that the business of "qualifying"
customers FORCES both me and the salesmen to invest more time than's
otherwise necessary for what could be a quick dealership visit by an
informed and serious customer doing research.  If you have any suggestions
on how I can streamline this part of the process, I'd appreciate it.

 -hh

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 95 07:56:00 ADT
From: "Southard, Keith" <KSOUTHAR@atu.com>
Subject: Reply Battery Tray Cleaning


Brian Scudder Wrote:

>What's the best way to clean the battery tray from acid and rust and to
>prevent the rust from returning?

I have been using plain old baking soda for years. It is cheap and has
been THE solution for neutralizing acid.  Simply spray the area to
be cleaned with water and sprinkle baking soda liberally on the area.
I let it sit for half an hour or so and then rinse with a heavy stream of
clear water. Let it dry, wire brush to remove loose rust. Once dry
apply a good rust inhibitor paint. Then buy a good quality SEALED
battery. I repeat the cleaning process each fall as part of the
pre-winter prep work. Have NEVER had to repaint the battery tray a
second time.



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 95 08:02:00 ADT
From: "Southard, Keith" <KSOUTHAR@atu.com>

>A minor counterpoint for Perry:

>Surveys of customers have shown that most buyers test-drive ONLY the model

Before you lay down your big bucks for that new car, instead of just taking 
the car
for a short test drive, find a car rental agency that rents the one that you 
are
considering and rent it for the weekend. Can be somewhat expensive but you
will get the chance to run the car hard and really get a sense of what the 
car
is like. This has changed my mind a couple of times on decisions to purchase
a particular piece of Detroit Tin.

KSouthard@atu.com

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 12:04:56 -0600 (CST)
From: "thak chaloemtiarana" <tc17@cornell.edu>
Subject: 914 competition

The first thing you do is to figure out "how competitive do I want to be?"
and secondly "which playground do I want to play in?"

If the object is to improve the car's performance to its highest potential,
then money's is the limit.  If the point is to see if you can get better
(slowly), then invest in seat time and incremental changes.  If you are the
competitive type and want to win trophies, then buy the rule book for SCCA
or PCA and stay within those rules.  I do know that the 914 is very
competitive in the stock classes (C stock and D stock).  Several national
champions have come from the rank of 914 drivers.  Once you go up to Street
Prepared class, the car is not competitive, and I am aware of few Prepared
cars that have been successful.  So if you want to play in SCCA, get a rule
book and stick to the stock class.  Spend money on tires and suspension
components.

PCA is a different matter.  Some regions are less strict and group cars by
models (all 914's run together for trophy, or all air cooled cars run
together).  Parade rules govern national or Zone competition.  The good
thing is that you will be running against similar cars (not against Honda
Civics and Mazda RX 7's as in SCCA).  The trick is don't make minor
modifications which will bump you up a class, but if you want to play in a
higher class, do all the modifications allowed.

Personally, I would take the go slow method.  That way, what you learn will
be learned well and your driving skill will develop with the improvement in
the car.  If you do everything at once, you may soon want to move on to
another car, and another, and another. . .

If you'd like to know what I did over the years with my 914, send me a note.
To do everything at once will probably cost you more than what you have in
the car.  Racing is expensive and it costs several hundreds of dollars to go
a few seconds faster once the basic improvements are done.
Thak Chaloemtiarana                              EMail:TC17@cornell.edu



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 09:04:39 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: 88 911 ClubSport for Sale

>>> '88 911 CLUBSPORT  Only 1 of 26 made.  Only 1800 miles.
>>
>>Only 26? I'm shocked. I figured at least 200 had to be out there...
>>
>>> My question:  What is it ? and why only 26 made ?
>>> If anyone wants more info - I'll call the dealership.
>>
>>It's a stipped-down semi-lightweight semi-competition model. Sort of
>>like the RS America, only less so. Or more so. You know what I mean...
>
>I don't have the production figures at hand, but definetly more than 26 CS's
>were made. Perhaps only 26 got imported to the US?
>
>It was a '88 version of the '72-'73 Carrera RS, even got the same paintjob.
>
>
>Trond V.

Trond,

The car was NOT an '88 version of the '73 Carrera RS. It weighed 2700 lbs.,
had the same horsepower rating as a standard '88 Carrera (it did rev a
little bit higher because the valves were lighter), and it had its own
unique paint job. Actually, it had a regular paint job with special decals
on the front left fender (I think it was left) and the rear deck lid. The
car was NOT special in any way except in the limited number.


Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)



------------------------------

Date: 11 Jul 1995 11:49:40 -0400
From: william.anders@smc.com
Subject: 911 exhaust options

  >Anyone have experience with aftermarket performance mufflers? Do you
  really
  >get any more HP? I already have the old style exhaust system, and I am
  >wondering if it behooves me to put something like a Bursch muffler on
  it???

  Theoretically, less back pressure should produce more HP at least at high
  RPM.  However, the beautiful stainless steel Monte muffler I purchased
  for my '73 911S gave me a BIG flat spot between 3500-4500 RPM, it now
  resides in a corner of my garage & soon to be mounted over my mantle.  I
  am currently running a stock muffler that has been "opened up" by
  removing about 50% of the internal baffles.  It's louder (though not
  nearly as loud as a Sport muffler) & with the air cleaner removed I have
  a "seat of the pants" indication of more power.

  The old style heat exhangers (or SSIs) with a stock muffler perform
  pretty darn good on a stock motor, so BEWARE of HP claims with fancy
  mufflers, I learned the hard way.

  Bill (Otto Krossit) Anders
  P.S.  The Monte is FOR SALE!

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 13:12:19 -0400
From: Ronskian@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 Heel and Toe

I too was having problems heel and toeing.  I had my belts done on the 944
and asked the proprieter about my problem reaching the gas pedal.

His name is Leighton Reese, and is an awesome roadracer.  Runs select ASA
events, came in second three times in a row at Brainerd.  Went to
ELF-Winfield school in France some years back and cleaned up.  Runs a very
nice garage now.

Anyways, he says, "How much did you spend?" I said, "200 bucks."  He
says,"That's enough."  He was in the middle of building the ASA racer in the
garage.  He grabs a scrap piece of sheet alluminum, cuts it to about 3.0" X
5.0", drills three holes in it evenly spaced along the right side, drills
corresponding holes along the left side of the gas pedal, and rivets the
piece to the pedal.

Now I heel and toe at every corner I come to!.  I find it difficult to drive
anything with standard shift w/out heel and toeing.

Ron Boltik
87 944

From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Product Announcement!


		     For IMMEDIATE Release:

                  Cash-Generating-Devices, Inc. 
	            in a new partnership with
			Microsoft, Inc.

	           ANNOUNCES RELEASE OF THE

               Sparko-Turbo-Distributor-Driveshaft
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Cash-Generating-Devices, a Seattle-based automotive research and development
has partnered with Microsoft, Inc. to produce the ultimate in distributor 
drive shaft technology.

In their unprecendented forray into the aftermarket auto parts industry, 
Microsoft chairman William Gates has stated:

"I **LOVE** this new product.  It's the perfect new direction for Microsoft.
As many know, I own many performance automobiles, and using our new Sparko-
Turbo shaft in my 959 has put the "P" back in performance!  I really noticed
the difference during my monthly laps around the inside of the warehouse!"

Microsoft plans on providing windows-based software to electronically 
calibrate and configure their new distributor driveshaft in future releases. 
The software may even be bundled with upcoming releases of Windows95.

Cash-Generating-Devices spent 3 years and 3 million dollars to develop the
ultimate distributor driveshaft.  Their patented, hydraulic design compensates 
for driveshaft wear thereby eliminating dwell-angle variance in conventional 
point-type ignition systems.  CGD claims, "It's the only distributor 
driveshaft you'll ever need!"

Independant labratory testing has shown an average 33% increase in overall
horsepower output when used with a Bosch 009 distributor.  Torque and
gas mileage have also been shown to be significantly improved.  CGD also
states that when used in conjunction with "Splitfire" sparkplus and their
special plug wires that a 50% increase in horsepower can be obtained!

Bosch, a German-based automobile parts manufacturer, refused to comment.

The Sparko-Turbo-Distributor-Driveshaft is initially offered at the MSRP
of $99.95.  A peak-performance version, which includes the aforementioned
"Splitfire" plugs and CGD's special plug wires is also available for $149.00.

CGD can be reached at (800) 555 2200.

> the beautiful stainless steel Monte muffler I purchased
> for my '73 911S gave me a BIG flat spot between 3500-4500 RPM, it now
> resides in a corner of my garage & soon to be mounted over my mantle.


I had the same experience in my '73 911S. When I bought the car last 
August it had a Bursch muffler that caused a hesitation of some sort 
between 3000-4000 rpm. After several seconds, it seemed as if the engine 
overcame the backpressure and then rocketed towards the redline. I was 
lucky in that I was able to find a used factory muffler locally, in very 
good shape I might add. It made a tremdous difference- no more flat spot.
YMMV- it seems as if the early engines are very tempermental to exhaust 
changes. I should also add that I unfortunately have carbs.

P.S. I have a Bursch muffler for sale if anybody wants to give a try. 
Maybe it will work on a 911t since the engine places less demand on the 
whole system or something like that.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa
new e-mail address nkumpe01@fiu.edu

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 13:56:06 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Autocross information - part6 : Tires

Hi,

I have been asked to submit my columns on autocrossing Porsches
to the archives. Here is the sixth of nine(?) columns. Please let
me know if there are any mistakes or omissions, or other questions
that I should answer. I am editing and submitting them one at a time,
and will upload the whole thing after final editing.

There have been several requests for permission to use this material
in PCA newsletters, etc. Please ask before using it, but basically
any PCA use will be granted if the author is noted. If not too
difficult, I would like a copy of the publication with my material.

	Three-Wheeling by Mike Piera Part 6 of ?

	Setting up a Porsche for stock class autocrossing : Tires

	Of all the modifications that can be made to make a killer
stock class autocrosser, tires give the greatest improvement over
factory equipment. Street tires are designed with tread life
as one of the top priorities, whereas autocross tires are
designed strictly for performance. There are only a few special
purpose street-legal autocross tires on the market : BFG Comp TA R-1,
Yokohama A008 RS-II, and Hoosier Autocrosser. Nearly all serious
autocrossers use one of these tires. There are a few newcomers who
make very soft performance tires such as Toyo which may be 
competitive. Goodyear and Bridgestone make good tires for road
racing, but they do not currently have autocross-specific tires. 

	In '94 the BFG tire was available in two versions, 
Competition (230) and autocrossing (226) but the 226 was discontinued
in '95 as the 230 seemed fast enough. The 230 was designed mostly for
road racing, but is also good for autocrossing, especially long 
courses or pro-solos where your tires get warm. The Yokohama is also
available in a road racing version (RS) and autocross (RS-II). Even
the Hoosier has a road-racing version, called the Street TD. The
difference between the two versions of these three brands is
basically the tread compound. The autocross version is generally
softer and designed to work best at lower temperatures (there is no
warm-up lap in autocrossing). The tradeoff of the autocross tires'
great performance is that they wear out much faster. For occasional
autocrossers, or those who also want to use their competition tires
on the track, the road racing compound can be used for autocrossing. 
These include the Goodyear, Bridgestone, Toyo, and Hoosier street TD.
The road racing tire will be slightly slower on most autocross courses.
In 1995, the BFG 230 "competition" tire is still winning most classes
in the big events, so may be the best compromize.

	The Hoosier is in a class by itself because it is a bias-ply
tire, not a radial. The handling characteristics are quite different,
and the Hoosier was not legal in SCCA stock classes even though it
was "street-legal", until 1995. In general terms, the Hoosier is not
as quick to respond to driver input, but will not lose traction as 
quickly as the radials. The bias ply tires work with a greater slip
angle than the radials. This means you must drive with more effort,
and allow the car to slide more than on radials. You can drive as
much with your feet as with your hands. This suits some driving styles
better than others. Tire pressures are low and tire roll-over is
greater than radials. Hoosiers are generally better suited to cars 
with a higher level of modification than a stock class car. These
tires can be faster than radials, but they are an aquired taste. If
you are serious, try a set and see for yourself. Hoosier is also
making a radial street-legal autocross tire, but it probably will
not be legal until 1996. This tire has a super-aggressive tread
pattern, almost a slick! There are only one or two grooves.

	The BFG R1 has a very stiff inner sidewall and a tread 
pattern similar in concept to the Yokohama, with an outer tread
area which will become a slick after use or shaving. The outside edge
is very square, but does not roll over even at very low pressures.
These tires work well at lower pressures than previous autocross
tires. Try pressures in the low 30's or even lower. Pressures are a
personal choice depending on your car setup and driving style, there	
is really no "ideal" pressure. A higher pressure will give quicker
response, but a lower pressure may give more cornering speed
in a constant corner. For the truly serious competitor who
needs immediate performance, tires should be shaved on a tire
shaving machine. New full-tread autocross tires handle poorly until
they are worn in. The Hoosiers are an exception and work well
after a few "scrub-in" runs. The BFG may actually last longer if
shaved due to less "scalloping" of the outer area, and less uneven
wear to the middle block, which causes the tread groove to wear to
the cord while the rest of the tire is still fine. The 230 is
better than the 226 in this respect (maybe why the 226 was dropped).
This is known as the "groove of doom" in the autocross community.

	After selecting a tire, the size must be chosen. Basically you
want the lowest profile tire in the widest size that will fit on your
rim properly. Also consider the rules, as PCA parade rules have silly
minimum circumference rules. I was able to get around the PCA rules
and still run a 50 series tire by squeezing a 225/50/15 on my 6"
rims in '91 (not recommended, but it worked!). For '94 I got a set
of 7" rims for the 225/50/15. This was legal, while my normal
205/50/15 on 6" rims were not. A standard 911/944 7" rim will fit on 
the front of most 911's, but a pre-78 911 may need the 911R offset to 
fit 7" rims on the rear. Revolution makes a wheel for this application. 

	Before spending lots of money on new tires, make sure you have
the widest rim that is legal for the class you are running. 
Also a smaller diameter rim is better because it will effectively
change your final drive ratio and lower the car if a smaller diameter
tire can be used. For example, several Porsche models such as the 911 SC,
Carrera, and 944 can choose between 15" and 16" rims. The 15" rim with 
50 series tires would be the best choice unless the width is less. A 
911 Carrera with 7" and 8" wide 15" wheels with 50 series tires should
be faster than 16" tires of the same width in an autocross.

	Here are some common Porsche rim sizes and tires. For the 914,
the 5 1/2" x 15" forged Fuchs alloy is best, with 195 or 205/50/15
tires. The 195 will really help acceleration and lower the car,
although the 205 has been more popular. Even with my heavier and
much more powerful 911S on 6" wide rims, I had one of my best events
ever on 195/50/15 Yokohamas, giving Roger Johnson's Corvette one of
his few losses at a Pro-Solo. For the early 911 or other Porsches
with 6" x 15" rims, the 205/50/15 is probably best. This tire will
also work very well on a 7" wide rim if a 225/50/15 tire will not
fit under the car's fenders (an early 911 with 7" wide rear rims).
The 225/50 fits well on 7" and 8" rims. But on a powerful 911, 
245/50/15 tires will work great on the 8" rears. These recommendations
generally apply to 16" rims also, but 45 series tires are available 
which are even better. In 17 inch rims, the new BFG 235/40/17 is
great for the narrow 7" fronts on late model 911s. The tire 
companies have "recommended rim widths" for their tires which will 
also help, and they can tell you what sizes successful 
autocrossers are currently using. The BFG tires seem to work OK
on narrower rims than you would think, so if you are stuck with 
narrow rims they may help.
	
	The Yokohama tires can be ordered from most tire dealers. Call
Kevin Rogers at Yokohama in California at (800) 423-4544 X-3862 for
technical questions. BFG tires are ordered direct from Team T/A,
although there are a few "team T/A" dealers who can get them for you.
Call (800) RACE BFG to join team TA. You will get their informative
newsletter and can find out how to order tires.

More to come!

Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com
'72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0 (last two for sale soon)
