Porschephiles #1546                         Tue Jul 11 16:12:41 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 10:50:55 -0700
From: Ken Mitchell  <KMITCHELL@CHP.CA.GOV>
Subject:  Porsche Wins Corvette/Camaro Challenge

Well I was hoping for more of our hotshoes would have come out
such as Ruby Ruperto (CP), Ron Green (CP), Bill Herron (ESP), Don
McKenna (SS), Jim Martin (SS), Manny Pretty (BSP), Ed Rainey
(BSP), Don Mc Williams (BSP), Brett Egen (BSP), Brian & Steve
Hobaugh (BSP), and Ren Marinus (SS). 

Also, I was looking forward to see some of the PCA-Zone 7
hotshoes make the event such as LLoyd & Patti De Martini, Tom &
Sandi Provasi, Terry Zacconi, Greg Peart, Larry Wilson, Ray
Scruggs, The Neidels, Ed & Marsha Wilson, Steve Nieslony (sp),
and Bill & Rebecca Newlin.

Maybe next time both teams can do a better job in promoting the
event. Its possible that some of the Team Chevrolet drivers
didn't come out because they figured that the course would be a
small tight course. Hopefully, once the word gets around that Bud
Behrens, Team Porsche, designed a bitch'n course maybe next time
they'll come out. (Mary-Anne Behrens, Team Porsche, will think
she's died and gone to heaven with all the V8's roaring.)

Porsche Dominance - In my opinion, was done by the numbers of
Porsche entrants vs. the number of Chevrolet entrants. The
structuring of the classes is probably the best it can be to make
it competitive. However, I think Scott Winder's car is prepared
like an ASP car just as Dwight's is. I'm not sniveling, just
pointing out that if its a true ASP car it should not have run
against the stock Corvettes. Maybe Scott classed his car wrong.

I really feel that the objective of this event, having lots of
fun, was definitely met. We need to do this again and since Team
Porsche did buy the beer I'm sure that Team Chevrolet will be
reciprocal and bring the beer next time.

Lets Race and have fun!!!!!

Ken "I'll learn one of these days not to hit Kones" Mitchell
nokones@ix.netcom.com

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 14:14:18 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 88 911 ClubSport for Sale

>> '88 911 CLUBSPORT  Only 1 of 26 made.  Only 1800 miles.
>
>Only 26? I'm shocked. I figured at least 200 had to be out there...

It may well be that 200 or so were made and only 26 got sold.  The thing
stiffed absolutely in the market.  Basically what Porsche did was a minor
decontent of their regular street car, slap a decal on the fender, and
bump the price.  To quote my daughter, Doi!

So they licked their wounds, went away, and a few years later came back
(to the US market) with the RS America.  And got it right.

Personally, I wouldn't touch the '88 with a ten meter pole, esp. one
which hasn't been driven and which is being offered at a premium.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 14:16:00 -0400
From: Tommywar@aol.com
Subject: 928 Shocks - Konis or Bilsteins?

I have an 82 928 which needs new shocks.  I have the original Boges on it,
but they are tired shocks.  I know about the different hardware to adapt
Bilsteins to Boge struts.  I have heard that Bilsteins require a change in
springs because the shock makes the car ride around 1 to 1.5 inches higher
than normal.  I also know that the Konis on their softest setting are a
little stiffer than the Boges.  If you have changed shocks to either
Bilsteins or Konis,  please let me know of your results.

Thank you,
Tom Warren

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 14:20:26 -0400
From: Tommywar@aol.com
Subject: 928 Speedo Swapout

My '82 928 has the 85MPH speedometer.  Boy, what a great idea that was!  Upon
looking through the latest Panorama,  I saw Imparts is having a clearance on
170MPH speedometers.  Does anyone know if the 170MPH speedometer simply plugs
in with no modifications.  I know the speedometer is electronic so it seems
like no recalibration would be necessary.

Thanks,

Tom Warren

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 13:21:24 -0500
From: jrg@tyrell.net (James Gallagher/Nicole Belden)
Subject: 911 steering rack for sale

I have a steering rack for sale if anyone is interested.  I had a catch in
my steering and my mechanic told me that it was probably the rack.  I got a
used one from Oklahoma Foreign Porsche (is that what it's called?) and it
turned out to only be a catch in the column lock.  Anyway...I have the rack
and I don't need it.  I think it's from an 85 or 86...not sure.  It's
supposed to fit all 911's (non turbo) from 1965-1989...I'm not totally sure
but the racks for sale in my Automotion catalog say that they have one part
for those years so I assume that it'll work.  It also has the same part
number for a 914 from 1970-1976 so I guess it would work for 914's too.
Drop me a line if you're interested.

- ----------------------------------------
1977 911S Targs

No...it's NOT as bad as everyone says...
It's STILL a Porsche afterall.

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 15:04:42
From: DENNIS DEEDS <5010.4218@trader.com>
Subject: RE: 914 Reunion

In response to Tim Radsicks evaluation of the 10th 914 Reunion, there is 
another side of the story.  Tim did not pre-register for the Reunion, and 
dropped in Saturday morning to see the car show.  He had missed the Friday 
night activities by then.  In the afternoon, following the car show, he 
came to the hotel and said he would like to register prior to leaving.  I 
want to make it clear that he was not asked to register and did not have 
to if he only came to see the cars.  After paying his fees, he received an 
embroidered 914 hat, an event pin, an event t-shirt, and an information 
pack - I dont think he mentioned those items when he talked about cost.  
He told me that he had a great time and enjoyed seeing the cars - are you 
listening Tim?  I asssumed he liked modified cars as he told me about a 
center speaker he installed on his car and that he would send details for 
a future newsletter.  At no time did he mention that he was anything but 
pleased about his visit.  By leaving Saturday afternoon, he missed the 
awards dinner on Saturday and the Sunday Tech Session and social event.  I 
was further surprised to see a response to the Radsick e-mail from Tim 
Jones who asked who would want to go to Palm Springs?  Tim, Association 
members from CA, NV, AZ, TN, OK, and Germany attended.  Furthermore, 
almost 1000 members of the National Council of Corvette Clubs were holding 
their national meet at the same hotel - but for 8 days - and sharing the 
parking lot with us.  Some of their cars are 15 years older than ours and 
also dont have a/c.  I can only assume that the *real* reason Tim Jones 
did not attend was that he is *not* an Association member according to our 
current membership listing.  Gentlemen, in the future, please bring your 
complaints and innuendoes to me directly.  I really do like to hear what 
people have to say, but realize that I cant make everybody happy all the 
time.  The only thread of truth in the previous messages was that Mike 
Willis was a real plus to the 3 days of events and I want to thank him for 
his insights and help.                                                     
                                                                           
Dennis Deeds 914 Owners Association & 914-6 Club USA                       
5010.4218@trader.com
 

------------------------------

Date:          Tue, 11 Jul 1995 15:46:59 EDT
From: "Asad Husain" <AHUSAIN@schmed01.ab.umd.edu>
Subject:       Re: 1983 944 vs. 1995 Mustang

Again,  No flame here.  But on the flip side, a part of the 
salesman's job is to sell.  How else can that be done unless someone 
drops by and tries a car out.  It's up to the salesman to convince 
any potential buyer that what is being sold is better than what 
the prospective buyer currently has or is comparing with.  Even if 
the looker is not really interested in purchasing the car at the 
time, who knows.  Minds do change.  If the Mustang really was better, 
maybe Hunter would cancel the order on his Bimmer.

Before taking someone out for a ride, the salesman should ask 
questions like "what monthly payments are you looking for?"  Simple 
questions can tell you a lot about a buyer.  I think Hunter did the 
right thing.  If he can't test out other cars, how can he decide 
what he likes.  I'm sure his "hanging around" terminology is just an 
idiom.  No one just happens to hang around dealerships unless they 
are at least a little interested.

> Again, I'm not inferring Hunter or anyone else on this list would "abuse" a
> vehicle during a non-interested test drive, nor do I believe you should buy 
> a
> car (or any product) without trying it out.  Flame away to your hearts
> content!
> 
 



**********************************************************************
Asad Husain, Director Technical Services     Phone: (410)706-3971
School of Medicine                           Fax  : (410)706-2043
University of Maryland at Baltimore
655 W. Baltimore Street 
Baltimore, MD 21201

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 95 12:24:19 mst
From: "Matt Dilligan" <MADILLI@sahp396.sandia.gov>
Subject: 914 hot start trouble

    Recently my 914 mas refused to start after a relatively short stop. At first 
I thought it was vapor lock, as it was maybe a little warmer that day than 
usual, but I'm not so sure, as it's also happened when it was relatively cool 
and the engine wasn't really even warm.
    When it happens the car will initially fire (residual fuel from the previous 
running?) and then just not even hint at firing. Once (after leaving it like 4 
hours) it started after prolonged cranking, but the other times (when I've left 
it overnight) it starts up immediately. Flooding?
    Once it's started it runs exactly as it always did (pretty good, with a 
slight hesitation off idle). The vehicle recently had it's entire fuel injection 
system checked out and the head temp sensor and f.i. points being replaced.
    It's a 1970 (1.7), btw.
    Please reply to this adress as I'm not on the list. Thanks

Matt

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 13:18:46 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <tjones@estinc.com>
Subject: RE: 914 Reunion

Dennis,

In reference to your reply to my comments about the 914 Reunion, I NEVER 
said anything like "Who would want to go to Palm Springs."  I said that 
under the conditions of driving my stock 914 through THAT particular 
stretch of I-10/110, I'd rather it be held in the Fall when the weather 
is more conducive to travel in said vehicle.  I do the Phoenix to Indio 
run quite regularly in our Jetta and was there last weekend for a wedding 
(so I couldn't break away for the reunion).  My point was simply that 
there may have been MORE attendees if the desert heat wasn't so extreme.

Believe me, no-one on this list is more appreciative of anything that you 
do to help promote the life of the 914 and its owner.  In fact, until my 
brother-in-law's wedding came up, I was hoping to get to come to the 
reunion, even if only as a spectator.

As far as Palm Springs is concerned, the entire area is beautiful.  The
wind farms out at the 110/I-10 interchange are a marvel.  The golfing is
great (the empty store fronts are starting to become a concern, though). 
But, it's just too hot for me and my yellow baby to make the run at this 
time of year.

No offence was intended (thus the <bg> <- that means BIG GRIN) after my 
comment about favorite things.  I am sorry that you felt that I was 
putting bad comments out about your event.

- ---
Tim Jones				tjones@estinc.com
Director of Development			Visit our Tape web page:
Enhanced Software Technologies, Inc.	http://www.estinc.com/

Subject: Re: 944 series Oil change Questions

> 	It's a bouncing baby 87  944 Turbo  (wooooo hoooo!!!)

> every 2,000 miles)  $13,800 - I am happy

> go back to "normal" oil (as the oil thread seemed to point towards several
> weeks ago).

weather/temperature conditions.

In my 86 951, for highway miles in 'clean' air, I usually drive 6000 mi
between oil changes.  With an extra FILTER change at 3000mi

The oil stays nice and clean at the end!!

That engine is DAMN tight at the piston/cylindar walls!!

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 13:28:22 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Porsche Wins Corvette/Camaro Challenge

>Porsche Dominance - In my opinion, was done by the numbers of
>Porsche entrants vs. the number of Chevrolet entrants. The
>structuring of the classes is probably the best it can be to make
>it competitive. However, I think Scott Winder's car is prepared
>like an ASP car just as Dwight's is. I'm not sniveling, just
>pointing out that if its a true ASP car it should not have run
>against the stock Corvettes. Maybe Scott classed his car wrong.
>
>I really feel that the objective of this event, having lots of
>fun, was definitely met. We need to do this again and since Team
>Porsche did buy the beer I'm sure that Team Chevrolet will be
>reciprocal and bring the beer next time.
>
>Lets Race and have fun!!!!!


Ken,

Yes, the event was a lot of fun and I had a great time meeting all
of the Corvette people. We all truly love our cars and love auto-
crossing!! It was great to have so many enthusiasts in one place!

Now, to the point of whether or not my car is an ASP car. When was
the last time you saw a 2900 pound 911 Targa (not a very stiff car)
with a stock 3.2 liter engine (exhaust is modified) running in ASP?
Dwight Mitchell's car weighs about 700 pounds less and has at least
as much horsepower as my car. I am sure he has modified his car in
every that is beneficial and the rules allow. I have no idea what
ASP rules allow. I suspect I've done things to my car that are not
allowed in ASP and I know I have not done all the things the rules
do allow.

And what do you mean by "stock" Corvettes? What does SS1 allow? I
can tell you that the SS1 Corvettes did not run like any stock
Corvette I have ever seen. They had a bunch more ponies than stock
and I am sure the suspension has been played with based on the
handling I saw.

Anyway, I finished 2nd in SS1 and would have finished 2nd in ASP to
Dwight Mitchell, so it had no effect on the outcome whatsoever.

No sniveling here either, just wanted to clarify...

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 15:47:20 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: ABS on a 911


>When was the first year ABS was available on the 911?

I believe '89 was the first year it was offered on 911s.  The
Carrera 2 and 4 have it, but the Carrera ('84-'89?) doesn't.

>When was the first year Porsche offered ABS on any of their
>cars?

It was offered as an option for 944s in '87, and became standard on
the turbo in '88.  I'm not sure when it was available on the 928.

Ross
'87 951

Porschephiles #1547                         Tue Jul 11 22:41:08 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 11 Jul 95 13:57:58 TZ
From: Marc Olson <marco@microsoft.com>
Subject: Wiper parking and alignment

Though I rarely drive my 911 in the rain, I've been working on and off 
for the past year to get the 'park' feature on my wipers to work.  My 
first attempt was replacing the wiper motor, which involved removing 
the entire ventilation system from the trunk.  No go.  Next attempt was 
done after a tip I got from someone on p'philes about the wiper 
switch--the clue was pushing the stem of the switch forward, which 
caused the wipers to park.  I took the switch out and was able to patch 
a piece of plastic that had worn over the years, preventing the idle 
circuit from engaging.

Much to my dismay, once the park circuit was working, it appears that 
the position of the wipers relative to the wiper motor is off, so that 
the wipers park about 6" from the bottom of the windshield.  Not quite 
totally obscuring my vision, but close.

Sooo, the question is--how to I get the right alignment between the 
wiper control arms and the motor.  Since the motor is now in its 'park' 
position, changing the location of the wiper arm attachment to the 
motor should allow the wipers to have their full range but park in a 
reasonable location.  As it stands, if I change the position of the 
wiper blades, I end up removing water from the hood of the car, as the 
wiper circuit goes too far down on the windshield.

The Haynes manual is useless in this regard, so any hints would be appreciated.

Marc Olson
marco@microsoft.com
'78 911 SC Targa

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 17:23:01 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: ABS on a 911

First year for ABS was 1987. I ordered it on my factory ordered 1987 944S.
Turned out to be about a $2000 option. The dealer didn't know the price when
we ordered the car and he through it would be about $1000. He ended up
splitting the difference. I had the first 944S in the Northeast, or maybe I
didn't but that is what I was told. 
The happiest day in my life was the one when I took delivery of that car. The
second happiest was when I finally sold it after suffering with it for 3
years. Or maybe I have that backwards. That was undoutably the worst Porsche
product that ever set forth in America.( can anyone think of another?) I know
I was in trouble when the steering rack puked all it's fluid on the way home
from the dealer.
 I certainly hope that others had much better luck with their 16 valve
numbers than I did. The only thing that always worked were the ABS brakes!

Regards,
Jerry

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 95 17:07:30 EDT
From: "John Hora" <jhora@VNET.IBM.COM>
Subject: 914 FI Wiring

Dave Darling wrote.....

       "Oops.  I think I may have done some mis-labeling when I took"
Dave..the 1/92 Pano page 51 has the D-Jetronic wiring harness....it
shows that the Green/Red goes to the Oil Pressure Sender...
The White wire in the same bundle goes to the Aux Air Valve....
Both of these wires are in the bundle that goes to the 12 pin
connector on the Regulator Plate (relay board drivers side engine)
There is another White wire nearby that comes out of the wiring harness
that connects to the square 4 pin connector on the Regulator Plate
next to the 12 pin ...this White wire goes to the Thermoswitch for
cold start valve...I check this on the color wiring diagram and it
looks correct....
John Hora

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 16:05:19 -0500 (CDT)
From: THOXNER@ualr.edu
Subject: Does Scott's Car Belong in ASP?

I do not know what rules you were using in this event, but if you were using
SCCA Solo II rules, then Scott's car is definitly in ASP. It doesn't make
any difference if the 3.2 liter engine is stock (or has had intake mods). The
3.2 did not come in your 78 911. There may be sets of rules that allow engine
swaps in stock classes, but SCCA rules do not. BTW, I have a 72 911 with a
3.2 liter that is bone stock (including Motronic). It is pretty competitive
in local and region events. I am a medicore driver at best. The Porsche/
Corvette challenge sounds like a lot of fun. It would be a pretty long drive
from Arkansas :).
Tom Oxner
85 911
72 911
61 356B

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 15:51:12 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: Porsche Wins Corvette/Camaro Challenge

Gee guys -

I have heard more talk about this event after it was over with then 
before it happened.  Why couldn't we have had this friendly discussion 
before and maybe raise the interest level up a few more notches leading to 
better participation.

By the way, I have done some simple PAX (don't ask me what it stands for, 
I'm not sure; it suppose to equal the cars out based on previous National 
SCCA caliber events) computations that when I have time to type them up 
will post to all.  I have taken the liberty to class everyone by the 
appropriate SCCA classes since the PAX is based on them.  Of course, this 
puts numerous 911's and 914's into Dwights class (ASP).  And the cars 
that I have put there are based on my knowledge of the car and its 
respective PCA-GGR class allowances.  Sorry, there are no PCA PAX figures 
available and then what would we do with them funny plastic cars and the 
f-body wannabees :-).

Maybe we can get this going again next about this time and it will drum 
up some more participation for both types of cars.  Maybe we should let 
the FORDS join the CHEVYS to help them out ;-).

mike lommatzsch

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 18:09:50 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: 911 Club Sport

>The car was NOT an '88 version of the '73 Carrera RS. It weighed 2700 lbs.,
>had the same horsepower rating as a standard '88 Carrera (it did rev a
>little bit higher because the valves were lighter), and it had its own
>unique paint job. Actually, it had a regular paint job with special decals
>on the front left fender (I think it was left) and the rear deck lid. The
>car was NOT special in any way except in the limited number.

To add to what Scott has written, there is an article on the Club Sports
in the October '88 issue of Excellence.

Here's a few specs:

Price as tested:  $46643
Horsepower:  214
Torque :  195 lb-ft
Curb Weight :  2600 lbs
0-60 :  5.7 sec.
1/4 mile :  14.3 sec @ 99 mph

The "Club Sport" decal was on the left front fender, BTW.  They went on
to say that the DME had a "sport map" added for this particular car that,
in conjunction with the lightweight valves, gave the thing an extra 320
rpm.

Unfortunately, I don't think the article states how many were made (which
is a bummer because that was going to be the whole purpose of my post).

Dang.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 19:43:40 -0400
From: ALAN968@aol.com
Subject: 968 Water Usage @ Track

Last weekend at Mid Ohio I was using 20-24 oz. of coolant per 25 min.
session.  The coolant was blowing out of the over flow tube on the resevoir.
 I installed a 'puke bottle' to catch the fluid.  Didn't want to upset the
people behind me.

I have added Redline water wetter to the system taking out the same volume of
coolant prior to the addition of the Redline product.

Opinions at the track included:

A blown head gasket (there may be some oil in the resevoir)
Air in the system

Anyone had a similar problem?

Alan
95 968

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 95 16:59:00 PDT
From: Thomas Pindelski <ThomasP@nacm.com>
Subject: K&N filters


There has been some comment on the Mercedes list recently expressing concern 
about K&N filters' ability to do a good filtration job; critics aver that 
the fact that you see grit on the 'exhaust' side of dirty filters means that 
the K&N's coarser weave is letting more dirt through.

Proponents cite major engine lives for motors used in dusty conditions, just 
like K&N's marketing materials do.

Any comments from members?

I use K&Ns on my 1990 928 (58k miles, the last 14k on K&N), 300SD 
(150k/125k) and BMW R90/6 (48k/24k).  The engines for the latter two may be 
cheap but I would rather not shell out for a new 32 valver....

Thomas_Pindelski@nacm.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 17:30:06 -0700
From: "Wayne Michelsen" <wayne@darien.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Drag Figures

On Fri, 7 Jul 95, James Pasha provided some numbers for 914 Cd performance:

> Somewhere, this is from memory, probably Panorama, there were figures
> printed about the Cd for the 914. It was expressed thusly:
>
>	Cd = .34 for a 914 with all windows up and the targa roof on.
>	Cd = .39 for a 914 with all windows down and the targa roof on
>	Cd = .45 for a 914 with all windows down and the targa roof off
>	Cd = .43 for a 914 with all windows up and targa roof off
>
> This included driver's side rearview mirror and North American ride
> height (nose high). It could be a little better with the car set level.

This stuff is interesting...
Does anyone have these kind of figures for varients of the 911 coupe and targa?
 I'm particularly interested in the '87-'89 years, but all others are still
interesting.

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 19:26:22 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: K&N filters

> There has been some comment on the Mercedes list recently expressing concern 
> about K&N filters' ability to do a good filtration job...
> 
> Any comments from members?

We went over this pretty well last summer. Summary: less restriction is
due exclusively to less filtration. Then again, poor tolerances that leave
unsealed gaps between the filter body and the canister could also contribute
to higher air flow.

Advice: just say no.

Stan

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 20:56:02 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Hard Nuts


Have you ever needed some metric sized nuts >DIN 8.8 for your P-Car project?
 
Check with your local Catapiller dealer.  Cat is one of the biggest 
exporters of earth moving machinery.  Thus specs are metric. (No 
kidding)  I found these nuts at a dealer.  The Cat dealer will have them 
in a separate catalog.  The nuts are SAE Grade 10.  They are thorougly 
hardened.  They come in Zinc plated or black phosphate (oiled) coated.
The thread size runs from 6mm to 30mm.  They are very reasonably priced.  
The 10mmx1.5mm are $.31 each.  These are HARD.  I shined one with a file.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 22:00:39 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: This list is the Greatest!

Hi

A little while ago there was a discussion on boost pressure for 944 Turbo S.
The list experts said that the max boost was 1.8 bar. After checking my car,
I was only getting 1.5 bar. After a few mail messages with the experts, I
knew that something was wrong with my car. I was dreading the thought of
spending BIG $$$ to fix the problem. The list experts all said that it was
probably something simple. After spending about 10-15 minutes under the hood,
I discovered a disconnected vacuum line. I reconnected it, road tested the
car, and before I could even look at the boost gauge, I realized that the car
was a LOT faster. I am now getting 1.8 bar, and boy am I happy.

What makes this list SO great is that I never even knew I had a problem
before the whole boost pressure discussion happened. I thought the car was a
rocket before! Now it is MUCH faster.

So Thanks to Everyone!

Barry Lenoble

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 20:57:57 -0600
From: "Bill  Hutton" <us009904@interramp.com>
Subject: Re: Reply Battery Tray Cleaning (long)

The subject of maintaining battery boxes comes up fairly regularly and =
I always add my two cents worth.

We all know one of the most vulnerable areas for corrosion on early =
911s are the battery boxes. Forunately this area is easy to keep in =
top shape with simple maintenance. During the prepurchase process =
the appraiser said "the battery box areas on this car are =
extraordinary".  Here's how I plan to keep them that way.

 I do not like to use agents to neutralize residual or spilt battery =
acid. This is because any thing you add to neutralize the acid makes =
salts (not NaCl salt but  sulfate salts). Salts can  catalyze corrosion. =
I prefer simple dilution. This means copious rinsing. You can't rinse =
too much, the warmer the water the more easily residual salts from =
the reaction of your Porsche's metal with the acid or from lead =
sulfate dissolve. In the early 911s there are drain holes for the water =
to exit. I use an old sponge or very  wet rags.  Sometimes I'll just let =
a small puddle of hot water sit on a  spot were there's a white powder. =
Of course anything you use is ruined by the acid (which reminds me... =
this job calls for some sort of eye protection at the least).
=20
I spread plastic (dry cleaning bags)  around the floor pan area to =
protect clean  areas .  I vaccum the area first as well. I do not think =
one should use wire brushes on the floor pan of the car (or battery =
box). This only provides a fresh surface for contamination. In severe =
cases light sanding (in between rinse cylces ) might be useful. =20

When everything has completely  dried you can see if any white =
residue remains. If you've manically rinsed there won't be any.  =
I liberally spray WD-40 in the empty battery boxes and on the floor =
pan where there was any evidence of corrosion or salt  forrmation. I have =
a few very small areas where the undercoating has been knocked off by =
stuff banging around in the trunk over the past 24 years. I  coat =
these with lithium based grease... but any thin film of grease will do.

This treatment has preserved my battery boxes/floor pan. Rinsing =
has stopped the reformation of white deposits (salts) rom areas that =
had been exposed to battery acid during my cars prvious lives. Since =
the bare/slightly corroded areas are very small, I only use grease =
to inhibit corrosion. Special paints do exist (look in Stoddards, etc, =
etc) but I prefer not to make this area look repaired in any way...=
just well maintained.

I do not know the details of the how the recently described  pads work. =
But anytime you neutraliize sulfuric acid you make a salt.  If you use =
or have used baking soda or pads rinsing and re-rinsing will also =
dissolve any salts. So regardless of whether you neutralize or =
dilute... you must rinse, rinse (and then rinse somemore) to =
properly finish the job.

Cars rust the most in the summer because the rate of oxidation is =
enhanced by high temperatures. If you've been thinking about cleaning =
those battery boxes... now's the time.

Bill Hutton

1971 911E Coupe #0038

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 22:33:43 -0400 (EDT)
From: Rick Shimkets <quartz@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: 914 riding high...too high?

	On the advice of this group I have been prepping my car for 
serious enjoyment, whether it be for autocross or just plain fun, with a 
few improvements.  I replaced the tall 165/15 tires with Yoko A509s that 
were 195/60/15.  I noticed I actually was draggin bottom from time to 
time.  I recently undertook the replacement of the suspension when I went 
on for an alignment and was told there was a suspension problem.  I 
replaced with KYB all around and new "lowering" springs as well.  When 
finished (after much agony and several personal wars with various bolts 
etc) I noticed that my car is sitting _WAY_ higher.  Never having really 
looked at another 914 (mine is jealous and gets upset about things like 
that you see)  I always thought it was SUPPOSED to be that low.  All the 
shocks 
were completely dead, probably originals from the looks of things.  The 
ride is amazing though much higher, and I'm wondering if I did something 
wrong somehow or if it really is supposed to ride that high.  THe car 
looks much better higher up I think.  But anyway, I was hoping someone 
might tell me just how to go about lowering the 914 and if it is worth it 
for the added cornering speed.  
	Also, I was wondering if I was a moron or it really does take a 
long time to replace the suspension.  It took me 3.5 hours total to 
replace the back shocks and springs (including compress/decompress) and 3 
hours on each front  At 10 hours I don't think I set any speed records 
here, but everything was so rusty!  Anyone else who is new to mechanics 
undertake this project?  Until we meet on the track....    Rick

doo machine and claims the car is fine.

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 21:19:27 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re: 914 -> Early 911 Brakes

Bryan R. Mattern <gt7451b@prism.gatech.edu> wants to pick
our P-brains...umm,errr "our collective knowledge base", yeah,
that's it...  and writes:

>I was thinking about bolting on the 911 front suspension to gain
>the benifits of better braking/handling.  From what I understand,
>the '65 to early '75 911 front calipers are fitted w/the same pad
>as the 914.  I understand Porsche went to vented rotors in '70 for
>most models, but they retained the same size pad until 1975(with
>exception the the "S" alloy calipers, which had a larger pad.  My
>question is this, what is the added benifit of going to a 65-75 model
911 front suspension?

Well, I'm not a braking expert, but I sometimes play one on the 'net.
There is more to brakes and braking than the size of the pad.
The 911 calipers have larger pistons (48mm vs. 42mm) which
provides greater clamping force on the rotor for a given hydraulic
pressure.  I was going to say that the 911 rotors are also larger
and thus the calipers sit farther out from the center of rotation
and provide marginally greater braking force due to the longer
moment arm (correct term?), but the difference in size is
negligable.

I'm sure others can elaborate and provide more details.  You
might want to check out Fred Phun's Brake Handbook, available
from places like Performance Products.

Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L




------------------------------

Date: Mon, 10 Jul 1995 12:46:00 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  Lap welds vs. butt welds

Hi p-philers,

I've taken my 914 to several restoration/body shops
for estimates on repairing rust damage to the rear trunk
and passenger side engine compartment  (lower firewall,
engine shelf, and boxed "frame" area).  When asked
whether they would repair the engine compartment areas
using lap or butt welds, every one of them replied
"lap welds, with a continuous weld along the seam".
The last place I went to specifically mentioned using a
flanging tool so that the two panels lay flat.  ASCII art:

   Panel 1 ________  __________ Panel 2
               _____/

When asked "why not butt welds" (which I understand from
the list is the way to go as they are stronger and less likely
to rust), they replied "because the back side of the weld is
not accessible" (and in the boxed "frame" area, its not).

My questions are:
Are butt welds the only way to go, or are lap welds with
a continuously welded seam acceptable?

In order to do a proper butt weld, do you need access to
both sides of the panel?

Should I keep looking for a different restoration shop?

Thanks for any advice,
Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L about to go under the cutter

Porschephiles #1548                         Wed Jul 12 02:00:10 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 20:19:20 -0700 (PDT)
From: tfab@netcom.com (thom fitzpatrick)
Subject: Hot Early 911 - Update

Hi!

	Well, I got a few helpful responses to my question about the hot-running
911T.

	To recap, the temp was running betwixt 210 and 250, regardless of
ambient temperature - anywhere from low 60's to mid 90's.
	
	Fan belt was tight, oil was new, valves adjusted about a month or so
ago.

	Well, tonight I ran 2 pints of Berryman B-12 in the oil, warming the
car up with it in the motor (to a bit above 210) and going thru various
engine speeds.   Decided to clean the air filter at the same time

(Hint:  wear ear protection when you stick your head into one of these
engine compartments without the air filter!!!)

	I ran it about 35 minutes or so, and then drained the oil and put a
new filter on.

	I then too it out an _whomped_ on it (once it warmed up, of course)
I really worked it, redlining (bouncing off the rev limiter anyway) in
4 of the 5 gears.

	I changed the oil again.

	It was all I could do to get the needle to almost, but not quite touch 210.
I set the hand throttle to 4.5k, and ran it for 3 minutes, and the temp
wouldn't _budge_ from 180.  Yes, it actually cooled down at idle! (didn't
do _that_ before!

	As a final test, I let it burble happily at idle for about 15-20 minutes
while I cleaned up the mess I'd made (can you change the oil in a 911
and _not_ make a mess?)

	So, I think I've temporarily fixed the problem, which I think was/is
the thermostat, so I guess I should start looking toward replacing that.
AutoSport here in Sac wants $95 for the thermo & $3 for the O-ring (OUCH!)
Been buying VW parts too much lately, not accustomed to such sticker shock!

	So, any feedback or interpretation of these results is welcome, and
thanx again for the help!
	
PS - do _not_ get this BErryman B-12 on your paint!  Don't ask how I know :(
Thom
- --
> I'm not a complete idiot, some parts are missing!

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 00:35:17 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944 Driveaxle

At 11:18 PM 7/11/95 -0400, FiewVinder@aol.com wrote:
>Yesterday, I was under my car, and noticed that one of the driveaxles on my
>manual 5 speed would slip in and out along the length of the axle.  The

>problems on the road. TIA.

Yes, perfectly normal.  The beautiful thing, well one of the beautiful
things, about Rzeppa CV's is that they allow the half shaft effective
length to grow and shrink as the suspension travels.  They are little
works of art!

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 00:35:03 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 968 Water Usage @ Track

At 07:43 PM 7/11/95 -0400, ALAN968@aol.com wrote:
>Last weekend at Mid Ohio I was using 20-24 oz. of coolant per 25 min.
>session.  The coolant was blowing out of the over flow tube on the resevoir.
> I installed a 'puke bottle' to catch the fluid.  Didn't want to upset the
>people behind me.
>
>I have added Redline water wetter to the system taking out the same volume of
>coolant prior to the addition of the Redline product.
>
>Opinions at the track included:
>
>A blown head gasket (there may be some oil in the resevoir)
>Air in the system
>
>Anyone had a similar problem?
>
>Alan
>95 968

Alan,

Air in the system: I suppose that if you left a fair amount in there,
it is possible that you managed to boil the coolant because of severe
over-heating.

More likely, you have either a blown head gasket or a cracked cylinder
head.  Any way you look at it, the head is coming off.  Sounds like a
warranty matter for you, though.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 00:35:07 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 993 C2 stalling

At 11:00 AM 7/11/95, rrouleau@dataradio.com wrote:
>My 993 coupe has an interesting habit. If the A/C is running and the 
>compressor is engaged, the engine stalls when coming to a stop. I 
>guess most 993 drivers have noticed that when you depress the clutch 
>and remove your foot from the gas, the engine speed drops waaaay down 
>then comes back up to idle. In my case the speed drops so far that 
>the engine flames out.  The dealer has plugged in his diagnostic voo-
>doo machine and claims the car is fine.  
>
>Bob Rouleau
>Montreal Canada
>bob@dataradio.com

So he's telling you the car is fine and yet it stalls.  Nice dealer.

I'd start by a) cleaning the idle stabilizer and b) checking basic fuel
mixture.  I'd also look for vacuum leaks.  I don't know whether the 993
sends an "AC on" signal to its DME, indicating extra load.  If it does,
check that too.  Given the age of your car, the lambda sensor shouldn't
be a decel recovery issue.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 22:04:24 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 914 -> Early 911 Brakes

Bryan R. Mattern (gt7451b@prism.gatech.edu) wrote:

>From what I understand, the '65 to early '75 911 front calipers are 
>fitted w/the same pad as the 914.
> ....
>My question is this, what is the added benifit of going to a .... 911 
>front suspension?  Besides possibly better handling from the larger
>torsion bars, I can't think of any.  In terms of braking, there should 
>be less fade under constant, heavy braking with the vented rotors, not 
>better braking.
> ....
>Also, what is the story with the BMW 320 Calipers ....  If they have a 
>larger pad area than the early 911/914, wouldn't this be the best 
>route to improved braking?

Bryan:

No.  Pad area has no impact on anything except pad life (larger pads 
last longer).

The 911 brakes, as you guessed, will give you better fade-resistance.  
The calipers are also stiffer, so you'll get better brake feel.  They 
also give you stronger spindles, which you probably don't need.  They 
also give you real five-lug hubs, so you can mount five-spoke 911 
wheels without those cheasy 4-to-5 adapters.

If you put the whole 911 front-end in, instead of just the brakes, you 
get a lighter crossmember in addition to the larger torsion bars you 
mentioned.

If these things aren't important to you, don't put the 911 brakes on 
your 914.  They won't give you more "stopping power", whatever that is; 
if you can already hit your stock brakes hard enough to lock all four 
wheels, there's no more "stopping power" available.  If you want to 
stop sooner, you'll need more tire, not more brake.

One thing:  There are a lot of cars running around with Ferodo DS-11 
pads.  These are (or were, anyway) the hot ticket for serious racing, 
so a lot of people have installed them on their street cars for "better 
braking".

Unless your daily commute involves 100-mph stops every few seconds, 
though, these pads will never get into their working heat range.  If 
your car has DS-11s, replace them with a set of Metalmasters or 
something... You'll feel a big difference.

By the way, if you put the whole 911 front-end in, instead of just the 
brakes, you also get a lighter crossmember and larger torsion bars.

 -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 22:05:21 -0700
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: 944 Driveaxle

>Yesterday, I was under my car, and noticed that one of the driveaxles on my
>manual 5 speed would slip in and out along the length of the axle.  The
>movement was about 1 inch.  Is this normal?  I haven't experienced any
>problems on the road. TIA.

Only one?  BOTH halfshafts should exhibit some axial play to accomodate the
suspension dynamics.  I have never measured this to confirm your 1"
estimate, but I suspect your axles are fine...

 -Milo
'86 951

(manufacture date codes of 1982). Think I've seen 1984 928S with ABS but am

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 21:20:43 -0700

>Do you take a bath with dirty water?!?

Not really a waste of time. I'm sure Porsche's recommendations weren't
founded without some research on their part. It's usually the oil contamination
you're concerned with at these relatively low intervals (+/- 6000 mi) rather
than
oil breakdown...something the filter at 3000mi should take care of. As for the 
bath water analogy, astronauts have been known to drink their own urine
after it's gone through a filtration system...

Porschephiles #1549                         Wed Jul 12 11:09:00 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 21:28:54 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: The real 911 ClubSport

>The car was NOT an '88 version of the '73 Carrera RS. It weighed 2700 lbs.,
>had the same horsepower rating as a standard '88 Carrera (it did rev a
>little bit higher because the valves were lighter), and it had its own
>unique paint job. Actually, it had a regular paint job with special decals
>on the front left fender (I think it was left) and the rear deck lid. The
>car was NOT special in any way except in the limited number.
>

Scott,

Sorry but most of the above is not correct, I looked the Carrera CS up at
home and it is listed as a lightweight model, sport version of the Carrera.
No rear seat, minimum soundproofing, sport seats,.....reminds me about a
certain '72 '73 model!

The standard HP rating for '88, as listed by Car&Driver, Motor Trend, Car
Trend was 214HP for the US 911 Carrera. The 911 Carrera CS is rated to 231HP!

In David Vivian's book 'Porsche 911', he has compared a 911 CS to a Carreera
RS and a Turbo SE, the table is clear, the CS outperforms the RS in all
cathergories, .....well 60-80 in fourth was actually in favor of the RS.
0-90 is almost 2 second difference. 

The paint job is very much in the spirit of the Carrera RS, the cars I've
seen are white with the red Carrera Stripes low on the sides of the car, but
it says 'Carrera CS' not 'Carrera (RS?)'. It is also a Decal saying 'CS' low
left on the front hood (viewed from front).

Let's see, in 1973 Porsche strips a 911 and make a lighter version with more
HP and call it Carrera RS. They do the same in '88 and call it 'Carrera CS'.

I know I have the original 'Auto Motor und Sport' or 'Sport Auto' test
somewhere, I shall return with the modification list when I find it.

Trond V.

Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 22:36:32 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: Lap welds vs. butt welds

>My questions are:
>Are butt welds the only way to go, or are lap welds with
>a continuously welded seam acceptable?

In my (humble) opinion you can do with lap welds. Most cars were put
together by spot welds alone. No continously welding seams at all, but if
you're doing 'splicing' you may want the seam welds. If you go with lap
welds, continous seam and 'spot welds' half an inch from the edge, you will
most certainly have a *very* good seam!

Configure you mail program with courier font and watch this crude ASCII art:


                     / /  O  <--- drill or punch holes
                   / /
                 / /
Panel 1        / /  O         Panel 2
_____________/ /_______________________
             \/______/

               |
            Flange




>In order to do a proper butt weld, do you need access to
>both sides of the panel?

Yes and no! There are special clamps and tools that will help you lining up
the panels. Don't really think you will have to get to the rear side if
you're a pro, but for me I will need that so that I can grind and add some
weld seams from the 'inside'. I would recommend TIG welding for splicing
panels, it's like night and day cmpared to MIG/MAG which will eat the
through the panels in notime if you're a little slow, unsecure, it *MUST*
flow in a continously rotating seam. 

>Should I keep looking for a different restoration shop?

Naah,...there are more to this, ask for the possibility to review some of
their structural work on others cars, what equipment they're using, (should
be TIG or top-end MIG/MAG, plasma cutters, etc, do they have any panel
beater equipment?(big plus if they have,...and use it), prices etc.

Lap welds can and should be sealed off permanently, then they will last.


cheers,
Trond V.
('...typical Lap welder, just recently stepped up to Butt welding outer
skins';-)


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 01:47:34 -0800
From: nms@slip.net (Nick Silva)
Subject: Re: 928 Shocks - Konis or Bilsteins?

>
> Date: Tue, 11 Jul 1995 14:16:00 -0400
> From: Tommywar@aol.com
> Subject: 928 Shocks - Konis or Bilsteins?
>
> I have an 82 928 which needs new shocks.  I have the original Boges on it,
> but they are tired shocks.  I know about the different hardware to adapt
> Bilsteins to Boge struts.  I have heard that Bilsteins require a change in
> springs because the shock makes the car ride around 1 to 1.5 inches higher
> than normal.  I also know that the Konis on their softest setting are a
> little stiffer than the Boges.  If you have changed shocks to either
> Bilsteins or Konis,  please let me know of your results.
>
> Thank you,
> Tom Warren


I had an 83. The Boges wore out around 80K, and I let them bounce for
another 10K or so.<g> I did not change to the Bilsteins mainly because of
the expense involved: at the time they were considerably more expensive
than the Konis, and not felt to be worth it by those parties I talked to. I
did hear about the ride height issue, but was not told that I would have to
change springs. The words "slightly taller" spring to mind, no pun
intended. So I got the Konis, and adjusted them to a mid-setting. The car
felt SO much better; at that point the car was bouncing and misbehaving,
and I never felt the shocks were too stiff. The car weighs so much you'd
have to get really stiff before it affected the ride.

In a nutshell, this is what I was told: If the car came with Bilsteins, get
Bilsteins. If it came with Konis, get Konis. If it came with Boges, switch
to Konis.

Nick
95 C4 silver (it was completed yesterday, and should be here in 3-4 weeks!!!)

________________________________________________________________________________
                         I'm growing Betsy in a bag.

                                nms@slip.net
________________________________________________________________________________

Date:     Wed, 12 Jul 95 11:59:42 CETDST (1059Z)
From: "James T. Moder" <aeusg-k-aer@email.kaiserslautern.army.mil>
Subject:  Car Rental in Deutschland

Nate,
  I just called Hertz concerning car rental for someone 21 years old. The owner
of the Hertz rental agency here in Ramstein, Germany says that they rent to 21 
year olds. You need a valid credit card (Visa, MasterCard) and a valid 
stateside drivers license (no international license required). The Hertz phone 
# is 01149-6371-58834 from the states. Be prepared to pay BIG bucks as car 
rentals are not cheap like the states. As a side note, the international 
drivers license is required in: Spain, Austria, Portugal, Hungary, Bulgaria, 
Romania, Czech, Yugoslavia. So if you tool on down to Austria, get one. Any 
other ?'s about Deutschland give me a hollar.
Oh yes, don't forget that gas is 1.55 deutschmarks per LITER.At todays exchange
rate of 1.37DM to the buck that's ~$4.53 a gallon. So remember the old 
adage,"You pay for your pleasure". Of course when I'm whipping down the Bahn at
245Km, who thinks of money!
Jim Moder
1983 944
moderj@email.kaiserslautern. army.mil

>>little bit higher because the valves were lighter), and it had its own
>>unique paint job. Actually, it had a regular paint job with special decals

>certain '72 '73 model!

>Trend was 214HP for the US 911 Carrera. The 911 Carrera CS is rated to 231HP!

>0-90 is almost 2 second difference.
>

>it says 'Carrera CS' not 'Carrera (RS?)'. It is also a Decal saying 'CS' low
>left on the front hood (viewed from front).

>HP and call it Carrera RS. They do the same in '88 and call it 'Carrera CS'.
>
>I know I have the original 'Auto Motor und Sport' or 'Sport Auto' test
>somewhere, I shall return with the modification list when I find it.

Trond,

You always seem to forget that Porsches sold in this country (the USA)
not the same as the ones sold in Europe or the rest of the world (ROW).

I have the Road & Track write up on the car in front of me (May 1988).

Let's see, the BHP is 214 SAE net @ 5900 RPM and the torque is 195 lb-ft
@ 4800 RPM. This is same as the stock USA '88 Carrera.

The CS weighs in at 155 lbs. less than the stock '88 Carrera. Hardly what
one would call "lightweight" in comparison.

Road & Track reports the 0-60 time as 5.7 seconds. That is the same time
the '86 Carrera Cabriolet recorded for Road & Track two years earlier.

The pictures of the car in Road & Track and the ones I have seen in person
(I have seen three different examples) do not have special paint jobs.
They all have decals on the driver's side front fender (I call that the
left fender) and on the rear decklid. There are no graphics elsewhere on
the car.

So Trond, everything I said was correct based on a U.S. model '88 911
Carrera Club Sport. Yes, I am sure the R.O.W. '88 Club Sport has 231 hp.
That is standard for the R.O.W. 3.2 Liter motors.

So, as I said before, hardly a special car in anyway except for the
limited production run. I have no idea how many they made. The car was
NOT a homologation special like the '73 Carrera RS. The car does not
have a special motor like the '73 Carrera RS. The car is NOT made of
thinner metal like the first 1000 or so '73 Carrera RS cars. The '73
Carrera RS was not a bone stock car with some sound deading removed and
special decals slapped on. The '88 Carrera Club Sport in no way reminds
me of a '73 Carrera RS.


Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 00:58:43 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: The real 911 ClubSport

Scitt,

>So, as I said before, hardly a special car in anyway except for the
>limited production run. I have no idea how many they made. The car was
>NOT a homologation special like the '73 Carrera RS. The car does not
>have a special motor like the '73 Carrera RS. The car is NOT made of
>thinner metal like the first 1000 or so '73 Carrera RS cars. The '73
>Carrera RS was not a bone stock car with some sound deading removed and
>special decals slapped on. The '88 Carrera Club Sport in no way reminds
>me of a '73 Carrera RS.

Do you know the exact wight difference between, say a '72 S/E/T and '72
Carrera RS then? Regarding thinner metal, wasn't it Aluminum and fiberglass
panels *instead* of certain steel panels that stood for the wight savings???

The CS's you've seen is *FAR* from what was delivered in Europe and ROW
then, I would prefer sticking to the cars as (intended) and delivered from
Stuttgart, not with major mods to meet US emission when discussing a cars
charachteristics.(...even though those mods certainly were made in Stuttgart).

The paint job is 100% Carrera RS look a like, (3-4 real life expperiences
and more magazine sightings) and if they painted the cars otherwise for the
USA, ....your loss!

The european press (at least the articles I've read) concludes with a sporty
lightweight 911, outperforming the periode Carrera and '73 Carrera RS with ease!

The CS was in no need of major rework, as the late Carrera's had almost
everything that was needed. Therefore 'bone stock' car, very little sound
proofing, and the old Carrera's decals in place. Not particulary 'slapped
on'. No rear seats too.

The car was no success, launched at the wrong time, almost immediately after
the '87 stock exchange crack, and I agree that perhaps a little to little
were done to the weight problem.
But before you comment too strong about a car, you should try it, or at
least read what the experts said about it,....or conclude that you're
speaking of *THE US VERSION* and only it.


Trond V.

....there's a world out there!

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 05:39:31 -0700
From: hairpin@ix.netcom.com (Dion Dunn )
Subject: 914 Lessons learned!

Fellow P-filers,

For any of you who have seen my cry for help on the net a few times 
because of a stiff engine that wouldn't turn over, the problem has been 
solved.  Unfortunately, all of the P-car mechanics I talked to 
(in my area) couldn't figure out what was wrong, but my girlfriend's Dad 
(who rebuilds Ford engines) pointed me right to it.  Bad starter, the 
first thing I replaced when I started this whole search 2 months ago!  
Not only was it bad in terms of cranking power (when tested), the collar 
was hitting the flywheel when it went out to engage which was binding 
everything up.  I took it back and exchanged for a Sportamatic style 
starter (for the 1-2 more amps it produces), bolted it in, and the 
engine turns over like its new!!!

Thanks for all the advice I did get.  It has helped me understand my 
engine a heck of a lot more!

Dion
72 914




------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 09:08:09 -0400
From: David944@aol.com
Subject: WAS...Should I go to Chicago for this 944 Turbo S

Sobb, sniffle, caugh, choke, cry....

So off I went to Chicago to see the Tubos S.  The owner is a great guy, only
ridding himself of his pride and joy to concentrate on his new 993 C4..
Maintained the car with love and care, and has the records to prove it.  A
good look at the paint job by Barrington Coach House proves very impressive.
 And a quick test drive with the owner only affirrms the performance
capabilities of this (IMHO one of the finest the Dr. ever produced) PCar.

I trade him my Chevy Corsica rent a car, and head off for the pre-purchase
inspection.  Cruising at 50mph on the expressway, with visions of sugar plums
dancing in my head, and the open road ahead..........the tach dies, oil
pressure goes to zero, and the car dies.  I coast over to to the shoulder,
and run up my Cellular One bill.  An hour later the owner arrives, and we
finally get the car started and off the expressway.  Onto a side road, he
gets in, and off we go again.  A cruise controlled 30mph 2 mile drive, and
wham, the same thing again.  Dead.

He did have the AutoAuthority Stage II chip removed, and the factory chip put
back in. (he only useses the Stage II at his bianual trip to Road America),
and the first thought is that there might be something amiss with the seating
of the chip... but who knows.

Who knows, just a loose wire, or a real bad omen, but am I to fool with the
unknown?  Logically, there may be nothing wrong with the car, but it just
felt like the my Grandmother doused an act of "acrobatic intamacy" with a
bucket of ice water.  So,  I rush to O'hare, catch the last flight to the
east coast, drown my sorrows in a several good libations, and send this
(rather depressing) note to my friends.

Thanks to all who gave me advice and places in Chicago to get my pre-purchase
(George Beuselinck,Craig Zaplatynsky, Bob Neal, Jon Lowe, Ezra Goldman, Harve
Hensley, Jim Fuerstenberg, Karen Allenmier, Rudy Garcia, Christine Ryan, Trev
Sadler, Barry Lenoble, Chris Bennet and Jim Meyer).

David Rothenberg
84 944 (Still my one and only)
8? 951 Turbo S (Still out there somewhere.....)

aka David_Rothenberg.JEFFERIES@itginc.com

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 08:43:22 -0500 (CDT)
From: alanr%austin.ibm.com@ibmpa.awdpa.ibm.com
Subject: 944 Heads-up and question.


Porschephiles,

Here's something you should check on your 944.  I noticed lately that
the steering effort on my 87 944S had increased significantly.  A check
under the car revealed that the cooling hose that goes to the back of the
alternator had come loose from deterioration and the wire reinforcement 
of the hose had become wrapped around the steering knuckle/rack.  Yikes!  
This could have been dangerous.  Check those hoses.  

I also have a question.  When investigating the steering problem, I found
a loose wire with a black plug on it hanging down from the vicinity of 
the A/C peep hole.  It is tie wrapped to the a/c line and runs from under
the fuse box to the front of the car.  I believe the colors are Orange, 
White, and Blue(?) wrapped in a black covering.  Does this attach to a 
temperature sensor to turn on the first fan?  My car has been heating up now
unless I force the fans to run by using the A/C.  I looked all over and
didn't find anywhere to attach the wire.  Where is the temp sensor?  On
the block?  Help.  :)  

Thanks,

 -Alan Reynolds            alanr@austin.ibm.com

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 9:54:38 -0400 (EDT)
From: Darrin <LUCAS001@WCSUB.CTSTATEU.EDU>
Subject: Re:  All this oil and urine talk


	I'm sorry if I started something.........


	Here's what I'll do:

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 08:09:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: 914 riding high...too high?

> 
> 	On the advice of this group I have been prepping my car for 
> serious enjoyment, whether it be for autocross or just plain fun, with a 
> few improvements.  I replaced the tall 165/15 tires with Yoko A509s that 
> were 195/60/15.  I noticed I actually was draggin bottom from time to 
> time.  I recently undertook the replacement of the suspension when I went 
> on for an alignment and was told there was a suspension problem.  I 
> replaced with KYB all around and new "lowering" springs as well.  When 
> finished (after much agony and several personal wars with various bolts 
> etc) I noticed that my car is sitting _WAY_ higher.  Never having really 
> looked at another 914 (mine is jealous and gets upset about things like 
> that you see)  I always thought it was SUPPOSED to be that low.  All the 
> shocks 
> were completely dead, probably originals from the looks of things.  The 
> ride is amazing though much higher, and I'm wondering if I did something 
> wrong somehow or if it really is supposed to ride that high.  THe car 
> looks much better higher up I think.  But anyway, I was hoping someone 
> might tell me just how to go about lowering the 914 and if it is worth it 
> for the added cornering speed.  

Sounds like the parts you replaced were bad broke.  You can check the
ride height with the "Automotion Methode":  There should be 2.5 - 3.5"
between the TOP of the wheel and the BOTTOM of the fender at the back,
and the car should sit level.

The previous owner of one 914 had cut two turns off of the stock spring
and put them over trashed shocks.  What a terrible ride that was.

And...  Lower is not always better.  (IMHO) much more than an inch
or so below stock height and the geometry starts getting screwed up. 

> 	Also, I was wondering if I was a moron or it really does take a 
> long time to replace the suspension.  It took me 3.5 hours total to 
> replace the back shocks and springs (including compress/decompress) and 3 
> hours on each front  At 10 hours I don't think I set any speed records 
> here, but everything was so rusty!  Anyone else who is new to mechanics 
> undertake this project?  Until we meet on the track....    Rick
> 

3.5 hours?  Sounds like you took the extra time to keep your fingers
from getting snapped off when the spring "sproinged".

Who *cares* how long it took.  Is the job done right?  Is all of your
blood *inside* your body where is belongs?  Those are the important
questions.  Set your speed records on the track.

Gary.

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 11:07:21 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Ooops - 914 FI Wiring!


If *anyone* on the list could take the time to do me a *huge* favor it'd
be much appreciated.  As you will see from the description below, I don't
want to have to remove wires from a connector and experiement until they
are correct.  The car is, of course, a D-Jet 914.

Problem #1
==========
The wiring to the connector for the trigger points on the distributor was
split - therefore I had to cut the connector off to re-wire that portion of
the harness.  PROBLEM!  Forgot to label each of the three wires to the 
connector and I now have an orientation problem.

The wiring diagrams I have so that for the D-Jetronic engine, the three wires
to the distributor trigger points go to pins 12, 22, and 24 on the connector
to the FI control unit.  From the diagram it appears that the wire to pin 12
goes to the center of the connector, if this is true I need to know the
orientation of the other two connectors.

The connector looks like this:
	     _____________
            /             \
	   | ===  ===  === |
	   -----------------
	      ^	   ^    ^
              |    |    |_________ ( to 22 or 24?)
              |    |_______________( to 12 (assumption))
	      |____________________( to 22 or 24?)

As you all know, getting these wrong will result in a non-functional engine
as the wrong injectors will fire(or not at all).  If no one can help, should
I just pull the spades out of the connector, wire-it up and use 
trial-and-error?

Problem #2
==========
I have a three-wire section of harness for the engine compartment area.  I 
am *not* sure where it goes/what it is for.  I looked on Scot Douglas' 914
and they were not present.  Any ideas?

The three-wires are, brown, green, and yellow/red.  I know for a fact that
they connect to the relay circuit board and the ground nearby at one end.
My diagrams show them to connect to the two small "poles" that are near 
the fuses on the relay board.  (They are the same sort of connectors that
are inside the plastic 12 pole connectors - but separate.)

The opposite end of these wires have no connectors, just a small section of
bare wire.  Any clues?

Thanks, Thanks, and Thanks again in advance,

Jerry(who needs to start his car this weekend)
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 - Jerry R. Brady         - Open Networks Engineering -          jrb@one.com -
 - 1976 Sunflower Yellow 914/2.0(ok,ok, it's a 1.7 with 96mm NPR)            -
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Stan,

Thank you for changing my mail to the digest group.  The wealth of
knowledge is incredible and I have within a short time learned more about
the P-cars.  I have been driving a 911 for about 3 years after having grown
up with them in my family.  Nonetheless, your group has increased my
excitement in what I believe is the finest automobile ever built and more
importantly, the most thrilling to drive.  I live in Marin County,
California and the 911 is built for many of the canyon roads.  I sometimes
get up at 3:00 A.M. and drive into the Point Reyes National Park area,
travelling north on U.S. 1; no other vehicles in sight, although sometimes
numerous deer on the roadsides.  Great fun, especially with a full moon and
the top off, listening to the whine of the 6 cylinders pushing me thru the
next turn.  My wife and kids wonder what the smile on my face is when I
come back a few hours later!

Anyway, thanks again for the digest and if you ever happen to get lost in
this neck of the woods, during a full moon, give me a call.  In the
meantime, I will stop thinking of the practical reasons to keep this
vehicle and let my kids enjoy the driving experience as my Dad let me.
Take care,

David

to take their cars into Eastern Europe where there is a theft problem. Have
fun!

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 95 08:50:45 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: 911: Fan/alternator disassembly


Yves-

You can bang it out from the back--the alternator and
fan will come out of the fan housing together--and then
you will need a small gear puller to pull the fan off
the alternator shaft.

Alternatively -- and I think this is a better method --
first pull off the fan with the gear puller, then take out
the long bolts around the circulference of the alternator.
These protrude through the fan housing, and can bind up if
you try to knock out the alternator with them in place.

Don't know about the color.  On my '72T and '72T the fan is
grey,i.e., natural metal, no paint (although yesterday I
painted the T's fan to match the body color...I like
to include a little personal touch when I do a rebuild...)

 -Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

Subject: 914 Reunion -- my OPINION!

 Dennis Deeds and all the P-Philes,
 
 Gee wiz Dennis?  I read the scathing note you sent to P-philes and frankly I 
 can't see why you have to be so upset at what I said?  I went back and read my 
 post and your post and I will make one attempt to rectify this situation and, 
 unfortunately, defend my honor, which I sort of have to do since you sent a 
 huge note to everyone saying, in effect, that my _opinion_ was a lie. (I fail 
 to see how an opinion can be a untrue, just that it might not match someone 
 else's opinion).  Apologies to all who don't care about this and I promise that 
 this will be my last public post on the subject.
 
 1) I didn't pre-register because I thought I might have to work Sat and Sun.
 2) I called down to 914 OA and they said it would be fine to pay if I show up.
 3) I _WAS_ disappointed as to the number of cars and the number of pure stock 
 cars.  Others may not have been.  That's what opinions are for.  That in _NO_ 
 way is a slam on the organization of the event, just that my expectations were 
 not fully met.  THAT'S ALL.
 4) Mike Willis' and Ray (Roy?) Juan's cars looked great to me -- the others, no 
 matter the condition made me quite jealous, since mine has no engine and is 
 covered in dust.
 5) Again, my _opinion_ but there wasn't a whole lot to do after the car show 
 for the folks not interested in touring the stars' homes.  I do not pretend to 
 speak for everyone, but one of the discussions some of us had at lunch was that 
 it would be a neat idea for the next reunion if there were some driving events, 
 more tech sessions, etc.  I didn't bring up the subject, nor did I participate 
 in the discussions much since I had never been to a 914 OA Reunion before.
 6) I did decide to leave and miss the dinner and tech sessions.  There was some 
 time to kill until dinner and as far as I could tell there was nothing on the 
 schedule once I made the decision to skip the stars' homes tour so I rode home.
 7) Before I left I went to pay Dennis because I felt that since I participated 
 in the event, I should pony up the cash.  I could have just left and never 
 paid, but that didn't seem right.  When I said that the price was a bit steep 
 for just a car show that merely reflects _MY_ participation in the event.  I 
 went to the car show, that's all that interested me, thus the price was high. 
 Others who attended the entire event may feel the same way, Dennis, but I will 
 not speak for them.  I don't think I whined about the price, I just said that I 
 paid it and then I made a few suggestions for improvements.
 8) Dennis seemed like a pretty nice guy, was able to pronounce "Karlsruhe" (a 
 city in Germany) correctly (which I cannot do), and we had a nice, 2-3 minute 
 talk.  I brought up possibly doing a subwoofer design article for the 
 newsletter because I wanted to see if he was interested.  Sounded like he was 
 so I will be working on it (if any of you are interested I'll post a copy to 
 p-philes.
 9)  Dennis and I both agree that Mike Willis was a big help.
 10) My summary said "A good way to spend a free day; wish there was more car 
 oriented stuff; Mike is cool!"  I don't see that as a slam of the event, nor do 
 I retract it.  Sounds kinda like a small compliment to me....
 
 I apologize if Dennis or anyone else thought that I was attacking them -- I 
 don't think my post read that way, but if it did, I am sorry.  I think the 
 EVENT could have been better with more interesting activities -- that's an 
 OPINION I held, continue to hold and one that I am more than happy to work to 
 solve for the next event, if Dennis would like suggestions from one of the 
 masses.  I think Dennis' note reflected his opinion, but I felt there were more 
 than a few personal attacks toward me because I gave criticism to the _event_ 
 and that is the only reason I post this to the public forum.  If anyone would 
 like to continue this off-line, please e-mail me at the site below.

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 09:56:12 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: The real 911 ClubSport

>>So, as I said before, hardly a special car in anyway except for the
>>limited production run. I have no idea how many they made. The car was
>>NOT a homologation special like the '73 Carrera RS. The car does not
>>have a special motor like the '73 Carrera RS. The car is NOT made of
>>thinner metal like the first 1000 or so '73 Carrera RS cars. The '73
>>Carrera RS was not a bone stock car with some sound deading removed and
>>special decals slapped on. The '88 Carrera Club Sport in no way reminds
>>me of a '73 Carrera RS.
>
>Do you know the exact wight difference between, say a '72 S/E/T and '72
>Carrera RS then? Regarding thinner metal, wasn't it Aluminum and fiberglass
>panels *instead* of certain steel panels that stood for the wight savings???
>
>The CS's you've seen is *FAR* from what was delivered in Europe and ROW
>then, I would prefer sticking to the cars as (intended) and delivered from
>Stuttgart, not with major mods to meet US emission when discussing a cars
>charachteristics.(...even though those mods certainly were made in Stuttgart).
>
>The paint job is 100% Carrera RS look a like, (3-4 real life expperiences
>and more magazine sightings) and if they painted the cars otherwise for the
>USA, ....your loss!
>
>The european press (at least the articles I've read) concludes with a sporty
>lightweight 911, outperforming the periode Carrera and '73 Carrera RS with
>ease!
>
>The CS was in no need of major rework, as the late Carrera's had almost
>everything that was needed. Therefore 'bone stock' car, very little sound
>proofing, and the old Carrera's decals in place. Not particulary 'slapped
>on'. No rear seats too.
>
>The car was no success, launched at the wrong time, almost immediately after
>the '87 stock exchange crack, and I agree that perhaps a little to little
>were done to the weight problem.
>But before you comment too strong about a car, you should try it, or at
>least read what the experts said about it,....or conclude that you're
>speaking of *THE US VERSION* and only it.
>
>
>Trond V.
>
>....there's a world out there!

Trond,

I can't believe you! If you remember, the car that started this whole
thread was '88 Club Sport for sale in the U.S. We have been talking about
the U.S.
spec car all along. I was the one that pointed out to you that the you need
to remember there are U.S. version of these cars. The U.S. version is a
"delete option" car that cost more and offers no special abilities.

I doubt that the European and ROW version of the Carrera CS is "FAR" different
than the U.S. version. I bet the only difference is the graphics, the version
of the 3.2 engine, the tranny gear ratios, and the ride height settings.
In other words, the difference between the European and U.S spec Carrera CS is
probably the same as the difference between the European and U.S spec Carrera.
Since I don't have specs for the Euro CS in front of me, I can't say for sure.

I've seen the U.S. Carrera CS in action and it is nothing special. The only
real difference is that it weigh 155 lbs. less. Big F**king Deal!!!

The first 1000 or so '73 Carrera RS bodies were made of thinner steel. This
was all they needed to make to homolgate that feature. The rest of the cars
made used standard thickness of metal. The weight of the '73 RS also depended
on what version was ordered. There was a lightweight and a touring package.

There is no way the '88 Carrera CS out performs a lightweight '73 RS. Sure,
the Euro CS has 231 HP compared to the 210 HP of the RS. But I can guarantee
the lightweight '73 RS weighs a good deal less and is a better balanced
race car. I don't consider tests showing that one car accelerates from 60
to 90 in top gear faster than another very important when evaluating a race
cars potential.

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 13:06:33 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 1986 944 Front Shocks and Suspension

At 08:59 AM 7/7/95 -0700, Rolando Saldana wrote:

>The 474 kit comes with 250 lbs front springs. However, if the front springs
>are replaced, would I have to replace the rear torsion bars to match? I
>hear they are a bear to replace!

Rolando,

I think you are going to find that 250# springs are too stiff for your
car if it retains its stock 23.5 mm torsion bars.  I'd recommend the 210#
springs.  The 250# seem to work fine with the turbo's 25.5 mm torsion
bar.  These numbers have worked for me and for an SCCA IT race 944.

Yes, the rear bars are quite a bit of work to replace, unlike the 911's.
Shop time est'd is about 6 hours, exclusive of the alignment you need
afterwards.  There is also a bit of trial and error in setting them up
with respect to getting the ride height correct, since everything is
unloaded during installation, and because you are changing the springing
and so the loaded/unloaded height delta!  We eyeballed mine when we did
them a few months ago, and were fortunate.

Kevin

>3rd and 4th gear.  My mechanic can't find anything wrong.  Any thoughts as to

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 13:32:00 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: A quick question on hose clamps

At 09:36 AM 7/12/95 -0400, Doug Donsbach wrote:
>What is the best technique for removing the Porsche
>OEM hose clamps used on small diameter hoses? My
>current approach is to cut them off with a good set
>of wire cutters but is there a better way?

They're Oetiker clamps, and there is a special tool which you can buy
(short money) for both cutting them off and crimping them on.  Or you
can just cut them off with diagonal cutters, replace with small zebra-
or band-style hose clamps.

When you do this, it is *real* important that you use new clamps with
rolled edges, like the factory does.  The flat edges on hardware store
clamps will eventually cut the hose.  The 944 paddocked next to me at
LRP last month learned this lesson the hard way!

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 12:31:14 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 break-in oil?

        How important is it to use a particular weight of oil
when breaking in a 914 engine?  I have heard that I should not

break in the engine using the oil I will run in it when it is
broken in?  (No, I'm not going to synthetic--it ain't in the
budget, but still...)
        Stan recommends breaking-in using 40 wt; but that's
what he recommends all the time in a 914.  I have also heard
that I should use 30 wt--and that's what the factory recom-
mended when the car was built.  I am considering using 20/50
Kendall dino oil, and am thinking that I should use it for the
break-in period as well.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 14:02:04 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 bal/belt ?????

>I managed to complete the installation of my timing belt w/o too
>many problems, however I understand that the bal/belt is a little
>tricky (i.e. deflection adjustments).  My mechanic wants $100 to
>put it on and adjust, WRONG.  Are there any special procedures for
>a backyard mechanic in this regard??  Thanks
>

Boy, you must really feel lucky.

If you are unwilling to spend the time and the money to have your
timing belt and balance shaft belt properly tensioned (i.e. Use the
P9201 belt tension tool), then start saving your money for valves and 
a head gasket set.

I have set the tension on at least 30 motors, and although I can get
pretty close by feel, I still use the gauge to check my work, and if
it is not in the specified range, I re-adjust it.

The special procedure for the backyard mechanic: Spend the money on 
the tool, or spend the money for another motor...Your choice...

(Sorry for the strong language, but I have strong feelings on this 
subject...)
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 14:05:02 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Heads-up and question.

>I also have a question.  When investigating the steering problem, I found
>a loose wire with a black plug on it hanging down from the vicinity of 
>the A/C peep hole.  It is tie wrapped to the a/c line and runs from under
>the fuse box to the front of the car.  I believe the colors are Orange, 
>White, and Blue(?) wrapped in a black covering.  Does this attach to a 
>temperature sensor to turn on the first fan?  My car has been heating up now
>unless I force the fans to run by using the A/C.  I looked all over and
>didn't find anywhere to attach the wire.  Where is the temp sensor?  On
>the block?  Help.  :)  
>


Hi Alan,

Well, this does in fact sound like the thermoswitch plug, which
should be attached to the thermoswitch, located high on the radiator,
driver's side, just underneath the two hoses there.

In order to re-attach it, you *may* have to drop the fan shroud
assembly.

It certainly would keep your fans from working on their own...
Good Luck!
