Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 11:20:16 -0700
From: "Wayne Michelsen" <wayne@darien.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: 911: Windsheild wipers

Chris,

I had the confused-parking sporadic-intermittent wiper-impaired problem on my
'87 911.  After some serious time spent in the debugging effort, I finally
found corrosion on the points of the wiper relay.  On my car, the wiper relay
is up in the "behind-the-AC/vent-ducting, above-the-firewall, under-the-dash
Abyss".  If I remember correctly, I had to pull out the speedo and clock,
remove the wiper motor, and reach thru the instrument holes to get it.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 14:25:07 -0400
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: A quick question on hose clamps

Some of these clamps are a. either difficult or impossible to find or b. very
very expensive per/each.  I was able to reuse mine by carefully expanding
them with a punch or other suitable tool.  First, you can just usually pull
of the hose without removing the fitting.  Then, remove the clamp, expand and
reuse.  If you don't expand them too much, you don't need the special tool to
recrimp.  Simply sure a pair of dull wire cutters, more example.

Allen Henderson

doesn't interfere with the display panel.  I used two strips of 1" wide velcro
under the dash/ash tray and the same on top of the display panel so I could un-

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 16:04:52 -0400
From: KFJC@aol.com
Subject: Re: #1(2) Porschephiles #1547 Tue Jul 11 22:41:06 CDT 1995

Parking wiper problem. Hint. when you R&R you motor, did you remove the first
drive arm from the motor shaft?  the multi-splined one?. On the early motors
this arm was welded to the motor shaft and mis-parking was not possible, on
late versions, however, the arm is removeable, and without knowing, you can
throw the park position off. So remove the wiper motor and mark the relation
of the arm to shaft, then move the arm in the opposite direction of rotation
a couple of spline notches, this will allow the  park position to be closer
to the bottom of the stroke. A little trial and error, and you should have
the park position where you want it. The engineers did not put the park at
the complete bottom of the stroke, to save startup strain on the motor and
adhesion friction of blades used infrequently.  Hope this can clear things up
for you (pun intended).:). 
ken
66 912
80 924
356c replicar

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 16:09:54 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 bal/belt ?????

>I'm curious about how often you have to re-adjust after getting 
>"the feel" for proper adjustment. I've never adjusted a timing belt
>on a 944, but I've done many VW's and Volvos using the twist method.
>Admittedly they're lower performance engines and the consequences of
>failure are more in the nuisance category rather than doing major
>evil to engine and bank account. Are 944 belts that much more prone
>to failure or are the consequences just so terrible that people are
>extra cautious? 

Well, the reason I am such a stickler on these belts is that I 
broke one on my first (and still) 944.  The belt stretched, 
started cannibalizing its own teeth and left me with 8 bent valves.
Luckily, it was in the garage and not at the autocross track.
The cost was around $1000 at the time (before I knew better) and 
I did the remove, replace, retime and retension myself (after buying
the gauge...)

There are enough valve to piston occurrences that I have sold a
bunch of complete heads as being cheaper than replacing 
valves and guides, etc.  

The reason that the tension is so critical is that the engine
grows 9 mm in every direction from cold to hot. Too loose a belt
and it chews teeth when cold. Too tight, and the growth of the 
engine stretches the belt so much it breaks the fibers, resulting 
in a loose belt (see above.)

So, since I run my car hard, and I don't trailer my car to the track
(no safety net) I choose to do it the way that the designers specify.
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services 
Orders: 800-ALL-P944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 85 Audi 5000S Sedan,  80 GMC Pickup (drivers)
86 944 Turbo, 89 944S2, 87 924S, 84 944 (parts cars)

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 16:17:06 -0400 (EDT)
From: Scot Alan Douglas <scootman@engin.umich.edu>
Subject: Re: 914 -> Early 911 Brakes

I'm not sure I agree with your post, while not discounting what you 
wrote, do you mean my 914 brakes would stop a 993 from 60 mph in the 
neighborhood of 120 some odd feet?  The new bitubo generates 2,000 
horsepower ob braking force which is a function of brake application 
pressure, velocity, and temperature.  Using the braking power, you can 
calculate the braking force at the ground by taking the difference 
between brake torque and the product of the wheel's rotational inertia 
and deceleration, then divide this mess by the wheel's radius.  I agree 
that bigger contact patch on the tire should provide better deceleration, 
but tire adhesion has alot to do with the tire's bulk hysteresis.  Also, 
the coefficient of friction increases over the static value with 10-20% 
slip.  Then the mass of the figures in as F=ma or F=md in this case.  
Oop, almost forgot about proportioning-that makes a difference too.  My 
point is, its not right to assume big tire are what's needed to increase 
braking.  If this were so,  Brembo wouldn't exist and Porsche would still 
be putting 914 brake on all of their cars.
Scot

On Tue, 11 Jul 1995, Andrew Warren wrote:

> Bryan R. Mattern (gt7451b@prism.gatech.edu) wrote:
> 
> >From what I understand, the '65 to early '75 911 front calipers are 
> >fitted w/the same pad as the 914.
> > ....
> >My question is this, what is the added benifit of going to a .... 911 
> >front suspension?  Besides possibly better handling from the larger
> >torsion bars, I can't think of any.  In terms of braking, there should 
> >be less fade under constant, heavy braking with the vented rotors, not 
> >better braking.
> > ....
> >Also, what is the story with the BMW 320 Calipers ....  If they have a 
> >larger pad area than the early 911/914, wouldn't this be the best 
> >route to improved braking?
> 
> Bryan:
> 
> No.  Pad area has no impact on anything except pad life (larger pads 
> last longer).
> 
> The 911 brakes, as you guessed, will give you better fade-resistance.  
> The calipers are also stiffer, so you'll get better brake feel.  They 
> also give you stronger spindles, which you probably don't need.  They 
> also give you real five-lug hubs, so you can mount five-spoke 911 
> wheels without those cheasy 4-to-5 adapters.
> 
> If you put the whole 911 front-end in, instead of just the brakes, you 
> get a lighter crossmember in addition to the larger torsion bars you 
> mentioned.
> 
> If these things aren't important to you, don't put the 911 brakes on 
> your 914.  They won't give you more "stopping power", whatever that is; 
> if you can already hit your stock brakes hard enough to lock all four 
> wheels, there's no more "stopping power" available.  If you want to 
> stop sooner, you'll need more tire, not more brake.
> 
> One thing:  There are a lot of cars running around with Ferodo DS-11 
> pads.  These are (or were, anyway) the hot ticket for serious racing, 
> so a lot of people have installed them on their street cars for "better 
> braking".
> 
> Unless your daily commute involves 100-mph stops every few seconds, 
> though, these pads will never get into their working heat range.  If 
> your car has DS-11s, replace them with a set of Metalmasters or 
> something... You'll feel a big difference.
> 
> By the way, if you put the whole 911 front-end in, instead of just the 
> brakes, you also get a lighter crossmember and larger torsion bars.
> 
> -Andy
> 
> -- 
> Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
> Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California
> 
>

Date:         Wed, 12 Jul 95 16:06:43 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: 993 C2 stalling

On Wed, 12 Jul 1995 00:35:07 -0400 you said:
>At 11:00 AM 7/11/95, rrouleau@dataradio.com wrote:
>>My 993 coupe has an interesting habit. If the A/C is running and the
>>compressor is engaged, the engine stalls when coming to a stop. I
>>guess most 993 drivers have noticed that when you depress the clutch
>>and remove your foot from the gas, the engine speed drops waaaay down
>>then comes back up to idle. In my case the speed drops so far that
>>the engine flames out.  The dealer has plugged in his diagnostic voo-
>>doo machine and claims the car is fine.
>>
>>Bob Rouleau
>>Montreal Canada
>>bob@dataradio.com
>
>So he's telling you the car is fine and yet it stalls.  Nice dealer.
>
>I'd start by a) cleaning the idle stabilizer and b) checking basic fuel
>mixture.  I'd also look for vacuum leaks.  I don't know whether the 993
>sends an "AC on" signal to its DME, indicating extra load.  If it does,
>check that too.  Given the age of your car, the lambda sensor shouldn't
>be a decel recovery issue.
>
>Kevin
>

I had this same problem with my 944S.  When I bought the car, I replaced
all the ignition components (wires, spark plugs, rotor, cap), everything
except the coil (it was $64). Being a purist, I eventually bought a new
coil. Guess what? The symptoms you describe above went away! It still
does it every so often, but not nearly as bad and it is such a rare
occurence I hardly notice it anymore.

Darren Evans-Young
'87 944S Indischrot
darren@ua1vm.ua.edu

Porschephiles #1551                         Wed Jul 12 21:51:27 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 14:11:19 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: The real 911 ClubSport

>Scott,
>
>>There is no way the '88 Carrera CS out performs a lightweight '73 RS. Sure,
>>the Euro CS has 231 HP compared to the 210 HP of the RS. But I can guarantee
>>the lightweight '73 RS weighs a good deal less and is a better balanced
>>race car. I don't consider tests showing that one car accelerates from 60
>>to 90 in top gear faster than another very important when evaluating a race
>>cars potential.
>
>Better balanced? Do you mean to say that Porsche got it right in '73 and
>changed to the worse for '88. I cannot believe my ears! Anti-evolution? The
>brakes are better, the suspension components, every f***ing mechanichal part
>in most cars are steadily developed towards better functioning and materials.

The '73 Carrera RS is a street legal race car. The '88 Carrera CS is a
slightly lightened poduction vehicle. The '73 Carrera RS has different
suspension pickup points on the rear and raised spindles on the front to
improve the roll center when the car is lowered. The '73 Carrera RS was
built this way so the RSR could take advantage of these features for
improved handling and braking characteristics.

The brakes on a '73 Carrera RS are better matched to the car than the brakes
on the '88 CS. The suspenion used on the production 911's did not change much
from '74 to '89. The only real changes were torsion and anit-sway bar sizes.
Brakes got bigger because the cars got heavier and heavier. You clearly have
no clue in this regard.

>The 60-80 in fourth gear was the *ONLY* of about 25 measurements between the
>Carrera RS and the Carrera CS that were in favor of the Carrera RS. The CS
>(Euro/ROW) version accelerates from 0-50mph in *5.1* seconds where the same
>year Turbo accelerates in *4.9*. Beats the carrera RS all the way up to top
>speed 151mph!
>
>That's the facts, if the car were altered for the US market, bad for you.

0-50 MPH in 5.1 seconds is not very impressive. I am fairly sure the '73
Carrera RS matched that. Straight line acceleration is a only one facet
of performance. Handling is the what makes the '73 Carrera RS so special.
How much speed you can carry out of a turn is more important than raw
acceleration.

>Porsche tried to reinvent the Carrera RS, the Euro/Rest Of the World version
>did,...however they decided to make the US version most suited to star in
>'Sloppey and the Bandit' with Burt Reynolds and Dame Edna in the main
>roles......   :-)

If the Carrera Club Sport was a successfull reincarnation of the '73 Carrera
RS, the car would have a large following today. Clearly, this is not the
case.

>guess I will have to scan in the road tests tomorrow???  :)

I would like to see the specs on the Euro Carrera CS, not the road tests.
How much does the car weigh? How is it different than the stock Euro
Carrera?

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 17:54:11 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: A quick question on hose clamps

At 02:25 PM 7/12/95 -0400, DrRSR@aol.com wrote:
>Some of these clamps are a. either difficult or impossible to find or b. very
>very expensive per/each.  I was able to reuse mine by carefully expanding
>them with a punch or other suitable tool.  First, you can just usually pull
>of the hose without removing the fitting.  Then, remove the clamp, expand and
>reuse.  If you don't expand them too much, you don't need the special tool to
>recrimp.  Simply sure a pair of dull wire cutters, more example.

I think you would be penny-wise and pound-foolish to work one off then
back on.  They're not designed for that sort of working the metal.  They are
not hard to find, nor are they expensive.  Porsche will sell them to you,
short money.  The aftermarketers, like Tweeks, have 'em too.

FWIW, I buy almost all of my own hard parts from PCNA, including and especially
the little stuff like fasteners.  It's the "right stuff," to use Carroll
Smith's phrase, I don't have to piss away time and money hunting high and 
low for alternate sources, and it's cheap.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 95 15:40:06 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Beware of the Yellow Oil


Really! Peeing in one's own oil! How rude!

First of all on the filter thing. I use AND recommend factory oil 
filters for most Porsches. Those excepted are the 914 and 924 as the 
VW and aftermarket *quality* filter DO work and can save some money.

Air filters should be as originally installed EXCEPT those miserable
oil bath crappers on the 914. I convert those to a PAPER element.

I use K&N filters for the track only. They work well and provide the low
restriction I want on the track. I put the PAPER element air filter in 
for my other driving as it keeps the countryside from visiting the 
inner tracts of my engine. 

For people with new engines to break in: Do an oil change at 500 miles,
change the filter with the oil. The go your regular interval. It doesn't
seem to make much difference whether you use your regular oil or not.
The reason for the early change is to inspect for any abnormal metal, 
sealing adhesive, assembly lube or crud that has worked loose since the 
engine was assembled. 

Exploding filters. haven't seen many except when the oil was so cruddy
that the passages and filter clogged. The big problem is the filter 
material splitting and no filtration occuring. Early 924 filters leaked 
because the oil pressure could reach 9.5 Bar when cold. The 914 with 
the big Melling oil pump can do this also. If you run an oil cooler
on ANY Porsche, put a 180 degree F oil thermostat in line before the 
cooler. This will prevent 100+ pounds of oil pressure from splitting the cooler. 911 coolers require an in-line thermostat. Same for 924/944/968.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 18:45:07 -0400
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: These Clamps Hurt!

Kevin and Mr. Baum,

I too like to do things right but don't like to throw away money.  The stress
on reused clamps-one time- I would think would be insignificant.  And, at
least on my '72S, pulling the old hoses off with the clamps on was no
problem.

As I recall on the '72 there were at least 2 sizes on clamps on the fuel/air
lines.  would this require 2 tools or does one tool fit all?  The Porsche
dealer had only one size clamp avaible when I checked, I believe and I think
they were 3 or 4 buck EACH, for a lousy little clamp.  I don't like to spend
my money that way.  You can.  Plus by reusing the clamps I didn't need the
special crimping tool.. By the way I have thousands in tools but didn't see
for one here.

Interesting to see the clamps generate so much interest.  

Baum Tools?  Now in the Florida Keys, No?  I think you used to be in Canoga
Park.  I went buy a few times when I used to live down there and then one
time you were gone.

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 18:45:56 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: re: ABS as standard equipment on PORSCHE cars

Mike,
Different models had ABS in different years.  Our 87 944T has ABS, and the
suspension was changed between 86 and 87 to accomodate it on 944s. 911's
didn't get it until the C4 came out (year?) then the C2, because of the
earlier 911 suspension design.  Don't know when the 928 got it. Of course,
the 959 had it, if you want to talk semi-production, non-US cars!

Jon Lowe

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 16:36:21 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: The real 911 ClubSport

>>The brakes on a '73 Carrera RS are better matched to the car than the brakes
>>on the '88 CS.
>
>Better match? How can you say so when you hardly saw one, never tried it.
>This is *besserwisser* attributes, and they almost s**k! This is getting
>ridicoulous, this is your typical no return style?! If you wanna believe
>what your writing, that's fine with me.

Trond, you are losing control here. The brakes on the Carrera CS are stock
'88 Carrera fair. Let's assume the '73 Carrera RS had the same calipers and
rotors as the '73 S (I don't know if the '73 RS had bigger brakes). That means
both Carreras have the same diameter rotors and the same size pads but the
Club Sport has thicker rotors. So, the 2700 lb. CS has better heat dissipation
than the 2200 lb. RS but less brake sweep area per pound. The CS weighs 23%
more than the RS. This is quite significant considering the sweep area.

>>from '74 to '89. The only real changes were torsion and anit-sway bar sizes.
>>Brakes got bigger because the cars got heavier and heavier. You clearly have
>>no clue in this regard.
>
>Hey, just because you're autox'ing your heavily modified 911, what gives you
>the right to point out who's got a clue or don't? Shit,...I give some facts
>here, like acceleration and cite respected auto journalist/book
>writers,...you go on gobbling about how great the Carrera RS was/is and how
>lousy the Carrera CS is. Facts man,...FACTS!

Trond, get a grip!! What does autocrossing have to do with this discussion?
You have no clue because you think Porsche made improvements in the suspension
components over the course of time ('74-'89). This is not the case. The RS
had superior suspension when compared to any of the non-turbo '74 to '89
cars. I
never said the CS was lousy. I said it was no '73 Carrera RS. The CS is a nice
car just like any 911 from that era.

>Concernig who's got the clue here,...I'm no 911 expert,...but I read when
>I'm unsure, I don't assume and guess! Yourself you're missing the curb
>weight by 100 pound, you stated 2700 Mike dug out 2600, then you assume that
>because I talk about the Carrera CS generally,...it has to be *THE* one as
>sold in the US a week ago or so. I for myself would much rather pick a '73
>if I could, but I'm not blind just because my taste might be so!!

I don't quote curb weights. I said 2700 lbs. and guess what? That is how much
the car really weighs (actually more like 2714 lbs). I am not blind. I hold no
dislike for the CS. It is a fine car. It is not as nice as the '73 Carrera RS.

>
>>0-50 MPH in 5.1 seconds is not very impressive. I am fairly sure the '73
>>Carrera RS matched that.
>Okay, you believe that,..but go home and check it!

"Excellence Was Expected" has some charts showing different magazines testing
the RS. The 0-60 times varied quite a lot. At least one of the rags had a
zero to 60 time in the 5.7 second range. That means the 0-50 had to be in the
zero to 4.7 range (plus or minus a couple of tenths).

>
>>Straight line acceleration is a only one facet
>>of performance. Handling is the what makes the '73 Carrera RS so special.
>>How much speed you can carry out of a turn is more important than raw
>>acceleration.
>Yes, and it is here such things as weight distribution, drag, braking power,
>body roll, aerodynamics, engine power is important!

Thanks for making my point!!

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 19:23:58 -0500 (CDT)
From: THOXNER@ualr.edu
Subject: RS Vs CS

I am at the office so I do not have all of the stats in front of me, but I
recall reading a road test of the CS in excellence. It was a Carrera with
about 150 lbs removed and lighter exhaust valves to raise rpm by a few hundred.
We could go back an forth arguing about which is better. I have not owned or
driven either, but I do believe that the all knowing amorphous "MARKET" is
wise enough to determine the validity of a product. Scott is correct in that
the 911 suspension was changed very little from 73 to 89. The improvements on
the RS suspension were never matched in the later 911's. The RS ran like
hotcakes, sold like hotcakes then and now. The CS was lees car for more money
and never sold. If only 26 were sold it was due to demand, not supply. I recall
seeing many RS's raced. If the CS are such great performers, why do you NEVER
see one win anything. If it were a winner from a performance standpoint, the
price would not stop some folks. THe bottom line is that the RS was a winner
and the CS was not.
Tom Oxner
85 911
72 911 (also with 3.2)
61 356

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 95 21:21:38 EDT
From: sdandeka@chipcom.com
Subject: Gray Market 911s


What is the general consensus on Gray Market 911s? I've seen two in the last
 week. One was a 1984 Targa with 65k miles (asking 14,900). It was in tough 
shape. I could not find most of the gears (maybe it me). The one I checked 
out tonight was a 1987 Targa with 72k miles (asking 18,000). In pretty good 
shape. Most everything worked. Body had only one ding on it. Engine seem
 very strong (from what I can tell). The clutch has been replace recently. It 
seemed like a good deal. 

TThe only real negatives were the oil tube were quite wet and the front trunk
was in disarray  (carpet was missing  there was some kind of electronic box
 in the front trunk). Also the VIN number tag was missing from the door
frame and the trunk area. I did find the riveted VIN number in the trunk which
had the "ZZZ" code.

I've read the section in the "Used 911 Buyers Guide" so I realize there is a lot
 to properly federalizing a 911. I wanted to know what kind of experiences
 people have had buying used gray market car. I plan on getting it checked
 out by a local Porsche shop but before I spring for that inspection I wanted
 to know if its just not worth the trouble.

I would have definitely bought the car if it was not a gray market model. However
I extremely apprehensive about going any further with this car.

Thank for any advice.

	-RISH-

<sdandeka@chipcom.com>

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 21:30:09 -0400 (EDT)
From: Mark Krieger <msk@unipress.com>
Subject: Re: Ooops - 914 FI Wiring!

Jerry,

Regarding your 914 wiring, I had a look at the shop book tonight.

Problem #1: The porsche factory books I have only go to 1975, and the 
distributor points are listed as going to 21, 12, 22 in left to right 
order. Since you show 22|24, 12, 22|24, I cannot help you on this one. I 
might try 22, 12, 24, but then I might blow it up by mistake doing this too.

Problem #2: This looks pretty much like rear window defroster from your 
description and from the wiring pictures I see in the book, especially 
the comments about green and red/yellow...and the fact that your car has 
em and Scot's doesn't: it's one of the few optional parts. As my 
teenager says about everything: "Donnn't worrrry about it!"

Good luck with this.

Mark

Mark Krieger          
UniPress Software     http://www.unipress.com

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 19:33:15 -0700
From: kemoto@nas.com (K E Motographics)
Subject: 3.2 911 Stalling

For several months, my '85 911 has randomly quit, ran fine for weeks,
started again, etc.  Idle perfomance is fine; the stalling occurs at
operating load and temp.  Fuel filter is clean.  Changed the DME relay.
Re-seated all electrical Motoronic connectors.  Recently, it does it more
frequently and is hard to restart.  Doesn't sound like fuel - more like
ignition since it is all-on and all-off.  It's presently in a
Bosch-authorized shop and won't exhibit the fault, at least when test
equipment is connected.  Might be there a long time at this rate.

Any ideas?  Does PCNA ever advise on hard-to-troubleshoot intermittant
faults?  The shop has a handfull of Bosch advisories but, of course, none
apply to this problem.

Ken Ehlers
P-less in Seattle

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 22:48:02 -0500 (EDT)

Phello P-philes,

Many thanks to all who offered their advise and/or support.  We have a
majority decision on #2, while #1 remains a mystery.

>Regarding your 914 wiring, I had a look at the shop book tonight.
>
>Problem #1: The porsche factory books I have only go to 1975, and the 
>distributor points are listed as going to 21, 12, 22 in left to right 
>order. Since you show 22|24, 12, 22|24, I cannot help you on this one. I 
>might try 22, 12, 24, but then I might blow it up by mistake doing this too.

The FI harness I am using is actually from a '70 1.7 D-jet engine, as a 
point of reference.  I talked to Brad Mayeur down in Illinois(who sold
me my current chassis and rebuilt my transaxle) - he is tracing one of
his harnesses tonight and is going to get back with me tomorrow.  I'll be
sure to post the result for posterity.

>Problem #2: This looks pretty much like rear window defroster from your 
>description and from the wiring pictures I see in the book, especially 
>the comments about green and red/yellow...and the fact that your car has 
>em and Scot's doesn't: it's one of the few optional parts. As my 
>teenager says about everything: "Donnn't worrrry about it!"

Yup.  I got two "rear window defroster" and one "heater blower motor"  It
*must* be for the defroster which explains the frayed ends and separate
(although small) harness.  As to the heater blower motor - I actually 
have two options - the '76 main engine harness has connections and so
does the secondary on the '70 - hmmm which one to use?  ;)

Put the swepco in the transaxle tonight(man, that stuff *stinks*) and had
better get her running soon(otherwise, Laura may change her mind about
marrying me - she's already wondering who I love more - her or the 914!)

Vacuum lines, ground straps, air cleaner(hey whats so bad about the oil
bath type!) and vroom.

Thanks for your attention,

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 21:51:25 -0500 (CDT)
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)
Subject: Re: Oil change every 2000 miles!

>
> Owners manual says 7500 mi between changes under standard conditions.
> 

Owner's manual also says (emphasis is mine):

    "Oil change intervals specified in the Warranty & Maintenance
    booklet accompanying the vehicle apply to *normal* operating
    conditions and must be adhered to, including intervals for
    oil filter change.
        If you drive mostly short distances, or if you operate the
    vehicle in dusty areas, or under predominantly stop-and-go
    traffic conditions, or when temperatures remain below freezing
    for extended periods, the engine oil should be changed more
    frequently."

Is your vehicle operated under "normal" conditions?  Or, is
your vehicle operated under what the warranty booklet calls
"severe" conditions (e.g., the second paragraph)?

I don't know of too many cars that are driven only on uncrowded
freeways, in dust-free conditions, on long trips, *and* when the
temperature remains 70 degrees F.  But, it's your car and your
money - you decide...

- -- 
mike
mjt@adc.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 21:42:50 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Gray Market 911s

> What is the general consensus on Gray Market 911s? 

Well, that's a good one for the "it depends" section... I put about six
years and 100,000 KM on an '81 911SC that I picked up in Weissbaden, had 
federalized there, and shipped back to the US. All without incident.
On the other hand, I've seen cars imported whole and federalized here
that were just nightmares...

> I've read the section in the "Used 911 Buyers Guide" so I realize there is a lot
>  to properly federalizing a 911. I wanted to know what kind of experiences
>  people have had buying used gray market car. I plan on getting it checked
>  out by a local Porsche shop but before I spring for that inspection I wanted
>  to know if its just not worth the trouble.

You don't know the half of it! It all depends on when the car was federalized
and who did the work. There was a *BRIEF* window in which very, very little
was required to federalize. The main rules involve DOT glass, seat belts,
and bumpers, plus aplicable EPA rules on emissions and local/state DMV
rules.

There are some *SERIOUS* advatages to the Euro spec cars, if the federalization
is done right. I kept (in fact, increased) the higher compression ratio
and compensated by using various 930 CIS components and custom recurving
the fuel distributor. Added an air pump, added a fake cat. Did some other
things best not talked about in a family publication. Wound up with about
250 HP instead of the 185 that a US spec car would have had. Also had
autobahn gearing, which meant low RPMs on the highway at the pathetic
US speed limits which was nice for gas milage, and meant that I could
just nearly nip 80 MPH in 2nd, which  had some serious autox advantages.

> I would have definitely bought the car if it was not a gray market model. However
> I extremely apprehensive about going any further with this car.

Here's my rule of thumb on this:

0) IS THE DOCUMENTATION COMPLETE??? If the answer is "no", then I'm probably
   going to give this a pass. In my case, the documentation included:

   last German title
   German bill of sale
   German statement of work on federalization
   translations of the above
   certificate that the translater was competent before the TuV to make such
   	translations
   shipping papers
   port of entry papers
   affidavit of physical inspection by Texas DMV
   certificate of compliance by the EPA
   certificate of compliance by the DOT
   original title application for non-titled car
   Texas title

   Now, in theory, all you *NEED* is the US title. However, if you ever get
   a visit from the EPA or DOT bearing a court order for a new inspection,
   it's *DAMN* handy to have the original paperwork... It's also very
   handy when your insurance company says that they can't insure the
   car because it's not US spec. At minimum, I'd want the EPA and DOT
   paperwork and I'd want to know who did the federalization and when.

1) what does my insurance company think. If this is going to give them gas,
   I'd like to know about it sooner rather than later. In my case, I used
   State Farm and had no trouble except needing to FAX them the document
   kit about every other year as some newbie would decide that my car was 
   all of a sudden a big problem.

2) what does my mechanic think. If you can get someone that can work on the
   car based on what it *IS* rather than what it's *SUPPOSED TO BE* (i.e.
   HINT: you can *NOT* tune up a somewhat modified Euro 911SC to US 911SC
   specs...) then you're OK.  Then again, this might be that excuse to
   really find a good wrench...

3) what do *I* think. In my case, the car was such a good deal that there was
   no way I could pass it up. DM 14,500 at a time when that would just about
   cover a trip to McDonalds... Today? I dunno.  I liked the extra power,
   I liked the funky Op Art velour upholstry that it had, and being in the biz
   kept having to custom engineer CIS repairs based on available parts
   from being too bad. I disliked the fact that nothing was easy, that it 
   was *NOT* a stock class car by the PCRs, and that some of the things on
   the car I had to obtain from Europe via the Porschephiles Buying Network.

Bottom line: there's nothing *wrong* with having a Euro car, some things
very *right* about doing so. But it's an individual choice, as are most
things...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 09:02:11 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: RE: Lap welds vs. butt welds



Pete,

I'll probably be the only person responding to say that a lap weld
can be better than a butt weld in this case. Here are the issues:

A lap weld leaves a seam that can wick in water and cause rust,
however a good body shop will coat the weld seam with zinc paste
which can be welded through and will "heal" to rust-protect the seam.
The factory uses *many* lap welds and they're generally fine.

A butt weld (or even hammer weld) is better if you can grind down both
sides and check for holes. It requires exact fittment of the panels to
keep from blowing through, and as an added precaution, I usually place
a piece of steel behind the seam I'm welding to absorb extra heat. If
you try to fill too wide a gap (> 1/8") you really make a mess. The 
back of the weld is going to be stalactites of weld, wire, and dripping
metal which in my opinion will attract rust more than a seam.

The welding process alone seems to change the carbon content in the 
weld area and make it more prone to rust. The zinc you can get into a
lap weld will help to prevent heat-related rust, where in a butt weld
even if you coat the back with zinc, most of it will burn away for 1/2"
on either side of the weld.

As I said, mine will probably be a minority opinion - so take it for
what it's worth. I'm currently replacing wheel arches and rockers on
an Alfa spider using the flange method.

Reid




------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 00:08:55 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: wiper parking for early 911/912

Ken

Thank Bog, someone finally addressed the *real* problem.  I thought I
might have to put up a post to sort it all out.  

So:  Park *isn't supposed* to be at the bottom?  I've been playing with
mine for a long while cause they park about an inch or two high off
the bottom position (which I was always assuming to be the correct
park position).  Since I like them low and out of the way I usually 
just do the old "manual park" by timing the downstroke.  Got real good
at it too.  

I still wish there were some way my wipers would park at the bottom
when I shut them off.  I am not overly concerned about start up strain
as I use these wipers so infrequently and try to keep them clen.

FYI my car is a 66 912.  Does this mean I have the welded style?
My spare parts catalog doesn't show this.  How did you find out 
the wipers were engineered to park high?  Hopefully not off some
mechanic that could not make them park in their rightful place.

A users "bug" is often called a "system enhancement" by the 
programmer. 


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

Subject: Help with 911 buying decision

Hello:

I am considering buying my first 911 and would appreciate any input
you can give me.  The car I am considering is a 80 911 Targa with 114K
miles on it.  The asking price is $14K.  I know I can get the guy down
to about $13k.  I am having an inspection done tomorrow to see if
there is anything obviously wrong with the car.  The inspection will
be the full 9 yards (compression test, body examination, etc).

The car hasn't had any modifications done to it (ie no Carrera Chain
tensioners...) but appears to be in good shape.  The Car has been
repainted but it appears to have been well done.  Targa top was
refinished last year and the car has had a new condensor installed for
the AC.  Currently is under the 2nd owner, he has had the car for at
least 4 years.  Has put about 12K miles on the car, and has not
replaced the clutch.  Don't know if it was replaced by the previous
owner.  Interior looks good, but not immaculate.

The prices I have seen thus far for 911s seem to be all over the
place.  Hemmings Motor News shows 911s in this same year running from
10K-25K.  My Blue Book shows the price being around $16K.  Locally not
many 911s have been for sale in my price range (under $15K) so I don't
have numerous examples to compare it to.

What would your advice to a first time Porsche buyer be?  Should I
consider this car further or walk away and search some more?  I am
asking for trouble with the high milage and (Gulp...) unknown clutch?

To cut down on unwanted bandwidth you can contact me directly.

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,

Ross Sabolcik

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 22:05:51 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: The real 911 ClubSport

Scott,

>than the 2200 lb. RS but less brake sweep area per pound. The CS weighs 23%
>more than the RS. This is quite significant considering the sweep area.

Yupp, and that seem to be the major drawback for the car,..maybe this is
where they missed then. Too heavy. The rest of the car seem potent. I did
not find the AutoMotor und Sport test from 87/88, but my basement has a
*lot* of car mags, but I'll find it.

Sticking to the facts as provided by different sources the CS had top speed
at 154mph, and 0-60 in 5.1, test drivers liked it and noted a significant,
but not brutal, difference from the carrera. If it was the hollow valve
stems, the modifications to the DME(?), or the 110 lbs less, wasn't stated.
Based on those criteria's I think it was a car with potential,.....as I
said, modifications for the States may have killed off a good thing!?

>>>Brakes got bigger because the cars got heavier and heavier. You clearly have
>>>no clue in this regard.
There are some facts you may have forgotten here,....material improvements
which can lead to better heat transfer from a hot disc, improved
calipers....improvements to the hydraulic system(brakes) etc. I do actually
understand that bigger brakes are neded for heavier cars, comparing brake
distances and tendency to fade on a track would be the only way to determine
whether RS or CS are better off on brake side.

>zero to 60 time in the 5.7 second range. That means the 0-50 had to be in the
>zero to 4.7 range (plus or minus a couple of tenths).
Read above, this was a typo from my side, it is *0-60* in 5.1 seconds, that
leaves the Carrera RS 0.5 seconds slower from 0 to 60.

>>Yes, and it is here such things as weight distribution, drag, braking power,
>>body roll, aerodynamics, engine power is important!
>
>Thanks for making my point!!

I don't think this speaks for the Carrera RS and against the CS, 

Positive racing attributes for the CS;(contra RS)
**************************************
 -Straight acceleration dominance, (a *big* plus out of curves, 0.5 a second
to 60, 2 seconds to 90)
 -The better cd values will give higher top speed at straights, and overall
less restriction 
 -Higher top speed ( 151-154mph )
 -Better spoilers rear and behind will increase downforce = higher curve
speeds! (better grip too!)

Possible negative attributes;
*****************************
 -Too soft suspension (not documented so far....)
 -Brakes (but a standard post '84 Carrera will not fade under *HEAVY* assault
at Nurburgring   old slope,...'Auto  Motor und  Sport' test against the
928S4 SOMETIME IN '86-'87,..i might dig it   up...W.Roerhl drove?)
 -Too heavy (but it outaccelerates the RS in all aspects)


I would love to read a comparison test, someone must have done this back in
'88 when the CS was launched as the successor of the RS. 

....maybe it is the heat  :)
Trond V.


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 22:18:31 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: 914 gurus - 

Miq,

>Aside from the battery and new shoes, what else should I plan on acquiring
>locally?

 -1 gallon fuel 'tank',...fill it, and feed the carbs instead of cranking the
new battery dead. 
 -If you suspect black sludge, empty oil and fill it up (almost full!) with
diesel oil and rotate it  for a while, either manually or by cranking.
You'll be surprised how much sh** that comes out, redo  if
neccesssary,..then pour in some 'el cheapo' oil and start engine,(crank or
manually first to get  oil around)...let it run for 5-10 minutes,...empty
'el cheapo' and fill her up with Castrol RX(?).
 The above is tested and never let me down,...but it's on your own risk..  ;)
 -A huge hammer, and a cowbar,...perhaps some porschephiler lives in the
area, maybe there is a  chance you could destroy his or her weekend if
problems increments??  :-) :-) :-)

>What is a good list of spares to take with me?
I leave this one to the 914 gurus....

Good luck and have a nice drive home,...no Cannonballing  ;)

Trond V.

understand *I* can explain, even to the uninitiated.

Date: Wed, 12 Jul 1995 22:31:10 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: RS Vs CS

Thoxner adds his 0.02,

>seeing many RS's raced. If the CS are such great performers, why do you NEVER
>see one win anything. If it were a winner from a performance standpoint, the
>price would not stop some folks. THe bottom line is that the RS was a winner
>and the CS was not.
>Tom Oxner

The Carrera was developed all the way, since the car was almost right in '88
only small modifications needed to make it more sporty was needed for the CS.

Things have changed too, in '73 there were no 300ZX, Supra's, Stealth's,
NSX, most manufacturers made economy cars, smogged their V8's, the Carrera
RS was just anti all that. And it was great!

Your point is not what we're discussing! We're not speaking of winners or
loosers here, merely performance fo a given car.

The CS lost out somewhere, but that does *NOT* change the facts;

It outaccelerates the RS in all cathegories.
It has a higher top speed.
It has better cd.
It has Carrera brakes,...which is as good as you normally get them.
It has more engine power.

*THAT* is what this discussionis about.

TV

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 08:22:14 -0400

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 09:08:28 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Autocross information - part7

Hi,

I have been asked to submit my columns on autocrossing Porsches
to the archives. Here is the seventh of nine(?) columns. Please let
me know if there are any mistakes or omissions, or other questions
that I should answer. I am editing and submitting them one at a time,
and will upload the whole thing after final editing.

There have been several requests for permission to use this material
in PCA newsletters, etc. Please ask before using it, but basically
any PCA use will be granted if the author is noted. If not too
difficult, I would like a copy of the publication with my material.


Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com
'72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0 (last two for sale soon)



	Three-Wheeling by Mike Piera			7/95

	Setting up a Porsche for stock class autocrossing : part 7

	In the first part of this series we put the car into the best possible
	condition for autocrossing without really modifying anything. Then we
	added the best wheels and tires in the second part. Now we will look
	at some items which can add even more improvements and still keep the
	car in stock class and allow the car to be driven on the street.

	There are several factory options that can make a big difference in
	autocross times. If any "sport suspension" package of springs (or 
	torsion bars) and/or sway bars was available for your year and model,
	it should be added. A factory Limited-Slip differential should be
	added to any front-engined Porsche if you are at all serious about
	winning. A limited slip can be used on a 911, but it is not
	cost-effective to add and may promote understeer. Judicious use of the
	throttle is much cheaper and may make you a better driver at the same
	time. Factory cloth sport seats should be added if they were available.
	They are lighter than standard seats, provide more "rear-end feedback",
	and will make you more comfortable while competing. 

	Any '85- 911 owner should order a FACTORY short-shifter kit TODAY if
	you don't already have one. They greatly improve the shift action and
	do not make it more difficult to shift on the street. They are also
	great on the earlier cars, but not legal in SCCA Stock because Porsche
	did not offer them until '85. Also any optional spoilers should be
	added (unless you are of the type who think they "spoil" the 
	appearance of your car). The small added weight should be more than 
	offset by the small handling improvements. 

	There are also some factory options to avoid. On any car
	with optional (not standard) air-conditioning, the compressor can be
	removed. The compressor is heavy in exactly the wrong part of the car,
	and can be re-installed if needed. Any other OPTIONS which add
	weight should be removed.

	The stock Porsche mufflers are quite efficient but tend to be heavy.
	SuperTrapp disk-type mufflers can be used to save weight and allow
	tuning of the back pressure. The exhaust gases pass around the
	disks and are dispersed to reduce noise level. Removing disks
	adds back-pressure and reduces noise level. Adding disks does the
	opposite. And it is very easy to remove all disks and run a basically
	open exhaust if it is legal at the event site. Changing the number of
	disks may alter the fuel mixture and torque characteristics of your
	engine, though. The street versions use a fiberglass-pack before the
	disks to further reduce the noise. On a car like a 944 turbo with
	catalytic converter (both the turbo and "cat" act as mufflers) the
	'glass-pack version may not be necessary. But even with the glass-pack,
	a 911 may be too loud for street driving. Most SuperTrapps do not come
	in an easy, bolt-on kit for Porsches, but a flange can be welded-on to
	make it bolt on. On some Porsches, like the Carrera 2 and 4, one or
	both of the stock mufflers can be "bypassed" with bolt-on bypass tubes
	which are readily available. This should be an easy way to lose weight
	and add a few horsepower.

	A larger front sway bar should be added to most stock-class Porsches.
	Get an adjustable version if possible. It is not legal in SCCA to use an
	adjustable early style though-the-body front bar on a late model 911
	because of the holes needed to mount it in a different position. But
	the '74-85 911 can use an '86-89 stock front bar which is bigger,
	inexpensive (from Porsche recyclers) and easy to install. A 944 can
	try a 944 turbo bar if cost is important, or an aftermarket adjustable
	bar. The hot setup would be an adjustable hollow bar, which is much
	lighter and almost as stiff as a solid bar of the same diameter. But
	be careful of stiff front sway bars on a 924/944 with steel a-arms,
	as they tend to break the mounts and can cause accidents. An
	early (pre-74) 911, 914 or 914-6 will handle great with a 19mm
	adjustable front sway bar. The H & H bar is inexpensive and reliable.

	A leather shift-knob can actually help fast shifting in an autocross
	situation. I have bruised my hand on stock hard plastic knobs while
	panic shifting. On an older Porsche, the shifter bushings should be
	replaced with new ones to further aid in precise shifting. A 1" 
	smaller diameter sport steering wheel like one of the various Momo
	models is an advantage. It will allow faster steering and more
	clearance around the legs and door for wild-flying hands. 
	Stay away from the aftermarket chips, which are illegal anyway in
	stock classes and are mostly "cash flow devices".

	The biggest improvement can be made by correctly balancing the handling
	characteristics of over/understeer (The definition of understeer is
	when the driver is scared, oversteer is when the passenger is scared).
	This balancing is done on a stock class car by adjusting the front
	sway bar, or by changing tire pressures or suspension alignment
	settings. Some drivers thrren)
Subject: Re: Wiper parking and alignment

RedNineCo@aol.com wrote: 

>It would be neat to get the wiperblades off a car from the UK(right 
>hand drive) and turn the eletric motor around and park the wipers to 
>the right instead of the left like the RTH drive european cars.

.. and like all the old racing Porsches.

 -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 09:08:28 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Autocross information - part7

Hi,

I have been asked to submit my columns on autocrossing Porsches
to the archives. Here is the seventh of nine(?) columns. Please let
me know if there are any mistakes or omissions, or other questions
that I should answer. I am editing and submitting them one at a time,
and will upload the whole thing after final editing.

There have been several requests for permission to use this material
in PCA newsletters, etc. Please ask before using it, but basically
any PCA use will be granted if the author is noted. If not too
difficult, I would like a copy of the publication with my material.


Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com
'72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0 (last two for sale soon)



	Three-Wheeling by Mike Piera			7/95

	Setting up a Porsche for stock class autocrossing : part 7

	In the first part of this series we put the car into the best possible
	condition for autocrossing without really modifying anything. Then we
	added the best wheels and tires in the second part. Now we will look
	at some items which can add even more improvements and still keep the
	car in stock class and allow the car to be driven on the street.

	There are several factory options that can make a big difference in
	autocross times. If any "sport suspension" package of springs (or 
	torsion bars) and/or sway bars was available for your year and model,
	it should be added. A factory Limited-Slip differential should be
	added to any front-engined Porsche if you are at all serious about
	winning. A limited slip can be used on a 911, but it is not
	cost-effective to add and may promote understeer. Judicious use of the
	throttle is much cheaper and may make you a better driver at the same
	time. Factory cloth sport seats should be added if they were available.
	They are lighter than standard seats, provide more "rear-end feedback",
	and will make you more comfortable while competing. 

	Any '85- 911 owner should order a FACTORY short-shifter kit TODAY if
	you don't already have one. They greatly improve the shift action and
	do not make it more difficult to shift on the street. They are also
	great on the earlier cars, but not legal in SCCA Stock because Porsche
	did not offer them until '85. Also any optional spoilers should be
	added (unless you are of the type who think they "spoil" the 
	appearance of your car). The small added weight should be more than 
	offset by the small handling improvements. 

	There are also some factory options to avoid. On any car
	with optional (not standard) air-conditioning, the compressor can be
	removed. The compressor is heavy in exactly the wrong part of the car,
	and can be re-installed if needed. Any other OPTIONS which add
	weight should be removed.

	The stock Porsche mufflers are quite efficient but tend to be heavy.
	SuperTrapp disk-type mufflers can be used to save weight and allow
	tuning of the back pressure. The exhaust gases pass around the
	disks and are dispersed to reduce noise level. Removing disks
	adds back-pressure and reduces noise level. Adding disks does the
	opposite. And it is very easy to remove all disks and run a basically
	open exhaust if it is legal at the event site. Changing the number of
	disks may alter the fuel mixture and torque characteristics of your
	engine, though. The street versions use a fiberglass-pack before the
	disks to further reduce the noise. On a car like a 944 turbo with
	catalytic converter (both the turbo and "cat" act as mufflers) the
	'glass-pack version may not be necessary. But even with the glass-pack,
	a 911 may be too loud for street driving. Most SuperTrapps do not come
	in an easy, bolt-on kit for Porsches, but a flange can be welded-on to
	make it bolt on. On some Porsches, like the Carrera 2 and 4, one or
	both of the stock mufflers can be "bypassed" with bolt-on bypass tubes
	which are readily available. This should be an easy way to lose weight
	and add a few horsepower.

	A larger front sway bar should be added to most stock-class Porsches.
	Get an adjustable version if possible. It is not legal in SCCA to use an
	adjustable early style though-the-body front bar on a late model 911
	because of the holes needed to mount it in a different position. But
	the '74-85 911 can use an '86-89 stock front bar which is bigger,
	inexpensive (from Porsche recyclers) and easy to install. A 944 can
	try a 944 turbo bar if cost is important, or an aftermarket adjustable
	bar. The hot setup would be an adjustable hollow bar, which is much
	lighter and almost as stiff as a solid bar of the same diameter. But
	be careful of stiff front sway bars on a 924/944 with steel a-arms,
	as they tend to break the mounts and can cause accidents. An
	early (pre-74) 911, 914 or 914-6 will handle great with a 19mm
	adjustable front sway bar. The H & H bar is inexpensive and reliable.

	A leather shift-knob can actually help fast shifting in an autocross
	situation. I have bruised my hand on stock hard plastic knobs while
	panic shifting. On an older Porsche, the shifter bushings should be
	replaced with new ones to further aid in precise shifting. A 1" 
	smaller diameter sport steering wheel like one of the various Momo
	models is an advantage. It will allow faster steering and more
	clearance around the legs and door for wild-flying hands. 
	Stay away from the aftermarket chips, which are illegal anyway in
	stock classes and are mostly "cash flow devices".

	The biggest improvement can be made by correctly balancing the handling
	characteristics of over/understeer (The definition of understeer is
	when the driver is scared, oversteer is when the passenger is scared).
	This balancing is done on a stock class car by adjusting the front
	sway bar, or by changing tire pressures or suspension alignment
	settings. Some drivers think a slightly oversteering car is fastest.
	But actually a SLIGHT understeer condition is usually fastest, if not
	quite as much fun. Also, a slightly understeering car will be faster
	in a slalom. When driving at 99% of the car's limits, you will
	be forced to go to 101% occasionally. If your car oversteers you
	will spin-out, or lose time when the rear end of the car comes out.

	To reduce excessive understeer the following can be done. Start with
	the first items which are easy to try one at a time at an event.
	If it is still not enough, try the later items.

	TO REDUCE UNDERSTEER :

	Change the front or rear tire pressures *
	Loosen the front sway bar (try small 1/4" increments)
	Try a larger tire or wheel width on the front if possible
	Add more negative camber in front (or less negative camber in rear)
	Add some front toe-out (or decrease rear toe-in)

	* Which way do you change tire pressures for more grip? 
	Normally you raise them. But with the new BFGs, if you are already
	at a fairly high pressure, lowering them may make them stick better.
	To reduce understeer, change the front pressures for more grip,
	or the rear pressures for less grip.

	TO REDUCE OVERSTEER, try the following :

	Change the front or rear tire pressures *
	Tighten the front sway bar (try small 1/4" increments)
	Try a larger tire or wheel width on the rear if possible.
	Add more negative camber in rear (or less negative camber in front)
	Add some rear toe-in (or decrease front toe-out)

	Note that in VERY slow corners, almost all cars will understeer, and
	this can not be tuned out. Using first gear may help, and slowing down
	enough so you can make it through and accelerate out is the best
	solution.

More to come!  Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com (see you in Harrisburg, PA)

I was at the alignment shop yesterday to finally get the four wheel
alignment that I desprately needed but it was to late....the insides of my
front tires are worn far beyond spec. Between that and the fact that my tie
rod ends are on there way to being shot I decided that it was not the best
to complete the alignment until these items have been rectified.

The question that I have for the list came up in the discussion with the
fellow who was trying to find the specs for my car to complete the
alignment. My drivers manual specs 0 toe in, the alignment shops specs said
0 toe in, but the Ray Scruggs guide to home alignment in his suggested specs
he would like 1/8" toe in...Does anyone have any opinions on this or has
specs of there own that they could post? I don't race the car, I just put a
lot of highway miles on my car each day....

Thanks,

Peter Rosvall

_______________________________________________________________________________
Subject: re: ABS as standard equipment on PORSCHE cars
Author:  JonLowe@aol.com
Date:    7/12/95  7:01 PM

Mike,
Different models had ABS in different years.  Our 87 944T has ABS, and the
suspension was changed between 86 and 87 to accomodate it on 944s. 911's
didn't get it until the C4 came out (year?) then the C2, because of the
earlier 911 suspension design.  Don't know when the 928 got it. Of course,
the 959 had it, if you want to talk semi-production, non-US cars!

Jon Lowe

is not as hot.

had the fan on high. He told me it was probably one of the boxes that
control the flaps for routing the air coming out of the A/C or a hose 
that had a vaccum leak. I guess it has deteriorated even more because 
this hot air problem was not there two days ago. I have also noticed 
the cruise control acts up sometimes, specially if I put the A/C on 
defrost...again vacumm leak.

are to get to (do we have to take apart the dash?). Also how do I find

more heat and the workshop manuals are on back order...help!

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 04:42:34 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: RE: RS Vs CS

>Let me get this straight-This is the best 911 made an yet no one bought it,
>or even bothered to develop it? Something seems to a little out of kilter
>here. The CS was lighter exhaust valves , a little less weight and some hokey
>graphics. If you think it is great, I am glad for you. But the rest of the
>world has a different opinion. BTW I am able to read you messages the first
>time, i do not need to have them sent to me twice. 
>Tom Oxner

About double messages;
Didn't strike you I cc'ed the list? If you wanna do something about this
problem, everyone seem to both cc the list and the person in question, start
a discussion about it. I wouldn't mind.

I wish people read messages before they spoke,......again.....'best or
greatest 911'?

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 08:56:43 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Re: Re: Outside mirrors for a '72 T

Rob Yasek said:

> I thought that '72s only had the driver's side mirror. That's all my '73
> has.

I've seen both mirrors on other cars.  I'm assumed that the right side
mirror was an option.

When I got my car, it had aftermarket mirrors on both sides.  They
look like they were both installed in the locations provided by the
factory (i.e., an access hole on the inside to get at the bolts you
have to tighten), but they were of a design that made the right side
mirror impossible to use, because it was completely blocked by the 
"A" pillar.  The original equipment mirrors look like they are
positioned toward the back of the mounting bracket, so you can
actually use the right-hand one.  The round mirrors from the '69
vintage cars, the ones I have on the car now, are similarly positioned
toward the back of the mounting bracket, but I'd like to get the
"correct" mirrors for the car.

- --Walt Thode

Miq,

I'll leave your _fastener_ question to Stan.  I just got back from a 1200 mile 
trip in my brand "new" 73 1.7 ($700).  Course it took about $2K to get it to 
where it was "safe" to drive without dropping a trailing arm.  2 days, no 
copilot, no stereo; just the hum of the flat IV and the top off.  Kickass!

What I brought (after much advice from the list) in no particular order:

Big flashlight (which was key when the pin holding my throttle pedal worked its 
way out at 2 a.m. in the rain)
Fuses 8 and 25 amp
Fire Extinguisher (oil/fire; I think SCCA or PCA are going away from Halon)
Hoses and clamps
Utility knife
Oil
Brake fluid (DOT 4)
Clutch and throttle cables
Spare plugs & ignition wires
Rags
Duct tape
Jumper cables
Jack & blocks
Rain-X (real lifesaver with those teeny wipers; also brought anti-fog for 
inside)
Basic tools

I'm sure there's other stuff that would be useful to have along but that's what 
I brought.

Good luck, and may the Porsche be with you!
Thwen.

Message-Id: <199507122124.AA65694@ptdis7>

------------------------------

ink a slightly oversteering car is fastest.
	But actually a SLIGHT understeer condition is usually fastest, if not
	quite as much fun. Also, a slightly understeering car will be faster
	in a slalom. When driving at 99% of the car's limits, you will
	be forced to go to 101% occasionally. If your car oversteers you
	will spin-out, or lose time when the rear end of the car comes out.

	To reduce excessive understeer the following can be done. Start with
	the first items which are easy to try one at a time at an event.
	If it is still not enough, try the later items.

	TO REDUCE UNDERSTEER :

	Change the front or rear tire pressures *
	Loosen the front sway bar (try small 1/4" increments)
	Try a larger tire or wheel width on the front if possible
	Add more negative camber in front (or less negative camber in rear)
	Add some front toe-out (or decrease rear toe-in)

	* Which way do you change tire pressures for more grip? 
	Normally you raise them. But with the new BFGs, if you are already
	at a fairly high pressure, lowering them may make them stick better.
	To reduce understeer, change the front pressures for more grip,
	or the rear pressures for less grip.

	TO REDUCE OVERSTEER, try the following :

	Change the front or rear tire pressures *
	Tighten the front sway bar (try small 1/4" increments)
	Try a larger tire or wheel width on the rear if possible.
	Add more negative camber in rear (or less negative camber in front)
	Add some rear toe-in (or decrease front toe-out)

	Note that in VERY slow corners, almost all cars will understeer, and
	this can not be tuned out. Using first gear may help, and slowing down
	enough so you can make it through and accelerate out is the best
	solution.

More to come!  Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com (see you in Harrisburg, PA)

Date: 	Thu, 13 Jul 1995 08:07:35 -1000
From: A D Castberg <castberg@uhunix.uhcc.Hawaii.Edu>
Subject: Re: wiper parking for early 911/912



On Wed, 12 Jul 1995 MKUEFEL@delphi.com wrote:

> Ken
> 
> Thank Bog, someone finally addressed the *real* problem.  I thought I
> might have to put up a post to sort it all out.  
> 
> So:  Park *isn't supposed* to be at the bottom?  I've been playing with
> mine for a long while cause they park about an inch or two high off
> the bottom position (which I was always assuming to be the correct
> park position).  Since I like them low and out of the way I usually 
> just do the old "manual park" by timing the downstroke.  Got real good
> at it too.  
> 
> I still wish there were some way my wipers would park at the bottom
> when I shut them off.  I am not overly concerned about start up strain
> as I use these wipers so infrequently and try to keep them clen.
> 
> FYI my car is a 66 912.  Does this mean I have the welded style?
> My spare parts catalog doesn't show this.  How did you find out 
> the wipers were engineered to park high?  Hopefully not off some
> mechanic that could not make them park in their rightful place.
> 
> A users "bug" is often called a "system enhancement" by the 
> programmer. 
> 
> 
> Mark W Kuefel
> mkuefel@delphi.com
> 
> 
This has worked for me on everything from a 356B to a 911SC:  simply 
remove the wiper assembly and put it back on in the position you want the 
blades to rest.  You have to take off the cover over the large nut that 
holds each blade assembly on with some models, other models don't have 
the cover.  The assembly attaches to the motor via a splined male/female 
attachment, so just moving the assembly one or two splines down will 
usually be enough to have the wiper blades rest just at the windshield 
molding.  The downside of this is that the blades become deformed easily, 
as they are not resting on a flat surface anymore but rather partially on 
the windshield and partially off.  If you don't use them frequently, this 
could be a problem (it isn't here, where we have about 130 inches of rain 
per year).

Rick Castberg
Hilo, Hawaii

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 95 09:35:00 PDT
From: Patrick Buddenbaum <Patrick_Buddenbaum@ccm.fm.intel.com>
Subject: 911 clicking and groaning


Text item: 911 clicking and groaning




  Greeting P-philes:
  I'm looking for some assistance to diagnose two early/potential problems
  on my '84 911 Carrera.  Car is still driveable, but I want to fix these
  before something bad happens (to the car, myself, or others).

  Symptom: Hear faint clicking from left rear wheel while driving.
  Intermittent, possibly independent of wheel speed, though I think it
  occurs at all speeds (road noise prevents me from hearing it at higher
  speeds).
  Cause: CV joint ???
  Fix: If CV joint - repack :-)? or replace :-(?

  Symptom: When slowing to a stop (coasting the last few feet) with foot
  off brake/gas/clutch, a *groan* is emitted from the front wheel(s).  Once
  again, very intermittent, usually occurs after have been driving a while.
  Tapping the brakes may or may not make the sound go away.  Feel a slight
  shudder through the steering wheel.  Occurs more often when I turn the
  wheels, such as coasting into my driveway, though also happens on
  straight stops, like coasting into my garage or up to a stop sign/light.
  Cause:  Frozen piston :-)???, warped rotor :-(???
  Fix: ?

  Any and all suggestions would be greatly appreciated.  Want to make sure
  the baby is in good shape for the Parade here in  sunny (this week,
  anyway) Portland.

  Thanks!
  Pat Buddenbaum
  pbuddenb@inside.intel.com
  '84 911 Carrera coupe

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 95 13:52:58 EDT
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: Oil coolers

Have done both ways:  Complete kit (Terbatrol, purchased direct, lots less
than $1300) in 77 Targa; piece parts in Porsche-engined Vanagon, including
the Automotion oil cooler.  Piece parts approach gets expensive in time
and dollars as you need the right hoses made up and you also need a 
thermostat.  Thermostat is also in the Automotion catalog.  Hoses are not;
I went to a hydraulic supply place after confirming that they had metric
fittings, which not all do.  Hoses for the Vanagon (about 15' long each way)
were $200, but they used VERY nice cadmium plated fittings that are
probably dissipating as much heat as the cooler itself.  You need four
hoses, two short (engine and oil tank to thermostat) and two long (thermo-
stat to front cooler and back).

Both cars are happy with their coolers; in your situation I would get the
Terbatrol without hesitation, unless I could steal a complete stock setup
including the "hard lines" (pipes) that Porsche uses, at a swap meet.
If you do the piece parts approach you have to measure things and do a
bunch of planning and purchasing that the Terbatrol people have already 
done.

Good luck either way.
B.
Wm Kennedy
kennedy@admin.njit.edu

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 18:27:03 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: More on Club Sports...

Hey,

I just found an article in the 1989 Road & Track "Special Series"
booklet on Porsche in which Paul Frere tests a European 911 Club
Sport.

I don't mean to add any fuel to this fire, but here are some
interesting things :

1.  It did not have paint work similar to the '73 RSs.  It has the same
     decal on the left front fender as the US model.  It appears to be
     devoid of any other markings.

2.  Power was unchanged from the standard Carrera - 231hp/207lb-ft
     (we already knew that).

3.  It says that the hollow valves and firmer shocks were the only changes.
     (aside from deleting a bunch of stuff).

4.  The car was 220lbs lighter than a *fully equipped* standard Carrera.  It
     was only 110-120lbs lighter than the base version.

5.  It says that the particular test car he drove was shod with 6x16 and
     8x16 wheels with the normal 205/55s and 225/50s F/R.

6.  0-60 was 5.3 sec, with a top speed of 154.3mph.

Unfortunately, that's about it.  The article was more of a "review" than
a road test.  It was a Euro car for sure, though and had no "Carrera" script
or lettering on the sides, etc.

I personally thought it was good idea when it came out, but IMO it was
more of a marketing ploy, where the '73 RS conceived *purely* with
competition in mind.

I'd gladly take either one...

Mike

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 10:43:43 -0500 (CDT)
From: gwj@louie.timeplex.com (Gregg Jensen)
Subject: Re: Oil coolers

>> Does anyone have any experience with putting a front oil cooler on a 2.7
>> liter engine?  I have a 77 911s and yesterday it was 105 (really) here in
>> Kansas City.  Driving home through traffic heated up the old engine quite a
>> bit (it was at 250).  I've been thinking about a front oil cooler and
>> wondered if anyone had any recommendations.  The one I saw in the Automotion
>> catalog was $1300 with a mounting kit.  They also had some other coolers
>> that were called "Deluxe oil coolers."  They ranged from $135 to $200.  I
>> don't think they came with hookups and a mounting kit, etc.  Can I put one
>> of these in my car?  $200 sounds a lot better than $1300.  What other kind
>> of stuff would I need to mount it and hook it up, etc?  Or do I need the
>> expensive one?  Thanks...

FWIW, I have a 77 911S also (my 2.7 was as bad as everyone says ;-( so I 
upgraded to a 3.2 ;-) ), and mine was as bad as everyone says ;-( ), and I
put a Terbetrol (sp?) on.  It was around $800 if I remember correctly and it
came with everything needed to install. I did have exchange one of the hoses,
as my setup was a little different. But they sent the other promptly (within
a day).  This oil cooler took my temp down from 250 to under 210 on really
hot days (St. Louis). 

These coolers are advertised in Excellence and I think Pano.  I recommend
them if the price fits your budget.

Gregg
gwj@louie.timeplex.co

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 95 15:50:54 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 911/914/6 Aircleaners, etc.


I've owned both the carburated 914/6 and the MFI 911. My findings were 
thus:

When on the track, the K&Ns worked very well. On the street, the MFI had
a few stumble problems and the carbs had crud get into the air 
correction jets. I went back to the paper element and the problems went 
away. The K&Ns pass more air and do a more than adequate job for the 
track. Paper does a better filtration job but is slightly more 
restrictive as a result.

When running either, inspect on a regular basis, clean or replace when 
they get clogged.

For the MFI, the 72-73 cars have a connection to the heat exchanger for 
passing warm air to the engine. This unit works interactively at all 
times improving driveability. If you have the rubber connection boot 
removed, consider replacing it. Inspect the driver's side (left) heat
exchanger for holes or damage that would keep the exchanger from warming the intake air. The down side is that the inlet is not filtered air at that point. I have added flexible tubing and run a hose to the top side 
of the engine sheet metal to reduce the road grunge pulled through the 
air warmer section. 

Many Porsche enthusiasts do not consider the pre 1974 911 engine to be 
a "smog" engine, yet it was for the US market. All of the little pieces 
of hardware are required for the California visual inspection each time 
you get a certificate for registration purposes. If you aren't sure 
about what is required, the California Air Resources Board has a manual
that has each model listed and each iteration, yearly or model, 
specifically described or pictured. There are some fine points for a 
split year, such as the 1973 911T which had both MFI and CIS in the same 
model year.

Technically, unless K&N has a CARB exemption for the aircleaner element, 
a non-paper element can fail you. The better inspection stations treat 
this as a direct replacement part. The lower restriction can alter the 
flow characteristics enough to make adjustment difficult. As much as I 
like to tinker, I always had to return the 914/6 carbs back to stock  
configuration to pass the bi-annual inspection. They just wouldn't come 
close to passing otherwise. And of course I returned them to my favorite
configuration afterwards.

The early K&N for carb and MFI had a straight plat for the top and a 
machined plate for the bottom. In either the 911 0r 914/6 water could 
(and did) go down the carbs causing other problems. They quickly came up with the hooded solution we now can purchase. These work well except on 
the '73 MFI. On the MFI cars, I use the round type cleaner in the stock 
housing. Some of the ancient Mercedes used the same round filter.

Jim Pasha

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 13:03:05 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: wiper parking for early 911/912

With all due respect, I'd caution against this.  The wiper's constant
hitting of the windshield rubber and molding will cause scars, plus
undue wear on the wiper blade.  Remember, that in the heat of action,
a wiper will exceed its path by a little bit each time as it changes
direction.  That's why there's clearance in the first place.

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

Trond et. al.

At the risk of keeping this contest going a bit more, I'll add the following.

When you (collective) say 231 HP for the Euro spec model do you mean SAE or 
DIN?  I know, for example, that my Euro spec '82 SC is listed as 204 hp DIN in 
the owners manual while the same year US spec is listed (I believe) as 180 hp 
SAE.  This does NOT mean that mine has 24 hp SAE more than my US counterparts.  
The SAE hp difference is a bunch (measurable anyways) less than that.

Perhaps you (collective again) could be specific about what scale you are 
referring to when discussing things like this.

But what's up with this description on that page: 

"If the frequency is not an authorized police frequency, the INTERCEPTOR
sends back a signal at low power. That signal simulates a vehicle rapidly
decelerating or accelerating to phenomenal speeds so the radar gun dismisses
it as an error. This occurs rapidly and alerts you to the presence of radar
with an adjustable tone and warning lights. Since the radar gun's target
speed reading is blank, you have all the time you need to adjust your speed."

Does it leave you naked to *authorized* frequencies, or are they just
covering their asses in their advertising?
