Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 22:28:59 -0600
From: "Bill  Hutton" <us009904@interramp.com>
Subject: Re: 911/914/6 Aircleaners, etc.

JIm wrote:


>  
> For the MFI, the 72-73 cars have a connection to the heat exchanger 
> for passing warm air to the engine. This unit works interactively at 
> all times improving driveability. If you have the rubber connection 
> boot removed, consider replacing it. Inspect the driver's side (left) 
> heat exchanger for holes or damage that would keep the exchanger 
> from warming the intake air. The down side is that the inlet is 
> not filtered air at that point. I have added flexible tubing and run 
> a hose to the top side of the engine sheet metal to reduce the road 
> grunge pulled through the air warmer section. 
>  
>
For the record, all MFI cars (70,17 2,2 l) have this temperature sensing 
ductwork. Correct function is critical for proper operation. The car will run 
rich if the integrety of the system Jim describes is compromized.

Bill Hutton


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 21:22:56 -0400
From: Phyl346@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 bal/belt ?????

Boy! does George B. speak the truth on this one. 

Bought my '83 944 w/ 78K on it.  Did lots of maintenance including the belts
which I tensioned by eyeball. 

I was lucky!!!

Within about 15K I started hearing a metallic tapping coming from the upper
balance shaft's rear bearing.  To make a long story short, I had over
tightened the bal belt.  After completely replacing the bearings, belts,
seals, races, etc, etc.    I broke down and purchased the 9201 gauge (which
George B. graciously instructed me how to use).  It's very expensive, but not
nearly as much as the noises your engine will produce if (read *when*) you
have a belt break due to incorrect tensioning.  The interesting thing is that
the tension I had set by eyeball was too loose on the cam belt and way too
tight on the balance shaft belts even though they *eyeballed* about the same.

Your choices:

Either pay the mechanic, take the chance (not recommended), buy the gauge, or
*rent* it from me.

Email me for the details

Phil Carr
Austin, Tx 
'83 944
'65 M.G. Midget
'70  BMW R60/5 

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 16:53:35 -0400
From: ChannellR@aol.com
Subject: Re: toe in or not to toe in

Peter Rosvall wrote:

>My drivers manual specs 0 toe in, the alignment shops specs said
>0 toe in, but the Ray Scruggs guide to home alignment in his suggested specs
>he would like 1/8" toe in...Does anyone have any opinions on this or has
>specs of there own that they could post? I don't race the car, I just put a
>lot of highway miles on my car each day....

I was going to go with 0 toe in on the front for my alignment but Galen
Bridges  (Porsche mechanic in Atlanta) has talked me out of it. (My
recollection of) His rationale was that ANY toe out was not good for
stability at speed and that the tie rod ends can give enough to create toe
out if they are set up for 0 toe at rest.He recommends a slight toe in.

If you have to replace the tie rod ends anyway, the turbo style tie rod ends
are stiffer and will not give as much. IMVHO I'd use them.  My car will have
1/8"-1/10" toe in when I get it back as well as turbo style tie rods. I'll
let you know how it works later if you like.

Rob Channell
channellr@aol.com
1979 911SC (turbo tail and tie rod ends :^)

PS. Love the list


------------------------------

Date: 	Thu, 13 Jul 1995 12:38:29 -1000
From: A D Castberg <castberg@uhunix.uhcc.Hawaii.Edu>
Subject: Re: wiper parking for early 911/912



On Thu, 13 Jul 1995, Steven Gilbert wrote:

> With all due respect, I'd caution against this.  The wiper's constant
> hitting of the windshield rubber and molding will cause scars, plus
> undue wear on the wiper blade.  Remember, that in the heat of action,
> a wiper will exceed its path by a little bit each time as it changes
> direction.  That's why there's clearance in the first place.
> 
Perhaps I was unclear in my original post, as I have received two 
messages cautioning against what I recommended.  As I said before, I have 
done this for three different Porsches, and it worked on all three.  It 
is a trial and error procedure, and you have to adjust it so that the 
park position is satisfactory and the extreme downward (to the left) 
sweep does not hit the windshield trim.  It can be done.  My park 
position is about two inches above the molding and the extreme downward 
sweep does not quite hit the rubber molding.  It may well be that certain 
models have greater differences between the two positions than others, 
but I doubt it.  Try it - it's a lot easier than putting in a new motor 
or reversing the current one.

FOR SALE: I have a 911 chassis which has been extensively modified for 
competition use and it must go...I'm out of room. The car started life 
as a '71 non-sunroof coupe which has never been in an accident nor does 
it have any rust. Modifications include: full IMSA spec roll cage tied 
into all door jambs pillars and shock towers, set-up for coil over RSR 
suspension, fully adjustable mounting for turbo trailing arms, Bracketing 
for upside down transmission, bracketing for rear entry motor 
configuration and 935 rear spring plates w/ heim joints. This car has 
been prepared with serious competition in mind. The craftsmanship is 
beautiful and the welds are georgeous. In addition to all the 
fabrication work that has been done the car has been fully seam welded. 
It woiuld cost over $10,000 to reproduce what I have collectig dust in 
my garage. I want to see the car go to someone who will build and race 
it. I am asking $4500 for the chassis and a few spare parts, considering 
all the time and materials that were put into this car this is a steal.

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 95 15:22:49 CDT

Subject: 73.5 911T CIS Conundrum

I am new to porschephiles so please go easy on my ignorance.

Here is my problem:

I have a 73.5 CIS 911T with many of the S options.  The car has 50,000 original
miles and has been kept in very good condition.  However I have been having
severe problems with cold starts and backfiring.  The mechanic I took the 
car to for major service shortly after I purchased it (about a month ago)
sez the problem lies in the CIS.  The airbox has a popoff valve that has
blow at least once, so it looks like the problem has occured before.  He
said they could slowly replace various pieces of the system and I might
be able to get out for a few hundred dollars or of as much as a $1000 but
he suggested replacing the CIS with dual weber carbs (new).  He quoted the 
work at about $1800 total which sounds steep to me.  He also said a third 
option would be to fit it with an EFI system but that would cost even more
in parts and labor.  I trust the compentency of the mechanics but I 
do not trust their pricing.  My question is what to do and how much 
should it cost for each solution.  What are the pros/cons of each   
solution.

My only concern about moving to dual carbs is the fact that the car
is about as straight as they come.  The mechanics assured me that it
could be converted back if need be if for some reason I sold it and
the buyer wanted it straight.

Any constructive insight will be gratefully received.

Yes it does. The Carrera RS had better weight distribution, similar cd,
better braking power, less body roll, and less pounds per HP (10.48 for the
RS versus 11.69 for Euro CS versus 12.62 for U.S. CS). Add to this the
superior suspension geometry and you have the makings of a clearly better
race car.

>Positive racing attributes for the CS;(contra RS)
>**************************************
>-Straight acceleration dominance, (a *big* plus out of curves, 0.5 a second
>to 60, 2 seconds to 90)
>-The better cd values will give higher top speed at straights, and overall
>less restriction
>-Higher top speed ( 151-154mph )
>-Better spoilers rear and behind will increase downforce = higher curve
>speeds! (better grip too!)

The acceleration difference could be attributed, and list a lot of it, to
the tire quality between '73 and '88. The other points you mention are
not significant.

>Possible negative attributes;
>*****************************
>-Too soft suspension (not documented so far....)
>-Brakes (but a standard post '84 Carrera will not fade under *HEAVY* assault
>at Nurburgring   old slope,...'Auto  Motor und  Sport' test against the
>928S4 SOMETIME IN '86-'87,..i might dig it   up...W.Roerhl drove?)
>-Too heavy (but it outaccelerates the RS in all aspects)

See above.

>I would love to read a comparison test, someone must have done this back in
>'88 when the CS was launched as the successor of the RS.

Again, the CS was not a successor to the RS so stop saying it was. It was a
marketing ploy to sell a car with less for more!!

Date: Thu, 13 Jul 1995 22:58:17 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: CS quotations, Pictures,...peace on earth!

I'm finishing off the CS debate too, Scott left the ring.....   ;-)

*BUT* you will be able to look for pictures called 911CS_x.jpg (x could be
1, 2 - masybe I'll scan 4)

I would then call for a poll,....anyone that actually *Can* see something
reminding of Carrera RS stripes-sign low on the side of the car,...send me a
mail. If you don't see it, one of us need a visit to the optician..  :-)

I would like to quote a few statements;


Kevin Blick;(Porsche 911-Supercars series)
##########################################
Page 13;
"The 2.7 Carrera continued in 1974 with unchanged power but lost some of its
raw appeal through the change to standard trim and American bumpers. Mindful
of that appeal, Porsche introduced a lightweight Club Sport version of the
1988 Carrera. Like its forebear, this cut interior refinements to save
weight and ran on stiffer suspension. The 231HP newcomer could then match
its predecessor for pace - but just barely."

Page 22;
"...Nothing typifies the new spirit better than the Club Sport, a
lightweight version of the Carrera introduced for the 88 model year. This
unashamedly recalls the glorious Carrera 2.7RS model, the first lightweight
911, even havind 'Carrera CS' scripted down the side. Like its famous
predecessor the CS has been stripped bare; no rear seats, no cassette
player, no sound insulation, no power-windows and no pvc
underbody-coating(which sadly means no 10-year rust warranty either-just
2-years)The result is a 50kg(110lbs) saving.
Like other sport version the CS has that distinctive large rear-wing,
re-calibrated dampers and forged alloy 16-inch wheels - 6 inch in front, 7
inch in rear - with 205/55 VR16 and 225/55VR16 tyres.
The 3164cc engine has no increase on the standard Carrera's 231HP, but
hollow stem intake valves and changes to the electronic engine management
unit allow it to rev to 6840 rather than 6500rpm. The gear shift has also
been given a short throw pattern for quicker shifts.
The result is a small, but distinctive performance edge over the standard
car: Porsche claims only a 0.2 sec improvement to 62mph(100km/h) and an
unchanged top speed (152mph) but AUTOCAR noted a wider margin - especially
in top end performance, the Club Sport being 3.9 seconds ahead to 120mph."

Page 30;
"...the Carrera RST scaled in at 20.4CWT (1037kg) or 18.8CWT (960kg) for the
lightweight RS version. In complete contrast the Turbo...................The
current Carrea weigh in at 1212kg, which the lightweight Club Sport has
trimmed back to 1160kg."


David Vivian (911 Porsche - The complete story)
################################################
Page 14

"...unburdened by luxury equipment or much in way of soundproofing the CS
successfully re-creates the raw excitement of the RS."

Page 127
                Club Sport  vs  Carrera 2.7RS   vs  Turbo 3.3
Max speed(mph)    152.1             150                158

Acceeleration;
0-30(sec)          2.0               2.1                1.9
0-50               4.0               4.2                3.8
0-80               8.7               9.4                8.2
0-120             19.6               23.4               18.5

In 5th
70-90             8.2                8.6                6.3
90-110            8.8                11.3               7.0

Date: 13 Jul 1995 17:26:50 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.COM (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: Gray Market 911's

RISH,
I've owned many 911's over the last 27 years.  Only one new, the rest used. 
My opinion on buying used 911's is that you should pay more for a very good
car because a lesser car will cost you at least as much initially to get it
right, and because a used 911's condition at the time of purchase is a pretty
good indicator of the care it's received and the care it will need.

Having said that, I have a hard time understanding why anyone would muck
around with gray market cars.  Unless there is an extraordinary deal(!), the
couple $thousand you save could easily evaporate as you ensure it complies
with US laws.  Further, although many of us buy these cars thinking we'll
keep them forever, chances are great you'll sell it later on and a gray
market car will draw fewer prospective buyers.  Again, unless the deal is
incredible (and therefore suspicious?), why risk it?

I have seen many US 84 911's in the $17k range.  Yes, they're high mileage or
a little rough (but so is the one you report on).  And 87's can be found in
the $20k range (last year I sold a near-perfect 88 factory turbo-look w/ 120k
miles for $26.5k; I bought it three years earlier for $23k!).  The cars are
out there.  Watch the papers *everyday* and be patient.

Shoot for an 87 or later, if you can.  You'll appreciate the clutch, gearbox,
ventilation, and torsion bar improvements.  BTW, leaky return tubes are no
biggy now that we have collapsable replacements.

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara, CA)
95 993 coupe, guards red
73.5 911T 2.7 coupe, ferrari red
85 535i, grey vehicle
- ---------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 05:55:06 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 73.5 911T CIS Conundrum

>I am new to porschephiles so please go easy on my ignorance.
>
>Here is my problem:
>
>I have a 73.5 CIS 911T with many of the S options.  The car has 50,000 original
>miles and has been kept in very good condition.  However I have been having
>severe problems with cold starts and backfiring.  The mechanic I took the 
>car to for major service shortly after I purchased it (about a month ago)
>sez the problem lies in the CIS.  The airbox has a popoff valve that has
>blow at least once, so it looks like the problem has occured before.  He
>said they could slowly replace various pieces of the system and I might
>be able to get out for a few hundred dollars or of as much as a $1000 but
>he suggested replacing the CIS with dual weber carbs (new).  He quoted the 
>work at about $1800 total which sounds steep to me.  He also said a third 
>option would be to fit it with an EFI system but that would cost even more
>in parts and labor.  I trust the compentency of the mechanics but I 
>do not trust their pricing.  My question is what to do and how much 
>should it cost for each solution.  What are the pros/cons of each   
>solution.
>

Well, Grady,

the proper thing to do is fix your problem, which may be as simple as
checking for false air leaks that would cause a lean air/fuel ratio 
and difficulty in starting.

The thisngs to check (in order of cheap to expensive):

1) The seals around the fuel injectors
2) the rubber boots between the intake manifold and the intake ports
3) The rubber o-ring in the flapper valve
4) the rest of the (now 20+ year old) rubber seals and air passages.

Don't change to webers, or mfi, or anything else.



Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services 
Orders: 800-ALL-P944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 85 Audi 5000S Sedan,  80 GMC Pickup (drivers)
86 944 Turbo, 89 944S2, 87 924S, 84 944 (parts cars)

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 10:53:13 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: toe in/out


As I understand it, the whole point of toe in, is to make sure that the 
wheels are parallel under braking ( to overcome the compliance of the 
rubber in the suspension mounts).

Cars with rose jointed suspension need less toe in.

There would seem to be no circumstances where toe out is advisable, it 
tends to make the car skittish in the straight ahead, and unpredictable 
under braking.

I often here people talking about "getting the tracking done" - this 
seems to be a garage con where the mechanic makes a minor change to the 
tie rods so that the steering wheel is more centered which has little 
benefit. 

Unless a car suffers a serious kerb clunck, then the tracking is unlikely
to change. If the car has a pronounced tendency to steer to the side, then
the likely reasons are, soft tire, brake binding, badly worn suspension
joints, bent chassis member or excessive toe out/in roughly in that order. 

The first three are easy to check, toe in/out is pretty easy to check with
no equipment - I find that the mark one eyeball is the best method, stop
the car with the wheels straight on a large flat area, put some chalk dust
on the front tire walls, go behind the car and eyeball along the sides of
the tires - if you align yourself with the outside edge of the rear tire,
you should not be able to see the front tire front edge, move out until
the edge is just visible and holding a ruler to the edge of the rear tire
measure the gap, you can then do some simple maths to work out the toe in,
repeat for the other side and average. If the toe in is within the
acceptable range, then you probably have a bent chassis/suspension
checking this requires to special jig/deep pockets. 

Note big fat rear tires make this approach more difficult, but you can 
still do it from the front.

+----------------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey                  |
|          3rd Floor                     |
|          Lion House                    |
|          23 - 31 St Mathew St          |
|          Ipswich                       |
|          IP1 3EL                       |
| email  : pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk  |
| Fax    : 01473 293737                  |
| Phone  : 01473 293715                  |
+----------------------------------------+

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 11:38:07 +0100
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 911 Clicking & Groaning / Tyre recommendations

> Symptom: When slowing to a stop (coasting the last few feet) with foot
> off brake/gas/clutch, a *groan* is emitted from the front wheel(s).  Once
> again, very intermittent, usually occurs after have been driving a while.
> Tapping the brakes may or may not make the sound go away.  Feel a slight
> shudder through the steering wheel.  Occurs more often when I turn the
> wheels, such as coasting into my driveway, though also happens on
> straight stops, like coasting into my garage or up to a stop sign/light.
> Cause:  Frozen piston :-)???, warped rotor :-(???
> Fix: ?

	I have the exact same symptoms with my '89 Carrera 3.2, right down to 
the noise being worse when I turn into my driveway!

	I have demonstrated it to my local dealer and the mechanic I spoke to 
said that it is due to using non-asbestos pads and that there is no known cure. 
I received similar advice from porschephiles when I asked about this a few 
months ago.

	I find it extremely annoying and would happily use asbestos pads if (a) 
I could find them and (b) knew that there wasn't *that* much danger to my/others 
health by doing so. BTW, I've wondered if there's a correlation between the 
weather (dry/wet/humid) and the loudness of the groan, but I don't have enough 
evidence yet.

	I did try removing my pads, cleaning out all the brake dust, cleaning 
everything with brake cleaner and reassembling with coppaslip on the back of the 
pads, but it made absolutely no difference.

regards,
Philip Katz ('89 Carrera 3.2)

P.S. Thanks to all who responded to my questions about tyres. I'm going to get 
Bridgestone RE71s as that's what most people recommended, though I'm waiting for 
Bridgestone to send me a brochure about the difference between RE71s and SO-1 
(Expedias) - anyone have first hand experience? A set of 4 tyres over here is 
about 650 pounds Sterling (including valve & balance) ... most of the brands 
suitable for Porsche fitment are within a few pounds of this.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 06:05:37 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: toe in or not to toe in

> ...but the Ray Scruggs guide to home alignment in his suggested specs
> >he would like 1/8" toe in...Does anyone have any opinions on this or has
> >specs of there own that they could post? 
> 
> I was going to go with 0 toe in on the front for my alignment but Galen
> Bridges  (Porsche mechanic in Atlanta) has talked me out of it. (My
> recollection of) His rationale was that ANY toe out was not good for
> stability at speed and that the tie rod ends can give enough to create toe
> out if they are set up for 0 toe at rest.He recommends a slight toe in.

Well, that's novel...

I agree that any toe in is not a good idea, but if the toe is set per
factory specs -- pressed, and using a mechanical or optical toe guage --
it should hold 0 toe at speed. I set my street and race cars for 0 toe
*EXCEPT* the 356 which I set for 1/8" toe in at the front and 0 toe
at the rear with a simulated loads in the driver's seat.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 95 06:36:00 PDT
From: "Dayton, Mike" <DAYTONM@hvsmtp1.mdc.com>
Subject: Porsche Racing Video


Hey,

Received a copy of the new video "Porsche- The Racing Legend"
last night from my dad.  Really good.

Has alot of interviews with nearly everyone who has played a part
in Porsche's racing history and lots of racing footage.  It basically
is a chronological look at the racing cars and successes through
the years.  At each point in history, they throw in a segment of Derek Bell
driving the particular car in question on a track and giving the viewer
the play-by-play.  He even gets a 962 sideways on occasions.

I especially enjoyed it for the things you can't get out of books (the 
sounds
for one thing).

Really good video.  I was amazed, though, at how many times "Porsche"
was pronounced as one syllable...

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 08:15:24 -0400 (EDT)
From: Michell Feig <mitchsf@shadow.net>
Subject: Re: 73.5 911T CIS Conundrum

Dear Grady:
I'm sure that you'll hear this from about a thousand other people, but 
here it goes:
DON'T PUT CARBS ON THAT CAR!
Take it to a different mechanic, fix what you have.  Take it from someone 
who made the wrong decision because I didn't have anyone to discuss it 
with.  Carbs will substantially decrease authenticity, resale value, 
drivability (unless they're set up correctly, which is very difficult), 
noise, and gas mileage.

Mitch Feig
1976 911S

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 09:40:37 -0400 (EDT)
From: blained <blained@nando.net>
Subject: Re: 86 911 A/C Question



On Thu, 13 Jul 1995, Armand R. Duco wrote:

> While having the 60K service performed on my 911 the dealer noted that I 
> needed a front condensor fan @ $376.00, hoever my extended warranty does 
> not cover this.  Is the easily replaceable?  I'm assuming that I can get 
> one cheaper than the dealer price if I scour the ads in Excellence..

It's a pretty simple bolt-on affair, and you can find them for $200 in 
the aftermarket.  I know - I had mine done at the dealer because I was 
leaving on vacation in an hour.  They were efficient, convenient, and 
gave a 2-year warranty (these fans are not much better than the heater 
blower motor in the engine compartment), but it hurt to see the price 
difference.

Blaine
p.s. YMMV alert - I have an '80 SC.

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 15:35:29 +0100
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: 911 Clicking & Groaning / Tyre recommendations


{various tales of "groaning" late 80s 911 front disks deleted}

My 911 used to make this "groaning" sound. Since I took it
to Silverstone for a track day a year or so ago it does not
make the weird sound anymore. The brakes had to work very, 
very hard at the track, one must presume that the full thermal 
cycling and full braking pressures allowed everthing to bed down 
in a more optimal configration.

Now, on the Trond flame war, my advice is don't mess with the
Vikings, look what they did here in the Yoo Kay a few years ago. 
Overrun with them we were, Vikings fired up up on Carlsberg Special 
Brew and psychoactive mushrooms and in the mood for a bit of rape 
and pillage are not a Good Thing.

Cheers

Ben

dollar has slumped since then, but the savings ratio is still the same.  my 2

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 08:14:58 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Mike Willis)
Subject: Re: price on 914

A couple of things on this.
If the pcar truely has 67K then I would keep it ORIGINAL the 73 and 74 2.0's
are becoming a collector and worth some money. If you make a race car out of
it then will not have same orig value.

Be sure to have a mechanic ck it out a lot can be done which is not easy to see.

Clutch is not a real prob if you do it your self with run about $350 for
parts w/o new flywheel. The flywheel in the 914's is soft and usually needs
to be changed. If again a true 67K might be able to get by with a resurface
on flywheel.


>A local dealer (Cincinnati, Ohio) has a '74 914 2.0 litre on the lot.
>This car has no visible rust, dents etc  It all looks original and appears
>dry (both from inbound water and outbound oil).  No strange noises
>and appears to drive well except for a potentially bad clutch.  The car
>has 67k miles.
>
>We are eyeing this car as a potential race car (read drivers ed, auto-x and
>later possibly pca racing, non-stock) convert.  The dealer is asking $6,500.
>
>What would be a reasonable price to pay for this beast ?

If the pcar is orig and miles are correct, eng, interior, paint etc are all
EXCELLENT then price is fair. I jsut sold a 73 2.0 for $6,500 but it had a
new paint job and excellent eng, and interior.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 95 08:51:29 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Re: 911/914/6 Aircleaners, etc.


Bill Hutton,

Thanks for the assist. I was trying to make the point that the 72-73 
have the rubber boot between the aircleaner and the air inlet 
temperature valve. That thing is located on the left set of MFI stacks
and regulates heated air into the aircleaner until the engine is warm.
It is important that this feature be connected when driving on the 
street, on the track the rubber boot may be removed to increase
airflow to the engine. The 1968-1971 MFI do not have this feature.

What Bill was referring to is the Temperature Compensation device.
The temperature compensation duct enrichens the MFI by passing heated 
air to the MFI pump as Bill pointed out. ALL except racing MFI have this feature. It is a thermostatic device which moves the enrichment rack 
inside the MFI pump. If your heat exchanger is damaged and does not send enough warm air to the pump, driveability is miserable and fuel economy
nil. The duct is a steel tube inside the heat exchanger, the connection 
is a black paper coated aluminum corregated flexible tube. Replacements 
are available from many sources.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 08:51:08 -0700
From: jcjensen@raychem.com
Subject: Re: Gray Market 911's

Lance Keigwin wrote:

>Having said that, I have a hard time understanding why anyone would 
>muck
>around with gray market cars.  Unless there is an extraordinary deal(!), the
>couple $thousand you save could easily evaporate as you ensure it complies
>with US laws.  Further, although many of us buy these cars thinking we'll
>keep them forever, chances are great you'll sell it later on and a gray
>market car will draw fewer prospective buyers.  Again, unless the deal is
>incredible (and therefore suspicious?), why risk it?

I agree with Lance's comments, but there are a few cases where gray market 
cars make sense, like the 73RS or 76 and 77 Carreras that were never 
available in the U.S.  As Stan pointed out recently, a window existed about 
10 to 15 years ago that made bringing these cars over relatively 
straightforward.  EPA offered a "one-time exclusion" for the emissions 
requirements, and the NHTSA had too many cars coming in to do any thorough 
inspections of the safety conversions.  The incredibly favorable exchange 
rate at the time didn't hurt, either.  All of these circumstances combined 
to allow buying one of these unique models an affordable proposition.

But unless you're looking for one of these special models, Lance's comments 
really ring true.

Jeff Jensen
jcjensen@raychem.com
73 RS almost restored

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 95 09:22:50 PDT

same perspective as when the thread started:  RS (Racer Superb), CS (Certainly 
Sucks).   
 
Ted Smith

I recently bought a fully federalized 83 SC Cab with all the docs.  It goes 
thru California smog testing like grease thru a goose.  All legal like and 
it's got a bit more horses than a US version, even after the smog additions.  
No regrets here, so if the car is correctly done with all documentation and 
the "plate" attached, don't be intimidated.  Besides, it's got these real cool 
yellow directional lights on each side above the fenders.  Not only do they 
work, alerting cars on either side of my intentions but they make my Armanis 
and Brionis feel more at home. 
 
Ted Smith


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 13:27:49 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: price on 914

In response to text from Mike Willis:

>Be sure to have a mechanic ck it out a lot can be done which is not easy 
>to see.

Ditto.  This is a *must*.  Please don't race it if it *is* original.  
Verify that all numbers match - verify paint code w/color - do spend
the money to have a *good* machanic give it the "works" - it can save
you many times that as a bargaining tool...

*** Do not be reluctant to walk-away should major problems be present ***

>Clutch is not a real prob if you do it your self with run about $350 for
>parts w/o new flywheel. 

You can get a clutch package(OEM disc, plate, t.o.) from Zim's for about $230.
[Have just spent $100 more than I needed to myself ;) ]  The clutch replacement
is easy - takes less time than dropping the engine.  If you have the flywheel
resurfaced have the machine shop record the amount of material taken off -
you will need to shim the throwout bearing by the same amount to keep proper
clutch geometry.

>>What would be a reasonable price to pay for this beast ?

$6,500 seems a bit on the high-side, unless it is a *perfect* specimen.

If you really have your heart set on building a race car, start with a 
structurally sound chassis and work up from there.  An immaculate oem
paint job won't help you on the track.   It would be an excellent canidate for
the stock classes should you choose to race it.

I started my current project, driver/autox/rennsport 914, over a year ago
and now it's almost done.  So far I have about $7,000 into the car(by doing
almost all of the work myself) and have a rebuilt transaxle, rebuilt engine,
functional car that I feel confortable driving hard since it isn't an original
specimen.  

- -- 
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 - Jerry R. Brady         - Open Networks Engineering -          jrb@one.com -
 - 1976 Sunflower Yellow 914/2.0(ok,ok, it's a 1.7 with 96mm NPR)            -
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 11:05:47 -0700
From: Novak.D@eworld.com
Subject: Re: 73.5 911T CIS Conundrum

Hello,

I had the same problem with my 1980 911SC.  I took the car to three mechanics
and they all suggested that I spend some big bucks to fix the problem.  They
gave the similar diagnosis that you were given.  

One things they suggested I replace was the worm up regulator.  I purchased a
rebuilt one at AUTOMOTION for $100+ and installed it myself.  Problem, the
worm up regulator needs to be adjusted when the car is bone cold and I don't
have the special equipment to adjust it correctly.

After discussing this with AUTOMOTION, they recommended me to a one man shop
around the corner from where I lived at the time in Sunnyvale.  WAS I
SURPRISED!!

The mechanic mad some minor timing and CIS adjustments while the car was at
operating temp, and the car ran better than ever.  This took about 15min and
a $20 donation.  That was a lot better than the $$$$$ everyone else wanted to
basically rebuild my system. 
(All three shops charged me $65 dollars to look into the problem, OUCH!!!!
 By the way,  the three shops I first took my car to are suppose to be the
best in the SF Bay area.)

I still need to take my car back for the worm up regulator adjustment, since
the car must be left overnight and be cold cold when the adjustment takes
place.  
Because I have not had the adjustment yet, the car is a bit stubborn on start
up,  once it gets going (2nd start) there are no problems.  This is probably
why it has taken me so long to get back to the mechanic.

It turned out, I never needed to replace anything,  Just needed an honest
mechanic.

Best of luck to you,
D Novak
1980 MTL BLK 911SC Targa 
1995 Jetta GLS

- ----------------------------- Begin Original Text
- -----------------------------


>I am new to porschephiles so please go easy on my ignorance.
>
>Here is my problem:
>
>I have a 73.5 CIS 911T with many of the S options.  The car has 50,000
original
>miles and has been kept in very good condition.  However I have been having
>severe problems with cold starts and backfiring.  The mechanic I took the 
>car to for major service shortly after I purchased it (about a month ago)
>sez the problem lies in the CIS.  The airbox has a popoff valve that has
>blow at least once, so it looks like the problem has occured before.  He
>said they could slowly replace various pieces of the system and I might
>be able to get out for a few hundred dollars or of as much as a $1000 but
>he suggested replacing the CIS with dual weber carbs (new).  He quoted the 
>work at about $1800 total which sounds steep to me.  He also said a third 
>option would be to fit it with an EFI system but that would cost even more
>in parts and labor.  I trust the compentency of the mechanics but I 
>do not trust their pricing.  My question is what to do and how much 
>should it cost for each solution.  What are the pros/cons of each   
>solution.
>

Well, Grady,

the proper thing to do is fix your problem, which may be as simple as
checking for false air leaks that would cause a lean air/fuel ratio 
and difficulty in starting.

The thisngs to check (in order of cheap to expensive):

1) The seals around the fuel injectors
2) the rubber boots between the intake manifold and the intake ports
3) The rubber o-ring in the flapper valve
4) the rest of the (now 20+ year old) rubber seals and air passages.

Don't change to webers, or mfi, or anything else.



Good Luck!

- ----------------------------- End Original Text -----------------------------



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 11:12:02 -0700
From: ehab@cisco.com (Ehab Aljandali)
Subject: RE: Grey mkt. 911's

As an owner of a Euro 84 Targa Carrera, I have to agree with most of the
postings. If you need more FREE hp and higher compression ratio... then the
Euro is a good alternative. I also like the fact that my power windows can
be used while ignition is off. Also, The fog lamps can be turned on with
only the side lites (US?). The turn signal can operate the left or right
parking lites for safety reasons. On the other hand if you do not do your
own repairs, mods and maintainance, then a US version is probably the
better choice, and would make it a no brainer for your mechanic. Sooo, I
would buy a Euro or a US any day as long as the Euro papers are as has been
described here before.
Autoxing the Euro depends on the course. A tight course will hurt your time
due to gear ratio, a widers and long straights course will allow you to
stay in 2nd and not have to spend time shifting up and down and should
improve your time.
My 84 power delivery seems to be different than my friend's US 84. I have
more power and torque around 4300+ rpm, he has more torque from 3000 rpm
and lessens at 6000rpm. This is feel of the pants comments drivning both
cars within minutes from each other so let's not start another CS vs
RS......

 Buyer,  Do some research, listen to this group and go with your gut feeling....

        Ehab.

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 15:25:13 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Rs vs CS actual driving experience

The thread on the RS vs the CS which has now deteriorated into juvenile name
calling needs to be put to rest. Perhaps I can help with some actual driving
experiences of both cars. We have in our region one of each vehicles and they
are both track driven. My friend and fellow instructor, Tony Bonanni, drove
both of these cars on the same day at Pocono race track.
The RS was fresh off of a very expensive restoration so it was driven at
8/10ths. His impression was that it was a nervous, high strung car that
wasn't particularly fast. It was quick off the corners but not a real
charger. He said the brakes were fine but required a high pedal effort.
Handling was good but he really didn't want to drive it at the limits. He was
a bit disapointed as he expected something unusually wonderful. 
The Club Sport was white as was the RS. Cosmetically the RS had the blue
Carerra graphics. The club sport had a chinsey decal on the fender.
The Club Sport drive was also good but not fantastic. He felt more
comfortable in that car as he said it felt more "solid." He though that the
CS had a bit more oomph off the corner but certainly wasn't much different in
performance than the RS. He though the CS brakes were a bit more user
friendly. He noticed nothing special about the car and couldn't believe that
someone would pay extra for what was basically a slightly stripped Carrera
with no outstanding traits.
It should be noted that Tony is slightly jaded as he drives a well developed
930 and is extremely capable in it. 
Hope this helps and please no flames as I am just the messenger.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
3:21 pm

regulator on all MFI Cars.

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 17:21:06 -0400
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: CAR RENTAL in europe

It is nearly always significantly cheaper to rent from the US than waiting
till you get there. All the major companies have special deals for American
tourists. You can make reservations on line using Eaasy Sabre through
Prodigy, Compuserve or AOL and get a guaranteed rate before you leave This
also gives you a great opportunity to compare rates. There are amazing
differences in rates so shop around. Hertz is generally expensive, Alamo and
(Euro)Dollar oftem have smoking deals. I have had deals with Eurodollar in
the UK as low as $17.00 a day for a two week rental, and they accepted
upgrade coupons. Meanwhile the best Hertz would offer at the same time was
around $65.00

One one occasion I arrived at Heathrow and tried to rent a car at a
previously quoted (back in the states) rate The agent refused and said thatit
 "was only for our American customers" ie the rate was not available if
booked in the UK. So I walked across the lobby, called my secretary in
Phoenix, waited for her to book a car and get a confirmation number then went
back to the rental counter and picked up my car at the US rate!

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 95 14:31:56 MST
From: thenke@amex-trs.com
Subject: Idle drops with 944 AC on...

I too have the idle running too low when AC is on with my '85.5 944.
The car then runs real rough/vibrating at 700 rpm or so.  Idles
fine when the AC is off.  This problem seems to gradually go away
as the car gets good and warmed up, but it takes quite a while, not
just 5 miles of driving.  I haven't found a solution yet, other than
turning the idle up, which isn't the correct fix.  I also get the
hesitation when engaging the AC while cruising on the highway,
but I perceived that as normal.  I also get the AC cycling
on and off about every 8 seconds while cruising the highway.
No solution on that, despite some good suggestions here, and a
couple good p-mechanics trying a number of things.

Terry Henkels
'85.5 944
Phoenix, AZ
    
The opinions expressed in this message are those of the author only,
and do not necessarily reflect the opinions of American Express.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 17:41:56 -0400
From: Michael Todd <miketodd@CS.Cornell.EDU>
Subject: 944S2 drivetrain woes

I seek the wisdom of my fellow Porschephiles on the continuing problems
of driveline noise and backlash on my '89 944S2. Basically, the sordid
history is as follows:

1) I took the car to Watkins Glen last summer and had what I thought was 
a great time. On driving back home, I noticed an unpleasant grating/grinding
noise from what seemed to be the rear end accompanied by quite a bit of
driveline lash. In retrospect, I should have driven back to the track and
the many experts there, but I drove home (not far) and sought local advice
(and also advice from you). The consensus seemed to be either ring and pinion
or CV joints. I prayed for the latter, took it to the local dealer, Gardner
Motors in Binghamton, where they took it for a short drive, confirmed that it
was most likely r&p or CV joints, but said they couldn't tell
more without dismantling it. I drove it home and stored it as I was leaving
for a year.

2) When I came back, I checked with porschephiles and found out about the
availability and prices of transaxles (thanks!). I also jacked up the
back and determined that the free play (about 1" at the rim) was the same on
each side, which seemed to suggest r&p rather than a CV joint.
I then took it back to Gardners (I had strong recommendations
from fellow PCA members), where, after a few days I was informed that I definitely
needed a new transmission. I managed to find an S2 transaxle from a '91 with
21K miles, from Larry Marks at Brothers, for a reasonable price, and had it 
delivered to Gardners. After repeated calls and excuses, I was told it was ready,
but there were complications in my picking it up and eventually my wife drove
me down on July 4th to pick it up. I left a check and drove home, but noticed
almost identical symptoms. I was pretty discouraged, to say the least.

3) I had an ex-race mechanic and 928 drive it in Ithaca. He said most of the
noise was a resonance in the exhaust system or a heat shield, but that there
was definitely some other noise or vibration in the driveline that was setting
it off. Because of the torque tube, he said it was very hard to determine if
the noise really came from the transmission, or was relayed from some problem
further forward, like the clutch. He also noted the excessive backlash.
(Of course, I have followed the many messages here about the 944 clutch in the
last year or two. While I did have a lot of grabbing one time when I was stuck
in very heavy traffic for a long time (apparently the pilot bearing), I have
had no other clutch symptoms -- it takes up smoothly at the same place each
time.)

4) I took the car back to Gardners, expressed my considerable dissatisfaction
with their diagnosis/cure. They were somewhat understanding, but wouldn't
commit themselves to fixing it at their cost until they had checked it
out further. They had talked to the Porsche rep, who mentioned problems
with the clutch as a possible diagnosis. I told them they had told me I
definitely needed a new gearbox. (Part of the problem here is that the service
manager was away when I first took the car in, and I was dealing with another
individual until I picked up the car.) 

5) They now tell me the new gearbox definitely has too much play, and they can
hear the noise from the transaxle when they run the car up on the lift.

6) I contacted Larry Marks at Brothers. He will take back the transmission
with a handling charge, which is high but probably reasonable if the transaxle
is OK. Is there a way to determine whether the r&p is bad without
dismantling the transmission? I would presume that the play can be determined
from feeling the play in the output flanges, but Gardners says you really
need to take it apart.

So what are my options? I could have Gardners switch the transaxle back, and
get the hell out of there and try to find a better mechanic. (Upstate NY
is not blessed with them.) I could have them continue to try to find the
problem. I'm out a lot of money (not so much if I return the transaxle), and
I seem to be back where I started. In all other respects the car drives like
a charm, and the problem is not noticeable when you're past 1st and 2nd.
Any advice or diagnosis would be *very much* appreciated!



I would appreciate direct replies as I am on the digest version of the list.
Thanks!
 
  -- Mike Todd

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 14:30:08 -0800 (PST)
From: BMESSINGER@ewu.edu
Subject: RE> 944 A/C concerns


Two 944 owners recently stated concerns that they were worried because when 
they turn on the A/C: 1. When in neutral this causes the rpm's to fall. and
2. when cruising it causes a "rearward jolt".

IMHO you (both) have no problems if these symtoms are only exhibited when
you hit the A/C switch. The A/C compressor is driven directly by the
engine, and requires significant power to drive. The moment you hit the A/C
switch, the compressor clutch engages the compressor putting instant 
resistance on the engine. The result (in neutral) is a drop in engine speed
that is usualy only momentary in modern cars, since engine management systems
in general will compensate and bring the idle speed back up to normal (but it
takes a second). On the go the result is a felt loss of power at the moment
that compressor starts spinning. 

If the rpm's drop when A/C is used in neutral and they don't come back up
after a second or two maybe you have a problem, but it isn't the A/C.

Again, this is my humble oppinion based on experience with A/C in general
and not 944's specificaly.

Many happy miles to you both.

Ben Messinger
bmessinger@ewu.edu
'72 914 (just sold)  
looking for a '73




------------------------------

Date: 14 Jul 1995 17:13:55 U
From: "John Tucker" <John_Tucker@engr.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: '71 911T Passes Smog!

                                                                     4:41 PM
  OFFICE MEMO                                                 Time:
                      Subject:
                      '71 911T Passes Smog!#000#                        07-14-95
                                                              Date:

I have a '71 911T Targa that I tried to get to pass smog two years ago and had
to get a waiver.  If I remember right, I spent $125 at a Porsche dealer and
they couldn't get it to pass and it wouldn't even register on the smog
referee's machine (>2000 HC, I think.).  I got the waiver and took it to
another mechanic to get it running again, after the Porsche dealer messed it
up, for around $248.  This time, I changed the oil, poured a can of SWEPCO 503
down the venturi's (alot of smoke!!), checked the timing, dwell and carb sync
and took it Charlie Rockwell at Rockwell Motorsports in Santa Clara, CA.   Tony
Vanacore recommended him to me after I posted to the list.  Thanks Tony. 
Charlie only does smog checks, adjustments, and dyno tuning.  One hour later, I
had a smog certificate in my hand!!!  Great news, since in California after
1-1-95 only one waiver will be issued for any car and this is after you spend
at least $450 on repairs by a licensed smog check repair facility.  Now I can
sell it and this will be a great selling point if the buyer knows how hard it
is to get one to pass. A mechanic told me that he has worked on 4 that won't
pass and numerous list members whose cars won't pass also replied to my earlier
post.  Have a good weekend.  Thanks for the help.  John.

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 20:32:31 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: Foggy gauges

Curious problem, I am not sure what causes it, only theory I can come up with 
is based on the idea that:

A) Humidity inside the car is high (or perhaps inside the guage)

B) The surface of the guage is relatively cold for some reason and thus the 
moisture condenses on it.

Are you running the A/C or is there somehow a water leak, like maybe from the 
windshield washer lines or from the rain into the trunk??

A cold interior (cooled by A/C) and a moist trunk area (maybe even the carpet 
in the trunk is wet), maybe causes this....let me know if you find it

On the repair side, North Hollywood Speedometer in Los Angeles is very good 
and reasonably priced (from my experience)


Dennis Kalma

'75 911S with Kremer 3.2


PS thought is....those guages aren't sealed but are open to atmosphere....no 
chance of a gasket leak causing it, but must be water in the trunk.....

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 23:17:48 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: '85 911 which dies

This is for the person who recently asked about this problem.  I had
forgotten that the symptoms were that of a bad engine temp sender.  You
probably have the original, single-wire version.  Upgrading it to the
later, two-wire version corrects the problem.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 21:26:22 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: toe in/out

Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk> wrote: 

>As I understand it, the whole point of toe in, is to make sure that 
>the wheels are parallel under braking ( to overcome the compliance of 
>the rubber in the suspension mounts).

    For the front wheels of mass-market street cars, that's true.  For
    the rears, of course, toe-in is used to imrove stability under
    acceleration.

    For race cars (or any self-respecting Porsche street car, for that
    matter), front toe can be used, not as a reactive "fix" for the
    compliant-suspension design problem, but as a proactive way of
    improving the car's straight-line and corner-entry behavior, i.e.,
    more toe-in for straight-line stability and more toe-out to make
    the car turn in.

    I suppose I'd better mention that the values here are VERY small;
    1/8' toe-in to 1/32" toe-out pretty much covers the usable range.

>There would seem to be no circumstances where toe out is advisable, it 
>tends to make the car skittish in the straight ahead, and 
>unpredictable under braking.

    On the track, small amounts of front toe-out CAN help make the car
    point, as I mentioned above.  At corner entry (before the inside
    front tire gets unloaded), the inside tire's toe halps to steer the
    car into the corner.

    Toe-out at the rear is FUCKING DIABOLICAL.  Two years ago, I had
    the pleasure, due to a sequence of wildly improbable events, to
    drive my 914 with (unbeknown to me) about half an inch of rear
    toe-out.  It seemed a little twitchy, but I put that down to the
    fact that I had been driving a pickup truck for the previous three
    months while the car was being painted and having its engine
    swapped.  Everything was fine until I hit 65 mph and the car
    SNAPPED around on the freeway.

    There I was, with only 25 miles on my new engine, bodywork, and
    paint, staring through the windshield at oncoming death.  Not a
    good thing.

    Toe-in is dynamically stable; it will tend to self-correctively
    counteract any sideways forces applied to the car.  Toe-out simply
    amplifies those forces, with often-scary results.

>toe in/out is pretty easy to check with no equipment [method for 
>eyeballing toe with "no equipment" except a ruler and chalk deleted]

    It's trivially easy to measure toe precisely.  If you don't mind
    crawling around on the ground, simply use a tape-measure to measure
    between the outside edges of the wheels on the axle in question.
    Measure once at the front of the wheel and once at the rear; the
    difference is, naturally, the amount of toe.

    If you don't like getting your knees dirty, you can simply
    construct two parallel lines, one on each side of your car, and
    measure in from each line to the tires.  The lines don't have to be
    parallel to the car, just to each other.  The easiest wy to
    construct these lines is to build a rectangle out of two pieces of
    fishing line and two wooden dowels ( or pieces of angle iron, or
    broomsticks, or whatever).  Put one stick in front of the car, one
    behind, and stretch the fishing line taut between them.  Measure as
    follows:

   fishing line                               fishing line
        |                                          |
        V                                          V

        +------------------------------------------+ <- wooden dowel
        |                                          |
        |        _   ___________________  _        |
        | <-a-> | | |                  | | | <-c-> |
        |       | |-|      front       |-| |       |
        | <-b-> |_| |                  | |_| <-d-> |
        |           |                  |           |
        |           |                  |           |
        |           |     YOUR CAR     |           |
        |           |  (Artist's       |           |
        |        _  |     Conception)  |  _        |
        | <-e-> | | |                  | | | <-g-> |
        |       | |-|                  |-| |       |
        | <-f-> |_| |                  | |_| <-h-> |
        |           |       rear       |           |
        |            -------------------           |
        |                                          |
        +------------------------------------------+ <- wooden dowel

    Front Toe-In = (a+c) - (b+d)
    Rear  Toe-In = (e+g) - (f+h)

    -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Fri, 14 Jul 1995 23:29:59 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: toe in/out

I'll add to what Andy said about rear toe-out:

>    Toe-out at the rear is FUCKING DIABOLICAL.  Two years ago, I had
>    the pleasure, due to a sequence of wildly improbable events, to
>    drive my 914 with (unbeknown to me) about half an inch of rear
>    toe-out.  It seemed a little twitchy, but I put that down to the
>    fact that I had been driving a pickup truck for the previous three
>    months while the car was being painted and having its engine
>    swapped.  Everything was fine until I hit 65 mph and the car
>    SNAPPED around on the freeway.

Amen.

A couple of years ago I upgraded my BMW sedan to A Dinan "Stage IV"
suspension, with adjustable rear camber, upgraded shocks and springs, etc. 
I did all the work myself, and took it in for an alignment -- all it should
have required was camber all-around and toe at the front.  They called me
and said "Your rear wheels are toed out." I said "What? I'm coming down." 

Sure enough, the rear wheels were now toed out, whereas 2.5 years
previously, at the last alignment, they were still toed in (I keep the
printouts). So it appears that the rear A-arm bushings had deformed to such
an extent that the rear-wheel geometry had changed for the worse. I also
recall the the car's rear end was awfully "lively" around that time. With
new bushings and rear toe-in, it's much better now. 

So I learned that while in theory a car's alignment shouldn't change over
time (barring curb surfing and more serious abuse), in practice things may
very well change, so I keep an eye on toe these days.

P.S. The Acura NSX has rather high front toe-out and rear toe-in,
ostensibly to "pre-load" the suspension and tires for quick turn-in
response.  Now wonder the tires wear out so fast!

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |
|        standard disclaimers apply         | 
|___________________________________________|

Date: Sat, 15 Jul 1995 10:04:50 -0400
From: ALAN968@aol.com
Subject: 968 Head Gasket

About a week ago I posted a note on water consumption with my 95 968.  The
problem turned out to be a head gasket.
To recap, the symptoms were blowing water out of the coolant reservoir
overflow tube, no white smoke from the tailpipe a possible trace of what may
have been oil in the coolant.

Has anyone else heard of a 968 with a head gasket problem?  This one has less
than 11K.

Thanks,
Alan
95 968 M030

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 15 Jul 1995 10:09:53 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: RChain tensioner guards vs. Carrera tensioners

> I'm investigating the purchase of a 1970 911S which has chain tensioner
> guards in lieu of Carrera tensioners.  
> 
> What's the scoop on these?  Are they as safe as Carrera guards?

There's nothing *wrong* with doing this, the guards will keep you from
eating the engine when the tensioners fail. Note that I said "WHEN".
They *WILL* fail. You will have to replace them. That's the advantage
of the Carrera tensioners -- as they're pressurized, you don't have
to replace them (typically -- ran into a failed set earlier this year,
first ever for me...).

Stan

Date: Sat, 15 Jul 1995 13:43:24 -0400 (EDT)

The original Monteray radio on my 944 is also busted. Apparently, the 
tape player doesn't quite work. I've also been told by MANY people that 
blaupkunt is not a great company, but for some reason, I went ahead and 
purchased a new Blaupunkt cancun for my car. It works perfectly. Great 
reception and everything, but then again, it is brand new. I am told that 
the radios being put in new Porsches are made in Germany, and that they 
are really good, but that the 
kind I bought, and the kind that are available in stores, are of less 
quality, and are made in Indonesia. 

I still kinda like having Blaupunkt in the car. My radio was really cheap 
too, like $110 at Lechmere. Hope this helps in deciding.

Date: Sat, 15 Jul 1995 11:12:17 -0700

>>windshield washer lines or from the rain into the trunk??
>>
>>A cold interior (cooled by A/C) and a moist trunk area (maybe even the carpet
>>in the trunk is wet), maybe causes this....let me know if you find it

>I have the same problem w/ my Targa in the winter here in N. California (where
>we do get some rain, once in a while).  I don't have any leaking problems in
>the trunk, but the Targa top does drip a bit in a hard rain.  I have concluded
>it is the humidity and temp differential when you first start the car.
>Moisture in the air, cold glass, heat in car, etc. .  What I have found is
>that after a bit of driving the fog lifts, somewhat.  Not a problem for me so
>far this summer.
>
>Regards

Ron Calef
Vision Communications, Ltd.
Sausalito, CA
email:  krc@tlg.net
86 Carrera Targa

Date: Sat, 15 Jul 1995 12:53:00 -0500

        You may be able to simply push on it and rotate it that
way.  If you can't, then pull it out from the front or push from
the back (from under the dashboard or maybe in the trunk???),
turn, push back in.  The gauges are only held in by rubber grommets.

Date: Sat, 15 Jul 1995 19:17:46 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re:       heater repair in 1980 SC

Heater and blower are two different systems. The heater basically sends the 
air over the exhaust system, through the body and into the heater box, the 
fresh air part gets sucked in through the grille in the centre of the trunk 
(near the windshield).

First thing I'd do would be to take off the cover at the back of the trunk (4 
screws hold it in) and check to make sure the little flappers all move when 
the slides on the controls are moved. Sometimes the cable clamps come loose 
and then you may have the flappers all in the wrong spot. If they seem to be 
moving in a proportional sort of way, check the fan. Does it blow and with 
sufficient speed (listen to the plastic whine). If in doubt disconnect the air 
hose which comes out of the centre of the fan itself and then turn it on. If 
lots of air comes out...not the fan.

If you still have a problem with fresh air at this point....I would be 
stumped. If fresh air is fine, but no heat, check the air hoses from the 
electric fan in the engine compartment through to the connection in the body 
above the rear axles. If that is all fine, check to make sure the flapper 
valves (underneath the car, above the axles) actually work. Get someone to 
move the heater control and make sure that the cable actuates the flapper. 
Note that "closed" ie no heat, actually allows the air blowing from the fan in 
the engine compartment to exhaust under the car...the flapper above the axle 
is open.

If this fails, gasoline and a match may be the only answer...

Let me know what you find...

Dennis Kalma

'75 911S with Kremer 3.2

Date: 14 Jul 95 12:20:00 +1700

Subject: 911 Accident

Unfortunate Accident Seen Yesterday in Millbrae, CA
911 with Targa Top and Whale Tail Wrecked
  * don't know status of driver but the weirdest wreck I've ever seen; the
   left rear wheel (and most of the fender) was torn completeley off, even
   the drive axle was gone.  The car was situated in its resting place in the
  middle of an undivided road.  Millbrae Police and Fire Department at scene.
  The driver/passenger compartment (and for that matter, the rest of the car)
  seemed completely unscathed other than the missing pieces.  I don't mean to
  be insensitive or morose, but I can't figure out how this may have happened.
 I'm assuming this was the result of a collision of some kind but it occured to
me that if a torsion bar snapped or somehow came loose, one might have a cat-
tostrophic failure of the whole swingarm/wheel assembly.  Does this happen to
911's?

   I guess there is really no point to this message....just an oddity.

Brian Mifsud

Date: Sat, 15 Jul 1995 22:28:52 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 968 Head Gasket

Please check your deck on all of your cyls with a good straight 
edge.  I have found 944's with #2 and/or #3 low.  Also check the head.

I have long suspected that this was the precursor to water pump failure.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 15 Jul 1995 23:36:24 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 911/914/6 Aircleaners, etc.

Dear Jim,

As a followup to your very good advise (as always) I would like to offer 
the following:

I have successfully replaced those paper/tinfoil oem Porsche air ducting 
hoses on the MFI units and between the heat exchanges and the body etc. 
with SCAT hose.  For the uninitiated reading this return, SCAT stands for 
Silicone rubber Air Tubing.  It is used on aircraft to duct hot air from 
the exhaust manifolds to where ever it is needed.  

This stuff is sized in 1/4" increments I think.  To get it to fit I 
simply removed some of the wire reinforcement and folded the end inside 
the tube and clamped it.  The stuff is impervious to all of the normal 
engine  fluids and by products.  Engine heat does not affect it.

It always can be found at your aircraft repair facilities.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Date: Sat, 15 Jul 1995 21:57:41 -0700 (PDT)
From: tfab@netcom.com (thom fitzpatrick)
Subject: Hot 911 Update

Hi y'all

	Yesterday I went to get a new thermostat for my 911, and they guys
at AutoSport talked me out of it.  Told me I should check to see what the oil
temp _really_ is before I go spending any crazy amounts of cash.  I did
get a cool reception from the mechanic that shanked my SO's BMW, tho :( (putz!)

	Anyway, I went and bought a meat thermometer, and tested the temp
by putting it in where the dipstick goes, and running the car a bit.  The
temp on the guage and the temp on the thermometer were right on the money.

	I guess monday I get to get a new thermostat after all...

	Anyone know of any good parts sources in Sacramento besides Niello and
AutoSport?  (Mike? Bob?)  I wanna do this ASAP - not mail order!

Thom

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 00:44:19 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Semperit tires

> My local tire emporium suggests Semperits for the rear now and
> later when fronts wear down.  
 
AGHHHHH!!!! Run away!!! Run Away!!!!

> Anyone with experience w/ Semperits?  
  
Not since the '70s. But it's still valid because near as I can tell,
they're still the same. Maybe even selling off the same old stock.
They sucked then, probably suck even worse now.
   
Do yourself a favor and get some Yokos. Personal experience indicates
AVS Intermediates. Should be about $175 a tire. You'll love them.
It'll be like a new car.

If you cheap out, at least consider the A-509. It's cheaper, and handles
about 85% was well. Still lightyears from where you are now and a
couple of galactic diameters per hour from the Semperits... (gotta
keep them units consistent, you know?)

Best buy: call Tire Rack or Discount Direct for the best price, get
the local tire outfit that sells Yokos to match the "delivered" price
provided you buy the install,etc. there...

Stan

Date: Sat, 15 Jul 1995 21:42:26 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: 944 shaky steering wheel


I've noticed that my '86 944 steering wheel shakes
at around 100+ km/h (60 mph). The strange thing is
that this doesn't always happen (even on the same
road). What can cause a shimmy to happen sometimes
and not other times?

 - front end was aligned recently

 - jacked up car and spun wheels checking for runout.
  Tires and wheels are true

 - wheel bearings adjusted recently and are tight

 - front tires (215 VR 60) at 29 psi
 - rear tires (235 VR 55) at 35 psi

 - wheels not balanced since new. The tread still has
  the little rubber 'stubby things' sticking sideways out of 
  the tread blocks, so the rubber is still relatively new (Pirelli P6). 

Idea's anyone?

Ken

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 01:01:34 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)

First off, this is the first I've ever seen. EVER. Even racing.

Second,it was DOA, near as I can tell. Either that or it failed just
about immediately. Didn't believe it, since "that can't happen"
(and me with my stories of the Old Days when SunOS 0.7 would say 'Shannon
and Dan say this can't happen' if you booted with less than 2 MB memory)
Yeah, right. It happened.

the top of my head, but I seem to remember that there is some semi-major
surgery required for all the pre-69 cars...

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 01:13:43 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911 Accident

>  but the weirdest wreck I've ever seen...

Had that basicly happen to my wife's '73 Beetle (one owner, about five 
different drivers EVER '73 Beetle I might add...) some years ago, but it 
was the passenger side. She was rear-ended (she was at a dead stop and someone
drilled her at about 60 MPH, trying to change lanes). Far edge of the
offending car's bumper hit middle of the license plate, came out under the
rear side quarter window. Forward  motion and spin control was applied by
mashing the front of the car into the car ahead, and folding the front 
end back to touch the wheels, preventing rotation.

She was fine, other than BIG bruises on her hands where she broke the
steering wheel from being jammed into it...

A year and $15k later the car was just like new... It mainly sits in a
warehouse, getting out for exercise every few weeks for a couple of
hours. She's very disinclined to put it in heavy traffic.

The net result also makes me disinclined to "over-restore" any of my
cars. I don't have enough warehouse space for that. Drive 'em, I say...

Stan

Subject: Re: 944 shaky steering wheel

>
>I've noticed that my '86 944 steering wheel shakes
>at around 100+ km/h (60 mph). The strange thing is
>that this doesn't always happen (even on the same
>road). What can cause a shimmy to happen sometimes
>and not other times?
>
>- front end was aligned recently
>
Were the settings set so that the maximum caster (within
specs) was achieved.

>- jacked up car and spun wheels checking for runout.
>  Tires and wheels are true
>

How true??? Wheel runout max is 40 thousandths of an inch.
Tire hop of any kind can cause this problem.

>- wheel bearings adjusted recently and are tight

Probably not the problem.

>
>- front tires (215 VR 60) at 29 psi
>- rear tires (235 VR 55) at 35 psi

Probably not the problem..
>
>- wheels not balanced since new. The tread still has
>  the little rubber 'stubby things' sticking sideways out of 
>  the tread blocks, so the rubber is still relatively new (Pirelli P6). 
>

Does this mean that the tire/wheel combination is now out of balance
or has not been re-balanced when new.  I would check the balance on these.

Also, check for any play in the ball joints or tie rods.
Check for worn shock absorbers.

Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services 
Orders: 800-ALL-P944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 85 Audi 5000S Sedan,  80 GMC Pickup (drivers)
86 944 Turbo, 89 944S2, 87 924S, 84 944 (parts cars)

fine, maybe it will be enough to buy a poster of the best RS (RS 3.8 ;-). 
(No sale attempt! This is in Norwegian, and only useful in Norway too!)

The calculations is rather straightforward but you need background data,
with List Prices the year the car was sold new, weight, inflation rates, and
so on,.... 

The bad thing is; Porsche prices are missing from '86 and back,...does
anyone have a clue to a source book or something that include the FOB
Stuttgart Prices for specific years?

Testing the program will be fun, I'm looking for a '71 - '73 Porsche 911S or
*maybe* a *very good* 914 for import,....great way to check out the
stuff....in practice.

What did a 914/4 cost in the US around '72,...the 914/6 then?

I have the prices for the '72 911's!

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 11:20:27 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914/6 conversion ??

> Ok I have changed my mind I have posted the 350 for sale and am looking in
> to the 914/6 conversion.  

I'll go back to my original position: it's not that hard to do if you (a)
have done it before and (b) have nearly infinite amounts of money. Plan on
car plus engine plus about $10k, minimum. Best advice: find someone that's done
it before and have them either do it for you or pay them to coach you 
through it. 

> Also what body modifications are allowed in
> the pca or scca I haven't gotten around to asking them ...

Sigh..... *DO THIS FIRST*!!!!! I have an acquaintance who spent over $50k
building this 911 "race car" only to find that the only place it was legal
was the local PCA autox, the "Modified" division of SCCA autox, and
IMSA road racing where his lame engine and bodywork choice would make him
a rolling German speed bump for even the slowest cars.... He'd need to glue
a cone to the top of the car so that people would know to slalom around
him...

> What class would a 914/6 with a 3.2 and a
> ferrari testarossa body qaulify for? What about a 3.2 with fender flares? 

For SCCA road racing, it would qualify to sit in the parking lot while you 
watch the race from the stands. There's probably a sufficiently progressed
class in PCA club racing where you can run with the 935s or something.

For SCCA autox, I think that's too big an engine for F Prepared, so you'd be
in Modified class with the winged kit cars. PCA? I dunno -- depends on
the region. *WAY* out there in the progression, though.

> LAST QUESTION, has anyone ever
> gotten a 911 taken out the back seat switched the engine around and switch
> the ring and pinion making it mid engined? If not why not?  

Yes. Turns out to be legal in both SCCA and IMSA, and someone did that
this year. Big writeup in current Excellence, I believe. MASSIVE amount
of work, big dollars.

Stan

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 14:28:05 -0400
From: "H.Shrikumar" <shri@eternity.cs.umass.edu>
Subject: 924 exhaust .. does it have a cat or not ?


Hi,

You all know, I bought this 924, all fine except for a known exhaust
problem that sounded like no muffler at all.  There was not too much
time to do more than a compression test, (and hey its only a 924 :). So
I bought the car, providing generously for a big exhaust job in my
negotiation.

Saturday we hoisted the car up all the way, we found it was worse than
I had though -- the entire exhaust _system_ between the exhaust pipe
and the last muffler was missing !! Non Sum .. "Gone to see Oprah" ..
AWOL !

Luckily, the projected cost is still within my provision. Bad news is
that I am hearing this "just one more week" refrain once again :-(.

+------------
My question is -- 
What are the exact components on the '82 924 exhaust system ? 
Does it have a catalytic or no catalytic ?
+------------

The owner manual "in the glove compartment" shows a catalytic.

Imparts faxed me a page from Bosals catalog that shows the exhaust pipe
from the manifold, then two cylindrical objects (which a parts dealer
says are both "resonators") and the final muffler at the tail-pipe.
This picture shows no lambda sensor and no catalytic ! I cant believe
that a car could pass the sniffer without either.

An interesting circumstantial evidence is that Tweeks' lists parts for
"924 w/catalytic" and "924 w/o catalytic". (in the Performance section,
for model years 79-82, "pls state year and month of manuf".)

+---------------
Would be very grateful if someone knew exactly what parts go into a '82
924 exhaust system, between the exhaust manifold and the final
tail-pipe. 
Maybe you have Haynes / the microfiche / seen it own eyes ? TIA!
+---------------

I suppose the Porsche microfiche would give me the final word on this,
wouldn't it ? I would order one first thing monday. But then I want to
also get the car on the road asap too (you know ... :-) !!

And what do you think .. since I need a complete exhaust system anyway,
A friend suggests I rather go for one the after-market "performance"
ones, (Bursch?) rather than duplicate the OEM stuff at a higher price?
Any opinions/ recommendations ?

TIA for advice / help  .. and thanx, above all, for lending me the
shoulder to cry on :-) !!



- -- Shrikumar

'82 924

shri@cs.umass.edu    ------+ Qua!-lx - cc:Mail<->Unix g/w for HP100lx/200lx
shri@shakti.ncst.ernet.in  | ftp://eddie.mit.edu/pub/hp95lx/NEW/qualx13.zip

Subject: A 914 Reborn...


at approximately 2:14pm EST, 16. July 1995 the engine started(on the first
try no less!).  No leaks, no fires, quirky idle, but ran smoothly!

It's been quite a year+ and it was absolutely, wonderfully statisfying to 
hear the engine run after all that work.  I would *NEVER* have been able
to do it without all of your advise, support, and help. 

As promised, I will be sending my Patron donation to the fund at month's 
end. [ Bart - could you e-mail me the address? TIA ].  I would hate
to see a resource like this fail to prosper and grow.  The technical and
social benefits are indespensible.

Now that I am preparing for the road, I look forward to meeting many of you
at various events around the country as I plan to attend as many as possible.

If you recall, I had never done *anything* more envolved than a brake caliper
rebuild 14 months ago.  I look forward to continuing my education and passing
the lore on down the line.

Many thanks.

With Sincere Regard,
		      Jerry

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 15:36:22 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: 914 vacuum arrangement/quirky idle


Hello! <grinning from EAR-TO-EAR>

As my previous post stated, my 914 is once again alive!  I am hoping that
with a few more days of TLC that she'll be as good a new, and when it 
comes to Porsche TLC I always look to pphiles for advice and support.  

Here is the scoop:

I'm waiting for the air cleaner to arrive and ran the engine without it(I 
put a paper dust mask over the rubber on the intake).  Looking through 
Haynes and the 914-914/6 handbook I was unable to make heads or tails of
the vacuum line routing from the diagrams, so (wanting to start her up
to she if she worked) I make educated guesses.  

I do not have a deceleration valve installed on the car(may order one, it's
a '70-based core engine) therefore I needed to route the vacuum for the
aux. air regulator, vacuum advance/retard and pressure sensor.  

While the base idle speed was good(about 900) it would ride a triangle-wave
up to about 2500 and the drop back to 900.  It would not stay constant at
900 but rose and fell as if someone were pressing and releasing the 
accelerator.

I resigned myself to the fact that I had false air entering the intake 
and since I have no deceleration vavle - I think it may be the aux. air
regulator - could this be causing the problem?  I am curious only because
of the fluxuation - a constant high idle wouldn't worry me.

I will continue to investigate and keep you posted on the results.  If 
anyone has any vacuum-line references for a d-jet. 914 (text or otherwise)
I'd appreciate it if you could help me out.  

My fax number is: +1 313 996 9908, voice: +1 313 996 9900, ext. 1227

Still recovering from the adrenalin-rush of breathing life into my 914,
	    Jerry
- -- 
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 - Jerry R. Brady         - Open Networks Engineering -          jrb@one.com -
 - 1976 Sunflower Yellow 914/2.0(ok,ok, it's a 1.7 with 96mm NPR)            -
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
