Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 19:37:32 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Any Ozark Region PCA members Online?


Dear Gig,

I tried to post you directly but was bounced out by the mail system.

During the formation of our Ozarks Lakes Region, Springfield MO, we 
requested the name of Ozarks Region.  At the parade that year our 
presentation was made.  There were some people there from Little Rock.  
They made the claim for the same name based upon the fact the Ozarks Mtn. 
area was primarily in Arkansas.  I'm not sure that an actual group of 
people were meeting as a local region in Little Rock at the time.  It may 
have been more like some people attending the parade thought it would be 
a good idea to lay claim to the name so a region could be put together.

The region was listed in Pano for many years.  Call your regional advisor 
for details. Yours is listed in PANO.  Get the thing going again.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974



------------------------------

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 17:29:15 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: Re: 924 exhaust .. does it have a cat or not ?


>+------------
>My question is -- 
>What are the exact components on the '82 924 exhaust system ? 
>Does it have a catalytic or no catalytic ?
>+------------
>

Here's what I found for the '82 924 in the EuroSelect catalog:
(from front to rear)

1. E xhaust manifold
2. Front exhaust pipe (looks like header)     p/n   477 253 101 R
3. Cat convertor                                            p/n   477 131 701 G
4. Muffler

There is a footnote to a front muffler which seems to be replaced
by the cat. saying "only for 49 state cars up to January 1977"

My price list from Carlsen (dated Sep 94) lists the cat at $150.

Ken 
'86 944


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 19:56:48 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: Turbo tie rod ends  and fat washers

Yup, they go between the rod and the tie rod. Found out via ratherer painful 
experience that the ball joint at the end of the tie rod requires a narrow (1 
3/8 I believe) open end wrench to tighten...turns out that a standard open end 
is too fat. I ended up buying a a thin wall wrench from Snap On at a price so 
low I merely screamed.....

Lotsa luck....if I were doing it again I would be tempted to buy an el cheapo 
wrench and then take my trusty black and decker heavy duty grinder and grind 
the wrench to the proper width...


Dennis Kalma

911S with Kremer 3.2 and nifty tie rods

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 23:01:33 -0400
From: AutoOasis@aol.com
Subject: Great adaptor for later 915 in early 911

P-Philes,

If any of you out there have thought about putting a 3.0 in an early 911 and
ran into problems with mating up the early axels to the 915 axel flange then
let me know. 

I was recently lucky enough to meet a machinist that is a Porsche fanatic
that designed an adapter that will allow this mating to take place. He gave
me a copy of the techinical drawing for these little babies and I would be
happy to pass it along to anyone that needs it. You should be able to give
them to any fabricator and bingo! adaptors.

Let me know and I'd be happy to fax or mail a copy of the drawing.

Steve
'67 with '82 3.0 and 915 mated with my early axels, better know as monster
motor from hell....

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 21:21:16 -0600
From: tgilton@micron.net (Terry Gilton)
Subject: Momo install


Just installed my new steering wheel. It was pretty easy, but I messed up
and didn't mark the old wheel postition. I have pulled the new wheel twice
now to get it straight. :-(

A previous poster mentioned that the Momo wheel didn't have a turn signal
turner-offer-tab-thingy (hey the bard did it too). Well, you actually have
to remove the part from the stock wheel and it fits on the Momo wheel.
There is a contact of brass on the same part that makes the connection to
the horn circuit, so it seems like you'd have to be creative to make the
horn work otherwise.

Also, I heard Momo was being sued by Porsche for the Porsche logos on their
horn buttons. Anyone else hear this one?

'74 911 (With a new wheel, and the original 2.7 STILL running strong)

******************************************************************************
* Terry L. Gilton, Ph.D.
* Boise, Idaho
* tgilton@micron.net

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 21:34:54 -0600
From: tgilton@micron.net (Terry Gilton)
Subject: Polished Fans


I pulled my fan out, cleaned it up and polished it. What a job! The outside
edge of each fan blade looks like a weld bead has been run on it, and this
is a serious challenge to clean up.

Ever notice that the blades are airfoils? It seems that if you just wanted
to move air, you wouldn't need the airfoil, just the blade shape and some
sort of symmetrical profile. Does the airfoil make the fan more efficient?

At any rate, I noticed that the leading edges of the fan blades were rather
square, and the blades themselves where pretty crudely finished. I
therefore cleaned up the blade shape and smoothed everything out. I also
balanced the finished product (static balance, like my RC airplane props).
After polishing, I clear-coated it, lest the aluminum oxidize again and my
effort prove fruitless.

With all this balancing and smoothing, I swear my old 2.7 gets another 10
to 15 microhorsepower to the wheels.

Also, it REALLY looks good.

'74 911 (with a nice fan and the original 2.7 + another 0.000015 HP)

******************************************************************************
* Terry L. Gilton, Ph.D.
* Boise, Idaho
* tgilton@micron.net
******************************************************************************

the fan belt easy? How is it done correctly? I managed to put a new belt on
my car, and even figured out that I needed more of the little spacers
between pulley halves for the new belt, but getting that thing on was a
REAL challenge! I think I can manage this in the future, but I keep
thinking there is something really simple that I am missing that will make
this a trivial task...

'74 911 (new belt on the still-strong original 2.7)

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 00:54:09 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Idle on 944 drops with AC on

At 04:56 PM 7/13/95 -0700, Marc G wrote:
>Hi All
>   Here's the problem, When I turn on the A/C in my 944 the idle drops 
>from it's normal smooth 900rpm to 6-700 and idles quite rough. The AC 
>works fine and the car otherwise runs great. Anyone else have this 
>problem?

I don't know what the problem is, not being an AC kind of person.  However,
there is an "AC Compressor On" signal to your car's DME, which should
let it compensate.  It should compensate anyways, as it always tries to
keep idle at 840 RPM.  You might try cleaning your idle stabilizer as well
as checking the other usual poor-idle culprits.

Kevin

Porschephiles #1560                         Mon Jul 17 13:22:33 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 00:19:47 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: Early 911 oil lines

I just stripped the fitting on the oil cooler on my '71 2.2 911 (#$@*!)

The rebuilt motor is back in the car but now I'm stuck.
The oil cooler is out and I will try to
find someone (maybe at a radiator shop?) who can salvage the threads
tomorrow.

There are two main oil lines on the car; one from the oil tank to the
oil cooler (approx 30 mm fittings) and one from the oil tank to a fitting
on the LHS of the case (approx 26 mm fittings). (I measured the outside
diam on the threaded portion of the fittings. I think this might give
slightly low values, i.e. maybe these are really 31 and 27 mm threads?

I am planning on buying a new oil line to replace the one that caused
all the trouble to start with, but would really 
like to salvage the oil cooler if possible. What are my 
chances of finding
a radiator shop that either has a big die that will fit or that is
capable of soldering aluminum and replacing the fitting? Should I just
bite the bullet and get another oil cooler? Anyone have one? 

The fittings on the longer line are in good shape, but the end that goes
to the engine doesn't fit! It looks like I got the wrong fitting in the
case. Its threads are about 30 mm (the size of the other line) but
they should be more like 26mm.

I assume that I have the correct oil lines for the car, and that
the idea of having different size fittings was to make it impossible to
mix up the lines.

Any idea where I can find the correct engine fitting quick?
The fitting should have approx 23mm threads for the case
and approx 26 mm threads for the oil line. 

Also, can some kind soul please tell me how the long oil line is
supposed to be routed from the lhs of the engine to the oil tank?
It looks like it should go over the top of the tranny, is this right?
It seems to want to rub against the clutch cable adjusting block.
Where do you mount the hold-downs for the line?

Time is somewhat of the essence now since the landlord is breathing
down my neck. I am doing this in my apartment carport and the
landlord just stuck a "parking ticket" on the car last Friday
saying that non-operating vehicles are verboten and it will
be towed if not off the property by next Friday :-).

They don't like us working on cars here. I still couldn't help
but laugh when I
got the ticket, for two reasons -  The car has been sitting
in the same spot without an engine for several months, and by
sheer coincidence they ticketed the car the day before I brought
the motor back and put it in. In their description of the offense,
the wrote "no rear plate or bumper, non-operating vehicle".
If the jerk had stooped about 6" he could have seen that there was
no motor in the car and wrote that on the ticket. My guess is that
he must have been pissed about the 2" of dust and spiderwebs.

 -Mitch

races, anti-fire or air conditioned or radio);

of the RSR model, or other;
12) every other interesting new about the specified model.

caracteristics of about 50 cars (most in Italy).

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 09:00:15 -0400
From: conrad@lcc.stonehill.edu (Claudia Conrad)
Subject: Re: 1960s Popular Magazines

Bill Miller asked...
>These are magazines that, althought widely distributed, are not included
>in the Reader's Guide to Periodical Literature. Does anyone know of
>sources to get details such as publisher, content, list of issues,
>indexes, etc.?
>Bill Miller USA

   This is a tough one.  You can get general info such as publisher, subjects
covered, etc., from _Ulrich's International Periodicals Directory_, which is
published yearly.  Your public library should have it, or be able to tell you
another library in you area that has it.  It is comprehensive in coverage, and
has a substantial listing of car rags listed in the "Transportation--Autos."
section.
   Indexes are a problem.  I know of no index covering automotive literature. 
_Ulrich's_ will tell you what indexes cover a given magazine (if any do).  But
when you look at it you will notice that for most enthusiast literature, you
are lucky if it is even included in Reader's Guide.  
   If the magazines you're interested in are still being published, I would
contact the publisher and ask if they produce an index to their publications,
or if they have any suggestions where you could get that type of info.
   By the way, I am a librarian.  I work at a small college in MA, but I also
am the librarian at the Museum of Transportation in Brookline, MA.  I haven't
been there too long, but if I run across a good source for auto magazine
indexes and such, I will let you know.  Good luck!

Claudia Conrad
1973 Carrera RS
1971 914-6

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 16 Jul 1995 21:23:58 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: Dead 914 fuel pump/oil pressure

In response to text from Dave Darling:

>
>        I think my fuel pump is dead.  I'm getting no "buzz" when
>I turn the key, and no apparent fuel pressure.  The relays *do*
>click when they should, and I *do* see a voltage change (0-12-0)
>when I turn the key.

If it is dead, I have a three connector(early) fuel pump laying around that
should work(it worked when it was removed).  Let me know if you need it.
Items I'm looking for in trade are:

  rear "porsche" reflector(have solanoid release)
  center caps(x4) for fuchs alloys(914)
  1 spare fuchs alloy
  deceleration valve
  fuel pressure gauge

>        Can I just jumper the battery straight through to the
>pump to confirm my diagnosis?

It's ok for the short term(the + line should be fused) but please don't
leave it like that...

>        Do I need to prime the pump or fill the fuel line from the
>tank with gasoline?

The fuel pump should run for about 1-2 sec when the key goes from off to
ignition on - this brings the pressure held by the regulator back up.  I
kept turning the car on and off until fuel started to appear in the engine
compartment(thereby identifying the send/return orientation) and hooked
the lines to the engine fuel system.  The non-ignition cranking before 
starting will bring the system up to its operating pressure.

BTW:  Anyone know a good source for a fuel pressure gauge?

>        On an unrelated question, how much cranking should it take
>to get the oil light out on a freshly-rebuilt motor?  The dipstick
>reads full, the filter is full of oil.

Mine never went out (after 1 minute of cranking).  So, I just connected
the coil wire and started her up.  It then went out.
>
>--DD  (will it start???)

Mine did.  Yours will too. :)

- --

 - Jerry R. Brady         - Open Networks Engineering -          jrb@one.com -
 - 1976 Sunflower Yellow 914/2.0(ok,ok, it's a 1.7 with 96mm NPR)            -

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 10:13:10 EDT
From: kresh@cvi.hahnemann.edu
Subject: Re: 915 Tranny code



RZ: 
the designation 734.. 

7= transmission for 6 cyl
3= 5 speed 911  (7= 911 turbo)

after 1984 the third digit was a letter for the year of the car
(example: E= 84; F=85; G=86)

regards, Jascha

prior to this i had a blowout with the same tire on a bmw 2002.

better safe than sorry !

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 08:19:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Nielsen <cnielsen@u.washington.edu>
Subject: Re: looking for a '71 door stay


Jerome, I have a '70 911E with the same problem. I found out that you 
must use the original roll pins that came out of your old check straps. 
If by chance you have thrown them away or destroyed them upon removal 
they can be purchased at any good hardware store. I found them at Eagle 
Hardware...cheap!. After fighting with this and other door related 
problems I finally changed everything over to the old RS style door 
panels, latches and check straps. This configuration simply uses a large 
leather strap between the door and the chassis to keep the door from 
opening too wide...looks great.

On Sun, 16 Jul 1995, neil a kumpers wrote:

> Hi Jerome,
> 
> 
> I had the same problem. You can keep the new  door stay and not drill new 
> holes. Just go to the hardware store and buy some allen? bolts. Fits 
> right in. Now if anybody can help keep the pin on the door post from 
> moving when I open the door, it makes a loud popping noise. Is there a 
> larger pin that I can put in that will stop it? Well, good luck Jerome.
> 
> Neil Kumpers
> '73 911S targa
> nkumpe01@fiu.com

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 95 08:20:39 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: 911 Alternator/Housing Orientation


Does anyone know the correct orientation of
the alternator in the fan housing?  My car is
a '72 911, but I think they must all be pretty
much the same.

I took mine out to paint the fan, and neglected
to mark it properly.  I think you have to get it
right for two reasons.  First, so the wiring harness
matches up neatly, and second, because there isn't
much tolerance for fan offset from center.  It runs
pretty close to the edge of the housing, so it's got
to be smack dab centered.

Many thanks!

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu
'72 911 E Targa
'72 911 T Coupe (in pieces, with alternator out of fan housing...)

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 95 10:20:52 CDT
From: pan@ukraine.corp.mot.com
Subject: Re: A/C Condenser Fan for 911

>I understand another alternative to paying around $200 for an 
>A/C condenser fan is to just buy the motor.  Vertex sells them 
>for about $70.  Has anyone done this before?  
> 
>
>Steve
Hi Steve,
  I was able to replace just the A/C condenser fan motor in my '82 911SC.
You can get the motor even cheaper by getting the part number stamped
on the motor and ordering it directly from a Bosch supplier.  For example,
my motor had the part #: 013 000 7081 and I got it for $37, including shipping,
from:

Battery Ignition Components, Inc
91 Meadow St.
Hartford Conn. 06114

203-296-4215
1-800-767-2950
							Sincerely,
							Davis Pan

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 12:06:40 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944 Waterpump questions

At 04:36 PM 7/7/95 -0700, kkan@Direct.CA wrote:
>About 1000 km ago, I replaced all the timing & balance belts and rollers 
>on my '86 944 (using the P9201). The car is now at 85,000 km (53K mi)
>and I've noticed recently a faint squeaking coming from the waterpump
>area which I only hear when the car is warm. There is no fluid leaking
>at the waterpump pulley. I checked the tension of the AC/Alternator belt
>in case it was making the noise. A momentary squeak can also be 
>induced by letting off the gas quickly and listening as the engine rev's
>back up to idle. 

It's usually the power steering pump belt which makes noise, not the 
alternator polyrib.  The waterpump has a weeping passage underneath the
pulley, to memory.  Did you locate it and check there?

>Is squeaking ok so long as the pump doesn't leak? Could the new 
>tighter timing belt (4.0 on P9201) have stressed the old pump bearings? 

Squeaking is OK, but is generally a sign of worse things to come soon,
like real leaking.  I'd keep an eye on it.  If it leaks, you'll see
coolant dribbling off the bottom of the timing belt covers -- no need
to remove them to inspect.

>1. Buy new or rebuilt?

New.  People say great things about Jay Pineau's rebuilt parts, so you
might consider using one.  Avoid ESP rebuilts.

>3. What is the likelihood of breaking off a waterpump bolt at removal.

Pretty low, to my experience.  But there are a heck of a lot of them!
And I think you get new ones with the WP -- could be mistaken.  Reinstall
with antiseize.

>4. The crankshaft pulley bolt is torqued to 154 ftlbs. Is it at all possible
>   to remove it by first blocking the wheels, setting the handbrake, and
>  putting the car into gear to lock the crank? Will this be too stressful 
>  on the driveshaft , gearbox, clutch etc?

Never tried it, might work.  Look at the torque spec for your engine, and
figure that you're "simulating" that, opposite direction, when you take
off the crank bolt.

You *might* be able to R&R the waterpump without removing the crank bolt.
I would pull all the other sprockets and rollers off, then remove the
four bolts (plus or minus) retaining the rear time belt cover (two at
the distributor rear cover, two low and to the block), then move the
cover forward yielding access.  Not sure whether this works...

>5. If 4. is not possible, where is the best price on a 944 flywheel lock?
>   (Perf Parts has one for $46!) The balance sprocket holder I will try
>   to weld unless anyone knows where to buy for less than $40!

If you want to be cheap and creative, get a friend with a *big* screw-
driver to wedge it against the flywheel ring gear while you twist the
crank bolt.  It works and is faster than removing the starter and
installing the lock.
 
>6. I understand the crankshaft pulley needs a puller to be removed.
>   Is there enough room to use the puller without taking out the rad?

No, you don't need a puller.

>7. What is the typical lifetime for an 85.5+ 944 waterpump.  85K km
>   seems premature.

It is entirely random, best I can tell.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 09:30:52 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: looking for a '71 door stay

Jerome,

> Anyone out there that can lead me to a original door stay for a 71 911 driver
> side?? I bought one but you have to drill more holes to make it fit, it seems
> porsche no longer makes the original door stay.

I replaced mine with the updated kind, I didn't have to drill but I do recall
having to do some filing with a big round bastard (rat-tail) file.
Scope it out and spend the $6-7 for a nice sharp new file of the
right size and you should be able to get the new door stay in in less than
an hour.

On the bright side- the new part is much simpler, cheaper and lighter weight.

 -Mitch

me directly at THOXNER@UALR.EDU , I will try to correct some of the inaccurate
info spread by D. Duffield. Thanks
Tom Oxner

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 09:38:35 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: early 911 oil cooler fitting

As a followup to my posting last night, I realized that the fitting
that screws into the LHS of the engine case is the perfect part
for repairing an oil cooler with a buggered fitting. I will take
it to a machine shop, ask them to cut the fitting off the oil cooler
and tap out the inside of the stub to accept the case fitting.
Hopefully the thread isn't too rare and someone will have a tap.

Also, re. the main oil line fitting on the LHS of the case,
I heard that there are two sizes.
Both have the same size thread into the case,
but use different sizes for the oil line fitting.

Please confirm or deny if you are familiar with these bits.

Thanks,

 -Mitch

Thom,

I have the same problem.  The good folks at AutoSport advised me to check 
out the oil temp and the thermo first before spending my hard-earned cash. 
 I bought the thermostat anyway and guess what... no change.  $$ down the 
tubes.

If you are going to buy one, get it from them.  I know you had a wierd 
experience there, but I've had nothing but the opposite.  They've been 
great.

I have my old thermo which you're welcome to swap out if you'd like to test 
yours.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Date: 17 Jul 1995 13:20:28 -0400
From: william.anders@smc.com
Subject: No More Points!

  Hello all,

  Has anyone had experience with the Pertronix Ignitor systems?  Especially
  for an early 911 with points.

  I have a '73 911 S & have tried a Crane Ignition system XR3000 that
  replaces the Bosch CD & the points with a light/sensor set-up.  While the
  CD replacement box worked fine, I had nothing but trouble with the points
  replacement hardware.  First, it was almost impossible to fit into the
  Bosch distributor (had to grind down the sensor wheel), then, possibly
  because of the tight fit or ?, had trouble with the vacuum retard unit
  working properly (with timing set correctly at 6000 RPM, the timing
  wouldn't retard enough at idle, all this works pretty well with the
  points installed).  Next, after about a week of operation & 1 autocross,
  the tach blew.  I have since removed unit, sold it, had tach fixed & am
  still looking for a good replacement for the points.

  Does the Igniter system fit inside a Bosch distributor?  Does it work
  with the stock Bocsh CD unit?  Can I use my stock coil?  Will my tach
  work OK & where will it connect to?  Will I have any problems with the
  centrifugal advance or the vacuum retard in the distributor?  Are there
  any other options out there to replace the distributor points?

  One last distributor related question.  Is there a shop in the So. Cal
  area that can test the advance curve of my Bosch distributor?

  Thanks,
  Otto Krossit

------------------------------

thinking about buying a 914.........)

Date: 17 Jul 1995 10:46:48 U
From: "John Tucker" <John_Tucker@engr.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: California Smog Waiver Rule

                                                                    10:15 AM
  OFFICE MEMO                                                 Time:
                      Subject:
                      California Smog Waiver Rule#000#                  07-17-95
                                                              Date:

This what a I received with my registration renewal info:

If after January 1, 1995, your vehicle fails Smog Check, new federal law
requires you to make necessary repairs to reduce your vehicle's emissions to
required levels.  
If your vehicle is not under warranty, and you have spent more than $450 for
appropriate emissions-related repairs at a licensed Smog Check repair facility,
you may be eligible for a one-time waiver.
Repair waivers will not be issued for:
Vehicles with missing, modified or disconnected emissions control equipment,
regardless of the costs to make repairs;
Vehicles identified as "Gross Polluters" - vehicles which have much higher
emissions than properly maintained vehicles in their class;
Vehicles that obtained a repair waiver after 1/1/95 in their most recent
biennial inspection or transfer of ownership.  Two consecutive repair waivers
will not be issued after 1/1/95.

This is just for everyone's info and also to provide more info regarding my
previous post stating that only one waiver would be issued.  This DMV card says
one-time waiver, but then also mentions not allowing two consecutive waivers. 
Therefore, I am not sure if you can obtain a waiver every other time you need a
smog check.  If it is really a one-time waiver than it goes without saying that
no two consecutive waivers will be issued.  Just thought I'd let you interpret
this for yourselves.  It also says that this is new federal law, so it may
affect people in all states in some way, I don't know.  John #000#



------------------------------

level is OK, measured with the dipstick and as indicated on the guage, and
the presure seems OK per the guage, about 30% of the guage at Idle, up to
50%+ with blips of the throtle, and the engine temp is normal.  What is
the trigger condition for the light, and what things should I check to
diagnose the problem.  The engine is a rebuilt 2.7L with MFI among other
updates...

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 95 15:28:00 EDT
From: Peter Tracy <pgt@novelmail.keps.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Waterpump questions



 ----------
>> From: porschephiles-request
>> To: kkan; porschephiles
>> Subject: Re: 944 Waterpump questions
>> Date: Monday, July 17, 1995 12:06PM
>>
>> You *might* be able to R&R the waterpump without removing the crank bolt.
>> I would pull all the other sprockets and rollers off, then remove the
>> four bolts (plus or minus) retaining the rear time belt cover (two at
>> the distributor rear cover, two low and to the block), then move the
>> cover forward yielding access.  Not sure whether this works...
>>

I recently changed the water pump in my '88. I was able to do it without 
removing the crank bolt and moving the rear timing cover out of the way just 
as Kevin suggests. It was not difficult.

Peter

------------------------------

Date: 17 Jul 1995 12:32:03 -0700
From: "Brian Delaney" <bdelan@farallon.com>
Subject: Euro 928 problems

Hi, Folks;

I have an '81 Euro 928 S which has an annoying idle problem.

(1)  When starting the card cold, the engine *almost* catches immediately. 
But after that quick tease, it drops back to requiring a long crank on the
starter.

(2)  Once lit, it barely idles at all.  What idle there is seems to cycle
wildly.  Hold a constant slight throttle, and the idle will range from about
2000 to about 50.  Foot off throttle: engine either dies or idles so low that
I'm concerned about oil pressure and bearing chatter.

(3)  At freeway speeds under this condition, the engine seems low on power,
and the exhaust note is significantly different.  Like it's not hitting on
all 8.

(4)  Once the engine is warm, the car will stay lit at idle.  But the idle
still cycles, from about 850 to about 500.

My mechanic has been unable to decipher this problem.  (1)  has always been
the case, (2) is a relatively recent development.

Second problem:  car pulls slightly to the right.  My mechanic insists that
the alignment is spot on.  Tire pressure has been checked.  Mechanic has no
idea.

The car has been a near constant headache since I bought it. Like finding out
that while the car was *mechanically* fit for California smog, the paperwork
had not been done correctly.  So I got to pay $3500 for the privilege of
having the smog equipment taken off, bolted back on again, and the forms
filled out. That process took 20 months.  I then got to find out that 20
months of neglect in an EPA impound yard had destroyed the leather dash, and
allowed A/C seals to dry out.

The point being that it has become difficult for me to enjoy the car anymore.
 So I am looking at selling the thing.  My mechanic has told me that if I'm
going to sell the thing, I shouldn't do any more work to it, because I won't
get my investment back in sales price.  He's probably right, but that just
feels like bad karma.  I've insisted on putting new pads, tires, and a bunch
of other stuff on, out of respect for the car (yes, it's a big water pumper,
but it still a Porsche) and for the next owner. 

 All of this means that I want to fix this thing right, but I don't want to
kill a lot of money doing it.  The Typical Porsche Dilemna.  I'll spend it if
I have to, but I reserve the right to grumble.

Any ideas out there?  I live in Oakland;  are there any mechanics which
people particularly recommend?    And how much would be fair to ask for such
a beast?

Brian Delaney             bdelan@farallon.com
'81 Euro 928 S
'92 ZX-11
We have enough youth.  How about a fountain of SMART?

Date:          Mon, 17 Jul 1995 13:26:30 +0000
From: "Dirk Bergstrom" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       Cars For Sale in CA

I've seen these two cars on my way to and from work for a while now, and 
I figured it was time to pass on the info:

First is an earlyish 944 (I'm an air guy...).  White paint in good
condition, no dings, one slight scrape, rubber trim OK, no evidence of
past collisions (no ripples, seams straight, etc.).  Interior is so so
(looked kinda faded and worn, but not thrashed).  Decent rubber on black
cookie cutters.  No puddles of precious bodily fluids under the car. 
This car has been for sale for almost a year--I don't know what the deal
is; never talked to the owner, just looked it over on the street.  (415)
493-5173 after 6:15 pm.  

The second car is more interesting:  1960 356 Super90 Cab.  Ivory paint, 
6 months old (car was masked, not disassembled; a nice paint job, but not 
concours), no rust visible anywhere, no dings, no ripples, no bubbles.  
The undercoat looks new.  Interior is in very nice condition, except 
for one nicely patched rip in the driver's seat; the steering wheel looks 
pristine, and there is a radio-shack radio mounted under the dash (could 
be easily removed...).  The wheels are in great condition.  Possible oil 
leak in engine (some brown discoloration on rear valence, like oil 
smoke?).  $35000 (415) 493-1259.

After I'd spent a few minutes looking over the car and taking notes, the
owner comes down the block with a handful of golf clubs.  I ask him a
few questions about the car, and he answers, adding that he just loves
the car.  When I ask him why he's selling, he says that this car is
actually a hook for a "bait and switch", what he's really selling is "an
identical car."  So I don't know what he's thinking, but it seems a bit
odd....  However, I figured that the car I saw was pretty nice, and the
price wasn't exactly low--maybe the car for sale was actually
worth looking at.  So I'm passing the word on to the list.  I pass this
guy's place every day on my way home, so I could be convinced to take a
look at the car if you're really interested.  Can't be that many '60
Super90 Cabs around...

No affiliation, etc. etc. etc..

Dirk Bergstrom
'75 911S, Broken &%$# window winder (just got the $30 part from 
Automotion)

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 13:56:44 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Mike Willis)
Subject: Re: California Smog Waiver Rule

>>> >If your vehicle is not under warranty, and you have spent more than
$450 for
>>> >appropriate emissions-related repairs at a licensed Smog Check repair
facility,
>>> >you may be eligible for a one-time waiver.
>>> 
>>> What isn't addressed here is what to you if you car has no smog parts (or
>>> they're completely shot) and the parts are absolutely, positively NLA from
>>> the manufacturer ...
>
>Ok, so where does that leave you, with respect to the waiver?  Can
>a car that needs a waiver one year, but then, because you can no
>longer get parts, is the car doomed?

No if the parts are not avail then you go to the Bureau of Automotive repair
and get the necessary waiver for the not avail parts. Not sure how much they
have tightened up on this. They do know what is and not avail in the market
place. So be sure that the stuff is not avail for ANY price. Missing parts
do not fall within the $450 cap. This is for Calif. not sure what is "right"
for other states.

MIke

>
>Pat
>pat@ixi.saic.com
>
>
>
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 14:02:36 -0700
From: sgmeza@popper.PacBell.COM (Sergio Meza)
Subject: Borla Exhaust for Sale

Fellow Porsche Pusher:

I have a used single inlet Borla stainless steel exhaust for sale. It has
dual outlets on the left side of the car and it comes with a catalyst test
pipe, stainless steel mounting strap and hardware. I had it on my 1994 3.2
Carrera TurboLook (recently sold and replaced with a 194-6 street/Time
Trial car) and it did wonders for both the perforance and sound of the car.

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 16:36:02 -0500 (CDT)
From: Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu>
Subject: Re: 944S Radiator Hose Problems

On Mon, 17 Jul 1995 sanjay@bga.com wrote:
[snip]

Exactly what I happened to my 944S hose (.04 revision).  It seemed to
happen after I overfilled (due to not RTFMing well enough) the coolant
reservoir.  I could be way on the left field on this one, but it seems
that the extra insulation that is wrapped around the power steering fluid
lines (the jug with the ZF label is right there) was rubbing against the
top of the hose.  I think that some joker while servicing my car (when it
was not under my ownership) had removed the power steering fluid jug and
not replaced it correctly.  The result was that the jug was not lined up
correctly and thus the power steering fluid hoses were routed differently
and thus rubbed against the radiator hose.  After looking at a few other
944s and the 968 I figured out that my instincts on how the jug should be
placed were correct and now the hoses are away from each other, plus it is
much easier to get to the oil filter.  BTW, which hose revision are you
having problems with?  The new hose I have is the .07 revision and I have
had it since March (~600miles) with no problems. 
I hope this was even slightly useful.
'85 Burgundy Ice Mazda 626LX	
'87 Guard's Red Porsche 944S				mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu
'93 Red-White Miyata Five-12	http://wuerlim.wustl.edu/users/mnk/mnk.html

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 95 13:49:00 ADT
From: "Southard, Keith" <KSOUTHAR@atu.com>
Subject: REPLY: 944S Radiator Hose Problems



 ----------
On Sat, 15 Jul 1995 17:51:47 -0500 (CDT) you said:
>Hi,
>
>I just got through replacing the radiator hose that goes from the termostat
>to the bottom of the radiator again.  I just replaced it six months ago.
>The car hasn't overheated at all....there's a new thermostat in
>there...there's a new water pump in there.....any clues what could be
>causing the problem.  Oh yes, it seems to always bust open at the top of 
the
>top bend.
>
>Sanjay@bga.com

Make sure that the hose is pushed all the way onto the water pump and the
radiator and make sure that it is TIGHT.  Have had the same problem
in the past & bought two new hoses as a result. The pressure generated
in the system will force the hose off until it runs against the water pump
pulley.  The pulley will rub through in fairly short order. All the while 
the
system DOES NOT leak because the clamp is just tight enough to seal
but not tight enough to hold the hose in place.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 17:51:57 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Steering Wheel Repair was Momo

Excerpts from mail: 17-Jul-95 Steering Wheel Repair was M.. by Bob
Polys@solar.sky.net 
> On a related topic: I have seen advertised a book(let) about repair of
> steering wheels such as was on the 356 types.  Apparently the book comes
> with an epoxy that is appropriate (their claim, not mine) for the repair of
> these wheels.  Does anyone have experience with these repairs or this book?
> What material were these wheels made with?  I have seen also advertised a
> "banjo" style wheel similar to the ones in my 550 books.  I do not have the
> name of the company with me, but does anyone have experience with the
> provider of replica type wheels?
>  
> Appreciate the help.
>  
> Great group.
>  
> Bob

    I don't know what kind of epoxy that was, but I have used PC-7
(similar to JB-Weld, only thicker) which is available in just about
every hardware store, to repair old hard rubber steering wheels for
Chevys.  This is the stuff that you're "supposed" to use, and it seems
to work pretty well.  The first time I used it, I got a couple of little
hairline cracks, but the second time I was more careful and it lookes
great, two years later, except for a few paint scuffs (not the epoxy's
fault.)  I used a Dremel tool to "grind out" the cracks to about 1/8"
wide (maybe even wider) and went all the way around the rim, where
possible, to try to relieve stresses in the old material before filling.
 To shape, I used a fine file and then covered the rough surface with
spot (glazing) putty and wet-sanded, primed, and painted.
    If you've got an old 356 wheel that is really shot, you might want
to try this before tossing it and buying an expensive repro one.

later.

nate

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 14:58:45 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: No More Points!

> 
>   Hello all,
> 
>   Has anyone had experience with the Pertronix Ignitor systems?  Especially
>   for an early 911 with points.
>

I put one in my 914 about a month ago.  Never tried to put one in a 911, but
I'd guess that it's reasonably similar.
 
>   Does the Igniter system fit inside a Bosch distributor?  Does it work
>   with the stock Bocsh CD unit?  Can I use my stock coil?  Will my tach
>   work OK & where will it connect to?  Will I have any problems with the
>   centrifugal advance or the vacuum retard in the distributor?  Are there
>   any other options out there to replace the distributor points?
>

Yes.  Don't know.  Yes.  Yes, same place.  Yes.  Yes.
 
>   Thanks,
>   Otto Krossit

The Igniter is a *very* tight fit inside the distributor.  All of the
electronics are contained in a little epoxy blob that replaces the points.
I had to file away at a couple of places to make it fit.  If I were to do
it again, I'd get the type that has just the interrupter (photocell/disk)
 inside the distributor, and the rest of the electronics outside.

Gary.

From: FiewVinder@aol.com
Subject: Pete Rose's 911 for sale?

     Today at lunch I stumbled upon a lot in Hamilton, OH (near Cincy) where
a red 911 was sitting.  On the windshield was written "formerly owned by Pete
Rose."  Whether it was or not, I don't know, but it was similar to a red 911
Pete used to own (he did a few local commercials featuring it).  Anyway, it
was a 1974 and it had 64,000 original miles.  I test drove it and it seemed
to run very strong.  However, the car was not in pristine condition.  The
interior was a little rough, and there was oil leaking on the exhaust,
causing a little smoke.  The car seemed a little sloppy shifting, but I don't
know whether that was normal for that year 911. It also had a botched window
tinting job. Red paint and Fuchs wheels looked pretty nice.  Tires were in
nice shape, too--Dunlops maybe?  He was asking $10,500.  If your interested
call Robert's Auto Sales and Service in Hamilton OH--513-868-2467.  All the
best,

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 16:33:43 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Sport-O-Matic!

Hi Dan. Re:

>A good friend of mine has a '70 911 with a sport-o-matic transaxle.  
>Apparently, the clutch has gone out on him and he needs to fix it.  I've
>called a few of my parts contacts and they all just laugh!  Is there a
>place where he can parts for this thing other than the dealer?  Or does the
>dealer even have parts?  Also, how hard would it be to swap out the s-o-m
>for a manual transaxle?   Please respond directly to my e-mail address, I'm
>not on this mailing list.

If he just needs a new _clutch disk_, he should look around for places that
rebuild them.  Here in the SF Bay Area I've heard of a place that does
Kevlar (or something) disks for about $80 - you supply the "core".  As to
the pressure plate, well, I don't know.

The Lash Int'l 914/4 914/6 manual (Automotion carries it) devotes 13 pages
w/lots of illustrations and figures to the Sportomatic. The pressure plate,
"carrier plate" and throwout bearing all look different from the usual
manual-tranny items, though.

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 16:45:49 -0700 (PDT)
From: tfab@netcom.com (thom fitzpatrick)
Subject: Re: California Smog Waiver Rule

And Mike Willis thus wrote:
> 
> >>> What isn't addressed here is what to you if you car has no smog parts (or
> >>> they're completely shot) and the parts are absolutely, positively NLA from
> >>> the manufacturer ...
> >
> >Ok, so where does that leave you, with respect to the waiver?  Can
> >a car that needs a waiver one year, but then, because you can no
> >longer get parts, is the car doomed?
> 
> No if the parts are not avail then you go to the Bureau of Automotive repair
> and get the necessary waiver for the not avail parts. Not sure how much they
> have tightened up on this. They do know what is and not avail in the market
> place. So be sure that the stuff is not avail for ANY price. Missing parts
> do not fall within the $450 cap. This is for Calif. not sure what is "right"
> for other states.

I went this route for my SO's BMW.  Believe me, since there is BIG MONEY to
bemade here, these places do their _damdest_ to find your part!  I was
quoted $1500 for the TO's for my SO's BMW.  I told them they were SOL
(hey, I liked that sentence)

If you go this route, take along a quart of vaseline...

Also, used/reconditioned parts count, so unless you have something
really exotic, you're prolly out of luck :(  

BTW - they do have MFI Pumps

Thom

was a giant white Ford Crown Victoria.  So now I'm driving a true land barge, a
great white whale of a car.  Can you say: Complete lack of road feel?  4000 lbs
and power steering boosted so high you can turn the wheel with a puff of
breath.  Actually it's rather scary to drive; controlling this much inertia and
barely knowing there's a road surface beneath you.  I understand the goal of
isolating the driver from the harsh rigors of driving, but lets be real.  I
just hope I can exchange it for something a little more interesting later.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 18:45:06 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: 944 Wheel balance affected by wheel locks?

Hi Ken. Re:

>Can the factory wheel locks affect the balance of the wheels?

I believe that if you buy McGard wheel locks from a dealer, those locks
weigh the same as the factory wheel nuts or bolts.  This is the case for
Jaguar, and is probably true for other "factory" locks that McGard makes
for the various car manufacturers.  

I spoke with the folks at McGard, and they told me that McGard's agreement
with the various car makes prevents them from selling you those "factory"
versions direct -- you _have_ to buy them from a dealer, etc.  Sometimes,
there's a difference between the "factory" version and the "generic" one
that McGard crosses if you call them directly.

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |
|        standard disclaimers apply         | 
|___________________________________________|

Porschephiles #1562                         Tue Jul 18 02:00:11 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 20:57:30 -0700
From: cjk50g@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Woodward)
Subject: RE: '85 3.2 stalling

>the stalling occurs at operating load and temp.  
>Fuel filter is clean. 
>Recently, it does it more frequently and is hard to restart.
>Doesn't sound like fuel - more like ignition since it is all-on and 
>all-off.

Don't give up on the potential for a fuel problem yet.  Check the 
pump's ground connections, delivery rate and pressure at the fuel rail. 
If its in the wrong you'll have your "all-off" situation w/lengthy 
re-starts as the lines refill.

Chris 

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 21:01:46 -0700
From: Papasan@eworld.com
Subject: Re: Dunlop & blizzak winter performance

i have the dunlops you are referring to on my c4.  cold weather conditions
are not too bad, but i think the c4 gives you this 
impression more than the tires.  this past winter i installed
winter tires on all four wheels, using bridgestone blizzaks.  this
is a setup not for the meek.  it is very "squirell-y" and unstable
at higher speeds.  the upside is that you could drive the car over
the top of an iceberg if so required.  all in all, my experience is
that if you have *lots* of snow go with the all around snows.
although i don't have experience with other snow tires on my 
C4, i would recommend trying the pirellis, as the blizzaks simply
have too much tread depth for light snow conditions.  the car
appears to be floating on the tires.  they are marvelous in deep
snow however.  if you are in a serious winter clime, i would go
for all around snows.  l live in pennsylvania which has semi
serious winters, and the dunlops don't cut it.  downside is that
you live with the car always feeling very "loose."  it makes you
a better driver though, particularly when you go back to the 
dunlops.
regards,
dan

Date: Mon, 17 Jul 1995 21:57:55 -0700
From: thomkuby@owens.ridgecrest.ca.us (thom kuby)
Subject: electrical bugs/turn signal switch

Greetings P-philers
for those of you who ain't electricians/mechanics can probably skip this
post...it's gonna be a long one...
I have this '68 912 with no turn signals.  I have all the other lights, but
no turn signals.
I have done the following:
a. consulted the factory wiring diagram(s) the color one for the original
911s and the black & white version for the 912-does anyone have the
foggiest idea where I might find the color wiring diagram IN COLOR for the
912? (hint: the guys in Reno have no clue-they said a color version of the
912 diagram  is in the OWNER'S MANUAL? has anyone else heard of this?) I
have all the factory workshop manuals pertinent to this car. I do not have
any parts catalogs though
b. tested ALL wiring for continuity-results all positive.
c. replaced the lower relay (down in pedal box with newer relay as old one
was NLA - howard adams in reno swears I have correct superceding part-I
have connected it according to the diagram, with howard's help...
d. replaced the upper relay (one by fuse block in trunk) This part bothers
me...the original relay posts are labeled (with north orientation, and
going counter-clockwise) "49a" ," KPC", and "15x49"
 - the replacement relay posts are labeled (again with northern orientation
and going counter-clockwise) "49", "49A" and "31"  again, this part is
supposed to be the correct superceding part as this relay is NLA, like it's
aforementioned brother down by the pedals.  The original relay sits there
and gets REAL HOT when I activate turn signals-new relay doesn't work at
all, I suspect incompatibility.
e. replaced the turn signal switch with one out of earlier car-this swap,
so far, has made no difference.
f. have checked/re-checked the wiring and fuses in the fuse
block-everything seems to be correct there.
the frustrating thing is this: I had all this shit working once (albeit
with the ORIGINAL turn signal switch-which had lots of other problems,
thereby prompting a swap) and then I took out the lower relay to put back
in a 914 (from whence it came...) and put a replacement relay in the 912.
I tested the replacement relay in the 914 first and it worked fine...
Does anyone out there have any ideas here? I can't be the only one that has
suffered from this particular gremlin.  does anyone know of any electrical
magicians? voodoo doctors? I'll try anything at this point.
If I don't resolve this problem *&#@* soon, I will probably say "screw it"
and turn this car into a "PCA event/autocross special" and go find another
street car that I can actually drive.  Out here in sunny southern
california, hand signals are a dangerous idea...the car is actually worthy
except for this damnable turn signal problem.
The little voice in the back of my head says;  "Track material..."
Help...
I hope to hear from somebody: please respond to either address listed below
and, thanks loads in advance.
cheers
Thom Kuby
Office:
 thom_kuby-cta@cl_c21smtp_gw.chinalake.navy.mil
OR
at home:
thomkuby@owens.ridgecrest.ca.us

Date: 14 Jul 1995 07:30:00 U
From: "Nans Kunz" <Nans_Kunz@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Brakes

 7/14/95       7:19 AM        Subject:    Brakes

Help, I need advice on brake pads.
I need brakes soon for my 86 951.  My car is used mostly as a daily driver on
the street with speeds occasionally over 100 mph.  I have also been to a
driving school at Sears Point, where the car gets driven fairly hard, and I
will probably return someday.  

My question is what are the choices and trade-offs in brake pad brands and/or
materials?  Is there one brake pad material and/or brand that is clearly
superior to all others or are all brake materials pretty much the same?  I
don't consider cost a major factor because of the importance of brakes and the
low frequency in which they need to be replaced, but I don't want to spend
extra money just to get a "brand name" either.  Two choices that I have seen
so far are:  "lifetime guarantee" over the counter Rabestos brakes from a
local Pep Boys for about $38 or OEM brakes on sale from the dealer for a
little over $30.  

Below I have listed the Brake Pad properties that I can think of that might be
important, but unfortunately most of these properties are not specified on the
package or any where else that I know of for the different brands of brakes.
>Coefficient of Friction; cold
>Coefficient of Friction; hot
>Abrasiveness; how fast it wears the rotors
>Conductivity; how fast the pads can conduct the heat away
>Temperature Resistance; how hot it can get before it is damaged
>Durability; how long it lasts ( of course compared to other pads under the
same driving conditions, your mileage may vary)
>Dust; how fast do the wheels get dirty
>Cost
>Availability
>Asbestos or not
>what is the metal in the semi metallic?

Any advice would be greatly appreciated.  I subscribe to the digest so I will
only see responses about once or twice a day.  If you want to respond
directly, my Email address is Nans_Kunz@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov.  If I get a lot
of good responses I will try to write up a nice summary.

Thanks,
Nans

86 951



------------------------------

Date:         Fri, 14 Jul 95 11:41:46 EDT
From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SS8299A@american.edu>
Subject:      An evening of Porsches


Well, it all began with plans to go see the new Hugh Grant movie "Nine
Months".  I decided to take my 928 because I hadn't driven it in several
days and the weather has been great.  I arived at my Mom's house outside
Wash. DC in a cute little town fittingly named "Old Town, VA".  I
quickly washed it in front of the house while several tourists walked
by, many stopping to look and comment on the car(this always makes you
proud!).  Then off we sped to the 8PM showing of what turned out to be a
very amusing movie.  Of course the highlight was Hugh's incredibly red
late 80's/early 90's 911 Cabriolet.  It definitely should have been
included in the credits, it had more screen time than some of the
supporting actors!  There were 2 sad parts, though, when he swerved off
the road and totaled the  front end(mechanic checks it out and exclaims
"good thing the engine is in the back, yuk yuk!")  and when he decides
to trade it in for a Ford Explorer to show his ball and chain, I mean
wife, that he is serious about having a baby(read 6,900 mile 944 turbo
for sale guy!)  Anyway, that's when the Porsche fun ended in the movie,
but I still had my 928 to look forward to driving home!  And what a ride
home it was!  I dropped of my parental unit, and started heading out to
the George Washington Parkway back to DC.  As I was approaching the
parkway I noticed some interesting headlights coming up behind me.  As
soon as I turned onto the parkway I realized that it was a 944.  We were
acting very civil and driving at normal speeds between the several
stoplights in Old Town.  We finally ended up at the last light before
the parkway opened up, right next to each other.  He smiled, I smiled
back and I started checking out his car.  It was black, like mine, and I
was trying to figure out if it was a turbo or not.  I decided that it
was not because of the boxyness of the car and a prominent rear spoiler,
when I always thought turbos were more rounded.  Well, I decided to keep
it civil and not "take off" merely to embarass him in his 944 with half
of my engine.  Well, he obviously did not feel the same way, for when
the light turned green he took off.  I remember thinking "poor guy, I'm
going to waste him".  I floored it and quickly caught up.  I shifted, he
shifted and I was watching my tach to shift at 5.7K and when I did this
I looked up, expecting to see him in my rearview mirror, but instead he
was right next to me!  I was instantly confused, how could a 944 keep up
with me?!  We both let up at about 70MPH(note people who chastised me
before for going 125 in a 45) and continued to play *SAFELY*(god, I feel
like I'm talking about sex!) with each other all the way to Georgetown.
It turns out that it was a 944 TURBO.  I felt better when I saw this.  I
should hope a '86 would be able to stay side by side with an '80 928!
Well, that's my night of Porsches, god I love my car!!!

Sean  '80 928


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 11:14:42 +0100
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Locking wheel nuts / Balance

> Can the factory wheel locks affect the balance of the wheels?
>
> Maybe the reason the shaky steering happens off and on is
> because whenever I remove the wheel, the wheel-lock is randomly
> positioned on any stud. It just so happens on the most recent removal,
> I re-installed the lock on the most out of balance position?

	Yes, the wheel locks can definately affect the wheel balance.

	Can't remember about my 944, but on the 911 the end of one of the wheel 
studs is painted (red on mine). Porsche advice is that the hole nearest the tyre 
valve *must* go on this stud, and the wheel lock *must* also go on this stud.

	BTW, doubt it will affect wheel balance :-) but in a recent Excellence 
article it was stated that the bottom of the crest on the centre cap should 
point to the valve for maximum concours points. I've looked at various factory 
literature and press photographs and the orientation of the crest always seems 
to be random. Any concours nuts out there like to comment?

Philip Katz ['89 911 Carrera Sport Coupe, taubenblau]

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 08:42:10 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 87' 944 reversing Lights not working

At 07:35 AM 7/18/95 +0100, Alex Brennan wrote:
>My 87' 944 reversing lights are not working.
>
>I have tested out the bulbs and they are ok.
>
>Would anyone be able to advise me as to where the reversing lights switch
>is located.

Alex,

There's a connector on the outside of the transmission case for this,
which gets dirty and loose.  It may be two single-contact connectors or
a double-contact, I forget.  Anyhow, clean it, make sure the contacts
are tight, and you should be all set.

Kevin

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 95 08:53:22 PDT
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: '81 928 Euro S problems


Brian,

Sorry to hear about your experiences with your 928.

>(2)  Once lit, it barely idles at all.  What idle there is seems to cycle
>wildly.  Hold a constant slight throttle, and the idle will range from about
>2000 to about 50.  Foot off throttle: engine either dies or idles so low that
>I'm concerned about oil pressure and bearing chatter.

A. First check the ignition system.  Timing, distributor cap, rotor, wires, 
plugs, plug gaps.  This is pretty standard.

B. Next check the fuel pressure.  Make sure the fuel filter is clean and that
the pump is delivering the proper pressure at various RPMs.  Fuel pressure
regulators can be troublesome.  Again, pretty standard.

C. With ignition and fuel okay, the problem becomes more interesting.
Look for air leaks, aka "false air".  This is air that gets into the engine 
behind the air flow meter.  If this un-measured air gets in, the engine
will run a little lean.  It should be okay after warm-up, when the fuel
injection computer runs in closed-loop and adjusts mixture based on the
feedback from the ox sensor.

You can use a stethoscope to listen for leaks.  Check the injector seals,
intake gaskets, and maybe the vacuum lines for the brake power booster,
fuel pressure regulators, and others I'm overlooking.

If you reach this point and everything's okay, now you gotta look at
sensors (air flow and temperature in particular) and the L-Jet computer.

This is my guess.  I haven't had this problem, but cold idle problems
are a common annoyance of my other car, a Saab 9000.  In fact, I took
these steps from the Saab mailing list.  Should be pretty similar since
the fuel injection components are very similar (L-Jet & LH-Jet).
Hope it helps.

Matt Carpenter
'84 928S
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 10:24:44 -0300
From: rosvall@itchy.mi.net (Peter & Julie Rosvall)
Subject: Re: Sport-O-Matic!

  Also, how hard would it be to swap out the s-o-m
>for a manual transaxle?   Please respond directly to my e-mail address, I'm
>not on this mailing list.

Dan,

I just completed a swap from a sporto to a five speed this spring. Once you
gather all the required parts, the swap is actually not that difficult;
everything is just bolt in and bolt out....there is no cutting or welding.
The clutch tube that you need for the clutch cable should already be
installed in the main tube.

I traded the old sporto trans but I threw out the clutch disk and assembly.
When I did it I knew I would regret it, it could have been anyones for the
asking....

Peter Rosvall
rosvall@mi.net

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 09:47:54 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Brakes

Street pads are fine for the street, as they stop without needing to be
heated first. The trade off is that they insulate the heat in the rotor.
Thats good for the street, as you'll warp the rotors, but still be able to
stop in the limit of big braking.

On the track this gets to be annoying. I toasted two sets of rotors using
stock pads (duh). My first change was to the original performance friction
carbon pads. They work fine at the track, but not nearly as good as stock
on my 4 mile commute. If you aren't going to start swapping components, I'd
get a set of carbon track pads and swap them for the track weekends. Its
not a big deal on a porsche to swap pads, especially since you have to
bleed the old fluid out before each event anyway.

Adding the cool brake kit is also a good idea for track use. It replaces
the indirect system of vanes used to direct air at the rotors with real
race car style ducts and hoses. They work, but won't compensate for overly
heavy left feet.

If you ARE thinking about surgery, there is no limit ($). I'm running the
"red" calipers off the 3.6 turbo and RSR 911, with 12.75" Coleman rotors.
The kit is from VCI in Joisey. The new GT-1 911 turbo evolution, currently
making 600 hp (pano), can be had with 15" rotors. As I discovered, this is
the usual spiral. The new calipers are too wide for the fuchs wheels, so I
needed new wheels, the new rear wheels hit the body so I needed new
suspension, the new suspension lowers the car, so I need new front control
arms...

Actually, you'll want to keep up with the control arm soap opera. Even if
your car is bone stock, its coming up on ten years old, and you should
check the arms for wear and loosness, especially where the ball joint is
attached to the hub carrier. The front suspension on the 944 series is off
the VW rabbit, and while there have been evolutionary changes, the current
problems reveal the limits in both the rabbit design, and the factory's
attention to same in the intervening years.

have fun,


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951 (Red Calipers, 255/40, 275/40-17s, turbo-cup suspension in process)
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
94 child
Groucho the cat (meow)



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 16:00:01 -0400
From: lucat@galactica.it (Luca Cattaneo)
Subject: CARRERA C2-RS

For Everybody in the world: please help me.

Hello, I'm an Italian with this intention: I'm trying to organize a list of
all the models of Carrera C2 RS 3.6 Liters made in 1991 and 1992 in about
2200 pieces.
There is something egual for the model 911 RS of 1972 (in a grat big book),
but nothing for the 3.6 Liters.
So, from every part of the world, please write an e-mail to this address:
lucat@galactica.it  
and in the subject write:
CARRERA C2-RS
If someone will be interested in the list, contact me and every 100 models
I'll send him.

In Your reply You have to write the following things:

1) date when You saw the RS (mounth and year- if You are not the owner);
2) nation where You saw the RS (or if You are the owner, nation where the
car was for the first time matriculated;
3) kind of RS (there are: BASE, TOURING-maybe just for Japan, LIGHT-maybe no
more then 100 models with the packet M003);
4) number of chassis (just the last four numbers);
5) colour of the body(if is the original or not, and please even the number
of color);
6) color of the safety bells and the write Carrera Rs inside the back cockpit;
7) if the chassis number is also on a small plate on the left side of the
vertical rod of the windscreen;
8) if the model is right or left way;
9) the capacity of the petrol tank (77 or 92 liters);
10) other extras not included in the series RS model (like Roll-bar for
races, anti-fire or air conditioned or radio);
11) mechanical modifications: like engine increased at 3.8 Liters, or breaks
of the RSR model, or other;
12) every other interesting new about the specified model.

I'll send this request every mounth in Porschephiles mailing list until the
end of 1995. I hope that You can help me; for the moment I have the
caracteristics of about 50 cars (most in Italy).

Sorry for my non perfect english, I wait Your reply.
Many thanks.
 

Luca Cattaneo-Milano-Italy

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 08:52:56 -0500
From: bill.williams@develcon.com (Bill Williams)
Subject: 914/911 Shifter Rebuild - Springs ?install??

Hi everybody!

Well, I'm rebuilding shifters (74-75 914s). Took 2 apart, 1 had a chunk
broken out of the contact surface of larger nylon spring retainer/thingy,
the other had a big burr on the top, flat part of the shifter 'ball' which
scored the inside of the shifter housing. The inside metal piece that's held
in place by the springs is perfect on one, the other has slight wear along
the ~1" reinforced piece.

Anyway, putting the 'best' pieces together: The remaining "good" shifter has
a bit of a wear indentation on the shaft about an inch down from the guts of
the assembly. I haven't figured out what effect this might have, yet...

Anyway, back to the question:  Anyone have tips for installing/compressing
the springs?! In hindsight it looks like if you had something to keep them
compressed-before removal-then you could just drop them back in. I'm past
that now though!

One more question : The bushing in the lowest part of the arm...How
tight/loose should it be? (Each was kind of corroded in place) Should I
Locktite it in place, or is it meant to rotate freely(i.e.: grease!)?

I've been reading postings about short shift kits, and they obviously
include the shifter arm. Do they include any of the other pieces that I've
found broken/damaged/worn in my latest adventure? (Obviously not the housing
itself!) Might be a good idea for those planning to go the short-shift route
to take theirs apart before-hand to see its condition. 

One last note, I do have 1 remaining shifter assembly that I haven't taken
apart---just in case!

Thanks for your help!

bill.williams@develcon.com

'74 914 1.8
'75 914 2.0
'73 914 parts x 2

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 08:10:41 -0700
From: "Wayne Michelsen" <wayne@darien.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re: Wanted Early 911/2 Car Cover

Ron,

> My suspicion is that the movers will roll my '66 912 into the moving
> van/semi will all the other stuff.  Would be nice if it had some
> kind of cover over it.

I think you're right.  But be sure to discuss the method of securing your car
in the truck.  On a move several years ago, I had my pristine '77 280Z shipped
in the moving van.  I did have a car cover, but the movers secured it by
running straps OVER the car and through each wheel well to the floor, one on
front another on the back.  The constant jarring of the load during travel
caused the straps to buff clear through the paint on all 4 quarter panels.

from the pump body, but no vibration and no whirring/humming noise.  I
take it this means my pump ist ja toasten.
        WTB:  One early (pre-75) fuel pump.  Working and cheap.

out of the car.  I had anticipated a gush of gasoline from the supply/
suction line (the one with the 9mm OD "hard" line).  Got nothing.  Then
I took the "return" line off the pump--GUSHER!  This is the one connec-
ted to the 7mm OD "hard" line through the tunnel.

for upside down transmission, bracketing for rear entry motor

been prepared with serious competition in mind. The craftsmanship is 
beautiful and the welds are georgeous. In addition to all the 
fabrication work that has been done the car has been fully seam welded.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 95 08:54:42 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 87 and later 944 water pump removal


As Kevin pointed out, it is possible to remove the water pump in a 1987 
or later 944 or 968 without removing the lower pulley (dropping the 
starter and using a flywheel lock, then removing the 190 ft-pd bolt 
from the cranckshaft).

You must, however, remove all pullies and the self-tensioning units 
from the engine to jockey the rear cover off the front of the engine.
968 owners may have to also replace any seals between the hydraulic 
belt tensioner and the block. 

Just did one, it is about the same time-wise, but easier than pulling 
that G** D**** pulley.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 12:04:08 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944S Fan Switch

At 10:31 AM 7/18/95 EDT, ATTY MICHAEL E RUDOLPH wrote:
>Dear Philers:
>   
>   I recently purchased a '87 944S and have had no problems.  However,
> my fan no longer works in any of the positions except the very last, 
>high position.  I need some help figuring out this problem before I 
>have to buy a new coolant system.  If anyone has some suggestions, I 
>would greatly appreciate it.  Thanks in advance. 

Typically a problem with the fan speed resistor block, which is located
on top of the fresh air blower.  The block has dropping resistors which
adjust voltage across the fan motor.  When it ages, the resistors
delaminate, overheat, and open some one or both of two internal breakers
in the resistor block assembly.

Call George B. at 944 Ecology for a good used part.  You don't want to
know what PCNA charges for 'em.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: 18 Jul 1995 17:55:08 U
From: Steve Poole <stevep@wrq.com>
Subject: Black Again

Here's a little plug for that product called "Black Again". It's an external
treatment and protectant for black plastic, rubber, and metal trim. I used it
on all my external hard rubber trim and was quite pleased. Then I used it on
the black air intake grill on the lid, which had a distinct gray tint ('79
911SC) and was even more pleased. Finally, I thought I'd try it out on the
Fuchs, which are beginning to ask for new black paint. Amazing! The dullness
is gone and the black is much deeper. They still need to be refinished
because of thin/scratched paint in places, but this is a great improvement
until then.

It doesn't seem to make any difference on the black manual antenna, and it
didn't work as well on the side trim as it did on the mirror, smile, and
bumper trim. I don't know yet if multiple applications improve the
appearance.

Larry at Carcare Specialties carries it. Dunno who else does. If your black
is fading at all then give it a try.

Steve Poole
stevep@wrq.com



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 95 08:43:00 ADT
From: "Southard, Keith" <KSOUTHAR@atu.com>
Subject: REPLY : 968cs - help! what is flattening the battery


Steve, I had the same problem last year in my '89 944. Turned out to be the
temperature sensor switch in the radiator. The switch was 'stuck' in the
closed position, keeping the fan running all the time. They normally 'fail' 
to the
closed position. It doesn't take long to drain the battery. The part is 
simple
to replace in the 944, takes about 20 minutes total.  I replaced mine with 
an
AUDI component. Local Porsche Master Technician advised to do so. It is
the same part manufactured by the same people to exactly the same
specifications but about 2/3rds the cost (about $35). BTW, your battery
should bounce right back.
 ----------
>From: porschephiles-request

Porschephiles #1564                         Tue Jul 18 19:38:25 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 10:07:13 -0700
From: "William Dunham" <dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com>
Subject: 911 idiot light solved

Thanks to those who replied to my question about the idiot light.  As several
of you suggested, the light is a brake system light, not an oil light. I
checked
the schematics last night, and that light is wired to two switches in parallel,
one that indicates that the handbrake is on, and one that they call the
"brake system failure" light.  I checked the switch for the handbrake and that
seems OK, but there is very little brake fluid in the reservior.  I'm going
to flush the brake system this weekend and see if that cures the problem
(pedal feels firm though).
At least it wasn't an oil pressure problem :-)

Thanks again

Bill
72 T
69 E targa



- -- 
William J. Dunham
Silicon Graphics
dunham@esd.sgi.com
(415)390-2129

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 10:36:10 -0800
From: pouceta@itersd1.iterus.org (Andre Poucet)
Subject: 911SC Oil leak / Smoke / Help

I've had similar symptoms (oil leaking on heat exchanger -> smoke, oil
light came up at low RPM) a couple of months ago and it turned out to be
the oil pressure switch that started leaking. When getting a new one (at
AJ-USA), they told me it was common for these little things to suddenly
fail (the plastic around the contact breaks down).

Anyway, less than 10.00 $ and the problem was solved. Let's hope it's not
something worse in your case. Good luck.


______________________________________________________________________________
Andre Poucet

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 13:33:12 -0400 (EDT)
From: Tom Baroni <tbaroni@JAKE.ap.org>
Subject: Re: 911 door seal replacement, sunroof cables

Paul,

I just replaced mine a month ago on my 87 930. I followed the step-
by step directions in one of the maintenance manuals I have purchased
recently. The job was not difficult. the process involves the removal
of the sunroof and installation of the 2 new cables. I purchased the
cables from automotion at $60 a piece. the cables actually include
the mounts. I can let you know the name of the book tomorrow.

rgds
tom 87 930 factory raspberry slant

high position.  I need some help figuring out this problem before I 
have to buy a new coolant system.  If anyone has some suggestions, I 
would greatly appreciate it.  Thanks in advance. 

   My work number is 414-730-8533 and my home number is 414-733-0126.

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 10:30:52 -0700 (PDT)

My very first car was a '59 bug.  Got the body and engine seperately,

about these cars?  We managed to get it about 5 miles from home when

> *try* to start my baby!

Oh..  Don't run the fuel pump "dry".  The gasoline acts as a lubricant
to keep its innards from frying.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 14:35:21 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Brakes

>Hi Doug,
>
>I was wondering what the difference between the "S4" calipers
>on the 951S and the "red" calipers on the 911 and your car are.
>
>Can you enlighten me?
>
>Thanks
>Mike
>951S

the red ones are more manly, mainly. As I recall, the S4s are like 308 mm
diameter rotors, the reds are for 322 mm, and there's a larger Brembo
(without porsche's patented quick release), the F-40 size at 330 mm.

There is also a difference in rotor vaning in some setups. Race rotors have
a curved vent blade, which is more effecient at high speed, as opposed to
the normal radial vane. The rotors I have are also slotted, since holes
need to be cast in, and floating. You should be able to get a different
rotor setup from any number of vendors, see any pano.

Floating rotors are held on by ridges on the hub, and allow the rotor to be
positioned by the caliper under braking. This makes for less pulling under
load, although they clank at low speed. I'm also running cool carbons which
are ok as far as stopping on the street, as the system is now so
overdesigned, but they squeal like a stuck pig. I'd like to find a used set
of C-2 turbo street pads. Anybody?

Regards,

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951 (Red Calipers, 255/40, 275/40-17s, turbo-cup suspension in process)
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
94 child
Groucho the cat (meow)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 17:22:52 -0400
From: ALAN968@aol.com
Subject: 968 Speedo

Read an article in Excellence about the speedo senders for the water cooled
cars.  Seems they think the sending unit on all 968's are on the transaxle.
 Wrong, it's on the left front wheel on the 95's.  Porsche uses the ABS
sensor to drive the speedo.  I found out in trying to solve why my speedo
would read 150 mph slowing to a stop.  I had Performance Friction pads on and
the frequency of the vibrations, squeal, was just right to induce a signal
into the ABS sensor.

Alan968
95 968 M030

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 95 15:16:00 PDT
From: "Channell, R." <CHANNELL@hsv.mdc.com>
Subject: Re: 911SC Oil leak / Smoke / Help


Barry asked if there was anything on top of an 80 911SC engine behind the 
injection  system that could leak oil.

Barry,
There is a seal on top of the engine behind all the FI stuff for what I 
think is an oil thermostat switch. IMO you just about have to remove either 
the FI or the engine to get to it. BTDT. I've also had to replace the cooler 
on the engine and could not figure out how to do it without removing the 
engine. BTDT too.You can probably check the thermostat switch with a small 
mirror. Position it over behind the FI stuff  at an angle so you can check 
the top of the engine for oil leaks. The switch is roughly (very) a flat 
diamond shape 2-2.5" long ways with a slightly raised circular shape in the 
center.

FWIW
Rob Channell
channellr@aol.com
1979 euro 911SC (with replaced engine oil cooler and thermostat switch seal)

PS. (IMHO alert here, no flames please)
 With the age of our cars and the low price of this seal, if you have the 
engine out for the engine oil cooler or something else you might should 
replace this thermostat. Don't ask me how I know.

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 18:04:35 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 Smile

>I am losing my Smile on my '83 911 SC.  I guess the rubber is getting old
and
>it no longer lies flat.
>
>My questions are:  1. How difficult is it to replace this piece of body
>rubber?   
>2. Where is the best place to purchase this part? 
>3. Are any special tools or other installation materials required?

This isn't very difficult.  In a nutshell, you need to remove the bumper,
take the old "smile" off, put the new one on and re-install the bumper.
In practice, I had a little trouble getting some of the nuts that attach
the rubber bellows to the bodywork off and I had a little trouble putting
the bumper back on by myself (having a friend help would be nice).

Bought the "smile" from Vertex for $85.  Worked for me.

HTH,

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911
