------------------------------

Date: 18 Jul 1995 20:33:45 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.COM (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: 911's summarized

> From: Wyn Rees <wrees@cuse.demon.co.uk>
> Subject:       911 C4 build 1988-93
>
> I am currently in the process of looking for my first 911 and wish to 
> understand more about these wonderful cars before I part with my 
> hard earned cash.
> A dealer( who was trying to put me off a car at one of his 
> competitors) said that the year of registration was no where near as 
> important as the year of build and mileage. He claimed that cars got 
> stockpiled from '89 and zero cars were manufactured through to 1993.
> I find this somewhat alarming and wonder how much truth there is in 
> this statement.
> Can anybody cast any light on this?
> Thanks in advance,
> Wyn Rees

Gees...it's discouraging to hear so much misinformation coming from
supposedly knowledgable professionals.  "how much truth.." to this assertion?
 Ah...none.

There's a ton of info in the archives and FAQ's on late 911's.   I'll
summarize some of it here (no turbo info; USA cars):

* 993 (95 on, terrific C4 version in late 94).  $63k and up, new.  Porsches's
most impressive 911 ever.  Big leap in performance and quality (and
cheaper!).  New body type, improved ergonomics, ride, brakes, power, quieter
inside and out.  Too refined?  Too quiet?  Too easy to drive well?
* C4 (89-94).  $35k-$55k.  Great car but criticized by the press and
enthusiasts for it's fixed power ratio (front vs rear), slightly slower
performance (than sister C2), steeper price, and tendency to plow
(understeer).  Early teething problems with electronics, clutches and
cylinder heads (see C2 below).  AWD version lost some of the 911 charm.
* C2 (90-94).  $35k-$55k.  Same great engine (3.6) as the C4.  Until mid 91
fix, many had cylinder head problems requiring machining and new P/C's. 
Factory pretty good about doing the service (even outside warranty).  C2/C4
body (964 type) integrated bumper and paint color.  ABS.  Recent drop in
value due to cheaper 993.
* Carrera (84-89).  $17k-$35k.  3.2 engine very strong, very reliable.  Big
improvements in 87 tranny, clutch, ventilation.  Oil-fed tensioners for all
years!
* SC (78-83).  $11k-$22k.  3.0 engine.  DURABLE.  Exploding rubber center
clutch.  Fender flares alloedg *big* tires.  Creature comforts.  Getting
heavier...
* 911 (74-77).  $7k-11k.  Generally speaking, bad years.  2.7 engines had
stressed-out magnesium alloy cases and many had thermal reactors (all US
77's, and all CA 75-76).  The combination cooked seals, caused oil leaks and
other miscellaneous problems like pulled head studs.  Fairly short lifespan
before needing rebuilding (a "proper" rebuild can turn these engines into
high performance, longer lasting ones, however).  "Carrera" 911 had SC fender
flares.  
* 911 (69-73).  $5k-25k.  2.0-2.4 engines.  Very desirable early years. 
Longer wheel base, strong, peaky engines.  Old today and so not as reliable. 
Fuel injection on S and E models, T in 72.  S is highly in demand.  T least
expensive but good driver with lower range torque.
* 911 (65-68).  $5k-$15k  Original 911 with 2.0 liter.  Stunned the world. 
Targa body had zip-out plastc rear window (67,68).  Some teething problems
(front end shake, and wheel/tire balance sensitivity).   68 was a so-so year
due to air-injection system which caused a lot of overheating and leaned-out
trouble (ie, fouled plugs).

Notes:
 - Pre 77 cars, except for some 76's, were not galvanized.  Body rust was a
serious (and $$) problem.  WATCH OUT.
 - The early cars are also notorious for tail wagging.  Not a problem at all
for an experienced driver, even an advantage.  But dangerous to the
uninitiated.
 - Get your hands on the 10/93 issue of Panorama and refer to the article on
buying an older 911.   _The Used 911 Story_ by Peter Zimmermann is excellent
(spiral handbook for about $18).
 - Always have an expert 911 mechanic thoroughly examine the car *before*
purchase.

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara, CA)
95 993 coupe, guards red
73.5 911T 2.7 coupe, ferrari red
85 535i, grey

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 95 10:58:50 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: 911 Door Seal


It's easy.  Just pull off the old seal, clean off any remaining
adhesive, and glue the new seal in.  Get a tube of 3M Trim Adhesive
at your local autobody supply shop.

The whole job takes 20 minutes.

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 95 12:29:48 PDT
From: rmoises@fx.com (Roger Moises)
Subject: Re: Monterey Historics (minimal p-content)



  The Sports Car Racing Association of the Monterey Peninsula (SCRAMP), which
organizes the races along with Steve Earle's General Racing, Ltd., can be
reached at (800) 327-SECA. They should be able to provide you with all
of the ticket and scheduling info.

  This year's "Historic" will be held August 18-20. I've attended the Historic 
off and on for a number of years and I'd recommend going on both Saturday *and* 
Sunday. Saturday is a good time to cruise the paddock, vendor, and parking areas
(you can certainly judge the quality of this event by the *awesome* cars that 
can be found throughout the parking areas). Saturday is usually reserved
for special parade laps and festivities for the featured marque (Lotus this
year). If I recall correctly, Saturday's racing includes most of the "older"
pre-war machines, and ends with the mid-80's F1 cars. Sunday's racing
usually includes the 60's sports/GT cars and the 70's Can-Am/FIA cars.

  I've found that Saturdays are *much* more crowded than Sundays; come as early
as possible for the best (closest) possible parking place. The Monterey transit
buses run shuttles from "remote" parking sites to the track; the only drawback
are the horrendously long lines of people waiting for shuttles to return to
their cars at the end of the day! I believe that the gate ticket price is the 
same as the advance price.

  Hope this helps!


Roger Moises (rmoises@fx.com)
Dow Jones Telerate Systems, Inc.

        The electrical resistance through the pump worked out to be
about 2 ohms.  I popped the plate on the end (with the fittings) off
the pump, and saw some rust on the internal bits of the mechanism.
So I conclude that my impeller is frozen.  I'm going to just get my-
self another pump--maybe try to resurrect this one later.  Time is
of the essence, now.

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 17:01:34 -0700
From: Stefan Czereyski <czereysk@saifr00.ateng.az.honeywell.com>
Subject: Recharging your A/C Condenser

In reply to your questions 

When I went to recharge my A/C system I learned that my fender mounted A/C
condenser leaks badly.  There may also be a leak in the hose fittings by the
condenser as well.  The car is an '83 911 SC Euro and it has an after market
A/C unit.
The hose fittings are easy to deal with, but I am clueless about the
condenser.  I assume it can not be repaired.  Thus, I am searching for a
source of used or new condensers.  The compressor is Japanese, Seiko, I think,
but I can't find a name or any numbers on the condenser unit.
My questions are:
1. Who is a good source for after market A/C Porsche units who might also be
knowledge about the different after market units that were available in the
mid 80s?
2. What is this likely to cost?
3. Is this a job I can do myself (note, there is no Freon left in the system)?
 4. This may be the most important question - Would it be wise to convert my
A/C system now to use the environmental friendly refrigerant as oppose to just
repair it to use Freon that wont be available in a year or so?



o Unless you already possess FREON you cannot buy it. I hope you bought
  a 30 lb ($240) before Nov. 94. Now only A/C certified mechanics can buy it.

o You can get hoses repaired at a hydraulic hose shop or remade. Check the
  yellow pages or your local airport repair facility.

  Many indepents stock hoses, receivers, condensors etc... Most stock some
  items but all so check around. Try BAP, Checker, AutoZone, PEP Boys etc...

o You need new O-rings when you remove hoses

o You need a new receiver-drier if the system is open to the air for more
  than a hour or so.

o You new a vacuum pump to evacuate any moisture before you recharge it.
  I got one for $19.95 from Harbor Freight Tools (runs off compressed air).

o You need a Freon R-12 gauge set (hi + low pressures gauges) about $40 - $60
  most auto parts stores

o An Electronic Freon leak detector to check nyour hoses & connections. Otherwise
  your just wasting your money, the Freon and zapping the environment. I got
  an electronic handheld one for $89.95 from J. C. Whitney plus $20.00 extra
  for an extension probe. For some reason the same things sell for $200 - $300
  at auto-parts stores.

o An A/C repair manual with pressure table. Get thew Haynes A/C manual.
  About $12 at AutoZone.

o Changing to R135 is a good idea if extensive rework is needed as everything
  legal to buy. Needs certain changes. You can really put on most any thing
  you want in terms of available compressors, receivers, driers, condensors
  etc... As long as they are compatible the only problem will be custom
  hoses & brackets. Suggest finding a good independent A/C shop. A dealer will
  eat you alive - they just want to put in new everything.

Stefan Czereyski
83 944 Black
85 XJ6 Blue
65 XKE Red

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 17:43:39 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 13:24:18 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 fuel pump/fuel lines

>Dave, you shoud have a filter between the pump and the tank on the
>suction line (9mm) If the fuel filter is stopped up, you would have no
>fuel past the filter in that line.

        Hmm...  But it's a new filter, new lines--except for the "hard"
lines.  Oh, sh*t!  I just realized that my new filter is *NOT* the kind
that's impossible to mount backwards!  DOUH!
        One more thing to check!
        I'm going to also try using a vaccuum pump to see if I can get
anything through the "supply" line (the 7mm).  (Thanks to Soren for the
suggestion!)
        I bet a backwards filter *is* the problem.  It's a pretty big
coincidence for the pump to be working when I pulled everything out, and
not working when I put it back in.  Things like that are usually dumbsh*t
mistakes on the part of the installer (me).

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 09:11:38 -0700 (MDT)
From: Wade Guthrie <wade@realm2.realm.net>
Subject: Re: Monterey Historics (minimal p-content)

> I'm hoping to make the pilgrimage to Monterey this August.  

Me too, maybe we could set-up a Porschephile gathering at the
Historic races!  Anyone else interested?

> Does anyone have any information
> on the event schedule for the Monterey Historics?  Or a pointer
> thereto? [...] Does it run for multiple days?  When is the best time to 
> see 60s and 70s vintage racing machinery in action?  

It runs all three days (August 18, 19, and 20).  Last year (my first 
historic races), they had practice sesssions on Friday andraces
Saturday and Sunday.  I think they went old to new on both days.

> Is it usually crowded
> or hard to get into?  How much are the tickets and does one need
> to get them in advance?

It was pretty crowded last year, but the marque was Ferrari.  You
can get a $30 one-day ticket or a $75 3-day ticket by dialing
1-800-327-SECA.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 95 09:23:29 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Fangio


I watched Fangio push the W196 around Laguna Seca a few years back.
He was quite a sight, but the Mercedes Benz people had a 500SL roadster
in front of him to slow him down, he was 81 at the time. Fangio expressed
that it wasn't representitive of the car to be held back like that. His
fellow Argentine F1 drive, Frolian Gonzales, felt the same way.
On the Sunday exhibition, the driver of the 500SL got a taste of what 
Fangio once did to his competition as they exited turn 9. Fangio 
bore down on the 500SL with full throttle, making the 500SL driver 
lose his concentration and loop off the course into the dirt. Fangio 
and Gonzales ripped past and had two full laps to themselves. Fangio was smiling and driving, driving the piss out of the GP car.

At the autograph session later we asked Fangio how the car felt. He 
replied (my translation) "After so many years, it was a good drive. We
stopped racing that car too soon. It felt good to feel 40 again."

He and Gonzales signed autographs, even an Argentine flag my buddy 
brought. It has been the only Monterey Historic that honored a single 
man. 

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: 18 Jul 1995 10:02:50 -0500
From: "Elliot Entin" <elliot.entin@alphatech.com>
Subject: 911 A/C Condenser

                       Subject:                               Time:9:32 AM
  OFFICE MEMO          911 A/C Condenser                      Date:7/18/95

When I went to recharge my A/C system I learned that my fender mounted A/C
condenser leaks badly.  There may also be a leak in the hose fittings by the
condenser as well.  The car is an '83 911 SC Euro and it has an after market
A/C unit.
The hose fittings are easier to deal with, but I am clueless about the
condenser.  I assume it can not be repaired.  Thus, I am searching for a
source of used or new condensers.  The compressor is Japanese, Seiko, I think,
but I can't find a name or any numbers on the condenser unit.  
My questions are: 
1. Who is a good source for after market A/C Porsche units who might also be
knowledge about the different after market units that were available in the
mid 80s?  
2. What is this likely to cost?  
3. Is this a job I can do myself (note there is no Freon left in the system)?
4. This may be the most important question - Would it be wise to convert my
A/C system now to use the environmental friendly refrigerant as oppose to just
repair it to use Freon that wont be available in a year or so? 
TIA 
Elliot

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 22:06:20 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 914 fuel pump/fuel lines

At 01:24 PM 7/18/95 -0500, Dave Darling wrote:
>        I bet a backwards filter *is* the problem.  It's a pretty big
>coincidence for the pump to be working when I pulled everything out, and
>not working when I put it back in.  Things like that are usually dumbsh*t
>mistakes on the part of the installer (me).

What can happen is that the car might run fine at idle, but starve for
fuel at higher RPM's.  This happened to a friend running an MFI 911 in
vintage events.  He chased his tail with the MFI system for about a
year, maybe longer.  His mechanic *finally* had the "oh shit" realization
of what was up!

Kevin

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 12:01:26 -0600
From: gwilensky@gryphonsw.com (Gabriel Wilensky)
Subject: Fangio

>>Juan Manuel Fangio, arguably the greatest grand prix driver
>>of all time, died last night in Argentina.
>
>>BTW he was 84 years old
>
>This isn't Porsche news, and commenting on it probably qualifies me as a
>certified 'old guy', but, the best thing I've ever seen in any race was
>Fangio, driving a factory Mercedes F1 car at a vintage race ( during the 1st
>or 2nd year of the Long Beach Grand Prix), and absolutely destroying the
>competition! He was in his late 60's at the time, and among others, Sterling
>Moss was part of the field! On the first lap, he (Fangio) came on to, and
>exited,  the pit straight before any other cars were visible to spectators.
>
>Phil Van Buskirk, PMLetter@aol.com





That's a good Fangio story. Even though I never saw the man, I heard other
stories that made him a legend, like once in a race when he hit a barrel or
something on the edge of the racetrack while going tight around a corner
and a kid that was sitting nearby got up and put the thing back in the same
place. In the following laps Fangio hit the thing again and the kid kept
puting it back. At the end of the race, which of course Fangio won, he went
to the kid and thanked him because that barrel (or whatever it was) marked
the fastest (and clearly not obvious) way around the corner.

Phil (or anybody else), if you know more stuff about Fangio, I would like
to know.



Thanks,


Gabriel

From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: 944 Squeaky Brakes / Lighting ???

>        87  944 Turbo has brakes that would drive the most loving
>scraper of fongernails down the blackboard (SCREEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEETCH!!)
>crazy.  At slow speed braking (brakes must also be cool - if I've been
>doing heavy braking, no squeal), the most irritating, high-pitched squeak
>emminates from the brakes (front, I believe).  Any solutions before I take
>the pads out and coat the BACK of the pad with white lithium grease or a
>light coating of Neverseize?
>
>
>        ALso - I love my fog lights - however, when switching to high beams,
>the fogs go off (on my 914 as well).  Any ideas on how to keep fog lights
>on all the time?
>
>
>        Darrin Lucas
>
>        73  914  2.0
>        87  944  Turbo
>        71  911  Targa
>
>        90  Audi 90 Quattro  (For Sale)

I've never used it, but there is special goop to put behind the pads to
keep them from squealing. Try a car parts place. Grease of any kind and
brakes are bad idea. I've never had the problem with stock brakes on my 86,
though.

There is a relay wired to the fogs. Get the wiring diagram. Technically,
the fogs and high beams are for different driving conditions. I also figure
that more light is better, when its safe enough to run high beams.

have fun,

doug dykaar

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 11:13:00 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Re: Monterey Historics (minimal p-content)


> I'm hoping to make the pilgrimage to Monterey this August.  My
> plan is to catch the Concours Italiana on Friday August 18th,
> miss the Pebble Beach Concours altogether, but to catch some
> of the Historic racing at Laguna.  Does anyone have any information
> on the event schedule for the Monterey Historics?  Or a pointer
> thereto?
> 
> Does it run for multiple days?  When is the best time to see 60s
> and 70s vintage racing machinery in action?  Is it usually crowded
> or hard to get into?  How much are the tickets and does one need
> to get them in advance?

I don't have a precise schedule, but here is how it usually runs:
Friday is usually a practice day.  The pits are open and less crowded,
so it's a good day to see things up close.  Saturday used to be the
only race day, but now it's spilled over into Sunday as well.  As I
recall, they have practice/qualifying in the mornings and "official
races" in the afternoons.

It's not hard to get into.  I think you can buy tickets at the gate.
Saturday has usually been more crowded than Sunday, but I don't know
if that's still true.

My schedule will probably be:
Friday AM: Italian Concours
Friday PM: Historics
Saturday: Some Historics, maybe some other sights
Sunday AM: Pebble Beach (miss the mobs by arriving early)

Maybe I'll see you there.  Anyone want to plan a Porschephiles
gathering sometime during the weekend?  Where's a good brewpub in the
Monterey area?

- --Walt Thode

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 10:53:07 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: Monterey Historic Auto Races

Paul et al.,

> Does it run for multiple days?  When is the best time to see 60s
> and 70s vintage racing machinery in action?  Is it usually crowded
> or hard to get into?  How much are the tickets and does one need
> to get them in advance?

I believe there will be practice Friday and races Saturday and Sunday.
Last year I went on Saturday and they had races in chronological order,
the 60s and 70s cars were in the afternoon. It's not too crowded
once you get in, but parking is a bit of an exercise. Try to get there in
the morning because it takes a while to park, catch the shuttle bus,
and get situated. Be aware that the remote parking areas can be very dusty,
so don't spend the morning detailing your auto before you drive it there. 

I think it cost something like $16 to get into the
races on Saturday. The paddock pass costs a lot extra ($20?) but shouldn't 
be missed.  The cars are BEAUTIFUL and should definitely be seen up close.
You don't have to buy tickets ahead of time, don't waste the extra $2-3 
per ticket, there's no way that they will sell out (we're talking several
square miles of hot, dusty wilderness here, and a few thousand fans).
Oh yeah- don't forget a brimmed hat and sunscreen.
It can be real hot. I prefer to bring beer money instead of lugging
an ice chest up and down the hills.

If you're thinking of staying overnight, make your hotel reservations now.
Every motel in Monterey and Carmel will be full that weekend.

If someone else has more schedule details, please post as they become
available.

 -Mitch


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 14:25:13 -0400
From: pigozzi@pilot.msu.edu (Bruce Wm. Pigozzi)
Subject: Meguiar's Questions

Nathan Hanson just asked a good question about correcting a problem
involving a Meguiar's product.  I've used the #26 yellow paste wax for some
time but now find myself looking to clean my 84 944 before the next coat of
wax. I went to my local supplier of miscellaneous auto products (Meridian,
here in central Michigan, take your Porsche newsletter coupon) and
confronted a display of about 10-12 different products (all Mirror Glaze).
Each one is numbered and the "instructions" usually describe two or three
you should use before and two or three after the one in your hand.  I came
home a little confused and pulled out a few of my trusty mail order
catelogues - thought to be a good source of information.  Here I find (was
it in Imparts?) a two page display of Meguiar's products, all with numbers,
but it seems not the same numbers as in the Meridian Auto Supplies.  

I take this as time for some research.  I have found an array of products
with numbers that simply bewilder.  My list has stopped with (just numbers):
00, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, 16, 17, 19, 20, 26, 34, 36, 39, 40, 42, 62,
and 66.  I'm sure there are more.  Each of these also has a short name and,
at least in the catelog, a category (wash, cleaner, polish and ??). 

I've looked for Meguiar's on WWW to no avail.  Is there a source which
reduces this array to a manageable selection process.  I tried starting a
flow chart but gave up.  I now have a bottle of #5 for tough spots and
scratches, #6 to do the whole car once, and trusty #26 for the final shine
(thus, in that order 5-6-26).  But, I'm afraid to start.  Is my sequence
right!?  I'm afraid I'll have Nathan's problem.  I'm figuring on going over
the whole car at least twice.  Am I naive, will it take 3 or 4 or perhaps
15-18 steps??
Bruce Wm. Pigozzi
Associate Professor of Geography
Michigan State University

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 21:54:37 -0500 (CDT)
From: Paul Christopher Schlesselman <schless@jove.acs.unt.edu>
Subject: Re: Squeaky Brakes / 944/951 Lighting

On Tue, 18 Jul 1995, Darrin wrote:

> 	87  944 Turbo has brakes that would drive the most loving
> scraper of fongernails down the blackboard (SCREEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEETCH!!)

Probably time for new pads and to get the rotors turned, be sure to have 
them anti-swirled??
to remove spiral action of brake lathe.  Be sure pads are in good shape
and brake pistons arn't hanging up.  Orange rubber gue is available for 
pad-piston contact area. 
> 
> 	ALso - I love my fog lights - however, when switching to high beams,
> the fogs go off (on my 914 as well).  Any ideas on how to keep fog lights
> on all the time?
> 
Yes I have done this, but I later added the Aux Euro driving lights.  The 
Aux Driving (951)
light now come on with high beams.  A special relay in the fuse box connects 
driving lights to 12v when high beams on. (relay was installed at factory  
but does nothing on US models, I added wiring and aux reflectors)

944 or 951
**Also, I had to modify the doggle in the fuse box to make it ROW compliant.
**and a few mods to wiring on under side of fuse panel.
 
A good retrofit is to use 7 inch H4 with 100/55w bulbs.
So now on high I have 2x100w 7 inchers and 2x100w driving lights (sucks 
power!)

schless@jove.acs.unt.edu                        Perfection is Acceptable 
http://www.unt.edu/~schless                          
- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 18:39:25 -0700
From: jcjensen@raychem.com
Subject: IMSA GTS2 Sears Pt- We won!

     How I spent my last weekend:
     
     I'm currently having my 911 engine rebuilt by Rob King of S-Car-Go 
     Racing in San Rafael, California,  Rob was the mechanic for a GTS2 
     entry at Sears Point this weekend, and allowed me to join the crew as 
     errand boy/car polisher/CV joint ball cleaner.  Despite the job 
     description, I had a fantastic time.  GTS2 is made up of a pack of 
     911s, several Mazdas, and several Nissans.  The BMWs that normally 
     race were not in attendance.
     
     The car I crewed for is owned and driven by Kevin Buckler, who is in 
     the Porsche parts business (Racer's Group and Performance Wholesale). 
     The car is sponsored by Togo's sandwich shops, whose owner is a big 
     Porsche fanatic (a Ruf and an early modified 911).  This was Kevin's 
     first IMSA race, and he was driving a car that wasn't even driveable 
     until July 7!
     
     The car is brand new, having been built to GTS2 specs from a 1970 911 
     chassis.  It's amazing to see the transformation the car went through, 
     ending up looking like a brand new RSR.  The engine was a 3.6 built by 
     Jerry Woods (who stopped by with Bruce Anderson on Sunday) and 
     produces approximately 350 hp.  Engine management and fuel injection 
     was by Motec, and is all computer programmed.  In fact, a high idle 
     problem the morning of the race was solved in about one minute by the 
     Motec technician, simply by reprogramming the accelerator pedal 
     calibration.
     
     The car has all the usual goodies, including carbon fiber body panels, 
     RSR rear wing, adjustable heim-joint spring plates, coil-over 
     suspension, adjustable trailing arm mounting, transmission cooling, 
     and full tubing to reinforce the chassis.  One thing that caused 
     problems was wear on the CV joint: the extreme angle of the shafts as 
     a result of lowering the car so much really stressed the CV.  An 
     upside-down transmission mount will probably solve this.
     
     The car weighed in at slightly over 2100 pounds, and consistently 
     turned 1:42s.  Kevin qualified the car second, behind a purpose-built 
     tube-frame Mazda RX-7.  Kevin was ahead of all 911s, including a 
     factory-backed entry and several tube-frame cars.  It so amazed the 
     other teams that Alwin Springer, director of racing for PCNA, stopped 
     by to see the car's setup after qualifying on Saturday!  Everyone 
     wanted to know how this new driver in a brand new car could be going 
     so fast.
     
     The race was incredibly exciting, the longest 45 minutes of my life.  
     All cars pulled away cleanly after a false start, with about 10 911s 
     among the 15 entries.  Included in the field was the essentially 
     bone-stock 993 that was raced at Daytona.  (This car was turning 
     1:57s, in comparison to the race-prepared cars that were in the low 
     1:40s.)
     
     Kevin stayed in second place most of the first half, with 2 laps 
     running in front.  The Mazda began pushing him hard while he led, 
     though, and Kevin wisely let him by.  At about lap 15 (of 26 for the 
     45 minutes), Kevin's car started smoking heavily.  What was it? Oil? 
     Tranny? Tires rubbing because suspension sagged?  We couldn't tell 
     because the pits were upwind of the track.  Since Kevin's lap times 
     were still ok, all we could do was hope he didn't get black-flagged 
     and could finish the race. Shortly after this, the leading RX-7 slowed 
     suddenly with mechanical problems and pitted.  That left us in the 
     lead, with a strong battle between positions 2 and 3 allowing Kevin to 
     gain some breathing room.  Incredibly, the car held on and won by 9 
     seconds, finishing in front of an RX-7 and a 911. The crew was 
     ecstatic!  Kevin drove a great race and the car came through!
     
     We were then told to get the car to the winner's circle.  So our first 
     problem was: where the hell is the winner's circle?  As the car pulled 
     away to go find the winner's circle, it revealed a large spreading 
     puddle of transmission fluid, the cause of all the smoke.  Turned out 
     that a line to the transmission fluid cooling pump was leaking, but 
     the tranny held on to the end.
     
     My congratulations go out to Kevin, car fabricator Roger Hamlin, and 
     mechanics Roger Hawley and Rob King.  The teamwork required to build 
     and run a successful racecar are truly awe inspiring.  I can't wait to 
     get my own car on the track, even if it's only a PCA driver's event.  
     I can always pretend!
     
     Thanks for bearing with me.  It was so exciting I had to write about 
     it.
     
     Jeff Jensen
     jcjensen@raychem.com
     73 RS almost restored

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 22:25:33 -0500 (CDT)
From: Paul Christopher Schlesselman <schless@jove.acs.unt.edu>
Subject: Re: 944S Fan Switch

On Tue, 18 Jul 1995, ATTY MICHAEL E RUDOLPH wrote:

Which fan are you refering to?  ac/heater or radiator.

AC/heater has voltage droping resitors are barried benith cowl near
air intake vents (hazy on the exact location).  They allow lower ac 
ventelation flow rates.

Radiator fans are 2 speed or 2 stage controled by relay/thermal switch
combination.  thermal swithch is mounted in radiator, low is on at about 
195F high at about 115F (again, hazy) .  relays 
are in the fuse box.  fans are always on, low speed, when ac is on.  
So an emergency option is to keep ac on if fan-thermostat not kicking on 
fans.  


> Dear Philers:
>    
>    I recently purchased a '87 944S and have had no problems.  However,
>  my fan no longer works in any of the positions except the very last, 
> high position.  I need some help figuring out this problem before I 
> have to buy a new coolant system.  If anyone has some suggestions, I 
> would greatly appreciate it.  Thanks in advance.

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 22:56:02 -0500 (CDT)
From: Paul Christopher Schlesselman <schless@jove.acs.unt.edu>
Subject: Re: Radio tuning solution (fwd)


this is the ever popular windshield antanae problem.

There is a signal amp hidden benith windshield behind glove box.
It MUST recieve 12v power if you like to listen to Rush on AM.
SO you MUST be sure that the wire in loom behind radio is feed 12v.
It is given power only when radio is on (antanea-orange wire out of deck)

I dont remember the color combo of wire in the loom-check schematics.

> sucks. I have the windshield antenna on my 87 930. Can not
> receive any am stations. 

> > Please advise me if I'm the only one out there that has this problem.  The
> > reception sucks big time.  Its the Monteray series, I herd from other

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 20:07:47 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Steamed at Stupidity

Joe Browne <brownej@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>, calling the kettle black, 
whined: 

>Yesterday, I am following a Continental .... at the proper speed limit 
>plus 9 mph. .... He managed to kick the tire up, it hit my car under 
>the bumper and dented the hell out of the airdamn/fascia.  I am pissed
>because;
>
>1.  Why can't people drive with visibility more than 3.5 feet in front 
>    of their car?

    Just a thought, Joe:  If you had been driving with a little more
    visibility yourself, this probably wouldn't have happened.

>4.  Does anyone else have this story and did you sue somebody.

    That's it... Look around for someone else to blame it on.
    After you sue his insurance company, you can get back on this list
    and bitch about how high your insurance rates are.  Way to go.

>I don't believe that I was following particularly closely.  There was 
>a good 4-5 car lengths between us but certainly not enough to react to 
>still life tire corpses.

    The definition of "not following too closely" involves leaving
    enough room to react to ANY unforeseen circumstance.  At -- how
    fast did you say you were going?  64 or 74 mph? -- That probably
    means a MINIMUM of 7 or 8 car lengths, not 4 or 5.  How'd you
    manage to get through Drivers' Ed without hearing about the "one
    car length for every 10 mph" or "two-to-three seconds between you
    and the car you're following" rule?

    Sorry for your misfortune, but there's really no one to blame but
    yourself.

>Thanks for letting me vent.

    No problem.

    -Andy

Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 20:02:13 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: 944 Lug nuts - weighed

In trying to determine whether wheel-locks can affect balance, I
weighed the factory nuts on my 944 phone-dials:

Regular lug nut : ~20 g

Hollow lug nut:         ~25 g
Lock + Plastic Cap: ~25 g

The locking nut weighs more than double a regular nut. The balance
weight stuck on the wheel is only 21 g. It so happened that the lock nut
was on the stud closest the valve stem. Maybe this had an additive affect?
But then again, maybe this is insignificant as the lugs are so close to the
wheel centre. Anyways, I moved the lock-nut opposite the valve stem.
We shall see tomorrow...

Ken '86 944

Subject: Re: electrical bugs/turn signal switch

Random guess from a guy who just got his turn signals working and who assumes 
a 912 is like a 911. Have you checked the ground at the rear signal light unit 
(it should be connected to the body very close to the signal light housing. 
Second, do you have the correct bulbs? I believe they are dual filament and 
there is a single filament which will fit....

If these are obvious suggestions... FWIW

When you drive a tank ...

> 2.  If they can't talk on the phone and drive, shouldn't they choose?

I believe that New Jersey actually has a law that states that you must 
pull over if you are going to use a cel-phone.  At least it's that way on 
the Jersey Turnpike.

> 3.  How can trucks just shed their tires and leave them in the middle of
> the road to be met by my wallet?  I noticed 4 other tire carcasses in the
> highway during the next 10 miles as well as a mattress.

Keep in mind that the tire probably came off of wheel 14 in the back and 
the driver didn't know he lost it til his next stop.  As for the mattress 
 - I guess someone's sleeping on a boxsprings tonight!

> 4.  Does anyone else have this story and did you sue somebody.

I tried to go after the DOT in Florida over just such as this (a DOT sign 
had come off of the stand (men at work) and was invisible at night).  
Front wheels went over, but vaccuum sucked the sign's edge up and ripped 
off my right heat exchanger and muffler and the right rear tire was 
totalled.  The lawyer I contacted just laughed and apologized for not 
being willing to take my case.  Calls to the State Patrol were greeted 
with "Drive more carefully" and "Stuff happens."  My insurance company 
paid up, but didn't even try to confront the DOT folks.

> 5.  Most importantly,  I seek advice on where to get a replacement fascia
> for less than the price of a new car.  Send me e-mail directly to avoid
> cluttering the list.

N/C

> good 4-5 car lengths between us but certainly not enough to react to still

of times.  My condolences.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 95 06:21 BST-1
From: steve_s@cix.compulink.co.uk (Steve Sampson)
Subject: Re:  968cs - help! what is flattening the battary?

In-Reply-To: <199507181306.JAA05285@ew0200.ASTRO.GE.COM>
First off, thanks to all of you that sent useful ideas. 

Finally I got the car up to the dealer, and he said that it was either 
the thermostat, or a relay in the control box. It WAS the relay. He 
fitted a new one and charged parts and labour to warrenty.

The battery only went all the way down once, and appears to be fine. I 
hope that if it fails, it does so soon, since the car will soon be 2 
years old which is (I think) the end of the warrenty period. The idea of 
a trickle charger through the cigarette lighter sounds good. I will look 
around for one. Here in the old world (the UK) I am not sure such a thing 
has been invented. Perhaps its my lack of technical knowledge! 

The obvious answer, to disconect the battery turns out to be not too 
smart, because the car then looses a lot of its settings. While after 10 
mins or so it should re work them out, the dealer says it often does not, 
and has to be reset from the computer in the garage. 

So, if you dont use the car very frequently, you get into a catch 22 
situation. If you dont use it the battaery goes down. If you disconect it 
the car looses its memory. Oh, and for a reason I do not understand, you 
cant charge it with the battery connected! The dealers suggestion was 
start it up once a week and just let it run in the garage. He has no idea 
however how long to run it for to replace the loss from starting and a 
weeks standing. Anyone? 

Hopefully I will get more time to use it soon, which will be the best 
solution!

One of you asked 'what is a 968cs'? The cs stands for club sport. Perhaps 
it was only released in the UK & Europe. Its a 2 seat(recaro) 968 with 
low profile tyres, lowered suspension, 17" wheels, engine, gearbox (with 
closer ratios) and wind up windows and some lights. Not much else, so the 
weight has dropped. The result is its cheap, quick and much less to go 
wrong. (Except for that relay!)

Thanks again, Steve.

The Car:
Speed Yellow RS America/RSR as featured in the BF Goodrich
tire ads run in many of the auto mags in the US.  It started life
as one of the first exampes of the '93 RS America and has since been
converted to full 3.8 RSR specs, and then some... Monte will gladly
fill in the details.

This car has a very successful history of PCA Club Racing and
IMSA competition and most recently placed 5th in the IMSA Bridgestone
Supercar series event at Sears Point.  This is a very fast and sorted
out race car with all the best equipment.  With over $100K invested,
the owner is asking $86,500 negotiable.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 18 Jul 1995 22:42:54 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: 911 Smile

It is not a big problem to replace the smile, assuming you are not intimidated 
by the thought of removing the front bumper. Basically you need to unsnap the 
little nylon clips which hold on the rubber strip at the front of the bumper, 
separate the bellows at the side from the bumper and then unbolt the 4 bolts ( 
2 on each side) which hold the bumper on to the mounts. You should be able to 
separate the bumper at least far enough to reach the screws which go around 
the outside edge of the headlight bucket (from the underside up and the 4 
screws inside the front trunk panel and the thing comes off. Replacement is 
(to quote the British) reverse of the previous steps. Note I don't have air, 
but do have headlight washers and the whole round trip took about 1 1/2 hrs 
including help from my 9 year old son....

I went with the Porsche piece.....well made and appeared to be made out of 
galvanized metal with rubber....ought to last...

Have fun


Dennis Kalma

smilin' 911S with Kremer 3.2

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 01:25:33 -0400 (EDT)
From: Williams Stephan <willias@ERE.UMontreal.CA>
Subject:  Porschephiles' Porsche finds new home  


My first Porsche.

1988 944S. Purchased from a Porschephile (944 FAQmeister Dennis Mitch),
discovered through the Pphiles mailing list, inspected in a shop 4500 km
away thanks to the many recommendations of Bay Area 'philes.

3000 miles to its new home in beautiful but excessively weathery
Montreal. Side trip for a Parade Lap of my home town. By the end of the
journey my only wish was that I could have lived even further away.
This is a wonderful car.

My sincere thanks to the people who make this list possible, to those
that make it the incredible ressource that it is, to everybody who helped
me with the car, and to DM for taking good care of it, then making it
available to the Porschephiles first!

 nuclear tests.

 to the French Government.

 and so on, on the list, please send a copy of the mail back to the 
 addresses below, so that  we can keep track of this project. If you 
 have any comment please send mails to us. And also, if you are 
 multi-lingual and have friends who may not understand English, 
 please translate this message and add it to the end of the mail. 
 Thank you very much.

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 05:10:30 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Cure for Steamed at Stupidity

You hit something in the road.  This indicates you didn't have time to
react and avoid the obstacle.  This means you were following too closely/
overdriving you lights/not paying attention/calling ET on the bone phone/
(fill in the blank _________).

I'll bet that trucker never knew he lost a tread till he pulled it in for the
night.  (If I see a truck with a tread aflappin' in the wind, I try to signal
him - from *in front* of course.)  You don't hear that Stinkin' Lincoln pilot
bitching do you?  (or maybe he is - on the "Lost Lincoln Net")   *You're*
the one with the bunged fascia and *you're* the one that'll end up paying
to make it right therefore, *you're* the one that's got to keep his eyes
peeled and WATCH OUT!

My car rides so low I've gotten used to removing the fascia, banging it
out and painting it  on a yearly basis (don't even bother with putty any 
more,  you just wouldn't believe what chipguard can hide down that low).
I used to p*ss and moan but now try to look at it as "maintenance".

Are the roads safe?  No.  Will they ever be safe?  Probably not.  Best
defense?  Maintain an elevated level of alertness AT ALL TIMES.
It requires a bit more effort than "regular driving" but is one helluva
lot easier that straightening pinged sheetmetal.  (no IMHO here, I
this for a fact).  

Having sat through this sermon, you may ask, "If you're so good, Mark,
how come you're still pulling the front end off every year?"  Answer:
cause I SCREWED UP!  It's *my* fault.  I've gotten so used to driving
I sometimes loose sight of how dangerous hurtling down the road
at speed with all those other lunatics can be.  Then, WHAP!, and
I'd give nearly anything to be able to take back the previous minute.

Just a though for all the whiners out there who always think it's the
other person's fault.  I need to step off this soapbox, sit on it, and
finish this brake job I've started.


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 05:10:53 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Sell 944 Turbo or Keep the Kids?

To: David, David, Alan,

And all the rest of you guys that have the unmitigated *gall* to
suggest I'm not a "sensitive, 90's sort of guy" and that I value
my car more highly than children.  I broke down over the weekend,
borrowed one of my friend's children, and took the little monsters
for a ride in my beloved P-Car.  Can you believe the ungrateful
little wretches were less than impressed?  

My question is:  How do you get all those little fingernail scratch
marks off the inside of the trunk lid?  Was I out of line when I asked
my buddy to pay to have it repainted?  Is there a product availabe
to get the urine smell out of Perlon carpet?

Whope, sheath them flamethrowers, boys.  Only KIDding! ;-} (pun intended)

Seriously:  I made the decision years ago to not have children.  I
reasoned (purely personal) that there are more than enough people
on this earth right now for my tastes without me going out there and adding
more.  Plus, I'm barely responsible for myself and don't need to be
taking on any 18+ year commitments.  I really enjoy my friends' children
and like to think I have a positive influence on them in some ways (choice
of automobiles, for instance).   I'll almost always give a kid a ride in
my car if they agree to follow the rules (get parents permission, buckle 
up, ask before touching any knobs, no food or drinks allowed).  *My* rule
is to drive as safely as possible to bring the precious cargo home in
one (undamaged) piece.  No "thrillers" till you're old enough to know
better.

I sometimes forget how much people think of their children (having
none myself) and sincerely apologize to anyone I may have offended.
Bottom line:  Keep the car.  Keep the kids.  Keep the job.  (you'll
need it to pay for it all).  And who says we can't have it all?


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 11:00:06 +0100
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 968CS - help! what is flattening the battery?

> The idea of a trickle charger through the cigarette lighter sounds good. I 
> will look around for one. Here in the old world (the UK) I am not sure such a 
> thing  has been invented. Perhaps its my lack of technical knowledge!

	I have seen such a device advertised in the UK in the Motoring & Leisure 
magazine which all CSMA (Civil Service Motoring Association) members get. You 
could probably build one yourself cheaply from a battery trickle charge plus 
Cigarette Lighter plug (available in Tandys).

> The obvious answer, to disconect the battery turns out to be not too 
> smart, because the car then looses a lot of its settings. While after 10 
> mins or so it should re work them out, the dealer says it often does not, 
> and has to be reset from the computer in the garage. 

	If it *should* do it, but doesn't, and the car is still in warranty, I'd 
be chasing my dealer hard to get it fixed. Otherwise you may be laying yourself 
open to big bills in the future.

	BTW, I took a 968CS for a test drive last year. Beautiful car (and it 
got rave reviews from the press), but a bit too impractical for a daily driver. 
Even getting in and out of the Kevlar seats is a bit of a job for my (corpulent) 
body. How do Porsche get away with taking lots of bits out of a car and then 
charging *more* for it?

	For our transatlantically-challenged friends, PCGB also sell (sold?) a 
968 Sport which is halfway between the stripped-out Club Sport and the fully 
loaded 968. Don't have the exact spec but could dig it out if anyone really 
wants to know.

Philip Katz <Katz_P_M@bt-web.bt.co.uk>

P.S. Am I missing bits when I get the Digest? Someone followed up to a posting 
about hitting a tyre lost by a truck ("Steamed at Stupidity") and I saw the 
followups but not the original message. Also a message I sent yesterday evening 
about wheel locks affecting tyre balance never appeared, though that could be a 
problem with the link from me to tta.com ...

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 13:43:59 +0200
From: Hans-Petter Lien <lien@hoggar.ethz.ch>
Subject: corrosion?

Hi there -
- ----------
First, I'd like to thank everybody who responded 
to my 944 wooden hinge request. Looks as if building
such a piece could be a fine project for the winter, 
when the pcar is covered up anyway...
*
Also have a q. about the durability of the galvanized bodies 
of pcars. Saw a slightly dented and otherwise neglected 
looking 924 recently, and noticed something which seemed
to be corrosion on the one front corner and around the lower 
door area/wheel wells. What do you have to do (or rather, 
_not_ do after an accident) to be left with such an ugly 
looking body?? I thought the 924s were galvanized....
Does anyone have experiences with galvanized but still corroded 
pcars? What's the half-life of bare pcar metal compared to other 
bare car bodies anyway? And what's the correct procedure when 
repairing dents on galvanized metal (welding/drilling, pull, paint 
type jobs)? Is the galvanizing on pcars any different from the 
one Audi uses (having larger production numbers)?
Would like to know before needing a repair job!

Sincerely,
Hans-Petter Lien
lien@hoggar.ethz.ch
'87 944 S wine red [bordeaux :-)] 
(No obvious corrosion so far!)

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 08:31:33 EST
From: Lynn Kane 904-833-3660 <KANEL@mail.firn.edu>
Subject: High beams, Fog Lights, and Swirl Marks

TO: Darran Lucas
RE: Fog Lights and High Beams

The reason your fog lights go off when you turn on the high beams is that 
fog lights are not designed to work with high beams.  They are designed to 
augment your low beams.  Additionally, in some states it is illegal to run 
fog lights on anything but low-beam.


TO: Nathan Hanson
RE: Swirl Marks

Last weekend a tip was offered to end swirl marks on a TV show called 
_Shadetree Mechanic_.  They sprinkled corn startch on the wax before they 
buffed it off and they maintained it eliminated the swirl marks.  They said 
a handy way to do it was to put the corn startch in a salt shaker.


Mike Kane
 -'84 944 (in pieces)
kanel@mail.firn.edu

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 95 09:15:27 PDT
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: Pete Rose's 911


To find out if the car was Pete's, just take the VIN #
to an Ohio title bureau.  They'll be able to tell you all
the owners since '92 (when their system was installed).
Before that, you need to go to the county where the paper
was kept.

Matt Carpenter
'84 928S

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 07:52:48 -0700 (PDT)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: 90 911 C4 Bleeding brakes ?

Fellow Porschephiles,

I am a new owner of a 1990 C4.  Over my lifetime I have bleed quite a few 
brake systems.  But none have been ABS and none have been as "complex" as 
the C4's.

And so I was wondering - can you bleed the C4s brakes they way you can 
any car?  In particular I am worried that since (I think) the hydralic 
fluid is shared between the brakes and the differential locks - how can 
you bleed the entire system?

Also, I can usually tell when a line has been flushed when I start seeing 
new fluid coming out the bleed valve at each wheel.  But if the fluid in 
the car is "new" looking then how do you know when you have flushed the 
line?  Is there a guess on the number of pedal presses needed to clear one 
of the four lines?

Any other hints would be appreciated.  I'm bleeding them in preparation 
for my first drivers' ed event.  I may have my shop do them (b/c of lack 
of time) but wanted to know how anyway.

Thanks,
Scott (scokelly@netcom.com)

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 95 07:18:00 ADT
From: "Southard, Keith" <KSOUTHAR@atu.com>
Subject: Reply: Following too closely


Joe Browne <brownej@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>, wrote:
               
>Yesterday, I am following a Continental...4-5 car lengths .... at the 
proper speed limit
>plus 9 mph. .... He managed to kick the tire up, it hit my car under
>the bumper and dented the hell out of the airdamn/fascia.  I am pissed....

You were OBVIOUSLY following much too closely otherwise you could have
avoided the confrontation with the tire. If you value your life and car
you should leave enough room between yourself and the car ahead to react to
any situation, including a live tire. You have NO ONE TO BLAME EXCEPT
YOURSELF. 4-5 car lenths at 64 mph is about half what most people need to
react, given that they are NOT normally poised, ready and waiting to react 
to
an emergency situation. If you were traveling at 74 mph your 
IRRESPONSIBILITY
is even more evident.

Stop whining, be a man and take responsibility for YOUR own mistake.

KSouthard@ATU.Com
'89 944 Silver Streak Daily Driver & Autocross Machine
'71 914 Rolling Rust Bucket and Spare Parts Assortment

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 11:25:12 -0400 (EDT)
From: Matt Clement <mclement@access.digex.net>
Subject: Re: 993 C2 stalling



On Tue, 11 Jul 1995, Bob wrote:

> My 993 coupe has an interesting habit. If the A/C is running and the 
> compressor is engaged, the engine stalls when coming to a stop. I 
> guess most 993 drivers have noticed that when you depress the clutch 
> and remove your foot from the gas, the engine speed drops waaaay down 
> then comes back up to idle. In my case the speed drops so far that 
> the engine flames out.  The dealer has plugged in his diagnostic voo-
> doo machine and claims the car is fine.  

I have the same problem with my 87 944S, and was told by my mechanic (an 
independant Porsche specialist, not a main-agent dealer.) that it was 
probably a problem with either the vacuum or the DME.

- -- Matt


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 95 09:35:27 CDT
From: Darvell Hunt <dvhunt@cessna.sim.es.com>
Subject: Re: Steamed at Stupidity 

>>1.  Why can't people drive with visibility more than 3.5 feet in front 
>>    of their car?

>    Just a thought, Joe:  If you had been driving with a little more
>    visibility yourself, this probably wouldn't have happened.

No, I think you're wrong there.  I had a tire flipped up at me as well, which
ripped my front plate and plate holder clean off.  Only a few hundred feet
would have prevented it.  It's hard to dodge something flying straight at
you.

>    Sorry for your misfortune, but there's really no one to blame but
>    yourself.

Don't be so cynical.

In my case, a big truck hit the tire, flipped it at the car in front of
me, who flipped it at me.  Some things can't be avoided.  As for who to
sue -- I doubt you can -- even if you had the license number of the car
in front of you.  Things like this happen.  It's like the car in front
of you flipping a rock and breaking your windshield.  It it really the
fault of the car in front of you?  Is it really your fault?  Who knows.

According to the insurance company, it probably doesn't matter.

Dar

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 11:45:40 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Reply: Following too closely

On Wed, 19 Jul 1995, Southard, Keith wrote:

> Joe Browne <brownej@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>, wrote:
>                
> >Yesterday, I am following a Continental...4-5 car lengths .... at the 
> proper speed limit
> >plus 9 mph. .... He managed to kick the tire up, it hit my car under
> >the bumper and dented the hell out of the airdamn/fascia.  I am pissed....
> 
> You were OBVIOUSLY following much too closely otherwise you could have
> avoided the confrontation with the tire. If you value your life and car
> you should leave enough room between yourself and the car ahead to react to
> any situation, including a live tire. You have NO ONE TO BLAME EXCEPT
> YOURSELF. 4-5 car lenths at 64 mph is about half what most people need to
This depends on where you happen to be in the country... I used to live 
in Indiana (both northern and southern) and you could do this. In 
Mississippi, you can even have 20 car lengths if your heart so desires, 
but in New Jersey, if you back off even one car length at 55 mph, someone 
will cut in and use that space. Here, it really is a matter of having to 
trust the driver in front of you to not do stupid things or stop 
suddenly. There is no alternative but to stop driving. Like I said, the 
sapce will be used, and I have never seen anyone more than 10 ft. off of 
anyone's bumper, at 55 mph, 75 mph, or even 90 mph. In some places, 
that's just the way it is, it isn't irresponsibility, it's just the way 
things are.

People who attempt to drive and carry on a meaningful conversation 
without a handsfree phone are dangerous to follow, anywhere. Consider 
that this person is probably more concerned with the safety of whatever 
he's talking to or about than other people's safety. If you do have 
acellular phone, do what I do, pull off to the side of the road and use 
it... With only 10 ft. between me and that guy in front of me, I can't 
even afford the time it takes to look at the buttons and make sure I'm 
dialing the right number...
 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 08:47:15 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: flying objects

I once let a lawnmower slip off the bed of a pickup because I had
neglected to close the tailgate(!).  Someone in a dilapidated panel
truck then ran over it.  I think if he had sued me he would have won.
Same as if you're carrying a mattress on your roof and it slides off,
or some such.

The above are clearly the result of negligence.  The tire fragment,
given that the laws are geared toward average drivers, may not be.  It
is, however, something you could probably collect on if you have
comprehensive coverage.  I still have no deductible on mine, which
came in handy when someone keyed my Cherokee.  If you hit an animal,
that's comprehensive also.  Comprehensive claims do not raise your
premiums the way collision claims do, but if you have too many the
company may yank coverage or require you to take a higher deductible.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno

And Steven Gilbert thus wrote:

> truck then ran over it.  I think if he had sued me he would have won.

I ran over a shovel a while back.  My car is too low to go over it, and I 
didn't see it in time to do anything about it (75MPH +/- - in a 55 Zone, BTW)

What was _embarassing_ was I had to stop, get the jack out, and lift the car 
up to get the damn thing out!  And I was stuck in an area with concrete walls
on both sides, so I couldn't get off on the shoulder!

My worst episode was taking out a deer between 50-60 MPH in a karmann ghia,
at night (of course) on Icehouse Road, off of HWY 50.  I then had to
crawl home with only the light of one of the stars and one parking light
that miraculously survived.   I sold that car for 50 cents and bought a
Scirocco (and put the change in a piggy bank :) ) and the day after I 
bought it I smacked _3_ deer - I ran into a whole pack of them at 6:00am 
again on Icehouse road!

Thom

dreary, drizzly foggy and cold (grin - I know, I used to live there !)

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 11:25:06 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: corrosion?

>Also have a q. about the durability of the galvanized bodies 
>of pcars. Saw a slightly dented and otherwise neglected 
>looking 924 recently, and noticed something which seemed
>to be corrosion on the one front corner and around the lower 
>door area/wheel wells. What do you have to do (or rather, 
>_not_ do after an accident) to be left with such an ugly 
>looking body?? I thought the 924s were galvanized....

The early 924s (through '79) only have the floor galvanized.
I have a friend with a '79 924 that has developed rust bubbles
around the windshield, the sunroof, and in both front quarterpanels.
Much of the floor pans are exposed metal with absolutely no
rust.

Ross Stites
'87 951

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 10:43:04 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: Do fog lights really work??

You wrote: 
>
>I have never been able to descern any improvement in night visibility
>by turning on my foglights.

Fog light do not shine far ahead of the car the lenses on fog lights 
spread the bean along the front of the car so you see the lane markers 
etc.

Fog lights are not driving lights. Do not really do any good in normal 
weather condtions. Most of the time the lights are out of adj and shine 
toward the sky of straight down either way are useless.

Driving lights will light up the road in front of the pcar and result 
in better visability. Be careful with these as most will blind oncoming 
drivers and if that driver is a cop it is ticket time. 

mike 
- -- 
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 95 13:49 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Why do they *do* that?

Well, the 944 has been running a little hot lately, and with help from some
fellow Porschphiles I diagnosed the problem as a sticking thermostat.  It's
been getting worse, especially with the hot weather lately, so on Monday I
got a new one.  Put it in the car, and it's running much cooler now -- just like
it did before the thermostat began acting up.

Problem is, when I say "put it in the car", I mean I put the bag on the floor
behind the driver's seat, intending to do the install this weekend.  So, of
course, now that I have the part, the car acts like I don't need it.

How do they *know* these things?

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 14:30:14 -0500
From: Joe Browne <brownej@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  Following too closely

I appreciate the words of support in time of crisis ( banged-up valence)
and even the words of contstructive(I hope) criticism. Perhaps I was
following too closely to the 'gentleman' in the 5000 pound, 74 mph, phone
booth.  It just seems that there must be a certain level of risk and
performance that one can accept as a given when driving on public
roads.  I dare say that on most freeways, if a car was able to come to
an instantaneous halt (not possible but indulge me), there would be a pile
up of biblical proportions.  Would that driver be responsible for the
pile-up?  My view is yes.  If you agree, then you may also agree that
leaving something in the middle of the road is wrong, and that also not
watching the road ahead in time to react to it is also wrong.  And yes, 
not leaving enough room to come to a complete stop if an inanimate
object pops up between my car and my sight limitation (lincoln) is wrong. 
I just feel that my wrong is a lesser wrong, yet I am the one paying
100%.  There is some injustice here, and I passed it on to the only crew
that I thought might understand the sight of an ugly scar on a beautiful
machine.  UPDATE: since the tire was airborne after being hit by the car
in front of me, it is a comprehensive claim and not a collision claim.  My
rates will be unaffected.

Subject: re: Do Fog Lights Really Work?


Seems like 90% or so of BMW drivers (excluding yours truly) use
them in all kinds of weather, sometimes even in daylight. I still
haven't figured out why. I only use mine if there's fog.

I always figured that fog lights were good for preventing someone from 
hitting me head-on, and the low beam placement does prevent blinding
yourself with your own lights. 

I really like the red rear fog lights that are popular in Europe. They
really increase visibility in any bad weather.

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 14:13:01 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: 1983 930  - A Question

>Did Porsche export 930's to the US in 1983?  I have a recent article in 
>Road and Track (or MotorTrend) which indicates that there were no 930's 
>imported during that period.  

No they didn't import 930s in the early '80s.  An easy way to tell is
to look at the VIN in the windshield on the drivers side.  Grey market
cars have a string of 4 or 5 (can't remember) Z's at the beginning of
their VINs.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 15:35:46 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: 1987 944 tire sizes.

>Could I get larger tires for my rear wheels?  Does it affect anything in
>a bad way?  Currently I hav 215 60R15's and was wondering if an upgrade
>to a larger or fatter wheel does anything.
>
>Danny Tong
>1987 944 White.
>
>------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> "I'm not an alcoholic, I just     |  Danny Tong    bbaxter@u.washington.edu
>  play one in real life."          |    "And on the eighth day, God created
>        - Brian Bain,  1995        |        Danny...Whoa, that was cool..."
>------------------------------------------------------------------------------


225/50-15s will fit your 7" rims without changing diameter (much). Thats
the setup on my "5". Think of it this way, the only thing keeping you from
flying off into the woods backwards are four small contact patches, each
about the size of your open hand. Any improvement you can make will go a
long way. The lower apect ratio is a shorter, stiffer sidewall, that will
speed up steering response.

Beyond wider tires, larger diameter wheels and wider, lower aspect ratio
tires usually require stiffer suspension to take advantage of the increased
grip. But hey, its only money.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951 (Red Calipers, 255/40, 275/40-17s, turbo-cup suspension in process)
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
94 child
Groucho the cat (meow)

Subject: 1988 944 Turbo S VIN number discrepancy


The 944 FAQ sheet indicates the 1988 944 Turbo S chassis number
should be in the 97JN50000- range. The VIN number on my newly
acquired 1988 944 Turbo S is WP0AA2959JN151550. The original 
dealer sticker for this car clearly indicates the 944 Turbo S 
option package:

    - 4 cly 2.5 liter 247 HP with larger turbocharger
    - sport chassis
    - 7Jx16 wheels with 225/50VR16 tires, front
    - 9Jx16 wheels with 245/45VR16 tires, rear
    - anti-lock break system
    - limited slip differential
    - all cloth interior
    - cloth door panels
    - full power seats
    - split rear seats
    - rear window wiper
    - headlight washers
    - protective side moldings
    - HI FI sound system
    - special interior

Can anybody tell me why the chassis number is for a standard
944 Turbo.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 16:13:26 -0400
From: ALAN968@aol.com
Subject: Re: corrosion?

The question was:
>Also have a q. about the durability of the galvanized bodies 
>of pcars. Saw a slightly dented and otherwise neglected 
>looking 924 recently, and noticed something which seemed
>to be corrosion on the one front corner and around the lower 
>door area/wheel wells. What do you have to do (or rather, 
>_not_ do after an accident) to be left with such an ugly 
>looking body?? I thought the 924s were galvanized...

When Porsche first began using galvanized steel on it's cars the surface
quality/texture of the zinc coated steel wasn't that great.  As a result
there was a lot of metal finishing done by hand to achieve a smooth look.
 The metal finishing frequently removed most if not all of the free zinc
coating in some areas.  These areas would have no galvanic protection if
exposed to the elements.  If the damage was in a metal finished area and the
area was not properly prepaired prior to painting then it could rust, rock
chips are a problem.  Also if the area was prone to trapped water then all
bets are off.  Trapped water will eventualy penetrate any panel.

Alan968
95 968 M030

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 16:17:36 -0400
From: Fred Pack <fhp@unipress.com>
Subject: 944 broken console 'hinge'

There have been some recent postings about this problem, and how expensive a
new console is. Well, it isn't expensive any more!

Here's a repeat of a posting I made a few months ago:



You NO LONGER must buy the entire unit for approx $150.

You can buy only the 'hinge'; PN 944 552 553 01 010. It now costs $19.
(When introduced about 6 months ago the cost was $13.)

The reason I keep calling it the 'hinge' is that this part is actually the
entire plastic bottom and hingable top frame. It lacks only the upper padded
leatherette top, which you re-use from your existing broken console.

Tools needed for installation: 1 phillips head screwdriver.
Time for installation: about 10 minutes.



Fred Pack					fhp@unipress.com
UniPress Software				phone: (908) 287-2100
2025 Lincoln Highway				fax:   (908) 287-4929
Edison NJ 08817					http://www.unipress.com/

'89 944S2
'72 914 2.0L

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 16:53:32 -0500 (EST)
From: tstaples@ichange.com (Tony Staples)
Subject: Late model 911 windshield

I am looking for a source for a new OEM 911 windshield, with the built 
in antenna, for my 1988 911 Cabrio.  My local (Upstate SC) dealer quoted
 $2300 list installed (I howled in laughter as I was leaving :>) ).  
Several local glass shops quoted around $1000 installed.  (more howling!
 :>)))) ).  I need to replace the windshield as It has become somewhat 
pitted after 76,000 mi.  It is not bad enough to qualify under my 
insurance coverage, but it drives me nuts as the rest of the car is 
flawless.

I can buy an aftermarket windshield with no antenna for $180.  The OEM 
windshield without antenna can be had locally for $350.  I find it 
ridiculous that a built in antenna triples the price!  $400-$500 would 
be more like it.  I am interested in keeping the car original, so I want
 the correct OEM part.  I am capable of doing the installation myself, I
 just need to find a reasonably priced source.   TIA for any leads on a 
good source.

As to the previous messages regarding Porsches and kids, let me say 
this: I have found precious few things in life better than strapping my 
two year old daughter in as my co-pilot for a Sunday morning jaunt 
through the mountains of western NC.  Watching the sunlight streaming 
through the trees illuminate the grin on her face like a strobe, and 
listening to her squeal in delight while accelerating hard off of a 180 
degree switchback really makes my day.  We stop for an occasional 
waterfall or scenic view.  Watching her eyes light up at one of these 
"discoveries" is a feeling without description.  The bonus is it lets 
Mom sleep in as well.  I enjoy the car even more with my daughter along 
than I do without.  My advice, keep the car and enjoy them both.

Sincerely,
Tony Staples
tstaples@ichange.com

'93 Elizabeth (future Porschephile)

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 14:26:58 -0700
From: Stefan Czereyski <czereysk@saifr00.ateng.az.honeywell.com>
Subject: larger tires for my rear wheels


Danny Tong Wrote:

Could I get larger tires for my rear wheels?  Does it affect anything in
a bad way?  Currently I hav 215 60R15's and was wondering if an upgrade
to a larger or fatter wheel does anything.
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Danny, I currently have a 1989 944. It is equipped with 205s on the front
 and 225s on the rear. 16" wheels.

Keith Southard

I ran 225ZR50/16 DUNLOP D40M2s on my 83 944. Great traction & handling.
However the extra width puts a big strain on the steering, alignment and
front tires. Neeeded new tie-rods (were new when I put on the tires) after
only 10K miles. Tires more subject to asymmetrical wear. Now run 205ZR50/16
on the front and it is much better.

Stefan Czereyski
1983 1944 Black
1985 XJ6  Blue
1965 XKE  Red

Agree whole-heartedly having been rear ended (not in my P-Car,
thank God) having come to a full stop to wait for the car in front of me
to make a stinking left turn.......All because the FOOL behind me
WASN'T PAYING ATTENTION. How many times have you seen
this little scenario played out at a stop light?

Incidently, every state that I have lived in (5) follows the general
insurance company rule. The guy with the bent grill gets the
ticket for, you guessed it, FOLLOWING TOO CLOSELY.  Mmmm,
maybe there IS a message in all this?

While we don't have the traffic problems to the extent of some of the
more densly populated areas, Anchorage does have some nasty
traffic problems during the rush hours. During those times it becomes
nearly impossible to keep a "safe" amount of distance in front of
you UNLESS you are willing to cede a little ground and not get too
hung up on "giving up" your place in traffic to someone else. I'm rarely
in such a hurry that a few extra minutes is so critical. Just relax and
enjoy the ride. Rush hour traffic is no place to practice your racing
skills anyway.  Incidently, Anchorage has the RUDEST drivers
that I have encountered ANYWHERE.

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 14:17:38 -0800 (PST)
From: BMESSINGER@ewu.edu
Subject: 550A replicas


To anyone interested in these (yes, there is more than one) 550A kit-cars
here is some info that might be of interest.

AUTO CLASSICS 550
	this kit, produced by Auto Classics International differs from the
	"BECK" 550 in that it has the "rensport"-style doors on the rear
	fenders (better cooling and engine access) and uses a space-frame
	that includes side impact beams.  
	
	weight: 1400
	suspension: vw ball joint (front)
		    trailing arms, adjustable coil-overs, Z-bar
	
	note:use of trailing arm suspension gives room for a bigger
	     engine than in the Beck car.


		Auto Classics International
		Dept. KC09
		125 W. Gemini Dr., Ste. E1
		Tempe, AZ 85283
		602-730-6802



BECK VINTAGE 550 SPYDER
	
	This car differs from the ACI kit in several ways. First, it uses
	vw torsion bar suspension at all four corners and has an original-
	style ladder-type chassis. From what I can gather, the Beck is more
	like the original 550A (same chassis, same suspension).

	weight: 1250

		Beck Developement
		1531 West 13th Street, Unit E
		Upland, CA 91786
		909-981-3840


>From what I've read, the Beck is more like the real thing technicaly, but
the ACI kit is said by some to handle better and have more engine compartment
space. If you are really interested you might see if Kit Car magazine has 
done a comparison (they were planning on it). I don't know, because I'm not
into fake Porsches. I think the 550 kits are neat, but what do you say to the
person who asks "Cool car; what is it?"? Response:"Thanks, it's a...well..a
...actually.."

 I saw one once in Kennewick Washington, chased it down in my 914 and pulled
along side to get a better look. At an intersection I leaned over and said
"Is that a real 550?" He glared at me real mean like and said "Just about."
At that moment I knew I could never own one because I too would always be on
the defensive. Food for thought.

Ben Messinger
bmessinger@ewu.edu
'72 914 1.7  sold :(
looking for the right '73

Keith Southard

I ran 225ZR50/16 DUNLOP D40M2s on my 83 944. Great traction & handling.
However the extra width puts a big strain on the steering, alignment and
front tires. Neeeded new tie-rods (were new when I put on the tires) after
only 10K miles. Tires more subject to asymmetrical wear. Now run 205ZR50/16
on the front and it is much better.

Stefan Czereyski
1983 1944 Black
1985 XJ6  Blue
1965 XKE  Red

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 95 15:45:20 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 968 Speedos


Alan968 points out that the left front ABS speed sensor is the point of 
reference for the 968 speedo. This is correct as the Getrag 6-speed does
not have a provision for the magnet on the ring gear nor a place for a 
Hall sensor. 

All 924s, 924S and 944 up to the 1985.5 model use a speedo cable driven 
from the left front spondle/hub. All 944 models 1985.5 to 1991 use a Hall
pickup on the transmission in the area of the ring and pinion.

All Getrag 6-speed and tiptronic models use the left front wheel ABS 
speed sensor to derive vehicle speed. This also applies to 911 models as well. 

Makes me wonder whether mileage on the odometer is recorded correctly if
all wheels are locked up and you're sliding. Of course this could never 
occur with ABS, right? :-)

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 95 15:00:00 ADT
From: "Southard, Keith" <KSOUTHAR@atu.com>
Subject: RE: Following to Closely


No problem, Joe. And yes, it has happened to me. Just this spring. It 
happened
to be a hand truck that came out of the back of a delivery truck. The gate
swung up and out that bugger came. It sure looked BIG when it came right
at the windshield of my Chrysler. Long and short of it was that I ended up
with a pretty good hand truck and some new paint and grillwork on my LAND
BARGE. Just couldn't get out of the way. I didn't get any sympathy from any-
one including the insurance company claim adjuster who just "tsk, tsk.....
shouldn't follow so close". I am much more aware of what is directly in
front of me as a result. But they are right. Sure, the guy SHOULD have
made sure his door was latched, but I also have a responsibility to "see
and avoid" and adjust my driving style as necessary, OR just accept that
S**T can and does happen, get out the old checkbook and continue on
when it does.

Sorry to hear you live in Detroit (just kidding) things are bad enough
here in Anchorage where drivers also practice the 1-car-length
rule at (usually) 65 during rush hour (and more often than not cut
someone off to get their car into a space that is 1/2 car in length).

Don't take any of the flame personally, it's been a great discussion
line. If you ever find yourself headed this way, just shout. We have a
pretty active (though small) region and always like to meet and talk to
other enthusiasts.

 ----------
>From: Joe Browne
To: KSOUTHAR
Subject: Following to Closely
Date: Wednesday, July 19, 1995 5:58PM

Just a note to clarify my comments on slaughtering a tire and valence.
I'm not sure from your address where you live, so I will assume you do
not live in Detroit (not many of us will admit it either).  This town has
some of the fastest and slowest drivers I have ever encountered.  You
are right that 74mph is irresponsible in some areas, but not in Detroit.
This speed is actually probably very close to the avg. for Detroit.  In
Nashville it would be excessive, also in Louisville and probably Chicago.
In Detroit, Boston, LA, I am pretty sure that it is the normal speed.  I 
used
to have to adjust each month when I went to Seattle because the normal
speed there is around 60 mph.

I just did not want you to think me a Fabio-like,speed demon.  I autocross
on weekends and attend the occasional track day to get my speed fix.  I
do not get it on the public roads since it is too unpredictable, as you
state.  Deep down, I'm trying to get you to admit that stuff falling off of
trucks and being left in the middle of the road is inherently wrong.  Also
that running over road obstacles as big as tire and kicking them up for
the guy following is also wrong.  If this happens to you, I hope it doesn't,
we will talk again and see if your opinion is any different.  Enjoyed the
discussion!
