Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 16:34:37 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Re: Re: Monterey Historics

Are there sufficient Porschephiles going to the Monterey Historic
Races and/or Pebble Beach Concours that we should plan a get-together
in the Monterey area during the August 18-20 time period?  Several
people have mentioned plans to attend.  There are always enough
Porsches around to make it worthwhile even if you won't look at
another marque, and the featured marque at the races this year is
Lotus -- as a former Elan owner, I'm looking forward to that.  I'll 
act as a coordinator if more want to join us.  So far those I know 
of include:

elliot.entin@alphatech.com 
paulm@sgi.com 
hcrms@chevron.com
stern@nprdc.navy.mil
thode@nprdc.navy.mil

So far the suggestions for a meeting place include:

1-  There is an interesting bar in a redwood tree where I went last
1-  year. A bit crowded though. Anyone know it?
 
2-  How about London Bridge, on Warf 2, under Tony Romas?

Saturday night has been suggested as a time.

Here is some descriptions of the weekend events that I grabbed off
a web page, in case you're not familiar with the weekend -- I couldn't
find any more exact schedule of races:

August 18 - Concours Italiana - Carmel

A pristine event featuring 450 of the finest Italian made cars.
Celebrations include Italian foods, vendor booths, and everything you
need to restore, shine, or re-finish your fine crafted Italian
automobile, (or Japanese, German and even American car). Located on the
driving range of one of the county's most beautiful golf courses, at
the Quail Lodge in Carmel. Head on down Carmel Valley Road and join in
the fun and admire the awesome beauty of these fine classics. For more
information and tickets call (408) 538-9516.

August 18-20 - Monterey Historic Automobile Races

Come to the sunbelt of Monterey at world famous Laguna Seca Raceway and
enjoy vintage racing machines from every era imaginable. Owners
actually race their rare and expensive automobiles against each other
in a much loved competition that attracts enthusiasts from around the
world. A show you shouldn't miss! Spectators can stroll through the
open paddock admiring these finely precision crafted automobiles.
Located at the Laguna Seca Raceway on highway 68 between Monterey and
Salinas. Call 1-800-327-SECA for more information.

August 20 - Concours D'elegance - Pebble Beach

See the ultra-rich display some of their most treasured possessions.
This one is not only a car show it is THE world renowned car show,
showing off the most beautiful and rare automobiles in the world. Many
celebrities return every year and partake in the festivities. Wear your
tux and you'll blend right in! Or just come dressed relaxed and enjoy
all of the beautiful machinery and coastal scenes along Pebble Beach.
Located on the lawn in front of the prestigious Lodge at Pebble Beach.
Show off your precious automobile in the parking lot, or just bring
your clunker and trade it in on a classic! This show is one of my
favorites in the Monterey area. For more information, call (408)
624-3811.

=======================

Here's an alternate set of events from a different web page; it's 
interesting that the phone numbers differ in some cases:

      Concours Italiana

      Aug. 18 

      World Classic Vintage Sports and Classic Car Auction 
      Monterey

      Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance 
      Pebble Beach 
      (408) 649-2724 
      Aug. 20 

      Monterey Historic Automobile Races at Laguna Seca 
      Monterey 
      (800) 327-7322 
      Aug. 18-20 

=======================

Let me know if you plan to attend, or if you know of a better meeting
place or time; I searched for a brewpub in Monterey, but the closest 
I could find was in Santa Cruz.

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 95 11:21:17 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  Do fog lights really work??

I have found that the fog lights, properly adjusted, with properly
adjusted low beams do help.  Note:  as stated by others, these are
for bad weather - fog, and rain also. 

So, when the fog is bad, it's raining, or I'm driving through the low
clouds, I use the fogs, with my H4s on low.

When it's a clear night, and I'm _miles_ from other drivers, I use
the H4s on high, and if they are mounted, my rally lights ( a pair
of 9 inch, 130 watt, off-road-racing lights with as 5 mile reflective
range.)  8-)  
With these, I see the deer better too. 8-)

Pat Norris
pat@ixi.saic.com
'86 944 ZEROLEG

recent 944 Turbo owner, I was expecting a much shorter life for major
components.

number is (310) 923-8051

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 20:13:17 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Do fog lights really work??

>I have never been able to descern any improvement in night visibility
>by turning on my foglights.  I can see that they come on, but they dont
>help.

>My question is. Does anybody notice that they really help and if so,
>what tests can I do to find out what is wrong with mine?

Fog lights work great.  In fog.  I grew up in East TN - it is *foggy* there
probably 180 mornings/year.  Fog lights (especially the amber ones) don't
reflect off of the fog near as much as headlights and if they are mounted
low enough, will kinda shine "under" the fog.  

Now, driving lights are another issue.  They may actually improve night
visibility (I wouldn't know - my H4 high beams make it look like high
noon)...

Sorry for wasting this bandwidth...

Mike
'76 Euro 911 

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 16:38:11 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: Re: 1987 944 tire sizes.

>>Could I get larger tires for my rear wheels?  Does it affect anything in
>>a bad way?  Currently I hav 215 60R15's and was wondering if an upgrade
>>to a larger or fatter wheel does anything.
>>
>>Danny Tong
>>1987 944 White.

Doug Dykaar responded with:
>
>225/50-15s will fit your 7" rims without changing diameter (much). Thats
>the setup on my "5". 

If you want to maintain a side wall height of 215 x 0.60 = 129 mm (i.e. to
keep speedo
reading correct), 235/55-15 (235 x 0.55 = 129.25 mm) should be used. Using
225/50
will cause a significant height difference if you are retaining 215/60 fronts.

I've got 215/60-15 on the front and 235/55-15 on the rear on standard
phone-dial mags
for my '86 944. Not sure what difference it makes with the standard width
tires since I
bought the car this way.

Ken '86 944

driving without the ability to stop before (OR avoid) things like this
is akin to driving without due care and attention.

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 22:51:18 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: The saga continues...


glory and glee fades into funk and frustration as my newly born baby
refused to idle today.  After starting, she'd come up to about 2,000RPM
and then stall - toying with the throttle helped but one shouldn't have
to that with a fuel injected engine. [ BABY = '76 914 ]

So, I checked wiring - verified static timing.  My fuel pressure gauge should
be arriving tomorrow so I can check the pressure.  I also think it may
be the cold start valve not getting a signal or bad ground(the valve is new).

Pulling one of the plugs revealed alot of loose carbon - so when the engine
was running it was running a bit too rich, right?  Well, due dilligence
and some elbow grease should get her fired up again.

Question - can the small screw at the end of the manifold pressure sensor
used to calibrate it?  My engine is of non-stock displacement and I will
need to set the fuel/air ratio after she will idle long enough for me
to set the timing/dwell.

Any ideas/help would be appreciated, TIA,

Jerry

down the road, suddenly a 4X8 sheet of wood either fell off of the truck

windshield level to our 911SC!  I immediately braked, then hammered the 
throttle as I projected the 'angle of incidence' for what now had become 
an inevitable impact. Apparently, the air pressure over the hood caused a 
'bubble' that lofted the panel up and to the right. I hit the wood with 
the right headlight bezel, shattering the wood and destroying the radio 
mast (small price compared to edge-on int the windshield. We exitted and

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 20:42:24 -0700 (PDT)
From: Walter Stander <wstander@cts.com>
Subject: Re: Do fog lights really work??


Yes, I do notice improvemnt IF the main beams are on dim AND the fog 
lamps are adjusted to illuminate the right edge of the road. Using high 
beams in fog causes the light to reflect back at you, further impairing 
your vision. As for testing, find a relatively flat place to stop and see 
if the fog lamps are aimed (probably best done in your garage at night). 
With only the fogs on, you should see two thin flat beams pointing to the 
right side. Adjust as necessary until the spot is 25-30 feet out. There 
are more precise ways done with computers, etc., but this is worth the 
shot and 25 minutes or so.

Walt
On Wed, 19 Jul 1995, steve cohen wrote:

> I have never been able to descern any improvement in night visibility
> by turning on my foglights.  I can see that they come on, but they dont
> help.
> 
> My question is. Does anybody notice that they really help and if so,
> what tests can I do to find out what is wrong with mine?
> 
> -STeve

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 00:05:30 EDT
From: AWJK94A@prodigy.com ( DREW SPENCER)
Subject: Re: 90 911 C4 Bleeding brakes ?


Scott,

Bleeding the calipers on a 964 is not alltogether different than
any other type of disk brake system.  The only thing you need to
be aware of is that there are *2* bleeder valves.  From what I've
read, Porsche began using what is essentially ATE Super Blue (without
the blue dye in it) in '92.  How do I know this?  Well, prior to
going to my first track event I decided to do the same as you.  I
went to the P-car dealership and paid $25 for a can of factory fluid.
When I went to the track, an acquaintence had a can of ATE Super Blue
which I then compaired to my can.  Sure enough, it's the exact same
stuff.  You should be able to get the ATE Super Blue for $10-$12/can.
The blue fluid also helps to identify when you've bled out the system.

Good luck,
Drew
Drew Spencer (awjk94a@prodigy.com)
'93 RS America
'82 911 SC


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 22:30:25 -0800 (PDT)
From: dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com (William Dunham)
Subject: Re: IMSA GTS2 Sears Pt- We won!



Contratulations on the win.  There was some great racing in the GTS2 class
(way better that the WSC/GTS1 race IHMO).  I was sitting in the grandstands
along the "S's" and we could see the cars come down the front straight into
turn 1 up the hill, through the carousel, and down through the S's in 7, 8, and 9.
Great racing between the Mazda and your beautiful 911 until the Mazda let go.
The smoke from the 911 seemed to get worse with each lap, leaving us all wondering
whether the car was going to make it to the finish or not.

There was also a great battle between a red 911 and yellow 944 for 4th/5th.
It seemed like every other lap they would swap positions.  This was my first
IMSA race and I was really surprised how many 911's were entered, almost the
entire GTS2 field.  The sounds and smells alone were worth the price of 
admission.  There's nothing like the smell of racing gas and burning brakes
in the morning.

Thanks for the great story.

Bill

> 
>      How I spent my last weekend:
>      
>      I'm currently having my 911 engine rebuilt by Rob King of S-Car-Go 
>      Racing in San Rafael, California,  Rob was the mechanic for a GTS2 
>      entry at Sears Point this weekend, and allowed me to join the crew as 
>      errand boy/car polisher/CV joint ball cleaner.  Despite the job 
>      description, I had a fantastic time.  GTS2 is made up of a pack of 
>      911s, several Mazdas, and several Nissans.  The BMWs that normally 
>      race were not in attendance.
>      
>      The car I crewed for is owned and driven by Kevin Buckler, who is in 
>      the Porsche parts business (Racer's Group and Performance Wholesale). 
>      The car is sponsored by Togo's sandwich shops, whose owner is a big 
>      Porsche fanatic (a Ruf and an early modified 911).  This was Kevin's 
>      first IMSA race, and he was driving a car that wasn't even driveable 
>      until July 7!
>      
>      The car is brand new, having been built to GTS2 specs from a 1970 911 
>      chassis.  It's amazing to see the transformation the car went through, 
>      ending up looking like a brand new RSR.  The engine was a 3.6 built by 
>      Jerry Woods (who stopped by with Bruce Anderson on Sunday) and 
>      produces approximately 350 hp.  Engine management and fuel injection 
>      was by Motec, and is all computer programmed.  In fact, a high idle 
>      problem the morning of the race was solved in about one minute by the 
>      Motec technician, simply by reprogramming the accelerator pedal 
>      calibration.
>      
>      The car has all the usual goodies, including carbon fiber body panels, 
>      RSR rear wing, adjustable heim-joint spring plates, coil-over 
>      suspension, adjustable trailing arm mounting, transmission cooling, 
>      and full tubing to reinforce the chassis.  One thing that caused 
>      problems was wear on the CV joint: the extreme angle of the shafts as 
>      a result of lowering the car so much really stressed the CV.  An 
>      upside-down transmission mount will probably solve this.
>      
>      The car weighed in at slightly over 2100 pounds, and consistently 
>      turned 1:42s.  Kevin qualified the car second, behind a purpose-built 
>      tube-frame Mazda RX-7.  Kevin was ahead of all 911s, including a 
>      factory-backed entry and several tube-frame cars.  It so amazed the 
>      other teams that Alwin Springer, director of racing for PCNA, stopped 
>      by to see the car's setup after qualifying on Saturday!  Everyone 
>      wanted to know how this new driver in a brand new car could be going 
>      so fast.
>      
>      The race was incredibly exciting, the longest 45 minutes of my life.  
>      All cars pulled away cleanly after a false start, with about 10 911s 
>      among the 15 entries.  Included in the field was the essentially 
>      bone-stock 993 that was raced at Daytona.  (This car was turning 
>      1:57s, in comparison to the race-prepared cars that were in the low 
>      1:40s.)
>      
>      Kevin stayed in second place most of the first half, with 2 laps 
>      running in front.  The Mazda began pushing him hard while he led, 
>      though, and Kevin wisely let him by.  At about lap 15 (of 26 for the 
>      45 minutes), Kevin's car started smoking heavily.  What was it? Oil? 
>      Tranny? Tires rubbing because suspension sagged?  We couldn't tell 
>      because the pits were upwind of the track.  Since Kevin's lap times 
>      were still ok, all we could do was hope he didn't get black-flagged 
>      and could finish the race. Shortly after this, the leading RX-7 slowed 
>      suddenly with mechanical problems and pitted.  That left us in the 
>      lead, with a strong battle between positions 2 and 3 allowing Kevin to 
>      gain some breathing room.  Incredibly, the car held on and won by 9 
>      seconds, finishing in front of an RX-7 and a 911. The crew was 
>      ecstatic!  Kevin drove a great race and the car came through!
>      
>      We were then told to get the car to the winner's circle.  So our first 
>      problem was: where the hell is the winner's circle?  As the car pulled 
>      away to go find the winner's circle, it revealed a large spreading 
>      puddle of transmission fluid, the cause of all the smoke.  Turned out 
>      that a line to the transmission fluid cooling pump was leaking, but 
>      the tranny held on to the end.
>      
>      My congratulations go out to Kevin, car fabricator Roger Hamlin, and 
>      mechanics Roger Hawley and Rob King.  The teamwork required to build 
>      and run a successful racecar are truly awe inspiring.  I can't wait to 
>      get my own car on the track, even if it's only a PCA driver's event.  
>      I can always pretend!
>      
>      Thanks for bearing with me.  It was so exciting I had to write about 
>      it.
>      
>      Jeff Jensen
>      jcjensen@raychem.com
>      73 RS almost restored
>      
>      
>      
>      
>      
> 


- -- 
William J. Dunham
Silicon Graphics
dunham@esd.sgi.com
(415)390-2129

Subject: Why do they *do* that?

Tracy

How does your car know to behave when you threaten it with a
new part?  Well, its kinda like when you were a kid sitting in
the doctor's office.  When that sucker came at me waving a
three foot long (as I remember it) needle, I suddenly became
aware that I didn't feel sick *at all* anymore.

This is how a Porsche feels when it eyeballs an irate owner
coming at it with a box from Stoddards in one hand and a pair
of rusty waterpump pliers in the other ;-)

Some things you just *know*.


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

>>> <AnalogMike@aol.com> 06/27/95 03:40pm >>>
I have had this special "Porsche only" limited use insurance for a few
years because it is very inexpensive and I don't drive my car on the
street often.

But this year they have changed the "carrier" from The Great  American
Insurance Group to American Modern
Home Insurance Group in Ohio. I am on the extremely limited CLASSIC
plan (<2500 miles per year, must be garaged,  can't be left parked in
public parking for shopping trips, can't be driven to work, etc etc).

The cost was $177 per year for an agreed value of $17,500.
Now it will be $291 per year, with the only benefit an increase in mileage
to 3,000 miles (big deal - I put about 250 miles on  my car in each of the
last 3 years).

Did anyone else see this huge increase? I am thinking of adding the 911
to my normal GEICO policy, but don't want them to get worried about me
driving a "performance car" so I'll probably just pay the extra and keep
this insurance.

Anyone else find a good classic insurance that will insure a '72 911S
(not yet 25 years old). I tried some that advertise in Hemmings a few
years back but none would take me.

Regards, Mike Piera  '72S and '73E targas, '73 914/2.0
- ---------------------
Mike-

Here's a couple options for you:
1) Contact Great American directly - they may offer to continue your
policy directly at the same rate.
2) There is a 1000 mile option from American Modern which will be
somewhat less expensive.
3) Check with some of the other agents selling the American Modern
policies (listed in a recent ad in AutoWeek, I believe).  They should, but
may NOT necessarily all quote the same rate.
4) Sell the car ...no, no, NO, this is not an option!
For what it's worth, I had a rather rude experience with the President of
Leland-West, but I'll let you decide whether or not you want to continue
doing business with them.

Brad Anesi

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 13:54:41 -0600
From: Jan Bjernfalk <bjernfal@tombo.corp.es.com>
Subject: Re: 1983 930 - A Question 

Porsche stopped exporting 930s to the US after the '79 model year, and
resumed with the '86 models.  If you are seriously interested in this
car, have it checked out thoroughly.  Horror stories abound about grey mkt
930s with poor quality emissions conversion hardware.

Jan Bjernfalk
Happy owner of a new (to me) '86 930

Date: Wed, 19 Jul 1995 14:21:34 -0600
From: Jan Bjernfalk <bjernfal@tombo.corp.es.com>
Subject: Re: 1988 944 Turbo S VIN number discrepancy 

Don't worry, all is well.  The digit after the "N" in your case is
actually the 3rd digit of the model number (i.e. 951) -- you want
it to be a "1", S-car or not.  It's the NEXT digit that should be a "5",
and indeed in your case it is.  Maybe there's a bug in the FAQ.

Jan Bjernfalk
Former 951S pilot

a *master* of the English language, (by your own addmission)
could fail to address the subject that binds the members of
this list in our quest for communication and understanding.

Course I could be missin sumpin here.  I slept thru most of
second grade (or was it the other one?). 

Concerning your comments about engineers and the English
language:  Some of the most outstanding engineers I've worked
with couldn't structure a sentence to save their slide rule.
Notice I qualified this statement with "some", not "all".  There
*are* exceptions.  Engineering is a tough disipline.  Engineering
courses are structured to weed out all the non-hackers that don't
pack the gear to be engineers and divert them to more meaningful
majors such as psych or English.  Have you taken a close look
at your Porsche factory manuals lately?   Mine aren't exactly
an eloquent treatise on the English language.

Dern feriners.  They aughtta learn the language if they want to 
sell us Americans thare cars.  Does has lotsa pictures, though,
just like the menu at Denny's.

and the rest of the slow learners?  No big words and *lotsa*
pictures?  Maybe a comic book style format?  In the meantime,
you might be able to get Bob to give it a rest.  If I wanted to
be graded constantly on my spelling and grammar I would
have signed up to alt.crotchety.ex.schoolmarms.  (Whoa boy 
ahowdy, Bob, lookee at that.  I managed to avoid a split infinitive
in that last sentence!  Luck, probably.)  Last time I checked my
screen it looked like I was on porschephiles@tta.com.

Am I coming across lumpy chicken?  If you fellers ain't readin
me "in the slot, five by five"  or I fail to "communicate accurately,
without ambiguity"  (Poetic license to add the comma, Bob.  I think it
reads better that way.) just drop me a post.  I'll try to type slower.


Mark W Kuefel

>From:   IN%"Bob356@aol.com" 19-JUL-1995 23:37:52.02

>I say damn the rules, lets just communicate!

Perhaps the example was trivial, but the point is exactly that: to
communicate, and to communicate accurately without ambiguity.  Would you fly
on an airplane that was built to specifications written by engineers who
communicate in such a fashion?  I wouldn't, and I AM an engineer.  The
English language (as are most languages) is a powerful tool...it's a shame to
see so many people ding its edges with carelessness.

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 95 06:08:07 -0500
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William Marten)
Subject: Re: The saga continues...

jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady) wrote:

>Question - can the small screw at the end of the manifold pressure sensor
>used to calibrate it?  My engine is of non-stock displacement and I will
>need to set the fuel/air ratio after she will idle long enough for me
>to set the timing/dwell.

The answer from 'How to Tune & Modify Bosch Fuel Injection' by Ben Watson
is, of course, 'yes'.  The problem is, if you lean the mixture at idle, it
may be too lean at full throttle.

For a 'starts cold and stalls' symptom, the book also advises checking the
trigger points {car starts using fuel from the cold-start valve, then dies
when none of the others kick in}, the aux. air valve, and the cylinder head
temp sensor.

Hope it helps,

Bill Marten
wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu
Madison, WI, USA

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 08:25:38 -0500
From: wise@db.erau.edu (John Wise)
Subject: Re: Public Flame!!! :) :)

The point I was trying to make is that communication standards change as a
function of the medium.  

I would probably not want to fly an a/c that was built based on e-mail
messages on the I-net.  But then I would not spend hours composing my
dinner conversion with my family to make sure that every word was just
right.  I do, however, spend weeks working on technical communications were
accuracy is critical.  

My wife says I always want to express everything exactly right (too much
time in science, engineering, & research), that I need to lighten-up and
let myself make a few mistakes in casual conversation.  And as much as I
hate to admit it, she is right.  

John "I need to follow my own advice" Wise


John A. Wise                                    Tel: (+1) (904) 226-6384
Center for Aviation/Aerospace Research          Fax: (+1) (904) 226-7050
Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University            E-mail: wise@db.erau.edu
600 South Clyde Morris Blvd.
Daytona Beach, FL 32114-3900   USA

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 07:12:55 -0500
From: sils@melbourne.geoquest.slb.com (Raimond Sils)
Subject: Things going "bump" in the night

'philers,

All this chatter about hitting road debris reminded me about the time a
poor little fox went head-to-head with the front air dam ("spoiler" -
whatever), and my left tyre. (Curbside for those in Oz).

Driving through the countryside, I saw his little red eyes a way in the
distance, and slowed up, as it could have just as easily been a roo. He
looked my driving lights straight on, and trotted off the road, sat on the
verge, and waited. When I was about 20 metres away charged back onto the
road. I had veered into the middle of the road by then, (no oncoming
lights), and he just managed to wallop my spoiler, bending it all the way
up. Ouch. (Who do I sue?)

I stopped, and looked for the (now, messy) little critter to check if he
was suffering, but he was nowhere to be seen. I guessed he had been
deflected back into the scrub with a 90kph hangover. All I could see was a
little red fluff on the re-arranged spoiler.

I was fortunate, it could have been a 'roo. They usually win fights with
car bonnets. (And Aussie wildlife purists will tell you that foxes are
feral anyway)

Oh and on driving lights / fog lights. Once, in pea - soup fog (hoping not
to have to drive by Braille), I turned on the high beams and nearly blinded
myself. (My own little Spielberg - effect, minus the wind!). They are
aligned correctly, but the driving lights project out and down the road. -
I drove rather sedately back down the hill, following the cat's eyes and
side posts with low beam.

I apologise for my indulgence, hope you excuse the bandwidth.

Raimond
'81 931

Date: 20 Jul 95 08:47:48 GMT+05.00
From: Miliano/PAPY_MIS01//US/TELEMAIL/BASF////@basfx400.parsippa.basf-corp.com
Subject: Do Fog Lights Really Work


There are only a few things that really tick me off.  People who camp out in 
the left lane like it's their birth right.  People who haven't figured out 
how to use turn signals.  And idiots who drive around at night with their 
fog lights on when it ain't foggy!    They're called FOG lights for a 
reason.  Like FOG horns you use them in the FOG.  Innocent people driving 
toward you are blinded by their eight jillion candle power and if adjusted 
properly (i.e., aimed at the ground in front of your bumper) they don't 
improve the driver's view of the road at all.

If you want lights that work while you're driving around, go buy DRIVING 
lights.  They work great.  Rally drivers and people who run 24 hour races 
have units that can blister paint at 200 yards.  I had a pair on my rally VW 
for a while and when I crossed the George Washington Bridge heading west 
with these babies on, people in Chicago started pulling down their window 
shades.  Honest.

I just had the common sense and courtesy to turn them off before blinding 
people. Unless they were in the left lane going too slow.

Dom Miliano
Excellence Magazine

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 22:43:51 +1000
From: netspawn@midcoast.com.au (Jon Samyia)
Subject: brakes

To whoever can help me,
                        my name is Jon, and I am doing a *very* important
assignment on brakes and braking systems. *Please* I urge anyone with info.
on brakes to send it to me at: netspawn@midcoast.com.au

A quick summary of what I have to do follows:
 -trace the development of brakes and braking systems from their earliest
beginnings to the present day brakes used in cars. Photos and/or sketches
can be used to illustrate an answer.

 - Explain the operation of a modern braking system and carry out a detailed
analysis of the component parts explaining the materials used in their
construction, the properties of these materials which determined their
selection, the manufacturing methods used and an explanation of the
microstructure of these materials. Again photos and/or sketches can be  used
to illustrate a point.

As one can see this is an assignment that would be approached from an
engineering perspective.

A thousand thank-you's to *anyone* who can send me *any* info relating to
the above.

faithfully, Jon.

Here's a good use for fog lights: In NY state, when your wipers are on,
so must your headlights be. If the rain is slight and the visibility good,
I typically use the fogs, figuring that I can convince a cop that these
are sufficient. It's worked so far ...

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 95 08:46:21 PDT
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: Loctite 271? fuel system threadlocker


I'm going to be disassembling my fuel system on my '84
928S (L-Jetronic).  Just about every threaded connection
has red threadlocker on it.  When I put it back together
I want to use the same stuff, so, what is it?  Is this 
Loctite 271 (high strength)?

At the auto parts store the red Loctite is "high strength"
and says it requires special tools or heat to break.
Well, I don't have special tools, and I don't want to use
heat to loosen connections on my fuel system.  But, the
medium strength is blue, and there is certainly red all
over the connection in my fuel system..

Incidently, my fuel filter connections were the same way,
but when I asked Stoddard about it, the mechanic there
said to *not* use threadlocker, but to tighten it to the
point where it wouldn't leak.  Was he wrong?

So, what's on my fuel system now?  What should I use?
Where can I get it?  Should I go back and use threadlocker
on the fuel filter connections?

Stay tuned for more questions!  :)

Matt Carpenter
'84 928S
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 09:25:13 -0400
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Gold Chain Affiliation or True Love?

In hopes of perhaps diverting some of the dialogue on "following to closely"
and since Bart has not chosen to update us recently with a new "Snake or
Corvette" story, I offer the following:

Many years ago, my wife and I were on a PCA Treffen to Stuttgart.  As we
cruised enroute high over the Atlantic with friends and new acquaintances,
the air was full of "Porsche talk" enhanced with plenty of beer and wine.
 The free-flowing spirits and the comradery of Porsche ownership apparently
affected a "non-Porsche owning" young couple (late 20s or early 30s)
traveling with friends from Houston.  This fellow promptly decided "they had
to have one" and a message was forwarded from the plane back to the bank and
local dealer to arrange a bank draft and pickup during our visit to Porsche
AG in Zuffenhausen.  (don't remember if it was a 911 or a 928).  Many
(including myself) were envious at the ability to "casually" buy a new
Porsche on a whim. 

After 10 days or so, we (as most) had struggled getting our dirty laundry
stuffed into our bags with all the inevitable additional souvenirs of such a
trip.  By then, my enviousness of the buying capability had about evaporated
(probably the excessive transfer of latent heat from mouth to liter mugs at
the Cannstatter Volksfest).

This couple (nice folks incidentally) appeared at the bus for the return trip
from the Graf Zeppelin hotel to the airport looking fresh, crisp, and
carrying only a small hand bag.  When someone asked "where's the rest of your
luggage", they matter-of- factly replied: "Oh, we don't carry old clothes
back, we leave them for the maid and porter.  You can always get new clothes
back home or wherever you're going." ...!!!!

My questions are:

1.  Is there still money ($$$) and intelligent life in Houston?

2.  Did the experience for these folks create a lifelong love of Porsches or
was it merely a "castoff" for the next desirable "object d' jour".?

Perry

> AUTO CLASSICS 550
> 	this kit, produced by Auto Classics International differs from the
> 	"BECK" 550 in that it has the "rensport"-style doors on the rear
> 	fenders (better cooling and engine access) and uses a space-frame
> 	that includes side impact beams.  
> 	
> 	weight: 1400
> 	suspension: vw ball joint (front)
> 		    trailing arms, adjustable coil-overs, Z-bar
> 	
> 	note:use of trailing arm suspension gives room for a bigger
> 	     engine than in the Beck car.
> 
> 
> 		Auto Classics International
> 		Dept. KC09
> 		125 W. Gemini Dr., Ste. E1
> 		Tempe, AZ 85283
> 		602-730-6802
> 
> 
> 
> BECK VINTAGE 550 SPYDER
> 	
> 	This car differs from the ACI kit in several ways. First, it uses
> 	vw torsion bar suspension at all four corners and has an original-
> 	style ladder-type chassis. From what I can gather, the Beck is more
> 	like the original 550A (same chassis, same suspension).
> 
> 	weight: 1250
>

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 10:41:02 -0400 (EDT)
From: gp310ad@prism.gatech.edu (ROBERT DUCKWORTH)
Subject: Salvage Title (fwd)

> 
> What does a salvage title do?
> 
> I have a targa shell with a salvage title.
> 
> Can it be assembled/tagged and driven?
> 
> Delaware.

Around here it's your title/proof of ownership.
If you rebuild the vehicle the DMV inspects it and
if it passes they issue a title stating that it's a rebuilt car.

There is also a theft recovery title. Same deal. You have to have the
car inspected. You can end up with either a clean title or a rebuilt
title. It depends on what you had to do to put the car back in shape.

This is based on phone calls to DMV. I'll be trying it soon :-)

 -bob



>

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 11:22:17 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Salvage Title

>What does a salvage title do?
>
>I have a targa shell with a salvage title.
>
>Can it be assembled/tagged and driven?
>
>Delaware.
>

Sure, I am currently driving a 1986 Audi 5000 Wagon that has 
a salvage title here in NY State.

The car was declared a total loss before I bought it and the parts
to fix it from a salvage yard.

After I put it together, I had my work inspected by the NY State DMV
(to make sure that I could account for all of the replacement parts)
who authorized the salvage title so that I could register it in NY State.

The process took me about 6 weeks.

Of course, in Delaware, the procedures may be different.

Check with your state's DMV or DOT.
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 08:24:02 -0700
From: Stefan Czereyski <czereysk@saifr00.ateng.az.honeywell.com>
Subject: Fog lights

Fog lights were never intended to improve night vision. Many people
misuse them. They have to activate every evailable knob or button on
their dash. 

The idea is to keep reflected light back to you at a minimum as this
reduces contrast hence your ability to dsicern objects (i.e. visibilty
is reduced). In reality you don't reduce the reflected light at all
with low mounted fogs any more than highs. The key difference is where
it goes. On high the beams are close to your line of sight & come back
at you. The lower they are, i.e. at ground level, the reflected light
can take a different path, and your contrast is undiminished - presto
increased visibility. It's the same principle as sitting on the left
side of the room watching TV. Turn on a lamp on the right side & you
can see it in the screen and contrast is reduced. Move yourself or the
lamp and it appears to vanish and you get your contrast back. The amount
of light however does not change - only the percentage reflected into your
eyes.

If there's no fog (or snowflakes) you really won't see much difference since
the illumination is close & fat by design (those engineers again) not long
& narrow. And don't forget they pull 10 - 20 amps. So if you've got everything
else on you could exceed your alternator capacity (typically 60-80 amps).
When this happens all they extra needed juice comes from your battery
running it down. If your car is not equiped with an ammeter you'll never
know. Also at low rpms as in stop & go driving the alternator output is
only about 20-30 amps. That's why you frequently get a "dead" battery every
couple of weeks in winter driving - you probably d3epleted 10%-20% every
day till it wouldn't start.

So turn off those fogs unless you really need em - or buy long range driving
lamps if you drive fast down dark country roads.

Stefan Czereyski
83 944 Black
85 XJ6 Blue
65 XKE Red

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 08:28:17 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: 914:  Brighter headlights?

Hi Thwen. Re:

>What are the options for replacing my headlights with brighter ones ('73 914)?
> 
>Currently when I'm on a road with no streetlights I don't have enough light to 
>see very well.  So I end up being one of those people I hate who run their 
>fog/driving lights when it's a clear night.  (and yes, fog/driving light 
>thread, they _definitely_ make a difference in my case--especially when
>driving 
>on a curvy road through a wooded area with no streetlights)

I have Cibie Z-beams on my 914, using stock halogen bulbs. They throw
_plenty_ of light. Automod in Atlanta is where I usually get them (they're
kind of hard to find).  Or, you could use Hella 7" units.  The Hellas are
"flat", the Cibies are convex and match the plastic fairing that surrounds
the headlights.  I also have an original pair of European Bosch headlights,
and they're flat, so perhaps the flat 7" headlights are more "original".

When I bought the car, it had some generic US-made headlamps, and they were
terrible.

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |
|        standard disclaimers apply         |

Date: 20 Jul 1995 11:28:26 -0400
From: william.anders@smc.com
Subject: 79 911SC CD ignition box

  > Does anyone know a way for a backyard mechanic to determine if the CD
  ignition
  > box is working OK.  I am experiencing a miss around 4000 RPM and
  sometimes
  > higher RPMs, but it isn't consistant.  I don't think its the FI system
  or plug
  > I guess the coil could be going as another point of failure.  The car
  only has
  > 41K miles.
  >
  > Also what is the best replacement if the CD unit is dead.  Any experince
  with
  > MSD, Jacobs, Permatune (with or without integrated coil), or anything else
  > anyone can recommend.  Solid state electronics should have improved since
  1979
  > so I am open to the groups experience here.

  In my experience the Bosch CD box would not cause this type of problem
  (miss around 4000 RPM), but more likely would fail completely (i.e., the
  car would not run).  For us backyard mechanic types, the only test I know
  of is the "sound" test.  With the ignition on & the motor not running,
  the CD box should emit a high pitched hum, but not very loud.  In your
  case I would go back & check the distributor cap very carefully & ohm out
  the plug wires.

  As for replacement, Bosch units are usually very expensive.  The
  Permatune units are a very good deal & work really well, this is my
  recomendation for a stock replacement.  The MSD, Jacobs etc. are used
  mainly by racers or for modified engines.  In a stock engined, street 911
  you will gain very little, if anything, over a properly working stock
  ignition.  Besides, they are expensive & usually require seperate add-on
  modules for connecting your tach & may require that you replace your
  stock coil.  Good Luck

  Otto Krossit

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 11:46:55 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Loctite 271? fuel system threadlocker

At 08:46 AM 7/20/95 PDT, mwc@lubrizol.com wrote:
>
>I'm going to be disassembling my fuel system on my '84
>928S (L-Jetronic).  Just about every threaded connection
>has red threadlocker on it.  When I put it back together
>I want to use the same stuff, so, what is it?  Is this 
>Loctite 271 (high strength)?

Matt,

I don't *think* it's original, and I don't think you need it.  I don't
like to use any kind of sealant on fuel connections because of the
chance that a little goober of the stuff will get into the fuel and
do a nice job of sealing up an injector or fuel distributor.

You should put everything back together very, very clean and with
new seal rings.

You don't need "special tools" or heat to break red Loctite.  Just
grunt.

If you're seeing this "red Loctite" on the *outside* of your fittings,
that ain't what it is.  It's paint marking the fitting as tightened
and checked.

Kevin

Subject: selling the 944

I will be moving to Australia in a couple of months, and, alas, taking the

idea what a fair price would be--I am concerned that it be a fair price
for anyone, but especially if the buyer is my brother or my friend. Can
anyone offer advice? The stats:
 '89 944
 Guards Red Leather interior
 47,200 miles
 Blaupunct CD player
 Diligently maintained; oil change every 3,000 miles; timing belt changed 
at 30,000; perfect mechanical bill of health at 45,000 mile service. 
Exterior in excellent condition, but for a handful of small stone nicks;  
hood repainted courtesy of the local dealer whose mechanic closed it on 
one of his tools.
I am the second owner; bought it 18 months ago when it had 28,000 miles.  
Previous owner also maintained it meticulously, and kept full maintenance 
records. 
Thanks in advance for any pricing advice.
Luther

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 12:24:21 -0400 (EDT)
From: blained <blained@nando.net>
Subject: Re: 79 911SC CD ignition box



On 20 Jul 1995 william.anders@smc.com wrote:

>   In my experience the Bosch CD box would not cause this type of problem
>   (miss around 4000 RPM), but more likely would fail completely (i.e., the
>   car would not run).  For us backyard mechanic types, the only test I know

Not so.  My CD unit exhibited this behavior once it got warm, and once my 
mechanic replaced it, all the while stating "they usually fail 
completely", the problem went away.  Oh, just thought of a good test for 
this type of problem, which is how I diagnosed it.  If it's due to 
overheating, turning the car off and placing a bag of ice around the unit 
for a bit will generally make the symptoms disappear for a while.  You 
could then perhaps opt to simply keep your ice chest in the engine 
compartment when going on picnics.

Blaine "oops mor mispelleeng" DeLancey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 09:11:26 -0700 (MST)
From: "Tim's Porsche Account" <timjones@giza.estinc.com>
Subject: Re: 914 Questions

On Thu, 20 Jul 1995 KeithS40@aol.com wrote:

> Also, I want to put some new tires on my car. It has the original Fuchs
> wheels. What about MXV4's or Yoko's. This car is for street use only.

Keith, I prefer the Yoko's on mine.  My '74 has Yoko's while my '75 has 
Michelin's and the Yoko's win hands down.  I realize that the '75 is 
about 400 lbs heavier, but that doesn't explain the drift I get in the 
backend on a low-speed, tight turn (i.e.: left from a stop light).  The 
Yoko's stick really well in street applications (avoiding potholes, Gen-X 
slow walkers, et al).

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 10:02:31 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: PCA Club Racing and steel lug nuts

>Hey,
>I have a question for Larry Herman or some of you other PCA Club Racers. I am
>considering trying a Club Race next year and have just read my rule book.
>There is a safety rule that says all lug nuts MUST be made of steel. Is this
>true and does Porsche even make steel lug nuts? After the recent thread on
>lug nuts (aftermarket quality not as good as OEM) I would be hesitant to use
>aftermarket lug nuts.
>TIA
>Rob Channell
>channellr@aol.com
>1979 SC euro s/r coupe with a mod or two :)

I am not a club racer (yet) but I have an opinion:

I even use steel lug nuts with my Fuchs for autocrossing. I have not seen, but
have heard enough stories for RELIABLE people about alloy lug nuts failing.

I torque my alloy lug nuts to 94 lb-ft and my steel lug nuts to 100 lb-ft.
I re-torque them after they have been run to make sure they are still correct.

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 95 13:46 EST
From: Peter Rhim <0006877381@mcimail.com>
Subject: 95 911 Turbo sighting...

Today during lunch, I passed Jim Ellis Porsche in Atlanta...

As I was driving by, I spotted a shocking yellow 911 so, what else, I made a
quick U'y and headed back to the dealer.  I knew it had to be a Turbo.  The car
was beautiful.  Everything on this car was huge: wheels barely fit in the wheel
wells, tires (rears were 285/30) had the wildest tread design I have ever seen,
enormous brakes (front rotors were probably 1 1/2" thick with those huge red
calipers).  The new owner <VVVBG> had just come back from his first test drive
of his new car.  62 miles on the odometer.  Subtle blue leather interior with a
6sp wood shift handle, comfortable looking sport seats and a 200mph speedo.  I
bet the dealer had a fun time "prepping" his car for him.  Commenting on the car,
, the new owner said "this car is quick, almost scary...I was afraid to get on
it hard..."  He went on to say he had waited about a year to take delivery.  The
salesman asked me if I wanted one...I deadpanned him and said "I'll take two." 
He came right back at me and said "Yeah, for about $120K a piece & did I mention
the 2 yr wait?"  As I left the dealer, I had to slap myself to get the big grin
off my face...and all I did was look!  BTW, the new owner looked to be in his
mid 30s!!!  Lucky b_stard!!!

Cheers,
Peter
6877381@mcimail.com
No Porsches *yet* & approaching my mid 30s fast!!!

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 12:01:14 -0700 (MST)
From: kmweber@aztec.asu.edu (KURT M. WEBER)
Subject: Re:  944S Fan Switch



>Dear Philers:

>   I recently purchased a '87 944S and have had no problems.  However,
> my fan no longer works in any of the positions except the very last,
>high position.  I need some help figuring out this problem before I
>have to buy a new coolant system.  If anyone has some suggestions, I
>would greatly appreciate it.  Thanks in advance.

>   My work number is 414-730-8533 and my home number is 414-733-0126.


>   Thanks again.

>   -mike weeldreyer

Mike,

My '87 Jetta GLI has had this exact same problem twice now.  The
four speed fan would only work in the high position.  After some
removal of dash trim and consulting with my Bentley manual I
managed to locate the "box" consisting of the multiple tapped
resistor and a thermal cutout.  This box was located near the fan
motor and was easily removed from the adjacent ductwork.
The "box" is not really enclosed, but rather an approx. 2" X 3"
metal plate sunken into the ductwork near the fan.  The proximity
of the thermal cutout to the tapped resistor and to the motor and
ductwork indicate that the thermal cutout is intended to protect
the vehicle and occupants from overloads, fan motor stalls, etc.
The "box" is of Bosch manufacture and there is a good chance that
your 944 has something similiar.  The thermal cutout was at fault
on my car both times.  In case you are not familiar with thermal
cutouts they are like a fuse (shaped like a bullet shaped diode)
but activated (blown) by temperature rather than current.  The
temperature rating is usually marked on the side of it.  an ohm
meter can confirm whether it or the tapped resistor is at fault.
I would be seriously surprised if it was the resistor since it is
a rather robust wirewound ceramic part.  When the fan is switched
to high, the resistor and cutout is bypassed.

I clipped out the old cutout with diagonal cutters.  I could not
unsolder it since it was originally welded in rather than
soldered.  Radio Shack, believe it or not, had the exact same
part in stock (less than two dollars).  I installed the new one
by soldering it.  I had to flux the area kind of heavily in order
to  solder to what was once welded but it worked fine.  I am sure
an automotive electrician could handle this if you are not
comfortable with doing it yourself.

The second time it failed (about a year later) I replaced it
again, this time with the next higher temperature rated cutout.
That was two years ago and it hasn't failed since.

good luck,

Kurt Weber

- --
kurt weber
kmweber@aztec.asu.edu

Date: 20 Jul 1995 12:06:08 U
From: "John Lucas GRC" <John_Lucas_GRC@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re:  Loctite 271? fuel syste

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               RE> Loctite 271? fuel system threadlocker


Matt writes:

>I'm going to be disassembling my fuel system on my '84
>928S (L-Jetronic).  Just about every threaded connection
>has red threadlocker on it.  When I put it back together
>I want to use the same stuff, so, what is it?  Is this 
>Loctite 271 (high strength)?
<snip>
>Incidently, my fuel filter connections were the same way,
>but when I asked Stoddard about it, the mechanic there
>said to *not* use threadlocker, but to tighten it to the
>point where it wouldn't leak.  Was he wrong?

>So, what's on my fuel system now?  What should I use?

Matt, I just had to pull a fuel line out in order to change the
thermostat housing on my 928S (don't ask why!!) and found
that there was no Loctite or anything else on the couplings. 
I also removed the fuel cooler when I changed an a/c pipe and
there was no Loctite on the fuel line connections there either.  Finally,
I replaced the fuel filter last year and none of the connections
back there had anything on them.

All I did was tighten everything up to where it doesn't leak.

Note that the fuel line fittings are all compression fittings and
seal very well when you tighten the fittings.  Just use common 
sense and don't overtighten!

The Stoddard mechanic is right. 

John
'84 928S


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1572                         Thu Jul 20 21:14:14 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 15:15:58 -0400 (EDT)
From: Walker Mark Edward <walkerb@server.uwindsor.ca>
Subject: Following too close & fog lights

Especialy when driving a beloved Porsche, you are ultimately responsible 
to make sure you don't screw up, or get screwed because of someone else.  
It is not about following too closely - it's about you thinking of things 
that can go wrong and try to avoid them.  This includes, but is not 
liiimted to, others flippng tires at you, stones flying at you, animals 
crossng the road, and such things.  

It is best to assume somebody, includng yourself, will screw up and there 
wll be major consequences.  With ths in mind, you will be more conscious 
of everythng around you and you will be better prepared when something 
bad happens.

For P-philes questioning the effectiveness of fog lamps, they do work 
when set up properly.  They should be aimed lower than the low beams and 
about the same left/right alignment.  With my less than perfect night 
vision, I find fog lights work very well.  Driiving lights (they augment the 
high beams) are very good too.  They are aimed a little higher than the 
high beams and, therefore, send light further ahead of you.

Mark.

199? 911 DREAMS

------------------------------

from the past 3 days.

leak was still existant, and it did not leak, not did the OEL
light come on.  This leads me to believe that it only leaks
when the oil is run through the oil cooler, which I think is
only when the engine is hot, and a switch diverts oil through
this cooler.  Is this how the oil cooler operates, or does
oil always circulate through it?

I am planning on fixing this myself, which will probably mean
pulling out the engine, and replacing the seals, and rings,
and whatever else looks like it needs fixing.  I have never
done this, but am eager to try, as I have fixed just about
every thing else on the car.  I had the engine half way out
2 weeks ago when I replaced the motor mounts.  Any pointers
to full removal of the thing?  Thanks again.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 95 16:45:22 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Convert degrees <--> inches

> After having an alignment done on the racecar I need to convert the results
> from degrees into inches (and visa - versa).  I was unable to find a formula
> after looking through ALL the reference books I have on racecar setup ;-(.
> Can anyone help me out?  If it is something obvious I am just TOTALLY
> missing it ;-(.
> Alex Noordergraaf [noorder@btg.com]

L = R sin Theta

The sine of the angle Theta in degrees from "parallel to centerline", times
the radius of the tire, equals the length you wanted. Measure R in inches,
and you will get L in inches.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

	 other object in the universe, including those
	 objects which are the products of our competitors.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 95 13:51:06 -0700
From: selfridg@encoreengineering.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: "928..BOOM" Project Update

Those who have been here a while probably remember a thread
about a high reving, high HP 928 that was destined for a
home-made fuel computer and a supercharger.  One P-phile
suggested that reving to 8500 RPM at full power would
result in my 928 going "boom."  Well, its got 6500 very
agressive miles on it, and things are going very well.

There was, however, one recent mishap that's worth
mentioning.  During one of my usual freeway passing
maneuvers--at 50MPH, manually downshift to first (it's a
3 speed auto), and stomp it--the impulse actually sheared
the mounting bolt on the air conditioning compressor.
Apparently, the vacuum switch did not disengage the AC
clutch in time, and the low to high RPM instantaneous
change jerked the compressor belt hard enough to snap the
bolt.  The compressor stayed put (it was attached by the
tensioning bracket), but the belt was thrown into all
the other V-belts, and derailed them all.  After noticing
that I had no power steering, no air conditioning, and
low voltage, I exited the freeway and discovered the
missing belts.  From then on, I have been shutting off
the AC prior to these high power/high rev downshifts.

I realize this message is almost certainly flame-bait,
so go ahead and let me have it.

BTW:  The new fuel computer design and program is complete,
the parts came in, and assembly has begun.  I made a
mock-up of the supercharger (a "Gearcharger" from Vortec),
and found that it is too deep for my mounting location.
I could do away with the AC compressor, and mount it
there, but right now, I'm looking at moving the radiator
and fan forward 1.5 inches (that should make enough room).
Since I know interest is high for a 928 supercharger kit,
I will be sure to let everyone know how things develop.

Many enjoyable miles to all.

- --Mike

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 95 16:58:12 EDT

Tracey, you said you got rear-ended. Does that mean that you hit someone
from behind, or does it mean that someone else ran into the back of your
car? Normally, it means the latter, and normally, they are the ones that
have to pay the deductible, not you. And if your insurance company tries
to charge you for the deductible, just send the bill along to the guy that
hit you, it's his responsibility to make good on the damage he caused.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 14:00:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Engineering and the English language

I attended Brooklyn Technical High School in the late 50s, where a
favorite cartoon had the caption "Yesterday I couldn't even spell
eenguneer and now I are one!"  I had a machine shop teacher who wrote
"colled rolled steel" on the board and talked about "hermorphodite
calipers," while coming at me with "Gilbert, can't you do anything right?"

Of course, we were all Oxonian scholars back then--at least compared to the way
my students write today, to say nothing about their teachers.  There's
a notion in progressive education that the very teaching of writing is
authoritarian and hence an instrument of oppression, and we're now
seeing the results.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 95 15:06:55 cst
From: lcrisler@mail.millikin.edu
Subject: WTB C2 Parts

          Thanks to several of you I have a consensus of what P-Car
          parts I will need to convert my 84 to C2 bumpers.  Below is
          the parts I will need to do the job right.  If I have to go
          to retail salvage yards I will probably have to do the job
          "almost" right.  Here are the needed parts from any 89-94
          non-turbo C2 or C4:
Front Bumper Parts
     Impact Bar            964 505 010 00
     Impact Absorber (2)   928 505 015 22
     Lights and Sockets
          Turn Signals  R  964 631 406 01
                        L  964 631 405 01
          Side markers  R  964 631 412 00
                        L  964 631 411 00

Rear Bumper Parts
     Reinforcing Bar       964 505 020 01
     Impact Absorber (2)   964 505 016 00
     
Heat Protection Panels (Probably a good idea)
          Outer         R  964 505 082 01
                        L  964 505 081 01
          Inner     Upper  964 505 083 01
                    Lower  964 505 073 01
          Heat Protect  R  965 505 248 00
                        L  965 504 405 01

          Thanks for the help.  Please reply directly to Larry Crisler
          lcrisler@mail.millikin.edu

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 95 17:17:50 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Following too close & other idiot moves

> Especialy when driving a beloved Porsche, you are ultimately responsible 
> to make sure you don't screw up, or get screwed because of someone else.  

Living and driving in the Boston area (outer limits, but it counts), as I do,
I have long since come to the conclusion that any assumption that any other
driver will take any action other than the most bone-headed, idiotic, and
most likely to cause an accident or at least major damage must be invalid.
OK, sometimes they don't, but if you want your P-car (or any other car)
to last around here, you have to assume that they will be trying to hit you.

A fine example of this phenomenon occurred while I was still driving my
first car ever, a 1971 Porsche 914 (red, OK rust red) in 1981. At 2:30 am,
on Soldiers Field Road, I made the horrible mistake of stopping for the
red light by the radio station. The fellow in the 1974 Mustang II hadn't been
planning to stop, but when his headlights reached my engine he kind of had to.
This was the start of my education regarding the correct attitude wrt the
other drivers around here. If you are at the stop line, leave it in gear
and keep an eye on the rear-view - be ready to peel out when the next clown
comes blazing through. And any time, any where, any situation, be ready with
at least one contingency plan to deal with each possible bone-headed move that
any other driver on the road might be able to pull. In the fullness of time,
they WILL pull exactly those moves.


- --

John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

	 objects which are the products of our competitors.

do I check that--the thing only turns on for 1-2 seconds when I
turn the key.  That's not enough time to see much on my digital
multimeter.

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 17:47:28 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: PCA Club Racing and steel lug nuts

Yes you MUST have steel lug nuts. They are the same as the ones VW uses and
are readily available. I got my set from Zim's if I remember correctly. They
were used and cost about 1 $ apiece. They were also used on 356's so you can
get them thru Porsche where they are expensive. 
Most people who deal in 356's will be able to supply you with a set.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 18:00:00 -0500 (EST)
From: tstaples@ichange.com (Tony Staples)
Subject: RE> Loctite 271? fuel system threadlocker

Matt writes:

>I'm going to be disassembling my fuel system on my '84
>928S (L-Jetronic).  Just about every threaded connection
>has red threadlocker on it.  When I put it back together
>I want to use the same stuff, so, what is it?  Is this 
>Loctite 271 (high strength)?
>Incidently, my fuel filter connections were the same way,
>but when I asked Stoddard about it, the mechanic there
>said to *not* use threadlocker, but to tighten it to the
>point where it wouldn't leak.  Was he wrong?

>So, what's on my fuel system now?  What should I use?

Matt, I am a Sr. Design Engineer for an OEM of fuel injection and engine
 management systems.  My specific background is in fuel injector, and 
fuel rail design.  The Stoddard mechanic was absolutely, positively, 
110% correct.  DO NOT put any type of threadlocker on any of the 
fittings, as this will almost certainly wick into the innards of your 
system.

This can create havoc with the extremely tight clearances in a fuel 
injector or can ruin a pressure regulator.  The fittings in your system 
(Bosch) are designed to seal properly without Loctite.  Be sure to clean
 off all of this before you reassemble the connectors. You might try 
acetone for removing the loctite.  If you would like some specific 
recommendations on improving this injection system please e-mail a 
request to me.

Sincerely,
Tony Staples
tstaples@ichange.com
'88 911 Carrera Cabrio - guards red/tan 
'93 Elizabeth (future Porschephile)

the video tape in the office, called everybody into the kitchen, and
proceded to show off his handy work on the tv/vcr.

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 19:18:58 -0400
From: AlanG23848@aol.com
Subject: RE Rusty Rotors on 944 Turbo

Mike,

I had the same problem with my rotors on my 1989 944 turbo,  I painted the
rotors with Rustoleum semi gloss grey.  They look great and do not rust.   If
you are concerned with heat problems contact Bill Hirsh Automotive in Newark
NJ  they make very high temp paints in spray cans in any color.

Alan

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 16:31:58 -0700
From: "William Dunham" <dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: Convert degrees <--> inches


Or, using the small angle approximation (sin Theta = Theta) then
L = R sin Theta = R Theta.  Just flexing my mathematical muscles...

Bill

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 17:10:34 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Rusty Rotors on 944 Turbo

Mike,

Whenever I buy new rotors I have them black zinc coated at my local metals
refinishing business.  The coating comes off the braking surface almost
immediately, but stays on all the rest forever, w/out discoloring. No rust
anywhere -- it's very appealing.  Cost for 4 rotors is usually $50.

Black zinc is different from black oxide (rusts) and cadmium (doesn't hold
up too well).


 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |
|        standard disclaimers apply         | 
|___________________________________________|

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 21:04:41 -0400
From: rhansen@tiac.net (rhansen)
Subject: P-51s and other remnants of WWII

Several claims to fame.

1. Picked up 1960 356B cabrio at the factory in 1960. Drove it 60,000 miles 
plus in Europe over the next four years.Drove from London to Greece, 
Yugoslavia, Austria and back with wife, (and two children in rear seats 
(ages 12 and 14)). They have never forgotten the trip for obvious reasons.

2.Flight in the P51 in 1944. In those days you could just about step into 
any aircraft as long as you had Army Air Corp wings. After all most fighter 
aircraft were only worth ten times a pilots annual salary. In my case, I was 
taking a squadron buddy to Hamilton Field near San Francisco to the altitude 
chamber because he was going overseas. I spotted the 51 on the flight line 
while I was waiting for him and asked the ops officer if I could take it up. 
Why not, he said? The crew chief started it up and off I went for 40 
minutes.I lifted it off by feel and after a stall or two at altitude, I was 
ready to land it. It was a great aircraft. In some ways better than the P-38 
that I had flown in England and North Africa in combat. In other ways, not 
as good. 

There are only seven P-38s in flyable condition today.

At the end of WWII you could buy a 51 and a spare engine for a couple of 
thousand dollars, but that was big bucks then which accounts for the few 
left flying today.

3. My last flight in the Air Force was in an F 111 which reached mach two 
and cost about five hundred times my annual salary. This was not a case of 
asking the ops officer to take it up, but involved a lot of paperwork and a 
qualified test pilot to make sure it got back on the ground safely.

interior heater). The inlet for this smaller heat exchanger seems
to be plugged - it has a cap on the end. Is this right? Maybe

Porschephiles #1573                         Fri Jul 21 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 19:53:12 -0700 (PDT)
From: tfab@netcom.com (thom fitzpatrick)
Subject: Re: mfi ducting

And Mitchell Craig thus wrote:
> 
> I just put my motor back in and am in the process of trying to get
> all the plumbing correctly hooked up after having had it apart for a 
> long time. There is one hose I'm not sure about, from the LHS tin
> shroud to the LHS exhaust. It is some kind of heat riser for preheating
> the MFI pump. The diam of the tube on the sheet metal shroud is smaller
> than the diam of the outlet on the exhaust. What kind of hose does it

There are two hoses of concern.

One is a special "hose within a hose" insulated jobber, used to provide
heat to the MFI pump, which tells it when the car is warm, and causes
it to then lean the mixture out.  This goes in the engine compartment 
down to the left side, to a pass-thru fitting, and up to the rear
(of the car) of the MFI pump.

The second is a large heavy doody rubber jobber that goes above the valve
cover (exhaust) and runs to a take off on the top of the heat exchanger,
towards the front of the car.

The car will run like crap without them.  I know from experience!

Thom
- --
> I.R.S.: We've got what it takes to take what you've got!
Thom Fitzpatrick & Amy Burgess
tfab@netcom.com
ftp://ftp.netcom.com/pub/tf/tfab/home.html
'56 VW Sunroof Kombi
'72 Porsche 911T Targa
'78 BMW 530i
Desperately seeking '51-'55 Barndoor Deluxe Project

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 23:19:03 -0400 (EDT)
From: Matt Clement <mclement@access.digex.net>
Subject: Re: P-car Paint Color, Want Opinions


On Thu, 20 Jul 1995, Robert M Zampardi wrote:

> Well as it turns out my 77s/turbo needs to be repainted; the shop says
> I have a choice now, considering the Speed Yellow from Porsche, but am
> also thinking about Guards Red; the latter chiefly for resell potential;
> the former for me.

A red or black car will be an easier car to sell -- hard to believe, I 
know, but some Porsche drivers like being recognized for their good, 
classic judgement.  That said, unless you're going to have a glass-out, 
super-expensive paint job done on the car, I'd stick with whatever color 
is already on there.  A two-color paintjob, that is, where bits of color 
remain from a previous paintjob, are even worse than the tarnished 
original paint job.  

I personally was put off a car (a 944) because I could look down into the 
hatchback latches and see that this beautiful black car used to be a 
beautiful red car.  That indicated a shoddy paint job to me, which I took 
to be indicative of the car that the Porsche had received.  No matter how 
clean it looked, I couldn't believe that the owner hadn't cut corners 
earlier if he had cut corners on the paint job.

- -- Matt
   '87 944S, with a hard-to-source burst radiator hose and coolant all over
             the garage.  



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 23:23:17 -0400 (EDT)
From: Matt Clement <mclement@access.digex.net>
Subject: Re: paint, cops & opinions



On Thu, 20 Jul 1995, Robert M Zampardi wrote:

> Spoke to an officer today, WTB some 911 parts, said i might be asking
> for trouble with the speed yellow.

Speed yellow sticks out, to a cop.  It also sticks out to a potential 
buyer.  If he is looking for a car that will make him stand out (a very 
likely possibility, if he is buying the car just because it's a Porsche), 
the speed yellow will appeal.  If he's buying it as a performance car, 
the speed yellow cop magnet may not be so cool.

> BTW so far no one has voted RED.

I vote red, if it's done correctly.  You can't go wrong with red -- 
everyone likes red sports cars.  People are less fussy when buying a used 
car, so stick with something generic -- red, black, perhaps white.  This 
will appeal to more people. 

- -- Matt
   '87 944S


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 20:43:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: P-car Paint Color, Want Opinions

With apologies for being redundant, I strongly second the advice to
keep the color original.  That is, unless it's a glass out, engine
out, interior out, bare metal or down-to-primer paint job, complete
with changing the color-code plaque on the doorjamb.  A car that's
been painted another color any other way will simply be worth less.

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 23:30:55 -0400 (EDT)
From: Matt Clement <mclement@access.digex.net>
Subject: Re: Leather repair/refinishing on 911 steering wheel



On Thu, 20 Jul 1995, Craig Gower wrote:

> The top of my steering wheel has lost some of its smoothness,  seems as
> though it may have suffered some sunburn.  Anybody have any experience in
> refinishing just that portion of the wheel, or other suggestions?  I have
> been told about lightly sanding the wheel (with a very fine abrasive 200 or
> 400)??? and spraying on a leather dye.  Where can I get a Blue dye to match
> the original dark blue leather interior (ie) the existing wheel?

If you are interested in re-dying, leave it to the professionals.  
They'll do a bang-up job, and will be responsible for mismatches in 
color.  They're fairly reasonable, cheaper than you'd expect.  I just had 
all four seats in my 944S done front, back, and sides, for $175.  Call 
your local auto detailer, if they don't have the facility on site, they 
surely can refer you.

Your other option, for about $50, is to get a pre-dyed leather skin.  I 
have no direct experience with these, but have heard they look quite good 
- -- not as good as the original factory stitching, but close.  Any P-phile 
readers have experience with this (as my wheel is in sad shape, and needs 
a facelift to match the seats)

- -- Matt
   '87 944S, with peeling steering wheel

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 07:53:05 -0500
From: wise@db.erau.edu (John Wise)
Subject: 79 911SC CD ignition box

I had similar problems with my 77 (before I swapped engines).  I was lucky
in that my mechanic had several old units (from cars he had converted for
racing). He loaned me one, I swapped it, & the problem went away.  I was
lucky enough that he told me to keep the old unit (he came out ahead in
that he swapped my engine for a 3.2 a year later).  

So you might try your mechanic to see if he has a used laying around that
you could borrow for a day.  It is an easy task.

John

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 95 12:13:01 -0400
From: "THOMAS R BRITTON" <britton@a1.esvax.umc.dupont.com>
Subject: RE: 1988 944 Turbo S VIN number discrepancy


Brian,

Your Vin number is fine, Porsche did not reserve a special VIN number 
for the Turbo S, it just says it's a Turbo. The FAQ # range you mentioned 
is wrong or a typo. One way you can tell if it's an "S", is to look at 
the engine block on the exhaust side, towards the back is a "engine 
type" plate, reading "M 44/52" for the "S" car and "M 44/51" for the 
reg Turbo.

Check it out.

Tom Britton.



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 95 07:38:08 -0500
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William Marten)
Subject: Re: 2 dead 914 fuel pumps!

So Dave's busy killing off $150-$300 fuel pumps . . .

>I heard LOTS of bubbles going into the tank from the return line.
>        So what is it that will kill fuel pumps that quickly?

[the preceeding was severely edited]

Lots of *air* being forced into the fuel tank through the return line
suggests that no *fuel* is being delivered by the pump -- probably because
no fuel is being delivered *to* the pump.  Check the in-tank filter {a
'sock' or screen} and make sure the line from the tank to the pump isn't
clogged.

Fuel is the only coolant and lubricant the pump has and running the pump dry
for extended periods of time will cause it to fail 'prematurely'.  The
process may be accelerated by plugging the supply line {making the pump work
even harder}.

If, OTOH, it turns out that the pump still runs when removed from the car
and run straight from the battery, try replacing the fuel pump relay on the
board in the engine compartment.  I had a problem with one that would work
for short periods of time, overheat, and fail.

Good luck,

Bill Marten
wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu
Madison, WI, USA

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 09:40:02 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: headliners

   Now that my  66 is 100% in the mechanical area, I have decided to work
on the cosmetic side. When I 1st purchased the car I used just about every 
chemical I know of to clean the headliner. It brightened it up marginaly. 
The other day I was a a friends place and have been watching
the resto of a VW type3 Ghia. I had mentioned to him that one of his jobbers
had given me a price of $100 to hang my headliner. I found this price to be 
too good to be true, and and was inquiring how anyone could charge so low,
and if the quality of work would come up to my expectations. Here's the
break out of the cost. Headliner is $50.00, I have to R&R all the glass and
the rubber would have cost me about $260 (assuming I didn't bend the trim
when I removed it). So I have $410 before the "gotcha's". Then my friend
Mike shows me the headliner in his type3. Looked like new! He hands me
a can of stuff called TOPPER. 
 Later that evening I decide that I'll try it on my visors and measure my
results. It looked GREAT! So, yesterday I mask off all the rubber and trim,
then clean the surface of the liner and let it dry. Before application I 
match the color of the visors with the headliner color that is under the 
where the mirror attaches. Looks prefect. So I figure I have nothing to 
loose. It took me about 3 hrs to get done. The surface texture was not 
altered. The dye/paint is flexible and checked by my appilication to the
inside trim on the qtr windows. So I'm a happy camper, for now. Time will
be the test on this "fix". Topper is latex and is cleanable with water 
before it drys. I am so pleased with the finished job that my confidance has 
been boosted enough to consider applying Surflex to the black trim.

Usual discalimers apply no affiliation, don't sell it..ect...ect..

Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1966 911 cpe

Soliciting your long-distance diagnosis: 77 911S fouls one plug.  Compression
in that cylinder same as rest of engine.  Have swapped everything (plug,
plug wire, dist cap, injector, which fuel dist port feeds that cylinder)
and same plug is still fouled.  If engine isn't run for two or more days,
cloud of smoke on starting.  After a minute, or if engine is run daily,
no smoke.

Valve guides?  Rings?  

I hesitate to just call the engine a core and start rebuilding, because 
the bottom end is showing no signs of trouble, runs cool and makes great
oil pressure.  And yet if I pull that cylinder head, the "while I'm at
it"'s start.  Is it possible/responsible to timesert a case without
opening it up?

If I take this problem as a sign from above that I need a 3.0liter engine,
do I need a complete engine or can I use 2.7 CIS induction system and
Triad stainless heat exchangers on a 3.0 long block?

Your insights always appreciated,
