Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 09:50:44 -0500
From: bill.williams@develcon.com (Bill Williams)
Subject: The 914 FUEL PUMP CONTROL SYSTEM

OK - Dave... :>0

I checked after work, there's more to 914 Fuel Pump Problems than meets the
eye! 

Here goes (for all 914s):

Resources Needed:

 - Factory or non-factory wiring diagrams w/relay board schematic
 - for 1.7s and 2.0s:  Kjell Nelin's "D-Jetronic Fuel Injection for the
Porsche 914", avail. electronically 
      (my inspiration!)
 - OHM meter

The 914 FUEL PUMP CONTROL SYSTEM 
          (All 1.7 & 2.0, some things may also apply to the 1.8's different
fuel controlsystem):  

Note:  

Carefully check the ends of 2 wires that connect to the pump (blk/red &
brn).  If any of the wire is not flexible, cut back to a flexible section,
add wire if necessary (& solder), and install a new connector.  


 - (NEG) on the pump is the BROWN wire.  (BROWN is ALWAYS NEG )
        It runs inside the wiring harness to the nearest ground connection.  
         (75-76s have a ground connection in the front, under the fuel tank).

To CHECK BROWN (GROUND) (NEG - ):
 -  DOWN 'N DIRTY:  Connect (fasten securely) a new length of wire from the
Pump - (NEG) directly (fasten securely) to a known good GROUND point.  If
the pump now works, you have a found a ground problem.  ---

If so, --you could leave the new wire, but instead, please try to fix it
properly:

 -  Trace BROWN wire back through harness. Find GROUND point. Since it's near
the Battery (pre-75s), clean the wire ends and connector, and especially the
body mointing point, w/Baking soda & water.  Brighten exposed metal w/fine
sandpaper.  Install and tighten,.  Try the fuel pump now with your repair.
If this worked, spread a little WHITE grease (less/no staining)over the
fresh connection to help prevent corrosion.  

NOTE:  If the GROUND is in the middle of a major rust spot, Move the ground
point.

If the pump didn't begin to operate, the ground wire is broken somewhere,
likely at a point where other wires come out of the protective shirk-wrap.
Inspect and fix with the help of an OHM meter (Continuity check).  

If you decide to replace the entire ground wire, please use BROWN wire in
the same or (my pref.) HEAVIER gauge.  With luck, you might be able to pull
the new wire through the harness by tightly taping it close to the old wire. 



+ (POS) on the pump goes to the wire:  BLACK w/RED STRIPE which runs inside
the harness to the big, multi-connector at the front right of the Relay
Board ( PIN # 13 ).


  -- To be safe, Disconnect the POS Battery terminal connection before
proceeding. --  

Pull this relay board connector straight up and off the relay board (Flat
screwdriver can be carefully used to help pry up)  The wire pins are
numbered on the connector's bottom.  Check the connectors, especially the
BLACK w/RED STRIPE wire ( PIN # 13 ) that goes back to the fuel pump.  Do a
Continuity Check between this end and the fuel pump end.  


To check Continuity you'll need to make a length of wire (w/fuel pump-type
connector) to act as bridge back to the relay board wire end and your OHM
meter]  

[75-76 wire runs through the center tunnel - you'll have a bit more work to
trace the wire - possible inside problem points are @ firewall access point
between seats and at exit point at the front of the tunnel.]


If these wires, so far are good, and you're still having problems:

The RELAY BOARD:  (Please read Kjell Nelin's description of the relay
board's construction!)

Embedded in the underside of the relay board are 70's-style, usually sturdy,
circuit tracks.  You can trace and check the continuity of these circuit
tracks!  In the manual (in non-factory manual too!) is a good photo-diagram
of the relay board circuit tracks....it would be best if you'd find it and
follow along...

The fuel pump [ + ] wire is connected to the ppin that's in the
top-/left-most postion.  The track goes down to 2 places: 
 - Pin 87 on the second relay up from the rear of the relay board [FUEL PUMP
RELAY]. This is the Pin located at [7:00] position.  Check continuity
between this Pin 87 and the Pin 13 at the top connection.  

Note that this circuit track also goes to the pin bank at the bottom right
of the relay board.  The pin that the track connects to there is the
bottom-/right-most Pin 12 (see diagram in manual).  Check the track to this
point too.  Note that the WHITE wire that connects to this Pin 12 goes to
the Supplementary Air Valve.  It wouldn't hurt to check that connector, even
wire Resistance, now that you're good at it  :>)  It would appear that the
Supplementary Air Valve requires this input from the Fuel Pump Relay to
operate (this is the only wire to it).  

Other FUEL PUMP RELAY pins:

Pin 30 (12:00) is the Power Supply track .  NOTE:  terminal (pin) 30 is
ALWAYS [ + ] POWER and the related wire is ALWAYS RED.  On the Relay Board
Pin 30 is in the 12:00 position for all relays. --Battery's Disconnected -
right? --  Check the track continuity between all 12:00 pins. Remove the
lower 25A fuse (blue) and check between its left contact point and the
bottom rely's 12:00 pin.  If it's OK, check, clean and retension the fuse
holder connectors, install a good fuse.


At this point, you might want to reinstall all relays, wires/connectors
(incl. fuel pump). Connect the Battery.  
See if the heater blowe works (lever beteen seat, blower in engine
compartment). 

All relays have the same Part #911.615.109.01   Try switching the fuel pump
relay with the Heater Blower Relay (Bottom Relay)  (Top relay is for Rear
Window Defog grid, 2nd relay is the POWER SUPPLY Relay). 

- ----Disconnect Battery POS before proceeding----

Note that the POWER SUPPLY Relay is critical, and is track-connected from
its Pin 87 [7:00 position] to the Fuel Pump Relay Pin 85 [3:00 position].
The track is further connected to the 4-terminal connector at the
bottom-left of the relay board [Note: 1.8s don't use this
connector],specific pin is the TOP RIGHT SPADE terminal.  Check continuity
between these end-points.  The dbl. wires (16 & 24) from this spade (as well
as the others at this connector, except 1.8s) runs to the computer
(configuration varies w/engine size/year).  I'm not digging deeper now, but
you could check the connection & wire continuity)

Pin 86 [3:00] on the Fuel Pump Relay is connected to the TOP LEFT SPADE,
also at this connector.  You can also check the track continuity between
these two points, and check the wire back to the computer (connection 19 at
the computer's connector).

While we're at this connector, the bottom left spade belongs to wire 31.
Manual shows it going to the cold start valve wired in series with the
thermo-switch.


The bottom right spade wiring is different on the two computers I'm looking at:

039 906 021A   (2.0  1975)  dbl. wires #18 and 33
022 906 021E - Dr914's catalog shows this as 2.0 computer (pre-75?)- Dave D.
confirm #'s for your 74 2.0 and please report!!!

part # label missing - from '73 1.7  - single wire, red ink #16 (looks like
16, but maybe 18???)

Electrically, from the manual, the bottom two spades are connected together
internally, and go to the starter (yellow wire, pin 6 on bottom right
multi-pin connector.


Well, that's it!!!   Is your pump working now?

I hope this has helped!  Please make any corrections/additions/variations to
this file by using the fancy parantheses {{{ in threes on each side }}} and
send the file back to me:   bill.williams@develcon.com

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 08:38:51 -0700 (MDT)

Subject: Re: paint, cops & opinions

> BTW so far no one has voted RED.

I've always felt that red was a good color for the Italian cars but that
silver was more 'proper' for the Porsche (that said, I still prefer fly
yellow Ferraris -- go figure).  I also like the subtlety of silver.

Original color is usually better than any other, but I don't know anyone
who would refuse to buy a car just because was repainted a different 
color (particularly if it was repainted properly).  There are usually
much larger factors in the purchase of a Porsche.

I am looking for.  I was thinking of buying the PCA Tech Tips 
book, Volume VI I think covers the 911 engine.  I am willing to

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 12:22:52 -0400
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Intake gaskets ?

They do exist in theory. The gaskets are actually built into the blocks.
 They do not exist as a seperate part.  So, they do exist but only as part of
the whole.

Dr. 914

car could be determined by the color.

were "British Racing Green".  Either France or Japan was yellow.

Date: 21 Jul 1995 17:51:59 U
From: Steve Poole <stevep@wrq.com>
Subject: Re: Best material to learn 911 engine repair

>I am looking for.  I was thinking of buying the PCA Tech Tips 
>book, Volume VI I think covers the 911 engine.  I am willing to
>spend a little money (of which I have little) for the best source
>of information and technical detailed literature on the repair of

I just bought Volumn VI of Up-fixin' Der Porsche, Barry, and would highly
recommend it. Among other things it has Bruce Anderson's history of the 911
engine (written in '83 or '84, I think), which is quite interesting. There's
a huge amount of information in that book for $15. It doesn't have the kind
of exhaustive system-wide detail that you're looking for, but I think you'll
find it to be well worth the price.

Steve Poole

Porschephiles #1575                         Fri Jul 21 16:03:44 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 10:11:07 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: 914:  Brighter headlights?

> 
> P-pholks,
> 
> What are the options for replacing my headlights with brighter ones ('73 914)?  
> Currently when I'm on a road with no streetlights I don't have enough light to 
> see very well.  So I end up being one of those people I hate who run their 
> fog/driving lights when it's a clear night.  (and yes, fog/driving light 
> thread, they _definitely_ make a difference in my case--especially when driving 
> on a curvy road through a wooded area with no streetlights)
> 
> TIA, Thwen.
> 

Currently, headlight upgrades are illegal in California on public
roads, so DO NOT DO THE FOLLOWING!

1)  Get a set of Hella 7" H-4 headlights.

2)  Replace the 55/60 elements with 55/80's or 55/100's

3)  Install a relay (or two) near the headlights for the high-beam
    circuit.  Use a heavy gauge of wire from the relay to the power,
    as 100w lights do draw some current.  

Headlights will run $30~40 each.  GPR had the elements cheap ($8)
last time I checked.

Gary.

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 18:32:21 +0100
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Locking Wheel Nuts and Balance

> Can the factory wheel locks affect the balance of the wheels?
>
> Maybe the reason the shaky steering happens off and on is
> because whenever I remove the wheel, the wheel-lock is randomly
> positioned on any stud. It just so happens on the most recent removal,
> I re-installed the lock on the most out of balance position?

        Yes, the wheel locks can definately affect the wheel balance.

        Can't remember about my 944, but on the 911 the end of one of the wheel 
studs is painted (red on mine). Porsche advice is that the hole nearest the tyre
valve *must* go on this stud, and the wheel lock *must* also go on this stud.

	I came a cropper yesterday when trying to remove my wheels to clean them 
for the local PCGB concours on Sunday. The wheel nuts (which were last fastened 
by my local dealers) were *incredibly* difficult to open, and I ended up 
shearing off the third one I tried to open. When I went to my dealers, they 
sheared off 2 more. Total cost to drill out the nuts and replace the studs was 
132 pounds Sterling. Ouch ... an expensive way to take my wheels off!! What can 
I do to prevent this happening again (especially as the studs were properly 
lubricated and torqued to 130 MN / 94 ft-lb)?

        BTW, doubt it will affect wheel balance :-) but in a recent Excellence 
article it was stated that the bottom of the crest on the centre cap should 
point to the valve for maximum concours points. I've looked at various factory 
literature and press photographs and the orientation of the crest always seems 
to be random. Any concours nuts out there like to comment?

Philip Katz ['89 911 Carrera 3.2 Sport Coupe - Taubenblau Metallic]

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 11:56:46 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Peeling Out (was: "re: Following too closely / idiot moves)

John Lupien (lupienj@wal.hp.com) wrote: 

>If you are at the stop line, leave it in gear and keep an eye on the
>rear-view - be ready to peel out when the next clown comes blazing 
>through.

    John:

    This is DANGEROUSLY BAD advice.  Remember, you're stopped for a
    reason; presumably there's cross traffic that you're choosing to
    ignore in favor of staring intently at your rear-view mirror...
    When you "peel out" into this traffic, you're likely to die.

    Besides, when do you make the determination to squirt out into this
    traffic?  When the car behind you is 50 feet away?  100?  500?

    Let's say that the car coming up fast behind you is a Ford Taurus
    GL (only because I have braking data for that car here in front of
    me), and that he's traveling at 70 mph.  For you to avoid being
    hit, you have to accelerate to 70 mph before he closes the
    distance.

    Ok... I have no idea what you drive, but let's give you the benefit
    of the doubt and say you're in something spectacular that can do
    0-70 in 6 seconds.
    
    This means that -- assuming you've trained under John Force, your
    tires are warm, the road's clean, and you're willing to let the
    Taurus' front bumper just tap your rear at the instant that you
    match his speed -- you have to leave the line when the Taurus is
    600-PLUS feet behind you, so you'd have to make the decision when
    he was about 700 feet back.  If you wanted to leave enough time to
    check for cross traffic, he'd have to be about 900 feet back. 

    Keep in mind that these numbers assume the absolute best case.
    
    Since the Taurus can stop from 70 mph in under 200 feet, you're
    going to look pretty stupid jumping out of the way when he's still
    half a block behind the point where he planned to start braking.

    Another reason not to follow your advice:  When a clutch cable
    breaks, it will inevitably be while the pedal is depressed.  If
    this happens during a shift, it's no big deal -- annoying, but not
    life-threating.  If it happens while you're sitting at a traffic
    light with the car in gear, you'll be catapulted into the
    intersection where, again, you're likely to die.

    One more:  Constantly holding the clutch is tiring.  After a while,
    you'll probably let up on it a little, thereby wearing it out at a
    tremendously-accelerated pace.  Expensive and pointless.

>And any time, any where, any situation, be ready with at least one
>contingency plan to deal with each possible bone-headed move that
>any other driver on the road might be able to pull.

    This, on the other hand, IS good advice.  Just be sure that your
    contingency plan has some merit.

    -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 95 12:03:08 PDT
From: calzia@mojave.wr.usgs.gov
Subject: NARP

        Thwen Chaloemtiarana asks what's a NARP?  At the risk of dating
myself, I believe NARP is an acronym for Not A Real Porsche.  I think this
dig began in the mid '60s when 356 owners would flash their car's
headlights (using the "light horn" lever on the steering column) at other
356s, 911 owners would do the same to other 911s (or, God forbid, a
912--You may be forgiven for this atrocity cuz a 912 looked like a 911 head
on), but never would a 356 salute a 911 because (drum roll, please) it was
Not a Real Porsche!  And later, no self-respecting 356 or 911 would never
ever salute a 914 cuz 914s are NARP!!

        I have always enjoyed this ritual between P-cars but,
unfortunately, it doesn't happen much anymore.  Maybe the Porschephiles
could resurrect it as a serect sign of recognition for those in the know.  

        I'll be flashin'!

Jim Calzia
1973 911S

I seem to recall reading that it goes back to the beginnings of
international auto racing...

British - green (BRG)
French  - blue
German  - silver
Italian - red
USA     - white with blue stripe

I don't remember the others.  Hmmm, where is that book?  <scratches head>

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 10:21:43 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: 914 Questions

> 
> Has anyone installed the Weltmeister spring set to improve the shifting. I
> see that Auotomotion has them.
> 
You didn't say if you had an early or late 914.  I have a "side-shifter"
('73-up), and don't know much about "tail-shifters".

The biggest improvement can be gotten by renewing ALL of the bushings.
The most over-looked is the one inside the very last coupling.  (Ball
in cup, inside the black cover)

If all of the bushings are in good shape, the shifting really isn't 
all that bad.  If you're having trouble finding the gears, putting
a short-shifter on it will make them even harder to find.

The only benefit of stiffer springs is making it harder to do a
4->1 shift instaed of a 4->3 shift.

> Also, I want to put some new tires on my car. It has the original Fuchs
> wheels. What about MXV4's or Yoko's. This car is for street use only.
> Thanks
> Keith Schultz
> 
Guys on this list like Yoko's.  If it's for street *ONLY*, I would get
185/65-15's rather than 195/60-15's.  The ride will be a lot more
pleasant, especially on *real* roads.

Gary.
> 


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 12:24:25 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: paint, cops & opinions


Sean P. Simmen said:

>I agree, the classic Porsche color is silver. . . .

The "classic" silver for Porsche is a non-shine, burnished look -- to
resemble aluminum. I remember the owners of early 356s with this color
would clean their cars with a brillo pad to maintain the "look."

Larry Wilson



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 12:33:30 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: paint, & opinions

Gary Helbig says:
>USA cars were white, Italian: red, German: Silver, and British cars
were "British Racing Green".  Either France or Japan was yellow.

Nope. USA was white with blue trim. Germany was white. Belgium, yellow.
Holland, Orange. France, blue, etc.

It was not the CanAm series -- they painted usually with whatever color
their sponsor logo used. The "country-colors" were used in "international"
racing (Europe) before they got so crass as to put sponsor advertising on
their cars.

Larry Wilson

a road that has no reason to have a stop light to begin with. I was
stopped because the light was red. No other reason at all, and I
rather wish, in that particular case, that I hadn't stopped. Hindsight

is that I'm not in the idiot's way before he gets to where I was
patiently waiting for the light to change. And that means getting
out of his way. Why would I want to try to accelerate along the path
he is most likely to follow?

that was 6 pounds less weight... hence the "Silver Arrows".

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 95 13:06:01 PDT
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com>
Subject: Re: paint, & opinions

Gary Helbig says:
> I seem to remember a race series (Can-Am?) where the country of the
> car could be determined by the color.
> 
> USA cars were white, Italian: red, German: Silver, and British cars
> were "British Racing Green".  Either France or Japan was yellow.
> Gary.

Ask and yye shall receive:



         THE COLOR IN RACING    (ROAD AND TRACK- 1960)


    REFERENCES are often made, in R&T, to the "red"  cars
        from  Ferrari  or  Maserati,   the   "green"   cars   from
    Vanwall, Aston Martin or  Jaguar  and  the  "white"  or  "sil-
    ver" cars from Mercedes-Benz.
       These are not arbitrary colors  picked  by  each  construc-
    tor for his cars (except in the  case  of  strictly  national,
    local or club  competition,  where  anything  goes),  but  are
    the result of a decision reached in the early days of  racing.
    Cars were, and still are,  distinguishable  by  assigned  num-
    bers,  but  further  separation  (prompted  no  doubt  by  na-
    tionalistic feelings) was felt desirable.  This is  why  racing
    cars from Italy are red,  the  cars  from  England  are  green
    and the  cars  from  Germany  are  white  (or  sometimes  sil-
    ver-the  result  of  leaving  the  aluminum  body  unpainted).
       A private  owner  will  generally  paint  his  car  in  the
    color(s) of his  own  country,  rather  than  the  manufactur-
    er's.  According to the C.S.I.  of  the  F.I.A.,  "The  use  of
    distinctive colors  of  nationality  is  compulsory  when  the
    supplementary  regulations  of  the  competition  require  it.
    These  colors  are  determined  by  the  nationality  of   the
    competitor."  So,   a   Ferrari   owned   by   an   Englishman
    would be painted green, even though it  was  an  Italian  car.
       Thus, it has become a  tradition  for  racing  cars  to  be
    painted in the colors of the entrant, although  they  are  oc-
    casionally seen  with  minor  variations.  Mercedes,  for  ex-
    ample,  honored  Englishman  Richard   Seaman,   who   was   a
    Mercedes  team  driver,  with  a  green  border   around   the
    grille opening  of  his  car.  The  shrewd  Germans  had  also
    noted that this would allow  quick  identification  if  Seaman
    and one of  the  other  Mercedes  drivers  (who  would  be  in
    identical cars) chanced to pass rapidly by  the  pits  at  the
    same time.
       Because  these  colors  were  assigned  during   the   days
    when racing cars  possessed  chassis  that  were  visible  be-
    neath  the  body,  many  countries  have  a   combination   of
    colors: one for the body,  one  for  the,  chassis  and  some-
    times another for some other  part,  such  as  the  wheels  or
    hood.  This  presented  a  problem  when   streamlining   came
    into fashion and the chassis  disappeared  from  sight.  As  a
    consequence, the color formerly allotted  to  the  chassis  is
    now applied in the form of stripes  or  other  trim  over  the
    color assigned to  the  body  by  the  Code  Sportif  Interna-
    tional  of  the  Federation  Internationale  de  L'Automobile.
       To further simplify (or  complicate)  matters,  green,  the
    color assigned to the British Empire, is used as a  basis  for
    all  cars  from  England  and  its  possessions.  The  common-
    wealth  countries  use  green  as  a  body  color  with  other
    colors, at their choice,  as  stripes.  Canada,  for  example,
    uses two white stripes 4 in. wide, one on  each  side  of  the
    car's centerline and 6 in. apart.
       British racing green, to  dispel  some  of  the  arguments,
    is not any particular shade of  green,  but  Napier  green  is
    preferred.  Stirling  Moss  drove  a  light  sea-green  BRM  in
    the 1959  French  Grand  Prix.  This  was  quite  contrary  to
    the accepted general  opinion  of  what  constitutes  "British
    Racing Green" but was, nevertheless, acceptable.
       The color applied to a racing car has also  had  its  share
    of side  effects.  For  many  years  U.S.  drivers  would  not
    drive in, or in  competition  with,  cars  painted  any  shade
    of green; they believed the color  to  be  unlucky.  This  has
    diminished in recent years, especially  since  the  advent  of
    more British international competition.
       The chart lists the racing colors of each  country  as  as-
    signed by  the  C.S.I.  The  car  number  and  its  background
    color, a necessary aid to identity, are made  to  contrast  as
    as much as possible to aid race  officials  and  lap  scorers.
    Colors assigned to chassis or  underframe  in  the  chart  are
    now applied to stripes or trim.


    COUNTRY         COLORS OF CAR            NUMBERS
    Argentina       Body: blue               red on white
                    Hood: yellow
                    Chassis: black
    Belgium         Body:  yellow            black
    Brazil          Body: pale yellow        black
                    Chassis and wheels:green
    Canada          Body: green              white
                    Stripes: white
    Chile           Body: red                half blue-
                    Hood: blue               half red or
                    Underframe: white        all red on white
    Cuba            Body: yellow             white on black
                    Hood: black
    Czecho-         Body: white              blue
    slovakia        Hood: blue and white
                    Underframe: red
    Egypt           Pale violet              red on white
    Finland         Black                    blue on white
    France          Blue                     white
    Germany         White                    red
    Great           Green                    white
    Britain
    Holland         Orange                   white
    Hungary         Body, front: white       black
                    Body, rear: green
                    Hood: red
    Irish Free      Green with horizontal    white
    State           band of orange around
                    body
    Italy           Red                      white
    Luxem-          Pearlgray                white on red
    burg
    Mexico          Gold                     white on black
    Monaco          White with red hori-     black on white
                    zontal band around
                    body
    Poland          Body and hood: white     red
                    Underframe: red
    Portugal        Body and hood: red       white
                    Underframe: white
    Scotland        Green                    white
    South           Body: Gold               black on white
    Africa          Hood: green
    Spain           Hood: yellow             black on yellow
                    Body and chassis: red    white on red
    Sweden          Body and hood, lower     white
                    part:blue-upper:yellow
                    Three cross bands of
                    blue on top of hood

    land            Body and underframe:
                    red

                    pale blue with yellow
                    horizontal band around
                    body and hood

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 95 13:59:35 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: MFI Ducting


Mitch-

>There is one hose I'm not sure about, from the LHS tin
>shroud to the LHS exhaust. It is some kind of heat riser for 
>preheating the MFI pump. The diam of the tube on the sheet 
>metal shroud is smaller than the diam of the outlet on the 
>exhaust. What kind of hose does it take?

Think of this as one hose, in two parts.  The first part
runs from the LH heat exchanger to the engine surround feed-
thru, and the second goes from the feedthru to the thermostat
device on the MFI pump.  It attaches to an inlet on the LH heat 
exchanger about 6" down from the top of the exchanger, the top 
being where interior heat is supplied.   The MFI system won't 
work well without both parts.  If you're not fussy about 
originality, just about any old hose will do, preferable a 
reasonably think one that is a fairly good insulator so hot air 
from the exchanger will arrive at the MFI pump in a reasonably 
efficient manner.  FWIW, I used a heavy piece that I had on hand 
for the lower part, and one of those flexible things for the upper.

>Also, the fitting on the exhaust is on a kind of jacket or heat
>exchanger 

This doesn't make sense to me.  The outlet for the hose to the MFI 
pump sticks out of the heat exchanger as noted above.  On the 
bottomof the exchanger there is something like what you 
describe, a sort of heat exchanger exterior to the main heat 
exchanger if you get what I mean.  Its outlet is large, about 2" in 
diameter, and it supplies heated air through a hose that runs 
through a hole in the engine surround in the rear left corner and 
then on up to a big plastic 'box' and then into the air filter.  The 
box is supposed to mix hot and cool air to provide the engine 
with a constant, optimum temperature air supply.  Lots of guys 
don't install this hose.  It tends to suck up road dirt and direct it 
into your filter.  I don't have mine on, and I can't tell the 
difference.  I may be way off base, but I think it's just another of 
those things that was stuck on cars of that vintage to overcome 
the new emission laws.  It has virtually nothing to do with 
performance.





Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 17:13:27 -0400 (EDT)
From: takaharu@sas.upenn.edu (Takaharu Mizutani)
Subject: Re: paint, cops & opinions (fwd)


Matt Clement wrote:
> Speed yellow sticks out, to a cop.  It also sticks out to a potential 
> buyer.  If he is looking for a car that will make him stand out (a very 
> likely possibility, if he is buying the car just because it's a Porsche), 
> the speed yellow will appeal.  If he's buying it as a performance car, 
> the speed yellow cop magnet may not be so cool.

I agree totally. This is the reason why some newer fire engines and 
ambulances are painted bright yellow. Very high visibility. Police cars 
would also be painted yellow for this same reason, except that taxis 
already use yellow, and it would not be good to mistake a taxi and a 
police car.

> > BTW so far no one has voted RED.
> 
> I vote red, if it's done correctly.  You can't go wrong with red -- 
> everyone likes red sports cars.  People are less fussy when buying a used 
> car, so stick with something generic -- red, black, perhaps white.  This 
> will appeal to more people. 

I agree partially. I prefer black cars, because many cars in black look 
really nice. This is, however, a bad choice if you live in a sunny area 
because your car will heat up more, IMHO. (Is this just a myth?) It is 
also a bad choice if you get worried about the car being dirty. Black 
shows dirt very well, and is a pain to keep clean. My father's Nissan Maxima
looks great in black, but _only_ when it's clean. He's not as fastidious 
about car cleaning as I am. :-)

My vote for the next best color is silver. It is a classic German car color,
and I think Porsches look great in silver. The new 993 turbo was shown in 
silver in a couple car mags, and I've seen several silver 911s in person.
They're beautiful.

On a side note, if you ever decide to upgrade that older 930 to newer 
rotors and calipers, silver also shows off those huge red calipers well, 
especially in the newer 5-spoke wheels.

Anyone agree with silver?

- --

takaharu@mail.sas.upenn.edu                            Philadelphia, PA, USA

Porschephiles #1576                         Fri Jul 21 20:14:19 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 21 Jul 95 14:13:44 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: Material for 911 Repair


Barry-

>Problem:  Everytime something on my car breaks, like once a week
>so far this summer, I seem to be at a loss for knowledge about how
>to fix it

That's the way it is.  God forbid you should actually have the\
same problem twice and therefore know how to solve it.  It doesn't
happen.

I've never found the manuals to be much help diagnosing problems.
They're good to help you figure out how to remove and reinstall
stuff, but that's about it.  And in spite of all the bad-mouthing
given to Haynes, I think they're actually pretty good.  They have
pretty good photos, and when you encounter a place where they might
not be exactly correct, there's usually enough there to get you
through it.

I've never seen the Workshop Manuals, and can only assume that they
must be 30 to 50 times better since they cost 30 to 50 times more.

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 15:00:24 -0700 (PDT)
From: tfab@netcom.com (thom fitzpatrick)
Subject: Re: MFI Ducting

And Bob Spindel thus wrote:
> 
> >Also, the fitting on the exhaust is on a kind of jacket or heat
> >exchanger 
> 
> This doesn't make sense to me.  The outlet for the hose to the MFI 
[blah blah blah]
> those things that was stuck on cars of that vintage to overcome 
> the new emission laws.  It has virtually nothing to do with 
> performance.

Yes, it _does_ have to do with performance!  The hose in question is
a thick rubber one that goes from a point above the left (LIL) side 
valve cover (top right) and connects to an outlet on the heat exchanger
on the back part of the heat exchange, up kinda by the end of the
cam.  I think you're confused with the one that carries air thru
the heat excahnger to the passenger compartment...

I have heard of aftermarkey heat exchangers being made without this
little duct/outlet on them.  I know it was a concern when I went to
get SSI's for my '72.  It has them, thankfully!

The fitting above the valve cover, on the right, is just a "pass-thru"
to the engine compartment.

Inside the engine compartment, there is a paper hose, about 1 1/2" in
diameter, that actuallu has another hose inside it (or is s'posed to
anyway) to insulate it.  This goes to the top rear of the MFI pump.

This is to provide warm air to the MFI pump, so it "knows" when the engine
is warm and leans the mixture accordingly.

If you take either of these hoses off, the car will run like crap.

There aren't many subjects about these cars which I can pontificate with
much certainty, but by golly this is your lucky day, 'cause this is 
one of them! :)

Thom

> Artificial Intelligence usually beats real stupidity.
Thom Fitzpatrick & Amy Burgess

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 09:24:17 -0500
From: Joe Browne <brownej@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  Lighting

My wife and I run some local road rallies and have been experimenting
better road lighting for a while.  We did it in phases to maintain a budget. 
Phase 1-  replaced the standard sealed beams with Hella conversion
units.  Sealed beams were 45watt low beams/55watt high beams per US
law.  We added 55watt low/80 watt high bulbs to the Hella units.  We
were concerned about the lows being an irritant to other drivers
(needlessly as it happens because the Hella units have a very distinct
cutoff on low beam and will not blind anyone on low beam if aimed
properly).  After a few rallies, we did phase 2 to get more light-  replace
the 55/85 watts with 80/100's.  This necessitated running power directly
from the battery (fused, of course) into high current relays and then to
the headlamps.  The wires that used to go to the headlamps drove the
switch terminals on the relays.  Not as tough as it sounds.  We had lots
of lights and still were okay to drive without being a menace.  Later,
phase 3 saw us add some Hella Rally 4000, which caused air rescue to
go out looking for the plane running the backroads with his landing lights
on.  We no longer need more light.  You can film color tv in front of our
car.   The road rallyists motto, " if you have enough light, you don't need
snow tires!"  

This was all done to our Jetta and my old Jeep CJ.  I don't rally in the 911
because the roads are gravel at times and I don't want to fix the chips.  I
have replaced the sealed beams with 80/100 Hella conversions and
notice a substantially safer amount of light.

J.Browne
wife veronique
14 month old son ( messy eater)
79 sc targa (also messy when eating truck tires)



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 95 15:30:14 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: MFI Ducting

Hi Thom,

I don't want to make a big thing out of this, but I'm pretty
sure my note to Mitch Craig about the LH heat exchanger
hoses was clear.  The first part dealt with the important
hose from the exchanger to the MFI pump.  It's the one
you need or it'll run crappy.  I think that's the one you are
talking about too.

The second part of my message dealt with the 2" diameter
hose that supplies hot air to the plastic box that regulates
the temp of the air being sucked into the engine.  That one
you don't need, and in fact, there are some who routinely
remove it becase, as I said, it can suck up road debris and
deposit right into the engine air intake thereby dirtying
the air filter, or if particles get through the filter,
ruining the engine.  Note that this hose, the unnecessary one
is 2" in diameter.  The hose to the MFI pump (which is in
two sections, one above and one below the engine surround) is
only about 1" in diameter.  It's hard to mix them up.

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu
'72 911E
'72 911T

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 18:48:16 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Best material to learn 911 engine repair

>stuff deleted

>these engines.  I have been, and continue to plan on doing all of 
>the work to this car myself, I enjoy working on the car, but am
>frustrated with my lack of resources for education in the matter.
>Along with difficulties with just the Haynes manual, Its time for 
>something much more informative.  Are the shop manuals what I am
>looking for?  Do they give detailed instructions? Do What can 
>someone recommend?  

Having just spent about 30 seconds deep in thought, it seems to me
that fixing things (911s included) is basically knowing *how* some-
thing works (to diagnose the problem) and then having the tools/
ability/know-how to take it apart and fix it.  Having stated this 
questionable gem of wisdom, I would recommend getting your hands
on anything that explains *how* the particular item you're concerned
with works.  There are alot of sources out there for this kind of
info relative to 911s.  Bruce's book is good, the Bosch "Technical
Instruction" Manual for K-jetronic is good, the Haynes' manual has its
moments...

If you have the luxury of time, sometimes it is fun to just tinker
around and take things apart, see how they work, etc.  (I'm a mech.
engineer - taking things apart to see how they work is my life...)

Unfortunately, gaining this knowledge is a time-consuming venture.

FWIW,,,

Mike
'76 Euro 911


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 18:50:29 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Removing CIS boot from 911SC

>How do I go about removing this CIS boot?  I looked there
>last night and saw various ways this may be possible.

Barry,

This is real easy.  You basically remove the air filter cover and
loosen the two clamps that secure the boot to the sensor beam/
throttle plate jobbie-do and pull it off.  It's been awhile since I've
done this (sorry), but you may want to make sure nothing is connected
to this boot before you yank it out.  :>) 

That's it.  Once you do this you can line up the clamp screws for easy
access in the event you ever need to do it again.

Mike
'76 Euro 911

something leaking from the cover but a film none the less.  I think this is a 
function of dust, or whatever penetrating the cover and somehow bonding 
(electrostatically?) to the car finish.  It rinses off easily but my guess is 
that this is a byproduct of covering a car.  Any physical scientists out there 
have any input or solutions.  I've tried washing the covers to be sure they 
were as clean as possible but get the same results.  Haven't tried creating a 
dust free environment but, hmmmm, that would keep me out of trouble for a 
weekend......Ted Smith

Date:          Fri, 21 Jul 1995 11:06:49 +0000
From: "Dirk Bergstrom" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       How Low Can You Go?

After the thread on revving ones engine about town (six months or so
ago), I'm hesitant to bring this up, but I'm getting nervous...

What constitutes "lugging" a 911 engine?  How many revs is too few?  Can
I tool around town at 2000 in 3rd, can I try to accelerate from 2200 in
5th, just how slow can I go in first?

I asked my mechanic what was lugging, and he said "anything below 3000."
This seems excessive, but what do I know?.  I knew what was lugging in
my old four cylinder rice burner, but a performance flat six is a whole
different world.  Obviously the answer will depend on a large number of
factors, but I'm looking for some general rules of thumb

I've been going on the assumption that 2200 was "the bottom" in anything 
other than first, unless I was basically coasting.  I'd hate to put undue 
strain on the motor (a sort of stock 2.7).

We need another contentious debate, now that the fog lights and 
tires-in-the-road threads are fading...

Dirk Bergstrom
'75 911S, Newly repaired window winder

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 11:02:37 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Outside mirrors for older 911

To close the loop on my "rectangular mirrors for 72-73 911" question:

Several respondents indicated that the mirrors I wanted were only
available for the left side.  I got some indications of sources for
left side mirrors and a couple of offers for sale or trade of that
single mirror.  However, my problem is that someone had installed
aftermarket mirrors on both sides.  I neet to have matching mirrors
on the car, or repair the holes on the right side.

One respondent said he'd checked in England and found only round
ones on the 2.4-liter cars there.

I thought I'd seen ads for dual mirrors like I described, or seen
them on a car somewhere, or something.  I could be mistaken.

It sure looks like the car was set up for mirrors on both sides,
because of the holes on the inside of both doors for accessing the
nuts on the mirror bolts.

If I could find some aftermarket mirrors that were positioned to the
rear of the mounting bracket (so the right side one is not blocked by
the "A" pillar), I'd consider them.  But I haven't spotted any.

I guess I'll stick with my round ones.  Bummer...

- --Walt Thode

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 20:05:13 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Help me make it through the night

On Fri, 21 Jul 1995 Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV wrote:

>   The other day I unconsciously tried to put the key into the dashboard to
>   the left of the steering wheel in my wife's 318i. It felt good to see
>   that I haven't lost that P-car instinct after 2 plus months of
>   maintenance/repair induced withdrawal.
On any of our cars, you can always watch the driver try to (without 
watching) place the key into the ignition, and then shift from park to 
reverse. A fairly simply task? I think not. The Porsche, with key on left 
dash, Toyota on right dash, Buick and VW on right steering wheel column, 
then all but Buick with center shift (Buick has column shifter), it's 
amazing that there aren't little scratch marks and fingerprints in these 
most common areas... Of course, we don't have a Saab, or else, someone 
might try to place the key into the shifter... :)
 -Derek



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 20:33:54 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: 1 oily 911 plug

> 77 911S fouls one plug.  Compression in that cylinder same as rest of
> engine....

With normal compression and plug fouling the usual culprit is a worn valve
guide.  Smoke after a couple of days' inactivity reinforces that diagnosis.
 But, before replacing it, ask yourself why that one is worn when the others
aren't.  Possibly a slightly bent valve stem?  (Over-revving might do that to
a single valve.)

Good luck in finding the problem.

Bob Joyce
Knoxville, Tennessee USA
1965 356SC
1988 924S

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 20:11:28 +0000

Correction: WERE illegal. I went to my local sports car accessory 
shop (the same price I got my Momo Corse wheel - ohh so much nicer 
than that lousy plastic steering wheel), and asked for H4s, and Hella 
is now selling DOT-approved H4s. I think they're called Vision 
Plus's... They don't say anywhere on the box that they're H4s, but 
they are. (Just look at the bulb itself - says H4 right there.) 
They're got the almost-flat glass in front, and the 
radically-different light pattern, and everything else like the Euro 
H4s - only DOT-approved. (Probably just from the addition of the 
three teats for alignment.)

Date: 21 Jul 1995 18:46:10 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.COM (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: 84 -> C2 look...argh!

> From: lcrisler@mail.millikin.edu
> Subject: WTB C2 Parts
>
> Thanks to several of you I have a consensus of what P-Car the parts I
> will need to do the job right.  If I have to go to retail salvage yards I
will
> probably have to do the job "almost" right.  Here are the needed parts
> from any 89-94 non-turbo C2 or C4:
<snip>
> Thanks for the help.  Please reply directly to Larry Crisler
> lcrisler@mail.millikin.edu
- ----------
Larry,
Please don't do it!  Don't spoil the car's originality!

How many of us are now desperately seeking original equipment or otherwise
struggling to put our older cars back the way the factory built them (and
cursing the PO's for doing the sh*t they did!)?  Not only are Porsches much
more valuable in their original state, they are often easier to maintain,
sell, and certainly admire.  (There are a few legitimate exceptions for
mechanical improvements like chain tensioners). 

The only excuse I can see for modifying these works-of-art is to improve them
for racing.  And even then it's a good idea to try to limit  changes to
improvements that can be easily turned around (wheels/tires, springs, sways,
height, even engines).  Okay... extreme changes are sometimes necessary for a
track car.  But usually a modifier accepts that such changes make it a race
car forever.

If you must have the C2/C4-look sell your Carrera and buy a 964.  For the
$10-15k difference you get a real C2 with a 3.6, ABS, improved ergonomics,
legible dash dials, better ventilation, etc.  If you consider resale you'll
probably spend less this way (figure your 84 will be worth about 20% less due
to your mods).

There oughta be a law...

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara, CA)
95 993 coupe, guards red (stock in every way)
73.5 911T 2.7 coupe, ferrari red (with PO's Carrera cup mirrors, choice of
color, wood dash)
85 535i, grey

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 95 11:20:04 -2400
From: Brian Mifsud <mifsud_brian@tandem.com>
Subject: 914: Bad Trigger Points?

Hello All,
    My '76 2.0 was missing badly on start up in the morning, after 
crossed fingers I drove a few blocks and the missing mostly subsided but
I was not confident enough to drive the 30 miles to work.  I called in to 
the boss and took the car apart.
1) good spark at all 4 cylinders, all parts are very young, rotor, cap, 
   plugs, points, condenser...good connections...good spark (ouch, it                      
   always hurts when I check spark)
2) pulled injectors out of manifold, put glass vials over ends, removed     
   battery, disconnected coil, and powered up fuel pump from remote          
   battery...no leaks after 5 minutes of running pump.
3) replaced battery, double-checked (disconnected?) coil, cranked engine 
   for 15 seconds (didn't floor accelerator while cranking)....got fuel 
   in #'s 1 & 3. Compared levels...same. No fuel in #'s 2 & 4.
4) switched leads to injectors...retried..got no fuel this time in #'s 1 
   & 3, got fuel in #'s 2 & 4...same level.....OKAY, injectors are good, 
   but I'm not getting a signal from two of the four injector 
   leads....CALL Automobile Atlanta's tech line....says trigger points 
   bad or bad connection.
5)  pulled distributor and ECU, checked continuity between trigger points 
    connector and ECU pins....all good..checked continuity between ECU 
    pins and injector leads.. all good.. found previous mechanic had 
    switched #'s 1 & 2 so it explained the side-to-side rather than 
    diagonal firing (fuel) order....no problem to fix (tan booted leads 
    go to rear, black to front).
6)  trigger points..good continuity for 180 degrees of distributor 
    rotation on both sides (A & B)..examined points..no obvious pitting 
    or carbon, cam follower looked ok.

What Gives?....either my ECU has died on only one of the two channels... 
or there is something I am missing about what makes up a "good" set of 
trigger points.  One fellow I talked to says the voltage across trigger
points is very low and they need to be clean.  The missing when cold, 
then (somewhat) smooth running after temp is reached may be due to the 
resistance of any GUNGE on the contacts lowering.  I haven't had a chance 
to go back and actually measure the resistance across each set. Does any
one know what it too much?  I did use common grease on the cam about 600 
miles ago and it was sort of messy in the trigger point area..does this
need to be PRISTINE?  Any suggestions?  Any other way to check the ECU
out of the car?

thanks

brian mifsud 408 285-9920   mifsud_brian@tandem.com



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 12:47:13 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Best material to learn 911 engine repair

> I am willing to
> spend a little money (of which I have little) for the best source
> of information and technical detailed literature on the repair of
> these engines.  

> Are the shop manuals what I am
> looking for?  Do they give detailed instructions? Do What can 
> someone recommend?  

Yes! Well, after a fashion anyway...

The shop manuals are fabulously detailed, have all the spec and call
out all the approved proceedures and such but they make significant
assumptions about your skill level as a mechanic. If you find that
they are NOT what you need, your best bet is to buddy up with someone
in your PCA region and seek mentoring.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 20 Jul 1995 14:19:54 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- smoking sc

Barry writes:


My 1981 911SC began to smoke ALOT last night on the way home.
Not from the exhaust pipe, but from oil leaking somewhere from
the front of the engine onto the muffler / heat exchanger.  Near
the front oil cooler on the engine.  It looked like my car was 
on fire.  The OEL light on the dash came on too. 

*******************************************

Most likely you have a bad oil light sender.  It's located forward 
for the FI ducting.

The part is about $10.

The hard part is getting to it.

Here's what you do:

1) Lower the engine.

2) May need to remove the throttle body to lifting plate ducting.

3) Clean the area around the old sender (brake cleaner is good).

4) Replace sender.

5) Put everything back together.


How to lower engine:

1) Support engine with floor jack.

2) Disconnect the hard oil line (not the one from the oil tank) on the
   right side of the car.  You need something like a 30 or 32 mm wrench
   and a 36 mm wrench.  Some oil will leak, a few ounces.

3) Disconnect the oxy sensor (don't forget this!)

4) Remove the a/c compresser - do not remove any gas fittings, just the 
   3 bolts that mount it to the bracket.  Tie this out of the way near
   the center of the engine compartment.

Note:  I think this is all that you have to remove but watch when you 
       actually lower the engine.  Look for anything getting pulled.

5) Loosen (a few turns) the transmission mounts.  These are forward of 
   the transmission and look just like the engine mounts.

6) Remove the engine mounts at the rear of the engine compartment.

7) Lower the engine with the floor jack until you have enought room
   to get your head past the FI ducting.


I've heard that this sender may be removed w/o lowering the engine.  I 
wouldn't do it because the area is *dirty* and you are going to get 
crud into the oil.

Lowering the engine like this is fairly easy - I've done it lots of times...

Oh, items (5) and (6) I'm refering to the large bolt in the center, not the 
two small ones on the side.


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 16:57:27 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: 944 wheel-locks DO affect balance

Well, I took the car up to 120 km/h (75 mph) on the same roads on which
the steering was shaking before. The steering wheel was rock-solid; the 
shaking was gone! The wheel weight, valve stem, and wheel-lock are
now equidistant, forming a triangle. I guess this makes sense since some
have indicated that the 944 suspension is very sensitive to slight imbalances.

So, next time you remove a balanced wheel, note the position of the lock-nut.

>In trying to determine whether wheel-locks can affect balance, I
>weighed the factory nuts on my 944 phone-dials:
>
>Regular lug nut : ~20 g
>
>Hollow lug nut:         ~25 g
>Lock + Plastic Cap: ~25 g
>
>The locking nut weighs more than double a regular nut. The balance
>weight stuck on the wheel is only 21 g. It so happened that the lock nut
>was on the stud closest the valve stem. Maybe this had an additive affect?
>But then again, maybe this is insignificant as the lugs are so close to the
>wheel centre. Anyways, I moved the lock-nut opposite the valve stem.
>We shall see tomorrow...
>
>Ken '86 944
>


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1577                         Sat Jul 22 02:00:15 CDT 1995

Subject: 944 - free-play at front suspension


Is it normal to have a bit of play when you push/pull
inwards/outwards at the top of the front wheels?
I checked, and the play is not coming from wheel-bearings.

The car is tracking fine, with no imbalance at high speeds.
However, the 'looseness' of the front end (or what I perceive
as coming from the suspension) is most apparent when 
braking towards a stop light, facing down a hill with the road
slightly bumpy. I also SOMETIMES 'feel' it when making right
turns on a bumpy road or turning onto a hill, but not always.

Could the play be coming from the shock mount at the top 
or the shock strut? If so, can anything be tightened up?

The car has 86K km (54K mi).

Ken '86 944

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 17:19:03 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: Indexing spark plugs for 944


I've read that slight performance improvements can be
had by indexing, or orienting the spark plugs at the correct
angle within the cylinder. This positioning is achieved by
inserting spark-plug washers of different thicknesses until
the open spark gap points the right way.

1. What is the best metal to use for the washers, taking into
   consideration factors such as thermal expansion, corrosion
   caused by dissimilar metals etc. ?

2. If I'm standing in front of my 944, looking at the engine,
    which direction should the open gap of the plug face? Left?
   Right? Towards me? Away from me?

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 20:43:56 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: Peeling Out


>>If you are at the stop line, leave it in gear and keep an eye on the
>>rear-view - be ready to peel out when the next clown comes blazing 
>>through.
>    This is DANGEROUSLY BAD advice.  Remember, you're stopped for a
>    reason; presumably there's cross traffic that you're choosing to
>    ignore in favor of staring intently at your rear-view mirror...
>    When you "peel out" into this traffic, you're likely to die.

John never said to peel out in a straight line.  Pulling onto the 
shoulder or taking an unplanned right turn are both acceptable
alternatives to being rear ended.  I always leave enough room between
my car and the car in front of me so that I can get out of the way
if someone behind me isn't going to stop.  A year ago just outside
of town a semi lost his brakes and slammed into the rear of another
semi.  Unfortunately, there were two cars and a van between the two.
Luckily, everyone lived.  Everyone of them stated that they had been
completely suprised.  Any of them following my (or Johns) advice 
would have been spared.

>    One more:  Constantly holding the clutch is tiring.  After a while,
>    you'll probably let up on it a little, thereby wearing it out at a
>    tremendously-accelerated pace.  Expensive and pointless.

Sounds like you need to get yourself to a gym and get in shape.
Either that or you've got a mechanical problem with your clutch.
Clutches shouldn't be that hard to hold in.  

Ross Stites

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 20:55:41 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: 944 - free-play at front suspension

Ken,

>Is it normal to have a bit of play when you push/pull
>inwards/outwards at the top of the front wheels?
>I checked, and the play is not coming from wheel-bearings.

No this is not normal.  Check the ball joint.  It's probably
easiest to have a friend move the front wheel while you watch
the joint.  If it is this, get ready to dig deep since you 
have to replace the entire control arm.  The ball joint is
not replaceable.

>Could the play be coming from the shock mount at the top 
>or the shock strut? If so, can anything be tightened up?

This is a posibility that Kevin Gross mentioned to me when
I was noticing the same symtoms that you describe above. 
Since I had the bad ball joint I'm not sure how to fix a
loose strut.

>The car has 86K km (54K mi).

You may want to check at your local dealership.  You may be able
to get them to replace the control arm for free (you pay labor) 
if that is the problem.  The local dealership here tried to get 
this done for me, but PCNA wouldn't cover it since I had 75K miles.
I do know that a couple of years ago they covered several cars with
~50K miles.

Let me know what you find out.

Ross Stites
'87 951

Date: 20 Jul 1995 14:26:21 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- stupidity

Joe writes:

 -snip-

I don't believe that I was following particularly closely.  There was a
good 4-5 car lengths between us but certainly not enough to react to still
life tire corpses.  Thanks for letting me vent.

***********************************

Joe, 

Sorry about your car.

Proper following distance is 2 seconds.

A 15 foot long car at 65 mph needs 12-13 car lengths, not 4-5.

Proper distance is not always possible to maintain, but it's 
dictated by the physics, not what is generally done.


- --Soren

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 22:52:13 -0400
From: Paterekpf@aol.com
Subject: Re: #1(2) Porschephiles #1575...

In reference to early 356 silver Porsches, the dull appearance was due to the
use of nitrocellulose lacquer.  it would dull down in a matter of months to a
gray surface. Porsche started using 2 stage clear coat begining in 1969.  It
was NOT brillo that made it look like that!  A current perfect match from
original paint on a 904 is 1992 crystal silver from Audi which can be
purchased from any Porsche, Audi, VW dealer.
John Paterek PCA Tech Com. Paint, Upholstery
Paterekpf@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 95 23:09:49 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Peeling Out

> >    One more:  Constantly holding the clutch is tiring.  After a while,
> >    you'll probably let up on it a little, thereby wearing it out at a
> >    tremendously-accelerated pace.  Expensive and pointless.
> Sounds like you need to get yourself to a gym and get in shape.
> Either that or you've got a mechanical problem with your clutch.
> Clutches shouldn't be that hard to hold in.  

I'll agree with the first point here in part, and wonder if
a clutch cable or hydraulics, throwout bearing, and so on might
not be taking more of a beating as a result. But I'll also agree
with the second - my Bug has a Gene Berg 1400lb clutch pressure plate
on it, and the time it stuck in 1st gear 35 miles from home, I
had the opportunity to operate the clutch many times on the way home.
Although I did experience some muscle fatigue in the lower left
leg, it was nothing compared to the discomfort when the cops
pulled me over for "excessive noise" 8 miles from home - which
was a perfectly fair assessment since I was doing 5000rpm at
24-25mph max. Basically I hauled it up to speed, stepped on the
clutch and coasted down while idling, repeat as needed. But I
was only going about 12 miles an hour through the area that he
pulled me over, and it wasn't too loud really if you didn't
count the headers, but once I explained my transmission problem
he just looked perplexed and waved me on.

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 22:57:04 -0800 (PDT)
From: dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com (William Dunham)
Subject: 911 electrical questions



I'm in the process of going over the electrical system on my newly purchased
69E and I have a couple of questions.  The car doesn't match the picture
showing all of the engine control electricals on page 206 of the haynes manual,
but if I understood what they all do I should be able to figure it out.  I'm
trying to figure out if any of the systems have been modified from the 
original state.

1. The Haynes schematics show a wire going from something called a
"switching SCR" to a light on the bottom of the tach.  Near as I can
tell the only lights on the tack are the signal lights at the top, and 
the high-beam indicator at the bottom.  What does the SCR do, and what is the
function of the wire from that unit to the dash area?

2. The haynes manual refers to the "ignition trigger unit (CDS)" and a
"CDS oscillator" on separate pages.  Are these the same thing and what
do they do?

3. On the car, the regulator seems to be a two-stage deal, with the wiring
from the generator going to a small unit which is wired to a larger unit
that looks like the one shown in the haynes manual.  The manual only shows a
single regulator unit.  Does this sound like the original setup for a 69E?
What is the purpose of the smaller unit?

Bill
69 911E targa
72 911T (with a brand new clutch cable)

PS. thanks to those who replied to my clutch cable questions, it turned
out to be a much easier job than I had anticipated for once :=)

- -- 
William J. Dunham
Silicon Graphics
dunham@esd.sgi.com
(415)390-2129

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 03:14:36 -0700
From: derek@best.com (Derek Au)
Subject: factory car covers

Have a question for those who are familar with the porsche factory/dealer 
car cover:
Does anyone know who manufactures these car covers, and if so, if they make 
car covers out of the *same material* for non P-cars!?  I love this 
material.  I use the factory/dealer car cover for my 356 and both 911s. 
Would be so lucky if I could get covers for my '57 VW Beetle and '64 VW 
Transporter made with the same material. TIA.

Anyone thinking of getting a car cover should read this: (my 2 cents on car 
covers)
The factory car is excellent, the best I've seen.  And it does'nt cost 
*that* much more than aftermarket covers.  It is made of some kind of woven 
nylon fiber, a light gray in color and is coated with bright silver on the 
top.  The material is something similar to material commonly used to make 
sports bags, but seems to smoother and finer.  Its extremely tear resistant, 
lightweight and its *almost* completely waterproof.  Every time it rains, 
there are pools of water on the car supported by the car cover material!  
The silver coating helps to reduce heat by reflecting it away.  Best of all, 
it says "Porsche" in red and has the logo printed on the front.  Its made 
for the car, and it *fits*.  One negative, the cover is so light that it 
gets blown around in a light wind and can be a pain to put on and remove 
with only one person.

Derek Au
derek@best.com

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 09:07:24 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Early 911:light and mystery lever questions

>        2) Next to the heater lever, on the other side of the
>             parking brake, there is a short lever (about half as long
>             as the heat lever) with a round, black knob.  I can pull
>             it, but nothing seems to change.  What does this do?  The
>             owners manual says nothing about it.  I don't have air
>             conditioning or aux. heat, if that has anything to do
>             with it.

This is the "ejection" seat activation lever :>).  Actually it is the 
"hand throttle".  By pulling it up, you can cause the car to fast idle,
etc.  Basically it is connected to the throttle and is used during
starting.

Mike 
"76 Euro 911 

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 09:03:50 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: How Low Can You Go?

>What constitutes "lugging" a 911 engine?  How many revs is too few?  Can
>I tool around town at 2000 in 3rd, can I try to accelerate from 2200 in
>5th, just how slow can I go in first?

I found some "Minimum Upshifting Points" listed in a '79 SC Owner's
Manual:

1st - 2nd :  2500rpm
2nd - 3rd :  2400rpm
3rd - 4th :  2700rpm
4th - 5th :  2600rpm

I didn't find this same chart in my Owner's Manual (for a 2.7 liter),
but would expect the numbers to be similar.  What I did was took
the highest one (2700rpm) and think of it as the "minimum" for 
shifting - instead of trying to remember different rpms for each
gear.

In practice, I actually shift in the 3500-4000 range, FWIW.

BTW, if anyone needs an Owner's Manual for a '79 SC, have I got a
deal for you...

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 09:07:17 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 STALLS WHEN OIL CKed

On 21 Jul 1995, Elliot Entin wrote:
> I have an '83 911 SC.  When I remove the oil cap to check the oil (engine
> running) the engine begins to idle rough and after a short while stalls.
 This
> has occurred a majority of times I have checked the oil.  Sometime I'm
quick

This kinda indicates that you are getting some "false air" in the CIS system.
I know this sounds strange, but I read once in a Toyota factory service
manual that rough idling could result if the seal on the dipstick wasn't
sealing properly.  Now, I haven't exactly figured out "false air" could be
getting into the intake system from the oil tank filler neck, but I thought
I would throw this in.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 09:38:49 -0400 (EDT)

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 09:42:34 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 3.0 vs3.2

> What perfornance could be exspected from a 2.7 914/6 or a 3.0 914/6 both
> fuel injected?

Ah.... Another "how high is UP" question....

Bone-stock low-end US spec 2.7 with CIS will make 150HP, 3.0 will make 185 HP.

High-end "prepared" engines can make a whole pile more -- more than double
that. How much money do you have?

As to what that "feels" like, the stock 2.0 914 weighs a bit over 2000 lbs
and makes a bit under 100 HP. Add 50% to the power and maybe 10% to the
weight with a low end engine. Add what, 300% power and 10% weight for the
high end.

Note that extreme engines are NOT advised for the street. Further note that
to work on the CIS in a 914 you will have to carve "access panels" in the
rear trunk and in the firewall between the passenger compartment and the
engine compartment.

Finally, when you add that much power to the already marginal brakes and
stock suspension of the 914, you're not asking for trouble, you're
outright DEMANDING it... You really need to add some form of crash protection,
possibly some chassis stiffening, better brakes, etc *FIRST*.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 11:12:46 -0400
From: ChannellR@aol.com
Subject: Re: How Low Can You Go?

Dirk said:
>What constitutes "lugging" a 911 engine?  How many revs is too few?  Can
>I tool around town at 2000 in 3rd, can I try to accelerate from 2200 in
>5th, just how slow can I go in first?

>I asked my mechanic what was lugging, and he said "anything below 3000."
>This seems excessive, but what do I know?.

IMHO (my opinion is almost always humble) the lowest RPM you should use will
vary with the load put on the engine. I think 2000 or 2200 RPM is OK for
tooling around town in 3rd or accelerating slowly in 5th (not pressing the
"go" peddle very hard). If you find yourself pressing the throttle down more
and more( vague terms here, I know), you are lugging the engine and should
downshift. You may be able to maintain the same acceleration rate in a lower
gear with less throttle.

If you are trying to accelerate hard, somewhere near 4000 rpm may be closer
to where your minimum rpm needs to be. This is where my car seems to
accelerate best. Not sure about a 2.7.

As an aside, my mom used to drive me crazy. She would be in 5th gear(Honda
Civic) by the time we reached 20 mph and would almost floor it trying to
accelerate. This is an example of what I think is not good for the car
(either Honda or Porsche).

Does this make sense or am I having delusions again?

FWIW
Rob Channell
channellr@aol.com
1979 911SC euro s/r coupe(with a mod or two)

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 12:10:03 -0400
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: Re: How Low Can You Go?

Howdy.

> What constitutes "lugging" a 911 engine?  How many revs is too few?  Can
> I tool around town at 2000 in 3rd, can I try to accelerate from 2200 in
> 5th, just how slow can I go in first?

Yer Kindly ol' Unka Bart jumps in to note that this is a classic RTFM case, 
which points out how important it is to obtain a Owner's Manual for your year 
and model if at all possible.  No offense intended, but this is covered in your
owner's manual.  I don't know about your '75 911S, dirk, but my manual ('86 
Carrera) says 1500 rpm, and I use 2000 (except for first, in heavy traffic)
as my lower limit.

A similar RTFM issue is Oil Temperature/RPM.  The manual will warn you not to 
exceed a certain rpm until the oil temp reaches the operating range.  Mine says 
NTE 4500 rpm, a knowledgeable friend said NTE 3000 rpm, so I use that.  
I'm told that this Oil Temp/RPM bit will often result in a blown head-gasket if 
the manual is not followed, and I believe that other things can be blown by 
forcing cold, thick oil through the cooling system at high rpm.


Cheers

(yer Kindly ol' Unka) Bart

Frau Dora, 
(fond memory of a couple of little feline varmints in my heart)
'86 Indischrot Carrera Cabriolet, 
'87 Alpenweis Syncro.
Custodian, Porschephiles Phund

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 13:32:38 -0400 (EDT)
From: blained <blained@nando.net>
Subject: Re: 79 911SC CD ignition box



On Fri, 21 Jul 1995 MLBDayton@aol.com wrote:
> My '76 911 exhibits an embarassing trait in that the engine will cut-
> out sometimes when I make a left turn.  The CD box is one item on the
> list of things to check in the "process of elimination". :>(

I thought mine was doing the same, but found it to be overheating.  
However, at one time I did have trouble with it cutting out at track 
events during hard cornering.  After the wiring harness burned one day, 
it was diagnosed as having been worn through where it passes from the 
engine compartment to the rest of the car (don't remember exact 
details).  Check this before you have the same problem.  They said it 
might have been bottomed out at some point or something.  I had to fight 
both the insurance company and the sorry losers at the garage to replace 
the entire harness instead of splicing it back together.  You might also 
check the wiring by your CD unit.  Sometimes the grommets that hold it to 
the firewall age and break, and then it has a tendency to move about a 
bit during cornering, acceleration etc.  This might aggravate any loose 
connections.

Blaine "every (both) Porsche I've owned has had some sort of fire, I'm 
loathe to buy any more, just keeping the one I've got" DeLancey
aka Blaine "'69 912 K&N Filters make a nice flame out the rear grille 
when they light up" DeLancey

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 14:31:14 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Electric mirror and wheel alignment question

I am just in the process of debugging my electric mirrors on my 911. I bought 
the entire set up from Porsche, installed it and everything works except the 
"up and down" control on the driver side mirror (Passenger side is just 
fine....
Basically if you move the switch for the mirror, no matter what direction you 
move it the mirror only moves left and right. I checked the wiring, there 
appears to be a magnetic clutch which probably changes the adjusting motor 
from "Left right" to "up down". I have checked to see if there is current in 
the wire (a white one according to the factory manual) to the clutch, and it 
appears ( or at least my ammeter thinks) that there is power to the clutch 
when the "up down" control is enabled. I am suspicious the mirror motor/clutch 
assembly is faulty .... any ideas on how to repair it or is replacement the 
only option?

Secondly, has anyone ever aligned their 911 themselves (as opposed to going to 
an alignment shop?? I basically don't trust most alignment places and was 
wondering if there was another way to get a good front and rear 
alignment......

Thanks

Dennis Kalma

'75 911S with Kremer 3.2, wonky DS mirror and misalignment

Subject: How hot can it get without blowing up!!

I finally got another crack at the track. This time a tight, 
twisty very technical course at Shannonville (about two hours 
outside of Toronto). After about 15 minutes of spirited 
"pacing", my engine temp.would start nearing 250F, and I would 
reluctantly take a break from the fun. I drive a '71 911T with 
a 2.2 litre engine. The owner's manual says it shouldn't be 
driven past 265F.

I plan to eventually install an oiler cooler, but over the 
winter project season, in the meantime my question to those 
wiser than I is whether I can safely run in the 250F range for 
the rest of the summer. I've been using Castrol Syntec 5W50. I 
don't know if this should make a significant difference one way 
or the other as to protecting my engine from harm. Also my 911 
temp is usually in the 180 to 210 range under normal use.

On a somewhat related subject, I have an opportunity to buy a 
2.2 Litre "S" motor. Assuming leak downs check out, is $3,000 a 
reasonable price? And that's Canadian bucks.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 95 10:06:54 PDT
From: dupree@alldata.com (Jim Dupree)
Subject: RE: Loctite 271? fuel system threadlocker (mwc)

Matt,

 You should NEVER use any loctite on any fuel system fitting. All the fittings seal themselves (ie. flarenut fittings) or they use seal rings of copper or aluminum. I have been working with Bosch fuel systems for alot of years and the most common problem is contamination. To use a sealant on fittings is just asking for trouble. If you have a fitting that leaks there is some other problem and it should be inspected very closely to determine the problem.
I would suggest you carefully clean all the junk off and put it all back with clean fittings and NEW seal rings.

Jim Dupree
"71" 914/4
dupree@alldata.com
Database Development, Alldata Corp. (full time)
Autosport Technology (part time)
Autocrosser (some time)

Porschephiles #1579                         Sun Jul 23 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 16:17:16 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Satyan K. Shah" <skshah@mailbox.syr.edu>
Subject: 944 pasenger side floor wet


My fellow porschephiles,

  I have noticed some unusual with my 944. A few months ago, when I went 
to clean the carpeting on the floor of the passenger side, I noticed that 
the carpet was wet, and that it was not just a small spot, but almost 75% 
of the passenger side floor. I figured it was be wet shoes & the rain, 
and brushed it off.

  Now, months later (it hasn't rained in Upstate NY for a while), I 
notice again, that almost the entire passenger floor is wet. I am now 
VERY CONCERNED. I hope that it has something to do with my A/C, or maybe 
it happens from washing the car? Don't know, but please help if you have 
had a similar problem or know what it might be. Thank you.

 Satyan K. Shah

- ------------------------------------------------------------------
Satyan K. Shah  	E-mail: skshah@mailbox.syr.edu

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 00:47:22 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944 pasenger side floor wet

Satyan,

This is usually caused by a problem with the drain from the sunroof area.
There are four hoses from around the recess in which the sunroof sits.  Two
runs down the front A-pillars.  Pull the A-pillar trim and make sure the
hoses are whole and properly hooked up.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 00:47:18 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 924 Cooling problems.

Ashley,

This is usually the sign of a thermostat which has ceased to open at
the right temperature, and so not allowing coolant to circulate through
the radiator.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 01:04:11 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944 - free-play at front suspension

At 05:10 PM 7/21/95 -0700, kkan@Direct.CA wrote:
>
>Is it normal to have a bit of play when you push/pull
>inwards/outwards at the top of the front wheels?
>I checked, and the play is not coming from wheel-bearings.

Ken,

As your shocks get old, it is common for them to develop play between the
piston and the shock body (the rest of the strut).  If you pull the wheel
off, then put one hand at the piston/shock interface and use the other
to push and pull on the top of the brake rotor, you can feel the play.

This may be what you have.  It's not fatal, but it is something you should
get taken care of sooner or later.  If you autocross or track the car, this
looseness might be more noticable because of the camber changes it
induces.

Kevin
