Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 01:04:15 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: C2/C4 distributor repair

There was some discussion recently about belt failures within the dual
distributors.  The only solution available to someone with a broken belt
until now has been to replace the distributor, expensive.

The good news is that the needed belt, along with the upgrade vent kit, have
just become available.  With it, your original distributor can be repaired,
and hopefully with the vent kit installed the belt failure won't recur.

Please drop me a line if interested.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 01:04:08 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Untightened swaybars

At 02:27 PM 7/21/95 -0400, David I Johnson wrote:
>I've read and been to workshops where autocrossers and road racers back off the
>attachment bolts(at the link not the frame) on the front or rear bars for
>specific handling characteristics. What is the thinking on this and how well
>does it work?

Dave,

You change the spring rate of a sway bar by changing the length of its lever
arm.  Longer arm length means softer spring, which means better stick at the
front and so more oversteer or less understeer.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 21 Jul 1995 20:39:02 -0400
From: asdunn@nytimes.com (Ashley Dunn)
Subject: Re: Early 911:light and mystery lever questions

1) Instrument lights. The instrument gauges are held in the dash by a large
rubber ring. By using a soft instrument or wrapping a screwdriver in tape,
you carefully pry the gauge out of the dash. At the back of the gauge are
some light bulb holders that are pressed into the back of the gauge. They
look like little .22 shell casings. You just pull those out and insert a new
bulb.

2) black lever - that's your hand throttle. You lift up on it and it will
hold the throttle up. It's kind of a crude cruise control. I never use it
except when I start my car in the morning. I use it as a kind of choke. Have
no idea if that is what it was designed for.



>          I've only had my 69 911T for a few months, so I'm still
>          exploring it.  So far I have 2 unsolved questions:
>
>          1) How do you replace the instrument lights?  I've torn the
>             trunk apart to get to the speedo, I've even taken it out.
>             But I still don't see how to get the lightbulb out of the
>             gauge.  What's the trick?  I don't want to break it
>             quite yet.
>
>          2) Next to the heater lever, on the other side of the
>             parking brake, there is a short lever (about half as long
>             as the heat lever) with a round, black knob.  I can pull
>             it, but nothing seems to change.  What does this do?  The
>             owners manual says nothing about it.  I don't have air
>             conditioning or aux. heat, if that has anything to do
>             with it.
>
>          Does anyone have any ideas?  TIA
>
>          Chris Voigt
>          1969 911T, 59kmi

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 23:31:58 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 3.0 vs 3.2

Andrew George <ageorge@freenet.columbus.oh.us> asked:

>What perfornance could be exspected from a 2.7 914/6 or a 3.0 914/6 
>both fuel injected?

Andrew:

The 2.7 in my 914 makes about 260 HP, but it's built to something 
slightly above Euro Carrera RS specs, with Weber carbs.  

Slightly-modified (i.e., cheaper) 2.7s can easily make around 210-240 
HP, which is plenty in a 2100-pound car.

As regards fuel-injection, though... The 914 engine compartment is 
pretty small, which makes it really hard to fit the 
mechanical-injection stuff in there.  If, as your e-mail address 
implies, you live in Ohio, you may be able to put Webers on the car and 
stay emissions-legal.

Carbs are a bit of a pain, especially if you live somewhere with strong 
seasonal weather changes (like, umm, Ohio), but there are a whole bunch 
of people who understand them real well.  Mostly because SCCA 
[mean-spirited expansion of this acronym deleted] won't allow 
fuel-injection on 914-6s.

By the way, there's more to the conversion than simply dropping a 200+ 
horsepower motor into your 914... For safety's sake alone, you really 
should upgrade the brakes, stiffen the chassis, and add a roll cage.  
Once that's done, you'll probably want to beef up the suspension and 
regear the tranny.

For reliability, you should update the chain tensioners to the 
Carrera-style pressure-fed versions and add a big front-mounted oil 
cooler.  If you decide to use a 2.7, make sure that all 24 head studs 
are Dilivar, and that the holes they're in are Time-Serted.

Since you're going to be spending AT LEAST $15K on this conversion, you 
probably don't want to just throw an old, tired motor into your car, so 
when yuo rebuild it, have your engine-builder do the oil-bypass mods, 
add piston squirters, mod the middle air-deflectors, boattail the 
crank, etc.  Adding a 930 oil pump would be helpful, too.

It's a big job... Good luck.

 -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 03:31:14 +0200
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: My 'new' 911, & Sportomatic questions!

Howdy all,

Picked up my '65 911 wedensday, bought from SF(through a fellow p'filer.)

The car started immediately I started cranking it and it was a great
pleasure to actually drive a car out through the harbour gates. (356's and
trailers have been the story so far..... :)

No problems encountered, and the 125 miles trip home went like that.....

I'm getting used to the Sportomatic now, but I would prefer changing to a
901. In the mean time I wonder;

Does the Sportomatic need ATF? In that case where? I would not suspect the
gearbox to live on other stuff than 80/90W something, but is there a closed
'circuit' for the converter somewhere??

Is there any god informative reports or technichal specifications for the
Sportomatics available? I hate being in doubt!!

How's the car???
****************
For being a '65 the car is *very* dry, but I noticed the need for new
'pick-up-points' for the front suspension. This is of course the typical
front suspension pan rust. It is perhaps the most available rust repair
panel for the 911's and I plan changing it for the winter. I used the better
part of thursday bumping out 'repro patches' and it is actually not
difficult as long as you have the tools. Later I cut the worst pieces off,
and welded in the patches. Really flush fit. It is almost impossible to
spot, and the technician that checked out the car at the 'DMV' didn't really
notice it.

I started to rip out the front hood seal and found some rust just above the
line where the fender bolts to the chassi. This was impossible to guess as
the wheelhouse did not show any signs, neither the seals, they just were
crackled and dry. Guess the seals was the reason to this too.
 
These fenders are expensive and hard to find, and since they are rust free
apart from these areas I plan to remove them this winter and cut the rusted
area and weld in fresh steel. The visible parts of the fender are otherwise
perfect! The patch will be butt welded and will only be to the mounting flange.

Anyone seen or done this before??

Rust proofing.
**************
I'm planning to rustproof the car by drilling holes in all hollow sections
and fill it up with oil (vegetable 'lin-oil'). Anyone have an idea where
these hollow section mainly are located??

I'm going to do;
The front 'channels' as running on the outer sides of the chassi, the heater
channels on the side of the pan, the 'chanels' running from the rear of the
pan up to the shock towers and rearwards.

Are there any other hollow sections that could need rust proofing??

I'm rather happy with the car, preparing it for another 30 years of life
with rust proofing and new seals. Hopefully there will be a 901 installed
soon, and I just can't wait for the Porsche club to hire the Rudskogen track
for a weekend of testing and fast driving!

Race car search.
*****************
In the mean time my search for a '65 911/912 for vintage racing goes
on,...if you happen to know of such a car, in a state that is 'appropriate'
for a serious race car I'd be interested.

...off for a week in the Mountains,(.Porsche roads :-)

cheers,
Trond V.

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 11:40:55 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: My 'new' 911, & Sportomatic questions!

Trond,

You said:

>Does the Sportomatic need ATF? In that case where? I would not suspect the
>gearbox to live on other stuff than 80/90W something, but is there a >closed
'circuit' for the converter somewhere??

The Sporto uses stadard manual trans fluid for the main housing. The torque
converter gets its oil supply from the engine.  It is supplied by an extra
set of oil lines from the oil tank thru a pump that is driven off of the
drivers side camshaft, and thru concentric oil seals in the bell housing.

>Is there any good informative reports or technichal specifications for the
>Sportomatics available? I hate being in doubt!!

Only comprehensive supply of Sporto data I know about is in the factory
manuals.  They give a good description of how it works, how to adjust it,
etc.  If nothing else, spring for the microfiche  shop manuals  and Part
Manuals for your 911 year. I'd call Stoddards here in the US and have them
ship them to you.  I THINK they are less than $20.  The pictures don't do too
well from what I understand, but you should be able to get by. The parts
manual will be INDEPENSIBLE!

Converting from a Sporto to a manual gearbox is rewarding.  I did it on a 71
911T we used to own. Not hard to do, but requires a LOT of parts.

I'm confused about a '65 911 having a Sporto.  According to Excellence was
expected, the Sporto did not come out until  model year'68. Was your car
retrofitted with the Sporto, or was it a prototype or what?

Jon Lowe
jonlowe@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 11:40:51 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Fuel Cell / Fire System

Andy,

You said:
>Does anyone know of a supplier of fuel cells that fit in the stock 914 
>gas-tank location (or, better, inside the existing tank)?  I'm finally 
>gonna get one (I've been in three car fires, and I didn't like any of 
>them), but I don't really want to lose my front trunk.  One MUST draw 
>the line somewhere, after all.

Fuel Safe will make custom bladders for just about any OEM tank, for a price.
 Each application is different, so give them a call for a catalog and more
information. I know of no one that makes a replacement tank that will go in
the standard location for a 914, but they can modify your OEM tank.  I saw
one they did for a 550 at Brumos Porsche.  Couldn't even tell from the
outside.  Open up the gas cap and inside was another cap for the bladder!

Fuel Safe
18062 Redondo Circle
Huntington Beach, CA 92648
800-433-6524
714-862-6622 FAX
714-842-2211 Voice

Jon Lowe
jonlowe@aol.com

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 95 12:10:33 EDT
From: Gregg Kricorissian <grkricor@ccs.carleton.ca>
Subject: Alternator light

Bill Dunham's recent post made me think of a peculiar electrical problem
that I have been ignoring on my 1977 911S since I bought it in 1989.  It has
to do with the alternator warning light and the EGR light.  Goes like this:

1.  The alternator light glows normally when the ignition is turned on, but
remains dimmly lighted after the engine is running.  The EGR light is also
on (though the car no longer has its EGR 'goodies').  Intensity of the
warning lights do not seem to change as the engine is revved.

2.  The problem used to come and go when I first got it, though the battery
has *never* gone dead.  Replaced the votage regulator with a German
aftermarket solid state unit when I bought the car: no change in the
symptoms.  You can leave the car sitting for days at a time without battery
discharge, so I don't suspect the alternator diodes.

3.  The past few years, the lights have remained lighted, and I've learned
to ignore it.  The battery never goes dead (now making a statement like that
is tempting fate, isn't it?), and it doesn't boil over.  However "something
is broken, and I wnat to fix it".  (How's that for a switch on an old saying?)

I'm an EE, but the problem is that none of my manuals seem to have a wiring
schematic that shows the EGR light circuitry, and so it's kind of tough to
track down the problem. The only clue I've found is that the system voltage
at the back end of the car is a bit higher than I'd expect, but I put that
down to voltage drop along the regulator's sense lines to the battery at the
front of the car.   

I'm hoping that this is a common problem, that combined experience and
net-knowledge can help me sort out.

Many thanks,
...Gregg

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 11:52:07 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Fuel Cell / Fire System

> >Does anyone know of a supplier of fuel cells that fit in the stock 914 
> >gas-tank location (or, better, inside the existing tank)?  
> 
> Fuel Safe will make custom bladders for just about any OEM tank...

Jon is right on track here... This is the only way you can get a 
good setup. Note however that you'll have some re-plumbing to do --
the fuel return lines will need to run up to the top of the cell
instead of just into the bottom of the tank.

I've *seen* one that that they did for a 914, but neglected to get a price.
I'd imagine that it's between $500 and $1000, though.

Stan

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 16:50:45 -0400 (EDT)
From: Rick Shimkets <quartz@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: Teaching other drivers a "lesson"

Howdy P-folks, I was wondering if I might have a group opinion on 
something.  Here in New England where people are nasty drivers I have 
seen a pattern I really dislike.  While my girlfriend was driving her 
Acura and I watched helplessly in the passenger's seat, she decided that 
the car behind her was following to closely and she intentionally hit the 
brakes hard for a second to throw him off.  I heard a screech from behond 
and, although we weren't hit, I screamed at her for the next 10 mintues 
about it.  She insisted he needed to be taught not to tailgate _her_, and 
I tried to drive into her impetuous mind how foolish it was and how the 
possible consequences are horrible.  Sure, teach him a lesson but never 
walk again.  Or worse, teach him and the child in his car a lesson.  
Anyway, she came to see it my way, that it just wasn't worth it.
	Last night on my way home from work (about 1AM, late worker) I 
was "taught a lesson."  On a highway entrance which splits from one lane 
to 4 suddenly I was following another car closely for just a couple of 
seconds until the highway would split and I would go around.  Right 
before the split the driver in front decided to slam on his brakes (from 
50mph down to about 10) before I could go around.  I've never been fond 
of my 914 brakes, but I floored them and the front wheels locked for a 
second and then released.  It was a miracle that I was able to avoid 
colliding, and was very perturbed.  He then made a finger gesture to me 
out his sunroof and proceeded to swerve back and forth across the highway 
(now 4 lanes) in front of me to keep me from passing.  Of course since he 
was in an inferior car I managed to fake one way and zip past him on the 
other side, but I thought the whole incident was ridiculous!  There seems 
to be this mindset up here in the north and it is foolish!  Has anyone 
else ever experienced this?  Am I really evil for following closely for a 
brief moment until I can get around?  Thanks for your opinions and for 
letting me vent!   Rick and Gretchin with 2 tiny wear marks

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 95 15:32:58 -0600
From: COREY_JACKSON@HP-Loveland-om10.om.hp.com
Subject: Re: Hot 924

Item Subject: Text_1
     My '85.5 944 was doing this.  I kept bleeding the cooling system, 
     checking mixture of antifreeze, etc.  It finally went away when I took 
     the temp sender out of the radiator and replaced it.  I did replace it 
     with one that drops both switches by about 5-10 degrees each.  These 
     are readily available for 924s, mine cost $12.  I figured that the 
     fans would run more often with the lower temp, but strangely they 
     don't!  The only thing I can figure is that I got a good sized air 
     pocket out of the system when I refilled and bled it.  BTW mine stays 
     just a hair below the first mark now, with brief excursions up to 
     horizontal when racing on short courses.
     
     These lower temp switches take a lot of stress off the cooling system, 
     but I wonder how much stress they put on the fans, and if you lose 
     some (small) efficiency by running at a lower water jacket temp?
     
     If you want to force the fan(s) to run at fast or slow speed all the 
     time, I could give you a diagram of which line(s) to jump on the relay 
     board.  I had wires with male quick disconnects on both ends which I'd 
     put in to get both fans running fast for autoXing.
     
     Good luck
     Corey

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 14:34:46 -0700
From: hairpin@ix.netcom.com (Dion Dunn )
Subject: 914 brake question...

P-filers,

OK small steps, small steps.  Yesterday, I finally had the car out on 
the back streets around my home.  It still needs a little more tuning 
etc. including the brakes which were OK but needed to be blead.  I have 
a rebuilt front left caliper and the rest are original.  

So this morning I set out to bleed the brakes.  All brakes went fine 
(squirting out the excess air, etc.) except for the front right.  I 
couldn't get the bleader valve off without stripping it. (I even took 
the caliper off, still no luck) So I left it as is.  The problem now 
is, I have even less brake pressure than before I blead the brakes.  I 
know I still need to fix that front right caliper, but how could almost 
no pressure be happening?  It seems the master cylinder is OK and all 
of the lines or OK.

By the way, does anyone have a front right (rebuilt or new) caliper for 
sale?

Any help is greatly appreciated!

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 18:31:26 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 DIY Alignment

>Secondly, has anyone ever aligned their 911 themselves (as opposed to going
to 
>an alignment shop?? I basically don't trust most alignment places and was 
>wondering if there was another way to get a good front and rear 
>alignment......

A guy named Ray Scruggs advertises a pamphlet in the back of Pano/
Excellence entitled "Home Alignment of the Porsche 911".  This booklet
will give the knowledge/procedures to do an alignment by yourself.  
Having purchased/used this booklet, I'd have to say that the principles
are sound, but the quality of the alignment is definitely a function
of how much time one puts into it, and the accuracy of the measurements
taken.

It does work though.  Contrary to the statements of your local alignment
shop knuckle-dragger, this isn't rocket science...(the guys at the local NTW
laughed out loud when I casually mentioned that I was planning on doing
my own alignment)...

HTH,

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 19:29:18 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 brake question...

Two choices:  
1.  Loosen the brake line where it goes into the wheel cylinder to bleed the
brake.  I just had to do this on the clutch cyl of my Vangon.

2.  Pull the cylinder and drill out and put in new bleeder valve.

If you don't like either of those, I will sell you a used one off my wrecked
73 for $35.

Ralph Ricks  73 & 76 914  etc.

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 19:18:11 -0700
From: david@west.net
Subject: Re: Teaching other drivers a "lesson"

I too have been "taught a lesson" from a driver just recently.

I was driving in the inside lane south on the 101 in the San Fernando
Valley at about 72 MPH.  This is actually somewhat slow for the 101.  A guy
in one of those ubiquitous Toyota Camry's was following closely enough that
I couldn't see his license plate.  I signaled and moved to the right to let
him by and then signaled and moved in behind him at a distance of about 4
car lengths with the intention of making more room.

What happend next can only be described as foolhardy (though I admit to
following too closely, even if for just a moment).  This man slams on his
brakes to the point of bringing up tire smoke!  I hit my brakes and moved
quickly to the right, missing his bumper by maybe a layer of paint.  He
then proceded to flip me off as most of these guys do and then took off,
weaving through the heavy traffic like a NASCAR driver.

It was fortunate that the space in the right lane that I created by moving
hadn't been closed up (as is usually the case in LA driving) or I wouldn't
have had an out and we would have had a VERY serious accident.  The brakes
on my '71T are pretty good, but not that good!

Yes, I've learned a lesson from this (though in LA ya gotta take the road
when you can), and I'm trying to allow more space before I merge back.
Still, had I been in a lesser car I can't even imagine the consequences.

What are ya gonna do!?

Regards,

Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
'71 911T Coupe
'70 Type II Panel

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 23:43:21 -0500
From: knestle@interaccess.com (Ken Nestle)
Subject: Re: Teaching other drivers a "lesson"


When I was younger and rode motercycles, my rule for survival was to
consider every car on the highway to be driven by a homocidal maniac who
was 'out get me'. In other words *EXTREME CAUTION*.

Unfortunately, it seems that now *all drivers* must consider *all other
drivers* in this same manner.

I think the term 'Defensive Driving' covers it.

Don't ever, for any reason, under any circumstance, put yourself in a
position where the other guy can 'get you'.
Because, if you do, he will.

By the same token: 'Always leave the other guy an out.'
If you leave him someplace to go in a pinch, he will. If you don't, he can't.

Somebody has to have some brains out there.
And, as we all know, it sure as hell ain't the other guy.
So, unfortunately, it has to be you.

"Let's be careful out there."

Ken

'75 914 (Chevy powered)

- --
knestle@interaccess.com
          If you love something - set it free.
                    If it doesn't come back - hunt it down and kill it!

Date: Sun, 23 Jul 1995 22:31:30 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: 914 brake question...

<<snip>>
 
> So this morning I set out to bleed the brakes.  All brakes went fine 
> (squirting out the excess air, etc.) except for the front right.  I 
> couldn't get the bleader valve off without stripping it. (I even took 
> the caliper off, still no luck) So I left it as is.  The problem now 
> is, I have even less brake pressure than before I blead the brakes.  I 
> know I still need to fix that front right caliper, but how could almost 
> no pressure be happening?  It seems the master cylinder is OK and all 
> of the lines or OK.
> 

One thing I've discovered is that even the *tiniest* amount of air
in a 914's brake system will screw it up.

This is probably true for all cars, but my 914 seems more touchy
about it than any others I've worked on.

Gary.

radically different view of tailgating (whole northeast vs. rest of 
country) because many times, people 'tailgate' simply in following.

> seconds until the highway would split and I would go around.  Right 
> before the split the driver in front decided to slam on his brakes (from 
> 50mph down to about 10) before I could go around.  I've never been fond 
> of my 914 brakes, but I floored them and the front wheels locked for a

> He then made a finger gesture to me 
> out his sunroof and proceeded to swerve back and forth across the highway

> brief moment until I can get around?  Thanks for your opinions and for 
I experience it every day. The Californy Wave (see Beverly Hillbillies 
the movie, the hit, not the flop) is invoked quite often here. I find the 
best way to return their courtesy is to return the Wave, and if they've 
also blown their horn, show them up (our cars are equipped with those 
neat-o air horn units, the kind that will deafen anyone) and show them 
what a REAL horn sounds like. Of course, I'm just joining in the hate 
bash, but I've been up here long enough to realize that I wasn't going to 
make a difference by not doing anything... People in the northeast are 
amazingly rude, and in many other parts of their life. It seems that a 
good number of them have been brought up with the teaching that THEY are 
the center of the universe.
 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 08:53:52 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  I've been Keyed!! -Reply

Howie:

Sorry to hear about your bad luck!!  I hope I can help with some advice.

 I have been detailing cars on the side for about two years.  The only
proper way to remedy your damage is a repaint.  I know you don't want
to hear that, but any other way will not do justice to your original paint. 
I'm only saying this because you own a P-car and the general
concensus among the "Faithful" is to do the job right the first time.  

Now, if it was a lesser car,  you might get away with what is called
"Color Sanding".  This involves sanding (that' right, sanding) the paint
surface with either 2000 or 1500 grit sandpaper until the flaw is
corrected.  From this point, the surface is rubbed out with varying
degrees of liquid compound, going from a heavy to fine grit.  Eventually
all of the sanding marks are removed.  Actually, after sanding paint with
2000 grit sandpaper, the paint just looks really dull.  The problem with this
method is it just removes paint,  no paint is added.   So, if the key scratch
is too deep, this won't work.   Paint is only a few microns thick.   

 I would get opinions from a few good paint shops and then a few from
detail shops to get a good handle on how bad the damage is.

Hope this helps,

Eric
80 911sc
86 GTi (looking for another daily driver - 88 GTi??)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 07:48:20 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Gold Chain Affiliation or True Love?

Oh, from a few days back...

> 1.  Is there still money ($$$) and intelligent life in Houston?

Ummm. Yes. Well, at least maybe...

Houston *IS* coming back. And probably better than before. In the '80s,
it was the "Aawl Bidniss" or nothing. These days, it's just about everything
*BUT* "Big Oil". 

Intelligent life? That's harder. By my standard, it's pretty bleak as this
is still a hotbed of repressive neo-Nazi my-way-or-no-way Southern reformed
evangelical "Christian-ness" (which seems to all have strayed a bit from
the original intent...). There is a thriving alternative scene though
that is likely to bring in all manner of new talent and ideas, and even
the mainstream "cultural" scene is more progressive than most major cities
(Houston Grand Opera, for instance, routinely premiers one or two *NEW*
operas a year - no mean trick in a city where most people equate opera with
Bugs Bunny...) Still, it's not NYC or even (dare I say it?) LA... But
the good news is, it's not Topeka either.

Thing seem to be looking up -- at long last you can actually get a good
cup of coffee here! And conversation seems to be making a comeback, which
means that people are actually starting to READ! I was in a bookstore I
hadn't visited before over the weekend and was astounded to find *LITERATURE*
instead of "Men Who Lick Camshafts and the Nazi Sheep that Love Them" or
some such. Amazing.

And, there is now a 24 hour scene. You can actually get real food at 3:30 AM
if you want it, or drop off your dry cleaning, or even buy auto parts. 
Admittedly, not *PORSCHE* parts, but it's a start...

On the whole, I'd rather be here than lots of places. 

> 2.  Did the experience for these folks create a lifelong love of Porsches or
> was it merely a "castoff" for the next desirable "object d' jour".?

Who knows?? There are still a *LOT* of the "gold chain" crowd owning Porsches
because it's "the thing to do" -- it confers status, and indicates money, 
taste, and a bit of flair. Would some of these people be happier in a Lexus?
You bet. That's why they sell so many. Would they be as happy in say a 
pre-A Roadster as a C4 Cab? Probably not. Then again, isn't that true for
most of *US*?

I'm perpetually surprised by some "old fart" driving a 928 or something,
moving really cautiously and like he (typically he, anyway) has *NO* 
business in a Porsche, who pulls up next to me and comments on my 356SC and
wants to talk about the '67 911S he had or the time he went to see the
904s run at the 'ring or whatever. Blows me away, and reminds me -- yet
again -- not to judge people before I have a chance to know what's what.

Besides, look at the good news -- the poseurs who buy Porsches typically
don't run them hard, leave them with low miles and in nearly perfect
cosmetic condition, and eventually get bored and want to sell the car for
some reason. To *US*, the enthusiast market. Hopefully at a good price,
but even so where are you going to find a car that a "car guy" has owned
in that kind of shape for a good price?

Stan

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 08:05:28 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@mail.orion.org>
Subject: Re: 911 front strut OIL

Any motor oil will do as well as hydraulic or machine oil.  I don't like 
used motor oil as eventually the water from combustion processes will 
settle out on the bottom.  The idea is to conduct heat from your shock to 
the strut tube so it can be dissapated.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 09:28:21 -0500
From: Joe Browne <brownej@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  Re: teaching lessons

This thread will follow the 'comment early, comment often' theme.  I
sympathize with fellow p-filers who have difficulty with angry drivers.  I
submit the following observations;

1.  Irrational behavior ( slamming brakes, blocking,etc.) is not caused by
your Porsche, but probably is elevated or accellerated by it.  I have had
this behavior surface when driving my wife's Jetta.  
2.  People take driving too personally.  This includes me as well.  If
someone pulls up behind me and flashes lights, I typically am not angry at
the person ( more embarrased that I didn't see the car closing and
voluntarily move out of the way.  If I am going in the left lane at around
70mph (do-gooders alert!- flame me about the speed limit) and a truck
pulls out at 56mph to pass another going 55, I become a raving lunatic
and start wishing for a rocket launcher.
3.  I wont't single out vehicles, but some are more predictable based on
the types that go for that image.
4.  I am getting old and soft, because it doesn't seem worth it anymore to
ruin my life or even a complete sphincter's life because of a stretch of
asphault.  I typically give in or try and de-escalate these things now.  The
sad thing is that with just the right type of psychopath, they take that
personally as well.

repeat the experience.

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 09:18:55 -0500 (CDT)
From: Chuck Campbell <campbell@Starbase.NeoSoft.COM>
Subject: major service woes???

I just had my car in for major service (valves, plugs, etc.) and this past
weekend took my first long drive since then.

I was astounded to see that I've lost nearly 60 miles range on a tank of gas!
I had thought my around town mileage was lower too, but that is always such
a moving target with varying traffic.

I used to get 25 mpg on the highway, and now I'm at slightly under 20 :-(

What might have been done that would cause this?  The only out of the ordinary
thing I recall was the mechanic indicated the plugs I had in there were too 
high a heat range, and he replaceds them with different plugs, but no other
indication of any other service items which should have had such a major
efficiency change that I can tell.

If I wanted to try the hotter plugs again, what might that do which would 
make it a bad idea??

 -chuck

No, it's not crazy. Those honda civic engines don't live well with lugging,
although they are pretty near bullet proof most ways. 5th gear is never
indicated below 40mph, and then only downhill in no hurry.
Denise McCluggage wrote about roller crank bearings in the Porsche 1500
Speedsters which would flat-spot if the revs got below 1500rpm
with the clutch engaged...

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 09:33:30 -0600
From: "Lee C. Jacobs"  <LJacobs@Calvin.HSC.Colorado.EDU>
Subject: Re: Buying a 914

Well, I've been trying to hold my tounge ... But since I own the car in
Question and have a lot of people judging the car without knowing anything
about it, I feel it's my duty to state my side... (Please ignore unless
you responded to Charles Cox's question about buying a 914 that I 
advertised).   This is long and wordy...

I have put a few 'plugs' for my 72 914 for sale in a few threads on the
P-Philes.  In them I've only asked $3700, yet the person who asked the
question decided to show the ad (to non-P-Philes and Non-PCA people) for
$4k.  I didn't want to waste a lot of bandwidth with blatent 'buy me'
salesmanship, but since so many people are quick to speak, I feel I must.
Please forgive me for the waste of bandwith.

Recap: 1972 914, 2.0L, Original Paint, 8 wheels/tires, A/C off car,
       heater off car. All original except engine/trans.
 
 - This has a 73 2.0L and side shift (73) trans. 
  This engine was built by a Porsche mechanic (well respected).
  This engine has less than 200 miles on the rebuild (haven't even
  done my first valve adjustment yet).  Too many reasons to list
  why I'm _*considering*_ selling it, and I wouldn't want to make
  you cry. :(  Suffice it to say I lost a wife, a 951, a dog, a job,
  and a father all within two months. (not neccisarily in that order).
  I wasn't willing to buy the car with the compression the way it was,
  so got the P.O. to _completely_ rebuild engine with no change in price.
  He could get things cheap because he does lot's of business for the
  Denver/Boulder area.  I was just trying to pass on the savings to
  the next owner (If I _do_ sell it).  Clutch and other components were
  checked while dropped, and I did surprise inspections.
 - The paint is original (i.e. never been repainted, therefore, no chance
  to hide anything)...   Yup, needs repainting, but take a look at
  it (JPG's in the tta.com/Porschephiles/Images/UPLOAD as LJ914*.*)
  and I think you'll find it's not as bad as I make it sound...
  Has a lot of door dings, scratches, etc... but nothing _too_ major.
 - For P-Phile members and PCA members, I've only asked $3700.00 but I'll be
  darned if I'll let people criticize something without even seeing it
  first.  Charles Cox should have read some of the earlier threads more
  carefully before asking the question to the P-Philes (Sorry, Charles).
  But it's good to get as many views as possible.  I welcome anybody
  who cares to take a look to come on over and share a sip and a tall
  tale or two with me, maybe even take a gander at the car.
 - The P.O. has owned this car over the past 10 years before I
  have.  He's well known to the Boulder, Colo. area.  The car is well known,
  even Tom Conway (Carquip) is familiar with the car and remarked that it
  is "very solid".  He was surprised that I managed to get the P.O to rebuild
  the engine before buying.
 - I bought the car for club racing... I didn't give a care about A/C or
  heater... I bought it because it's *solid* and *no major rust*.  Your
  definition of major and mine are probably different, but the only rust
  is on the battery support bracket / tray.  Nothing on the Frame, nothing
  on the body.  Even no rust on the 'side valances' (can't think of the
  proper name right now).  Only the heater fan and the heater hoses are
  off the car.  ( I prefer as light a car as possible, but don't have the
  heart to chop up such a great looking interior - Even original radio!).
 - Yeah, it has problems... but hey.  Mr Cox came to look at it sunday, I
  let him drive it, then out of *courtesy* I took him to PCA club racing
  at second creek, so he could be 'introduced' to a few other cars.  Along
  with that, I took copies of FAQ's for him to read when he got bored.
  Jeesh, I'm real wishy-washy about selling the thing, but times are a
  little tough for me right now and I'd rather buy a pre-setup race
  car (I might be talking to Ralph Ricks once I get back on my feet!).
 - I'll let my 914 speak for itself... Since I'm probably a little
  biased on this one.
 - P.S. The rear sway bar is _not_ on the car, precisely because I'd
  much rather have one on the front *only*.

*** thanks for letting me vent ***

(anybody want to buy a 914, my price goes up tomorrow !!, and not for sale
next week !!!)  (Gee... Am I taking this too personally or *what* ??)

LJacobs@Calvin.HSC.Colorado.EDU  (Large Aspirations, Small Wallet, and a 914)

work, cams, etc.,  but I don't think the pistons were changed).  I'm 
sure that this
is not helping the consumption any though.

Is this type of consumption normal for a T , or an S for that matter?

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 11:40:49 -0400
From: "Robert S. Fourney" <knee@Glue.umd.edu>
Subject: Wanted:  Source for 356 Flywheel Shims

Hi,
	I'm looking for a source for 356 flywheel shims.  Stoddard has
them in the standard sizes (.80mm--1.1mm?) for about $21 which wouldn't
be a big problem, but I think I need a .75mm or so.  I've heard that
it can be built up from several of the old 36 HP VW shims, but don't have
a source for these either.

	The only shim I have is too thick, so I am estimating the desired
shim by torqueing down the gland nut with the "soft metal gasket" (no
oil seal) and measuring the endplay.  I'm getting an endplay of .035"
with no shim.  This means that a shim of .80 mm would have be a little
on snug side, with .75 to .78 being much better.

	Since I am using a slightly crinkled "soft metal gasket" and not
torquing to anywhere near the final torque, I feel that when I 
do tighten it all the way with a new gasket the clearance will only
decrease?  So, is there a source for "non-standard" sized shims?
A source for 36 HP VW shims?  A cheaper source for the standard
sized shims?  

	Thanks,


	Bob Fourney

(PS, I'm new here and would appreciate the magic words required to switch
to digest mode!  Thanks)

It contains great strategies for dealing wih brain-dead drivers (assume the

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 07:45:59 -0700
From: kelleyad@loop.com (Bill Kelley)
Subject: Re: 3.0 vs 3.2

Andrew George <ageorge@freenet.columbus.oh.us> asked:

>What perfornance could be exspected from a 2.7 914/6 or a 3.0 914/6
>both fuel injected?

The performance is great.

I put an injected 2.7 in my 1971 914-6, and there are only a couple of
things you really need to do.

First, you will have to relocate the engine lid release to clear the CIS.
Second you will have to change the fuel pump to the CIS pump.

The resulting car is quick, with great low and mid-range response.

If you live in a warm climate, or are an aggressive driver, you will find
that you need to increase cooling efficiency for the 2.7. Start by swapping
pulleys around on the fan and crankshaft until you have the crnak
over-driving the fan. You might want to check out the newer fans with more
blades, as well.

Consider buying a second engine lid grille and cutting out the sheetmetal
at the rear of the engine lid, doubling the grille space. It's pretty easy.
You might also want to try putting an oil cooler up front, and a
thermostatic valve in the engine compartment.

As was said earlier, upgraded brakes are a very good idea. I put 'S'
suspension and brakes on mine. And the 6 x 16" wheels that everybody seems
to just throw away work perfectly with 205-section tires on a 914, if you
roll the lip on the rear of the rear wheelwells...

Finally, for peace of mind, I installed tensioner 'collars' to prevent
total tensioner collapse.

The whole project (except the car) cost me $4-5,000. Should be less today...

Have fun!

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 12:23:29 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Metro NY AutoX, 7/22- 7/23, long

Hi Autocross Fans:

(If you are not an autocross fan, press N now, so you can get back to reading
about rude drivers, and other rec.autos like topics)

This is a short recap of the autocross held by the NY Metro PCA region.

This was a two day event. The first day was a car control clinic, with an
autocross in the afternoon. The second day was a full day autocross, where
the winners got trophy's, etc.

The car control clinic was made by laying out an autocross course, and then
splitting it up into four sections. The drivers would then work on one
section for about 1/2 an hour, and then move on to the next session. There
were 2 instructors at each session to help. 

Since I have been to two autocrosses, I am not a novice, but I still have A
LOT to learn about driving, so I was at the clinic. First was the slalom. The
cones were set at the same distance apart for entire run of 8 cones. I found
that I was usually going too fast at the end of slalom, and had a hard time
getting through the last gate. My intructor had me work in going faster
initially, and them maintaining a constant speed, and getting into a smooth
rthyme.

After slalom came the Esses. The gates were set FAR wide apart. The trick
here was to get the car turned way before the gate, so that you could go
through the gates straighter, and have more time to turn for the next gate.
My car did not want to turn. It just wanted to plow straght ahead. I started
to experiment with sudden throttle changes, to try to get the car to rotate
better, but I never did it very well.

Next up was the threshold brake section. You would accellerate in a straight
line and then have to make it through a decreasing radius left turn. The
straight was long enough to get up to redline in second gear, so you were
going pretty fast. My car has ABS brakes, so I the braking part was simple. I
had a lot of fun drifting the car around the turn. When I could see the exit,
I could get the car straight, and then power out if the turn. I was at a good
part of the powerband, and the power would really stick the back wheels.

The last section was a skid pad. I have never driven on a skid pad before,
and I probably learned more about car control in that than in any other
section. You could quickly and easily see how changing one car input
(throttle on / off, steering in / out) would affect the car.

A few notes:
I was having a hard time getting my car (89 944 Turbo S) to turn in. It was
pushing in every turn. One of the instructors said that I could get the car
to turn in better by loosening the front shocks (adjustable Koni's). I make a
small adjustment, and the car would turn much better. The car was better
balanced, and I could get oversteer if I wanted it. My car was not very well
suited for the course. The entire course was taken in second gear, but the
rpm's were too low, and the straights too short to allow the turbo to provide
much boost. 

There were two guys there with new 993 C4 Cabriolet's. They were very nice
guys, but did not have clue on how to drive. I give them credit for coming
out and trying to learn. one guy listened to the isntructors, and seemed to
get the hang of it. The other guy either wouldn't / couldn't listen, and
never did get it. Beautiful cars!

In the afternoon autox, I came in first in my class, and second overall (the
instructors did not drive). I was really looking forward to Sunday.

On sunday, there were about 50 cars, 30 Porsches, 20 non Porsche. The course
was mostly the same. The major changes were that the slalom cones got more
spaced out, the high speed straight had a lane change added, and the skidpad
was removed. The lane change in the high speed section really killed me.
Without it, I could power out of the previous turn, and have full boost the
entire length of the straight. With the lane change, I had to get the car
over to the right before the lane change, so that I could take the lane
change straighter. If I stayed on the throttle long enough to get full boost,
I just ended up spinning the rear wheels and getting pretty sideways. Fun,
but not fast.

I walked the course twice, and I thought I picked up some ideas. During the
autoX my times were OK, but there were a LOT better drivers than the day
before. I am amazed at the difference between a really good driver, and an
average driver. All of the good drivers were 5-10 seconds faster than the
rest of the drivers. The times were in the range of 61-63 for the good
drivers, and 69-75+ for the rest. All of the good drivers had either Comp T/A
R1, or Yoko A008 tires. I know the tires make a difference, but I can't
believe it is that much of a difference.

I came in second in my class, about 6 seconds behind the class winner. I
don't feel too bad because he is an instructor for NNJR, and was driving a
944 S2, with Comp T/A R1, full harness, etc. No doubt about it, he is in a
different driving league than I am. 

There are a few things that are causing me some problems. I was able to cut
my time over three seconds from my first run to my last run, but I did it by
driving harder / better. Except for a few obvious things like which way to
enter the slamon, and which way to enter a lane change, I never did recognize
when one line would be better than another. I know that I need more
experience, but my times could change so much due to other things that I know
it's going to take a long time before I can determine which lime is better.

I had originally wanted to make a post about how various lines were better in
various turns, but I never could tell. Oh well.

The next Metro NY Autocross is Aug 20. I'll be there!

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1582                         Mon Jul 24 15:26:54 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 12:37:29 -0400
From: LToy@aol.com
Subject: greetings! & re:  too low? (lugging)

Greetings!

New to the list (actually, been reading for a few weeks).  Starting a low-key
(haven't convinced the wyf of the *need*--she understands the *want*) search
for an '87 or '88 Carrera coupe.  (No Unka' Bart--I'm not abandoning the
quattro!)

What I've done
1.  read the faq
2.  been referred to a P-car mechanic (swires, bellevue, wa);  need a
recommendation in the bay area (my search will be seattle or sf bay area)

What I need (besides the solution to domestic harmony on P-cars)
1.  suggestions/comments/practical experience w/ a search and how to keep
sane
2.  same, for these specific cars--what should i watch for?
3.  where can i get a list of options available on these cars?  per the faq,
earlier 
years were available in standard and sport models.  same in '87 or '88?
 what's
the difference?  any options to avoid?  any must-have options?

Finally, in the spirit of contributing  (my 2 pennies, or PMFI):
what's too low rpm?  Two "seat of the pants" techniques I've followed.  
First, if you can better _maintain_ speed in say, 3rd gear than 4th, 
you're lugging.  Put another way, if you have to use more throttle in
4th gear than in 3rd gear, use 3rd.
Second, if when you use more throttle, you get no (or minimal) acceleration,
again, shift down.  These rules of thumb are discussed extensively in trailer
towing (small boat, for me).  Also, as guidelines, they take into account the
current situation (load, speed, etc), instead of blindly following a minimum
rpm level (altho that usually works fine).

tia,

Linus Toy
'91 Audi 200q (mine)
'89 Honda Accord (hers)
looking for the *right* 911 (ours;  hey--gotta sell it to her too!)

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 11:33:02 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 3.0L into '73 911

> I'm thinking of replacing the tired 2.4 in my '73 911T with a 3.0L SC engine.

> this. I asked this question once before and got bounced from the list the
> next day for some unknown reason, so I didn't get to see any replies (if
> there were any).

Have done it. It's a nice conversion, if well done. But doing it is a
major pain in the ass...  Doing a 3.2 swap is an even bigger pain, though
so it's all relative.

Is your car a '73 or a '73.5? If the latter, with CIS, it's easier. IF
not, then well... Actually, I would be very tempted to swap a 3.0 long
block in under a set of 2.4 MFI and get the space cam recut. *THAT* could
be very interesting.

Shoot me a note with specific detail questions if you have them.

Stan

> be a big problem, but I think I need a .75mm or so.  I've heard that
> it can be built up from several of the old 36 HP VW shims, but don't have

Well, Stoddard is the mother ship for all such parts...

Based on your description, I'd say you need to pull out the spec book and
check dimensions on the flywheel and the crank. That should be instructive.
I'd bet that something is off-spec...

If it's NOT then you have a problem. 

> So, is there a source for "non-standard" sized shims?
> A source for 36 HP VW shims?  A cheaper source for the standard
> sized shims?  

I have no idea where to get thinner shims, but would be inclined to take 
a 1.0 mm and machine it down. I would prefer to use Porsche shim cut
down than something I didn't know what was... 36HP VW parts? Try
Gene Berg or Vintage Parts Inc (818-848-2833). VPI is the only place that
routinely advertises 36HP stuff, but Gene has or knows where to get
*EVERYTHING*....

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 13:01:33 -0500
From: Joe Browne <brownej@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  Seattle

Wish I could meet you in Seattle, but I don't go there anymore (used to
have a business contact there). I am not sure if you know the town, but I
thought I would reccommend a couple of diversions.

1.  Go to Schillshole (sp?) and eat at either Anthony's Home Port or Ray's
Boathouse.  The seafood is great.  Nice view, not too expensive.  If you
can get halibut cheeks, they are pretty terrific.

2.  Over in Bellville, just across the water to the east, is Jake
O'Shanessy's pub with about 50 microbrews on draft and some of the
nicest, best looking wai........servers I ever had the pleasure of being
drunk with.

3. To continue on that theme,  Chateau St. Michelle has a winery tour on
demand just north of Bellville.  The best part is the end where you sit and
get a few glasses pro bono.  Across the street from St Michelle is
Columbia wines which is not as much to look at but great tastings.

If you know all of this, I apologize for the fool I am.  It is risky asking for
help in a strange town, lest you end up at Bertha's Kareoke.

I second Mike Dayton's opinion.  It isn't hard to do a
first-rate alignment yourself.  It just takes time.  And
Ray Scrugg's little booklet is really pretty good, especially
if you've never done a 911 or a 914.  He takes you through
it step by step.  Once you do it yourself, you'll wonder
what all the fuss is about.

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 95 09:36:00 ADT
From: "Southard, Keith" <KSOUTHAR@atu.com>
Subject: REPLY: 944 Questions


>1. What years are desired?

Definately post 85.5. Obviously the later the better.

>2. What years should he avoided?

Have not heard that any are absolutely terrible. I understand that the pre-
85 models have a problem with the location of the heater valve (over
the clutch) that eventually leaks and causes the failure of the clutch.
Corrected in later models. Also, earlier models basically used the 924
interior components. Later ones are much nicer.

>3. What type of things should he look out for.

Make sure to get the 2.7L engine (earlier ones had a 2.5). Pay particular
attention to camshaft and balance shaft belts, when they were replaced.
Check on when the water pump was replaced (if ever).

>4. What would be some bonus buys, options to look out for etc.?

ABS, 16" Wheels, Sport Seats. No matter what, make sure the previous
owner kept good maintenence records. Get the car checked THOROUGHLY
by a P-Car mechanic (not the guy at the corner gas station).

------------------------------

Date:         Mon, 24 Jul 95 12:47:08 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: 924 Cooling problems.

On Sun, 23 Jul 1995 00:47:18 -0400 you said:
>Ashley,
>
>This is usually the sign of a thermostat which has ceased to open at
>the right temperature, and so not allowing coolant to circulate through
>the radiator.
>
>Kevin
>

Ashley,

Get this fixed soon! Mine was like that and then failed completely
and suddenly at the track almost overheating my engine. Noticing
how my new thermostat works, a sign I saw during winter was that
the temp gauge registered below the normal range. My new one will
not register below the normal range once the engine is up to operating
temp. I believe my old thermostat was not closing or opening completely.
I had the same symptoms as you, but thought that was normal since it
was my first watercooled car.

Darren Evans-Young
'87 944S Indischrot
darren@ua1vm.ua.edu

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 11:29:51 -0700
From: tfrazer@sonic.net (Thomas Frazer)
Subject:  Re: Teaching other drivers a "lesson"

Teaching that darn tailgater a lesson can have some big repercussions:
During a raining night here in Sonoma County, a driver slammed on the
brakes to get a car off their rear bumper.  That car spun, went across the
divider on highway 101 and was hit by a loaded semi truck travelling the
opposite direction.  Tally: family of five dead, one little kid survived,
and the driver of the car that started this whole thing went to jail for 5
counts of manslaughter.

Pays to think the whole act through.

Tom Frazer                                     "I shall fly like a BEE, up to
President Dauenhauer Mfg., Inc.                 the honey tree"

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 95 14:45:13 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: Best Material to Learn 911 Engine Repair

          One reference that I just thought of that I find a great
          companion to the factory manuals is the parts manual.
          Stoddard used to sell the hard copy of the 1978-1982 911
          manual for about $90.

          It's about 3" thick, and a great reference when you're
          trying to figure out how something comes apart, not to
          mention when you need the part number for some innocuous
          little washer.  Many of the numbers have been superceded,
          but Stoddards has always been able to cross-reference with
          no problem.

          BTW, the quality of the printing is excellent.

          Mark_Salvetti@abbsmtp.abb.com
          1979 911SC Targa

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 95 14:45:18 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: Factory Car Covers

          Derek, what color car do you use your factory covers on?
          I've heard a number of people complain that the factory
          cover leaves fine scratches on dark cars, particulary on
          corners and fender bulges.

          I use 100% cotton.  Less bulky that Evolution, machine
          washable, soft and breathable.  Not very water repellent,
          but I use a cover only to keep off the sun and bird
          droppings, and make the car a little less tempting to steal.
          Does a decent job of keeping off dirt when the car is
          garaged for the winter.

          Mark_Salvetti@abbsmtp.abb.com
          1979 911SC Targa

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 13:48:37 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: smtp%"Re: Teaching other drivers a "lesson"

>Still, had I been in a lesser car I can't even imagine the consequences.

We had something similar happen to my dad and I when we were traveling
in a 1-ton (loaded) pickup.  We had no choice but to destroy the rear of
the car in front of us, since a 5000+lb truck stops considerably slower
than any car that I know of.  The truck had a scratch in the paint!
I guess we learned our lesson!:)  Additionaly, the accident was 
determined to be their fault.   Getting full on your brakes right in 
front of a truck is pretty stupid and someplaces is considered 
reckless.  Also, minimum speed on most rural interstates is posted
at 45 mph.  Being below that for a nonemergency situation is illegal.
Thought I'd head off the discussion before it got started on why it
wasn't considered our fault.

Porsche content:  I do get a bit testy about having someone on my butt
when I'm in the Porsche.  I know that I can outbrake just about anything
on the road.  I hate the thought of having to brake for an emergency with
someone close behind me.  If possible I move to another lane or leave
them.  If I can't do either of those, I usually tap my brakes lightly
to let them know how close they are.  Incidentally, for the same reason
I feel comfortable travelling closer to someone in the Porsche than
I do in other vehicles.

Glad I live in the midwest with reasonable people as a whole,

Ross Stites 
'87 951

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 14:14:22 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Questions


>>1. What years are desired?
>
>Definately post 85.5. Obviously the later the better.

The newer the better is always a good rule.  The 85.5+ cars
had the updated interior.  This is neither good nor bad, just
different.  The big advantage is that the later cars (85.5+?)
have the improved suspension with the aluminum control arms.
Of course, this is much more expensive to fix and is only 
an advantage in a competition situation.  I thing the early
944s get a bad rap.  They have the same performance as the later
cars and are generally much cheaper.

>>3. What type of things should he look out for.
>
>Make sure to get the 2.7L engine (earlier ones had a 2.5). 

The '89 model is the only one to use the 2.7L engine.  All other 944s
had 2.5L engines except the 944S2 that had a 3L engine.  

>4. What would be some bonus buys, options to look out for etc.?

>ABS, 16" Wheels, Sport Seats. No matter what, make sure the previous
>owner kept good maintenence records. Get the car checked THOROUGHLY
>by a P-Car mechanic (not the guy at the corner gas station).

ABS is only available in '87+ cars.  Most US 944s are fairly loaded.
The options you want will be much more dependant on your intent for 
the car than anything else.  Is it going to be a sunnyday cruiser, a 
daily driver, a concours car, a racer, or some combination of the 
above?

Have you read the 944 FAQ yet?  This would be a good starting point.
I'll be glad to answer additionaly questions.

Ross Stites
'87 951

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 15:43:20 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: General Question

Also sprach Sean P. Simmen:

>Why does using the A/C give you worse gas mileage?
>Sean  '80 928

It increases the load on the engine and therefore the consumption of fuel/air
increases.  It is like going up a hill:  the only way to maintain your
current speed is to give the car wider throttle, since the engine has to work
harder to get itself up the hill.

The same would be true for fully-loaded, trailer-toting pickups: the more
you pull/load the lower your effective MPG.

- -- 
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 - Jerry R. Brady         - Open Networks Engineering -          jrb@one.com -
 - 1976 Sunflower Yellow 914/2.0(ok,ok, it's a 1.7 with 96mm NPR)            -
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: 24 Jul 1995 15:48:39 -0500
From: "Elliot Entin" <elliot.entin@alphatech.com>
Subject: Re: General Question

                       Subject:                               Time:3:33 PM
  OFFICE MEMO          RE>General Question                    Date:7/24/95

When you engage your A/C, you cause your compressor to do work (normally it is
idling).  The compressor must compress the gas in your A/C unit.  To do this
requires work (energy) and that is a load on your engine.  Now your engine
must power the compressor as well as make you go.  The addition load on an
engine usually translates into about 2 miles less per gal.
Elliot.

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 95 15:57:42 EDT
From: "Bill Elwell" <B.Elwell@zds.com>
Subject: Re: Teaching other drivers a "lesson" 


I could not resist jumping in on this thread.  If you like to play games 
with fellow drivers, try one of these techniques.

Technique #1

Someone pulls up behind you an makes it known (in some obnoxious way) that 
he/she/it wants to pass you.  Move to the right and let them pass.  As they 
pass, accelerate to match their speed.  Follow along far enough back to be 
out of their blind spot.  Continue to match their speed.  Three out of ten 
drivers will accelerate to outrageous speeds trying to pass you.

Technique #2

If you are in the left lane and someone is blocking your efforts to pass 
try this.  Scoot over to the left just far enough to allow your left 
headlight to shine past the back of their car and onto their rearview 
mirror.  Five out of ten drivers will move left to get your headlight out 
of their rearview.  Move with them, keep that light in the mirror.  This 
gets the attention of some drivers.  In other cases, the driver is so 
thick, they will drive off onto the shoulder to keep your headlight out of 
their mirror.  (Yes, I know.  If they are on the shoulder, I am too)

The games some people play!

Bill Elwell
b.elwell@zds.com

     however there were a few minor oil leaks and the air-conditioning

     soon as I get the car).  Secondly, if I sink big bucks into the car

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 95 16:06:56 PST
From: finnh@autodesk.com
Subject: Ive been Keyed ! - A happy ending

     I'd like to thank everyone who responded to my request for suggestions 
     on repairing the scratch inflicted on my shiny white P-Car.  I was/am 
     truly amazed at the support and empathy from this group.
     
     This is how the saga ends:
     
     The day after, having parked the 911 in it's garage I showed the nose 
     to tail scratch to my two boys, (5 & 10). Needless to say, they 
     weren't happy about their favorite car getting messed up either.  
       About an hour later, my five year old comes up the stairs from 'his' 
     workshop with his white construction hat on and informs me with 
     certainty that he has 'fixed' my car!  After pushing my heart back 
     down my throat, (visions of hammers and saws dancing in my head), I 
     let him lead me down to look at his workmanship. 
        Well,... he had taken a large gum eraser from a drawing kit and 
     rubbed off about five inches of the 'scratch'!
     
        Blown away!!  It wasn't a scratch after all!  It was a pencil line 
     someone had run down the length of the car.
        If that kid got an allowance, I would have given him a raise!  
     (Instead he got the front seat for a week.) ;-}
     
     Well, that's it. Thanks for all the advice, it's in my P-Car notebook 
     now.
     
     How!e

Subject: Timing Belt Time.

  
  Well it's time to change the timing belt in my '83
  928S Euro (65K miles). I called the one of the local
  Houston dealers (Momentum Porsche) and they quoted
  me a price between $700 - $1300 depending upon whether
  I had the water pump done, what kind of shape the
  pulleys were in, and whether the factory said the
  the tensioners should be upgraded. The cost of parts 
  was something like $94 for the belt, and $160 for 
  the water pump (euroselect with an exchange), 
  maybe tensioners and pulleys (I don't know how much), 
  and coolant. Maybe you can see where I'm going with 
  this, I'm thinking of doing it myself. The shop 
  manuals, a tensioner tool, the above parts, some 
  gaskets, misc parts, and a few knuckles. I could do that.  
  As fringe benefits I could score some new tools, 
  get to get under the hood of my car, and if I'm 
  lucky I might even save a little money. I was wondering 
  though, does doing this kind work yourself adversly
  affect the value of the car (assuming the job is 
  done right) as opposed to having an card carrying 
  "expert" do it. Any words of wisdom from the 
  p-patriarches (or p-matriarches) on the list 
  would be appreciated.
  
  Thanks for any advice,
  Doug Cook

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 13:40:21 -0700
From: nms@slip.net (Nick Silva)
Subject: Re: Teaching other drivers "a lesson"

> Howdy P-folks, I was wondering if I might have a group opinion on
> something.  Here in New England where people are nasty drivers I have
> seen a pattern I really dislike.  While my girlfriend was driving her
> Acura and I watched helplessly in the passenger's seat, she decided that
> the car behind her was following to closely and she intentionally hit the
> brakes hard for a second to throw him off.  I heard a screech from behond
> and, although we weren't hit, I screamed at her for the next 10 mintues
> about it.  She insisted he needed to be taught not to tailgate _her_, and
> I tried to drive into her impetuous mind how foolish it was and how the
> possible consequences are horrible.  Sure, teach him a lesson but never
> walk again.  Or worse, teach him and the child in his car a lesson.
> Anyway, she came to see it my way, that it just wasn't worth it.
>         Last night on my way home from work (about 1AM, late worker) I
> was "taught a lesson."  On a highway entrance which splits from one lane
> to 4 suddenly I was following another car closely for just a couple of
> seconds until the highway would split and I would go around.  Right
> before the split the driver in front decided to slam on his brakes (from
> 50mph down to about 10) before I could go around.  I've never been fond
> of my 914 brakes, but I floored them and the front wheels locked for a
> second and then released.  It was a miracle that I was able to avoid
> colliding, and was very perturbed.  He then made a finger gesture to me
> out his sunroof and proceeded to swerve back and forth across the highway
> (now 4 lanes) in front of me to keep me from passing.  Of course since he
> was in an inferior car I managed to fake one way and zip past him on the
> other side, but I thought the whole incident was ridiculous!  There seems
> to be this mindset up here in the north and it is foolish!  Has anyone
> else ever experienced this?  Am I really evil for following closely for a
> brief moment until I can get around?  Thanks for your opinions and for
> letting me vent!   Rick and Gretchin with 2 tiny wear marks


I think the reaction of the driver being tailgated is in direct proportion
to how nervous tailgating makes him. Look at it this way: I'm on the
freeway, doing 70, medium traffic. Cars typically hang 1-2 car lengths from
my bumper, way too short a distance if there's any trouble. If I move into
the next lane and drop back, the same thing happens again in another lane.
I have noticed there are two distinct kinds of tailgaters: aware and
unaware. The aware tailgaters want to get by, feel you're holding them up,
so they tailgate you to pressure you into moving over. Since they are
presumably aggressive drivers, they will be on the lookout for sudden
braking by you to "teach them a lesson". The unaware drivers are much more
dangerous. They fixate on the cars in front of them, oblivious of the
speed. If I had to suddenly come to a stop (traffic, animal in the road,
accident...), they would probably plow right into me.  It's these people
that should be taught a lesson. The aware drivers I get the hell out of the
way of before they have a chance to tailgate me. To teach the unaware
driver a lesson, a light touch on the brakes is all that's necessary. You
don't have to scrub off speed, but you're just giving the person a message
that they are following too closely. This is very different from dropping
40mph and swerving all over the highway.

Another trick I have used to get cars away from me is to pretend I'm drunk.
I weave the car just enough so that people notice something's wrong, and
boy do they stay away if they think you're intoxicated. I just hope I never
do this with a cop around!

Nick

________________________________________________________________________________
                           Jasper, this one's evil.

                                nms@slip.net
____________________________________________________________________________

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 95 17:27:08 EDT

Any copyrighted image is illegal to copy for distribution
without express consent of the copyright holder. The magazine
pictures you are interested in scanning are almost certainly
copyrighted.

>  me a price between $700 - $1300 depending upon whether

Did you check any other places?  This seems very high
for a timing belt change, though I'll admit a lack of
experience with 928s.  My 951 cost ~$300 at the local
dealership for replacement of all the belts.

>  I was wondering 
>  though, does doing this kind work yourself adversly
>  affect the value of the car (assuming the job is 
>  done right) as opposed to having an card carrying 
>  "expert" do it. 

Just keep and file your parts receipts, and document when the
work was done.  I can't see why anyone would be bothered by 
this.  The amount of money you'll save over paying the 
dealership for repairs will more than make up for any loss
in value you could possibly suffer anyways.

Ross Stites

For those who wanted to know the outcome:

This last Saturday I went up to Minneapolis to pick up my
car.  It ended up being the DME.  I had a used one put in
for about $1k total (analysis, parts, labor).  My car ran
fine all the way home, and I'm very happy to have it back.
Hopefully, this is the last time for a while that I have
to pay the very high labor rates of a Porsche mechanic.

Thanks for all the replies and support when this initially
happened a month ago.

Ross Stites

Walt,
A respected Porsche body shop around these parts tells me they have done
several mirror updates for these older 911 using BMW '75-'78 5-series
mirrors.  Supposedly they look extremely like the original rectangle ones
Porsche used on the left side only, and the base contour matches the door's
curve properly.

I have ordered a pair from a local BMW dealer to see for myself.  They should
arrive in a week or so and I can let the list know of the results.  For those
interested in doing their own comparison, the BMW part numbers are:

Left side   - 51 161 822 076
Right side - 51 161 821 793

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara, CA)
95 993 coupe, guards red
73.5 911T 2.7 coupe, ferrari red
85 535i, grey

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 17:54:36 -0400
From: ChannellR@aol.com
Subject: Re: General Question

Sean asks,
>Why does using the A/C give you worse gas mileage?

Some of your engine's power is used to turn the A/C compressor when you turn
the A/C on. Your car will slow down slightly or you have to give it just a
little more gas to maintain the same speed.  You may also notice that the car
will not accelerate as fast when the A/C is on. The bottom line is that this
increased load on your engine (maintaining a constant rpm and speed) requires
more power (more gas-air mixture to burn) than when the A/C is off. 

Acceleration and gas mileage *MAY* be improved (YMMV) by removing the entire
A/C system. I took mine off because it weighed over 43 pounds. :) I haven't
done any empirical (sp?) tests but it *FEELS* faster, at least I keep telling
myself that as I sweat in the local traffic.

Rob Channell
channellr@aol.com
1979 911SC euro s/r coupe (no A/C but don't care. What was I
THINKING???!!!!!!!)

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 17:55:33 -0400
From: ChannellR@aol.com
Subject: Re: HELP!!!! 911 Buying Decision

   Ross said:

> I have about $15,000 to spend and would like to get a 3.0L SC.

Nice car. I spent about that to get mine 6 years ago. I've spent that much
again maintaining and modifying it.(should've gotten it checked out better
before I bought it but didn't have a clue or know anyone that did)
     
>     Anyway, I found a 80 911SC Targa with 114k miles on it.  No 
>     maintenance records,

DOH! First instinct says run away. I got bit by this.

>     however there were a few minor oil leaks 

Were the oil leaks included in the $2000 price for repairs? I have a leak
between the timing chain housing and the rest of the case. Fixing it involves
removing it, replacing the gasket, and then re-timing the cam(not sure about
this)? Maybe about $300 including parts for someone else to do it. Moral is
some small things are expensive to fix.

>and the air-conditioning 
>     needs a new compressor (at least).

Same comment as for the oil leaks.
 
>     1) How many miles can I expect to get on a 911 3.0L engine before I 
>     need a major rebuild?  By major I mean head work or new rings, etc.

In his book (well worth owning by the way) Bruce Anderson said he had seen SC
engines last 300,000 to 400,000 miles with proper maintainence. What kind of
maintainence did this car have? Mine lasted from 95,000 to 125,000 miles
before it went completely South.
     
>     2) How much should I expect to pay for such work? (ie ballpark range)

BTDT My estimate was $8000 for a total overhaul. My wild guess at a topend
overhaul would be about half that. I may be off, though. 
     
>     3) How much $$$ would a really big mileage 80 911 command?

Not sure. I have seen them from $7000-24,000 It all boils down to condition
and all you can do is look at how the car is now and how it has been cared
for. If it's missing the records you are missing half the information and
have a 50/50 shot at best. If you have to have the car get it, spend money on
it, and drive it, and don't worry about it, but if you take your time and
don't get in a rush, you may be able to get a car that will cost much less
money down the road. You'll also have a higher resale value when you get
ready to sell.
     
>     Does anyone have any information/advice for a future Porsche owner?

Don't let me dissuade you from this car. It is your money and I haven't even
seen the car.Even if I had this would still only be an opinion. I bought mine
without the proper knowledge and it has cost me much money to get a nice car.
I could have done it cheaper by buying a more expensive car. I'd be happy to
relate more details directly if you like.

Rob Channell

1979 911SC euro s/r coupe

1989)



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 15:07:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: allanh@handmadesw.com (Allan N. Hessenflow)
Subject: Re: General Question

> Ok, I've got how it works now.  So, if it eats so much gas why doesn't
> someone make one that runs on electricity off of the battery like the
> radio does (or like my A/C does at home)?

That doesn't help - then you just have to burn more gas to produce the
electricity to run the A/C.  Except now you've added two more steps, the
alternator and electric motor, with losses in each of them, so the whole
process will be less efficient and use even more gas.  Turning on your
radio is also reducing your gas mileage, although it's really
insignificant.  It uses multiple orders of magnitude less power than the
A/C.

allan

- -- 
Allan N. Hessenflow     allanh@kallisti.com
http://www.handmadesw.com/~allanh/

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 15:07:16 -0700

Subject: Re: Teaching other drivers a "lesson"

>Teaching that darn tailgater a lesson can have some big repercussions:
>During a raining night here in Sonoma County, a driver slammed on the
>brakes to get a car off their rear bumper.  That car spun, went across the
>divider on highway 101 and was hit by a loaded semi truck travelling the
>opposite direction.  Tally: family of five dead, one little kid survived,
>and the driver of the car that started this whole thing went to jail for 5
>counts of manslaughter.

According to my CHP (calif hwy patrol) friends this is a prime example of
being at fault. It is illegal to slam on your brakes for no apparent reason.
When they investigae any rear end accident they try and detirmine if in fact
the first driver had to slam on their brakes. So watch out if you are caught
up in this situation.

mike

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 18:24:50 -0400 (EDT)
From: Matt Clement <mclement@access.digex.net>
Subject: Re: General Question



On Mon, 24 Jul 1995, Sean P. Simmen wrote:

> Why does using the A/C give you worse gas mileage?

It's simple -- it's one more thing taking the engine's power away from 
propelling the car.  It's most noticable on the four-cylinder Porsche's 
(you're probably fairly immune to serious lack of power in your 928 ... 
lucky guy!)

- -- Matt
   1987 944S (yep, a four-banger)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 18:31:27 -0400 (EDT)
From: Matt Clement <mclement@access.digex.net>
Subject: Re: A/C better on gas mileage?



On Mon, 24 Jul 1995, Sean P. Simmen wrote:

> I just mentioned my question to the list to my lab co-worker who informed me
> that there have been studies done by consumers groups concluding that it is
> BETTER on your gas mileage to use your A/C than to roll down your windows!
> They say that the wind resistance caused by rolling down your windows creates
> more drag on your engine than the A/C does!  Makes sense!  What do you guys

I have seen this study, too.  I believe the magic number is around 45-47 
mph, where the wind resistance offered by the open windows actually 
consumes more energy than rolling up the windows and turning the AC on.  
Certainly, around town, it is much more economical to roll down the windows.

- -- Matt

>   affect the value of the car (assuming the job is 
>   done right) as opposed to having an card carrying 
>   "expert" do it. Any words of wisdom from the 

I would say that, if it is done correctly, it shouldn't affect your value 
adversly.  Make sure that you keep ALL THE RECEIPTS for parts you put on 
the car, but assuming that you do, not many people are scared off by a 
knowledgable owner/enthusiast.  I've found, in both buying and selling my 
p-cars, that being an enthusiast makes the deal feel that much better -- 
someone who so obviously cares about his vehicle wouldn't neglect it.  
With receipts to prove it, you can't go wrong.
