Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 15:48:25 -0700
From: Charles Wilson <charliew@sequent.com>
Subject: Timing Belt Time.


I did a belt and water pump on an 82, US 928 a few years ago.
First thing I did was I found someone selling the shop manuals
used for $150.  Great deal.  That gave me the knowledge and
confidence to tackle the job.  As I remember, the thing I
fretted over the most was removing the crank pulley bolt.
That sucker was ON there.  I used a half-inch breaker bar
and a LONG piece of pipe and finally pushed with everything I
had and it came loose.  I was afraid maybe the thing was
reverse threaded.  It wasn't.  Once I knew that, I went for it.
When I put the belt on, I got one of the cams off by a tooth,
so I had to loosen the belt, remove the valve covers, and
"slip" the belt by hand on that one side.  That was better than
taking the whole thing apart again.  Good luck.  The hard
part is getting the timing back in place with the new belt.
The marks on the cams don't both line up exactly at the same time.
The shop manual tells you (sorta) how they should look (I still got
it wrong, tho.).  The "books" say it is an 8hr. job.  Took me only
12.  Not bad.

Charlie (looking for an SC).
> 
>   
>   Well it's time to change the timing belt in my '83
>   928S Euro (65K miles). I called the one of the local
>   Houston dealers (Momentum Porsche) and they quoted
>   me a price between $700 - $1300 depending upon whether
>   I had the water pump done, what kind of shape the
>   pulleys were in, and whether the factory said the
>   the tensioners should be upgraded. The cost of parts 
>   was something like $94 for the belt, and $160 for 
>   the water pump (euroselect with an exchange), 
>   maybe tensioners and pulleys (I don't know how much), 
>   and coolant. Maybe you can see where I'm going with 
>   this, I'm thinking of doing it myself. The shop 
>   manuals, a tensioner tool, the above parts, some 
>   gaskets, misc parts, and a few knuckles. I could do that.  
>   As fringe benefits I could score some new tools, 
>   get to get under the hood of my car, and if I'm 
>   lucky I might even save a little money. I was wondering 
>   though, does doing this kind work yourself adversly
>   affect the value of the car (assuming the job is 
>   done right) as opposed to having an card carrying 
>   "expert" do it. Any words of wisdom from the 
>   p-patriarches (or p-matriarches) on the list 
>   would be appreciated.
>   
>   Thanks for any advice,
>   Doug Cook
>   
>   alternatively if everyone gave me their $0.02 
>   I could pay to have it done.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 15:53:16 -0700 (PDT)
From: allanh@handmadesw.com (Allan N. Hessenflow)
Subject: Re: General Question

Thomas wrote:
> I've got a stereo system that draws between 80 and 90 Amps at full volume
> and have never noticed that power drop from my engine the way turning on the
> A/C feels.  Would an electric A/C draw more than 90Amps?

So you have about a 1000W amp in your car?  Even that wouldn't normally
come at all close to drawing that kind of average current, even at full
volume, unless it's a class A amp.

Anyway, if you're serious about that kind of current, yes, you could run an
A/C on that.  But to supply it you're going to need a bigger alternator,
and it is going to make a noticeable difference in mileage.

allan

- -- 
Allan N. Hessenflow     allanh@kallisti.com
http://www.handmadesw.com/~allanh/

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 95 15:57:23 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: C and SC


To those of use that started in OLD Porsches, the term  "C" refered to
356C model and "SC" refered to a "C" model with the "SUPER" or 90+ HP 
engine to the "C" NORMAL's 65-75Hp. You did pay extra for the priviledge.

As marketeer's get their hands on things to sell cars, the name became 
911S for "SUPER" or later "SPORT". There was the first 911 "CARERRA" in
1974. The 911 "SC" was never really defined, yet the ad copy hinted back to the "tradition" started by the 356SC. They were always 911s, no 
matter what the factory tried to call them. 

These days, the C is typically thought of as "CARERRA" irrespective of 
model designation. 

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 16:24:39 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: A/C better on gas mileage?

> 
> I just mentioned my question to the list to my lab co-worker who informed me
> that there have been studies done by consumers groups concluding that it is
> BETTER on your gas mileage to use your A/C than to roll down your windows!
> They say that the wind resistance caused by rolling down your windows creates
> more drag on your engine than the A/C does!  Makes sense!  What do you guys
> think?  Sean  '80 928 (probably doesn't matter with the worst drag coefficient
>                        of any Porsche!)
> 

A group in Australia did a study on this several years ago.  They also
tested with and without air deflectors around the windows.  Results:

With A/C off, windows rolled gave the best mileage.
     A/C on,  Windows up
     A/C off, Windows down, with deflectors
     A/C off, Windows down, no deflectors gave the worst mileage.

That was then.  A/C units have gotten better (at least the pre-R12
units), and cars more streamlined.  I think you'ld see even more
of a difference today.

$0.02, Gary.

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 19:40:11 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Clutch Suppliers?

As long as they are selling the rubbercentered Fitchel and 
Sachs clutch assembly, go for the cheapest.

I bought mine from PAR Porsche in Yonkers a few years ago.

Make sure that you replace the pilot bearing also. You would
really hate it if the job had to be done again for a $20 part...

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 19:51:53 -0400
From: AlanG23848@aol.com
Subject: Swirl Marks in Paint

The best thing to use is a buff from a new type of spong waffle pad.  The
best products I have also used are from a company in Texas called Auto Wax.
 Get four products

1. Waffle pads for buffers
2. Blue clay for cleaning the paint
3. Body Shine (#49) for using the clay
3. Clear coat finish polish (pink) to buff the paint with the waffel pad.

These items can be used if you hav clear coat or not and will provide the
best shine you can get without he swirl marks.

also you must  wax the car when finished.

Alan Gottlob

89 944 Turbo (Black)

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 19:57:24 -0400 (EDT)
From: Andrew George <ageorge@freenet.columbus.oh.us>
Subject: Re: General Question

On Mon, 24 Jul 1995, Allan N. Hessenflow wrote:

> > Ok, I've got how it works now.  So, if it eats so much gas why doesn't
> > someone make one that runs on electricity off of the battery like the
> > radio does (or like my A/C does at home)?
> 
> That doesn't help - then you just have to burn more gas to produce the
> electricity to run the A/C.  Except now you've added two more steps, the
> alternator and electric motor, with losses in each of them, so the whole
> process will be less efficient and use even more gas.  Turning on your
> radio is also reducing your gas mileage, although it's really
> insignificant.  It uses multiple orders of magnitude less power than the
> A/C.
> 
> allan
> 
> -- 
> Allan N. Hessenflow     allanh@kallisti.com
> http://www.handmadesw.com/~allanh/

The answer is to use solar cells because on the days you need AC there is
probably enough sun to be collected, that way you dont drain on the engine
or the battery.  You should also have a capacitor or a small battery to
store some of the suns energy if the clouds cover the sun
Andrew GEorge




------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 15:05:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: Walter Stander <wstander@cts.com>
Subject: Re: General Question

Sean,

Energy is energy.....whether from a belt driven compressor or an 
electrically driven device. I suspect that an electrically driven 
compressor would take an excessive amount of power (as my home A/C does 
in the summer compared to electric use in winter) and the battery 
requirements (weight, charge, etc) would obviate the gains of not loading 
the engine. BTW: Is your concern MPG or loss of power in driving? 

Walt

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 20:09:32 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:General Question

>>Thomas wrote:
>>> I've got a stereo system that draws between 80 and 90 Amps at full volume
>>> and have never noticed that power drop from my engine the way turning on the
>>> A/C feels.  Would an electric A/C draw more than 90Amps?
>>
>>So you have about a 1000W amp in your car?  Even that wouldn't normally
>>come at all close to drawing that kind of average current, even at full
>>volume, unless it's a class A amp.
>>
>>Anyway, if you're serious about that kind of current, yes, you could run an
>>A/C on that.  But to supply it you're going to need a bigger alternator,
>>and it is going to make a noticeable difference in mileage.
>>
>>allan
Keep it in mind that 745 watts = 1 horsepower. So the 1000 watt stereo
(ouch, my ears) is really down in the noise. Especially for a 928.
A real auto air conditioner takes a lot more power than that.

(Did I really say that a 1000 watt stereo is down in the noise? Freudian
slip, I guess).

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 95 17:36:27 -0700
From: stuartk@SIRIUS.COM (Stuart A. Kleinfelder)
Subject: Re: General Question

>
>I've got a stereo system that draws between 80 and 90 Amps at full volume
>and have never noticed that power drop from my engine the way turning on the
>A/C feels.  Would an electric A/C draw more than 90Amps?
>

You claim your stereo *draws* 90 Amps. *90 Amps* at 12 volts is 1080 watts,
which is about 1.5 H.P.

Hope you have some pretty thick cables (say, 6-gauge copper) going to power
your stereo or your car will catch fire just after you melt your ears.

Sounds a little over-kill for Bach, but I don't know what you listen too.

=8^)

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 17:26:10 -0700
From: peterg@airdata.com (Peter Gregory)
Subject: 911T engine ground strap?????

My 73.5 911T (CIS) has been running kind of rough lately - annoying surging
~2500-3000rpm in any gear.  The surging matches some sympathetic frequency
that makes the engine rock from side to side, or something equally annoying.

I've put in new Bosch platinum plugs, but haven't checked the cap/rotor yet.

But, other interesting and possibly-related symptoms include:

Oil temp gauge is shaky, +/- 10lb.
Tach occasionally drops to zero, then back up to correct rpm.
Oil level gauge is all over the place (VIOLENTLY up/down full-scale at 
   2000-4000 rpm).

I've thought, "could all four of these symptoms be a manifestation of the
same problem?"  If so, the only thing I can think of is the engine ground
strap.  If so, where is it?  I haven't spent much time underneath the car
yet.

If not the ground strap, then ??????

Thanks,

Peter Gregory

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 17:54:48 -0700 (PDT)
From: allanh@handmadesw.com (Allan N. Hessenflow)
Subject: Re: General Question

John C. C. White wrote:
> Keep it in mind that 745 watts = 1 horsepower. So the 1000 watt stereo
> (ouch, my ears) is really down in the noise. Especially for a 928.

It's certainly not much compared to what the engine can produce.  But it's
a significant portion of the average power used to drive around, and so
a significant difference in mileage.  I seem to remember something like
20-30hp being quoted as average power requirements for a car.  Of course a
1000 watt stereo, unless it's class A, will in practice use a *lot* less
than 1000 watts.

> A real auto air conditioner takes a lot more power than that.

Do they?  You can get room air conditioners that plug into a standard 15A,
117V socket, so they can't be taking more than 1750 watts.  I'd expect a car
air conditioner to be smaller than that, but then I don't actually know.
Although, if you believe the numbers above, and the 2mpg difference someone
else mentioned when using air conditioning, and assume average mileage
is 20-30 mpg (to make the arithmetic trivial), that would correspond to
2hp for the A/C.

allan

- -- 
Allan N. Hessenflow     allanh@kallisti.com
http://www.handmadesw.com/~allanh/

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 16:46:16 -0500
From: Brian Scudder <bscudder@spdmail.spd.dsccc.com>
Subject: Re: Timing Belt Time.

Doug is pondering doing a timing belt replacement for a 928:
> Any words of wisdom from the 
>  p-patriarches (or p-matriarches) on the list 
>  would be appreciated.
>   Any words of wisdom from the 
>  p-patriarches (or p-matriarches) on the list 
>  would be appreciated.

Doing a 928 timing belt is not all that difficult, it just takes lots of
time. You must take everything off the front of the engine. And "while
you're in there" you will want to replace the water pump because it is
so much work getting to it.

Besides, your basic tools, you'll need a flywheel lock (~$35) and the
tensioner tool (~$400). See if you can borrow these.

Zims sells the belts for about $50, and you can get the waterpump from
Jay Pineau (713)251-2222 for $150, exchange.

I think I spent around $350 for parts (the incidentals add up).

Good luck,
Brian Scudder (just spent my last $0.02)
'83 928S ('merican model)
'70 old blue truck (no A/C)
'93 cat

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 21:32:08 -0500
From: Bill <us009904@interramp.com>
Subject: Average/Typical MPG for 1973 911T w/ MFI

Harvey,

If you have MFI, you do not have a 73.5 CIS car. I'm going to assume your 73 
is very simialr to the '72 2.4 L MFI car. In my collection of early road tests 
I found ('72) 2.4L Ts got 15-18 mpg, Es got 15-18 mpg and Ss got 14-17 mpg. 
While the low S numbers are close to your milage, I think you are right in 
showing concern. Of courser, the engine mods could be solely responsible for 
your observed 10-12 mpg. How much highway (65 mph) driving do you do?

Unless you are driving your car with great vigor I suspect your MFI may be 
running too rich. This could mean the unit and air stacks need to be adjusted/
aligned. Running rich is a common sign of a worn MFI unit (been there - done 
that!), trouble with the cold start solenoid, or, as has been recently 
discussed, improper temperature input to the MFI (bad heat exchanger or 
disfunctional duct work).

Needless to say, there could be any number of other causes for poor fuel 
economy as well. 

Best wishes for getting this resolved.

Bill Hutton
1971 911E #0038


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 23:26:32 -0500 (EST)
From: tstaples@ichange.com (Tony Staples)
Subject: Re: need to buy a radar detector

William Cianco writes:
>Fellows
>
>From:just got my second speeding ticket since I bought my 911SC 18 
months  
>ago.
>
> need to buy a radar detector.  
>
>
>What's the best one on the market for the price?

First of all, the price is irrelevant.  Any radar detector is far 
cheaper than the additional insurance charges of a ticket spread over 
three years.

As far as detectors go, every test review I have recently seen rates the
 Valentine One Radar Locator as head and shoulders above everything 
else.  Integrated Laser, multiple bogey tracking and a remote display 
are some of its trick features.  I have two of these and as Karl Maulden
 would say: "Don't leave home without it."  I bought my first one when 
they first came out in '92.  Bought my wife one for her new Chrysler 
Cirrus, and I'm getting ready to order a third so I don't have to 
shuffle mine from my Pickup to my P-car.  I have a major leadfoot (It's 
the lonnnngggg pedal on the right) and, thanks to my Valentine One, a 
safe driver discount from State Farm.

Mike Valentine (company owner), was the technical wizard behind the 
original Escort from Cincinnati Microwave.   He sold out his half of CM 
to his partner (business school dweeb) and went off and did work for the
 military until '88.  He then brought the "G-Analyst" to market
while starting development work on what is now the Valentine One.

I think the companies phone number is 1-800-331-3030.  The radar locator
 is $329, $399 with built in Laser.  The remote display is an additional
 $69 and it will keep those detector bunnies of your donkey so that you 
I don't have to "teach 'em a lesson"!  :<)  It isn't cheap, but the best
 never is.  Of course Porsche owners know this already.  Oh yeah, if you
 happen to live where detectors are still illegal, the Valentine One is 
undetectable by a VC2 detector detector.

Tony Staples
'88 911 Carrera Cabrio - guards red/tan (and a Valentine One)(and still 
cheap insurance!)



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 23:45:08 -0500
From: mac3d@superlink.net (Ed Dougherty)
Subject: re:leather care products

>Please help, I went to the store the other day to purchase a product to care
>for the leather seats in my 911.  Boy! was that confusing.  Too much to
>choose from, so I didn't purchase anything, and decided to post this note.
>What is the best product on the market to help preserve, condition, &
>soften, the leather in my car?  I live in Florida, the heat has been
>unbeleiveable, so I also need this product to offer UV protection.  Any &
>all responces would be appreciated. Thanks in advance:
>Howard

Try "Mothers" leather conditioner. I just used it on my drying-out leather
interior, and the difference was incredible. After 2 applications, the
leather softened up beautifully and the "dry lines" disappeared.

It has a peculiar smell, but that goes away in a couple of days.

For vinyl/plastic interior bits, ArmorAll makes a "low-gloss" that does
quite a good job. It leaves the dash top and whatnot looking clean but
without that artificial looking ArmorAll shininess, it looks almost like
buffed leather.

 -ed
87 951, Guards red
89 Doberman, Dobe red

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 21:06:27 -0700
From: mikew@cwo.com (Mike Willis)
Subject: re:leather care products

snip snip
>For vinyl/plastic interior bits, ArmorAll makes a "low-gloss" that does
>quite a good job. It leaves the dash top and whatnot looking clean but
>without that artificial looking ArmorAll shininess, it looks almost like
>buffed leather.
snip

Here we go, DO NOT USE ARMORALL on your porsche or anything else for the
matter. Try to stay away form silicone stuff on vinyl. There are many good
vinyl conditions that do not contain silcone. 

These conditioners will not be found in the normal places in fact I ordered
mine from Car Care Specialties 201-796-8300, IE Larry Reynolds.(He is also a
list contributor) They work much better than the silicone stuff and also do
not give you the "satin sheet" effect while driving down the road.

Also Larry has an excellent leather treatment and it works I used on my 74
carrera and it brought back the leather smell as well softner and protects
the leather from uv rays.

Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA

mikew@cwo.com

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 21:55:39 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: 944 questions

David Novak asked a couple of questions.

>3. What type of things should he look out for.

The advice you've gotten thus far is very good (i.e., get the latest model
year you can afford, 85 1/2 and later). But, if you run across a
low-mileage 1986 944 Turbo (951), it's a pretty good car but you'll want to
make sure the previous owner(s) took advantage of the "campaigns" (updates)
Porsche offered during the warranty period.

Campaigns included:
1) water pump
2) exhaust system
3) motor mount
4) clutch

There may be others as well, but these four alone account for over $3,000
in parts. If not documented with receipts, then discount the purchase
price.



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 21:55:44 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: C and SC

James Pasha said:

>To those of use that started in OLD Porsches, the term  "C" refered to
>356C model and "SC" refered to a "C" model with the "SUPER" or 90+ HP
>engine to the "C" NORMAL's 65-75Hp. You did pay extra for the priviledge.

Jim, you've got this all messed up, probably because of your tender years.

For the 1956 model year, the 356A came with two 1600cc engines: the NORMAL
(60 DIN) and the SUPER  (75 DIN). Beginning with the 1960 model year,
Porsche continued to equip the 356B with the NORMAL and SUPER engines, and
added the SUPER 90, so named because the engine put out 90 DIN horse power.
For the 1964 model year the 356B gave way to the 356C, the NORMAL engine
was dropped, the SUPER engine redesignated as the C, and the SUPER 90
redesignated as the SC with 95 DIN.

With respect to the 911, the "S" designation referred to "Sawing," which is
what the driver had to do with the steering wheel to keep the rear of the
car rearward during vigorous cornering. :<)



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 22:30:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: tfab@netcom.com (thom fitzpatrick)
Subject: Re: C and SC

How about "cool" and "super cool" :)

Thom

Thom Fitzpatrick & Amy Burgess
tfab@netcom.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 24 Jul 1995 13:13:40 -0400
From: Ronskian@AOL.com
Subject: Re: 944 pasenger side floor wet

Satyan,

I had very similar problems with my 87 944.  I'd get a spot on the floor
after it rained or I washhed the car.  In looking for the source of this
leak, I found that the drain holes near the battery on the passenger side and
near the fuse box on the driver side were plugged.  The water wasn't draining
from the cowling area at the base of the windshield.  I cleared the drains,
but that didn't exlplain the leak into the passenger compartment.  Under the
battery I found a hole in the metal about the size of a pea.  Water would
build up because of the plugged drains and was pouring thruogh the hole!  I
took some JB weld and plugged the leak, sanded it down and painted it.

No more leaks!!!!!!

Ron Boltik
Former owner - 87 944

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 02:51:15 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: General Question

In the good ol' fifties, they figured a race car would end up weighing four
times the weight of the engine.  That's good logic if you think about it.  

If it takes 1000 pounds of batteries to replace a 200 pound engine and 60
pounds of gas, you're on the back side of the power curve, so to speak.

Like the guy with his electric A/C, there ain't no free lunch.  The energy
you pump into those batteries has to come from somewhere, and there's no
guarantee that PGE (Public Graft & Extortion) or your local power provider
can be enough more efficient than your aircooled  recip engine to ever give a
return for hauling those heavy batteries.

People involved in airplanes understand what it costs to carry a pound.  It
costs $25 per year in fuel to carry every extra pound in an airliner.

Ed Heinemann of Douglas Aircraft, after building the amazin A-4, said , "You
must build in lightness."

Ralph Ricks   81 Vangon, 76&73 914, 51 Devin/VW, 1946 Bellanca with 6 cyl
opposed Franklin engine, 1934 Franklin Sedan with aircooled upright six.

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 05:09:55 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Loctite Query

First off, I promise not to use loctite on Porsche fuel injection fittings.

Does anyone have info on the correct loctite thread locker to use in
a gasoline environment?  One of the lead plugs fell out of my Weber
40 IDFs so I tapped it for a setscrew and secured it with Hydraulic
Loctite.  I've used the hydraulic loctite before on oil pressure sending
units (non-Porsche) with apparently good results.  I've never used it
to seal a gasoline exposed part and am a little anxious about it.

I use 271, 272, and 222 all the time but have never seen a good
application guide that covers all the loctite products.  Does anyone
have information concerning specifications or possibly a URL for
a loctite homepage on the web?

I was promised this information from a loctite distributor months
ago and am still waiting.


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 95 11:19:34 +0200
From: Trond Vidar Olsen <Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no>
Subject: Late 356 engines and more!

Larry Wilson writes:

    | was dropped, the SUPER engine redesignated as the C, and the SUPER 90
    | redesignated as the SC with 95 DIN.

Larry, isn't the "Super 90 redesignated as the SC" statement a huge
shortcut? 
I mean they had very little in common? The SC engine was much more a
hot C engine with Alloy cylinders (nikasil?) a hotter camshaft, other
carburettors (maybe just the jets?), counterweighed crank, bigger
valves? 

    | With respect to the 911, the "S" designation referred to "Sawing," which is
    | what the driver had to do with the steering wheel to keep the rear of the
    | car rearward during vigorous cornering. :<)

Then I've just became owner of a 911SS, the first
S is for Standard (as all '65 911's) the second for the Saw. Perhaps I
even could add another S for Sportomatic?? The 1965 911SSS, or even Triple
S. Porsche's answer to Datsun SSS, as always Porsche ahead (?) of their
time since the Datsun SSS's are cirka 1970-72 models :-)

- ---------------

I watched an interesting program about the Beetle's history on
Discovery yesterday.

It was a story about hard work and success. the Beetle (and Volskwagen
Werke) was actually the cornerstone in rebuillding Germany after the
second WW. 

They showed parts of the promotion films from the early 50, and they
showed a car climbing the Alps without effort, where Humbers, Jags, US
iron, and other water cooled cars stood alongside the road with that
familiar cooked radiator. The promotion showed the Beetle taking
*horrible* passes up those roads,...meeting cars etc had to drive out
on the gravel!! (...what were they thinking of????  :)

Another funny part was signs reading something like 'feel free to fill
up your radiator'  alongside the small 'rivers' along the
roads, and buckets hung onto the pole, so that they could be
used to fill water on the radiator.

They actually mentioned the Porsche Sportcoupe to be the only car to
have the same attributes, for good or worse.

Certainly in his wildest dreams (how wild can they go?) Hitler could
not have guessed that he would contribute in  rebuillding the German
economy,...after first trashing it by a devastating war. (among *much*
crueler merits!)

- -----------

cheers,
Trond V.

> >brakes to get a car off their rear bumper.  That car spun, went across the
> >divider on highway 101 and was hit by a loaded semi truck travelling the
> >opposite direction.  Tally: family of five dead, one little kid survived,
> >and the driver of the car that started this whole thing went to jail for 5
> >counts of manslaughter.

> being at fault. It is illegal to slam on your brakes for no apparent reason.
> When they investigae any rear end accident they try and detirmine if in fact
> the first driver had to slam on their brakes. So watch out if you are caught

That's a nasty story, but perhaps the tailgater should have been more aware
of the potential for such behavior before he risked the lives of his
family. I have thought about the culpability of slamming on the brakes, and
I assumed this was one case where "the driver behind is always at fault"
does not hold true. But it seems to me to be a simple matter of saying that
you saw an animal dart in front of your car, as there is no way to disprove
this. Nobody else needs to have seen the animal, and no such animal needs
to have existed. Mind you, I'm not advocating this, I just like to think
about all the angles.

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 95 05:45:01 -0400
From: "THOMAS R BRITTON" <britton@a1.esvax.umc.dupont.com>
Subject: RE: 944 pasenger side floor wet


Satyan,

Also check the "blower bay" under the hood. around the relay box and 
the battery are drain channels that can get clogged and the backup 
water will overflow into the blower housing and leak onto the inside 
floor area. You say it hasn't rained but this is probably from washing
your car. Take a garden hose and force out the dirt and stuff at the 
drain holes in the blower bay area.

hope that helps.

tom britton
951 S had the same problem once.

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 95 09:34:55 PDT
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: for sale: radar detector (Escort DSP)


Well, I've learned the hard way that a local police department
around here is now using Stalker radar (Ka band).  My venerable
Escort DSP is only X and K, so I'm selling it to upgrade.

If you live in an area that only uses X and K and need a spare
detector, or perhaps a detector for the daily driver, this is
the unit to have.

The Escort DSP is an extremely sensitive unit - it uses the
Motorola 56001 digital signal processor.  I think it runs at
10 MIPS, constantly analyzing incoming signals for police
radar.

It's a high quality unit, black steel case, leather pouch,
rubberized on/volume knob.  Controls are cleanly laid out.
Beeps (X) and braps (K) sound clear, not like the cheap video
game that some of those plastic detectors sound like.
It has all the standard features: highway/city, mute, auto-mute, 
dark mode.

Perhaps the coolest feature is the built-in security.  Every
150 hours of driving the detector shuts off.  It's permanently
disabled until you slide the "digital key" into the earphone
jack in the rear, enabling you for another 150 hours.  So, if
a thief takes it, it will do him no good when the thing shuts
down.  A "return postage guaranteed label" ensures return of
the detector.

Asking $125/OBO.

Matt Carpenter
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 08:20:05 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Re: Average/Typical MPG for 1973 911T w/ MFI

Regarding typical mileage for an MFI T -- I don't know whether mine 
is typical, but it seems to fit with the figures someone quoted.  
My '72T, which should have the same exact MFI, etc., as your '73,
currently gets around 17 in town, a little higher on the highway.
I've had it for 7 years, and it's always been about that; it seems 
to have dropped a mile per gallon or two over the last several 
years, either because of the stupid oxygenated fuel they sell in CA
now, or because of general deterioration of the MFI or ???.

I'd say 10-12 MPG is way too low.  You're losing some somewhere 
along the line.

- --Walt Thode

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 95 09:25:48 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Following Too Closely


This current thread on the rudeness of many drivers is getting pretty 
grim. Fact is, there are far too many dickweeds out there for all Porsche
owners to deal with. 

It is extremely difficult to tell who has common sense on the road. A 
neighbor lady who is quite charming and fun to hang around with is a 
terrible driver. As she puts it, "I hate cars." She drives an Explorer
with very little awareness. I have seen her scatter fellow commuters as 
she applies makeup or pulls up her phone. So what do you do? She waves 
each time I pass her on hte road, whether shes's on the phone or not.


There's at least 5 million more drivers like Loretta, male and female,
cruising the highways of California. I hope I do not have to meet them 
while driving. 

Just try to stay away from them. Drive offensively when possible, use
a warp factor that precludes them from getting too close or routes that
avoid the problem. Remember, eventually the odds will get them. Loretta
has trashed her Explorer twice.

Jim Pasha

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 11:18:52 -0500
From: Ross.Sabolcik@natinst.com (Ross Sabolcik)
Subject: HELP!!!!! Should I fear the 2.7L?

     Hello All:
     
     I have been shopping for a used 911 and I have been looking at 3.0L 
     SCs primarily.  I have been having little success in searching for 
     3.0L that seem to fit into my price range and requirements.
     
     As a result I have also been searching at 76-79 911.  I have read and 
     seen alot about the problems with the 2.7L engines.  
     
     *Should I shy away from a 911 with a 2.7L engine?
     
     *What are the necessary mods to a 2.7L to increase its life?
     
     *If someone has done all of the recommended mods (ie 11-blade fan, new 
     studs for the heads, larger oil coller, carerra tensioners) how many 
     miles (ie how robust) is the 2.7L
     
     All the information I have received so far from this group has been 
     excellent.  Thank you all for your input.  I really appreciate the 
     help.
     
     Ross Sabolcik
     (sabolcik@natinst.com)

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 95 12:32:55 EDT

Subject: 914 For Sale

Well it looks like I'm going to have to let my restoration project go.
Here're the details on what I've done so far:

'76 914 2.0L
 - Body COMPLETELY stripped and beadblasted
  Wheelwells slightly flared
  Completely reseamsealed and painted
  Red, slightly darker than Guards Red
 - Interior, light gray with dark red dash & custom console, with
  built in high speed fan for extra cooling, professionally stitched 
  marine grade vinyl
 - All suspension components powder coated
  all new ball joints, bushings, bearings, etc.
  new Bilsteins, 110 LBS strings, 20.5 mm H&H front swaybar
 - Calipers rebuilt, new SS brakelines, new 19mm Master Cyl
 - Tank powder coated
 - Wiper, Headlight, front blower motors rebuilt
 - Wiring cleaned and wire loomed
 - Both trunks lined with carpet trunk liner (b*tch of a job but 
  results are worth it) 
 - Extra sound proofing and carpeting (Medium gray)
 - The basic nut and bolt replating
 - Exterior trim and inner door handles powder coated black 
  (chrome stripped first)
 - New weatherstripping
 - Power windows (kit from Performance Products)
 - Currently engine and trans waiting rebuild (planning
  ~2.6L with short gears, pending more advice from Stan)
 - Refinished polished 15x6 deep dish 5 lug Fuchs, new 205/60's
These wheels against a red car with black trim looks great
 - Turbo tie rod kit
 - Short shift kit
 - Momo wheel
More neat stuff but I'm tired of typing.
When finished, the car will be better than new.

If anyone is interested, reply to strcklnd@aur.alcatel.com

Thanks,
Craig

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 12:37:25 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Insight needed for CV Boot replacement Please.

At 10:15 AM 7/24/95 -0700, Novak.D@eworld.com wrote:
>was told the procedure for replacing these CV boots is quite simple.  Do
>any o you have any insight that might be helpful to me?

If you're not going to clean and repack the joint, it is simple.  Remove
the four bolts holding the joint to the stub axle.  Remove the snap ring
retaining the joint to the half shaft.  Remove and replace the torn boot.
Reinstall with a fresh gasket.  On cars with four (vs. six) bolts, use a
dab of red Loctite on the bolts.  Torque to spec.

Before removing the bolts, clean out their socket recesses.  Make sure
you get full engagement of the socket bit before twisting.  They really
crud up, and it's easy (well, for me at least!) to yutz the bolt head.

>I am a bit mechanically inclined and have an OK selection of tools,  are
>there any special tools I should consider purchasing before I start the job.

You'll need the right socket bit to get the CV bolts off, either an allen
or triple-square.  I think you car uses allen head bolts.  You'll also
need the right snap ring pliers to get the snap ring off the half shaft.
I think on your car you have a pretty standard external snap-ring.  Some
Porsches have a chamfered design to their snap rings, which requires a
special set of pliers available from Snap-On.

>What CV grease would you use if this was your porsche.

For street use, any good name brand MoS2-based grease will be fine.  Bruce
Anderson is a big fan of Swepco's products in general and has recommended
their grease for CV applications.  I've used it and it's fine.

Kevin

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 14:31:51 -0500 (CDT)
From: Paul Christopher Schlesselman <schless@jove.acs.unt.edu>
Subject: Re: 951 Air Recircultaion


Howdy

This is control path for recirculation flappers:
vacuum from port at brake booster enters plastic line and goes through
firewall.
Behind dash just to left of glovebox door one of two electo-pneumatic valves
sends the vacuum back through firewall to the flapper valves.
An electic signal is sent to valves from the AC control switch.
Valve is normally off so you get no recirculation, and the other is normally 
off so you always get hot water flow in heater system.

THe electro=pneumo swithces can be seen best if you remove the glove box.
If the heater valve suts off you know that the valves are getting 
vaccuum, and the flapper shuld also sut (unless jamed from rust/debris).

> I was wondering if anyone know how to the air recirculation vent on a 951.
> I looked under the hood there apears to be two vacume activated pumps. Which
> close the vents but niether seem to trigger when the internal solenoid is
> triggered.
> 
> 87 944 turbo

- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
schless@jove.acs.unt.edu                        Perfection is Acceptable 
http://www.unt.edu/~schless                          
- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 12:49:11 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Late 356 engines and more!

Trond Vidar Olsen says: Larry, isn't the "Super-90 redesignated as the SC"
>statement a huge shortcut? I mean they had very little in common? The SC
engine >was much more a hot C engine with Alloy cylinders (nikasil?) a
hotter camshaft, >other carburettors (maybe just the jets?), counterweighed
crank, bigger valves?

Sure, Trond, Porsche made a few improvements with the SC like the
counter-balanced cankshaft with different mains (the S-90 went through main
bearings regularly), but probably the higher compression (9.5:1 versus 9:1)
and better breathing (intake and exhaust ports were different) accounted
for the 5 more hp (DIN) of the SC over the S-90. Both engines used the same
alloy ferral-coated barrels, the same Solex 40 PII-4 carburetor, and the
same camshaft. So, I don't think "redesignated" is a "huge" shortcut. Maybe
a tiny one, but for most P'philers, it's fine since they'd flunk a
flash-card test of 356 models anyway.

Henry Elfrink Manual (Fourth Edition, 1968) gives a detailed comparison of
both engines. Elfrink has always been THE BIBLE for me ever since I picked
up my 1961 356B coupe at Sonauto.



------------------------------

Date:         Tue, 25 Jul 95  15:56:48 EDT
From: Tom Blue <tblue@STATE.VT.US>
Subject:      Following too --- vs.  Road Manners

Perhaps I've been living rural Vermont too long, but I'd like to extend on Jim
Pasha's latest on this topic.  We have our rude folks here too, but it goes for
BOTH sides.  I once saw a white Mercedes "crowding" a farmer on his tractor on
Rt 100 (a rural two lane through the center of the state) til the farmer pulled
over towards the shoulder so he could pass.  As the Mercedes was going by the
farmer turned on the PO driver to the MANURE SPREADER and the the Mercedes a
real (not totally undeserved) present.  On the other hand I too have been the
object of contempt from the joker who wouldn't let me pass or back in while
there was a semi in the oncoming lane.  And the stories can go on and on.

I suspect however that many of us miss the point that "basic road courtesy"
is really not a bad concept.  If we don't crowd too close and are constantly
watching what is going around us we can generally avoid any too serious a
confrontation -- whether it be another driver or deer/moose/cow/horse, etc.
(as I've seen accidents involving all of them).  Don't get me wrong as the
states attorney said several years ago "Mr. Blue your driving record is a
little spotty"  (I don't currently have any points though).  In the end, I
really don't think the strain on the ego is worth the high blood pressure
or worse.  So when the road is clear I drive for the fun of it, and if there
is any risk it is to me.  Fortunately, I have that luxury in Vermont on an
empty stretch of asphalt through the farms and the mountains or just down
the interstate.  But I still have to be on the lookout for the individual
(grandmother, tourist or farmer with a trackor around the bend) who pulls out
in from of me only to go 25 regardless that the posted speed is 50!

It is easy for me to say not to push too hard, and I felt the way many of you
do when I was commuting between NYC and North Jersey on the Parkway or Cross
Bronx, etc.  But precaution still seems to be the most prudent approach.  It
is like the first rule of sailing -- "the skipper must at all times take any
reasonable course to avoid a collision".  It doesn't help you feel better if
you had the right-of-way, and got hit.  There are some things even insurance
coverage (yours or theirs) won't make up for.  So the next time some uncooth
ill-mannered cretin intrudes into your space -- back off and let him go.  It
isn't worth the mental or physical price.  Let us set the better example.

Enough bandwidth from me.  Enjoy the day.

Vermont Dept. of Social Welfare  || Home:  Box 1235 Rt # 1
103 S. Main St.                  ||        Waterbury, VT  05676
Waterbury, VT  05676             ||
(802) 241-2850 || Fax: 241-2830  ||    (802) 244-6498

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 13:51:02 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Porschephiles gathering in Monterey

The consensus seems to be that London Bridge would be a better meeting
place than Hog's Breath Inn for our Monterey Historic weekend
Porschephiles gathering.  Here are directions to London Bridge from
elliot.entin@alphatech.com:

  Follow signs to Fisherman's Wharf and Cannery Row.  Wharf 2 is just
  before Fisherman's Wharf, off of Del Monte (note Naval Postgraduate
  School borders Del Monte about .75 miles from Wharf 2 turn-off).  
  Tony Roma's, the chain barbecue steak restaurant) is a large round 
  building with windows all around (easy to see from the road).  
  London Bridge Pub is below Tony Roma's.  There is a large parking 
  area in front of and around Wharf 2 and Fisherman's Wharf.

I think we'd settled on Saturday night, August 19, around 7 PM as the
best time for the most people.  We've got something like 8-10 people 
who have expressed interest.  Anyone else, feel free to join us.

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 95 16:55:41 TZ
From: Harvey Yancey <harveyy@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: improvements to a 71 911T

Hi Dan,

I recently bought a 1973 911T and have made several "upgrades"
and improvements, principally the seats and door panels.

I purchased and installed Recaro SE seats with updated belts
and retractors.  It ran about $1000 ... best money you will ever
spend.  I kept the original seats in case the next owner wanted
them.

As far stereos go, you should be able to find something to fit without
cutting up the dash.  You can put speakers in the lower door panels
as there are already holes there.  I bought some updated aftermarket
door panels (after I found out how much original parts would cost)
and cut holes in them instead of the originals.

The max size wheels that you'll probably be able to go with is
7x15's according to all my friends on this alias,  but that will
vary from car to car.

IMHO practicality is more important than originality unless you are
talking about a low volume, high $$$ machine like an RS Carrera.
I bought mine to drive and to have fun.  If that means being not
"original", so be it.

Hope this helps ...

harveyy@microsoft.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 14:47:33 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: 914-Alignment Help

> 
> Can someone set me straight on the best height front/rear and alignment
> specs for a street only 73-914...it has Bilstein all corners and 195/65/15
> tires...I have read Ray Skaggs book and the Stoddard report in Pano and
> I still have questions.....like how low before bump steer sets in.....
> should the rake be so the front is higher or lower than rear...is there
> a European stock setting that is different from US because of bumper
> laws that would be best..no racing in this baby just backroad twisties..
> HELP!...Thanks
> 

Would you settle for a bunch of opinions instead?  Well too bad, I'm
going to say them anyway.

#1: Rake.  No.  Car should sit dead level.
#2: European.  No.  They is *all* the same.
#3: Height.  No strict rule here.  High enough to fit over the
    speed bumps.

I usually measure the height via the "Automotion Methode":  Measure
the distance between the TOP of the wheel, and the bottom of the rear
fender lip.  With a stock body, this should be between 2.5 and 3.5
inches.  If the fenders have been modified, this will change.

Next, measure the height at the four jacking points.  They should
all be equal.  If none of them have ever been bent, that is.  (which
is kind of rare.)

Bump steer happens when the front suspension is set too low.  The
verticle (sp?) displacement along the tie-rod ends becomes too great,
as the body is now lower.  So the steering rack is moved up to compensate.
You should not be seeing bump-steer on a car that is a a "street" height.

Hope this helps,
Gary.

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 14:03:49 -0700
From: kelleyad@loop.com (Bill Kelley)
Subject: Re: Porsche Pictures

>  I work about ten yards away from a very nice full color scanner and
>would like to start compiling a colection of Porsche images for you guys to
>play with.
>        My questionb is whether it is illegal or not to scan images out of
>magazines and make them available to others on the internet?

>I have a couple already and am just waiting to here a verdict on this-

Well, chances are the sources are copyrighted. Which means the pictures
are copyrighted.

Magazines license these images for specific use from the photographers, who
retain ownership.

So the bottom line is that you could be sued by two different entities.

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 17:24:26 -0500
From: red@tam2000.tamu.edu (Thomas)
Subject: Who wants there P-Car pictures scanned???

Howdy fellow Porschephiles,
        Since it's summer time and I'm kinda bored I am gonna offer to scan
pictures of your porsche and maintain a database of them on my WWW server
(http://cba-ip-gen.tamu.edu/) 

The details are as follows:

Rules:
        -I will scan no more than two images per Porsche
        -There is no limit to the number of Porsches you can have scanned
        -The pictures must be photographs and not copyrighted
        -I will display the pictures on a Porschephiles image archive WWW
page for all to enjoy and download, if my server has a problem with the
demand the pictures will be moved to a different address that is more robust.
        -If you want the pictures back then you must include return postage
and self addressed envelope
        -I am doing this because I like porsches and porschephiles
        -There is no charge because the scanner is owned by a state and
federally funded university and therefore you paid for it with your taxes
(thanks!)
        -I will of course except donations which will be put in my "I want a
911 SC" fund
        -The images will be high quality Jpeg's, the software to view this
format is widely available and even supported by NetScape 1.1N
        -I recommend that you have the picture copied before you send it so
that I do not have to take the time to mail it back to you and to save you
the cost of return postage and envelope.
        
Procedure:
        1) find a good picture at least 3" X 3" and no more than 8" X 11"
        2) Write your Name and E-Mail address on the back of the picture
        3) put picture in sturdy envelope with correct postage
        4) send the envelope to:
                        Thomas Eastham
                        600 University Oaks #E109
                        College Station, Texas, 77840
        5)Check WWW page often for your picture to appear
        6)If you do not have access to the WWW then include Diskette (3
1/2") and I will mail your picture back to you.

Disclaimer:
        I make absolutely no guarantees about anything!  I only promise to
do my very very best.

The offer is good until August 28th, so get those pictures in!

antenna for a 68 911L.  I've checked w/ most of the big names places 
and they seem to only have the black one.  They seem to miss the point 
on OEM...  sigh.

Next, many moons ago, I had asked about '85 928S rear wheel bearings. I 
got all sorts of tips and would like to thank all those that responded. 
 Now, I gotta 'nother question.  Despite the odds, the bearing was shot 
and I've picked up another one (tain't cheap!) But, I'm shipping this 
thing to my dad in the Middle East where parts, for some reason, are 
quite scarce...  Are there any seals/gaskets that I should drop in the 
air-mail package just in case the old ones are shot?

Third, as another baseline for gas milage on older cars, keeping in 
mind that mine has Webers, I'm getting a notch over 21 mpg if I spend 
it all on the highway (or The Beltway) and around 13~14 when I'm 
fartin' around Northern Virginia (Potmac Mills and Old Town Alexandria 
for those that are truly curious :^)).

Which brings me to autocrosses(ing?) in Northern VA.  This 
up-and-coming weekend will offer:

July 29th: The Porsche-Corvette challenge at NOVA Comm College -  
Manassas (66 to 234 North, then a back parking lot, jest listen for the 
roar and watch for low flying cones...).

On the 30th: The Corvette-Porsche challenge at Old Dominion Speedway.  

This is a mutal admiration club thing between Potomac PCA and the 
corresponding 'vette club.  

If any one wants some digital snaps of their wheels,  I hope to 
'acquire' one of them there fancy Digital Nikon/Kodak cameras.  I think 
I can squash an image on to a single floppy - may have to live w/o the 
16 million colors though; I'm not going to know until Friday night.  
NOTE: It's all gonna depend on the heat, it's been pretty brutal the 
last few days and I don't know if the laptop would appreciate the 
enivronment.

Scott Sawran

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 16:29:16 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Re: improvements to a 71 911T


Dan Jansen <dan@fibecin2.flight.wpafb.af.mil> said:

> I just bought my first Porsche two days ago and ,
> as the subject would imply, it is a 1971 911T
> Targa and its so cool.  However there are some
> things I'd like to change about it and after two
> days of this list I am having trouble deciding
> what is more important- authenticity or
> practicality.
> 
> I'd like to add the auto-retracting seatbelts for
> convenience and some sport seats with greater
> support from a later model.  I want to add my CD
> player but don't want to cut up the dash and dont
> know where to add speakers.  I'd like bigger
> wheels and tires and maybe a sway bar or two.

My '72 has "auto-retracting seatbelts" and I guess I thought
they were not new on that year.  In any case, I'd certainly
add them in a minute with no concern about authenticity.

My car came to me with strange Pioneer speakers on the back
deck panel.  They're ugly as sin, but I haven't had the
energy to replace them.  Speakers in the front door 
pockets are common, but I bet there are other places they
can be put.  You can probably find a CD player that fits in
the available radio slot if you look a bit.

I've been able to run 205-60x15's on my car, which came to
me with 7" wide wheels.  It's close to rubbing on the
fenders, but OK.  If you don't flare the fenders, no harm
is done to resale.

> Would these kind of modifications ruin the value
> of this cool car?

No, if for no other reason than they can probably all be 
put back the way it came.  But most people would want some
or all of what you mention, in my opinion.

> Also, I am planning on using this car as a daily
> driver and my sole means of transportation- until
> winter if i buy a 4x4.  Is this prudent or had I
> better make plans to be in the shop alot?

I've been using my '72 as a daily driver for seven years.
I'm in San Diego, where that may be more practical than
in snowbound areas.  I've had no real problems except for 
the top-end rebuild I knew was needed when I bought it.  
These cars are reliable!

- --Walt Thode

Date: Thu, 20 Jul 1995 11:37:53 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: 914: Brighter headlights?

On Thu, 20 Jul 1995, Thwen Chaloemtiarana wrote:

> What are the options for replacing my headlights with brighter ones ('73 914)?  
> Currently when I'm on a road with no streetlights I don't have enough light to 
> see very well.  So I end up being one of those people I hate who run their 
> fog/driving lights when it's a clear night.  (and yes, fog/driving light 
> thread, they _definitely_ make a difference in my case--especially when driving 
> on a curvy road through a wooded area with no streetlights)
I would go with the H-4's I'm not sure if the 914 headlights are the same 
as the other VW air-cooled headlights (engine that is, the lights are 
gnat cooled I think... because that seems to be where they all collect), 
but if they are, look through Hot VWs and you can get pretty good prices 
on them. ('roundabout $15/ea) I'm going to put them on my Bug, and we're 
considering upgrading all the other cars to H-4 (the Porsche has some 
strange Euro lights that are at least as powerful as the H4's, if not 
more, and no, they aren't street legal, but who cares?)
 -Derek

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 1995 20:45:45 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: 69 vs 76 912

I have an engine, with mount, from a 912E.  It is a long bar, and totally
different from the early 912.  I believe the 914 engine I saw in an early 912
had just a simple piece of 3/16 x 2" steel bar about two feet long bolted
upright (2" side) onto the end of the 914 engine.  It did not look too tough,
and should be a very good combo.

FYI:  I have 912E engine for sale, complete with tin and mount and exhaust.
  It's apart.

Rgds, Ralph Ricks

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 00:58:43 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914: Brighter headlights?

Get a  igital voltmeter and check the power to your headlights, and
especially the ground.  Run a long wire from the front to the battery, and
check for voltage drop to the brown wire from the headlight.

I've been driving 914's for 16 years, and never had a complaint about the
hedlights.   

BTW:  city drivers showing off their driving lights are a particular
aggravation to me in the low 914.  Even worse are the yuppie 4WD shopping
carts with their high headlights in my mirror.

Ralph Ricks

Porschephiles #1587                         Wed Jul 26 12:33:13 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 03:48:25 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: Shim for 356/912

Re: Special Endplay Shim for a 356 Engine.

      Though it is true that Porsche only made endplay shims from 0.8mm to
1.1mm,  I've got a few around .030". (and a few around 0.046").  If need be,
we can surface grind a shim to whatever thickness you need, though you
SHOULDN'T need a  shim grossly out of the range unless something ELSE is
 wrong- like a flywheel machined at the hub area, or a crankshaft that had
some dowel pin "work". Don't use the VW 36HP shims as these are both the Mark
of The Turkey and won't work as well- Porsche used only ONE shim for a
reason! (I just took apart a 912 engine that had been rebuilt in L.Al,
{scary} that had  three  40HP/1500/1600 VW shims inside!  The 
VW 40HP/1500/1600 engines use an endplay shim that larger in BOTH I.D. AND
O.D. It ate into the  Flywheel Main bearing Big Time. Story is in progress,.
(And I recently   took apart a 2-piece case where some idiot used aluminum
"shims" in the form of aluminum foil, behind the rod AND Main Bearings,
'cause he couldn't find the  right size bearings! It lasted a while, but
eventually the foil oozed out and everything went  to Hell.)
   
   Re: Real "SC"'s. Trond is correct- the Super-90 is quite a bit different
than the '64-'65 SC. The  Super-90 Crank, Flywheel, Heads,  Main Bearings,
End Play Adjusting Shim and Cylinders and Pistons are NOT the same as those
in the "SC". And that's most of the  engine.  Super-90's are my Favorite
Engine as they take special, unique parts.  Methinks when the "C" came out
the Factory just carried  the "S" of the 356B series over and called the
"Super" version  of the "C" the "SC". And don't  forget, "REAL" SC's have
Pushrods!

    Re: 912 Owner looking for an Oil Temp Sender- it is possible  to convert
the gauge to use  a cheap sender, but it costs almost as much as buying a
used sender. Let me know  what year 912 you have, as the senders are
different and maybe I can fix you up with the right one. Give me a call at
(408) 727-1864.

  AND: KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro

------------------------------

Date: 26 Jul 1995 00:52:44 -0400
From: william.anders@smc.com
Subject: dry cell battery for '73 911

  > I'd like to change over to the Optima 8000 dry cell battery for my '73
  911.
  > Questions are:  Where do I get one?  Will it fit in one of the existing
  > battery boxes? Or will this require some kind of "custom" installation?
  >  Will the existing securing strap still work??  Do I just disconnect
  the
  > battery on the other side? I would appreciate any advise on this
  matter. I'm
  > tired of the constant cleanup and corrosion.  Thanks in advance for
  your help
  > Please email me direct for I only get the digest version
  >
  > Steve Moore
  > '73 911
  > poorshdude@aol.com

  Steve,

  Can't help you with the Optima 8000, but I too was tired of the mess caused
  from
   lead/acid batteries.  I installed a pair of Gel  batteries from WestCo
  Battery Systems
  in Anaheim,  Ca (800/214-8040) in my '73 911 S.  They work great!

  They have 2 sizes that will fit in the stock  battery boxes.  The larger one
  uses the
  original mounting bracket, but the posts are too tall to attach the cable
  clamps to.
  In this application you would need to replace all the cable end clamps with
  eyelets.
  The posts are replaceable with a large screw or bolt.

  With the smaller size you don't have to change the cable clamps, however I had
   to
  stick a piece of 2 x 4 on top of the battery in order to use the stock clamps.
    In the
  future I plan on making some trick stainless clamps that will work without the
   wood.

  Either size of these Gell cells puts out way more cranking amperage than the
  stock
  batteries & the small ones way less.  So far I've been really happy with this
  set-up.
  Less mess, more cranking power & the Gels don't seem to lose their charge when
  the car sits for 3 or 4 weeks between starts.

  Good Luck,
  Otto Krossit

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 07:51:07 -0400
From: ChannellR@aol.com
Subject: Re: timing chain housing oil leak

Bob,
Thanks for answering. I looked in the factory manual and am not sure quite
how this would work. It looks like the gasket that goes around where the
chain comes in could be replaced without removing the chain or sprocket.(The
picture doesn't look like the gasket goes all the way around the opening
where the chain comes in.)
      The gasket and o-ring around where the cam come in look like they have
to have the sprocket removed to replace them. It looks like the bolt through
the center of the sprocket holds it in place with the cam. I can't see how
the roll pin in the sprocket does anything other than tie the 2 sprockets
together. If this is the case then when the bolt is removed to take off the
sprocket the cam must be retimed when it is re-installed(unless you are
*REAL* careful not to move anything).BTW the engine is a 3.2 Carrera if that
makes any difference. 
    I feel I'm missing a some crucial info. Can you help?

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 08:21:51 -0400
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: RE: Average/Typical MPG for 1973 911T w/MFI

Harvey:

When I had a new 72  911T (2.4) MFI the mileage was a "lousy" 14 MPG compared
to my previous 2.2L 911T w/Zeniths which regularly got 20-22 MPG.  All in
all, the early 2.4 911T's  were a step-down in drivability and mileage offset
by the modest power gain (plus the tendency of "full service" gas jockeys
trying to rip open the oil filler door before you could stop them !)

Perry.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 06:39:57 -0600
From: tgilton@micron.net (Terry Gilton)
Subject: Dash Cover Install


I just installed one of the ABS plastic dash covers on the doubly-cracked
dash of my '74 911, and I thought I'd pass along a little experience:

1. I felt guilty putting it on because it ain't the real thing. But this
guilt can be dealt with by promising the car that you will put a real OEM
dash in it when you do the windows-out refinish. The car didn't ask WHEN I
would do the paint...

2. The covers don't fit right out of the box, so be prepared to spend a
couple of hours working on it. You MUST trim a little at a time, attempt to
fit it, trim some more, fit, trim, etc.

3. Whilst doing the fit and trim exercise above, be careful not to cut the
leather/vinyl on the windshield posts with the sharp, freshly trimmed edges
of the plastic. I said I was sharing experience :(

4. The dash cover is too shiny. This can be altered, if you are careful,
with a rag and some acetone. A *light* rub with some acetone on a rag takes
the shine off just right. Put the acetone on the rag, open the rag up and
let a little evaporate, and then do the light rub. Try it on the cover,
underneath, before you install so you can see what it does. You don't want
a really wet rag; the acetone is capable of turning your dash cover into a
ball.

5. The cover is glued onto the dash with silicone glue (like RTV). The
thing actually fits very well when you get it trimmed correctly. The trick
is getting enough weight on it while the glue is drying. I have some lead
shot in 25 lb cloth bags, so I used 4 of them spaced evenly on the dash to
hold it down while the glue dried.

Once on and stuck down, the thing looks pretty fair. I honestly like it
better than the cracked dash, but it is only a cosmetic bandage and not a
long term fix.

'74 911

******************************************************************************
* Terry L. Gilton, Ph.D.
* Boise, Idaho
* tgilton@micron.net
******************************************************************************

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 09:02:44 -0400
From: Lou@GreenMtnSW.com (Lou Krieg)
Subject: Re: General Question

Allan N. Hessenflow wrote:

>Do they?  You can get room air conditioners that plug into a standard 15A,
>117V socket, so they can't be taking more than 1750 watts.  I'd expect a car
>air conditioner to be smaller than that, but then I don't actually know.

A typical room air conditioner may be 5-6,000 BTU. If I recall from my
youth the days of aftermarket air conditioners for cars, they were rated at
30,000 BTUs and up. So there is your difference of 2HP for the home AC vs.
10-12 for the car. Mostly a matter of virtually no insulation in a car,
plus the big greenhouse, and an engine/transmission which is also
generating heat which leaks into the car...(although that should be less of
an issue for a 356/911 than a front engined car..).

  --Lou

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 10:01:21 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: 69 vs 76 912

Hope I wasn't misunderstood.
The 912E engine is same as 914 2.0 engine except for type of EFI and tin and
exhaust, and that long, heavy motor mount bar.

Fitting the 914/912E engine to the early 912 will require a modification or
replaication of the 912 mount bar, which will have to fit between the block
and the fan housting.

Ralph Ricks

Date:          Wed, 26 Jul 1995 16:03:14 +0000
From: "Peter Remeijer" <peter@qv3pluto.LeidenUniv.nl>
Subject:       Re: 924 BUMPER W/ DRIVING LIGHTS

Hi Tom,

> I went out to the leindenuniv http: address on the INTERNET and downloaded the
> p-car jpgs on peter's home page -- thanks peter.  I immediately noticed that
> the 924 in the picture had drivin lights inset INTO the front bumper next to
> and inside of the turn signal indicator.  Was this a European version or a
> later version than my 78?

You're correct, it's the european bumper version. Although mine is a 
'85 model, the bumber has been the same in europe throughout the 
whole life of the 924 including th 924S. The lights will normally 
give dim light, and give only  bright light if you signal and the main 
driving lights happen to be down. That's only a question of electrics 
though, and would be fairly easy to rewire. As far as I understood, 
the different bumber shape was mainly due to the more strict US legislation 
with respect to low speed collisions. 

Peter Remeijer.
'85 924.

BTW I'm planning to put more 924 photo's on my page in the coming few 
days including some snapshots taken at the Nurburgring we visited 
last year together with the dutch Porsche Clubs. (We even have a 
dedicated 924 club in the Netherlands ! )

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 11:02:03 -0500 (CDT)
From: Chuck Campbell <campbell@Starbase.NeoSoft.COM>
Subject: Re: 911 wont start when hot?

I recently had this problem.  It turned out to be wear in the commutator
bushings of the starter motor.  When hot, the outer race expanded, allowing
the brushes to ground and the starter motor would not spin until cool.

Solution, replaced the starter and all is well.

I don't know if this is your problem or not.

 -chuck

1983 911 Cabriolet (Guards Red)
> 
> I remember earlier in the list everyone was talking about a 911 that
> wouldn't start when hot.  What was the conclusion? Was it vapor lock like
> in a 914? A hot start valve? Something else? My car has the same problem
> and I need to fix it because it is really frustrating.  The car runs
> perfect but as soon as you depend on it and go into a store or something
> the thing wont start.
> Thanks in advance
> Andrew George

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 11:42:20 -0500 (CDT)
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)
Subject: 911 electrical problem

I have an annoying minor electrical "feature" on my '87 911 targa.
If you open either door, front lid, or rear lid, the radio loses
its memory and the clock stops.  It doesn't matter whether the
engine is running or not, or even if the key is in the ignition.
For a while, turning on the dome light caused the radio to reset
and the clock to stop.  But now, the dome light, trunk light, and
engine bay light all don't work.

Any suggestions?

- -- 
mike
mjt@adc.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 09:57:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: 911 electrical problem

> 
> I have an annoying minor electrical "feature" on my '87 911 targa.
> If you open either door, front lid, or rear lid, the radio loses
> its memory and the clock stops.  It doesn't matter whether the
> engine is running or not, or even if the key is in the ignition.
> For a while, turning on the dome light caused the radio to reset
> and the clock to stop.  But now, the dome light, trunk light, and
> engine bay light all don't work.
> 
> mike
> mjt@adc.com
> 

I think I know what's going on...  (I used to be a stereo installer *YEARS*
ago, and did an installation that had a similar problem)

The "always" power lead for the radio is connected to the dome light
power on the groung side.

The "always" power lead is the one that keeps the memory/clock alive.

The dome light "ground" side will have 12V on it unless the doors
are open, or the interior light is on.

This is a too common mistake for stereo installation; someone poked
around under the dash with a voltmeter until a lead with +12 that
stayed there with & w/o the key was found.  That lead was used for
memory backup.

Find that lead from the stereo, and hook it up to the fuse box on 
the suppy that comes straight from the battery without being switched
by the ignition.  In German cars, it's red.  (Or yellow.  Darn, I hate
being stuck without a manual.  Little help here guys?)  If you found
it hooked to a brown, or black with a green or yello tracer, that's
definately your problem.  (Ain't it nice that all German cars have
wires that are color-coded the same way?)

Gary.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 13:01:32 -0400
From: pigozzi@pilot.msu.edu (Bruce Wm. Pigozzi)
Subject: NEW General Question

I know there was a lot space given over to the with/without/AC question. I
just read three days worth of the digest form so I got it in massive doses.
BUT, my perversion of the question was never addressed.  

I have a perception, borne from driving lotsa different cars, not just
Pcars, that cars have LESS BREAKING POWER when the AC is turned on.  I've
noticed this in my 944, my Subaru SVX, a couple of Honda Accords, VW GTi's,
and even a Cadillac.  I've never forced the issue to a full blown test, but
I consistently sense that a car has significantly less breaking power with
the AC on.  

Is there any reason (I can't think of one except that power is being
diverted from the hydraulic system by the AC) why there might, indeed, be
less breaking power with the AC on? 

Bruce Pigozzi

Subject: Need Tire Info, Firehawk SZ vs ???

When I bought my '78 911 SC this spring it came with an oddball

up front and 225/50ZR16 in back.  The fronts have 50% - 60% tread,

rears was replaced after 18K miles (reason unknown) and the worn
one has about 24k miles.

The worn back tire is starting to make me nervous about some upcoming
trips (400 and 800 mi) over the next couple of weeks.  Looking at
my options I could:

a) Continue the one tire at a time trend and buy one more Firehawk for $145.
b) Ditch the whole set for four Yoko AVS Intermediate ($650), Bridgestone
   RE71 ($660) or BFG Comp TA ($540).
c) Combine (a) with a new set of wider wheels and track tires (many
   $$$ but deferred until next year).

The car is a fair weather daily driver that takes a few long trips
a year.  I'm planning to attend a PCA novice drivers school this fall
and expect to drive at several drivers ed events next summer.

I'm especially interested in anyone's personal experience with Firehawks.
They seem ok on the street but I don't have a clue how they perform on
a track.  I want to keep my expense to a minimum (I wouldn't waste the
bandwidth if it didn't matter) but don't want to spend another dime
with Firestone if these tires suck.

Thanks in advance for advice on solving my tire dilemma.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 95 13:16 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: NEW General Question

pigozzi@pilot.msu.edu (Bruce Wm. Pigozzi) ponders the imponderable:
=> Is there any reason (I can't think of one except that power is being
=> diverted from the hydraulic system by the AC) why there might, indeed, be
=> less breaking power with the AC on? 

Sure -- the cold air is denser, which makes your car heavier, therefore your
braking effort increases! :)

But seriously, I don't have an explanation, I just thought that I'd add a Fun
Fact (TM):  When I am stopped with my foot on the brake, and I shut off the
A/C compressor, the brake pedal will rise.  Not much, maybe 3-4mm (subjective,
of course).  My guess is the DME (or whatever you've got) can't compensate
exactly for the increased load, so the engine runs just a bit slower, thereby
generating just a bit less vacuum at idle.  Thus, less power assist, thereby
increasing the pedal effort required.

My US$0.02.  Feel free to flame -- they've got the A/C in the office cranked,
and it's *cold*!

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)


------------------------------

Date: 26 Jul 1995 10:11:02 U
From: "John Lucas GRC" <John_Lucas_GRC@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re:  Subject: 928 A/C

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               RE> Subject: 928 A/C

Mike Maloney writes:

>Hi, I have an 86 928S with a freon leak.
     << snip >>
>The charge lasted about one week. The compressor has
> what I consider too much oil around the pulley and surrounding
> parts and I am guessing that is where the problem is.

>Since a compressor is very expensive (new $1800, rebuilt $500),
> I wanted to look into getting the seals replaced. 

I've just gone through a problem with my a/c leaking too. Before you
spend a lot of money or time, I would suggest you go over the whole
system.

First, pull the air cleaner cover and remove the air cleaner.  There are
a/c lines running along the right fender and across the firewall behind
the airbox that you should inspect.  You may have to pull the lower half
of the airbox too (two bolts, no sweat).  

Starting at the compressor follow the hose to the pipe on the right
fender.  Then follow the pipe along the fender to the firewall.  Then
along the firewall to the fuel cooler.  From the other side of the fuel
cooler there is a short right angle pipe that goes to the evaporator.
Make sure that there is no accumulation of dirty/oily "stuff" at any
connectors ... if so, you have a leaky O-Ring and must replace it.

Be sure to get a/c o-rings as they are made specially for a/c systems.
I got mine from Eurasian at about $4 - $5 each.  Also, get a can of
a/c oil (compatible with the type of refrigerant you use) and coat
the o-rings with the oil before you install them.

Also inspect the a/c line running from the evaporator back to the 
front of the car (to the drier?) and the connections at the drier.

If you open up the a/c system, cap the open ends with baggies or
something to keep as much contamination and moisture out as
possible.

I had a dinged a/c pipe (someone had probably wacked it with a 
wrench when working onthe car) and bad o-rings.  Been great
since I replaced all the leaky parts!

I also had the a/c shop evacuate the system for a good 1 1/2 hours
as it had been opened to the outside.

If you don't find any leaks, then you might indeed have a 
compressor problem.  

Good luck!

John
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 13:29:51 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  Need Tire Info, Firehawk SZ vs ??? -Reply

Victor,

I would save the whole set of tires for spares.   Then, I would buy the
Yokos, because I'm a firm believer of them.  Yokos are good tires for the
enthusiast and the AVS tires are good street rubber.   All of them (Yoks)
get about the same wear.   RE71s are good, but the AVS are a better
choice for the money.   The BFGs are old technology, but they would
probably wear better (220 wear factor vs. 160).  

For track use, save your money for a whole set of wheels and racing
(read, shaved) BFG R1s.   Depending on the rules, use the stock wheels
for track and buy a different set for street.

Hope this helps,

eric
80 911sc (waiting for pay-off to do performance mods)
86 GTi (looking for another)

Porschephiles #1588                         Wed Jul 26 19:57:03 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 26 Jul 95 12:51:48 CDT
From: Paul Holdredge <holdredg@cae.cig.mot.com>
Subject: 914's, Chicago area...?

Hey all.


Is there any porsche events planned in the Chicago area? My shiny
iron oxide-ed 914 would like to meet some friends, and I might like to
meet some P-philes in the area. I'm in the northern suburbs. 


Second, is it just me or is there a deep divide between 914 owners and
all other p-cars owners?  I've noticed that other 914's wave at me on the
road, but only one 911. Admittedly, most new 911 drivers around here are people 
that might be happy in a lexus or similar, but it seems like some purposely
ignore me...perhaps because I'm not in a 'real' porsche. What _is_ the 
sentiment here? I don't mean to start a big debate, I'm jsut curious how 
other p-car enthusiasts regard the 914. I feel that it is a porsche in 
every regard. Except where it was built. And those dang little VW marks
on the windows....:)


paul

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 95 11:39:10 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Numbers in Windows


The trick of putting (or leaving) the ET you had at the drag strip dates
 back to the first organized and sanctioned meets of the late 1940s. 
Here was bragging proof of what you car could do in the 1/4 mile. A few
birds wrote their own ETs withoout participating, so we ignored most of 
them.

Larry Wilson wrote his age on the window of his Porsche once. No one 
believed anyone could be that slow.

Jim Pasha

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 16:16:18 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@mail.orion.org>
Subject: Re: Best material to learn 911 engine repair

I would recommend the shop manuals if you have the bucks.  The factory 
manuals I have start at the beginning of the 911 saga.  This is a lot of 
information in any terms.  Sometimes regions will purchase the manuals 
for members use.  Thus they can be shared.  Don't forget that the parts 
manuals have a lot of information also.  I would try for used ones.  
These pages are of Euro dimensions.  Remember this when xeroxing pages to 
be included in your shop manuals.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 95 16:01:03 cst
From: dougc@mails.imed.com
Subject: FYI: Gray-market Cars

  
  I was thinking about doing my timing belt in my
  '83 928S Euro. I asked my fellow porschefiles a 
  few questions, got good responses. I call my 
  local p-dealer. "The domestic 928S shop manuals 
  are not completely accurate for the Euro model, 
  and we can't get them (or any other Euro specific 
  parts) from Porsche. We also don't have the
  Technical bulletins for the Euro, Porsche won't 
  give them to us. Porsche doesn't recognize or 
  support the gray-market. We don't even have the micro-film
  to tell you what parts to try to order, same reason. 
  The tensioner gauge isn't made anymore by Porsche. 
  This is the last year for the 928. We're not 
  sure whether your timing belt has round teeth 
  or square teeth, we/you will have to look at 
  it to tell which one you need. The flywheel 
  lock isn't in stock." So I ask them, "If I bring
  my car to you, how will you know how to work
  on it? How will you know if there are Technical
  bulletins that should be applied?". "We can look 
  at it and tell. You're lucky Mercedes dealers 
  won't work on gray-market Mercedes at all." 
  
  I think I'll red-line my car and drive off an overpass.
  
  Sorry, I think the Lithium pills are kicking in now.
  
  How do people with Euro spec. cars deal with these 
  kinds of obstacles?
  
  Doug Cook
  '83 928S Euro, in desperate need a timing belt.

Date: 26 Jul 95 17:32:07 EDT
From: "Sean O'Neal" <soneal@lexmark.com>
Subject: Porsche 914 Body repair

I just bought a '74 914 1.8.  Its just got this little problem of having only 
half of a floor on the passenger side and a lot of rust around the underside 
under both doors.  It is, of course, missing both the inner and outer rocker 
panels.

In trying to find rocker panel replacements and a floorboard fix, I found a guy 
at an auto parts store who was willing to cut off the entire floor of a car he 
has including the inner rocker panels encompassing the cockpit area.  This 
wouldn't be too much more expensive to buy than the inner rocker panels alone.

I was wondering if anyone out there has ever tried to do this and if it was 
successful.  From what I can gather, rust in this area is extremely common.  I 
would like to know if I could get this new piece welded into my car and keep 
the car from sagging when finished (it sags ever-so- slightly now).  Please let 
me know if this is a foolish thing to attempt and what a good alternative is.

aTdHvAaNnKcSe

Sean O'Neal
Printer Development
Lexmark, Int'l
Lexington, KY
soneal@lexmark.com
