Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 15:04:28 -0700
From: Charles Wilson <charliew@sequent.com>
Subject: Re: Grey Maket Cars

I doubt if there is much difference in the
timing belt and water pump of a EURO and US
928.  The guy's BS'ing you.  Just get the
US parts and I bet they'll work.  Either that
or go to a generic Porsche mechanic (non-dealer).
In fact, if you find a good one (who is so busy
he doesn't mind telling you how to do it yourself)
he will probably answer your questions for you. I
have a mechanic like that.  If I don't mind waiting
a week for him to get to me, he'll work on the car.
Sometimes I choose to do that.  Other times, I ask
how hard the job is and what the gottcha's are.  He
tells me honestly and I go and do it myself.

Charlie

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 19:02:40 -0400 (EDT)
From: neil a kumpers <nkumpe01@fiu.edu>
Subject: seat belt surgery

Hi,
   
My '73 911 targa currently has properly functioning seatbelts in the safety 
sense, howver they only retract about 5 inches after using them. My 
question is- can I buy a used retractor from a late model Porsche, cut 
off the male part of the seatbelt, and have the male end from my current 
seatbelts stitched on by somebody with a heavy duty sowing machine? The 
only problem then would be the retractor anchor. In my car the retractor 
is held by one rather large bolt. If other Porsche use the same type of 
anchoring, I would then have no problem using a good used retractor. I 
figure by doing it this way I can save a fair amount of money without 
comprimising on safety (Before flaming me for trying to save money 
on a safety related item, please note that I would have the end sowed 
on by somebody with a heavy duty sowing machine and 
thus be able to withstand the stress of a potential accident.)

Thanks for any help or suggestions,

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa  

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 16:09:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: Porsche 914 Body repair

Couple of quick comments:

The cost of the labor is a lot more than the cost of the parts.  So I
would use *new* parts.  They are available.

Spend the extra bucks to get the frame stiffened.  Parts Werks makes
some nifty frame rail supports that work great, and aren't that
much extra labor when the car is stripped down as far as you will
have it.

The welders in this area prefer "domestic" steel.  Higher carbon
content.  And at least one metal stamper is galvanizing the parts.

(More opinions later, if requested.)

Gary.


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 95 16:09:06 PDT
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: I Need a Grommet for my 912

Hey all,
I need a grommet/spark plug wire holder for my 912. The Part # is
616.09.904 and is called a "Cable Holder". Carlsen wants $17 for this tiny
grommet/holder. They even think that $17 is a bit much but they don't
set the price. So I'm looking for a used one. It has a dual purpose, first it
plugs a small hole in the ducting and second it keeps the wires from
'floating' around in the engine compartment. Anyone got one they like to 
sell??? If not I guess I'll fork over the $17 for a $0.50 grommet...8{.

>and I need to fix it because it is really frustrating.  The car runs
>perfect but as soon as you depend on it and go into a store or something
>the thing wont start.

This problem is usually caused by the fuel pressure leaking down.  The
two main culprits are the fuel accumulator and the fuel pump check 
valve.  I would check the accumulator first as it is easy to get to and
replace (they are also relatively cheap @ about $40).  It could also be
something like leaking fuel injectors, I suppose, but I'd try the fuel
accumulator...

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 18:16:34 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: 3.0L into '73 911

Not too sure about a '73T, there is a good article by Fred Schroeder in 
Upfixin (Volume 6 I believe). I have fitted a 3 litre (upgraded to 3.2) into 
my '1975 S. No major problems, but a lot of details like making sure the 
wiring all lines up (there are differences and various control circuitry whihc 
need to be understood and then tested. I also fitted the fuel pump in the 
front (under the steering rack) which caused some extra work as I needed some 
new fuel lines and one extra wire for the engine cut off sensor. 

If there are specifics, I willing to type ad nauseaum.....let me know

Dennis Kalma

stayed back after that"...

The result - a 10 minute chase through highway and industrial areas with
the tailgater trying to run me off the road - literally. He came very close
to succeeding. I only got out of the situation after he blew past me on
a freeway onramp, stopped his car sideways on the onramp, got out and
started running back towards my car (to beat the living shit out of me,
and I'm not a large guy - he'd have had an easy time of it). Luckily
for me he left just enough room for me to squeak by and drive down the
highway at a pretty crazy rate of speed (and off at the next offramp).

I do NOT suggest trying this. The guy behind me was past the point of caring
about his car - he was trying to hit mine to get me to stop (he didn't
succeed though it was touch and go). The adrenalin still builds a bit when
I think about it and it happened about 6 or 7 years ago.

You never know what'll happen when you piss someone off just that extra
little bit. If he'd had a gun, I'd be dead.

Ross

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 18:59:34 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Wonky Mirror, new alignment problem

Thanks for the interest in the mirror question....the one where only the left 
right worked but not the "up down". Did a fair bit of digging, turns out the 
wiring in the mirror module is ....shall we say...inconsistent with the wiring 
diagram in the factory service manual. Finally noticed that there were 2 brown 
wires going to the heating element in the mirror itself, when there should 
have been a green/grey and a brown. When I traced the wiring, figured that 
Grey green = brown, and Yellow/Brown = Brown and then took the pins out of the 
holder and switched them around....it all works. Sure wish there was an easier 
way to extract the pins out of the holder though....took me an hour to do it 
with a tiny screwdriver.

New Problem: Took the machine on its first drive around the block in 10 years 
( I am a bit slow on my restoration stuff). Everything went great, still 
missing windows and have no licence or insurance yet so didn't get into 
anything interesting .... until. Turned back up onto the driveway, heard a 
"bending" noise, and when I checked, the drivers side front tire had clipped 
the edge of the front fender and bent it down a bit. Nothing which cannot be 
repaired, but now I am worried about the tire size/alignment and whether it 
will all work.

Specifics are: Hartmann 17" Carrera Cup lookalikes (7" I believe), Yokohama 
A008P's, 205/50 - 17, no suspension mods, however front fender lip was sitting 
at 25.5 inches above ground, camber still rough at this point, but I think it 
is about 1 degree negative.

Are these tires too bloody big for a stock '75 911S front fender?? Should I 
raise the car up a bit and will that help......any ideas out there???


Dennis Kalma

'75 911S with Kremer 3.2

PS just put in Recaro LSL's.....they are divine...

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 20:35:23 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: 951 Hood Shocks

Preparing for the trip to Parade, I decided to replace both hood shocks on
my 951 so I won't lose my head when I check the oil level. Being an alert
P'philer, I first checked out the 944.faq to see if there was any "trick"
procedure I needed to know about (I never replaced them before).

Boy, was I relieved to read:
 "5.4.6  Hood and hatch shocks worn out
           . . . They can be replaced easily. . . ."

Hah! FAT CHANCE they can be replaced easily! How do you compress those
babies? Who's THAT strong? And, at the same time, slide in the retaining
pin with your third hand? 911 shocks must be wimpier (less weight to hold
up).

I'm having the kid do it. I called him, and he asked, "You didn't break the
windshield, did you?" Hmm, I don't remember reading any precautions about
that in the 944.faq. Seems that inexperienced folk (like me, and mechanics
at a couple of the independent garages around here) want to push the 944
hood waaaay back to minimize the distance needed to compress the shock and,
in the process, the corner of the hood nearest each side of the windshield
moves up into and cracks it. No, I didn't do that.

Maybe 5.4.6 should be re-worded: "They can be replaced easily by Arnold
Schwartzeneger, if he has a helper to insert the pin."




------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 19:35:24 -0700
From: kelleyad@loop.com (Bill Kelley)
Subject: Re: Speaking of Speakers...


>Noticed the recent postings regarding speakers and their placement and
>thought I would see if anyone had any ideas
>for my problem
>
>I got my 88 911 Cab last month and finally got around to messing with the
>CD that had been installed.  Sounded like...
>well terrible.
>
>Looked at the speakers, Boston Accustics, and the cones had all but gone
>away.  Went to a local stereo place for
>replacements they said $500.00!!!  ( 2 rear speakers and 2 in each door
>panel)  Guy said they were really GOOD
>speakers, Darn I HOPE SO.
>
>Well I said go ahead and replace them... they started to but the new ones
>were round whereas the old ones where
>square (these were the ones in the door panels).  Of course you could
>still see the outline where the old speakers were
>mounted so I said forget it!
>
>Picked up a car audio mag and noticed, as the stereo guy said, that all
>the speakers shown had round grills :(
>
>Anyone here know of a good car audio mailing list where I might get some
>info on either having these re-coned or get
>other ides?
>
>TIA,
>
>Craig

Don't know what part of the world you are in, but Speaker City in Burbank
California is an excellent place to get speakers reconed.

However, they have the Vifa 6.5 inch woofers for $19.95, currently, and
they will blow your old speakers away (even before they fell apart) I used
'em in the doors of my 911.

All car speakers are either round or elliptical. When you speak of a
'square' speaker, either the grille is square or it's a multi-driver
speaker system mounted on a base plate that is square. Either way, I'm sure
reconing is the cheapest way out if you want to keep the original
configuration.

Personally, I'd go for the best sound first, and find a cosmetic fix (like
square grilles) later.

My .02.

P.S. After putting sound systems in nerly a dozen 911s, I have a few
thoughts on the matter that might be boring to the P'philes in toto, but
send me an e-mail, and I'll let you have it.

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 23:41:30 -0400
From: ChannellR@aol.com
Subject: Fwd: timing chain housing oil leak


- ---------------------
Forwarded message:
>From:	spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
To:	channellr@aol.com
Date: 95-07-26 15:22:46 EDT


You're right. The gasket that seals where the chain enters from the
crankcase does go completely around and you do have
to remove the cam sprocket in order to slip the gasket over
the chain.  You have to remove the cam sprocket for the gasket
and o-ring around the cam also, just as you say.  And you're
also right in that you would have to maintain the position
of the cam sprocket with respect to the sprocket with the hole
for the pin.  If you don't, you will have to re-time the cam.  But
I don't see why you can't maintain their relationship by being
careful.  But what if you slipped...?  Well, then you'd learn
to retime a cam!

I guess it may not be as easy as I thought, but I wouldn't
hesitate to tackle it.

Sorry.  I don't think I thought of all the ramifications
when I sent you that note.

Regards,

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 1995 23:45:08 -0400
From: ChannellR@aol.com
Subject: Fwd: Timing chain housing leak


- ---------------------
Forwarded message:
>From:	spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
To:	channellr@aol.com
Date: 95-07-25 13:47:49 EDT


Rob-

Good advice about buying a 911.  In it you mentioned
your oil leak-

>Fixing it involves removing it, replacing the gasket, and
>then re-timing the cam (not sure about this)?  Maybe $300
>including parts for someone else to do it.

The timing chain housing is sealed from the rest of the
engine in two places, one where the chain itself enters
from the engine, and the other where the camshaft extends
into the timing case.  The former opening is sealed with
a simple paper or fiber gasket which probably costs about
$2 or less.  The latter is sealed with an O-ring and a
paper gasket, which also probably cost less than $2 each.

Where's your leak?  Either one is pretty easy to fix, and
you can do it without having to re-time the cam.

 -Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu
'72 911E
'72 911T

You should see the car I saw the other day. It was a '77 911S with less than
40K miles on it. The sunroom must have broken at some point and the PO didn't
want to fix it. Instead, he removed the metal sunroof and used a piece of
plexiglass about 1/4" thick and about 1/2" wider and longer than
the opening in the roof. He then gooped tons of silicon along the edges and
screwed it directly to the roof with about 50 screws! It sort of looked like
aircraft construction techniques. Ugh!

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 22 Jul 1995 21:00:53 -0400 (EDT)
From: neil a kumpers <nkumpe01@fiu.edu>
Subject: Re: Early 911:light and mystery lever questions (fwd)


I tried sending this out last night but haven't seen it yet. Please 
excuse if this is a duplicate.

Neil

Hi Chris,

I have a '73 911s targa and can probably help you. First of all you don't 
have to tear the trunk apart to get to the speedo, or the other 
instruments for that matter. The instruments are held in place by rubber 
rings. If you twist the instruments while pulling on them they should pop 
right out. As for the bulbs, there should be a little round part sticking 
out from where the lights are. They are copper in color. This is from 
memory. just get needle nose pliers and twist those and they will come 
out as well.

As for the lever to the left of the parking brake, it's your idle 
adjustment (and cruise control up to 75-80mph in my car). When working 
properly it should be connected to your accelator pedal. It's used to adjust your idle when 
your engine is cold, at least in my car. I think you can access it by 
unscrewing the parking brake assembly and looking in the tunnel.  
Attached to that lever should be a plastic piece that should rest against 
the accelerator cable. Once again, this is from memory. 

You should really get the Haynes manual. It is pretty good for simple 
repairs on older 911s and it's only $15.

enjoy your car,
Neil Kumpers
nkumpe01@fiu.edu
'73 911s targa

On Wed, 19 Jul 1995, chris voigt wrote:

> 
>           1) How do you replace the instrument lights?  I've torn the >
trunk apart to get to the speedo, I've even taken it out. > But I still
don't see how to get the lightbulb out of the > gauge.  What's the trick? 
I don't want to break it > quite yet. > > 2) Next to the heater lever, on
the other side of the > parking brake, there is a short lever (about half
as long > as the heat lever) with a round, black knob.  I can pull > it,
but nothing seems to change.  What does this do?  The > owners manual says
nothing about it.  I don't have air > conditioning or aux. heat, if that
has anything to do > with it.

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 95 16:55:41 TZ
From: Harvey Yancey <harveyy@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: improvements to a 71 911T

Hi Dan,

I recently bought a 1973 911T and have made several "upgrades"
and improvements, principally the seats and door panels.

I purchased and installed Recaro SE seats with updated belts
and retractors.  It ran about $1000 ... best money you will ever
spend.  I kept the original seats in case the next owner wanted
them.

As far stereos go, you should be able to find something to fit without
cutting up the dash.  You can put speakers in the lower door panels
as there are already holes there.  I bought some updated aftermarket
door panels (after I found out how much original parts would cost)
and cut holes in them instead of the originals.

The max size wheels that you'll probably be able to go with is
7x15's according to all my friends on this alias,  but that will
vary from car to car.

IMHO practicality is more important than originality unless you are
talking about a low volume, high $$$ machine like an RS Carrera.
I bought mine to drive and to have fun.  If that means being not
"original", so be it.

Hope this helps ...

harveyy@microsoft.com





------------------------------

Date: Tue, 25 Jul 95 10:36:27 +0200
From: kevinh@hasler.ascom.ch (Kevin Holden)

Porschephiles #1590                         Thu Jul 27 14:54:43 CDT 1995
Porschephiles #1590                         Thu Jul 27 14:54:43 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 00:33:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: David Sanderson <biom@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: 2.7 L problems

I am posting this messeage for my friend who does not have e-mail access. 
Any replies will be forwarded to Dave. Thanks in advance...

Re 911 engine dilemma:

     My recently rebuilt 2.7 litre engine started to puff blue
exhaust after heavy acceleration.  Upon initial inspection it
seemed the valve guides had gone.  The repair shop pulled the
engine and intended to send in the heads to have them redone at
their cost.  However, on closed inspection it was noticed that
the exhaust valves had been hitting the pistons.  Also, one of
the pistons had broken rings and damage around the ring grooves.
 When I originally had this rebuild done, the stock pistons and
cylinders I was told were in good shape and so they weren't
replaced.  The repair shop is now recommending I replace all of
these.  

     Can you replace only one piston and cylinder of should you
do all six?

     What would be a good choice for replacement.  I wouldn't
mind having a little more power.

     During the rebuild I had the cams ground to a more
aggressive shape.  Could this be causing the pistons and valves
to collide?  

     My mechanic doesn't think the valve hitting the piston
caused the ring failure but rather, tired, worn pistons or maybe
bad gas or a foul fuel injector.  What do you think?

     If I am going to drive this car to the parade in Portland I
am going to have to make some quick decisions on repairs.  I am
however, reluctant to order new pistons etc. when I don't know
what caused the problem in the first place.

     Thanks for any suggestions.                              
Dave Hinton

...


David J. Sanderson, Ph.D.                 (604)-822-4361 VOICE
UBC Biomechanics Laboratory               (604)-822-6842 FAX
biom@unixg.ubc.ca

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 06:09:41 -0700 (PDT)
From: dough@netcom.com (Douglas Holtsinger)
Subject: Re: 951 Hood Shocks


Hi Larry,
I replaced my hood shocks with the help of a friend who put in the pin,
and I'm not very strong.  It's all in the technique.

I used my upper body strength rather than my arms to compress the shock.
I put my shoulders as close to the top of the shock as possible, elbows 
bent all the way back to my chest, knees also bent, both hands gripping 
the top of the shock, upper body roughly perpendicular to the shock like 
I was hitting a tackling dummy, and facing towards the rear of the car.  
I attached the lower mount of the shock and pressed down using my upper 
body muscles, leaning in as I went (easy part).  Once it's compressed, 
slowly ease up pressure on the shock until the assistant can get the pin 
fitted (hard part).  You could have the assistant guide the shock to its 
fitting.  It will take a few tries... it gives you a pretty good workout.

'84 944
Doug Holtsinger

> Preparing for the trip to Parade, I decided to replace both hood shocks on
> my 951 so I won't lose my head when I check the oil level. Being an alert
> P'philer, I first checked out the 944.faq to see if there was any "trick"
> procedure I needed to know about (I never replaced them before).
> 
> Boy, was I relieved to read:
>  "5.4.6  Hood and hatch shocks worn out
>            . . . They can be replaced easily. . . ."
> 
> Hah! FAT CHANCE they can be replaced easily! How do you compress those
> babies? Who's THAT strong? And, at the same time, slide in the retaining
> pin with your third hand? 911 shocks must be wimpier (less weight to hold
> up).

Date: Wed, 26 Jul 95 19:33:00 cdt
From: "Mohan, R Capt 57TG/TGOE" <MOHANR@tg57.nellis.af.mil>
Subject: Re:  Teaching the "teachers" a lesson!


I also recently experienced another driver attempting to "teach me a 
lesson."
I was following a high school girl, driving a lowered mini-truck (sans brake 
lites), driving in the left lane, with a closing velocity of 1.5 mph on 
right lane traffic.  I proceeded to
move right to pass (in a rental, not my Porsche), at which point, she 
accelerated until reaching the traffic in my lane, then matched speeds to 
create a moving barricade.  Meanwhile, her teen boyfriend provided the 
accompanying "I'll tell you how fast YOU can drive on MY road!" gestures 
from the passenger seat.  Rather than push the limit to make a point, I 
backed off to a safe following distance, and proceeded to follow 
her.....wherever she went.  Pretty soon, she began giving me opportunities 
to pass, which I respectfully declined.  She then put other cars between us, 
which I promptly removed.  After 20 minutes, she made a radical maneuver 
into a parking lot to shake me.  At this point, I figured she would think 
twice about who she pissed off the next time, so I let her go.

Bob Mohan

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 11:06:24 -0400
From: RedNineCo@aol.com
Subject: Re: timing chain housing oil ...

Hi,
there are a few places where the oil could be leaking from .one of them is
the least expected place.in the middle of the cam housing on the back
side.you will notice there is nothing there except what looks like glue or
epoxy.It is not uncommon for the strain inside the sproket erea to pull on
the shaft that is epoxied to this erea and get a pin hole leak.
If it is a leak between the cam tower and the chain housing you will need to
remove it all,sprocket,chain,tensioner,dowel pin,etc.
there is a rubber -O- ring that goes around a backing plate and a gasket
samwiching it to the cam tower,and these go over the camshaft and this can
only be acheived by getting every thing else out of the way.

After all is put back together the cam timing needs to be put back in
spec.Even if you could put the dowel back at the same spot on the spline you
would'nt get what you had prior.even with the dowel pin in place the timing
adjustment is able to mis adjust.0 7-.010 MM
Best advise is to check the opposite side and match it to spec.
If it is wrong valve slamming is possible,and off cam timing.

Just some caution

Scott
RedNine Co.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 11:23:12 -0600 (CST)

insert in the windshield gasket.  The old shocks came off after some effort
because they were already shot.  The problem I faced was that I could not
get the new ones compressed enough to install on the brackets.
Consequently, the hood is held up with a vise grip on shock method.  Any one
have a workable solution short of asking Arnold S. for help?

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 08:41:59 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: An interesting debate- to me that is.

> 
> Dear P-Philes,

> My recent purchase of a Porsche 911 has sparked a debate with my
> co-workers.  Is the hood in the front or back of the car or,
> similarly, where is the trunk?  Is the hood the front part of an
> automobile or is it the covering of the engine compartment?
> 
> Any opinions or definitive answers are, as always, appreciated.
> 
> Dan Jansen
> '71 911T Targa, Oxidized Silver
> Dayton, Ohio
> 

Asking for opinions?  Brave.....

The difference between "American" and "English" is that in the 
American language, it can mean whatever you want.

"English" definitions:

Hood:  Covers the head of the driver
Bonnett:  Covers the motor
Boot:  Covers the trunk  (Actually, Boot Lid)

that he had sold the car to cheap. and was holding me hostage for more
money.I gave in,only to have the dealer request more money to get my
title.(this was going in circles).I had only his misrepresented bill of sale
that state an even higher selling price than the verbal agreement,after
payment in full was received.
To make a long story shorter  I filed a formal complaint with the District
attorney's office and one at the attorney general's office.They inturn
investigated the matter  and put the RMV to this case.
This is the first time I have ever had satisfaction with the regestry in my
life and probalby the first time they ever did what they should have done
from the beginning.(when is the last itme you said the RMV realy helped me
out).They ordered the dealer to release the title or give up dealer wrights
and licenses.he refused so they did.

and penalties and finally broke him down.

afterall,Not to mention the date of  07/22/94 on the old bill of sale
and get the new one with 07/22/95(exacty one year)

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 11:24:37 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Lifespan of a 944 Turbo S

Hi All,

A common question that I see every now and again concerns the lifespan of 944
Turbos. At last weekend's Metro NY AutoX I met a guy who owns an 88 944 Turbo
S. He has 140K miles on it! It is still a daily driver. According to him, he
even has the original water pump! The only thing he had to replace was the
clutch, at 90K. I think that the shocks need to be replaced, judging from the
way the car leaned in the autox, but it did not smoke, burn oil, or leak
anything. The interior was worn, but the paint was still in good shape. All
in all, I hope my car can last the long!

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 95 10:11:56 -2400
From: Brian Mifsud <mifsud_brian@tandem.com>
Subject: 914 2.0 has Miss when COLD.

Hello All...thanks for suggestions...I still have problem but other areas 
have improved.  Here is what I've done/know up to now.

1) SPARK...good at all 4 cylinders,timing + ignition components all good
2) INJECTORS..all tested, confirm they don't leak, and work properly when
   triggered by good signal.  Have not checked fuel pressure.
3) TRIGGER POINTS..confirm good ON/OFF every 180 degress rotation on each
   side at connector.  Measured 1 Ohm resistance across "A" to Common &    
   "B" to Common when points closed...Points clean and no pitting.
4) HARNESS..checked continuity between ECU connector pins and trigger 
   points pins...good. Checked continuity between ECU pins and INJECTOR
   LEAD pins (all 4) ....good.
5) INJECTION SYSTEM...testing injectors showed no fuel delivery (when 
   cold) on #1 & #4, but good delivery on #2 & #3.  When engine warms up,
   I get smooth strong responsive performance.
6) VACUUM LINES... all checked/replaced/or trimmed back to "good"  
   rubber..noticed idle moved up quite a bit when all known "leaks" 
   blocked
7) IDLE ADJUSTMENT..noticed adjustment on throttle body was set already 
   for lowest setting.. MIXTURE ADJUSTMENT on ECU was maxed out RICH 
   (clockwise).  Have left each of these alone to keep the missing 
   problem (which only recently cropped up), isolated and as simple as 
   possible. 
8) GROUNDS...found ground at case seam near flywheel...disconnected,  
   cleaned all corrosion on connector and block reinstalled...no change.

Questions:

1) How can I check the signal while engine running at each injector with
   only the use of a digital multimeter?
2) How can I check the ECU in or out of the car to see if it is doing its
   job? (I don't have a spare known "good" one to swap out)
3) (UNRELATED QUESTION)..my '76 2.0 with Cat convertor has a sensor   
   plugged into it.  Is this a Lambda sensor?  I don't see any mention of 
   it in my Haynes manual. 
4) RELATED QUESTION...SPECIFICALLY which book has a good diagnostic guide
   to help me out here.  Factory manuals I have for other German Cars   
   don't help very much in model specific diagnostics.

I'd appreciate any ideas or leads any of you have...so far most advice 
has been SPOT ON and am hoping to glean more of these precious NUGGETS.

thanks
Brian Mifsud 408 285-9920

Employment:
To keep roof over head,
Mechanical Engineer at Tandem COMPUTERS
To dream
Mechanical Engineer at Ferrari, Ducati, Buell, Porsche.........



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 12:20:36 -0500
From: ricp@ids.net (james stephenson)
Subject: Know a Good Porsche Mechanic??

Can anyone tell me if there is a good, reliable and reasonable-cost Porsche
shop within one hour drive of Rhode Island??

I have experienced bad service, poor work and overpriced repairs during my
last four years of track events with my 911, using four different shops and
paying out over $30,000. In the past, the first shop (RI) repaired my
transmission, and it leaked. The second (CT) replaced transmission and new
clutch ( orginial from Germany). Then a clutch rivit came out, he wanted to
charge me again for the same work. 

In 1994, I used Autosports Designs (NY) which advertises in Pano (page 84
June) saying "How many mechanics have worked on your Porsche?" and stating
that they did great work. Hoping these claims were true,  I had them put in
a new (used 21,000 miles) Carrera engine from a wreaked car and do some
suspension work, and add their custom chip in the fall of 1994. First day, I
asked for an estimate, but did'nt get one for 2 months - after Autosports
had already purchased the engine. The total bill was $21,000 paid in Dec 1994. 

Then this year, June 4, the engine failed due to a bent valves while
accelerating to the rev limiter at Watkins Glen. Upon calling Autosports,
they wanted my car brought in ($500 flat bed charge for their associate's
truck), and they could determine what caused the valve to bend ( Overreved
because of bad chip? Or was the engine bad by being overeved before be taken
out of the wreaked car, or maybe by me in May?)  And, after getting my car
in their shop, Autosports said they were too busy to get it fixed right
away, but could do it by end of June. I waited and called every week and
finally got an estimate for $3,000-$4000 (plus transport and taxes) on June
29, and a promise to fix it by mid-July. Now July 28th, the engine is still
in pieces, and won't be fixed for awhile..Autosports now says reason for
bent valve- "overreved engine". Is this great service or what?? Spending
$25,000 with Autosports, and getting treated like a "mushroom" (keep in the
dark - and feed manure).

I am discouraged. What would you do if you were in my position?? Is this the
type of service we all have to expect in car repairs? Can anybody suggest a
better alternative within 50 miles of Rhode Island?? 
    
James Stephenson
Rhode Island Capital Partners, 115 Brisas, East Greenwich, RI 02818
Phone 401-885-4357 Fax 401-884-2255 
E-Mail address: ricp@ids.net
Home pages http:/ids.net/~ricp/home.htm

     (1.37.109.16/16.2) id AA200272869; Thu, 27 Jul 1995 12:34Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 00:33:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: David Sanderson <biom@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: 2.7 L problems

I am posting this messeage for my friend who does not have e-mail access. 
Any replies will be forwarded to Dave. Thanks in advance...

Re 911 engine dilemma:

     My recently rebuilt 2.7 litre engine started to puff blue
exhaust after heavy acceleration.  Upon initial inspection it
seemed the valve guides had gone.  The repair shop pulled the
engine and intended to send in the heads to have them redone at
their cost.  However, on closed inspection it was noticed that
the exhaust valves had been hitting the pistons.  Also, one of
the pistons had broken rings and damage around the ring grooves.
 When I originally had this rebuild done, the stock pistons and
cylinders I was told were in good shape and so they weren't
replaced.  The repair shop is now recommending I replace all of
these.  

     Can you replace only one piston and cylinder of should you
do all six?

     What would be a good choice for replacement.  I wouldn't
mind having a little more power.

     During the rebuild I had the cams ground to a more
aggressive shape.  Could this be causing the pistons and valves
to collide?  

     My mechanic doesn't think the valve hitting the piston
caused the ring failure but rather, tired, worn pistons or maybe
bad gas or a foul fuel injector.  What do you think?

     If I am going to drive this car to the parade in Portland I
am going to have to make some quick decisions on repairs.  I am
however, reluctant to order new pistons etc. when I don't know
what caused the problem in the first place.

     Thanks for any suggestions.                              
Dave Hinton

...

UBC Biomechanics Laboratory               (604)-822-6842 FAX
biom@unixg.ubc.ca

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 06:09:41 -0700 (PDT)
From: dough@netcom.com (Douglas Holtsinger)
Subject: Re: 951 Hood Shocks


Hi Larry,
I replaced my hood shocks with the help of a friend who put in the pin,
and I'm not very strong.  It's all in the technique.

I used my upper body strength rather than my arms to compress the shock.
I put my shoulders as close to the top of the shock as possible, elbows 
bent all the way back to my chest, knees also bent, both hands gripping 
the top of the shock, upper body roughly perpendicular to the shock like 
I was hitting a tackling dummy, and facing towards the rear of the car.  
I attached the lower mount of the shock and pressed down using my upper 
body muscles, leaning in as I went (easy part).  Once it's compressed, 
slowly ease up pressure on the shock until the assistant can get the pin 
fitted (hard part).  You could have the assistant guide the shock to its 
fitting.  It will take a few tries... it gives you a pretty good workout.

'84 944
Doug Holtsinger

> Preparing for the trip to Parade, I decided to replace both hood shocks on
> my 951 so I won't lose my head when I check the oil level. Being an alert
> P'philer, I first checked out the 944.faq to see if there was any "trick"
> procedure I needed to know about (I never replaced them before).
> 
> Boy, was I relieved to read:
>  "5.4.6  Hood and hatch shocks worn out
>            . . . They can be replaced easily. . . ."
> 
> Hah! FAT CHANCE they can be replaced easily! How do you compress those
> babies? Who's THAT strong? And, at the same time, slide in the retaining
> pin with your third hand? 911 shocks must be wimpier (less weight to hold
> up).

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 14:13:52 -0500 (CDT)
From: Paul Christopher Schlesselman <schless@jove.acs.unt.edu>
Subject: Re: Lifespan of a 944 Turbo


Howdy

I have about 125k mi on my 86 951 and it still runs quite well
not quite as punchy as the old days but it will still rock and roll
(had to 145 mph while back)

Gone through some parts though, 2 H2O pumps, 2 sets of Motor mounts, a 
clutch plate & oil seal, shocks, tires, bad hatch frame, various tidbits.

Until I had about 90k people though it was new, still looks new on 
inside, paint chiped and little faded outside (silver).


> A common question that I see every now and again concerns the lifespan of 944
> Turbos. At last weekend's Metro NY AutoX I met a guy who owns an 88 944 Turbo
> S. He has 140K miles on it! It is still a daily driver. According to him, he
> even has the original water pump! The only thing he had to replace was the
> clutch, at 90K. I think that the shocks need to be replaced, judging from the
> way the car leaned in the autox, but it did not smoke, burn oil, or leak
> anything. The interior was worn, but the paint was still in good shape. All
> in all, I hope my car can last the long!

> Barry Lenoble
> BLenoble@aol.com
> 89 944 Turbo, Alpine White (46K miles)

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 11:06:24 -0400
From: RedNineCo@aol.com
Subject: Re: timing chain housing oil ...

Hi,
there are a few places where the oil could be leaking from .one of them is
the least expected place.in the middle of the cam housing on the back
side.you will notice there is nothing there except what looks like glue or
epoxy.It is not uncommon for the strain inside the sproket erea to pull on
the shaft that is epoxied to this erea and get a pin hole leak.
If it is a leak between the cam tower and the chain housing you will need to
remove it all,sprocket,chain,tensioner,dowel pin,etc.
there is a rubber -O- ring that goes around a backing plate and a gasket
samwiching it to the cam tower,and these go over the camshaft and this can
only be acheived by getting every thing else out of the way.

After all is put back together the cam timing needs to be put back in
spec.Even if you could put the dowel back at the same spot on the spline you
would'nt get what you had prior.even with the dowel pin in place the timing
adjustment is able to mis adjust.0 7-.010 MM
Best advise is to check the opposite side and match it to spec.
If it is wrong valve slamming is possible,and off cam timing.

Just some caution

Scott
RedNine Co.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 11:23:12 -0600 (CST)
From: "thak chaloemtiarana" <tc17@cornell.edu>
Subject: hood shocks

I have been one of the victims of this "easily changed" hood shock
directive.  I did not break the windshield, but managed to ding the metal
insert in the windshield gasket.  The old shocks came off after some effort
because they were already shot.  The problem I faced was that I could not
get the new ones compressed enough to install on the brackets.
Consequently, the hood is held up with a vise grip on shock method.  Any one
have a workable solution short of asking Arnold S. for help?
Thak Chaloemtiarana                              EMail:TC17@cornell.edu



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 08:41:59 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: An interesting debate- to me that is.

> 
> Dear P-Philes,
> 
> My recent purchase of a Porsche 911 has sparked a debate with my
> co-workers.  Is the hood in the front or back of the car or,
> similarly, where is the trunk?  Is the hood the front part of an
> automobile or is it the covering of the engine compartment?
> 
> Any opinions or definitive answers are, as always, appreciated.
> 
> Dan Jansen
> '71 911T Targa, Oxidized Silver
> Dayton, Ohio
> 

Asking for opinions?  Brave.....

The difference between "American" and "English" is that in the 
American language, it can mean whatever you want.

"English" definitions:

Hood:  Covers the head of the driver
Bonnett:  Covers the motor
Boot:  Covers the trunk  (Actually, Boot Lid)

that state an even higher selling price than the verbal agreement,after
payment in full was received.

attorney's office and one at the attorney general's office.They inturn
investigated the matter  and put the RMV to this case.

life and probalby the first time they ever did what they should have done
from the beginning.(when is the last itme you said the RMV realy helped me
out).They ordered the dealer to release the title or give up dealer wrights
and licenses.he refused so they did.

and penalties and finally broke him down.

afterall,Not to mention the date of  07/22/94 on the old bill of sale
and get the new one with 07/22/95(exacty one year)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 11:24:37 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Lifespan of a 944 Turbo S

Hi All,

A common question that I see every now and again concerns the lifespan of 944
Turbos. At last weekend's Metro NY AutoX I met a guy who owns an 88 944 Turbo
S. He has 140K miles on it! It is still a daily driver. According to him, he
even has the original water pump! The only thing he had to replace was the
clutch, at 90K. I think that the shocks need to be replaced, judging from the
way the car leaned in the autox, but it did not smoke, burn oil, or leak
anything. The interior was worn, but the paint was still in good shape. All
in all, I hope my car can last the long!

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White (46K miles)

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 95 10:11:56 -2400
From: Brian Mifsud <mifsud_brian@tandem.com>
Subject: 914 2.0 has Miss when COLD.

Hello All...thanks for suggestions...I still have problem but other areas 
have improved.  Here is what I've done/know up to now.

1) SPARK...good at all 4 cylinders,timing + ignition components all good
2) INJECTORS..all tested, confirm they don't leak, and work properly when
   triggered by good signal.  Have not checked fuel pressure.
3) TRIGGER POINTS..confirm good ON/OFF every 180 degress rotation on each
   side at connector.  Measured 1 Ohm resistance across "A" to Common &    
   "B" to Common when points closed...Points clean and no pitting.
4) HARNESS..checked continuity between ECU connector pins and trigger 
   points pins...good. Checked continuity between ECU pins and INJECTOR
   LEAD pins (all 4) ....good.
5) INJECTION SYSTEM...testing injectors showed no fuel delivery (when 
   cold) on #1 & #4, but good delivery on #2 & #3.  When engine warms up,
   I get smooth strong responsive performance.
6) VACUUM LINES... all checked/replaced/or trimmed back to "good"  
   rubber..noticed idle moved up quite a bit when all known "leaks" 
   blocked
7) IDLE ADJUSTMENT..noticed adjustment on throttle body was set already 
   for lowest setting.. MIXTURE ADJUSTMENT on ECU was maxed out RICH 
   (clockwise).  Have left each of these alone to keep the missing 
   problem (which only recently cropped up), isolated and as simple as 
   possible. 
8) GROUNDS...found ground at case seam near flywheel...disconnected,  
   cleaned all corrosion on connector and block reinstalled...no change.

Questions:

1) How can I check the signal while engine running at each injector with
   only the use of a digital multimeter?
2) How can I check the ECU in or out of the car to see if it is doing its
   job? (I don't have a spare known "good" one to swap out)
3) (UNRELATED QUESTION)..my '76 2.0 with Cat convertor has a sensor   
   plugged into it.  Is this a Lambda sensor?  I don't see any mention of 
   it in my Haynes manual. 
4) RELATED QUESTION...SPECIFICALLY which book has a good diagnostic guide
   to help me out here.  Factory manuals I have for other German Cars   
   don't help very much in model specific diagnostics.

I'd appreciate any ideas or leads any of you have...so far most advice 
has been SPOT ON and am hoping to glean more of these precious NUGGETS.

thanks
Brian Mifsud 408 285-9920

Employment:
To keep roof over head,
Mechanical Engineer at Tandem COMPUTERS
To dream
Mechanical Engineer at Ferrari, Ducati, Buell, Porsche.........



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 12:20:36 -0500
From: ricp@ids.net (james stephenson)
Subject: Know a Good Porsche Mechanic??

Can anyone tell me if there is a good, reliable and reasonable-cost Porsche
shop within one hour drive of Rhode Island??

I have experienced bad service, poor work and overpriced repairs during my
last four years of track events with my 911, using four different shops and
paying out over $30,000. In the past, the first shop (RI) repaired my
transmission, and it leaked. The second (CT) replaced transmission and new
clutch ( orginial from Germany). Then a clutch rivit came out, he wanted to
charge me again for the same work. 

In 1994, I used Autosports Designs (NY) which advertises in Pano (page 84
June) saying "How many mechanics have worked on your Porsche?" and stating
that they did great work. Hoping these claims were true,  I had them put in
a new (used 21,000 miles) Carrera engine from a wreaked car and do some
suspension work, and add their custom chip in the fall of 1994. First day, I
asked for an estimate, but did'nt get one for 2 months - after Autosports
had already purchased the engine. The total bill was $21,000 paid in Dec 1994. 

Then this year, June 4, the engine failed due to a bent valves while
accelerating to the rev limiter at Watkins Glen. Upon calling Autosports,
they wanted my car brought in ($500 flat bed charge for their associate's
truck), and they could determine what caused the valve to bend ( Overreved
because of bad chip? Or was the engine bad by being overeved before be taken
out of the wreaked car, or maybe by me in May?)  And, after getting my car
in their shop, Autosports said they were too busy to get it fixed right
away, but could do it by end of June. I waited and called every week and
finally got an estimate for $3,000-$4000 (plus transport and taxes) on June
29, and a promise to fix it by mid-July. Now July 28th, the engine is still
in pieces, and won't be fixed for awhile..Autosports now says reason for
bent valve- "overreved engine". Is this great service or what?? Spending
$25,000 with Autosports, and getting treated like a "mushroom" (keep in the
dark - and feed manure).

I am discouraged. What would you do if you were in my position?? Is this the
type of service we all have to expect in car repairs? Can anybody suggest a
better alternative within 50 miles of Rhode Island?? 
    
James Stephenson
Rhode Island Capital Partners, 115 Brisas, East Greenwich, RI 02818
Phone 401-885-4357 Fax 401-884-2255 
E-Mail address: ricp@ids.net
Home pages http:/ids.net/~ricp/home.htm

Subject: 911C4 clutch damper problems

My boss has a C4 with a clutch problem.  Some liquid filled damper goes rather
quickly I guess.  Rather than put back in the same parts with the same failure
possibility, he wants to try the RS clutch/flywheel arrangement.  It's cheaper
too.  Anyone have driving experience with this clutch/flywheel.  His (and my)
mechanic says it has a pretty different feel.  Much lighter in weight, more 
revvy, he wonders if it will suit the driver on the street.

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 14:20:25 -0500 (CDT)
From: Paul Christopher Schlesselman <schless@jove.acs.unt.edu>
Subject: Re: hood shock installation


did you try to tie a leather strap around the beast while it is 
compressed a inch or two?

Hell method: 
get one 'shock' on (hood rases enough?) 
second one must be attatched at one end and carefully forced into  
compression against convienient spot on sheet metal
(push hood down to commpress--tricky)

while 'shock' oozes back out quickly pop other end onto second 
mounting location.

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 14:13:52 -0500 (CDT)

Subject: Re: Lifespan of a 944 Turbo


Howdy

I have about 125k mi on my 86 951 and it still runs quite well
not quite as punchy as the old days but it will still rock and roll
(had to 145 mph while back)

Gone through some parts though, 2 H2O pumps, 2 sets of Motor mounts, a 
clutch plate & oil seal, shocks, tires, bad hatch frame, various tidbits.

Until I had about 90k people though it was new, still looks new on 
inside, paint chiped and little faded outside (silver).

Porschephiles #1591                         Fri Jul 28 01:14:06 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 13:35:44 -0500
From: bill.williams@develcon.com (Bill Williams)
Subject: Re: 914 2.0 has Miss when COLD.


>5) INJECTION SYSTEM...testing injectors showed no fuel delivery (when 
>   cold) on #1 & #4, but good delivery on #2 & #3.  When engine warms up,
>   I get smooth strong responsive performance.

- ---Seems like the above nnarrows it down a bit...


>Questions:
>

>2) How can I check the ECU in or out of the car to see if it is doing its
>   job? (I don't have a spare known "good" one to swap out)

- ---Find a VW shop that has the type II/IV computer/injection system tester 
- ---(They're getting pretty old now). There are 2 versions (that I know of) 
- ---Procedures for using both are found in the factory manual. You unplug the
- ---computer's connector, plug the tester's dbl. sided connector into the
- ---computer and then plug the harness connector into the other side of the
- ---tester connector. This tester checks all/most? functions of the fuel
- ---injection system. A non-dealer shop that picks up parts & VW equipment
- ---when dealerships go under is your best bet. (While you are there ask
about ---old fuel injection parts that they might have around -ign
distributors, ---fuel injectors, suppl. air valves, trigger points,
etc...many VW parts are ---interchangeable, or are at least usable in an emerg.

>I'd appreciate any ideas or leads any of you have...so far most advice 
>has been SPOT ON and am hoping to glean more of these precious NUGGETS.
>
>thanks

- ---I'll check for further info tonight.

bill.williams@develcon.com

Date:         Thu, 27 Jul 95 16:27:23 EDT
From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SEAN@american.edu>
Subject:      Floor Clutch

Well, this is a new one.  I am driving my 928 around town a few minutes ago
in  95 degree weather and pull up to a stop light.  I put the clutch pedal
in and try to put it in first gear.  It makes that nasty no syncho sound so
I say OK, let's go for second gear.  The same noise, so I try all the other
gears.  It won't go into gear.  I leave it in neutral and let off the clutch
to try again.  The clutch won't come off the floor!  I unbelt myself and
reach down and pull the clutch up off the floor.  The car is fine.  I decide
that this is a fluke and go on to get my hair cut.  Well, as I'm pulling back
into school, going about 15 miles per hour, the clutch sticks to the floor
again!!!  I reach down as I'm coasting and pull it up again.  Once again,
it works fine.  What the hell?!?!?  Is it the weather?  THe engine was
running hotter than usual.  My A/C decided not to engage when I pressed the
button also, but this isn't anything new.  Help.  Anyone?

Sean  '80 928 (not as delusionarily happy with it as I usually am)

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 17:37:24 -0400
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  Floor Clutch

The clutch is hydraulic. There is a master cylinder, fed by the same
reservoir that feeds the brakes, and a slave cylinder, down near the
bottom of the clutch housing. If either one is leaking, it may act
like that. Check whether your brake fluid has gotten real low. Also,
yu can check around the slave cylinder for brake fluid - in
particular, if you remove the rubber plug in the bottom of the
clutch housing you can stick a finger in and feel around for brake
fluid. If you're lucky, it will be the slave cylinder - it is much
easier to change, since nothing is in the way of access to it. The
clutch also needs to be bled, just like brakes, if there is any
air in the circuit (and your symptoms mean that there probably is).

- -------

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 15:47:41 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: HELP!!!!! Should I fear the 2.7L?


I've owned a 2.7 for 20 years, and after a new case and pistons at
66,000 it's been pretty good.  I just had a new, more efficient a/c
system installed, and on the way to Fresno from Anaheim over the ridge
the temperature never went above 225, and mostly stayed around 190 in
hot weather with the a/c on.

If you change to an 11-blade fan with the 76-77 pulley ratios, this
will make a nice difference in engine cooling.  My '75 had the
11-blade fan, but it operated at a slower speed.  So if you have a '74
or '75 you'd be better off with the later pulleys.

If I had it to do over again when I had the rebuild in the mid-80s,
I'd have swapped for a 3.0 (there was no 3.2 then).  But since I
didn't, I've been determined to make the existing engine last.

All things being equal, you'd be better off with an SC.  But
frequently things aren't equal.  IMHO, I'd rather have a 2.7 that's
been meticulously maintained rather than a later car that's been
abused.  Condition of the body is, IMO, the most important thing.
Everything else can be replaced.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 20:01:48 -0400
From: rgrayson@atlanta.com (Richard Grayson)
Subject: Re: 88 911 AC Improvments

>I recently read in Bruce Anderson's excellent book, Porsche 911 Performance
Handbook, about a simple 
>air-conditioning vent that is said to more the double your AC's cooling
capacity.  This would certainly be a excellent 
>addition to my BLACK CAB here in Florida!!!
>
>Anyone ever tried this Wonder Vent (TM) thingy from Performance Air.
>
>Guess I'm gonna give it a try but, twice the cooling capacity by the swap
of a vent!  I always wanted an "almost" Free 
>Lunch, course I don't know what this thing costs yet, could be dinner at... 
>
>Craig
>
Craig- I don't recall it being called a "Wonder Vent" but I bought a product
from Performance Air about two years ago for my 1985 BLACK coupe in Georgia.
It replaces the stock air "deflector" that is under the dash, forward of the
gear shift. Installation is straightforward, you basically cut a second hole
in the ducting and cover everything with a dual air vent.  You now have
twice the volume of marginally cool air coming out. It still won't make the
A/C cold. (How come the cheapest  American or Japanese cars on the road can
accomplish this but not Porsche?) But it does bring an improvement. It's
definitely worth the $30-$50 cost.

Richard Grayson 
rgrayson@atlanta.com

1985 Porsche 911 (daily driver)
1973 Datsun 240z (IZCC #309)

Subject: My 911 is back on the road!!!

Well, after several months the beast is back on the road with a new motor!
I fired it up last night and drove it around the block!
The new motor runs much better than the first one.

The challenging:
    Working in a carport in an apartment complex.
    Getting the exhaust off and the intake manifolds on.

The ultimate bummer:
   Having the original motor and my tools ripped off when the motor was 
      about 90% rebuilt. How does that old saying go in Latin, 
      "don't let the bastards grind you down" (no permite que illegitum 
       le carborunden or something like that?)

The bizarre:
   The management of my apartment complex threatening to tow my 
      non-running 911 away two days before I got the motor back in.
   The automatic sprinkers coming on and dousing all my tools,
      manuals, and parts (e.g. distributor cap and wires, air filter)
      just as I was getting ready to fire up the new engine,
      as I was cranking the engine to get oil pressure
      
The high points:
   Working with Ted Robinson at German Precision
   Working with EASY (Porsche junkyard in Emeryville)
   Getting an amazing amount of help, info, humor, and understanding from 
       YOU folks. Thank you all, especially Stan, Thom, Bob S., Bob B.
        Doug, Bruce, Martin (where has he been lately anyway?), Bill K.
        Bill C., Jeff, Dave, and everyone else that has chipped in their 
        2 cents worth.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 20:22:57 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@mail.orion.org>
Subject: Re: 2.7 L problems

Hi David,

Lots of answers huh?

Did the shop ever do the valve job?  Well so much for history.  You will 
be doing one now!  When the pistons hit the valves the shock is 
transmitted to the stem but not in a longitudinal manner. (in line with 
the valve stem)  Instead it bell shapes the ends of the valve guides.  I 
have some interesting "s" shaped valves in a bucket downstairs to illustrate.

The pistons can actually take quite a beating.  If you wish or are so 
inclined you can have them magnifluxed for cracks and such at you local 
aircraft repair facilities.  I would guess that your camshafts needed to 
be carefully indexed especially after you had them reground.  A lot of 
mechanics look at the illustrations in the repair manuals and reassemble 
the engine according to how it looks.  Most pictures come from the 
factory manual and have the dimples in the end of the camshafts pointing 
down.  Well there is a lot more to it.  If the camshaft is not indexed 
properly or is timed late in the crankshaft cycle the exhaust valves hit 
the pistons.  The 2.7 motor cis piston had a big dome on it for emission 
purposes.  I would guess that you have this piston.  I don't know what it 
looks like with the valve depressions in it but you might now have 
adequate valve clearance.  Valves seem to stretch at higher rpms.  
Actually they just hang there till the spring snaps them back.  

There are several choices for replacement pistons.  Your choice of 
camshafts at this point may be dictated by your selection of CIS.

When timing your cams, try for the middle of the valve lift.  This will 
give you the safety of a little extra clearance for the piston.

Good luck in all of you endeavors.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 21:00:59 -0600
From: dkelly@iquest.com (David Kelly)
Subject: Re: FYI: Gray-market Cars

dougc@mails.imed.com crys,

>  I was thinking about doing my timing belt in my
>  '83 928S Euro. I asked my fellow porschefiles a
>  few questions, got good responses. I call my
>  local p-dealer. "The domestic 928S shop manuals
>  are not completely accurate for the Euro model,
>  and we can't get them (or any other Euro specific
>  parts) from Porsche. We also don't have the
>  Technical bulletins for the Euro, Porsche won't
>  give them to us. Porsche doesn't recognize or
>  support the gray-market. We don't even have the micro-film
>  to tell you what parts to try to order, same reason.
>  The tensioner gauge isn't made anymore by Porsche.
>  This is the last year for the 928. We're not
>  sure whether your timing belt has round teeth
>  or square teeth, we/you will have to look at
>  it to tell which one you need. The flywheel
>  lock isn't in stock." So I ask them, "If I bring
>  my car to you, how will you know how to work
>  on it? How will you know if there are Technical
>  bulletins that should be applied?". "We can look
>  at it and tell. You're lucky Mercedes dealers
>  won't work on gray-market Mercedes at all."
>
>  I think I'll red-line my car and drive off an overpass.
>
>  Sorry, I think the Lithium pills are kicking in now.
>
>  How do people with Euro spec. cars deal with these
>  kinds of obstacles?

Find another dealer. The information you have been getting from that one is
false. Just now I yanked down my 8 volume 928 set purchased 11-91 from Jim
Ellis, Atlanta (isn't it great when you tape the receipt inside the front
cover?). FYI, list price was $283.86, much much less than automobile book
specialists wanted.

Volume 1, page 15-6g (fist example I happened upon) is a table discusing
camshafts in various models. In addition to listing engine/transmission
pairs they often spell out, "USA, Japan, Canada" on some, and "R. o. W."
(Rest of World) on others, sometimes it says, "All". Also they often tag
the data with model years. This is typical thruout the manual set.

Its likely you can not purchase European camshafts thru your Porsche
dealer, but that's not the issue here. Timing belt, tensioner, etc, are
going to be the same. Its the European emissions stuff that we can't get
here. You do need to check the belt type, between 1982 and 1983 the belt
changed from square teeth to rounded teeth (I think I got that right) and
most with the old design update to the new pulleys.

Conclusion: There are no "domestic 928 manuals", only a single whole world
model with yearly updates.

'83 928S
(7) cats

- --
David Kelly N4HHE,   n4hhe@amsat.org,    dkelly@iquest.com

Subject: Oil Thermo - Got it

Hi,

	Thanks for any replies on the thermo removal.

	I was sitting there thinking, "ya know, they pay me big bucks to
figger stuff like this out with computers, so why can't I figger this
out?"

	I guess it was a case of premature exasperation :)

	I was so paranoid about hosing it, and I've hosed just about everything
else this week.  (Hint: try this as root at a unix command line: seriously!)
# find / -mtime +2 -exec rm -f {} \; &
	Oye!  I'm still reeling from that one.

	Anyway, I took a "disposable" pulley puller and a grinder and ground
the L on one of the arms a bit thinner, and then used that to pry a tad
and it came out faster than a welfare baby :)

	Now for the test: Is water OK to test it in??   My SO might object to
me heating up a pot of boiling oil.  Although the medeival visual 
imagery is quite appealing, she might also take the metaphore to its logical
conclusion...

Date: Thu, 27 Jul 1995 23:19:57 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 2.0 has Miss when COLD.

There is always the possibility of a cold solder joint or other intermittent
connection in the brain.  Just as likely culprits are the wiring and the
distrubutor points.  
1. Check wiring carefully for loose connections; since it's two at the same
time, check the ground returns on the block under the intake box.
2. Pull the distributor and measure the continuity of the two sets of points
as you slowly (and repeatedly) rotate the rotor.  I don't know the required
duration, but it is something a little over 180 degrees; and they should be
equal.
3. Pull the breaker points and carefully inspect everything.
4. If that fails, I will rent you another brain for troubleshooting.  I'm not
sure I have an extra extra to sell, but will check if you need it.
I also have all other EFI parts, many for sale.

I am a rare lucky individual 914 owner who has one of those neat testers.
 NOT FOR SALE.
I have helped a lot of 914s with it...as recently as this week.
Electronics is my livelihood, so it fits my talents as well as my needs.

Ralph Ricks   76 & 73 914  2.0  etc.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 02:16:10 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 2.0 has Miss when COLD.

Sorry if my prior memo was redundant.  I am new here, and this is the first I
have seen of your problem.

You can't check inj signal with DVM.  You will see only the slightest wiggle
of a digit.  An Oscilloscope will do the job, however.

No way to check the ECU, but with tester like mine, or swapout.

That's not a Lambda sensor in you CAT; that's a thermo switch wired to a
relay in the rear trunk that lights a lamp on the dash.

The Haynes manual is all I have.  It doesn't matter much, as German
schematics are a bitsch to read, anyhow.  (Bitsch is the German name for a
town just across the border in France.  It's Bitche in French, as I
remember.)

Their schematics are wonderful compared to their fuses.  
Those fuses are one of the worst designs of the Industrial age.

You COULD get brave and pull the brain out of the box, and look for a spot of
corrosion or other mechanical intermittent...
Electrical circuits don't fail for electrical reasons, but for mechanical
reasons..

Get an 80lb oil pressure gauge and mount it either in the engine room, or
under the dash.  It will tell you amazing things when you have any kind of a
failure.  It will even alert you to a minor fuel leak before it becomes
hazardous.  30lb is the nominal pressure.

Car won't run?  If there's no fuel pressure, you have EFI problem.
                      If good fuel pressure, it's probably ignition, etc.

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 01:21:25 -0700
From: nms@slip.net (Nick Silva)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1591 Fri Jul 28 01:14:04 CDT 1995

> Well, this is a new one.  I am driving my 928 around town a few minutes ago
> in  95 degree weather and pull up to a stop light.  I put the clutch pedal
> in and try to put it in first gear.  It makes that nasty no syncho sound so
> I say OK, let's go for second gear.  The same noise, so I try all the other
> gears.  It won't go into gear.  I leave it in neutral and let off the clutch
> to try again.  The clutch won't come off the floor!  I unbelt myself and
> reach down and pull the clutch up off the floor.  The car is fine.  I decide
> that this is a fluke and go on to get my hair cut.  Well, as I'm pulling back
> into school, going about 15 miles per hour, the clutch sticks to the floor
> again!!!  I reach down as I'm coasting and pull it up again.  Once again,
> it works fine.  What the hell?!?!?  Is it the weather?  THe engine was
> running hotter than usual.  My A/C decided not to engage when I pressed the
> button also, but this isn't anything new.  Help.  Anyone?

You night also want to check the pedal itself. I had an 83 928S for many
moons, and the clutch pedal snapped once. I didn't do it suddenly however.
It developed a hairline fracture that kept getting bigger and bigger, and
at times would exhibit the behavior you describe: stick to the floor, I'd
pull it up..of course I couldn't engage the gears because the clutch was
never really out: only the pedal was. But if I changed the angle on my
foot, I could get it to work. Anyway, this may not be your problem, but its
something you may want to keep in mind.

________________________________________________________________________________
                           Jasper, this one's evil.

                                nms@slip.net
____________________________________________________________________________
____



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 02:01:38 -0700
From: nms@slip.net (Nick Silva)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1591 Fri Jul 28 01:14:04 CDT 1995

> The clutch is hydraulic. There is a master cylinder, fed by the same
> reservoir that feeds the brakes, and a slave cylinder, down near the
> bottom of the clutch housing. If either one is leaking, it may act
> like that. Check whether your brake fluid has gotten real low.

As an aside, I know from experience (story to follow) the clutch
fluid/brake fluid reservoir can get REAL low before you lose the clutch;
Sean's problem is probably in the slave cylinder.

Good Porsche story:

I was driving my 83 928S across the country, and I was returning home to
the Bay Area after having driven to Key West. On the way, I had my 60K
service at Champion in FL, which had on display a brand new (this was
awhile ago) gunmetal 959, the first one I had ever seen. I was stunned.

On the way back, I had just crossed the Arizona border when I ran over a
piece of metal in the road which, unbeknownst to me, had ripped the brake
lines off the car. I heard the crunch/clang, and I assumed some damage had
been done, but I had no idea how severe. I was closing fast on the
checkpoint and I said to my self, y'know, I'd better check the brakes
before I have to actually use them. The pedal sank to the floor
immediately. Oh shit, I thought. I'm doing 80, about to get to the
checkpoint, and I have no brakes. So I started easing off the gas, and
using the e-brake, which fortunately works quite well. I managed to stop,
and, confident in my e-brake, made for the nearest phone. I looked
underneath the car and sure enough there were dangling, mangled brake
lines. I called the nearest Porsche dealer, which happened to be Phoenix,
and told them the sit. I was about an 1 1/2hrs away, and I decided to risk
it. They said that as the fluid drained away I would eventually lose the
clutch, so DON'T pump the brakes at all, and try not to use the clutch.
Great. The freeway part was OK, although it was unnerving knowing that if
an emergency sit came up I couldn't stop, but Phoenix traffic was a
nightmare. BIG following distance and hand on the e-brake constantly. The
dealer couldn't fix it. No brake lines in the country, because "this sort
of thing never happens". Fortunately, we discovered only one line haad been
severed, so they (at my insistence) welded shut that line at the
distribution block, leaving me with 3 wheels braking. So much for Porsche's
cross circuit braking, which assumes that the brake lines are still intact.
I made it home to SF, and had to wait awhile for the lines to come in from
Germany. I had the rotors changed at the same time, and that was about as
exciting as it ever got in the Porsche.

Thjanks for bearing with me,
Nick

________________________________________________________________________________
                           Jasper, this one's evil.

                                nms@slip.net
____________________________________________________________________________

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 07:49:41 -0600

>Craig- I don't recall it being called a "Wonder Vent" but I bought a
>product from Performance Air about two years ago for my 1985 BLACK
>coupe in Georgia.
>It replaces the stock air "deflector" that is under the dash, forward of
>the gear shift. Installation is straightforward, you basically cut a second
>hole in the ducting and cover everything with a dual air vent.  You now
>have twice the volume of marginally cool air coming out. It still won't
>make the A/C cold. (How come the cheapest  American or Japanese
>cars on the road can accomplish this but not Porsche?) But it does
>bring an improvement. It's definitely worth the $30-$50 cost.

If memory serves me correctly, this upgrade really only does something
substantial on a pre '86 911, since the ventilation system was upgraded
starting with the '86 model year.

Modulator" from an A/C specialty company in Texas (the co. name
escapes me at the moment)?  This device replaces the receiver-dryer
with the "Liquid Modulator".  Supposed to lower temps, increase air
volume, and decrease pressure, and is also R134 compatible if you want
to make that switch ...I wouldn't at this point.  Comments, anyone?

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 10:58:14 -0300
From: cpaine@fox.nstn.ca (Christopher Paine)
Subject: Re: Whaltetail Porsche Parts

>To all:

>Has anyone ever heard of a business by the name of Whale Tail Porsche Parts
>located in Waterloo, Ontario? I've just found out about them and I'm quite
>interested if anyone has had any bad/pleasent experiences with them.....
>
>Thanks,
>
>Peter Rosvall
>rosvall@mi.net 
>
>
>

I've had dealings with Whale Tail 4 or 5 times, mainly for my S.O.'s 951 and 
my brother in law's 924 and service has always been fabulous. If they have 
the part, they're great. They're not, however, quite so great at calling you 
back if they have to try to find the part, so I haven't gotten much for my 
914 from them. They have specialized in used water cooled parts in the past. 
OTOH, my brother in law got some new rotors (not in stock when order 
placed)last week and they only took a week or so to arrive, so maybe they're 
getting better at that sort of thing. Anyway, I'd definitely give them a 
call. A guy named Randy runs it and is a friendly, competent individual. 
Prices are always good, he seems to know exactly how much you could get any 
given part for just about anywhere, and can match it. Good luck

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 09:42:03 EDT
From: CHPJ18D@prodigy.com (MR JAMES H ANDERSON)
Subject: Teaching lessons...

I don't want to start this thread back up but I have been trying to 
post this and it hasn't been reaching the list (at least not the 
digest.)  It did take me a while to write it so I'm going to try one 
more time.

Here's a trick that I like to use when I'm stuck behind a rather slow 
driver in the wrong (for their speed) lane.

Usually, along with myself, a long line of cars get stuck behind this 
driver and their "pace car" to their immediate right (correct lane 
for their speed).  As most of us know we can, eventually, find a way 
to get around the offending person, almost always by passing on the 
right.  

Here's where the lesson teaching begins.  You are now ahead of the 
offending driver with most of the "line" still behind him/her.  
Instead of just powering off (happy to finally be rid of this 
nuisance), slowly (no need to be dangerous here) get off the gas and 
slow down.  This will take a minute but one of the "pace cars" is 
sure to come past on the right.  When this happens the offending 
driver will always (and I mean always) jump into the right lane to 
pass you!  (This is where it gets fun.)  Now, you get on the gas, 
carefully, so as to keep that line of cars behind you without any 
significant gaps.  This will effectively leave the offending driver 
stuck behind the "pace car" until the entire line has passed.

This procedure works very well and can be orchestrated very casually 
without any dangerous or drastic maneuvers.

Good luck!

Jim                     
'86 Carrera         
'87 Pathfinder           

"If I just passed you on the right, you're in the wrong flippin' lane.
"


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 10:13:11 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 2.0 has Miss when COLD.

This is addendum to prior msg:
In the avionics shop we verify thermal problems by heating & cooling.

Take the ECU from your cold dead engine and heat soak it in the oven at
100-120 degrees for at least ten minutes.  Is the miss cured?

To double verify, take the ECU from your hot dead engine and stick it in the
freezer for 10-20 minutes.  Try it then.

Good luck,  Ralph Ricks

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 10:17:40 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1591 Fri J...

An observation regarding the single point brake failure:

IF the car builders were building airplanes, everybody would be afraid to
fly.  

Single point catastrophic failures are not allowed in aviation.  We need more
of that thinking in our cars.

Ralph Ricks  --various aircooled cars and a plane (aircooled).

removing the sump cover to get all the old oil out, cleaning it, and
putting it back on with a new gasket on each oil change...

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 13:21:03 -0800
From: s921142@hpg50a.csc.cuhk.hk (Chris Robyn)
Subject: opinions wanted on Lukes & Shorman (SF Bay Area)

Hi all,

This message is confined largely to the SF Bay Area 'philers, sorry!

I know L&S has a legendary reputation in dealing with air-cooled cars, but
do any of you water-cooled guys and gals take your car there?  I'd like to
hear your experiences just the same.  For months I've been contemplating
the "chip" issue with my 951, but there seems to be an endless supply of
aftermarket parts and I don't know where to go or what to buy.  I see all
these ads in Excellence for 400hp 944 turbos...but at what cost ( more $$$
and less reliability?). I just got off the phone with Harry Shorman and his
argument that all these modifications MAY complicate reliability rang true
with me...especially since my car has 94,000 miles on it.

So, I guess I'd just like to know if their "old-world" method, if you will,
of servicing Porsches is really the way to go if I'm not prepared to fork
out the big bucks, which I'm not, I just want to keep the car running as
reliably as possible.

So please, please send me any thoughts on Lukes & Shorman.  Thanks!

- --Chris
'86 951



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 08:17:32 -0700
From: Mike Willis <mikew@cwo.com>
Subject: Re: 2.7??

Before you embark on this get Bruce Anderson's book on 911 performace. It is
avail from all the mail order houses. The 911 cyl. do not get bored out you
change cyl and pistons to increase displacement. There is a limit on the 2.7
on what you can enlarge to and I can't remember and the book is at home. If
you want bigger I strongly suggest that you buy an good used 3.0 , 3.2 eng
etc. I do know that a good blueprinted 2.7 is fast enough for me. 135 though
the desert made the blood rush.

mike
>
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
same guy different provider
mikew@cwo.com

------------------------------

Date:         Fri, 28 Jul 95 11:13:59 EDT
From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SEAN@american.edu>
Subject:      Way Fake 959

I was putting gas in my other car (that's what it's been called ever since
the 928 was acquired) and lacksidaisically scanning the parking lot for
interresting cars.   Sure enough, there was an odd looking 959 replica. I
walked over to look at it as some guy waled up to the passanger side and
dropped some groceries in it.  I asked "what's this based on?" he looked
confused, I said "looks like a 70's 911".  The guy raised his hands in the
air and said "It ain't mine, I have no clue what you are talking about!
Here comes the owner!"  This other guy struts up and says hi.  I ask him
the same questions.  He says that it's a '73 91*2* with a body kit (no
shit).  He goes on to tell me that he put in a 3.2 liter engine.  I said
"so now it's a big six" and he said "no, it's an eight".  I said "eight
cylinder?", "Yes.", "what kind of engine?", "3.2 liter", "Right, but Porsche
didn't make a 3.2 liter V8!",  "Oh, well, whatever, it's a 3.2", I just
rolled my eyes and said "Ok, well, have fun with it." and walked away amazed
at the ignorance.  I can't imagine someone putting so much into their car
and having no clue about anything past the cosmetics!  Well, it did have
California tags...  (I can say that because I am 3rd generation Californian)

Sean  '80 928

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 12:14:04 -0400
From: "Dan Jansen" <dan@fibecin2.flight.wpafb.af.mil>
Subject: fakes & ignorance

Sean wrote:

>I just ... walked away amazed at the ignorance.
 I can't imagine >someone putting so much into
their car and having no clue about >anything ...

The guy I bought my 71 911T from told me on the
phone that it had a 4cyl 2.2 engine.  I had never
looked under the hood of a porsche before but as
a childhood porsche lover I knew they were all
sixes.

Furthermore when I asked about maintenance
records he said he didn't have any but I could
call the shop were it was serviced.  On my test
drive I happened to look in the glove compartment
and found receipts and records from the 4
previous owners back to '87.

In 4 days of ownership I know more about the car
than he did.  Go figure.



- -- 
'73 911T Targa, Oxidized Silver

> interresting cars.   Sure enough, there was an odd looking 959 replica. I
