> dropped some groceries in it.  I asked "what's this based on?" he looked
> confused, I said "looks like a 70's 911".  The guy raised his hands in the
> air and said "It ain't mine, I have no clue what you are talking about!
Groceries? Wait, now this IS a special car... :)

> Here comes the owner!"  This other guy struts up and says hi.  I ask him
> the same questions.  He says that it's a '73 91*2* with a body kit (no
> shit).  He goes on to tell me that he put in a 3.2 liter engine.  I said
Hm... This should've been the first indication that he was clueless, no 
such thing as a '73 912... now remember, he said HE put a 3.2 litre in 
(at least, that's what you told us).

> "so now it's a big six" and he said "no, it's an eight".  I said "eight
> cylinder?", "Yes.", "what kind of engine?", "3.2 liter", "Right, but Porsche
> didn't make a 3.2 liter V8!",  "Oh, well, whatever, it's a 3.2", I just
3.2 litre V8? There are conversions like that... If you ever see this guy 
again, ask him where he mounted the radiator. :) Of course, he may simply 
have a six and be so awestruck by the power of the six, that he believes 
it to be an eight.

> rolled my eyes and said "Ok, well, have fun with it." and walked away amazed
> at the ignorance.  I can't imagine someone putting so much into their car
> and having no clue about anything past the cosmetics!  Well, it did have
> California tags...  (I can say that because I am 3rd generation Californian)
There are many people out there like this, and of course, if you become a 
Porsche mechanic, you may well have the chance to do something similar to 
what was in Road & Track a couple months ago... three bugs (nothing else) 
sitting at a garage that says, "Radiator Repair" You could of course, 
tell them that water pumps are impossible to find for 911s (which isn't a 
lie), and offer to take it off their hands for real cheap. Hehehe... 

Just remember, there a whole mix of owners of all types of cars, Porsches 
just happen to have nearly all types. This guy is not obviously concerned 
about his precious German metal (or American fiberglass as the case may 
be) as most of us are. So what? He's probably back looking at you, 
wondering how come you don't have a convertible, slammed to the ground, 
fuschia, with 10 trillion watt quadruple amp 10-disc CD changer in the 
trunk 928. There are different things to do with your Porsche, that's 
just one of them. There are always three basic categories for cars: 
stock, custom, and race. Now, you hath seen the custom with an ignorant 
owner. I'm sure everyone has seen the sotck with original owner, and race 
with ignorant owner... harder to find, but they are out there.
 -Derek

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 11:42:16 -0500
From: bill.williams@develcon.com (Bill Williams)
Subject: Re: 914 2.0 Miss when COLD

Hi Brian:

I said yesterday that I'd look further into your prob. last night...but a
friend had me drive out of town to look at a vehicle with him so I'll have
to go with whhat I have at my office. There seems to be lots of advice for
you this morning though. 

I'd first pull the computer connector plug and check to see if all
connectors are making good contact, clean with electrical contact cleaner, etc. 

Especially check the wiring for the 2 injectors that aren't functioning
properly. My wiring diagram (turns out I have it here at my office) shows
pins on the computer connector 3, 4, 5, and 6 go to the injectors (it isn't
specific as to what # corresponds to which injector). The white wires on the
fuel injection system should correspond to these numbers so it should be
pretty clear.

As for the advice to bake and freeze the board, well...I suggest instead to
pull the case apart, inspect the guts for obvious probs., then while it is
apart, plug it back into the harness and lay it on some cardboard or
something non-conductive to protect it. Get a can of freeze-spray from a
electronics supply place (or borrow some from Tandem), start the car, and
then selectively freeze-spray small areas of the board to try to isolate the
prob. (Use a hot hair-dryer to isolate hot-running failures).

Good luck...post your progress


Bill


------------------------------

Date:         Fri, 28 Jul 95 13:25:58 EDT
From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SS8299A@american.edu>
Subject:      Re: Way Fake 959

>
>Again as I am saying more and more "You don't have to be smart to own a
>Porsche"

Unfortunately you are right, I just remembered another conversation I had on
the phone with a guy who was trying to sell his 928.  I was calling for my
roommate and I let the guy go on and on describing the car for sale.  When
he was done I told him that I was calling for a friend and that I was familiar
with the 928 because I have one.  He said, "yes, but mine is V8!"  and from
then on he threw V8 in every other sentance like the V8 was an option on the
928.  I have a feeling that someone coached him on what to say to people when
they called (the guy didn't speak english very well).  He was also telling me
that it was not an "S" even though he was insisting that it was a 1984 model.
I said "OK..." and politely bid him goodbye.  In retrospect I suppose I could
gotten a really cheap 928S for my roommate, but at the time I was turned off
by the guy's cluelessness.

Sean  '80 928 (with the V8 option)

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 10:54:19 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: 914 flares

> 
> I am looking for a little extra room for my rear ties and wide rims.  I did
> the baseball bat routine and cracked the paint on both fenders and got in
> return some clearance, but not much.  I want to put steel 916 flares at the
> back, but they are outrageously expensive ($800/pr).  I recall seeing an
> article in VW Greats or some other car mag that someone welded either a
> Turbo or SC flare onto the skinny haunces of the 914.  Anyone tried this?
> Will the SC flares fit without much trouble?  The Turbo and SC flares are
> less expensive and will get the job done!
> Thak Chaloemtiarana                              EMail:TC17@cornell.edu
> 

Or you could try something else:  A guy in Fremont (I think his name
is Bob Cross) slits the fenders along the top, spreads them, and welds
in a filler panel.  I've seen one car done this way, and it looks
pretty good.  The rear light buckets have to be moved out, so a new
panel is made for "under" the trunk lid.

You have to view the car at just the right angle to figure out how
he got such big tires on the car.

Gary.



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 10:58:44 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: Oil Changes and cleaning the sump cover...

> 
> I have been doing my oil changes on my 83SC by dumping the oil using the
> tank drain and sump drains, replacing the filer (Mahle, 'natch), and 
> putting the new oil in. My local mechanic told me that I should be 
> removing the sump cover to get all the old oil out, cleaning it, and
> putting it back on with a new gasket on each oil change...
> 
> So, how many of you guys do this?
> 
> Thanks in advance.
> 
> Mike Juzenas
> 83 911SC
> 

If there's more than a mL or two of oil on the cover, I'd be surprised.
There's a lot more "old" oil on the inside of the case.

But I do it anyway.  And seeing as how it's a NARP, I clean the screen
too.

Gary.

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 11:04:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: Rich Martin <richm@ncw.net>
Subject: Re: Porsche Brochures book

On Fri, 28 Jul 1995, James J Dempsey wrote:

> A few weeks ago someone mentioned a book called "Porsche Catalogs" (I
> think) that was published by Mallard Press, 666 Fifth Ave, NY, NY.  I
> wrote to them at that address and it was returned as "Returned to
> Writer, Moved, not forwardable".
> 
> Anyone know another source for this book?
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> 		--Jim Dempsey--
> 		jjd@bbn.com
> 
I have a copy of the book, bought it about a year ago, the title is 
"PORSCHE CATALOGS" by Malcolm Toogood, copyright 1991, published by 
Mallard Press. I notice in the front of the book, it says: "An imprint of 
BDD Promotional Book Company, Inc., 666 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY. 10103.
Also says: Copyright 1991 Quintet Publishing Limited.  
This must have came out in Great Britain first, then imported to the 
States later. Hope some of this info helps you. BTW, I think the book 
cost me between $12.00 - $20.00, don't remember for sure.

 -=Rich Martin=-
84' 944 (Guards Red)

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 14:12:56 -0400
From: "Robert S. Fourney" <knee@eng.umd.edu>
Subject: Options for distributer for 356

My father owns a 64 356 C which he mainly uses for commuting 2 or 3 days a 
week.  He had noticed a loss of power lately and recently rebuilt the carbs
(Zeniths) which helped a little, but it was still down on power.  Since the
engine for my SC is out of the car, he swapped distributers, and claims it
now runs like a new car.  He thinks he needs a new (or rebuilt) distributer,
since he has messed with this one a lot in the past and had no luck.  [Also,
the distributer he has now is NOT a Porsche distributer but a fairly common 
VW and/or Audi model].

	So what are his options?  He is balking at the prices he has seen,
and wonders:
	
	Whats a cheap place to buy a new one?  Tweeks is the lowest I've seen
		so far at about $430 and Stoddard is about $550 or so.
	What's a good source for rebuilt or rebuildable, and what should he
		expect to pay?
	Are there other distributers that work OK in this engine (e.g., is 
		his not working _because_ its an Audi distributer, or is it
		just shot, and if not would another non-Porsche distributer 
		fix him up?).   This distributer has been in the car for many 
		years so I'm assuming it worked OK at some time.  The only 
		reason I know it's not a P-car distributer is that I remember
		that I always have to take the points in to get new ones and
		have the guy match them up instead of just getting the 356 
		points.


Thanks for you help (and thanks for all who advised on the 356 endplay for
my SC)

Bob Fourney

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 11:24:13 -0800 (PST)
From: BMESSINGER@ewu.edu
Subject: 914 speedster conversion





I will probably get some strange looks from most of you for what I am going
to ask, but here goes. Have any of you other 914-nuts ever thought about
doing a speedster conversion to a 914? I have seen several 914's converted
to cabriolet configuration. They look good, but wouldn't a speedster
configuration look great? I have been obsessed with the idea for months
(I even made up drawings).

So are any of you interested in such a thing? Has anyone ever done/seen such
a thing? Do any of you think a 911-speedster windshield and frame could be
addapted (like the ones sold for 911-speedster conversions)? I don't know
the difference in width and base contour between 914 and 911 windshields.
Do any of you know? A custom windshield would be expensive to have fabricated
, but then again this whole thing sounds like a lot of expensive fabrication
 (side glass,top,etc.), but I still want to do this. 

Any comments or suggestions welcome, just no flames please (I would never do
this to a collectable 914.).

Ben Messinger
bmessinger@ewu.edu

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 12:17:18 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: hood shocks

When talking about hood shocks, is it front or rear?  I've replaced my
own front hood (trunk) shocks a few times with no problems--at least
none since I realized that the cotter pin only needs to be flipped up
to slip out!  I do them one at a time, and just use a little shoulder
action (easy if you're a little guy).  The rear (hood) is another
story--I've never done that job myself.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 11:31:02 -0600
From: gwilensky@gryphonsw.com (Gabriel Wilensky)
Subject: Speaking of Speakers...

Craig, if you are going to install new speakers in your car I strongly
recommend you listen to the ADS 300i speakers. GREAT car speakers, in my
opinion. I have a relatively old model on the door panels that are fairly
large and makes cranking the windows up and down hard, but the sound is
superb. I believe the newer versions of the same ADS speakers are smaller,
or at least they go flush with the door panel.

Good luck,

Gabriel

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 16:15:52 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: 944 - Strange noise driving me crazy

After my '86 944 warms up, (5-10 mins), I can hear a FAINT tapping sound at
a rate
of about 4+ Hz when the engine is between 2800 - 3200 rpm, loudest at around 
3000 rpm. The best way I can describe it is that it sounds like a mix between a
'gurgle' and a 'tap'. My initial tests show the following:

1.  No tapping sound until the car has warmed up

2.  Pressing in the clutch with the car rolling along in neutral, the sound
goes away.
     (Of course, the rpms drop.) Also no sound if clutch released, rolling
in neutral.

3. At stoplights in neutral and revving to 3000 rpm, I can SOMETIMES hear
the sound
    but rarely and more faint than if driving.

4. On arrival at home and revving to 3000 rpm, I can't make the sound happen
even
    when listening at the front of the car with the hood open.

5. Once warmed up, the sound is always there at around 3000 rpm, if engine under
    load. Can also hear it if coasting in gear, with the engine at around
3000 rpm.

6. Can't smell any exhaust fumes leaking.

7. Rate of sound increases with rpm 

8. Cam/balance belt recently (2000 km ago) replaced and tensioned with 9201
tool.
 
What's driving me nuts is that I can't re-produce the sound when the car is
stopped,
with the engine running and can only hear it when the car is moving.

Any ideas?

Ken '86 944 (86K km)

A friend of mine just rec'd the following:

911 parts manual, 72-73

911/912 supplement for 69
914 parts manual up to 73

These came from a Porsche dealer that  dropped the marque about a year ago, 
and this stuff was recently unearthed.  There are two copies of some of the 
items.  What's this stuff worth?

I had just decided I was going to put to together as complete a collection 
of paint color samples as I could find.  What luck.... in with all this 
stuff was (was... because they live at my house now) paint, carpet, vinyl 
samples and charts from 1970-1992!  Also in the pile was a parts product 
knowledge binder and 91 and 93 order guides for all models.  Hoo boy!

as I can put a value on this stuff for him.

Subject: In-car lap timers?
Date: Friday, July 28, 1995 1:02AM

Hi,

the west-coat for a holiday I wanna pick one up there somewhere along the
coast.

So the question is, where to buy one that's reasonably priced. I want
the type that has a transmitter on the track and a panel in the car.

Any ideas, hints, suggestions, used ones, new ones, anything?

Christian
 --
M. Christian Holmgreen / joker@diku.dk / mochmch@unidhp.uni-c.dk
M.Sc. student, University of Copenhagen, Dept. of Computer Science
   *** M.Sc. within two months... anybody wanna hire? :-) ***


Hi Christian,

The Racer's Group/Performance Wholesale sells "Hot Lap" in-car timing 
systems.
This is the official timing system of the POC/Zone 8 PCA.  They offer a 
PCA/POC discount.  They advertise in Pano and Excellence.  I have one and am 
very pleased with it.  You can buy the transmitter and receiver separate or 
as a package.

Bob Mohan

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 12:57:12 -0800
From: abt@hooked.net (Kurt)
Subject: Having some fun

It was a nice sunny Sunday afternoon, and I was driving the U-boat (83-928)
into work for awhile. The road to work ends with a nice windey road with
about 3.5 miles of great quick turns, short straights, and a few downhill
reverse camber to keep things lively. I was cruising along and I found
myself looking into the rearview mirror at a red convertible Miata, right
on my a**. Middle aged guy and SO out for a nice drive. He kept crowding
me, so I decided to light it up. A couple of turns later he was nowhere in
sight so I slowed back to normal speed. Well, here he comes, hands clenched
on the wheel, eyes fixed. SO was laughing and apparantly having a good
time. So off I went again, slowed again.., and he caught up again. I
finally decided to finish this and blasted off. A mile later I pulled off
to make the turn into my office.The little red Miata convertible went
screaming past, driver had a glazed and frustrated look on his face, and
white knuckles clamped on the wheel. SO was doubled up, with her head on
the door, laughing hysterically. I waved, she waved back, driver kept
going.

My wife says that they may be putting to much testosterone in the drinking
water here in Marin, California. It was a fun few minutes.


Kurt Kline

'83-928 Forest green
Wife- Sandi who loves the car and doesn't complain about the repairs.

Kurt F. Kline



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 95 11:44:16 PDT
From: Scott=D=Berry%MfgEng%GPID@banyan2.BV.TEK.COM
Subject: re: Options for distributer for 356

Bob:

I have a 66 912 that had an incorrect distributor in it (A Bosch 009) and was 
told by many experts to get an 050 and also told by just as many experts to stay 
with the original 022.  Well I went for an original 022 (which are no longer 
made).  I bought a used one and bought all the parts from Stoddard to rebuild it 
and spent many hours taking it apart and putting it back together trying to get 
the correct advance curve.  I could never get it right!  I eventually brought it 
to a distributor rebuild shop here in Portland, Or and paid the guy $30 to 
"recurve" the distributor to the correct specs.  I had him cut down the total 
advance to 27 degrees so I would end up with about 31-32 degrees max in the car. 
 The whole thing cost me about $175 and A LOT of time.  It was fun and I learned 
a lot about distributors.  BUT if you are not inclined to go through the hassles 
I would recommend a Bosch 050 distributor.  It's not original but it's cheap 
($60 from Imparts) and I have heard from many experts (The Maestro) that they 
are great.  I also think I could have taken my 009 distributor to the rebuild 
shop and have it recurved to match a 022 advance curve for $30 and been done 
with it!  You can also send a original distributor to Stoddard and they will 
rebuild it and recuve it for about $175.  If you need any more help let me know.

Scott
66 912  

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1594                         Sat Jul 29 02:00:10 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 20:30:21 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@mail.orion.org>
Subject: Cheap exhaust gaskets

I very often had to R & R the engine Saturday night while regularly 
autcrossing my '70E.  I often needed exhaust gaskets between the heat 
exchangers and the muffler.  I found that the header pipe gasket for a 
6cyl ford will fit the early model muffler.

Good luck on your own projects.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 95 09:54:00 PDT
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: SALE: '84 928S in NJ/PA area


I sent this a few days ago, but I did not see it in any of the digests sent 
to me.  Sorry for wasting space If I overlooked it or missed a digest.
 -----------------------------------------------------------------

'84 928S V-8 with 5 speed manual, approx.. 93,500 miles.
Slate Blue with Dark Blue interior, Platinum wheels with slots around 
outside edge.

Options include sun roof, leather seats and all the other 928 standard 
equipment that's usually optional on other cars.

Second owner.  Garage kept since new.  Never driven in Winter.
Oil changed every 3,000 miles.  Tires good, at half way point.
Last year for a 928S that will not bend valves when the timing belt breaks. 

Complete brake service done less than 10,000 miles ago including new rotors, 
master cylinder, rubber lines, rebuilt calipers, etc.

Mechanical work done at Porsche dealer in the past year includes:
 - Timing belt.
 - New fuel pump, fuel pressure regulators, pump relay.
 - New (NOT rebuilt) computer brain.

I had planned on keeping the car forever, but you know how that works when 
starting  a family.  My boy fits, but his crib, walker, stroller, high 
chair, toys, diaper bag, etc., etc., don't.

Asking $14,000.  Car can be seen in Parsippany, NJ or Easton, PA.  Graphic 
file of car available.  E-Mail or call for details.

Bill Smyth
smythb@dbisna.com
201-605-6281  9-5 EST, M-F
610-253-5478  evenings & weekends

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 21:30:53 -0500 (cdt)
From: zwerner@RoseVC.Rose-Hulman.Edu
Subject: HELP!!! alt problem 73 911

I'm getting desparate!!!!!  I just spent another 3 hrs trying to solve
my alternator problem with no success.  At least I found the 2 BLUE
wires which are supposed to go to D+ on reg from alt and dash lamp.
They go into a capacitor then come out as the RED wire to D+. The RED
line on D+ comes from the relay thru fuse 2 in the rear fuse block. I
still havn't found where the RED wire th EXC terminal comes from, it's
supposed to be the BLACK wire from alt.

My light comes on with the key, but does'nt go out when the engine
starts. Light will glow dimmer if I drive very far, but that is because
I'm driving off the battery!  The alt was checked out last weekend and
was OK. The reg was new last May.( I've bad this problem this long!!!).
Both reg and alt are Marchal.  ALL grounds are checked and cleaned, I
ran a new ground line from body ground to reg base just to check-- it
was OK, no change.

I have no idea what the capacitor's function is--- probably something
to do with pressure control reg??  Tomorrow I,m going to bypass the
capacitor and hook up the 2 Blue wires straight to D+/61.  Any
advice???  After that I'm going to run a line direct from lash light to
D+!  If that doesn't work, I guess I'll have to pull fan again so I can
wire direct to reg from alt.

I sure could use some info and advice ( moral support).  If anyone has
had a similar problem or knows someone who can help, let me know!!!  I
know the 73 1/2 CIS T is a oddball model, none of my factory parts or
shop manuals show any of this ( at least from what I can figure out
!!).

Thanks from everyone who has helped me get this 22 yr old ( 16 in
storage in a barn?? ) 911 going, it runs great when the bat is up! 
This problem is a real stumper and I don't know where else to ask!!!

                                       Paul Zwerner

                     zwerner@rosevc.rose-hulman.edu

rings). I am getting 1.3K miles per quart of Mobil-1 (15W50). 

The 1971 owners manual state oil consumption to be "1.5 to  2.0 US qts per 600 
mi."  I find this to be very high.

Can anyone share the oil consumption rates for their early 911?

Thanks,

Bill Hutton

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 95 14:46:41 cst
From: dougc@mails.imed.com
Subject: Re: Hood Shocks

  
  My hood shocks have been weak ever
  since I bought my 928S. Depending on the
  weather, the hood (it's in the front, like 
  it should be :)) will stay up. I had been
  procrastinating getting new ones, when 
  oneday I was at Walmart. They had this 
  little gizmo that works like a hood-stick.
  It clamps around the shaft (male part of 
  the shock) and has a spring loaded stick
  that flips under the female part of the
  shock as you lift the hood. To lower the 
  hood you hold the stick away from the
  female part of the shock and lower. 
  Before this I was also using the broomstick
  method on bad days. The stick part of
  the gizmo comes long, and the package 
  includes a little hacksaw and miter-box so
  that you can fit it to the length of your
  hood shock. It also came with some shims
  so that it would fit the different male
  piece diameters. It was the best $5 I 
  ever spent on my car. There is only one
  drawback. It is so small and discreet,
  (it's made of black plastic) that you 
  have to warn people working on your car
  or else they have a tendancy to try to
  close the hood w/o disengaging the gizmo,
  "STOP!!! YOUR BENDING THE HOOD!!!!" 
  I think I may paint it orange or something.
  I hope the guys who designed/marketed this
  make a million bucks, it is truely well done,
  much cheaper than shocks, and I doubt if it
  will ever wear out.
  
  Doug Cook
  '83 928S Euro

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 23:22:35 -0400
From: PIAUDIO@aol.com
Subject: Re: Opinions please - rebuilt or rebuid?

My 79 924 engine is kaput - threw a rod. I am considering two options:
1. Buy a complete, rebuilt engine for about $1300 plus freight, 12 month
warranty.

2. Buy a good, used bottom end for about $200 and rebuild it. I believe my
head is okay. I would also replace the water pump. No warranty - take my
chances.

I will replace the motor mounts and other things that make sense when the
engine is out of the car.

I am looking at doing this work myself. The rebuilt engine seems like it
would be easier to do and more guaranteed of success, but possibly more
expensive. I have not rebuilt an engine before, but it doesn't look too
intimidating. I am estimating that I can do the new bottom end, and bolt my
head back on (valve job done about two years ago) and have a decent engine
for $700-$800. Am I way off on my cost estimate or perception of the
difficulty of replacing bearings, rings, etc? I don't think this engine has a
reputation as a real fussy one to do.
Am I missing anything else that should be done?What would you do? 

BTW, I would like to sell it in the spring, so I would rather not spend a lot
of money on it.

PS. I checked out a third option - a Chevy V-6 or V-8 conversion kit from an
outfit in CA. For approx. $5000 I coulda had a V-8 and an honest to God NARP!

TIA
Paul Ingebrigtsen
piaudio@aol.com
79 924 Petrol Blau

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 18:37:21 -0700 (MST)
From: Scott D Ellingsen <sde@GAS.UUG.Arizona.EDU>
Subject: Prized 944T now running poorly


After enjoying this mail-list for several months, my turn has come to 
ask for HELP!

My 1987 944T suffered the loss of it's alternator last week as I was 
returning to Tucson from Phoenix.  Without going into that 24 hours of 
hell last Friday and Saturday, I'll simply say that I got it to the shop 
where the previous owner always took it for service.

I had been anticipating work on the cam/balance belts, etc...so this
turned out to be the impetus for getting the work done.  I had them
replace the following: 

Alternator
Water pump
Lower balance shaft seals
various rollers, etc.

Total bill: $1400+


Immediately after picking up the car I noticed a lot more vibration as the
engine was wound-up to 3500 RPMs.  My initial thoughts were that the 
belts hadn't settled in (not being experienced in these things)...except for 
the fact that my car was now running _significantly_ HOTTER than before.

I pulled over, called the shop, and spoke with the mechanic.  After agreeing 
over the fact that it was one of the hottest days of the year in Phoenix 
(114), I reiterated the fact that the car had always run 'nice and cool' 
(first hatch mark) on several previous freeway trips when it was 106 to 110 
degrees in June.  I got back in the car and 'nursed' it home....

The car never cooled below the second hash (just short of the RED) for 
the entire 100 mile journey home...the engine constantly resisting 
anything above 2800 RPMs by weakening and vibrating strongly through 
the gear shifter...so I drove it at 60 mph in 5th gear

Finally, I get it to my local Porsche dealer here in Tucson.  Our first 
discovery turned out to be misleading (fuel mixture was set too lean).  
Thinking this solved the problem, they (my shop) told me to come down and 
get my car today...WRONG....

The car heats up rapidly even when _cruising_ at 60 (3000 RPMs) and still
has lots of vibration as the engine goes from 2500 RPM on up.  When we
came to a stop (idle) the car actually began to cool down...and this was
today in Tucson (temp 114).  This behavior is completely backwards from
the way the car normally runs.   

My biggest concern is the 'vibration' and almost 'resistive' feeling that 
the engine is giving...the engine has completely lost the beautiful 
'whirring-purring' smoothness that it had before these guys worked on it.

My mechanic checked over everything they did (cam shaft/belt alignment,
tension, etc...only suggestion he had was that the other shop may have
used the wrong 'key-slot' on the balance shaft(s) for aligning the toothed
rollers.  Should I have him dig into this hypothe$i$ or not?

BTW, my fiancee noticed right away that the car wasn't 'normal' when we test 
drove it today (her first time in it since the alternator went) !  So, it's 
not just me...  ;)

HELP!


Thanks in advance,

Scott D. Ellingsen
Optical Sciences Center
University of Arizona

1987 951  (running like a 'Bug' right now)

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 00:27:24 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: Opinions please - rebuilt...

Last week I saw a 924 with a 350 Chevy in a PickYourPart yard in Wilmington
Calif.  The chevy trans was still on the engine, but the rear end was
missing.

>From the looks of it, the car understeered through a corner and into a
guardrail..  Not surprising with that weight and balance.

BTW, there are several 924s in the Pickyourpart yards here at any one time.
 Complete engines go for about $125 plus $25 core.  For an extra few bucks,
you even get a guarantee.

Ralph Ricks

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 21:01:40 -0700
From: nine11@teleport.com (Jim Coshow)
Subject: Parade Schedule (short form)

Here is a very abbreviated schedule of the Parade events. I left off the
banquets because if you don't already have a ticket, you're not going! (I
have also omitted the ice-cream social and the quilting bee but if that's
your preference, I'll bet you already have your ticket!)

Feel free to contact me for any further details:

Sunday, August 6
Goodie Store Opens 9:00 to 5:00 (and opens daily)
Art Show opens 9:00 to 4:00 (and opens daily)

Monday, August 7
Concours judging begins at 8:00 am

Tuesday, August 8 
Autocross at PIR starts at 7:00 am
Time-Speed-Distance rally begins at 7:30 am
Porschephiles get together

Wednesday, August 9
Autocross at PIR starts at 7:00 am
Drivers Ed at PIR starts at 8:00 am
Test Drive begins at 9:00 am

Thursday, August 10
Historic race cars at PIR all day
Autocross at PIR starts at 7:00 am
Drivers Ed at PIR starts at 8:00 am

Friday, August 11 
Autocross at PIR starts at 7:00 am
Drivers Ed at PIR starts at 8:00 am
PCA Club Racing Drivers Ed at PIR
PCA Club Racing Rookie school at PIR

Saturday, August 12
PCA Club Racing practice and qualifying at PIR
Porschephiles get together

Sunday, August 13
PCA Club Racing at PIR





Jim Coshow
'74 911 Club Racing #74


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 95 21:57:49 -0700
From: selfridg@encoreengineering.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re: Phone Dial wheel question

>Does anyone know if Phone Dial type wheels come
>in widths greater than 7 inches?  All my catalogs
>show only 7 inch widths.  (7 x 15,  7 x 16, etc)
>Thanks.  Bryson Beaulieu
>

That is a good question.  I have asked this same question
far and wide, and all answers have been "no" or "I don't know."

I have come to the conclusion that I should make some.  The
procedure would be to buy an additional set of these wheels
(preferably well used, and at a good price), and cut free the
inside half, at centerline plus an inch or so outward.  Then,
do the same with my good wheels, but cut at centerline plus an
inch or so inward.  Join the two halves, and weld.  Seems it
might be tricky to get alignment of the two halves right, but
I think it's worth a try.

In the effort to find wider wheels for my 928, I have yet to
find some that look as good, in my opinion, as the original
Porsche phone dials.

- --Mike

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 22:10:12 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Aerodynamic Drag

Andrew George <ageorge@freenet.columbus.oh.us> wrote:

>Do any of you Porsche mentors know what the percent aerodynamic drag 
>and friction take away from the performance.  In my formulas I got a 
>914/2.7 with 1G force under acceleration, with a 0-60 time of...... 2 
>SECONDS!!
>IT must be a lot!

Andrew:

Uhh... No.  The reason a 914/2.7 can't do 0-60 in 2 seconds is that the 
914/2.7 combination doesn't generate anywhere near 1G of continuous 
acceleration.

 -Andy

P.S.  One G (absent air friction, etc.) would give you a 0-60 time of
      closer to three seconds, anyway.

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 23:34:17 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: my personal fave

Except for some boats and ships, ALL engines are aircooled!

Some vehicles just haul water or extra nasty chemicals and copper fins, and
hoses, pumps, and belts, etc., to conduct the heat from the engine to the
air.

Ralph Ricks   73 &76 914, 81vangon, 51 Devin/VW, 46 Bellanca Cruisair with
165 hp Aircooled Franklin engine, 1934 Franklin sedan, aircooled upright six.

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 01:48:53 +0500
From: dpoad@inforamp.net
Subject: 5W50 vs 20W50


My 911 has been running way too hot on the track, plus the oil 
pressure seems to move south the hotter it gets. Local P-car 
gurus say that until such time I get an oil cooler, I should be 
using 20W50 oil instead of the 5W50 I currently have. The 
theory is the 5W50 is way too thin, and that the heavier 
weight, while not solving my heat problem, would certainly help 
lower it a few degrees. I don't follow the logic of this. If 
I'm running hard in the dog days of the summer, isn't the upper 
range of viscosity the issue? I could really a second 
opinion(s) on this. Any chemical engineers out there who could 
lend a hand?

Thanks in advance.

Doug Poad
'71 911T
Nissan Pathfinder

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 1995 23:51:49 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Hood shocks & personalized plates

Well, the kid did it, just like I thought he would. New hood shocks are now
safely installed on the 951. He connected the bottom end first (ball &
socket), then pushed the upper end down with both hands, and then rotated
the shock toward the clevis allowing the top to expand into position for me
to insert the pin (which I did, expertly). It took MUCH grunt-power to
compress the shocks -- more than I have. Maybe these are new
industrial-strength units for 944 hoods only.

Regarding personalized plates, I always thought the 914 looked like a shoe
box. So, when I got one I also got the plate, SHUBX. Present owner still
has the plate.



------------------------------

83 944, 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 85 Audi 5000S Sedan, 80 GMC Pickup (drivers)
88 944 TurboS, 89 944S2, 87 924S, 85 944 (parts cars)
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services and Information

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 05:43:54 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Prized 944T now running poorly

Yep, that's it.

One or both of the balance shaft sprockets is misaligned with
the balance shaft itself.

PAG, in its infinite wisdom, decided to use the same sprocket,
but with two different keyways, one for the upper balance
shaft, and one for the lower balance shaft.  If the kid who is
working on your car doesn't know that he can screw it up, he 
most certainly will.  Very common occurrence by second tier shops.

The good shops know how to read the factory service manual (one of two
places where this information is documented - the other being
an article in Excellence by our own Jim Pasha), the prerequisite
being that they do have them. (There, I've said it again, THERE
IS NO SUBSTITUTE FOR THE FACTORY SERVICE MANUAL!!!!!)

Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
83 944, 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 85 Audi 5000S Sedan, 80 GMC Pickup (drivers)
88 944 TurboS, 89 944S2, 87 924S, 85 944 (parts cars)
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services and Information
Orders: 800-ALL-P944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487

Date: 29 Jul 95 07:55:13 EDT
From: "Christopher s. Stavros" <102053.144@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 Distributors

Hi Bob,

Stan and Scott are both right.  But, I tend to side with Stan.  The 050 is
crap!! And, what about the Maestro...hasn't he retired yet?

I suggest rebuilding the original or an alternative.  The 031 is a great dist.,
if you can find a new one that hasn't been used too much.  Check the specs book
for the proper advance curve and go from there.

Stoddard will rebuild you dist. for about $150.00. But, if this only includes
replacing the bushings and shims, well, your no better off.  

I have recently addressed a letter to Bosch, in Canada, requesting information
in regards to the parts that are always wore.  If I can locate the parts that
are always wore, and cause most of the radical advance problems, I'll let you
know.

chris

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 05:01:03 -0700
From: nms@slip.net (Nick Silva)
Subject: Re: Best personalized plates

> My personal favorite was a random assortment on M's, N's and W's.  It was
> completely illegible.

This is a seemingly good idea, because it is almost illegible, but if
escaping easy memory detection is your goal, then it suffers from a major
flaw: its own illegibility. The witness says, "I didn't see the guy who hit
the old lady, but I remember his plate cuz it was all Ms, Ns, and Ws, and I
couldn't read it." Then the cops have you, because there can't be many
plates like that around.

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 95 08:31:07 MDT
From: hrubin@nyx10.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
Subject: 88 911 AC Improvments

I found that the AC volume was improved by removing the little
deflector that goes where the vent replacement would be installed.
It's that little bow-tie shaped thingie that's down near the gas pedal
If you're going to buy the vent from Performance Air, please let us
all know how well it works!
HR.

air-conditioning vent that is said to more the double your AC's cooling capacity.  This would certainly be a excellent 
addition to my BLACK CAB here in Florida!!!

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 95 08:36:36 MDT
From: hrubin@nyx10.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
Subject: Teaching other drivers a "lesson"

Through this whole thread on scaring other drivers and causing accidents,
there's been no mention of letting other people pass and cheering them on!
Yes, I like to zoom around in my 911 but often don't have the inclination
to be the fastest car on the road. So to those who want to go faster than me
I always look for a place to slow down so they can pass. More power to them!
And an added benefit is that I can drive 1/2 mile behind and locate police
and other road hazards by monitoring their brake lights.
Howard Rubin - hrubin@nyx.cs.du.edu

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 11:17:42 -0400
From: rhansen@tiac.net (rhansen)
Subject: 356s and the 050

I would advise the 050 as a replacement for a daily driver unless Stan's 
comment is based upon performance or an adverse impact on the engine as 
opposed to correctness.(Stan, why do you object to the 050?) I have checked 
the 050's advance curve on two of my engines (a super and a partial SC)and 
it checks with the factory manual at the 3500 rpm point, but is short of the 
full advance. It does a good job for me although I will probably get my 
original one reworked one day to see whether there is a significant difference.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 11:30:13 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 356s and the 050

> I would advise the 050 as a replacement for a daily driver unless Stan's 
> comment is based upon performance or an adverse impact on the engine as 
> opposed to correctness.(Stan, why do you object to the 050?) I have checked 
> the 050's advance curve on two of my engines (a super and a partial SC)and 
> it checks with the factory manual at the 3500 rpm point, but is short of the 
> full advance. It does a good job for me although I will probably get my 
> original one reworked one day to see whether there is a significant difference.

There is a measureable difference in the performance of a NEW or correctly
rebuilt cast-iron distributor and an 050. I'd characterize the 050 as
"adequate" -- it keeps the car on the road, it won't break things from
a too badly wrong advance curve (like an 009 will) and the main problems
are with the curve being wrong in some key places like off-idle and 
about 2500 RPM.

However, as Hairy is quick to point out, odds of finding a good cast iron
distributor are low. Hence the Stoddard rebuild program. Also hence the
need for some quality time with your Sun distributor machine. 

Nonetheless, for relatively cheap you can have the right stuff, as oppsed
to the "get by" stuff. So why not do it right?

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 15:30:48 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 5W50 vs 20W50

Doug,

I have been told that a lower viscosity oil is somewhat better at scavenging
heat.  But I do not know for sure, nor to I have any source of concrete
wisdom.

What sort of oil is the 5W50 you're using?  You might try an oil with a
narrower range.  The shop uses Mobil 1 5W30 in all Porsches, and it is also
an oil which Porsche endorses.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 15:30:54 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Prized 944T now running poorly

Scott,

I would agree with what George B said: sounds like the balance shaft
pulleys are mistimed.

Your overheating may be a problem with the water pump, and perhaps the
same care given to the balance shaft belt has also benefited the cam
belt, which drives the water pump.

The balance shaft belt timing is easy to see, once you get the timing
belt cover off.  I am surprised that mechanic #2 didn't pick up on that
right away.  Maybe time for a new mechanic.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 15:30:51 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Oil Changes and cleaning the sump cover...

Mike,

I think its probably a good idea to do it, although I know a lot of people
with pre-84 cases sometimes or always skip the screen cleaning.  I did one
a few years ago, and the screen came out covered with crud that looked sort
of like finely chopped up trash bag plastic.

I would think that because the screen surrounds both the pick-up pipe and
the drain, if you do not remove it you cannot get the case clear of anything
which doesn't go through the screen.

Kevin

>on the wheel, eyes fixed. SO was laughing and apparantly having a good
>time. So off I went again, slowed again.., and he caught up again. I
>finally decided to finish this and blasted off. A mile later I pulled off
>to make the turn into my office.The little red Miata convertible went
>screaming past, driver had a glazed and frustrated look on his face, and
>white knuckles clamped on the wheel. SO was doubled up, with her head on
>the door, laughing hysterically. I waved, she waved back, driver kept

>water here in Marin, California. It was a fun few minutes.

>'83-928 Forest green
>Wife- Sandi who loves the car and doesn't complain about the repairs.

I'm lucky enough to live on Mulholland Drive, one of the finest driving
roads in the country, and I've lived here for 11 years, so I know the road.
A few years back, I was driving a VW Golf I briefly owned, when a black
Turbo Cab came up on my tail with one of those more-money-than-sense El Lay
drivers... so I thought I'd have a little fun. I downshifted and proceeded
to catch the perfect line, flat out, for the next couple of miles. I
watched in the rear view as this guy charged, dodged, misread corners, made
stabs at passing, and generally seethed when he found he could not pass (I
left the door wide open, but his driving just wasn't up to it). Finally, we
came to the stop sign at a cross street, and as I stopped, he blew past me
at about 80.

Every local with a hot car seems to come up here sooner or later,And I'm
usually in the wrong car to really blow 'em away,  but there's no
susbstitute for driving ability and 'course' knowlege.

Bill Kelley

1981 928 Carelli Cabriolet
1987 C2 Turbo-look Cabriolet (for sale)
1989 951 (new toy)
1989 Yamaha FXR 600 (for when I want to go *fast*)

Date: Fri, 28 Jul 95 18:32:00 cdt
From: "Mohan, R Capt 57TG/TGOE" <MOHANR@tg57.nellis.af.mil>
Subject: RE: Phone Dial wheel question


Phone Dials are available in 7x16, 8x16 and 9x16 for 944 Turbo's.  The 9x16 
wheels
are magnesium rather than aluminum, and are stock on the Turbo Cup cars. 
 They are
usually identifiable by their pearl white paint jobs.  Robert Wood would be 
your best
source.  They are very rare and expensive.  Offsets make them suitable only 
for 951's
and 930's.

Bob Mohan

show only 7 inch widths.  (7 x 15,  7 x 16, etc)
Thanks.  Bryson Beaulieu

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 15:16:33 -0700
From: nms@slip.net (Nick Silva)
Subject: Re: Floor Clutch Fix

> Hi guys, thanks for all the great responses.  My next step is to identify
> WHERE the slave cylinder is and how to check the fluid, or even bleed it.
> Anyone with the 928 shop manuals?  Thanks, Sean  '80 928 (gearing up for
> 928 FAQ!)

It's on the clutch housing itself. It is what actually pushes the clutch
open. I had to have mine replaced once. It's just a small piston in a
bell-type housing. The hydraulic pressure from the master causes the piston
to extend from the casing and press the lever which operates the clutch.
Mine was leaking like crazy and I was having intermittent clutch problems.
When I examined the part, I couldn't believe the whole clutch was engaged
thru this little tiny rod of metal; it seemed so fragile.

________________________________________________________________________________
                        The conductor's name was Milo.

                                nms@slip.net
________________________________________________________________________________

RedNine Co.

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 18:22:04 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: need ideas on how to restitch leather steering wheel

Go to a sewing shop and buy some of the curved needles (name I can't recall). 
The one I used was on about a 1/2inch radius. Also get some of their good 
thread, preferably an upholstery thread, both for strength and diameter. Then 
it is a fairly simple matter of pulling out the loose stitching and redoing 
it. It took me about 1 1/2 hrs to do about half of a wheel, which is all mine 
needed. Watch the tension you apply, not too much and be prepared to lift the 
edge of the leather a bit so you can get to the hole....

Have fun!!


Dennis Kalma

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 18:36:48 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re:       factory manuals

The first part of the set covers the 911 from 1966 or so up to 1973, they give 
a lot of basic information which is not covered in later volumes, which 
basically only cover the changes from 1973. So you need both sets and need to 
flip back and forth a lot to find what you need to do. 

Not good manuals by any means, but they are better than the rest.

Dennis

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 18:45:06 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: HELP!!! alt problem 73 911

A long shot, but you might check the engine wiring harness. My 2.7 has several 
wires melted together, which tended to make some random shorts which in turn 
caused stuff like the battery to drain one day, the next the alternator light 
wouldn't go out (sounds like your problem??). Only way I found it was when my 
engine was replaced, the good folks at Kremer took it apart and then charged 
me for a new harness as  in their words....it was not acceptable. 

The harness runs inside the blower housing and exits towards the drivers 
side....


FWIW

Dennis Kalma

'75 911S with Kremer 3.2

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 22:24:21 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: easiest/lazyist oil change on 944

After many years of owning 944's of various models I have perfected what has
to be the easiest and lazyist way of changing oil on these cars. It is also,
happily, the least messy.
First of all the car has to be hot and you have no plans to use it for the
next 6 - 8 hours. I do this at night before contemplating a good nights
sleep. You can customize this step to fit your needs.
Next jack up the right side of the car so that you have access to the drain
plug. Please use a jack stand also. (Don't EVER depend on a jack when you
plan to put your head or other appendages under your car). Take you 15mm
combo wrench with you when you reach under the car. Place the box end over
the drain plug. It will fit between the drain plug and the pan shrouding.
Give the wrench a good push or whack and break the drain plug loose. At this
point have your drain pan handy. Slip the pan under the drain and slowly undo
the drain plug using the open end part of your wrench. The object is to
loosen the plug enough that oil starts to drip out, yet the plug stays in the
pan. 
Continue slowly unloosening until you have a steady thin stream of oil coming
out. (Don't get greedy here, be satisfied with a small stream or a
significant drip)
Crawl out and lower the car as much as possible, without crushing you drain
pan. Next poke a hole in the top of your oil filter so that the oil can drain
into the engine.
At this point you put a container of oil on your drivers seat to remind
yourself that there is no oil in the engine. Then go to sleep to whatever.
Next morning, or whatever, the car gets jacked up, the drain plug completely
removed and the aluminium "O" ring replaced. Tighten up the plug, change the
filter, fill with oil and away you go. Very little effort, no mess and the
sheet metal shrouding is left in place. 
This is not a method for the impatient. Hope it works for you.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue with oil draining as I type
Muffy & Portia,  the cats


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 22:34:21 -0400 (EDT)
From: Charles Stancil <cstancil@CapAccess.org>
Subject: 912E can't pass emissions test

I'm having trouble passing the emissions test here in Northern VA with my 
912E. 
 
The car hasn't had the thermal reactors in place since probably when it 
was new. In past years I've leaned it out and it would pass fairly 
easily. however this year I can't get it passed after three trys. 
Obviously there is something a little off which keeps the hydro carbons a 
little too high.  The co2 is OK. Before this last try I put in a new 
rotor and cap, new plug wires, new plugs, and air filter. I switched over 
to Mobil 1, ran it for 200 mi then changed to fresh Mobil 1 and filter. 
The car runs better but my hc were 4.5 with my maximum allowable being 4. 
We tested the hc just before this last state test and they were in the 
2-3 range but 15 min later at the service station they were 4.5. After 
the failed test, 15 min later at the shop the hydro carbons  were in the 
3s again. The state computer test starts at about 2300 rpm  then drops to 
idle. We found that mine does fine at 2300 rpm but when it drops to idle 
it dips for a split second down  lower than the correct idle rpm and then 
bounces back up to idle. At that second the hc jumps up to 6 and takes 15 
sec. to settle back down  to under 4. The state computer takes its idle  
reading before my car can get settled back down. I can't figure out what 
needs work without getting into some costly testing. Any ideas? My next 
alternative is to refit the thermal reactors. 
 
Are there any 912E drivers out there that still use thermal reactors?. 
 
How hot does the eng bay get? 
 
How many of those precious few ponies burn up before getting put to ground?
 
Help, my tags have expired, can't renew without passing emissions test.
 
A man on a emission
Charlie  





------------------------------

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 19:48:12 -0700 (PDT)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: Re: C2 question

Rish,

Like others have said - if the car is not a dog - $26,500 is extremely 
good.  Like you - I was looking for 87-89 Carrera and cam across an 89 C4 
for $27,500 that I had to have.  But, upon mechanical checkout, found 
that the cylinder heads were leaking badly and the front differential was 
leaking.  Also the car was just not well taken care of.  I think it was a 
leased car.

Anyway - they damage had been done and even though I didn't buy the car i 
now had to have a C2/C4.

The earlier years of these cars ( 89 & 90 - I think) had a tendancy to 
have small (and sometimes large) amounts of oil leaking for between the 
cylinder head and cylinder.  Another p-filer (Randy Kirby) and I looked 
long and hard for a car that didn't have the leaks.  And we both ended up 
purchasing cars with the leaks - even though the are very small.  It's 
not a problem unless it is causing a loss of compression.  And some cars 
never have the problem.  People will say that Porsche fixed the problem 
for free  - others say Porsche says it's not a problem.  It just goes on 
and on.  I know in my case that since buying a car with the leak - I 
haven't had second thoughts.  The car burns zero oil and never leaks 
oil.  I know that sounds contradictory - but I never see oil spots in my 
garage and yet I know it is a little wet on the motor.  Go figure.

When you move from a Carrera (..-89) to a C2/C4 the flywheels tend to go 
out.  I don't know the specifics of the problem.  My car had the work 
done prior to me owning it under warranty.

There are also other issues: cracked rear lense, dual distributor belt 
braking.

If the car you see for $26,500 checks out (even with wetness around 
cylinder heads) I think it would be a good deal - to me.  But I paid 
$37,00 for my 90 C4 w/ 46k - a "good deal" is relative to the person.

Good luck - and if I can be of any assistance - drop me a line.

Scott
(scokelly@netcom.com)
Currently driving 1990 C4 in my FIRST PCA Peachstate Driver's Ed event at 
Road Atlanta and loving it!!!

Porschephiles #1596                         Sun Jul 30 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 23:13:08 -0400
From: RUBBERDOC@aol.com
Subject: Re alt problems early 911

I had a similar problem with a 69E.  It turned out the
radio suppression device was defective.  Check to 
see if the pig tail coming out of the regulator goes to
the alternator or into what looks like a smaller regulator.
If this is the case, bypass the (device?) and connect 
directly to the alternator.  
Good Luck
Tom Bogaard
E-TCKET

weekends, etc.

low salaries are supposedly justified by the "Mt Rainier factor."  But you
can't eat Mt Rainier or insure P-cars with the view.)

 So where the Bimmer costs < 3% of value to insure per year, the P-car is
going to be > 10% per year.

also used the work *conspiracy*

others exist?  I'm not giving this one up so easy!

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 30 Jul 1995 02:23:58 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: 912E can't pass emissions...

Your idle is dropping too low....

Do you still have that aux air valve in there?  It is an 18" vacuum valve
that keeps the vacuum from going to more than 18".  If that thing is working,
it should keep the rpm from dropping too suddenly, and should help the idle
recover.  Hook up a vacuum gauge and see if you don't get more than 18" on
deceleration.  If it's working OK, try disconnecting it.  Also, be sure you
have no intake air leaks after the airflow sensor.

I have 73 & 76 914 2.0.  The engines are identical to yours, save for the
type of EFI.  The 75-82 VW vans have the AFC EFI like yours,  and my 81
vangon passes ok.  

CAT converters and hot pipes only help with CO, not HC, to my knowledge.  I
had to install a  CAT in my 76, and it dropped the CO from 1.25% to 0.01%,
but did not change the HC, which was OK, both before and after.  

Best regards, Ralph Ricks

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 30 Jul 1995 02:36:57 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: Insurance...(help!)

Want to save on insurance?  Borrow the money on your house, and pay cash for
the Porsche.  Then you won't have to pay collision/comprehensive, which is
the vast majority of the cost on this class and value of car.

Sure, it would break your heart if you wrecked the car, or if it was stolen,
but it would not bankrupt you.  This is called self-insurance.
If you are relatively confident in yourself, you can do this.  It will also
make you a safer driver, knowing that the bill for carelessness will be all
yours.  The money you save on insurance will pay part of the interest on your
mortgage.

I have always avoided collision coverage, and it has saved me many thousands
over the last nearly forty years of driving, complete with wife and raising
two sons through the hazardous years.  It has cost me a total of maybe $500
for repairs that would have been covered by collision or comprehensive.

Ralph Ricks

Date: Sun, 30 Jul 1995 02:43:21 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: Distributor for 356

Re: Distributor for 356

      Rather then spend $400+ for an "Original" replacement distributor for
your 356, I recommend you try an ".050"  Distributor. Though I'm sure there
will be other who will argue, I've  used several hundred .050's  over the
years (not on the same car), and have had one in my car for the past 10
years- still on the original points, thanks to a Delta Mark 10 CDI.  The .050
has some 27 degrees mechanical advance and with 3-5 degrees static works
quite well. It's  also less than a hundred dollars.
    Give me a call at (408) 727-1864 if you want further details. And:

KEEP THE 356 FAITH!
The Maestro

Subject: 914 Ignition Lock and Worn Key


I recently bought a wonderfully restored 914 which came with two

previous owner always used.  The other key was virtually unused, 
so it is still a perfect master key.

it will only accept the severely worn key, not the like-new one.

Is is possible or practical to have the ignition lock retooled to 
take the good original key?  Or should I live with lock as is and 
try to have the severely worn key copied?

Date: 26 Jul 1995 13:38:43 U
From: "Nans Kunz" <Nans_Kunz@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Brake Information

 7/26/95       1:28 PM        Subject:    Brake Information

Brake Information.
Two weeks ago I asked this great list for advice on brake pads (original
question below) and received five replies as summarized.  Thank You very much
to those whose responded.

 - One vote for Repco Metal Masters (better stopping power, less dust, and less
rotor wear than OEM) estimated price about $30/axle from Imparts
 - One vote for Ferodo AF from Automotion (looked up price $79.95/axle)
 - Two votes for OEM especially for that sale price 
 - One vote for swapping brake pads to carbon track pads whenever going to
spend time on the track, then swapping back to street pads for street (because
I guess track pads need to be heated up before they work effectively)

Thankyou very much,  right now I'm leaning towards the Repco Metalmasters.  
 __________________________
  Original Posting
________________________________
Help, I need advice on brake pads.
I need brakes soon for my 86 951.  My car is used mostly as a daily driver on
the street with speeds occasionally over 100 mph.  I have also been to a
driving school at Sears Point, where the car gets driven fairly hard, and I
will probably return someday.  

My question is what are the choices and trade-offs in brake pad brands and/or
materials?  Is there one brake pad material and/or brand that is clearly
superior to all others or are all brake materials pretty much the same?  I
don't consider cost a major factor because of the importance of brakes and the
low frequency in which they need to be replaced, but I don't want to spend
extra money just to get a "brand name" either.  Two choices that I have seen
so far are:  "lifetime guarantee" over the counter Rabestos brakes from a
local Pep Boys for about $38 or OEM brakes on sale from the dealer for a
little over $30.  

Below I have listed the Brake Pad properties that I can think of that might be
important, but unfortunately most of these properties are not specified on the
package or any where else that I know of for the different brands of brakes.
>Coefficient of Friction; cold
>Coefficient of Friction; hot
>Abrasiveness; how fast it wears the rotors
>Conductivity; how fast the pads can conduct the heat away
>Temperature Resistance; how hot it can get before it is damaged
>Durability; how long it lasts ( of course compared to other pads under the
same driving conditions, your mileage may vary)
>Dust; how fast do the wheels get dirty
>Cost
>Availability
>Asbestos or not
>what is the metal in the semi metallic?

Any advice would be greatly appreciated.  I subscribe to the digest so I will
only see responses about once or twice a day.  If you want to respond
directly, my Email address is Nans_Kunz@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov.  If I get a lot
of good responses I will try to write up a nice summary.

Thanks,
Nans

86 951

Date: Sat, 29 Jul 1995 23:51:19 -0700
From: paulm@kestrel.engr.sgi.com (Paul Mielke)
Subject: 993 turbo wait list update

Got your attention, mates?  ;^).

I was out on a bike ride with my 5 year old today and we just
happened to ride by the local P-dealer (purely an accident
I assure you).  We noticed a couple of very nice looking 993
C2 coupes on the lot, but they had plates on 'em.  So I figured
they must be the ones that the sales manager gets to drive.
But there was a sticker on the window.  Puzzled, I looked
at the odo reading on the first one.  2660 miles.  By now
I was totally mystified.  Why would somebody sell a perfectly
good C2 coupe with 2660 miles on it as a used car?  Right
on cue, the sales guy walked up and I asked him what was
going on.  Response:  "His new turbo came in."  How about the
other one over there with 5k miles on it?  Same story.  Oh.

So we got to chatting.  Turns out the wait list for the new
turbo currently extends to the end of next summer.  So you
might as well be driving a new C2 in the meantime, I guess.
Darn, didn't bring my charge card on the bike ride.

But, hey, you can special order a C4 and have it by the end
of November.  He said they were selling a lot more C2's
than C4's.

In case you're wondering, the deal they were offering on the
slightly used ones didn't seem all that great.  I think it
was $3k off the price of the same car new.  But he claimed
you don't have to pay "over $30k penalty" luxury tax on a
used car, so maybe this is a better deal than it seems.
Who knows, maybe there's even room to bargain.  I bet you'll
have no luck bargaining on a turbo, though.  Demand and
supply are way out of balance at this point.

Even for those of us who can't afford a Turbo, this seems
like good news.  Maybe 10 or 15 years from now there will
be lots of nice used 993 turbos on the market that we
can afford.  I'll drink to that!!

Cheers,

Paul Mielke
1980 911SC Coupe


Paul Mielke (paulm@sgi.com)
Silicon Graphics, Inc.

On Sun, 30 Jul 1995, George Beuselinck wrote:

> One other thing I was surmising...
> 
> If the balance shaft is far enough out of time, it might be causing
> the KLR (knock sensor) to believe that there is a terrible knock
> in the motor, retarding the ignition (for a resultant loss of power and
> also a resultant tendency to run hotter...)
> 
> Just a thought, but I would look for the upper balance shaft to be out 
> of time... It just might be the source of ALL the problems...
> Good Luck!
>

weekend too. (i.e. What if this vibration was causing my DME to change the
ignition timing and making matters even worse!)

this solves the problem, because I don't think I can go for another week

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 03:15:50 -0700
From: nms@slip.net (Nick Silva)
Subject: Re: 993 turbo wait list update

>  I bet you'll
> have no luck bargaining on a turbo, though.  Demand and
> supply are way out of balance at this point.

I think this really depends on the dealer/area you live in. When I was
looking to order my C4, there was a black/black Turbo available, the first
one the dealer received, because the orderer didn't want it after all. At
the second dealer where I actually ordered my car (in May), they had Turbos
available for September delivery, just one month after my August delivery.
Yes, a lot of the cars are pre-sold (sort of, it just means somebody
plunked down $2K to grab a spot in line), but a lot of cars are refused
when they arrive because of changing desires, financial conditions, etc.
Thus "pre-sold" cars become available to be sold. People just want options.
Look at the M3 situation: pre-sold for 7-8 months at the dealers I've
spoken to, but one of those "pre-sales" is my friend, who may or may not
take the car when it arrives. He just wants the choice, and does not want
to lose the M3 as an option due to a lack of foresight.

Nick Silva
1995 C4 Coupe (about 2 weeks and counting)

                        The conductor's name was Milo.

                                nms@slip.net

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 07:53:26 -0400
From: Z356@aol.com
Subject: 1976 912E in fire. Parts avaiable

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 09:00:43 -0400
From: RICKYDIK@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Ignition Lock and Wor...

Using the Haynes manual as a guide, pull the ignition lock out and take it to
the best lock shop you can find.  They will make new keys to fit the lock.
Before you start, make sure the shop has your blanks.

Ralph RIcks;  been driving 914s for 16 years.

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 09:03:34 -0400 (EDT)
From: Matt Clement <mclement@access.digex.net>
Subject: Re: Insurance...(help!)



On Fri, 28 Jul 1995 LToy@aol.com wrote:

> the quote:  $1402/six months!!!, 100k/300k liability, 240/500 deductible for
> comp/coll.

Ouch!  My stats: I'm 19, three speeding tickets on my otherwise clean 
record, no accidents.  Live in downtown Washington DC.  For my 1987 944S, 
I'm paying $1100/six months for full coverage, no deductible.  Coverage 
covers pleasure driving and to/from work.

The long and short of it is that you need to find a company that will 
give you a better deal.  Try some of the specialist insurance companies 
listed in the back of automotive magazines.

- -- Matt


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 95 09:12:31 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: Factory Manuals - Content

          Asad, the first set (2 volumes) covers everything through
          1973.  The second set covers everything new from 1974
          through 1983.  You really need them both.  Things like
          suspension, body, basic assemblies, etc you'll get from the
          first two volumes.

          The second set will have your particular wiring diagrams,
          CIS discussion, engine specs, etc.  This set often tells you
          what's new about a certain component, but how to get at it
          and fix it may be in the first set.  For my 1979, I probably
          use each set equally.

          You'll also want the little Spec Book (about $10) for your
          model.  It will have tightening torques, tolerances, and
          lots of other details that are not in the factory manuals.

          Don't expect too much from the factory manuals.  Don't get
          me wrong, they're probably the best there is, but they leave
          a lot to be desired. They're written for the pros.  I'm
          often disappointed, as they may tell you what you need to
          do, but not necessarily how.  Because you may need to
          reference both sets, it can get frustrating just trying to
          find the info you need. Sometimes the Haynes manual helps
          here, or Bruce's book, and of course this list.

          I've heard Bruce Anderson is working on a new
          maintenance/repair manual written more for the average
          wrench.  Anyone hear how it might be coming?

          Mark_Salvetti@abbsmtp.abb.com
          1979 911SC Targa

Date: 31 Jul 95 10:17:18 EDT
From: Mark Forrester/CAM/Lotus <Mark_Forrester/CAM/Lotus.LOTUS@crd.lotus.com>
Subject: Re: Grey Maket Cars

My experience as an owner of a Euro spec 911 SC has been that almost all parts 
are identical, same part numbers, etc..  There are some obvious ones which are 
different which I fortunately haven't had to deal with.  For that rare case 
where I haven't been able to get a part through a local US dealer I've had 
great success by ordering it through PCGB (Great Britain).

Regards,
Mark

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 07:46:53 -0700
From: hbrandt@interserv.com
Subject: Re: C2 question

I bought an '89 C-4 with 7600 miles (collector car that hadn't been driven) 
last year for $36000.  At 12,000 miles the engine was beginning to sound 
noisey and a valve adjustment didn't correct the problem.  Turns out the 
engine had premature guide wear. Even though the car was out of warranty,  
Porsche paid for all parts in the repair and also upgraded the cylinders and 
heads in the process.  I did have to pay the labor which amounted to about 
$3000.  I'm still glad at got the car.  It now has 18,000 miles and an updated 
engine that purrrrrrs.   I'd be careful with the car you're looking at.  The 
price sounds mighty low.  Perhaps the owner found out that he was going to 
need to have the cylinders and heads replaced and decided to unload the car.  
Keep me posted.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 10:58:46 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  need ideas on how to restitch leather steering wheel -Reply


First, find a spool of black cloth fishing line about the same size as the
stitching on it now.   Then, just follow the same pattern as the existing
stitching.  Use a needle nose pliers to pull the threading tight.  Don't pull it
too tight or the old leather will rip!!

Good Luck.

eric
80 911sc
86 GTi

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 10:28:52 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 Ignition Lock and Worn Key

>The problem is that the ignition lock is worn to the point that
>it will only accept the severely worn key, not the like-new one.
>
>Is is possible or practical to have the ignition lock retooled to
>take the good original key?  Or should I live with lock as is and
>try to have the severely worn key copied?

        Yes, quite possible.  The main problem is getting the lock
itself out of the steering column.  I don't remember all the stuff
you'll have to disassemble--but it should be in the Haynes book
somewhere.  (If you don't have the Haynes manual or the Factory
one, do yourself a favor and BUY ONE!)  Clymer/Lash is also OK,
it's a different look and covers the /6 as well.  But no electrical
diagrams...
        You can go to a locksmith or a Porsche shop and they should
be able to re-key the lock to whatever key you want.  Call around.
Ken's SporTech in Campbell, CA did five locks for me for $10 each.
One local locksmith wanted $15.
        It's pretty easy if you have a good supply of the "pins" in
the lock.  The pins can just shoot out of a removed lock cylinder
(spring-loaded), so wrap paper and tape around yours...
        Good luck!

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 95 10:48:10 -0500
From: Mike Selner <mike@is.com>
Subject: How to get a grease seal out?

I was wondering what is the best way to get the inner wheel
bearing seal out for repacking the wheel bearings if I want to
re-use the seal.  Usually the seal seems to be good for one or
two packings and I have a hard time getting it out without
wrecking it.

My usual method is to tap the inner bearing thru the hub while
supporting the hub/rotor so the seal and bearing can drop.  This
is rather hard on the seal, though.  I'm afraid to pry it from the back,
but maybe that is the way to go.

Thanks
Mike
951S

Date: 31 Jul 1995 17:18:31 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.COM (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: Early 911 mirrors redux

A week or so ago I said I heard that 75-78 BMW 5-series mirrors are very close
to those used on early 911's, and that both left and right mirrors are
available from BMW dealers.  Another 'phile said "no way" after examining his
own.

Turns out that BMW used a couple of flavors of mirrors for those models.  I
brought my '73 mirror in to compare to the manual chrome one I ordered and
guess what?  They *are* very close.  The BMW mirror is just slightly larger
(the glass and housing itself) but otherwise it is nearly identical!  It
mounts from the surface with hidden screws (as opposed to accessing screws
from the inside door), and the holes do not line up with the originals but
appear to cover them completely.  All in all, I'd say this is a very good
solution to the fact that Porsche did not manufacture a matching rectangular
right side mirror.

FWIW, I recommend anyone interested in left and right mirrors for early '70's
911's to check them out.  Again, the part numbers are:

(L) 51 161 821 793
(R) 51 161 822 076

I think they're around $40 each.

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara, CA)
95 993 coupe, guards red
73.5 911T 2.7 coupe, ferrari red (with tiny Carrera racing mirrors)
85 535i, grey

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 95 12:48:00 PDT
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: Re: Phone Dial wheel question


>Does anyone know if Phone Dial type wheels come
>in widths greater than 7 inches?  All my catalogs
>show only 7 inch widths.  (7 x 15,  7 x 16, etc.)
>Thanks.  Bryson Beaulieu

They don't.  You MAY be able to get them widened at a wheel shop, check in 
Pano for the names of a few.

The later style slotted (FORGED alloy, not cast) come in 8" wide.  I think 
the new 5 spoke style comes in 9", you will have to check.  Automotion or 
Perfomance make duped of this style that may come wider.

Aftermarket wheels are really rare, not many people make them for the 928. 
 Those that do have wheels that fit charge a fortune.

Bill Smyth
