Date: Mon, 31 Jul 95 13:31:09 EST
From: Paul_Foster@tdc.com
Subject: Saved by the George (a Cautionary Tale - Long)

     This Sunday I was enroute to my first autocrossing event at The Drop 
     Zone just outside of Walden, NY in my '84 944. I knew I was going the 
     right direction since a Hoosier Tires truck was leading the way. 
     
     I was not more than a mile from the site when my radar detector went 
     POOF right in front of my eyes, and I immediately lost all power. 
     There was smoke coming from under the hood in the vicinity of the 
     battery, and a burning smell from under the dash typically associated 
     with plastic giving its life for your olefactory enjoyment. The smoke 
     from under the hood was a cloud of sulphuric acid that didn't stop 
     emanating from a vent in the battery for 15 minutes! The alternator, 
     which I had just replaced with a remanufactured unit, apparently lost 
     all regulation.
     
     I flagged down some passing autocrossers to get a jump. No joy, but I 
     did get a ride to the site where another "racing buddy" found a tow 
     strap and got me off the roadway and to the site. Another instant 
     "buddy" took me into town to scout up a battery. His kindness cost him 
     the obligatory course walk.
     
     With the new battery installed, I was expecting it to fire right up, 
     and with any luck at all, still compete. WRONG. It was cranking, but 
     no spark. I hurredly consulted the owners manual to determine the fuse 
     to the brain, aka Bosch DME Control Unit. Uh oh...no fuse protecting 
     the brain. NO BRAIN!
     
     With visions of $500 flat-tows to Manhattan dancing in my head, 
     another instant "racing buddy" gets on his cell phone and calls George 
     Beuselinck, owner of 944 Ecology and purveyor of used parts. I explain 
     the situation to him. George thought it sounded like it might be a 
     fried brain, which he had in stock, or it might not. He asked if I 
     might be interested in him showing up at the event site in 45 minutes 
     with a replacement. Would I?!!! He said he would bring his '83 944 in 
     case it was some other problem.
     
     George connected the brain to the central nervous system, and the car 
     instantly fired to life. He checked the voltage at the battery and 
     determined the alternator was putting out 18 volts at idle. No telling 
     what it was at 4000 RPM. We disconnected the "tickler" wire to the 
     alternator so I wouldn't lose two brains in one day, or is that three 
     counting mine?
     
     We decided the best course would be an early departure to beat the 
     traffic back to the city, since any delay would probably mean dead car 
     in traffic blues. George even gave me his cell phone in case I needed 
     it on the drive back. A few miles away, I turned on the turn signal to 
     make a left, and no turn signal. No brake signal, no wipers, no radio, 
     no clock, but I still had interior lights, power windows, and the 
     cigarette lighter. Good time to restart smoking...no.
     
     I gingerly drove the car back to the mechanic who had replaced the 
     alternator hoping the entire time the charge on the battery would be 
     enough. It remains to be seen how much gets fixed under warranty, and 
     if the shop will help me out with the cost of the replacement brain 
     and new battery.
     
     I want to thank George Beuselinck for coming to my rescue on a Sunday 
     afternoon. I hope the car can be put back together again so I can 
     once-again show up at the Drop Zone to thank all my new-found "racing 
     buddies". The beer's on me. 


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 12:41:49 -0500
From: Brian Scudder <bscudder@spdmail.spd.dsccc.com>
Subject: 928 back on the road!!

It has been extremely hard these past five months to listen to you guys
and not be able to drive my car :^(  Saturday I was able to get it out
on the road. Way back in Febuary, while getting some practice laps in
before the start of the season, the transmission broke at where the
input shaft clamps onto the drive shaft! During the transmission
teardown, it was noticed that the hardening on the pinion shaft was
wearing off. I think that this set up a vibration which caused the
break. 

It is amazing on how all of the "while I'm in there" adds up: new clutch
bearings (throwout, pilot), rebuilt torque tube, vastly rebuilt
transmission (bearings, syncros, ring & pinion, 5th gear/input shaft,
limited slip), repacked CV joints, rear wheel bearings, rear brake
rotors.

I had almost forgotten how fun it is to drive. The power, the handling,
and the smoothness of the car is incredible. Much better than my old
blue truck that I've had to drive.

So, it's back on the road again. Still need to do some other things
before I can hit the track, but it sure cured my No-Porsche-Car
withdrawls.

Brian Scudder
'83 928S (back on the road!)
'70 old blue truck (going to get a rest)
'93 Redi (the cat - rests all the time)

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1599                         Mon Jul 31 19:42:08 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 13:55:24 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: '73 914/2.0 for sale

Hi,

I got an offer on my '73 914/2.0 from someone who heard about
it. But it's lower than I want to go, so I'm putting it here to see
if anyone is interested.

It is the original color - 914 bright yellow. It was repainted about
5 years ago probably (in Atlanta).

The tranny seems pretty good, I think only 103,000 miles.
I can downshift to 2nd and 1st easily using double-clutching. 
As usual, going to first without double clutching does grind some. 
Upshifts are ok, but the 2nd gear synchro sometimes grinds if 
you shift fast.

I don't think it ever had rust repaired- it is much cleaner than the '73 
that I had in 1980 !

It has a nice Momo steering wheel, Bursch muffler, Yoko 008R tires
on the Fuchs forged alloy wheels (best). Has a front flexible air dam.
The car has all the good options : sway bars, console, appearance
group, etc. These were standard on the '73 914/2.0.

Battery is relocated to the rear trunk in a nice welded-in recessed
metal well. Does not take up trunk space.

Needs some work and a good tune-up (sat for a while in a garage).
Has only about 103,000 miles. It's a late '73 model (June). 
Camshaft was replaced a few years ago, and engine freshened up.
The car came from Atlanta 5 years ago so is very rust-free, no winters
while it was in Connecticut.

Needs : some paint work (previous owner started restoring inside rear 
trunk and some small paint nicks with primer).
Radio was removed.
Needs a piece of metal welded in the front trunk where the removed
A/C condenser was (easy job, not structural, or use for oil cooler).
Needs pedal bushings replaced (I've had to do this on all older Porsches).
Has a small oil leak somewhere (what's new?).

I will part with it so I can afford to get my 911 back up to speed.
I could sell it as is for $3250. I also have a complete set of
factory manuals in mint condition that cost $300. This could be worked
into the deal somehow. I also have a nice set of styled-steel 5 1/2 x 15
wheels which could be put into the deal.

The car can be driven home.

EMAIL AnalogMike@aol.com or call (203) 778-6658 (Connecticut)

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S Targa, '73 E Targa (for sale soon), '73 914/2.0


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 13:57:37 -0400
From: pigozzi@pilot.msu.edu (Bruce Wm. Pigozzi)
Subject: Tire pressures

I'd been having trouble figuring out the operating pressures for a new set
of track tires (YoKo A008Rs) and a friend suggested that "Yoko's do very
nicely at 29psi with a 900# load and 26psi with a 600# load.  Figure your
weights and go from there, plus 4 pounds extra as a security blanket."

Well I used these as a starting point (29/900=0.032 and 26/600=0.043;
average the factors=0.0375; and figure 3000# for the car and big driver,
3000/4=750*0.0375=28.1, decided that 28 + 4 =32 was a good base.  Then
adjusting for the sway bars, temp, etc. I figured that running at 30 front
and 33 rear should work rather well, and it did.  I recognize that this is
rough but the starting ratios were really helpful.  

I just bought 8 other tires for two other non track cars (BFG Comp T/A VRs
and HRs); QUESTION: is there a way to find out the optimum operating
psi/weight ratios? 

I went back to the tire dealer who sold me the T/As and the concept of
optimum ratios or optimum psi-to-weight relationships was just too
complicated for them.  They would blankly and alternatingly pointing to the
"maximum operating psi" and the psi's listed on the door frame of the car as
answers to my questions.  "I don't want to operate at the max pressure, I
want to know what the optimum is."  "But how does the car manufacturer know
what tire I'm putting on the car and what ITS optimum operating
circumstances are?"  Is there any source of information that will give me
optimum operating psi for different weight loads, not just the maximums, for
different tires?  I must admit that the various codes on tires may yield
some of this but I don't understand the codes (Yes, I'm going to check
Consumers Reports when I get home but I don't recall them covering this
question.)  And, Yes, I'm going to ask my friend where he got the
information but I suspect it might be based on experience not "secondary
sources."  And, the answer might be of general interest to the larger group! 

(Sensing he really couldn't help me the dealer gave me an 800 number
(1-800-847-8475) but it turns out to be Michelin not BFG!)

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 14:33:07 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Phone Dial wheel question

Bill, if you don't know the RIGHT answer, don't respond.

8" phone dials were widely available for the '86 944 turbo as their 
default wheel.  They were also available for the '87-88 in 53.3mm 
offset. I know because I have had several of each.

Additionally, a 6" version came stock on the '86 carreras but was 
almost opted out of for fuchs, whihc cost extra.

The above applies to 16" diameters.  


Steve 
> From porschephiles-request@tta.com Mon Jul 31 13:19 EDT 1995

> the new 5 spoke style comes in 9", you will have to check.  Automotion or 
> Perfomance make duped of this style that may come wider.

>  Those that do have wheels that fit charge a fortune.

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 15:03:55 -0400 (EDT)
From: blained <blained@nando.net>
Subject: Re: 80's cars and pop valves



On Mon, 31 Jul 1995, steve cohen wrote:
> I now own a '82SC and was wondering if there had been a design
> improvement that would obviate the need for a pop valve; or am I living
> on borrowed time?

Get a pop valve - no real improvements were made to fix this problem, 
except perhaps the oxygen sensor added in '80 which might help keep the 
car from backfiring - it won't though, as I found out a couple weeks 
before I intended to put in the pop-off valve.  I replaced the OEM airbox 
with a NLA cast aluminum airbox with built-in metal popoff valve, and 
have been trouble-free since.  Have seen other aluminum airboxes which 
were crap compared to this - it's even anodized (or something) blac so it 
looks stock.

Blaine

Date:          Mon, 31 Jul 1995 15:35:24 EDT
From: "Asad Husain" <AHUSAIN@schmed01.ab.umd.edu>
Subject:       Re: Insurance...(help!)

> real parameters:  age: 33 (wife 29), homeowner (mortgage payer), 
> Seattle area
> (lowest zip code insurance index), no tix, etc.  home, cars, boat insured w/
> Farmers.
> hypothetical car:  '88 911 Carrera.  to be a third car, driven mostly on
> weekends, etc.
> 
> the quote:  $1402/six months!!!, 100k/300k liability, 240/500 deductible for
> comp/coll.

My wife and I are in the same age bracket.  We had one speeding 
ticket in the last two years when we switched insurance companies.  I 
pay $550/yr for full comprehensive/collison with the 100K/300K 
liability in a high premium area in Baltimore, MD for the Porsche. I 
was paying almost twice that with allstate. I insure with Erie.  We 
have two cars on the policy a 1990 Mazda 4wd van and a 1980 911SC.  
The Porsche is $25.00 cheaper per year than the Mazda!

GEICO was very expensive.  Shop around.

I also raised my deductibles to around 500 each and I put the savings 
in the bank so that I can use it in case something happens.

a spare assy and it looks great! not only that
it's about 1% of a new unit. another post indicated
'eastwood' but they have discontinued their 
product. the tamiya stuff should be available from
any hobby store. (@<$3)
thanks again.
best
jerry
'66 912

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 16:46:48 -0400 (EDT)
From: Rick Shimkets <quartz@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: HELP!!!  914 Narcoleptic!

Alright guys, I need some help once again!  For some bizarre reason 
(which is what I want to determine)  My '72 914-4 is cutting out on me 
after running for 5 minutes or so.  Problem is, it refuses to restart 
until it has had a few (about 5) minutes to cool down(?).  Then it runs 
fine for another 5.  THen it stalls again.  Going down the highway at 65 
mph this happened to me today, and with the clutch engaged the car 
spittered and sputtered.  I replaced most of the FI components 6 months 
ago, including the fuel filter, which I'm beginning to suspect.  It has 
been very hot here lately, and i wonder if there is some relationship 
between the heat and this problem.  I haven't relocated my fuel pump and 
I've heard about "vapor lock" but don't know if this is that.  Please 
help if you have any ideas, I'd very much appreciate them!  Rick

Date: 31 Jul 1995 21:57:47 GMT
From: Lance_Keigwin@BayNetworks.COM (Lance Keigwin)
Subject: Mail to Gabriel...

Sorry for the bandwidth.  Mail is being bounced.  Not in who's who...
- ---------
> Lance, I haven't followed the entire thread on the right mirror issue. The
> one you found from BMW is chrome? I have a 77 911 and I think Porsche
> actually does have a right mirror, but it costs a fortune! Since the right
> mirror is not critical to me, I'd rather spend that money in something
> else, unless there was an inexpensive solution like what you've found.
>
> Please let me know.
> Thanks,
> Gabriel
>
Gabriel,
The thread has been about the fact that Porsche never made a rectangular
right side mirror for early 911's.  I'm not sure what model years are
affected except that I know early 70's are.  Some of us have been looking for
good substitutes.  They have to look as close as possible to the originals
(and the BMW ones do; yes, they're chrome).

You might look around in junkyards, salvage places, etc. like PartsHaven (see
Excellence and Panorama ads) or Easy in Emeryville.  If I were you I'd go for
a proper used one if you can find one.  I'll bet you can.

Cheers,
Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara, CA)
95 993 coupe, guards red
73.5 911T 2.7 coupe, ferrari red
85 535i, grey
- -------

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 95 13:28:09 PST
From: "RADSICKT" <radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil>
Subject: Setting Backlash and Endthrust on 914 cam

 To all you experienced (and other) engine folks out there,
 
 When rebuilding the 914 engine, the FACTORY MANUAL (see George, I own one!) 
 says that I need to check the backlash and thrust of the cam.  OK, sounds good. 
  The thrust looks like a no-brainer, just use dial gauge and slide cam 
 front-to-back.  I've done that before.  I'm a little confused at to the 
 backlash procedures, though.  I assume what I am trying to measure is the 
 ability of the cam and it's gear to rotate, while holding the crankshaft 
 stationary -- basically measuring the mating of the cam gear and the crank 
 cam-drive gear.  Is this correct? Does this vary because of wear or is it 
 because of the spacing between the crank and the cam bores?
 
 (BTW, H.G. Bieker went ahead and align bored the case because it was out of 
 tolerance.  Sorry Stan, I told him to call me first so I could find out if 
 there was another reason not to, other than bearing availability.  Bieker said 
 that over 1/2 the 914 cases he works on need align boring.) 
 
 The manual says to install cam and check to see if it is good by roting the 
 crank backwards and seeing if the cam pops out.  It also says to make sure 
 there is almost no play between the cam and the crank drive gears.  Does anyone 
 have a better or more scientific way of doing this? How much play is too much?
 
 Assuming that the backlash is out of spec, I guess the only solution is to 
 install a different sized gear?  The old one had a "0" stamped on it.  The gear 
 I am using comes from FAT performance.
 
 Final question:  recommendation on torque specs for the cam gear bolts?  My 
 engine guy (Bieker) said that he remembers 18 ft/lbs and use red locktite and 
 lockwashers (but only after checking backlash), but he didn't sound too sure.
 
 Thanks for the help,
 Tim Radsick
 
 PS, if Mr 914, PhD (G. Hussey) is listening in, I found a couple of errors (I 
 think?) in your chart of part numbers for fuel injection parts in the back part 
 of your catalog.  I think the Aux Air Regulators for L-jet and 1975-76 D-jet 
 got confused (along with a couple of other things).

Date:         Mon, 31 Jul 95 17:24:50 EDT
From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SS8299A@american.edu>
Subject:      Re-coloring HEADLAMPS...

I was flipping channels the other day and stopped on what I think was
Private Benjamin (Goldie Hawn, 80's) where she had just married the guy of
her dreams (Italian or French soccer player) who has this beautiful black
930 with YELLOW headlights.  I also saw these headlights in Paris on all
cars.  So what are they for?  Could I make mine like that (they look
incredible on black cars!)?  How would I make mine like that?  A plastic
film?  Yellow dye?  Is it legal in America? Do I care if it is technically
illegal (I don't have a front license plate anyway!)?  Any info would be
great!  Sean'80 928

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 15:09:16 -0700 (PDT)
From: Walter Stander <wstander@cts.com>
Subject: Re: Re-coloring HEADLAMPS...

In France, I think ALL headlights are required on cars in populated 
areas; high-power aux lighting is used in the hinterlands. This is a 
result of some visibility study that showed that 'normal' lights are 
unnecessary in the city(light pollution?). Paris and, for that matter 
most large cities, are excessively lit cities so much so that even H4s 
are superfluous.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 16:01 -0800 (PST)
From: Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV
Subject: Re: Early 911 mirrors redux


  Lance Keigwin wrote:

FWIW, I recommend anyone interested in left and right mirrors for early
'70's 911's to check them out.  Again, the part numbers are:

(L) 51 161 821 793
(R) 51 161 822 076

I think they're around $40 each.


  
  I show these mirrors going for $32 each at Bavarian Auto Service,
  1-800-535-2002. The right mirror had a slightly different part number
  (superceded?) but mentioned the hidden bolts.

  Regards,

  Rob Yasek
  '73 911T
  '91 Bixby Noodlehead

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 20:13:48 -0400
From: LToy@aol.com
Subject: Insurance:  story update (& thanks!)

First, Thanks to all of you who've responded on my request for
stories/experiences.  There were many good suggestions for additional
companies, raise the deductibles, or even self-insurance (I don't think I've
got the guts for that one). $$ summary below.

Update:  I called another broker I've done business w/ over the years for
business.  He's an agent for Safeco.  He laughed.  Told a story:  He owns a
P-car.  Had all his cars insured w/ Safeco.  Safeco raised his rates on his
P-car by $600 one year.  Now he insures w/ State Farm (but still sells
Safeco).  Called his agent while on the phone w/ me.  the quote:  $595/six
months!  quite a difference (was $1402 w/ Farmers).  This is full coverage
(100/300 liab, 250/500 deductible on comp/coll), no mileage limits (tho not
used for work daily).  I'd probably raise the deductibles on those.  I like
this story.

btw:  Here's a summary of data points for premiums some have sent to me.
 Premium is per year, full coverage (that I can tell).  Deductibles noted, if
given.
car       location    prem/yr  company   comments
- ------    ----------  -------  -------   ----------
993 C4    Bay Area    1800     Amica     sngl male >25
85 911    Pac NW      900      St Farm   ?
93 RS Am  Bay Area    1100     Allstate  sngl male >35, 1000 ded
73 914\
74 911/   Calif       450      Leland W  PCA-both cars
928       ?           700      Geico     ?
87 944S   DC          2200     ?         0 deduct! sngl male <25
85 911    NJ          800      ?         3rd car/2 drivers

linus.
LToy@aol.com

Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 20:43:37 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Re-coloring HEADLAMPS...

On Mon, 31 Jul 1995, Sean P. Simmen wrote:

> I was flipping channels the other day and stopped on what I think was
> Private Benjamin (Goldie Hawn, 80's) where she had just married the guy of
> her dreams (Italian or French soccer player) who has this beautiful black
> 930 with YELLOW headlights.  I also saw these headlights in Paris on all
> cars.  So what are they for?  Could I make mine like that (they look
They are to not blind oncoming drivers. In Paris, your lights HAVE to be
yellow, supposedly because the street lights are good enough to see where 
you are going. Your headlights then, are used not for you to see other 
people, but for other people to see you.

> incredible on black cars!)?  How would I make mine like that?  A plastic
> film?  Yellow dye?  Is it legal in America? Do I care if it is technically
> illegal (I don't have a front license plate anyway!)?  Any info would be
> great!  Sean'80 928
I don't know if you care or not. I would just buy the headlights (they're 
made yellow like that) however... in JC Whitney, I was just looking 
through the catalog and... on page 51: Philips COLORCLEAR lihgts, 
something you may like even better. Halogens that are whiteon, and when 
off, choice of 4 colors. One of them, you may like better, black... Would 
actually blend in with your car, but unfortunately, on the 928 (unles 
yours are broken), the lights are only showing when they're on...
 -Derek

On Sat, 29 Jul 1995 Jerry944T@aol.com wrote:

> After many years of owning 944's of various models I have perfected what has
> to be the easiest and lazyist way of changing oil on these cars. It is also,
> happily, the least messy.

<Snip> 

> Regards,
> Jerry
> 89 944turbo S black (track Car)
> 89 944turbo S Glacier Blue with oil draining as I type
> Muffy & Portia,  the cats

Jerry -

Sounds appealing if your approach avoids the spill that normally occurs 
when the filter is removed. What's the purpose of the very slow drain rate?
Do you use factory filters? I usually still get a spill when removing the 
filter even if I puncture it. I always assumed that the anti-drainback 
feature of the factory filters worked well enough that too much oil 
stayed in the filter. Maybe I just didn't wait long enough.

Bill Addis

Consider yourself lucky. My '87 Carrera Cabriolet cost me $4,200 a year
until the Leland-West PCA program came a long and dropped it to less than
$500.

I am 47, no accidents, no claims, but live in an urban area in Southern
California (where insurance companies make all their money).

Now, I have 3 Porsches covered for about $1,200 a year.

But my '94 Grand Cherokee costs me $2,900 a year. Guess it depends upon
where you live...

Bill Kelley
